title: Colombia's Elections Are A Study in 'Violentology'
description: THE man on the telephone took credit for murdering one presidential candidate, but his message was addressed to a second, Cesar Gaviria. The leader in Colombia's four-way race for president, Mr. Gaviria advocates the toughest line against cocaine traffickers. ''He can walk around with 100 bodyguards,'' the voice snarled into the spinning reels of a radio station tape recorder. ''But tell his security people to try to find a bulletproof vest for his head - because that is where we are going to hit him. Understand?'' Accustomed to the Colombian drug mafia's twisted logic, many people here understood: Traffickers had killed a minor party's candidate, Bernardo Jaramillo Ossa, to intimidate the man most likely to set drug policy in the 1990's for Colombia, the world's largest cocaine exporter.

title: Distilling 25 Years' 'Adventure'
description: ABE AJAY is at the Aldrich Museum in Ridgefield, with the past 25 years of his life summed up by some 50 works, most of them relief constructions, and a video and a biography, written by the critic Lee Hall, that reads like an autobiography. It is a smooth package, but something must surely have been left out. Nobody can be this ''together.''

title: October Wedding For Miss Acheson
description: Mr. and Mrs. Patrick B. V. M. Acheson of Waterford, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter Caroline Mary Patricia Acheson to David L'Estrange Seward, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter L'Estrange Seward of Ottawa. An October wedding is planned.

title: THE FLOOPY PLAYS IN AGAIN, SANS SAM
description: Electric music makers like the radio and phonograph have pushed the piano out of the parlor. But now electronics is pushing the piano right back into the living room. Several new high-tech versions of the old player piano offer cases in point.

title: REAP WHAT YOU SEW
description: I was in a circle of young mothers who worked part-time. We baby-sat for each other, never exchanging money, and helped each other to sew work clothes that we couldn't afford to buy.

title: The 51st and 52d States;   Mr. Bush: Principled, but Mistaken, on the District
description: President Bush supports statehood for Puerto Rico but not for the 625,000 residents of Washington, D.C. For this, he is being politically thwacked, especially for saying that the District of Columbia's funds ''come almost exclusively from the Federal Government.''

title: Letters;   REAP WHAT YOU SEW
description: I am amazed at the subtext in the Hers column, ''Reap What You Sew,'' by Barbara Crafton (March 11). ''Feminine'' activities like loving, sewing, or even pulling up maple saplings (or do only husbands do that?) are entirely compatible with thinking, leading and doing. The seemingly necessary polarization of these in Ms. Crafton's life is not the result of feminist politics. If she wants to sew, she should sew, without turning it into an implicit attack on the needs and goals of many of her unacknowledged sisters.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week;   What Is Wrong With the Knicks?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or return unpublished letters.

title: Laudner Out
description: The Minnesota Twins will be without their regular catcher, Tim Laudner, for a while. Laudner said he might seek treatment for what he has called an emotional problem, The Star Tribune of Minneapolis reported yesterday.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: PASSION FOR GARDENING

title: On Language;   The German Answer
description: THE GERMAN QUEStion - in German, die deutsche Frage - is again in the world news. The question itself is widely understood to be ''What is to be done about Germany?'' The underlying question, however, of far greater historical linguistic import, is: Who coined the phrase? Did it enter the geopolitical arena in the 1930's with the rise of Hitler?

title: Dr. Rona L. Stein To Marry in June
description: Dr. and Mrs. Herman B. Stein of Hewlett Harbor, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Dr. Rona Lynn Stein to Stephen Henry Kaufman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David A. Kaufman of Henrietta, N.Y. A June wedding is planned.

title: Jordan 1990: New Politics, Islam's Way
description: The young woman in a dark veil had a problem: how, she asked the legislator, could she switch colleges? The legislator scribbled a supportive note to a college director he knew. The woman left. The man sighed. Only recently, said Abdel Latif Arrabiyat, a legislator from the Muslim Brotherhood, a man had asked him to adjudicate marital strife. Then, a retired soldier from the 1948 war had written asking for a raise in his pension. People, he said, did not seem to understand just what a parliamentary deputy was supposed to be able to do.

title: Pitcher Gallery
description: Despite the coffeetable contours of THE ART OF BASEBALL: The Great American Game in Painting, Sculpture, and Folk Art (Harmony Books, $40), the beverage of choice for its audience is more likely to be the fan's warm beer than the connoisseur's spritzer. Readers familiar with the histories of both American art and baseball will not find much that is new in Shelly Mehlman Dinhofer's text, but there is no dishonor in a book of pictures as carefully chosen, wide-ranging and handsomely reproduced as these. Here are diamond images, brilliantly faceted, in two dimensions: Thomas Eakins's 1875 watercolor of mustachioed ''Athletic boys, a Philadelphia club''; a play at the plate, in quintessential whirlwind John Marin style, drawn in the artist's last year (1953); a luminous George Luks oil, ''Boy With Baseball,'' circa 1925; Donald Sultan's enigmatic ''Baseball and Bat'' of 1981, a visual haiku in black and white. And in three dimensions: the liquid neoclassical poise of Douglas Tilden's pitcher (1888-89) and the megalithic stolidity of William Zorach's catcher (1940), together with their folk-art teammates from whirligigs and amusement arcades. Ms. Dinhofer, who curated the 1987 exhibition ''The Grand Game of Baseball and the Brooklyn Dodgers'' for the Museum of the Borough of Brooklyn, tends to root, root, root for the home team; expect a modest surfeit of Ebbets Field and Dodger lumber. Her visual analyses lack depth and connection - a number of tantalizing illustrations get no commentary at all - but her selections, discoveries and juxtapositions are rich. Here are portraits, fast and slow, to enact the archetypes and distill the game's fine old monosyllables: play ball; grand slam; strike three; safe at home.

title: Train vs. Car: Ending a Deadly Hazard
description: THE morning of Jan. 16 broke cold and gray. Jacalyn Kahn left her home in Ronkonkoma by 7 A.M. to catch the 7:22 express to Manhattan. She did not want to be late on her very first day at a new job.

title: HAVEL'S CHOICE
description: ONLY THREE WEEKS INTO HER UNCONVENTIONAL ambassadorship, Rita Klimova has high technology on her plate. Just back from New York in her chauffeured Lincoln Continental, she is having a small dinner at her official residence on the edge of Rock Creek Park in Washington. The principal guest, the publisher of an international videotex service, is explaining how he will install his system in Czechoslovakia with American money.

title: Lorna Wilkerson, Student, Is Wed
description: Lorna Anne Wilkerson and Michael Edwin Mushlitz were married yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York by the Rev. Martin C. Avila. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold G. Wilkerson of South Ozone Park, Queens. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard D. Mushlitz of Evansville, Ind.

title: Why Wall Street Likes Scientific-Atlanta's Mr. Fixit
description: The major reason Wall Street likes Scientific-Atlanta Inc. may be that it loves William E. Johnson, the former consultant who became the company's chief executive in 1987. Mr. Johnson, previously unknown outside the the major multinational companies that had sought his advice, is credited with executing Scientific-Atlanta's resurgence in the cable-television equipment and satellite communications businesses.

title: Vietnamese Communists Purge an In-House Critic
description: Vietnam's Communist Party says it has purged a senior member of the Politburo who spoke of the need for faster political change in the wake of liberalization in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Keene, N.H.;

Builder Cuts Size and Price
description: LEAD: A DEVELOPER who could not sell the apartments in his condominium town houses has redesigned the project, making the second-phase units smaller.

title: 'GET IT BACK TO THE INFIELD, WILLIE'
description: NINE SIDES OF THE DIAMOND

title: Bankruptcy Bar: Never So Solvent
description: YOU CAN'T JUST SAY YOU have the financing,'' Harvey R. Miller says decisively. ''You've got to have it all lined up and ready to go. A lot of these deals founder on being conditional.'' Miller is lecturing one of his colleagues, Ira M. Millstein, who is scribbling notes on a yellow pad perched awkwardly on his lap. The two senior partners at Weil, Gotshal & Manges, New York's third-largest law firm, are conferring in Miller's corner office on the 29th floor of the General Motors Building in Manhattan, overlooking Central Park. Miniature Texaco oil trucks and Continental and Eastern jetliners, memorabilia of a stellar bankruptcy practice, adorn the bookshelves and window ledges.

title: Airplane Seats
description: To the Editor: Regarding the article ''You Can't Be Too Thin in Economy Class'' (Practical Traveler, March 4), I'd like you to know that relief is in sight. As of May 15, Virgin Atlantic is converting all its 747's on the Atlantic to new, specially contoured seats that will give at least seven inches more legroom than on British Airways.

title: Amy R. Waugh To Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Goodrich Waugh of Southport, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Amy Randall Waugh to Philip Joseph Curry 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Curry Jr. of New Canaan, Conn. A June wedding is planned. Miss Waugh, a graduate of Trinity College in Hartford, is the direct-response representative at Victoria Magazine in New York. She was presented at the Fairfield Debutante Ball. Her father is the retired president of Main Street Management in Fairfield, Conn., and Pequot Travel in Southport.

title: AT THE BASTILLE OPERA, A NEW TRADITION RISES
description: The opening the other day of the $400 million Bastille Opera in Paris aroused feelings of deja vu in a visitor from New York. It was as if the French were moving in a time warp, recapitulating the Metropolitan Opera's experiences of a quarter-century ago. Even in purely technical matters, parallels were uncanny: before opening night in 1966, the Met discovered that its main stage turntable would not turn; the Bastille Opera found that its stage elevator would not elevate. Both houses, designed as sophisticated machines for producing opera, had to begin by relying on man-powered scene shifting.

title: Round 1: Islanders-Rangers
description: Word crept into the Rangers' locker room, then swept through it. The Penguins had lost; the Islanders had won and qualified for the playoffs. New York hockey madness was suddenly five days away and counting.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD:

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our teak furniture has an oiled finish that has become quite dark over the years. When new, the furniture was rubbed with linseed oil several times, and I have since been told that was a mistake, that I should have used mineral oil. I think the furniture needs to be cleaned, but am not sure how to do so. Would soap and water hurt?

title: Wendy Goldberg, Student, to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Goldberg of Swampscott, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Wendy Heather Goldberg to Charles Samuel de Gunzburg, a son of Baron Alain de Gunzburg of Paris and the late Minda Bronfman de Gunzburg. A September wedding is planned.

title: About Men;   A Whole New Ball Game
description: MAKING IT ONTO the second-string varsity high-school football team by my junior year meant that I had measured up to my dreams. Next year I would play on the starting team. Thinking about that junior year still stirs my competitive juices. Us against them. Me against the world. Thirty-seven years later the competitive drive still propels me.

title: Fashion;   Shaping the Look of Things to Come
description: The fall collections in New York got off to a rollicking start Thursday evening when eight young designers offered a sneak preview of their lines at the Martha International shop, 473 Park Avenue (58th Street).

title: 'A HACK OF GENIUS'
description: BEN HECHT

title: Leaping Into the Unknown
description: THE metal apparatus joining my bound ankles to the thin cord hangs off the edge of the bridge. It feels heavy enough to pull me over. Without my glasses everything is blurry. I look out, as instructed, to the trees on a faraway ridge, to the distant bridge that the cars cross over. ''Throw yourself at that bridge,'' the man says. ''10, 9 . . .'' I look down into the gorge more than 10 stories beneath my feet - the green-gray river twisted white at the edges where it meets the rocky walls. ''Stop,'' I say. I am in Queenstown, New Zealand. Embarkation point for famous hikes like those along the Milford Track, scene of skiing in season, sightseeing flights to nearby fiords, and wild jet-boating on the rivers, this area is a center for travelers coming to the South Island. Queenstown is a resort village built on the shores of a lake in the mountains. The village is touristy and expensive, but the air is clean and at night the snowy mountains glow the reflected indigo of the water. It is the site of the world's first mass bungy jump operation.

title: In the Saddest Way, New York Learns About Hondurans
description: IN the crude fashion that such tragedies favor, the arson that killed 87 people last week at an illegal social club in the Bronx opened a window on some of New York's better-hidden immigrants.

title: Where to Admire the Spectacle of Spring
description: LEAD: ''YOU don't have to go to Mississippi for magnolias or Georgia for azaleas,'' the state's director of tourism, Barnett Laschever, said. ''We have it all here. Little Connecticut is like a flower show.''

title: Smoking Aloft
description: To the Editor: Even though the ban on smoking on almost all domestic airline flights has gone into effect, I feel obliged to state my objections. I am a travel agent and a smoker, and although most of my clients request nonsmoking seats, there are many who insist on having a smoking seat. I do not believe that an entire aircraft can be smoke polluted from a small smoking section, and I know that many like myself will now fly only to Hawaii or to foreign destinations.

title: IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut;   Recent Sales
description: Bronxville, N.Y. $985,000

title: Tech Notes;   Scanning for Better Light
description: A research team headed by John C. Gustafson, manager of light source technology, at GTE Laboratories Inc. in Waltham, Mass., has used computer-aided-tomography, known as CAT scanning, to design more efficient lighting products. The team uses a CAT scanner to map the processes occurring within high-intensity-discharge lamps. These lamps produce light by electrically exciting the atoms of pressurized chemical gases trapped within a glass tube.

title: Mugabe Is Re-elected President of Zimbabwe
description: President Robert Mugabe easily won re-election today, but a low turnout dashed his hopes of a large popular mandate for turning Zimbabwe into a one-party state.

title: Katherine M. Blakeley Wed to Mark D. Teich
description: Katherine Marion Blakeley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Christopher P. Blakeley of Ambler, Pa., was married last evening to Mark Douglas Teich, the son of Helen C. Teich of Floral Park, L.I., and Hollywood, Fla., and the late David Teich. Rabbi Norman Kahan officiated at the Pierre in New York.

title: Innovative Food in Coliseum's Shadow
description: VISUALIZE Cody's American Restaurant & Bar, across the street from the Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale. Do you see a boisterous crowd of hockey fans downing hardy burgers and brew after an Islanders' game?

title: Sara Anne Keating and Neil W. Flanagan Wed
description: Sara Anne Keating, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Freeland Keating of New Canaan, Conn., was married there yesterday at St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church to Neil William Flanagan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Lawrence Flanagan of Ridgefield, Conn. The Rev. Henry Zenorini performed the ceremony.

title: Douglas Ostrover Wed to Julia Jordan
description: Julia Hughes Jordan, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Miles Jordan Jr. of Charleston, S.C., and Douglas Irving Ostrover, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Julian Ostrover of Stamford, Conn., were married yesterday at the Summerall Chapel at the Citadel in Charleston. Canon Samuel Chew Williams Fleming, an Episcopal priest, and Rabbi Milton Schlager performed the ceremony.

title: Review/Recital;   Siegfried Jerusalem, Tenor, In Beethoven and Schubert
description: The German tenor Siegfried Jerusalem has been singing at the Metropolitan Opera for a decade but gave his first New York City recital only last Sunday afternoon. For his debut, at the Frick Collection, he sang Beethoven's ''An die Ferne Geliebte,'' Schumann's ''Dichterliebe'' and selections from Schubert's ''Schwanengesang.''

title: Pastimes;   Bridge
description: Napoleon's indispensable foreign minister, Bishop Talleyrand, once asked a young man whether he played whist. When the answer was negative, the Bishop offered a warning: ''What a dull old age you are saving up for yourself.''

title: Verdi's 'Traviata' and Requiem
description: VERDI is the composer of vocal choice this week, with both ''La Traviata'' and the Requiem on the calendar in Connecticut.

title: NO SHELTER IN THE HACIENDA
description: PARADISE

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: LOIS T. BRONZ;

The Politics of Personal Involvement
description: LEAD: IT wasn't too long ago that it was rare for a woman to be elected to public office. And, in Westchester, black candidates are not numerous. But Lois T. Bronz was ahead of her time. Black and female, she has served on the Greenburgh Town Council since 1976, a decade after she moved to the county from Louisiana.

title: Jill Cuty Engaged to Stephen Griswold
description: The engagement of Jill Ann Cuty to Stephen Merrill Griswold, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger Parkman Griswold of Irvington, N.Y., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Peter Cuty of West Islip, L.I. A November wedding is planned.

title:
BASEBALL;

IN SHORT
description: LEAD: DODGERS! The First 100 Years. By Stanley Cohen. (Birch Lane/Carol Publishing, $19.95.) I grew up across the street from Ebbets Field in Brooklyn. The night lights from the stadium shone into my bedroom window. When I broke my arm, Sandy Koufax signed his name on my cast. The Dodgers were family. Stanley Cohen's ''Dodgers!

title: Recycle These Empties
description: THE downtown areas of many older cities in Westchester seem to have a lot of empty space in commercial buildings. Even when the first floor is used, there is often empty space on the floors above. Some of this space appears to have been empty for years. It is unlikely that much of it will ever be rented for commercial use, as many stores and offices have relocated from the old downtown areas to new shopping centers or office parks.

title: Giving Life To a Plot Device
description: To the Editor:

title: Rise in Migratory Seals Poses Safety Concerns
description: AN increase in migratory seals along the state's coastline, from Raritan Bay to Atlantic City, is posing a problem: where can the creatures find a safe haven in a heavily populated and developed region?

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Rowing

title: ISLANDERS CLINCH THE LAST BERTH IN PLAYOFFS
description: The Islanders concluded their regular season with a rousing 6-2 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers, at joyous Nassau Colisum tonight, and qualified for the Stanley Cup playoffs when the Penguins lost to the Buffalo Sabres, 3-2, in overtime in Pittsburgh.

title: Robert Leonard And Miss Saliba To Marry in July
description: The engagement of Wendy Jane Saliba to Robert Andrew Leonard, a son of Judge and Mrs. Charles Leonard of Merrick, L.I., has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Catherine Saliba of East Brunswick, N.J., and John Saliba of Keene, N.H. A July wedding is planned.

title: The 51st and 52d States;   Let Puerto Ricans Decide Their Fate, but Fairly
description: Puerto Rico is not America's Lithuania, but it is unhappy with its status as a highly dependent commonwealth. An overwhelming majority of 3.3 million islanders are agreed that they want change. But as Congress is learning, agreement stops there. What adds to the perplexity is a parallel but unrelated campaign to grant statehood to the District of Columbia.

title: Discovering A Neighborhood I Never Knew
description: IT'S raining today, and most of the snow that covered the grass and roads has melted.

title: Narrative Emphasized In 'Tale of Two Cities'
description: IF only for the sake of perpetuating a classic, one hopes that ''A Tale of Two Cities'' is faring better in classrooms than in the McCarter Theater's deadening and provincial production, which runs through next Sunday.

title: Fewer New York Teen-Agers Have Their First Job
description: Only one in four of New York City's older teen-agers is in the labor force, less than half the rate in the nation as a whole and lower than that of other big cities, Federal statistics show.

title: >Act Now to Ward Off Summer Weeds
description: EVEN though the forsythia has burst forth with its yellow bells, there is still time to get rid of summer nuisances before they appear. But these deeds of eradication must be done promptly, because spring is here, and the blooms are advancing.

title: She's a Beginner, but What Connections
description: I'd like to begin this interview with the film producer Julian Schlossberg by saying that it was undertaken without any thought of publication and no money up front.

title:
The Executive Life;

How to Retire And Stay Alive, Too
description: LEAD: It was a day that Henry Kates, chief executive of the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company, would never forget. Sitting in a conference room at a Phoenix hotel with some 300 other Mutual Benefit insurance employees, Mr. Kates listened as a 69-year-old company field manager gave his retirement presentation.

title: A Father-Son Conflict in 'Stone Carver'
description: SOMETIMES the readiness of a play may not depend on the honing of a playwright's craft as much as on the delicate resolution of the rocky relationship that may have inspired the play in the first place.

title: U.S. Fears Baltic Crisis Will Hurt Moscow Ties
description: Even before Mikhail S. Gorbachev's latest attempt today to halt Lithuanian secession, Administration and Congressional officials were expressing concern that the Baltic crisis was disrupting efforts to bring the United States military budget, arms control and the entire tone of Soviet-American relations into a new era.

title: Drinking Water Is Focus of Concern
description: AS millions of pounds of industrially produced chemicals pass through publicly owned sewage treatment plants, environmentalists say, irreparable damage is being done to both the surface and ground-water supplies that provide drinking water for the state's nearly eight million residents.

title: Gorbachev, at a Dizzying Height, Prepares to Kick Away the Ladder
description: WHILE all eyes have been on rebellious Lithuania in these days of imperial stress, Mikhail S. Gorbachev has entered a critical and precarious stage in the realization of his grand design for the Soviet Union.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: THEY emerge in March, after the sun has fallen from the skies and the friendly stars come out: earthworms. Along the knotted string that serves for a brain, a message is passed: ''Reach out and touch some worm.'' So one by hopeful one, then two by fortunate two, they leave the dark places that closet their days - long, pink bodies fevering for the touch of another.

title: Managing Erosion At Barrier Beaches
description: LEAD: WHEN the Long Island Regional Planning Board recommended four months ago that summer houses and businesses on South Shore barrier beaches be razed if they were extensively damaged by storms or erosion, an outcry arose from property owners.

title: TOO MANY, TOO RICH, TOO WASTEFUL
description: THE POPULATION EXPLOSION

title: Overachievers Stay on Track And in the Swim
description: IN A DRY, CRISP SATURDAY in December, just before dawn in the brown foothills of the San Gabriel Mountains, east of Los Angeles, some 350 men and women gathered in a parking lot at Chaffey College for the sheer joy, as one put it, of ''utterly exhausting'' themselves.

title: TROUBLE IN DAMASCUS
description: SYRIA'S NORTH-SOUTH HIGHWAY SLIDES by the town of Hama as if skirting a guilty secret. Yet according to the man who runs the Ministry of Tourism office, there is much to see there. He has marked out the points of interest on a small photocopied map: the old wooden water wheels and the citadel, the museum and restaurants on the banks of the Orontes River.

title: MANDELA'S GROUP CALLS OFF TALKS
description: President F. W. de Klerk's plans for negotiations with South Africa's black majority suffered a setback today when the African National Congress announced that it was suspending plans to attend talks with the Government scheduled for April 11.

title: Whitey Herzog Is Plotting 'Something'
description: Over in Port St. Lucie, the Mets manager, Davey Johnson, has another week to decide whether Dave Magadan or Mike Marshall will be playing first base on opening day. But over here, hundreds of orange groves away from Johnson's furrowed brow, Whitey Herzog has already decided.

title: Miss Thomas to Marry Chip Houghton
description: John C. Thomas Jr. of New York and Locust Valley, L.I., has announced the engagement of his daughter Suzanne Elizabeth Thomas to Francis Joseph Houghton 3d, a son of Margot Dooling Houghton and Mr. Houghton Jr., both of New York. A September wedding is planned.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our teak furniture has an oiled finish that has become quite dark over the years. When new, the furniture was rubbed with linseed oil several times, and I have since been told that was a mistake, that I should have used mineral oil. I think the furniture needs to be cleaned, but am not sure how to do so. Would soap and water hurt?

title: Style;   Dining with Mrs. V
description: After all the time I dined or lunched in that banquetted corner of Mrs. Vreeland's apartment, I cannot recall a single thing we ate. But the dialogue, the anecdotes, the wild flights of conversation still reverberate in my mind. This is what dining with D.V. was all about - food for the mind and senses. Not that the vittles weren't good. They were - soup, roast chicken, vegetables, some kind of bread pudding. Plain American fare. Everyone has a story of the surprising mix of guests, usually no more than six, often fewer, and even more often just a deux with Mrs. V. This recollection of Kenneth Jay Lane, the costume jeweler, is not at all unusual: ''Diana called one night. Obviously she had been expecting guests from Europe, who were not arriving in time. I was having dinner with my mother, just in from Detroit. Bring her, Mrs. Vreeland commanded. The evening progressed exactly as if the original guests had been there. D.V. talked on about Andy's new movie... about Candy Darling... reminiscences... the story of the first time she milked a zebra. The usual conversation. She never once said a word to me or looked in my direction. She spoke directly to mother. When we finally left, my mmother said: 'I don't know why you have never introduced me to your friend Mrs. Vreeland before. She is the most fascinating woman I've ever met.''' .

title:
IN SHORT: BASEBALL;

THE COMPLETE HOLTIN' JOE
description: LEAD: In 1939 I was sitting in the bleachers in Yankee Stadium when I saw one of the greatest catches I've ever witnessed in my life. Joe DiMaggio raced back in center field, behind the flagpole and the monuments at the 461-foot mark, turned, gyrated and gloved a smash off the bat of Hank Greenberg of the Detroit Tigers a second before it hit the wall.

title: For the Relief Workers, a Psychic Toll
description: The worst thing about the Bronx soial club fire was that there were so few survivors and so many families devastated, Laura Aiello, a Red Cross disaster relief worker, reflected Friday night. ''It left a terrible emptiness,'' she said.

title: The Hutch That Is And Used to Be
description: The former beautiful Hutchinson River Parkway ride through Westchester is now just another memory, replaced by so-called necessary expansion that turns out to be not so expansive after all. For the most part, most of the new multimillion-dollar ''expansion'' is still two-lane and if you're not extra careful, particularly around the Eastchester area, you're liable to think that which looks like a third lane is not really a third lane at all and you'll have a difficult and dangerous time getting back where you belong.

title: Pastimes;   Coins
description: Nantucket Island, which is renowned for the exploits of its whaling fleet, gave rise to a curious ivory medal in its early days. The medal is called a Nantucket mortgage button and commemorates not valor, but thrift.

title:
;

Sudden Death Yields to Sudden Life
description: LEAD: MORE people should know about the thin line between sudden death and sudden life. If you have not been to the line as I have, don't try it. The trouble is, someday you may not have the choice.

title: TAKING THE MEASURE OF THE NEW TEAM AT THE MET
description: In 1987, James Levine, the artistic director of the Metropolitan Opera, sent out strong signals that he wished to lighten his administrative and artistic load with the company, to concentrate on his conducting at the Met and elsewhere.

title: Recording Enters a New Era, And You Can't Find It on LP
description: The record, which in its various forms has captured the musical passage of the nation from ragtime to rap, appears to have entered a death spiral.

title: Kathryn E. Clow Weds C. C. Eddy
description: Kathryn Elizabeth Clow, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley H. Clow of Mendham, N.J., was married yesterday in St. Louis to Christopher Clifford Eddy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene W. Eddy of Angola, N.Y. The Rev. William K. Christian 3d performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of St. Michael and St. George.

title: WILL THE REAL SAN FRANCISCO PLEASE STAND UP?
description: The serious esthetes in San Francisco don't much like it, and nothing upsets them more than to be told that it's almost all right. But the glitzy new San Francisco Marriott, which the locals have sneeringly called everything from the Wurlitzer to a mutant from Las Vegas, is actually the most alluring addition to this city's skyline in years. Not only is it not half bad, it is also strangely appropriate to San Francisco, a city that has long danced on the edge of vulgarity, and has always had a slightly raffish quality to its architecture.

title: All About/Hypermarkets;   Will American Shoppers Think Bigger Is Really Better?
description: Somehow the usual comparison - more than five football fields, end zones included - fails to convey the huge expanse of the Carrefour store in Philadelphia. Transplanted to Manhattan, it would cover nearly two city blocks; transplanted to Egypt, Carrefour and a bit of its parking lot would cover the same area as the Great Pyramid of Cheops.

title: Review/Dance;   Energy And Power Of Sports
description: Two years ago the New Jersey Center Dance Collective made a fine impression in New York with a tribute to some of the pioneers of modern dance. On Thursday night at the Nikolais/Louis Choreospace, these dancers from Somerville, N.J., looked equally good in contemporary works.

title: Too Many Starting Pitchers Can Bring a Mound of Problems
description: The Mets are not the only team that has the highly unusual problem of having too many starting pitchers. Some problem.

title: Keeping Up the Fight For Clean Air
description: AS a new Governor in Trenton, I find that the ongoing debate in Washington over the Clean Air Act is even more disheartening than a similar debate I took part in as a young Congressman in 1976 and 1977.

title: Lifestyle;   Art Imitates Life: Auditioning for 'Bonfire'
description: Clearly, the place to have been this week past was the TriBeCa Film Center. There Brian De Palma was holding by-invitation-only auditions for socialites to portray socialites in the film version of Tom Wolfe's ''Bonfire of the Vanities.'' The movie will star Tom Hanks, Melanie Griffith and Bruce Willis; this time the search was on for bit players and walk-ons.

title:
Your Own Account;

Picking a Better Credit Card
description: LEAD: Americans spend $32 billion a year just to use general-purpose credit cards - for fees, interest and other charges, according to H. Spencer Nilson, publisher of an industry newsletter called The Nilson Report. But, Mr. Nilson says in a new study, they could save at least 25 percent of that by tailoring the cards to their spending habits.

title: 'Damn Yankees': An Explanation
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: White Plains Buoyed by the Success of Recycling Programs
description: LEAD: RECYCLING programs are very much on the mind of Joseph Nicoletti, deputy commissioner of the Department of Public Works here.

title: East Bloc Change May Sway Greek Vote, Too
description: The main election poster of Greece's conservative party depicts a crumbling Berlin wall, while that of the Socialists and Communists emphasizes modest change instead of the militant leftist measures advocated in the past. When Greece, a member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, holds its third elections in 10 months on April 8, the outcome is likely to be influenced largely by events in Eastern Europe.

title: For Democrats' Loyal Soldier, Time to 'Make the Break'
description: LEAD: ONE day after Gov. William A. O'Neill said he would not seek re-election, his Lieutenant Governor, Joseph J. Fauliso, made a similar announcement. ''There comes a time when you have to tear yourself away from it and make the break,'' said the 74-year-old Mr. Fauliso, who has been active in politics since the mid-1940's.

title: BLACK STUDIES' NEW STAR: Henry Louis Gates Jr.
description: IN 1981, WHEN THE MACARTHUR FOUNDATION ANNOUNCED that it would pay out generous stipends to 21 ''exceptionally talented individuals'' (the first crop of instant ''geniuses''), Henry Louis Gates Jr. was an unknown 30-year-old assistant professor at Yale University. A man called on the telephone and started talking about giving him something like $30,000 a year for five years, no strings attached. Gates told him to ''quit fooling,'' and the next morning at 8:30, still unconvinced, he waited by the gate of his Yale college for the messenger with the promised letter of confirmation. Embarrassed by his own eagerness, he retreated to his apartment; proof of his good fortune arrived soon thereafter.

title: Party in Guatemala Names Its Candidate for President
description: The governing Guatemalan Christian Democrat Party today named former Foreign Minister Alfonso Cabrera Hidalgo its presidential candidate in elections to be held in November.

title: GOOD BOOKS ABUT BEING SICK
description: I was reading Shirley Hazzard's novel ''The Transit of Venus.'' Though I had admired her other books, I'd always resisted this one. It struck me as too pure somehow, too heroic, larger or finer than life and therefore unreal. But now I read it with an almost indescribable pleasure. There were sentences that brought tears of gratification to my eyes and raised the hairs on the nape of my neck.

title: BUSINESS DIARY
description: COMPANIES

title: Signs of Spring in China, and New Discontent
description: In the first sign that Chinese dissidents are planning protests this spring, students said illegal posters were put up today at two or more universities, calling for peaceful demonstrations in Tiananmen Square in the coming week.

title: Getting Close to Nature in Montana
description: ACCORDING to a treasured adage in the American West, Montana is what America was. And nowhere does that natural beauty and spirit better exist than in Glacier National Park, a one-million-acre pocket of purity tucked into the northwest corner hard by Canada. Glacier's awe-inspiring alpine vistas are easy to get to but hard to forget. The severity of its mountain geography and its location, slightly off the usual over-traveled Western park trek, have in a wonderfully quiet way helped preserve Glacier from the hordes of Winnebagos, trailers and over-burdened station wagons that clog the roadways at places like Yellowstone and the Grand Tetons. Because of weather conditions, the upper reaches of the park usually do not open until June and the lower portions in April, but now is the time to plan a visit, since accommodations are limited and reservations often necessary.

title: Boning Up For the Next Battle Over Deregulation
description: AIRLINE deregulation has produced, besides much else, a steady stream of studies. More than a dozen institutes and Government agencies have churned out piles of papers since Congress decided 12 years ago to allow the airlines to fly when and where they want and to charge whatever passengers were willing to pay.

title: Ultimatum On Injuries
description: A baseball career can create a fantasylike effect on a man's life, but reality has intruded on Keith Hernandez's. One more disabling injury, he said, and his career is over.

title: Knight Criticism Is Not Justified
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Saco, Me.;   Project Goes To Creditor
description: A $40 MILLION project to convert a dilapidated textile mill into an upscale complex with homes, offices and a hotel has failed, and the developer has turned the property over to a creditor.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ended March 17

title: Suzanne Pearl Marries Kenneth Bakst
description: The Union League Club in New York was the setting last evening for the marriage of Suzanne Pearl, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Erwin Pearl of New York, and Kenneth Bakst, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Alvin A. Bakst of Rancho Mirage, Calif. Rabbi Jerome Davidson officiated.

title: Shuttle Launching Moved Up
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration today advanced the launching date for the shuttle Discovery and its payload, the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope, by two days to April 10.

title: 2 Officers Wounded and a Suspect Is Killed After a Bronx Robbery
description: Two New York City police officers were wounded and a robbery suspect was killed in a shootout yesterday morning after a car chase that led them from the Bronx into Westchester County, the police said.

title: Looking Ahead
description: MONDAY: Donald J. Trump's Taj Mahal casino and hotel are scheduled to open in Atlantic City.

title: Pastimes;   Chess
description: The late Tigran Petrosian was a great believer in the old adage, ''Give him enough rope and he'll hang himself.'' The world champion from 1966 to 1969 believed that extending oneself to find forcing moves to put the opponent under pressure was a great waste of talent. And what was worse, as he saw it, was that this kind of high-pressure play put the opponent on his guard and drove him to find the right moves.

title: Audubon Theater
description: To the Editor:

title: POSTINGS: Repairing a Landmark;   Church to Study Water Damage
description: The 160-foot-high granite tower of the First Church of Christ, Scientist, which has been a fixture at the northwest corner of Central Park West and West 96th Street since the turn of the century, has been extensively damaged by water leaks in recent years and is in need of repair. To help, the New York Landmarks Conservancy has awarded the church an $8,000 grant from its Sacred Sites and Properties Fund for a study to determine the extent of the damage and recommend repairs. The landmarked building, at 1 West 96th Street, is regarded as an excellent example of Beaux-Arts classicism.

title:
ART;

Quiet Photographs From Latin America
description: LEAD: WITH all the political news coming out of Latin America these days, it's natural to expect a show of photographs from that region to stress the documentary mode - chanting crowds and abandoned children. Therefore the mostly inventive and artful exhibition at the Bronx Museum for the Arts comes as an unexpected treat.

title:
Pastimes: Gardening;

A Gentler, More Natural Approach to Spring Lawn Care
description: LEAD: One of the places to start saving the planet, in my opinion, is in lawn care. The first step is to monitor the conditions under which the lawn is growing. Are the insect and disease problems real or are things being treated ''just in case.''

title: Talks on Hungary Coalition Shaken by Party Infighting
description: The party likely to hold the balance of power in Hungary's next government was torn by infighting today after saying it had made a deal with two other conservative parties for a second round of elections on April 8.

title: The View From: Old Lyme;   Sewer System Plan Raises Fears About Pollution of River
description: MERVIN F. ROBERTS, chairman of the Old Lyme Shellfish Commission and a member of the town's Board of Selectmen, is proud of the progress that has been made to clean up the Connecticut River over the last two decades.

title: Indians Stand Off Troopers After Copter Is Hit by Shots
description: Mohawk Indians living on land where the authorities believe shots were fired at a military helicopter stood off state troopers today who attempted to enter the territory to investigate.

title:
IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut;

Condos and House Lots to Be Auctioned
description: LEAD: TOWN-HOUSE condominiums and house lots will be sold next Sunday at Westchester's second major property auction in four months.

title: Coalition Rule Seems a Safe Guess in Bulgaria
description: Ten weeks before this country holds its first free elections in more than four decades, the outcome is a tossup. But whichever party comes out on top, Bulgaria's next government will be formed by a coalition.

title: Old Oil Tanks Threaten State's Drinking Water
description: LEAD: WHEN an underground storage tank in the Pawcatuck section of Stonington leaked 1,500 gallons of gasoline on Feb. 15, it threatened the water supply for more than 31,000 people. Now, as the cleanup continues, the water supply is still reduced by nearly half water use restrictions remain in place and the ultimate damage is still in question.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

On an Old Tree, Imagination Ripened
description: LEAD: EACH spring, when winter starts to slacken its grip on all things green, a childhood memory of an old willow tree comes to mind. It sprouted the first flags of spring - a signal that soon I would be in the embracing arms of its overgrowth, hiding under its leafy cover, reading books until the very end of summer.

title: Wall Street;   Those Newly Cash-Rich Insurers
description: A few months ago, two law professors started a stir in the insurance industry with a study that showed that defendants have been faring better in product liability cases. The widely reported findings, by James A. Henderson Jr. and Theodore Eisenberg, both of the Cornell Law School, suggested to some analysts that big liability insurers might soon be able to move unneeded reserves back into profits.

title: Marcy Sandler Plans to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Michael R. Sandler of Boston have announced the engagement of their daughter Marcy Ann Sandler to James Troy Janover, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan van S. Janover of New York. A September wedding is planned.

title: Buffalo Shuts Down Its Buses and Subways
description: Buffalo's financially strapped bus and subway system was shut down tonight, despite pleas from community leaders and protests from outraged riders.

title: Design Preview;   Playing It Safe
description: Showrooms at the Southern Furniture Market in High Point, N.C., reflect the season's business climate. When sales are strong, manufacturers take an optimistic outlook, presenting new lines and fresh designs. When sales are slow, however, there are fewer introductions and new pieces tend to have a conservative look.

title:
TELEVISION;

One African's Tragedy Focuses Attention on AIDS
description: LEAD: Lunch with John Zaritsky and Virginia Storring is mostly coffee and cigarettes. Coffee and cigarettes evoke the years the husband-and-wife team have spent in editing rooms putting together their award-winning documentaries. Coffee and cigarettes seemed to account for the reddening of their eyes as they talked about their latest film, ''Born in Africa.

title: America, Doubled
description: Today is Census Day but that's not what startled him. Yes, he said to himself, the decennial census is important because, like taxes, voting and jury duty, it applies to everyone. Yes, it's the basis for reapportioning the 435 seats in the House and reallocating $50 billion in Federal funds. Yes, it's a fountain of American facts.

title: Panama and U.S. Strive To Settle on Death Toll
description: Nearly three months after American troops invaded Panama, the Panamanian and American Governments, as well as human rights groups in both countries, are still struggling to compile a definitive tally of how many Panamanians were killed and wounded in the overthrow of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. The uncertainty has allowed critics of the intervention and of Panama's new civilian Government to offer much higher body counts and to charge, in the words of former Attorney General Ramsey Clark, a ''conspiracy of silence'' to hide the real death toll.

title: Question Of the Week;   Should Basketball Use Instant Replay?
description: There is no need for the use of replay in basketball. In the N.F.L. when a play is reviewed, more often than not it remains unchanged, regardless of accuracy. The officials in both the college and the pro games do an outstanding job on the whole, and replay is unnecessary.

title: Campus Life: Kansas;   Tenured Professor Is Dismissed On Ethics Charges
description: For the first time in its 123-year history, the University of Kansas has discharged a tenured faculty member.

title:
FORUM;

The Secure Way to Cut the Military
description: Steven L. Canby is an economist and military strategist. He is a former Army infantry officer. By STEVEN L. CANBY AS President Gorbachev dismantles the ''evil empire,'' American defense spending is increasing. The military budget is to increase steadily to $311 billion, in current dollars, by 1995 - $20 billion above present spending levels. The Bush Administration justifies these rising military costs by the possibility of a resurgent Soviet Union, enduring third-world threats and the continuing technological revolution in weaponry. New defense planning calls for high technology weapons that can exert leverage against the Soviet Union and other adversaries. The United States can no longer afford this approach to security.

title: The Fine Facades Of a Yugoslav City
description: MORNINGS in the old part of the Yugoslav city of Ljubljana evoke a blank canvas. Not until 9:30 does the fog begin to dissolve. The outlines of steep roofs, spires, leaden domes, statues and poplars emerge like an artist's first, quick strokes. In the beginning it is a pen-and-ink with charcoal. Only around 10 come the richer hues of the palette: orange and yellow ochers, pinks, sandy reds and dazzling greens. And as the sun finally splashes on the candy-striped facades, there is an unreal clarity to the architectural formations, as though you are seeing them reflected in water right-side up.

title: Let's Hear One Last 'Allagaroo' for City College
description: Allagaroo

title: Steering the Right Course in a Rental Car in Europe
description: AMERICANS planning to rent a car in Europe this summer should remember that automatic transmissions are hard to get there, that written confirmation of reservations specifying automatic shift are essential and that some travel agents began reserving automatics for their clients last fall for this summer.

title: Penn Varsity Holds Off Yale in Blackwell Cup
description: The Pennsylvania varsity crew withstood a closing sprint by Yale and won the Blackwell Cup today for the fourth year in a row.

title: U.S.-Japan Talks on Satellites Recess Over 'Technical Issue'
description: The United States and Japan today recessed talks aimed at opening the Japanese market to foreign satellite makers. Officials said that negotiators needed more instructions from their governments on what was described as a technical matter, and that the talks would resume on Monday.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: Did a tornado strike? Is it extreme sloppiness or a temper tantrum? None of the above, you say. Perhaps a trip is in the offing. Not that either? Then what accounts for this pitiful sight - the open closet door, the dresser drawers pulled out, dresses and suits on bed and chairs, hangers scattered hither and yon?

title: Mozart at St. George's
description: Kenneth Dake will conduct the St. George's Choral Society and Orchestra in Mozart's Grand Mass in C minor (K. 427) at St. George's Church on Stuyvesant Square, 16th Street east of Third Avenue, at 4 P.M. today. The program also includes Mozart's Piano Concerto No. 15 (K. 450), with Angela Laba as the soloist. Admission is $10. Information: 475-0830.

title: Central Europe's Grimy Coal Belt: Progress, Yes, but at What Cost?
description: Most, Czechoslovakia - On the edge of an open-pit mine in the mountains of Bohemia stands a small cluster of medieval buildings, the last reminder of a town that survives only in the minds of its former inhabitants.

title: Question Of the Week;   Should Basketball Use Instant Replay?
description: No, no, no, no. The refs are not perfect but neither are the players. Will there be a replay after every call that Bill Laimbeer doesn't like? It would take five hours to play each half. Leave the replay for the news at 11.

title: TEACHING STEELCASE TO DANCE
description: PREFACED BY CRASHING CYMBALS, Steve Martin breaks into song and tap dance atop a collection of desks, shelves and storage cabinets. Life-size on a video screen, the movie superstar looms over the entrance to the Steelcase showroom at the National Exhibition of Contract Interior Furnishings (NEOCON), mecca of the $8 billion domestic office-furniture industry.

title: New Zealand's Inventive Ceramics
description: THERE are many reasons for visiting Nelson, a city at the top of the South Island of New Zealand. Nelson, the province as well as the city, attracts visitors from all over the world, who go to hike and kayak in Abel Tasman National Park, and is a favorite vacation spot for New Zealanders, who like the clear water and miles of golden beaches. Another reason to visit is to see the work of the many craftsmen living and working there, particularly the potters. The quality of the local clay is excellent; indeed, much of the clay used by potters all over New Zealand comes from around Nelson, as does a good deal of the glaze materials, ground from naturally occurring minerals.

title: Summer Squall Wins Beam
description: Summer Squall established himself as the leading Eastern prospect for the Kentucky Derby by winning the $500,000 Jim Beam Stakes yesterday at Turfway Park in Kentucky.

title: Proposals on Fighting Drugs and Alcohol
description: The article entitled ''The Best Ways to Fight Drug and Alcohol Abuse'' (Opinion Page, March 11) prompts these thoughts.

title: Buzzer Beaters and Big Business
description: DENVER

title: BRADY SPEAKS UP FOR SAVINGS CHOICE
description: The Bush Administration moved aggressively today to reaffirm support for T. Timothy Ryan Jr. as the nation's top savings and loan regulator after the disclosure that Mr. Ryan used marijuana and cocaine in the early 1970's.

title: Currency;   All Eyes on the Group of 7
description: Foreign exchange traders will be focusing this week on the meeting of the United States and its economic allies in the Group of Seven next Saturday in Paris. The traders will be closely following the official comments during the week of the finance ministers of the seven members - the others are Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada - to see whether the group is likely to make a coordinated effort to rescue the beleaguered yen. The yen slipped perilously close to 160 to the dollar last week before rallying a bit because of profit taking. Without some formal statement from the Group of Seven after the meeting or dollar selling by central banks in the days that follow, the yen could fall further, taking the Tokyo stock and bond markets with it.

title: Democrats, Sick of Being 'Responsible,' Let Loose
description: THERE are Democrats who sincerely believe that their party will not take back the White House until it loses control of Congress. Obviously, that is not a program that any Democrat in the House or Senate will volunteer for.

title: Eiko and Koma: Life in the Slow Lane
description: Slow, very slow - that's the first quality almost everyone notices about the collaboratively choreographed works of Eiko and Koma. Audiences have found their unruffled pacing both strange and eloquent ever since the Japanese-born dancers made their New York debut 14 years ago.

title: The Term 'Nonwhite' Has Racist Overtones
description: To the Editor:

title: Data Bank/April 1, 1990

MUSIC;

Three Choirs to Perform In Benefit for the Poor
description: LEAD: SONGS of hope and self-reliance are among the themes that will help celebrate one of the state's most ambitious community projects, in a benefit concert Saturday night. Three choirs and their directors have donated their services to raise funds for the Martin House Community for Justice Foundation, a nonprofit corporation that helps provide housing, education and job training for the poor in

title: Workers of the World, Innovate!
description: To the Editor:

title: In Working for Mideast Peace, Fairness Is Vital
description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE VIEW
description: What is a National Ballet company? The San Francisco Ballet, which has just staged its first full-length - and lavish - production of ''The Sleeping Beauty,'' may provide an unexpected answer.

title: Tina Rosenbaum Weds
description: Tina Rosenbaum, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Erich Rosenbaum of Dallas, was married there last evening to Neal Kurzner, a son of Dr. and Mrs. R. Raymond Kurzner of New York. Rabbis Sheldon Zimmerman and Gerald Klein officiated at Temple Emanu-El. Mrs. Kurzner is a summa cum laude graduate of the University of Texas. Her husband graduated from Vassar College and received an M.B.A. from the University of Pennsylvania. They are vice presidents of Arty Imports, a distributor of silk flowers in Dallas. The company is owned by her father and mother, Esther Rosenbaum. Mr. Kurzner's mother, Barbara Kurzner, is an interior designer, and his father is an orthopedic surgeon in Jackson Heights, Queens.

title: Catholic Women Air Views on Abortion
description: Roman Catholic women in Wisconsin gave Archbishop Rembert G. Weakland of Milwaukee an earful of contending views last week in sessions he convened to explore women's attitudes on the church's opposition to abortion.

title: Lifestyle;   If This Is Friday and That's a Beer, We Must Be in the Love Transporter
description: Getting into a nightclub used to be the important thing. But the era of the velvet rope is over. Now real status isn't a matter of what club you go to, but what night you go.

title: Children's Books On the Holocaust
description: As a children's librarian and an individual drawn to stories and books on the Holocaust, I am pleased that David A. Adler has written a new book on the subject [''For Youth, Memories of the Holocaust,'' Jan. 28] . His work, both fiction and nonfiction, is regularly added to our collections in the Queens Library system, and I expect his newest book will be too.

title: Smoking Law Now in Effect For Workplaces in New York
description: The second phase of New York State's comprehensive smoking law takes effect Sunday with the aim of insuring that nonsmokers can work in smoke-free environments.

title: What Opera and Musicals Share: Not Much, William Bolcom Finds
description: William Bolcom is hardly the first major American composer to write both musical comedy and traditional opera. Gershwin managed that trick, of course; and so has Leonard Bernstein. But Mr. Bolcom may be the first to attempt both simultaneously. Next Sunday, the American Music Theater Festival will open its seventh season in Philadelphia with the premiere of ''Casino Paradise,'' a new work in the tradition of the modern Broadway musical, with music by Mr. Bolcom, lyrics by Arnold Weinstein and the book by Mr. Weinstein and Thomas Babe. (Previews begin Wednesday.) Meanwhile, Mr. Bolcom is also in the early stages of working on his first opera, ''McTeague,'' which will be produced by the Lyric Opera of Chicago in 1992.

title: The Executive Computer;   Dull at First Glance, I.B.M.'s Latest Have a Surprise Inside
description: The International Business Machines Corporation recently brought forth some new members of its Personal System/2 computer family, and analysts as usual quickly dismissed the machines, saying they were about as exciting as yesterday's oatmeal. But lurking within those computers were new disk-drive technologies that are likely to be increasing important as companies move from big, centralized computer systems toward small clusters of personal computers connected by a network.

title: Map Mixup Increases School Taxes
description: LEAD: VOTERS in the North Salem Central School District this spring are confronting the full effect of a mixup in tax maps that has cost the district more than $1 million in assessments.

title: Correction
description: A review of Frank Freidel's ''Franklin D. Roosevelt: A Rendezvous With Destiny'' on March 4 referred incorrectly to Roosevelt's first political office. He began as a member of the New York State Senate, not the Assembly.

title: Review/Music;   Morton Feldman's Trancelike Tribute to Christian Wolff
description: At the beginning of Morton Feldman's ''For Christian Wolff'' at the Alternative Museum last Sunday afternoon, Nils Vigeland - who played the piano and celesta to Eberhard Blum's flute - invited listeners with other engagements or expired patience to leave at will.

title: Criticism Distorts Nudist Lifestyle
description: The accusations against nude sunbathers made by Oscar W. Ruiz in his letter of Feb. 4 unfairly characterize nudists as a group and serve to distort public perception of the nudist lifestyle.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;

Resale Guarantees Spurring Trade-Ups
description: LEAD: IN the face of a persisting sluggish market, people with equity in their homes who want to move up to a new house are often loath to sign contracts, fearing their own houses will not sell in a slow resale market.

title: Fiscal Woes Force Schools To Anticipate Faculty Cuts
description: TRYING to juggle the rising costs of running their schools with the memory of last spring's battles with the voters, school administrators around the state are planning to cut their budgets by cutting their teaching staffs. As a result, ''hundreds of teachers throughout the state could be laid off this year,'' said Thomas Murphy, assistant executive director of the Connecticut Association of Boards of Education.

title: JUNGLE IS WINNING THE COCAINE WAR
description: In the article by Michael Massing, ''In the Cocaine War, the Jungle is Winning,'' (March 4), there are several insinuations of corruption under my command. Without wishing to enter into a debate, I must clarify certain points. I have always denied, and continue to do so, any allegations of personal corruption. During my nine months in the area, any man found violating regulations, including stealing or taking bribes, was punished. Fourteen officers were tried and punished in 1989.

title: Cycling in Italy
description: To the Editor: Bicyclist Margaret Logan's paean to car-free cities in Italy's Padana district (Travel, Feb. 4) was overdue. Associations to people and places, which, after all, are what travel is about, are so much more meaningful from the vantage point and speed of a bicycle.

title: Court Said to Take California Death Case
description: The state official leading the fight to carry out California's first execution in 23 years said today the Supreme Court had agreed to consider an appeal of a ruling that blocked the death sentence.

title: Heather B. Smith To Marry in June
description: The Rev. and Mrs. Leslie C. Smith of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Heather Bishop Smith to John Millard Kreitler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hobart C. Kreitler of Southport, Conn. A June wedding is planned. Miss Smith, 27 years old, graduated from the University of Vermont and expects to receive a master's degree in social work from Columbia University next year. Her father is the Archdeacon of the Episcopal Diocese of Newark. Her mother, Lois K. Smith, is an artist.

title: BOOKSHELF
description: Additional titles of interest.

title: A 'Liquidator' Shares Secrets of His Trade
description: Lawrence Garfinkle, aka ''Larry the Liquidator,'' is about to make his big speech. It's the one in which the take-no-prisoners takeover artist of Jerry Sterner's hit Wall Street drama, ''Other People's Money,'' reveals his motive: This obese, chain-smoking, doughnut-addicted arbitrageur does what he does not because he loves money, ''and do I love money,'' but because money is one of the few things that gives him ''unconditional acceptance.''

title: Pipeline Leak Imperils Water for Thousands
description: A petroleum pipeline damaged by a landslide sent an eight-mile slick down the Allegheny River today, threatening the water supplies of more than 100,000 people, the authorities said.

title: Rebels Show Strength In 2d Half
description: The Runnin' Rebels of Nevada-Las Vegas, a team that has scuffled and scrambled all season long, won a war of attrition this evening and in the process punctured Georgia Tech's lofty dreams of a national championship.

title: RUNNING A PIGEON UP THE FLAGPOLE
description: IN A FORTHCOMING MEMOIR about his 37 years in advertising, David Herzbrun, a former executive vice president with Saatchi & Saatchi Compton Inc., tells the following story:

title: SUBVERTING POLAND FROM PARIS
description: LEAD:

title: Duke and Las Vegas Gain N.C.A.A. Final
description: Duke defeated Arkansas, 97-83, and Nevada-Las Vegas beat Georgia Tech, 90-81, to advance to the championship game of the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament tomorrow night.

title: Homing In on Pigeon Towers
description: ON the door of the pigeon tower that dominates the front lawn at the Chateau de Vascoeuil in Normandy, there is a sign: ''Please close the door carefully. (Pigeons.)'' This warning is not intended to keep the pigeons inside the pigeon house, but to keep them out. The chateau's small, ornamental flock of white pigeons is confined to the attic, and the main part of the pigeonnier, once a honeycomb of pigeonholes, has been turned into a museum. The Vascoeuil pigeons may be lucky to be allowed any roosting space at all. Pigeon-raising at the chateaus and abbeys of France was abolished along with many other ''manorial rights'' in 1789.

title: Venture Capital Strays Far From Its Roots
description: LEAD: THE BATTLE FOR PRIME COMPUTER WAS ONE OF THOSE grade-B melodramas that enlivened the end-of-the-80's takeover wars last summer. Prime, a foundering minicomputer manufacturer based in Natick, Mass., was struggling to escape the clutches of Bennett S. LeBow, a raider supported by the Michael Milken-Drexel Burnham junk-bond network.

title:
DINING OUT;

In White Plains, It's Pasta for Today
description: LEAD: SITUATED prominently on one of White Plains's busiest streets, La Bella Napoli Pasta House can hardly be called a find. But what is particularly outstanding about this recent arrival is that it specializes in serving up the preferred foods of today - a number of salads, at least two dozen pasta dishes and fresh fruit - at moderate prices and in a dining room fancy enough to make having a meal here a little special.

title: 3 Parties in Romania Joining To Oppose Governing Group
description: Romania's three oldest parties said today that they were forming an alliance to fight the National Salvation Front in the country's first free elections in more than 50 years.

title: APRIL FOOLS' DAY, INTEL-STYLE
description: FOR THE 22,000 EMPLOYEES OF the Intel Corporation, the hottest item on their cafeteria newsstands this week will be an eight-page magazine with a strong resemblance to the National Enquirer. The subject matter is close to home: the workers and operations of Intel, the world's largest manufacturer of microprocessors, based in Santa Clara, Calif. Among the articles: an Elvis sighting at one factory, a U.F.O. sighting at another. But the feature most calculated to draw readers is an advertisement.

title: Team Approach To a Garden
description: To the Editor:

title: Duke to Meet U.N.L.V. in N.C.A.A. Final;   Final Flourish Hurts Arkansas
description: We have been told that this collection of Duke University Blue Devils, a combination of athletes who have endured bitter disappointments in the semifinals of the national collegiate tournament and those who are here for the first time, is to be judged on its merits, unrelated to any emotional baggage from the past. And then there are the quiet but forceful words of Phil Henderson, the Duke senior whose completeness helped push the Blue Devils to a come-from-behind 97-83 national semifinal victory over the Arkansas Razorbacks this afternoon at McNichols Arena.

title: On Second Thought
description: After admitting that he spied for Israel in 1986 and being sentenced to life imprisonment, Jonathan Jay Pollard has changed his mind. The former intelligence analyst for the Navy has asked to withdraw his guilty plea and stand trial, said one of his lawyers, Alan M. Dershowitz. Mr. Dershowitz asserted that Federal prosecutors had made false promises of leniency to persuade Mr. Pollard to admit guilt and help them in their investigation. Mr. Pollard's wife, Anne Henderson Pollard, who pleaded guilty to helping sell secrets to Israel, was released from a New York City halfway house Friday after serving 37 months of two concurrent five-year sentences. A spokesman for the United States Attorney in Washington said the Government would oppose any attempt to overturn Mr. Pollard's plea. At the time of sentencing, Joseph E. diGenova, the United States Attorney for the District of Columbia, said the ''severity of the sentence is the best evidence of the gravity of the damage done to national security by Mr. Pollard's espionage operation.''

title: Review/Jazz;   An Evening Devoted to Vocalese
description: Vocalese - the reproduction of jazz instrumental arrangements with voices - has become a flourishing jazz style thanks largely to Jon Hendricks, the youthful-looking 68-year-old singer and lyricist who on Thursday evening was the host of a Carnegie Hall concert devoted to the genre.

title: Japan
description: To the Editor: We are planning a trip to Japan and want to stay at Tokyo's Palace Hotel. The price for the cheapest room for two published by the Japan National Tourist Organization is $153 (figured at 154 yen to $1). The Palace Hotel is represented by both Utell International and Loew's Representation International, and both have 800 numbers. I called Utell, asked for the cheapest room and was quoted $312. Despite my protest that it was more than double the published price, they stuck by that figure. I subsequently called Loew's and was quoted $179.

title: The Latest Penny-Stock Shuffle
description: Aviation Education Systems of Melville, L.I., sells preparatory courses to would-be air traffic controllers. The Southnet Corporation of Tampa, Fla., is asking hotels to use its telephone operator assistance services. Exten Ventures of San Diego calls itself a merchant banker and collects fees for helping tiny companies become publicly traded. And Executive Telecard of Nanuet, N.Y., is marketing its own international telephone credit card.

title: BRINGING THE BEST OF THE EAST WEST
description: WHILE AMERICAN COMPANIES have been rushing to set up shop behind the Iron Curtain, bringing car phones to Budapest and Big Macs to Moscow, John W. Kiser 3d has been running in the opposite direction.

title: Federally Subsidized Housing at Risk
description: AT a time when homelessness and the shortage of affordable housing are high on the nation's political agenda, lawmakers and housing officials are grappling with the problem of how to prevent steep losses in the federally subsidized apartments built during the 60's and 70's.

Bigler of Reading, Pa. The Rev. Jerome Fasano officiated. Mrs. Bigler, a lawyer at United Engineers and Constructors in Philadelphia, graduated from the University of Virginia, where both she and her husband received J.D. degrees. Mr. Bigler, a graduate of Washington and Lee University, is an associate at the law firm of Richards, Layton & Finger in Wilmington, Del.

title: Israeli Infighting Pre-empts English TV News
description: More than 100,000 native English speakers living here and thousands of tourists who visit regularly were delighted last spring when the Israel Broadcasting Authority announced plans to introduce an evening newscast in English.

title: Dodgers Put Gibson on Disabled List
description: As if spring training wasn't short enough this year, rainstorms fell on the Mets and Los Angeles Dodgers today, wiping out their final meeting of the spring and tightening their countdown to opening day, one week from Monday.

IN THE REGION: New Jersey;

Berkeley Heights, 15 Years in the Future
description: LEAD: AN ambitious land-use plan approved last year by Berkeley Heights has been hailed by its proponents as a way to enliven the downtown area while producing affordable housing.

title: Miss Hirschhorn Planning to Wed
description: The engagement of Carolyn Joy Hirschhorn to Curtis Joseph Schenker, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Schenker of New York, has been announced by the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Hirschhorn of Longmeadow, Mass. A September wedding is planned.

title: 52 Killed as Lebanese Rivals Resume Full Warfare
description: Rival Christian forces pounded East Beirut with artillery fire today after a night of house-to-house fighting under parachute flares for control of Lebanon's Christian enclave.

title: Managing;   The Dark Side of Charisma
description: Good managers are easy to spot. ''Besides intelligence and a knack for strategic planning, they have enormous charm and energy,'' said Robert Hogan, a psychologist at the Tulsa Institute of Behavioral Sciences, who has studied thousands of managers. ''They have charisma.''

title: Question Of the Week;   Should Basketball Use Instant Replay?
description: Unlike football, which grinds to a built-in stop after every play, basketball is designed to keep moving. What with fouls and television timeouts, there are already too many stops and starts, and probably one-fourth to one-half of all the plays are disputed, even if only half-heartedly. Once you start giving them an official method of protesting, the games will never end. The new tenth-of-a-second clock, the main target of instant replay, is a disaster and should be eliminated, because human beings can't react that fast. Why add another needless level of technology to a game that started with peach baskets? Eliminate both.

title: Greenburgh Opens a Fitness Center
description: LEAD: GREENBURGH residents now have a place of their own to work out. Tomorrow, a new town-run fitness center opens at East Rumbrook Park on Dobbs Ferry Road. It is intended for everyone from novice exercisers to top-notch athletes, said Gabriel Gouveia, assistant commissioner of the Department of Parks and

title: Ernest DeMaio, 81, Electric Union Official
description: Ernest DeMaio, a union organizer and former official of the United Electrical and Radio Workers Union, died of brain cancer on Thursday at Norwalk Hospital in Connecticut. He was 81 years old and lived in Norwalk.

title: Surprising Auburn Going After Title
description: Carolyn Jones, the 5-foot-6-inch all-America junior, is the only returning starter from last year's Auburn team, which was runner-up in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: Emigration of Soviet Jews to Israel Is Found to Dip
description: Amid confusion about the status of the air routes by which most Soviet Jewish emigrants get to Israel, a senior Israeli immigration official says the number of arrivals has shown ''a slight decrease'' for the first time since the latest wave of emigration began last year.

title: Cruises
description: To the Editor: Your special cruise issue on Feb. 4 brought back memories of voyages spanning 47 years. It seems that old ships, like old soldiers, never die, but merely fade away (some no longer in service, others refurbished and renamed).

description: Laurie Hodges, the daughter of Mrs. Walter James Hodges of Washington and the late Mr. Hodges, was married yesterday to Pierre Fernand Lapeyre Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lapeyre of New Orleans. The Rev. John F. Myslinski performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Annunciation in Washington.

description: The wedding of Marina Musa Williams, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. George L. Williams of Port Washington, L.I., and Richard Michael Delaney, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward F. Delaney of Hawley, Pa., took place yesterday at the United Church of Christ in Wilmington, Del. The Rev. Neill Richards officiated.

title: Everyone Gives, Everyone Benefits
description: IN THE EYES OF MANY AMERICANS, THE nation's economic prospects look grim. Foreign competitors are clobbering us now, and paving the way toward future dominance. Trade friction with Japan is heating up.

title: Miss Lentz Engaged to Glenn Worgan
description: Mr. and Mrs. Martin Rowe Lentz of Ambler, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Robin M. Lentz to Glenn Simpson Worgan, a son of Joan B. Worgan of Erdenheim, Pa., and John N. Worgan of Philadelphia. A July wedding is planned.

title:
DINING OUT;

American-Continental Mixture at a Club
description: LEAD: COUNTRY clubs are not exactly celebrated for their wonderful food. In many cases the meals are almost institutional. But there is usually a marked improvement in the quality of the meals when a club is open to the public as well as to members. The improvement is not because the clientele is more discriminating, but simply because nonmembers are not driven to eat at the club either by loyalty or food bills that have to be paid regardless.

title: Lola L. Szladits, 20-Year Curator At New York's Library, Dies at 67
description: Lola L. Szladits, the renowned curator of the New York Public Library's Berg Collection of English and American Literature, who expanded the collection to include original manuscripts that ranged from W. B. Yeats to S. J. Perelman and Saul Bellow, died of cancer Friday night at her home in Manhattan. She was 67 years old.

title: Pastimes;   Stamps
description: In a year of stunning headlines capturing the tumult in Eastern Europe, the one three weeks ago in The New York Times was among the more arresting: ''Parliament in Lithuania, 124-0, Declares Nation Independent.''

title: Rostenkowski's Critics Are Wrong
description: Representative Dan Rostenkowski's plan for cutting the deficit has been attacked by nearly everyone except the White House. Critics charge that it contains too much deficit reduction, is unfair and would be bad politics for the Democrats. They're wrong on all counts.

title: New York Is Top Social Club Landlord
description: The city notice posted on the door of the Manhattan storefront said, ''Vacate.'' Still, a sign promised ''good times'' inside the Wanda Social Club, and through the windows, tables and chairs and a bar seemed to await a crowd.
