description: Trees Full of Bachelors

title: Sister Thea Bowman, 52, Worker For Catholic Sharing With Blacks
description: Sister Thea Bowman, a nationally active black educator who with song, prayer and persistent exhortation urged the Roman Catholic Church to embrace the culture of African Americans, died of cancer on Friday at her home in Canton, Miss. She was 52 years old.

title: POSTINGS: Saint Laurent Consolidation;   Smell of Success
description: The Yves Saint Laurent Parfums Corporation, which has undergone several administrative mutations in the last decade, will move many of its production and office operations to an $11 million facility under construction in Orangeburg, N.Y. The move will consolidate operations now scattered in Manhattan, Mount Pocono, Pa., and France.

title:
DANCE;

Audacious Choreography by Feld
description: LEAD: AMONG the many avenues of dance charted by choreographers in the second half of this century, the one created by Eliot Feld assumes the proportions of a superhighway.

title: IN SHORT
description: PLAYING FOR KEEPS: A History of Early Baseball. By Warren Goldstein. (Cornell University, $21.95.) Rich in delicious information, ''Playing for Keeps'' argues that the first years of ''base ball,'' as the sport was known in the 1850's and 60's, established patterns of double thinking that still govern the complaints and yearnings of fans. It may be no surprise that the good old days of fundamental play, team spirit, unselfishness, loyalty and love of the game were already being lamented by 1863. The more it changes the more it stays the same, and as with the New York Mutuals and the Brooklyn Excelsiors, so it shall be with the Orlando Whatevers. To that familiar principle Warren Goldstein, who teaches American studies at the State University of New York at Old Westbury, brings enchantingly detailed accounts of such matters as the 1867 betting scandal and the disruption brought on by players ''revolving'' - jumping from team to team - at about the same period. Irrationally, we still speak of the Red Sox or Yankees as ''clubs'' - meaning an emotional entity that is neither the group of players who rotate on and off the roster nor the corporation that operates the franchise. Mr. Goldstein takes us to the days of true clubs, when the first teams of Manhattan, Brooklyn and New Jersey were fraternal organizations of devoted amateurs. Even their uniforms and team names resembled those of volunteer fire companies. The author shows us how quickly the American desire to win converted the diamond into a workplace and the players into employees. Intense local rivalries led to the hiring of outside players. On that paradoxical model, other dichotomies emerge: we wish to see ballplayers as somehow boyish yet manly, enthusiastic yet ''professional.'' We idealize the sport for its own sake but make winning paramount, and we desire a sport that is a sophisticated city game yet pastoral, local yet national, paternalistic yet managerial, casual yet statistical. Thus our responses to modern strikes and lockouts and contracts reflect ambivalences already present in the ferocious ''fly rule'' debate of the 1860's. (Putting a batsman out by catching his hit on the first bounce was formerly a permitted but less ''manly'' alternative to the stylish, ''professional'' but uncodified catch on the fly.) ''Playing for Keeps'' tells this story with affection, though in the somewhat metallic style of the academic historian. Its calming long perspective should reassure lovers of the game - or business - as we approach new crises and apparent transformations.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Leominster, Mass.;

Big Mall Plan Stirs a Debate
description: LEAD: THIS city of 34,318 people about an hour west of Boston is debating whether to rezone for a new regional mall and add 28 acres of city-owned land to the site on which the developer has options. Among those objecting is the operator of the city's largest existing mall.

title: The Negotiations With Japan Get Personal
description: LIKE squabbling marriage partners, Japan and the United States have tried one idea after another to overcome their differences, falling each time into a new round of recrimination. This year it finally seemed that they had decided to get some meaningful therapy. The trouble is that each country has hired the other to do the psychoanalyzing.

title: The U.S. Stake in Reunification
description: The coming unification of Germany - a virtual certainty in the aftermath of last month's first free Parliamentary election in East Germany - provides the United States with a major opportunity to take commercial advantage of Central Europe's sudden opening to the West.

title: Lloyd Webber: Composer as Industry
description: LEAD: If the devil has all the best tunes, how do we explain the phenomenal success of the British composer Andrew Lloyd Webber? Even today, after eight hit musicals, one failure, one divorce and one requiem to his name, he still looks - well, if not angelic exactly, then rather like a choirboy in long trousers.

title: Campus Life: Miami of Ohio;   Plagiarism Is Rampant, A Survey Finds
description: Students submit plagirized work as their own far more often than might have been suspected, a survey of students here has found.

title: Quick Ways to Turn Out Spicy Shrimp Dishes
description: WHEN I'm in New York City on weekends, I often go down to Chinatown for a dim sum lunch. On the way back, I cannot resist the Chinese fish markets, with their enticing piles of shrimp. They are about as fresh as any I've found in the city, and come in all sizes, heads on or off, and are much cheaper than fish markets further uptown.

title:
FOCUS: Lowell, Mass.;

A Tale of 2 Cities: One Thriving, One Not
description: LEAD: DESPITE a slow economy and soft real estate market, this once depressed mill city turned high-technology superstar has more construction going on now than ever - about $173 million in residential, commercial, infrastructure and cultural projects.

title: POSTINGS: Freddie Mac Rules;   From 28 to 33%
description: Home buyers in four cities may benefit from an easing of rules on the underwriting of loans by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac. And if you live in the New York metropolitan area, which is not covered by the rules change, the advice for applicants is ''bargain.'' Freddie Mac, the Government-chartered company that buys mortgages issued by lenders, says it is easing its rules to aid families that do not usually qualify for mortgages.

description: GORDON LIDDY IS MY MUSE BY TOMMY ''TIP'' PAINE

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Menu;   Leaner Burgers, Stronger Seasonings
description: What makes these burgers better is the ingredients that make them taste like meatloaf. To make them as lean as possible, it is better to grind the turkey and beef at home, using the white meat of the turkey breast and a very lean cut of beef such as eye round. You do not miss the fat because the seasonings make up for it. Because the burgers contain turkey, do not serve them rare to avoid any possibility of salmonella contamination.

title: University Presses: Where the Books Are
description: THESE are turbulent times in book publishing, as longstanding imprints merge or are bought by larger companies. But Cambridge University Press and Columbia University Press, whose distribution operations are in Westchester, continue to produce books under their own imprints, as they have for centuries.

title: Young Americans Fill the Schedule
description: YOUNG American artists set the concert pace this week, starting today at 3 P.M., when the clarinetist Daniel McKelway, a 1989 winner of the Avery Fisher Career Grant Award, closes the ''Castle Concerts'' series at Manhattanville College in Purchase.

title: With Movies Like These, One Never Knows
description: The only easily predictable virtue of the annual New Directors/New Films Festival is that, unless one is some kind of a movie nut with pen pals around the world, one comes upon the film makers and their films in a state of blissful, naked ignorance.

title: Deborah Kroll Is Married To George Henry Weltman
description: The Garden City (L.I.) Hotel was the setting last evening for the marriage of Deborah Jayne Kroll, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome I. Kroll of Manhasset, L.I., to George Henry Weltman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Weltman of Stamford, Conn. Rabbi Charles G. Agin and Cantor Steven Pearlston officiated.

title: Food;   ALL THE WAY HOME
description: I WAS QUITE POSSIBLY THE FIRST GIRL IN my high school to serve fondue. I pushed quiche on skeptical college beaus and blackened fish on a recalcitrant husband. My experiments in sushi and sashimi failed, but my tapas were a hit. And I have spent hours driving through the snow in search of quinoa, jicama and chanterelles at local markets.

They pinned on all their whimsical Kelly buttons, bows, hearts, lips and black baby dolls to celebrate the Mississippi-born designer's life in the world of fashion.

Blair, 28, played for the Edmonton Eskimos and was the C.F.L. rookie of the year in 1987. . . . Manager Cito Gaston of the Toronto Blue Jays said yesterday that Mookie Wilson would be his regular center fielder. ''In the winter I started worrying about the wear and tear of playing Mookie out there every day,'' Gaston said. ''But Mookie's in great shape. He can handle it.'' . . . After more than three weeks of hospitalization with brain cancer and one chemotherapy treatment, Fred Lebow, the 52-year-old director of the New York City Marathon, was released from Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan yesterday.(AP)

On Thursday night at Roulette, the two men presented an hourlong work of Mr. Maroney's called ''Piano-ology/Music of the Spheres.''

description: BASEBALL

title: Debbie Reynolds Re-Creates 'Molly'
description: JUST before the final curtain of ''The Unsinkable Molly Brown,'' at the Shubert Performing Arts Center in New Haven, Debbie Reynolds, as a high society dropout returning to her ragamuffin's roots in the Rocky Mountains, wistfully sings a reprise of ''My Own Brass Bed.'' Her steady, pure sound, uncluttered by show business hard sell, is true to character and situation. It transports us as well to the time she was a winsome ingenue, on screen with Gene Kelly and Donald O'Connor. (Videotapes of ''Singin' in the Rain'' and audio cassettes from the soundtrack are being sold in the lobby.) Miss Reynolds, who has had more than a 40-year career as a performer (copies of her memoirs are being sold in the lobby), has chosen to do her most genuine, affecting work, almost three hours after the overture. This handy example of saving the best for the last might be explained by the packagers or the director of this production, which has been on tour for a year.

title: FOR A TAX BREAK, GIFTS IN KIND
description: WHEN ASHTON-TATE'S SOFTWARE sales turn soft, or woolens begin piling up in Lane Bryant's warehouse, the companies often donate some portion of their bloated inventories to charity - and reap a substantial tax write-off. Helping them give, and get, is a small but growing band of nonprofit companies that serve as middlemen, channeling hundreds of millions of dollars in gifts in kind from manufacturer to needy recipient.

title: HARNONCOURT'S MOZART SHOWS STEADY GROWTH
description: Ordinarily, American music lovers are able to keep abreast of successful European performers through their recordings, even if American opera companies and orchestras are slow to engage them. In the case of Nikolaus Harnoncourt's conducting of Mozart operas, that familiarity has been impeded by recent distribution problems of his record company. Throughout the 1980's, Mr. Harnoncourt has been recording Mozart stage works as part of a project to tape all of them by the mid-1990's. His West German record company, Teldec, has been faithfully releasing them. But their availability in this country has been erratic at best.

title: Psychologist Charts Hidden Attitudes
description: EVEN people who do not think they are sexists may unconsciously display a preference for males, says Dr. Mahzarin Banaji, an assistant professor of psychology at Yale University. A study by Dr. Banaji and Dr. Anthony Greenwald of the University of Washington also found that people who openly disagree about sexual equality may agree about the issue on an unconscious level.

title: Cuban-American Takes Aim at Castro, on TV
description: Using the infant medium of television to stunning political effect, a young Fidel Castro dominated the airwaves in 1960 seeking to rally supporters to his new rule.

title: Beauty;   STAYING FIRM
description: THEY DEFY GRAVITY. THEY ENCROACH on plastic surgeons. They bring muscle beach to the boudoir. Firming creams are the latest lure from the cosmetics industry, and their range is ambitious. They promise to transform eyelids, throat, bust, thighs and buttocks into expanses as bright and resilient as a trampoline.

title: 'The Aftermath': A Film's Real-Life Lesson on Drunken Driving
description: FRAYDUN MANOCHERIAN cannot forget two of his White Plains High School classmates who were killed by a drunk driver nearly four decades ago. The driver received a mere ''slap on the wrist'' as punishment, said Mr. Manocherian, a real estate entrepreneur and the president and founder of the New York Health and Racquet Club of Manhattan.

title: Carolyn J. Grant Weds J. R. Pardy
description: Carolyn Jaimie Grant, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene M. Grant of Mamaroneck, N.Y., was married last evening at her parents' home to J. Rodney Pardy, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James V. Pardy of Boulder, Colo.

title: The High Cost of Selling Art
description: For as long as they have bought works of art, American museums have also sold them. The practice, known as deaccessioning, is hardly new. Neither is the debate it provokes, a debate invigorated by a spate of sales in the last few years of works by artists from Delacroix to Picasso, Boucher to Church.

title: Risk Seen in Use Of Caller ID Service
description: I am compelled to write regarding my professional and personal concerns surrounding the use of Caller ID service in New Jersey (''Caller ID Stirs Debate on Phone Privacy,'' Feb. 11). There is no doubt in my mind that my staff and volunteers are placed at personal risk by the widespread use of such a service.

title: All Soccer's Roads Lead To Rome
description: THE Eldorado for all soccer fans will stretch from the Italian Alps to Sicily from June 8 to July 8, so those who don't care for the world's most popular spectator sport might prefer to choose some other time to make that long-planned trip to Italy. The monthlong competition for the World Cup will involve teams from 24 countries, including a poor-relations squad from the United States. They will compete for the cup in 52 matches in Milan, Florence, Rome, Naples, Palermo, Bari, Bologna, Cagliari, Genoa, Turin, Udine and Verona.

description: International/3-19

description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months. Recordings are available on CD, LP and cassette unless otherwise noted.

title: Review/Theater;   A Winner's Lot After the Lottery, in English and Spanish
description: This appears to be the silly season for the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater, which has put at the top of its 1990 roster Fred Valle's new play, ''I Am a Winner.'' In performance this farce gives the impression of an improvisation by actors who occasionally forget to stay in character as they develop the wholly unbelievable story. But there has to be a script: on one evening recently an actor was visibly embarrassed when he missed a line and the entire audience could hear a prompter calling it out.

title: 'The Journalist and the Murderer'
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT
description: PROPHET OF THE SANDLOTS: Journeys With a Major League Scout. By Mark Winegardner. (Atlantic Monthly, $18.95.) It's easy to spot a superstar after he has become one. The trick is to see the makings of a Mike Schmidt or a Ferguson Jenkins in an unformed adolescent. The baseball scout Tony Lucadello had just such a gift, signing 49 future big leaguers in the course of his 50-year career with the Chicago Cubs and the Philadelphia Phillies. Schmidt and Jenkins were his most notable proteges on an honor roll that also included the pitcher Jim Brosnan, the 1970 American League batting champion Alex Johnson and the 1974 Cy Young Award-winning relief pitcher Mike Marshall. Mark Winegardner, the author of ''Elvis Presley Boulevard,'' accompanied Lucadello on his rounds through the Midwest's college and high school sandlots in what sadly turned out to be the veteran scout's last season. As they drove from game to game, Lucadello's chatter revealed a gentle but wily character who courted young players and their families with the utmost sincerity, but who also could crow with pleasure when he recalled how a dab of tear-inducing onion juice helped him persuade a reluctant Dick Drott to sign a pitching contract for $96,000 less than several other teams offered. Describing how he went about sighting talent, Lucadello could sound like a sage: ''It's easy to talk yourself out of a ball player, but the most important thing about scouting is being able to project what a player will be able to do.'' Mr. Winegardner's engaging portrait of a scout's life is at its best when he simply allows Lucadello to talk - his voice is so distinctive that the author's travelogue and personal asides cannot help suffering by comparison. But the author's assessment of the Phillies' decision to cut the team's - and Lucadello's - already tight player development budget a few months before the scout's death in May 1989 is sadly on the mark: ''Good plan, fellows. Enjoy your stay in the cellar.''

title: 'A COMMUNIST TO THE MARROW OF MY BONES'
description: MEMOIRS

title: MOMA's BOY
description: As a 44-year-old downtown ''old guard'' (new category?) visitor to MOMA, I too am dismayed by the ''mallization'' of the museum (''MOMA's Boy,'' by William Grimes, March 11), but my concern is exacerbated when I read of Mr. Varnedoe's intentions for the Brancusi sculptures. In trying to establish his middle ground on culture, he is going to destroy the essential element of quiet space around the sculptures.

title: Till Final Buzzer, UConn's Glory Lit the State
description: LEAD: JUST days after his basketball team had been catapulted out of the national spotlight, Steve Pikiell was back on the University of Connecticut campus in Storrs last week. He wasn't thrilled to be there. The Year of the Huskies was over. The last page had been ripped out of UConn's storybook season last Saturday when the team was defeated by Duke, 79-78 in overtime, in the N.C.A.A.

title: Snipers in Honduras Wound 6 U.S. Troops
description: Snipers opened fire on United States Air Force personnel in Honduras today, wounding at least six, officials said.

title: Scholarship Yields A New Caligula, Who Is Merely Obnoxious
description: IN the popular imagination, Caligula is the Roman emperor people love to hate. In works as ancient as the historian Suetonius's biography of the tyrant, which dates to the early second century A.D., and as recent as the lurid 1980 movie, ''Caligula,'' the emperor has been used to epitomize depravity and cruelty in Rome.

title: Campus Life: St. Lawrence;   A Gift of Books To Replace Those Lost in Romania
description: As the Romanian Government fell last December, so did the Central University Library in Bucharest, burned to the ground by Nicolae Ceausescu's personal army.

title:
THEATER;

King Lear as a Modern Tyrant
description: LEAD: The arrival of the Georgian Rustaveli Theater at the Brooklyn Academy of Music for five performances of ''King Lear'' marks the American debut of the Tbilisi-based company that in recent years has gained international renown for its brilliant interpretations of Brecht and Shakespeare. The play, to be performed in Georgian with simultaneous English synopsis available, will be presented tomorrow through next Sunday at the Majestic Theater on Fulton Street.

title: Review/Opera;   A Mozart Tenor, Stepping Forward
description: Except for Kurt Moll's sonorous but bland Osmin and Nico Castel's noble Pasha Selim, the cast for the Metropolitan Opera's performance of Mozart's ''Entfuhrung aus dem Serail'' on Tuesday night was entirely different from earlier this season. Yet the sense of ensemble and shared musical accomplishment was, if anything, greater than before.

title: The Burmese Are Going to Vote; the Army Tells Them To
description: THEY'RE going to hold an election in Myanmar, formerly Burma, but the guest list is a short one. Even some of the candidates aren't invited.

title: The Charity Case
description: When I was a boy in my teens, I spent several months in a New York City hospital as a charity case.

title: Social Events
description: Remembering Willi Smith

title: THE WORLD: A Voice From Latin America;   Some Lessons In Democracy - For the U.S.
description: IN the United States there has been much talk about increasing credits, investment and aid to Eastern Europe at the expense of money destined for Latin America. The aim is to help emerging capitalism and democracy where socialism has failed. But from a cynical Latin perspective, this South-to-East shift constitutes a transfer of resources from where capitalism has failed to where socialism has failed.

title: Disney World
description: To the Editor: I noted with great interest that at Roger Rabbit's Hollywood, to be built by Disney-MGM Studios in Florida in the mid-1990's (Travel Advisory, Feb. 11), visitors will, among other activities, ''careen in an overaged Baby Herman's baby buggy through a Toontown hospital.''

title: Driving Abroad
description: To the Editor: My husband and I are shipping our camper to Europe for a trip around the world. Having traveled by camper for a year through the Middle East and Asia, we are aware that a carnet de passage, a passport for the vehicle and a guarantee that it will not be sold or otherwise abandoned, is required by many countries. The carnet de passage used to be available from the American Automobile Association, but now there does not seem to be any place in the United States to obtain it. We tried several embassies of countries that require carnets de passage, but all we were told was that, yes, it was needed; no one could tell use where to get one. We are hoping that once we arrive in the Netherlands (where it is not required) we will be able to obtain a carnet de passage from the automobile club of some other European country before we continue to Asia.

title: Mary Mower Weds Timothy Mitchell
description: Mary Kennard Mower and Timothy Papin Mitchell were married yesterday in New York in the garden of the bride's home by the Rev. John Ivey Jessup 3d. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. Robert T. Hensley Jr. of St. Louis and Edward Baldridge Mower Jr., also of St. Louis. The bridegroom is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Samuel West Mitchell of St. Louis.

title: Style Makers;   Renate Burstein, Wedding Newsletter Publisher
description: Renate Burstein is the publisher of some of the world's smallest-circulation newspapers. Ms. Burstein uses a desktop computer to produce two to eight pages of news about brides and grooms on their wedding day. The special-edition newspapers include articles about how they met, baby pictures, the menu, the guest list and a family tree. ''Anything the couple wants,'' Ms. Burstein said. Some of her clients read the newspapers hot off the press at the reception, while others give them to guests. She can also publish a paper to be sent to guests after the wedding.

title:
BASEBALL;

ON DECK: ISSAC NEWTON
description: LEAD:

title: IN SHORT
description: TWO SPECTACULAR SEASONS. 1930: The Year the Hitters Ran Wild; 1968: The Year the Pitchers Took Revenge. By William B. Mead. (Macmillan, $18.95.) This is a genial, well-researched barroom argument - or, rather, discussion - about hitting versus pitching, old-timers versus new(er)-timers. The ''Two Spectacular Seasons'' in question are 1930, the best hitters' year in major league history, and 1968, when pitchers like Bob Gibson, Don Drysdale and Juan Marichal forced baseball to make drastic changes (such as lowering the pitcher's mound) to keep the .300 hitter from going the way of the dodo. William B. Mead, the author of ''The Official New York Yankees Hater's Handbook,'' does not allow the stars of 1930 to get away with misty-eyed accounts of why their game was superior. He also does not haul out sheets of mystical new statistics to explain the ascendancy of pitching in the late 60's. Rather, ''Two Spectacular Seasons'' tosses all the arguments, numbers and theories into one fascinating jumble, then sorts them out chronologically so the reader can follow, one subtle step at a time, the progression from 1930, when nine major league clubs hit .300 or better, to 1968, when only six hitters topped .300 (Carl Yastrzemski's American League-leading .301 in 1968 - the lowest championship average ever - was two points lower than the National League average of 1930). Conversely, the great Lefty Grove's 2.54 earned run average in 1930 would have left him in the wake of such trivia-book fodder as Detroit's John Hiller (2.30) and Baltimore's Jim Hardin (2.51) in 1968. Fans looking for the one big reason for the decline in hitting can pick from: the increasing number of huge, better-conditioned athletes who can throw over 90 miles per hour; the growing sophistication in the use of bullpens; the increase in lower visibility (for hitters) in night games; coast-to-coast travel; the replacement of hitters' parks with streamlined pitchers' parks such as those in Los Angeles and Houston - as Satchel Paige used to say, you pays your money and you makes your choice.

title: A New Attraction in South Norwalk
description: SOUTH NORWALK'S restaurant row, in the area known as SoNo - Washington Street between Main and Water Streets - has gained a new attraction. It is the Old Rialto, formerly the Atlantic Club, which changed its chef and menu as well as its name. The fin de siecle building was once a theater, but the Old Rialto decor is more high seas than high C's. Ship figureheads point proudly at the bar, and pictures of sailing vessels line the dark-green walls. One end wall is exposed brick, adding another, lighter look to the high-ceilinged room.

title:
ART;

Drawing Moral Lessons From Nature
description: LEAD: THE traditional bestiary is more than a simple compendium or catalogue of animal types. It also has allegorical overtones, inviting us to draw moral lessons from the natural world, especially regarding the relationship of beasts to humans.

title: Forces Behind the Golf Swing: Teachers Find a Niche
description: When Ben Hogan built what is generally considered the most reliable swing in history by thickening his callouses every day in a divot-filled cocoon, he influenced a generation of golfers to trust that the things we know best are the things that are learned, not taught.

title: Peter Clare, Banker, Weds Teresa McEnroe, a Nurse
description: Teresa Marie McEnroe, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James E. McEnroe of Towson, Md., was married there yesterday at the Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Church to Peter John Clare, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Clare 3d of Manhasset, L.I. The Rev. J. Bruce Jarboe officiated.

title: The Ritual of Spring Changes for Guidry
description: When he played, Ron Guidry sat in the same locker every spring, the one next to the showers and the whirlpool, near the coffee machine and Coke dispenser and about as close to the center of the Yankee clubhouse as you could get.

title: YAZ INDEED!
description: YAZ

title: Rangers Survive a Crazy Division
description: ''The Patrick Division is completely nuts, and it has been all season,'' Roger Neilson, the coach of the Rangers, said last Tuesday night in the hours after he and his team had clinched first place and thus been granted the freedom to watch the madness safely work its way to a conclusion.

title: Silent Forests, Lonely Shores in Maine
description: THE name Acadia National Park summons up images of silent spruce forests as cool and dim as Gothic churches, stark white lighthouses clinging to granite headlands and blue vistas out to chill, island-studded bays - a rockbound, Northern antidote to sweltering summers. Unfortunately, many of the 4.5 million visitors who made the trip Down East last year remember a different Acadia: the park loop road clogged with traffic, tourists jostling for views (and parking) at scenic turnouts, beaches and nature walks on which humans far outnumbered wildlife.

title: Evening Hours;   In a Mansion And on a Stage, Charity Dining
description: A hundred guests were invited to a dinner last Monday in the salons of the turn-of-the-century Burden mansion on East 90th Street. Each guest was asked to contribute ''as much as you feel you can'' to the Love to Learn Scholarship, for four students in the visual and culinary arts. The winners, Luahn and Curtis Smith of the Culinary Institute of America and Amy Freeth and Robert Padro of Parsons School of Design, stood on the receiving line with the four hosts, Bill Blass, Pat Buckley, Wolfgang Flottl and Aileen Mehle . The old-fashioned church supper was put together by the food writer Gene Hovis and served in a Venetian garden setting by the decorator John Funt.

title: Mutual Funds;   Betting on the 'Green' Group
description: Spinning gold from garbage is the alchemy of the 1990's. That's the clear message from money managers, who are beginning to bet heavily on the environmental services sector. ''Cleaning up our polluted planet will be the growth industry of the 90's,'' said Donavon McKerchar, portfolio manager of Oppenheimer's Global Environmental Fund, launched last month.

Weiss, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Weiss of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., have been announced by her parents, Phyllis Golden-Gottlieb and Jason Gottlieb of Los Angeles. I think the furniture needs to be cleaned, but am not sure how to do so. Would soap and water hurt?

title: Where the Real Nations Are in the Center of Europe
description: AS Communism recedes, longstanding ethnic rivalries remain to haunt Eastern Europe. The region is dotted with minorities, from the tiny population of Sorbs, a Slavic people, in East Germany to the Turks who make up 10 percent of the population of Bulgaria. Old hostilities are still being played out, like the rivalry of Hungarians and Romanians for ownership of Transylvania. In some cases, however, efforts are being made to heal old wounds, as President Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia recently tried to do with conciliatory statements about the expulsion after World War II of 3.25 million ethnic Germans from the Sudetenland. Yugoslavia and Czechoslovakia have never been homogeneous nations at all; rather, they are combinations of distinct groups trying to share the same country. In Czechoslovakia, ethnic differences were played down during the four decades of cold war, but in Bulgaria and Romania the rigid Communist regimes suppressed ethnic minorities as official policy. Now, with the lid lifted in Eastern Europe, the ancient divisions are being given free expression and have become more evident than at any time since World War II. The re-emergence poses a challenge for the post-Communist republics: Can they accommodate the rivalries, keep the peace and build democracy?

title: Tina's World: In Search of the Honest Moment
description: One of the dozen pictures in the current Museum of Modern Art exhibition of Tina Barney's photographs shows a backyard barbecue in progress. Two tanned and handsome college-age boys, wearing shorts and holding drinks, flank an outdoor grill. Between them is a thin, attractive woman in her 40's who is addressing them with one hand while squeezing a rubber bulb with the other. The scene is suffused with the glow of yellow sunlight.

description: We are from the Atlantic Coast Conference. We play basketball banking on brains as much as on brawn. We deserved to be in the Final Four for a fourth time in five years. We're Duke. Thanks, Arkansas.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Fathers Share the Nurturing Role
description: LEAD: A FEW days ago, a young father skillfully placed his baby on my examining table and undressed him at the two-week visit at my office. After I finished my examination, the father dressed the infant and cuddled him in his arms. Then he sat down next to his wife while we discussed the baby's progress since birth.

description: Nothing very special had been expected in Madrid of the Velazquez exhibition that opened at the Prado on Jan. 23 and came to an end last night. Velazquez is not, after all, an unknown quantity in Madrid. Many of the paintings in the show had been in the Prado since the museum first opened in 1819. They can be seen any time, and at leisure. Furthermore, the Prado has never been in the business of selling itself.

We drove past fields of ponderous Herefords, past roadside stores that sold mountain honey and Elvis rugs. We followed Quaker Run until the blacktop turned to gravel, and we bounced over Chapman Mountain on a rutted road, which gradually dropped toward the sound of cold, rushing water.

title: Style;   VREELAND'S TOUCHES
description: If, as the art historian Mario Praz wrote, ''the surroundings become a museum of the soul,'' then a glimpse at Diana Vreeland's Park Avenue apartment is a reflection of the style and personality of one of this century's legendary taste makers. It wasn't a big apartment - life centered on a well-proportioned living room and small dining area - but it exuded bigness. Many of the pieces that made it that way will be auctioned at an estate sale at Sotheby's on April 19.

description: I CONFESS TO BEING ONE OF THE fortunate - suburban childhood, Ivy League college, graduate school, 15 years of steady promotions in international banking. Not that all this matters much as I sit in my small weekend house with the walls closing in on me. I am unemployed.

description: Mrs. Blake Edward Vance of San Diego and Colin Eggleston Smith of Berkeley, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Wheelwright Smith, to William Renn Klein, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Thompson Klein of Locust Valley, L.I. A July wedding is planned.

title: Off the Street
description: For the past 20 years, James Graseck has played classical violin in the oddest yet, for New Yorkers, most familiar places: the city's streets and subways. Then last week he performed solo at Alice Tully Hall, renting it for $5,000, and the 1,000-seat house was nearly sold out at $16 a head. The evening of Paganini, Schubert and Bach was ''a dream come true,'' Mr. Graseck said. Although he broke even, Mr. Graseck said his street performances generate an income ''commensurate with other musicians'.'' The 37-year-old violinist, who received a master's from Juilliard in 1974, also performs with Music Under New York, a subway music program. His favorite locations are the main hall in Grand Central Terminal, downstairs at Penn Station and the 53d Street and Fifth Avenue subway station - all acoustical gems. Oldies requested include Vivaldi's ''Four Seasons'' and Mozart's ''Eine Kleine Nachtmuzik'' as well as ''The Devil Went Down to Georgia,'' a country-Western classic.

title: Texts of Gorbachev's Statements to Lithuanians
description: Following are the texts of statements made yesterday by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union to the Lithuanian people and to the Lithuanian Parliament. The statements, as distributed in translation by Tass, the official Soviet press agency, were read by announcers on Radio Moscow and on the Soviet television.

title: IN SHORT
description: BIG STICKS: The Batting Revolution of the Twenties. By William Curran. (Morrow, $18.95.) William Curran, the author of ''Mitts,'' gives us a detailed and lively history of baseball in the 1920's, with chapters on Babe Ruth, Rogers Hornsby, John J. McGraw, Ty Cobb, the Chicago Cubs and the 1927 Yankees' ''Murderers' Row.'' His focus is the ''batting revolution'' that, he argues, transformed the ''scientific'' game of the 1910's into the power game of the 20's. Previously, teams struggled to score a run at a time as batters choked up on the bat to gain enough control to push the ball over the infielders' heads. In the power game, batters were encouraged to swing from the heels and, to quote one of Mr. Curran's colorful but somewhat misplaced metaphors, ''runs scored by the half dozen and base hits showered the still-new steel-and-concrete ball parks like cherry blossoms in a high wind.'' Batting averages rose an average of 40 points from 1918 to 1925. More remarkable was the increase in home runs. In 1917, Babe Ruth tied for the league lead in home runs with nine; the league record was 16. In 1919, Ruth hit 29 homers in 130 games; in 1920, he hit 54. The only losers were the pitchers, whose collective earned run average ballooned from 2.68 in 1917 to 4.33 in 1925. The hitting revolution was abetted by new rules that restricted and then prohibited trick pitches like the spitter. The so-called rabbit ball, which is usually identified as a primary cause of the hitter's ascendancy, had nothing to do it; Mr. Curran takes a full chapter to dispute angrily the theory that the owners imported a ''live'' ball to increase home run production. Mr. Curran writes well, but not well enough to hold the interest of the general reader. However, for those who thrive on stories, statistics and descriptions of past batting heroes, pennant races and World Series, ''Big Sticks'' may prove irresistible.

title: At 64, a Composer-Lyricist Nurtures Young Talent
description: ''I WRITE nonsense songs, too,'' Francis (Ranny) Reeve said, looking up from his host's piano after playing two operas of his that might have bewildered an audience that hadn't spent 49 years trying to play the piano only properly.

title: Question Of the Week;   Should Basketball Use Instant Replay?
description: Basketball thrives on its quickness and constant excitement, and using the instant replay would only be unwelcome interruption. N.B.A. games are already too long now. Basketball should trust its referees and let them make the final call. Save the replay for football.

title: Spain's Savory Suckling Pig
description: WHEN Don Quixote and Sancho Panza come upon a wedding feast in the Castilian countryside, the first thing they see is a huge steer on a spit, stuffed with ''twelve little suckling pigs embowelled, to give it the more savory taste.'' Today, roast suckling pig - cochinillo asado - plays as prominent a role in Castilian Spanish cuisine as it did in Cervantes's day, but not as support for a steer; it is in itself a star attraction.

title: LEARNING JAPANESE THE SONY WAY
description: THE SONY CORPORATION learned the hard way with Betamax, its ground-breaking videocassette recorder that was ultimately knocked out of the market by the rival VHS technology. The lesson: when you bring out the hardware, make sure the software comes right along with it. Consider Sony's Repeat Learning System, a package of foreign-language audio aids developed for Japanese traveling in the United States. An English-to-Japanese version of the program was introduced here last year to capitalize on the increasing number of American executives doing business in and around the Pacific Rim.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Dinner;   For Country or Organic, Or for People-Watching
description: This is a summary of reviews of Manhattan restaurants by Bryan Miller that have appeared in The New York Times. Ratings are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have ratings. Prices are current.

title: Consumer Affairs Unit Toughening Up
description: AFTER years of accusations that it was more interested in quieting consumers than in protecting them, the New Jersey Division of Consumer Affairs appears to be responding more forcefully to complaints about businesses - and about itself.

title: A Role for Records? Purists Say: 'Yes. Just Listen.'
description: Michael Heth says customers walking into his hi-fi store in this affluent San Francisco suburb are often shocked.

title: U.S. Debates Aiding Burmese in Drug Fight
description: With nearly half the world's opium now being grown in Myanmar, formerly Burma, and increasing amounts of Southeast Asian heroin going to the United States, a squabble has broken out between the State Department and the Drug Enforcement Administration over whether to renew ties and financing to the Burmese military Government, Western diplomats and law-enforcement authorities say.

title: Rock at the Wop-Boppa-Lu-Bop Crossroads
description: ''Keep the spirit, but don't go to such extremes,'' Little Richard was told by his producers during a mid-50's recording session. That advice had the effect of goading the singer into the frenzied performance of ''Good Golly Miss Molly'' that was released as a single and became one of his biggest hits.

title: Review/Dance;   Fleeting Action in a Victorian Parlor
description: Danial Shapiro and Joanie Smith took five giant, dowdy footstools, placed them strategically about the stage and built an exuberant and surprisingly poignant dance around them in ''Rhapsody,'' a new work presented by the Second Avenue Dance Company/90 on Thursday at the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University.

title: IN SPRING, THOUGHTS OF FALL
description: It's a long, long way from now to September, but I cannot put thoughts of fall fishing in the Roach River out of my mind.

title: Dream Town, Short on Land and People, Finds Time Fleeting, Too
description: Welcome to Islandia, South Florida's ultimate dream city: no street crime, no drugs, no pollution, no traffic.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: LOST IN TRANSLATION: A Life in a New Language, by Eva Hoffman. (Penguin, $7.95.) Forced to leave Poland for Vancouver, British Columbia, in 1959, Eva Hoffman learned what it was like to carve out a space inside a new linguistic universe. This memoir ''tells the story of how one more immigrant came to love her adoptive country (and its slangy, elastic, exuberant language),'' Peter Conrad said here last year. ''To all of us, childhood looks like a paradise lost, and every reader will be able to substitute his or her loved, irrevocable places for Eva Hoffman's Cracow.''

title: Melissa Seide Is Wed To Andrew K. Rubin
description: Melissa Anne Seide, the daughter of Lewis Seide of Rye Brook, N.Y., and Illona Saudi of Flushing, Queens, was married last evening to Andrew Kevin Rubin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leslie Rubin of Trumbull, Conn. Rabbi Jerome Wallin performed the ceremony at Temple Agudath Shalom in Stamford, Conn.

title: SWORDS WITH THE SPIRIT OF THE SAMURAI
description: Gleaming swords austerely displayed as functional sculpture in ''Court and Samurai in an Age of Transition,'' at Japan Society Gallery, 333 East 47th Street, may summon in viewers complex feelings of admiration for their beauty and repugnance for their bloody 700-year history. The 23 medieval blades, on loan from the Gotoh Museum of Tokyo through next Sunday, include extraordinary examples of crafting.

title: A Lisztian Treasure Comes Into Its Own
description: The great composers of Italy honored their poetical classics - Dante, Ariosto, Petrarch, Tasso - but tended not to set their words to music. They must all have known Petrarch's sonnets to Laura from childhood, but it was Franz Liszt who made three of them into magnificent songs. He set them in 1839, shortly before making some tours with the tenor Giovanni Rubini.

title: 'Born on the 4th of July' and the Birth of My Political Campaign
description: LEAD: MASSAPEQUA'S Ronnie Kovic has decided not to run for United States Congress. The paraplegic author of ''Born on the Fourth of July'' and Academy Award nominee for the movie's screenplay took himself out of consideration for a run in California, where he now lives. That's too bad. I wanted to work on his campaign.

title: Better Students: Parents at Fault Too
description: In reference to Professor Power's article [''Remedial School: Paying the Piper,'' Opinion, March 11] , I have to agree that some students are ill prepared for college work. But as Professor Powers points to the school districts as culprits, I would go one step further.

title:
THE NATION;

Force of Mormon Faithful Is Felt in Politics
description: LEAD: THE Mormon Church works in mysterious ways - mysterious, at least, to those unfamiliar with the faith. But it works nonetheless as a strong political influence in much of the West, as the abortion debate in Idaho has shown.

title: Judging Design By Little Things
description: For years now, I have thought that cars ought to be rated on the basis of their ashtrays.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: April 1, 1990

A new regimen for weight loss. 6* 1 THE T--FACTOR FAT GRAM COUNTER, by Jamie Pope-Cordle and Martin Katahan. (Norton, $2.50.) Ways to reduce fat in one's diet.

title: IN SHORT
description: NOW PITCHING BOB FELLER. By Bob Feller with Bill Gilbert. (Birch Lane/Carol Publishing, $18.95.) Freckle-faced boys in short pants routinely came up after games to ask Bob Feller, ''What's it like to be a real baseball player?'' Mr. Feller, now 71 years old and still a spring training coach for the Cleveland Indians and a player in old-timers' games, answers for all baseball buffs. His earnest autobiography, ''Now Pitching Bob Feller,'' is full of immense respect for the game. The book, written with Bill Gilbert, who wrote ''The Duke of Flatbush'' with Duke Snider, compares past times with the present, and Mr. Feller dutifully sticks in thoughts on current salaries, free agency and artifical turf (none of which he much likes). But best are the descriptions, inning by inning, of his prowess and problems on the mound for the Indians, the team for which he pitched from 1936 through 1955, with four seasons lost while he served in the Navy during World War II. He first pitched in an exhibition game in 1936, at the age of 17, before he started shaving and before his senior year in high school in his native Van Meter, Iowa. In his debut, his fast pitch, often wild, so frightened Leo Durocher, the shortstop of the St. Louis Cardinals, that the batter bolted off the field after two called strikes. That fastball earned Mr. Feller the nickname ''Rapid Robert''; he pitched no-hitters in 1940, 1946 and 1951, led the league in wins for six seasons and was elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1962. But one dream was denied him: to win a World Series game. Poignancy permeates Mr. Feller's recollections of two games lost in the 1948 series, which the Indians took from the Boston Braves. He was benched in the 1954 series, which the New York Giants took in four straight games. ''I wanted to win a World Series game. . . . I've never been quite sure why [Cleveland manager Al] Lopez didn't use me in that series. . . . I've never asked him myself.'' Mr. Feller found consolation quickly. He planned to take his boys fishing the day after the series. ''What time do we leave tomorrow?'' one asked. ''At times like that,'' Mr. Feller concludes, ''a young son is a good thing for a man to have.''

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Warning on Soviet Crime

title: Style Makers;   Roger Gorman, Album Designer
description: Roger Gorman, a Manhattan-based art director, won the Grammy Award for Best Album Design this year with his innovative boxed presentation of David Bowie's ''Sound+Vision.''

title: BUFFET TAKES STOCK
description: HE ALWAYS EXPECTED THAT HE would one day be rich, Warren E. Buffett says, although it is doubtful that the man now known as the Oracle of Omaha had any inkling of just how rich he would actually become. Last year, Forbes Magazine estimated his personal fortune to be in excess of $4 billion. With Berkshire Hathaway, a one-time textile manufacturer, as his vehicle, Buffett at age 59 has achieved an enviable standing in the world of finance. Laurence A. Tisch, the chairman of Loews Corporation and president of CBS, and himself no slouch in these matters, says that Buffett has had ''the most brilliant career in American investment history.''

title: Stunt Kite Flying: Dancing in the Air
description: ON a recent Sunday afternoon, Brian Vanderslice went ''flying,'' as he puts it. During the week he fixes fax machines, typewriters and copiers, but on weekends he flies stunt kites.

title: Spira Persistent, Puzzling
description: It takes a while for his favorite high school teacher to come up with the exact adjective to describe her former student. ''I'm a math teacher,'' she explains, ''and I like to be precise.'' Finally it comes to her: ''Tenacious.''

title: Teacher Ignites Lifetime Love for Words
description: JUDITH DOBBROW'S first graders at Head O'Meadow Elementary School in Newtown have no reading textbooks, no reading workbooks, no practice sheets on skills like sounding out letters. Nonetheless, the children read and write with enthusiasm and score well on standardized tests, their teacher says.

title: Ohio Valley of Tears Is Facing More
description: Fifteen years ago more than 60,000 people worked in the coal mines and the steel, glass, pottery and paper plants that lined the banks of the Ohio River just south of Wheeling, W.Va. Today fewer than 30,000 are employed there.

title: Special Today: The Business World/Magazine Pt.2
description: Warren Buffett, America's premier investor, tells how he does it.

title: Nicklaus Powers Himself Into Lead
description: Jack Nicklaus rose to the occasion of his much-awaited first senior tournament today by becoming the conquering power golfer of his youth. Against a field of more than 50 golfers, it was no contest.

title: William Van Orden, Statue's Protector, 67
description: William Van Orden, a part-time sculptor who devoted the last part of his life to the defense and restoration of a statue of the actress Myrna Loy, died of cancer on March 18 at the Country Villa Westwood nursing home in West Los Angeles. He was 67 years old and lived in Venice, Calif.

title: New York's Public Hospitals Seek More Fiscal Autonomy From City
description: New York City's financially strained public hospital system is pressing to gain more fiscal autonomy from the city government, and officials of the Dinkins administration say they are reviewing the idea with an open mind.

title: Audubon Theater
description: To the Editor:

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: >Karaoke Crooning

title: Tax Protesters Battle Police in London
description: A huge rally protesting a new tax turned into a riot in central London tonight as demonstrators battled the mounted police with rocks, bottles and stones.

title: Lori Schwartz, Buyer, Wed To Kirk Palmer, Recruiter
description: The Harvard Club in New York was the setting yesterday evening for the wedding of Lori Ann Schwartz, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Schwartz of Manhasset, L.I., to Kirk Palmer, a son of Muriel Yarger of Orange, Calif. and Joseph Palmer of Lawton, Okla. Rabbi Charles Lippman and the Rev. Kenneth Jones, a Presbyterian minister, performed the interfaith ceremony.

title: Ellis Island, 'Elegant' Ruins and All, Caught in Student Photos
description: LEAD: ELLIS ISLAND was the entry point to the United States for more than 12 million immigrants from 1892 to 1954. But by 1982, when a photography instructor at Montclair State College visited the island, he found, he said, that ''this important part of immigrant history had been left to rot.''

title:
THE VIEW FROM: SAUNDERS CULINARY ARTS PROGRAM;

Out of the Kitchen and Into the Limelight
description: LEAD: DINNER is served. Or, more accurately, 79 dinners are being served, and with great professional aplomb.

title: 11-Year-Old Organizes a Passover Fashion Show
description: LEAD: ELEVEN-YEAR-OLD Rachel Rosenbluth of Englewood has singlehandedly put together an unusual fashion show to be held on Tuesday in Bloomingdale's at the Riverside Mall in Hackensack. The show will feature Passover fashions modeled by Rachel's fellow sixth-grade schoolmates at the Yeshiva of North Jersey in Ridgefield

title: IN SHORT
description: COMEBACK. By Dave Dravecky with Tim Stafford. (Zondervan/Harper & Row, $17.95.) Dave Dravecky was young, popular, celebrated and at the height of his powers when life threw him a curveball he never could have imagined. Mr. Dravecky, then a pitcher for the San Francisco Giants, was diagnosed in the fall of 1988 as having a desmoid tumor in his left arm - his pitching arm. That discovery of cancer and his subsequent bouts with the disease are described in ''Comeback,'' the story of his recovery and his later agonizing decision to leave the game he loved. At the book's core is spirituality: Mr. Dravecky's belief in God sustained him through his travail. There is an inspirational tone to the book, as well as the wit and flavor common to baseball, when Mr. Dravecky gives anecdotes about teammates and managers and offers a few insider's tips about the sport. Mr. Dravecky is a gamer, as is evident in his description of his comeback victory over the Cincinnati Reds 10 months after cancer surgery. He also describes with candor and a quiet dignity his decision to retire last November. ''Comeback,'' written with Tim Stafford, a contributing editor of Christianity Today and Campus Life magazines, is not a book with the usual exploits and shenanigans - no ''Bull Durham'' here. Mr. Dravecky has given new depth and meaning to the word comeback.

title: Janet M. Novotny Married To Donald Latham King Jr.
description: Janet Marie Novotny, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Novotny of Cleveland, was married yesterday to Donald Latham King Jr., the son of Dr. and Mrs. King of Darien, Conn. The Rev. Frederick Tuttle Bender performed the ceremony at Saint Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien.

title: A Piece of Outer Space to Call His Very Own
description: LEAD: IT IS EMBLEMATIC OF RENE ANSELMO'S career that at the exact moment his personal and professional fortunes were poised atop a test rocket in French Guiana two summers ago, he was back home in Connecticut, recuperating from quintuple bypass surgery. He is a man for whom business, and life itself, seems frequently to teeter between victory and calamity.

title: The High-Octane Ethanol Lobby
description: WHEN WORD OF THE INTERNAL REVENUE Service decision came to Thomas Daschle's Capitol Hill office the Friday afternoon before Thanksgiving, the South Dakota Democrat was deep in debate on the Senate floor, and the celebration had to begin without him. On returning to his office, with its rustic decor of buffalo hides and Indian headdresses, he found the members of his staff literally jumping with joy.

title: 'The Journalist and the Murderer'
description: To the Editor:

title: BONN'S NEW PLAN FOR SINGLE MARK SETS OFF A FUROR
description: A heated political debate broke out today as the West German Government confirmed a report that it was considering a plan for German monetary union under terms far less favorable to East Germans than those originally discussed by Bonn.

title: Helping Black Artists Start Their Careers
description: NOW in its last two weeks, the exhibition ''Against the Odds'' has successfully inaugurated the ''new'' Newark Museum and at the same time celebrated black art in an unusual way. The first must have been the easier task, since the museum can make anything look good now that Michael Graves has transformed it from an old lady down on her luck into a ''dish.''

title: Michael and Hope and Julian And Francesco
description: For art critics, mainstream television used to be a place to get away from it all, take a break and put the mind on automatic pilot. But these days, art, artists and even art critics are popping up in all kinds of unexpected time slots. The collaborative painter Tim Rollins and the art critic Hilton Kramer discuss Robert Mapplethorpe's photographs on ''The Phil Donahue Show.'' The painter Kenny Scharf talks about the Whitney Museum's Biennial on Robert Lipsyte's ''11th Hour.'' The contemporary art collection of Eugene and Barbara Schwartz is glimpsed on ''Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous.''

title: Where Are the Practical Taxis of Yesteryear?
description: To the Editor:

title: Johnny-Come-Latelies
description: To the Editor:

title: On Weekend for Counting, Census Itself Is Under Scrutiny as Never Before
description: As census forms are filled out in households around the country this weekend, the nation's residents are writing an end to a decennial demographic contest that has more winners and losers than ever before.

title: IF YOU SAY SO, SYD
description: THE GAME ACCORDING TO SYD

title: Tristesse, Again
description: Francoise Sagan was only a teen-ager when she became a literary smash with her portrayals of hedonistic French youth on the French Riviera. Then, in a long, slow decline, she became one of her own jaded, Bohemian characters. Last week, in the latest sad chapter, the 54-year-old author was found guilty of drug use and possession. Too frail to travel from her home in Lyons to Paris for her trial, she was tried in absentia and received a six-month suspended sentence. Because she had been a friend of President Francois Mitterrand, she at first asserted that the charges were politically motivated when she was accused of supplying certain Parisian circles with cocaine, heroin and hashish. Miss Sagan began her meteoric career at 18 with the novel ''Bonjour Tristesse,'' which sold more than 500,000 copies in 1954, won the Prix des Critiques and became a worldwide success. Other books by Miss Sagan, who garnered the admiration of intellectuals, consistently appeared on France's best-seller list. After she was charged, she admitted in a television interview that she had taken drugs.

title: Q and A
description: Co-op Assessments

title: Bridegroom 'Tony' Learns Acting Trade
description: LEAD: DAVID DUNDARA'S friends call him ''Dave.'' Yet dozens of people in Greenwich Village every night call him ''Tony.'' Not many people know that he is, in fact, two people.

title: A Bank Too Big to Fail
description: To the Editor:

title: A Birthday Party For Cold Fusion
description: COLD fusion, or whatever it is, is now one year old, and still no one can say for certain whether or not it is real. Last week, a conference in Salt Lake City marked the anniversary of the announcement that Drs. B. Stanley Pons and Martin Fleischmann had generated cheap, potentially limitless energy in a laboratory beaker. But the journal Nature published a report by Dr. Michael H. Salamon, who says that he found ''not an iota, not a sniff, of conventional fusion,'' even though he tried to repeat the experiment using Dr. Pons's own apparatus.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Clinton South;   New Dimensions for a Low-Density Neighborhood
description: WAY out west where the sky almost meets the horizon - between Ninth and 12th Avenues - millions of square feet of new development are being planned that would, if constructed, radically change the character of this midtown Manhattan neighborhood.

title: For Contras, It's a Long Way Home
description: In the lush valleys north of this regional capital, the life of a contra rebel has become one of long-practiced routine.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: MINNEAPOLIS;

Indians Defend Tenant Policy
description: LEAD: INDIAN rights advocates and the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development are at odds over preferential tenant selection at the 212-unit Little Earth houses, believed to be the country's only Indian-owned urban project.

title: Q and A
description: Insuring Free Rental Cars

title: Correction
description: The National League schedules in SportsMonday March 26 contained some incorrect information. The Chicag Cubs' home series July 16-18 is against San Diego; The Phillies' series against St. Louis April 13-15 is at home, not on the road; The Dodgers' series April 13-15 is on the road against the Astros, and they play a home series April 19-22 against the Astros.

title: Oriental Outlook
description: A former minor league pitcher of no great distinction is about to make a mark as the first Japanese manager of an American baseball team. His name is Hide Koga and he is the new skipper of the Salinas Spurs of the Class A California League, a team that will have at least a dozen Japanese players on its roster when it plays the season opener Friday against the Modesto A's.

title: To a Fading U.S. Bugle, Rhineland Sings a Dirge
description: At 5 P.M. each day, life at the United States 8th Infantry Division headquarters comes to a brief standstill as the American flag is lowered for the night.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

Where Nature Reasserted Herself
description: LEAD: WEST FIRE ISLAND, a wild, windy, overgrown sandy islet in Great South Bay, lies 50 miles east of New York City. From its damp desolation one can hear raucous revelers in Fair Harbor, a scant mile south on Fire Island. Here nature is resurgent.

title: Fatalities Prompt Road Safety Steps
description: LEAD: AFTER four fatalities in 27 months along a half-mile stretch of Middle Neck Road in Great Neck, Nassau County and the town of North Hempstead have agreed to take steps to make the heavily trafficked thoroughfare safer for pedestrians.

title: A Reminder
description: Daylight saving time resumed at 2 A.M. today. Clocks were set ahead one hour.

title: Question Of the Week;   Should Basketball Use Instant Replay?
description: They should have instant replay in the N.B.A. because it will help out a lot on the close calls. But the N.C.A.A shouldn't have it because of the great expense. The schools can do more for the teams with that money.

title: 4 Years in Drowning of Baby
description: A woman suffering from a personality disorder will spend at least four years in prison for letting her newborn daughter drown moments after her birth. Kimberly L. Harvey, 25 years old, of Vestal, was sentenced on Friday to four to 12 years in prison by a state Supreme Court judge here. The baby's father, James J. Brady Jr., 30, formerly of Binghamton, is serving two to six years in prison after pleading guilty to the same charge in September. They were accused of allowing the baby to drown when she was born head-first into a toilet Feb. 1, 1989. A pathologist certified that a full-term baby was born alive.

title: THE DRINK OF MILLIONS
description: In the article ''The Drink of Millions,'' by Elizabeth Kolbert (March 4), the statement attributed to me requires some clarification.

title: Airplane Seats
description: To the Editor: ''You Can't Be Too Thin in Economy Class'' reminded me of my Tower Air charter flight from New York to Athens last August. Like the plane seats described in the article, ours created extremely cramped conditions. A woman's complaint that when the man in front of her leaned back in his seat, his seat was practically in her face, turned into a very loud argument that attracted the attention of many passengers.

title: Workshops on Being a Better Parent
description: LEAD: MORE than 400 mothers and fathers of school-aged children here turned out recently for an evening of workshops on how to be better parents.

title: Works in Progress;   Fill'er Up
description: IF THE HIGH-DENSITY POLYETHYLENE spread on the floor of Bee Canyon in Orange County, Calif., creates the impression of an enormous trash can, appearances are, in this case, not misleading. The Bee Canyon Landfill, opened for commercial use last month, is now accepting 3,000 tons of solid refuse daily on 50 acres of canyon land prepared thus far. ''It's a box canyon; the deepest portion will be about 400 feet,'' says Frank Bowerman, director of the county's waste-management program. Thirty years from now, we'll have 350 acres suitable for a regional park.''

title: The Man Will Eat Literally Anything
description: The wind howled and the rain poured on a freezing night outside Elstree Studios. On the set, a stylized neon sign flashed above the entrance to Le Hollandais, a smart restaurant. Suddenly a white Jaguar pulled up and the actor Michael Gambon, cast as Albert, a bullying thief, jumped out, barking orders at his henchmen. They grabbed a man from their midst, threw him on the trunk, ripped off his clothes and pummeled him with their fists. Then Mr. Gambon sauntered over, smeared dirt all over the luckless thief and, with hardly a backward glance, swaggered into the restaurant.

title: THE CITY THAT DISAPPEARED TWICE
description: TOKYO RISING

title: Randi Hutter Weds Stuart Epstein in New Jersey
description: The Loews Glenpointe Hotel in Teaneck, N.J., was the setting last evening for the marriage of Randi Hutter, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert V. P. Hutter of Livingston, N.J., and Stuart Joel Epstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin E. Epstein of Kings Point, L.I. Rabbi Azriel C. Fellner and Cantor Henry Butensky officiated. Mrs. Epstein, 27 years old, is a freelance medical writer. She graduated magna cum laude from the University of Pennsylvania and received a master's degree in journalism from Columbia University. She expects to receive an M.D. degree this May from Yale University. Her father is the chairman of pathology at St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston.

title: Ann Lamborghini to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Lamborghini of Stonington, Conn., have made known August wedding plans for their daughter Ann Louise Lamborghini and Lieut. Michael Douglas Lane of the Navy Medical Corps, who is the son of Margaret L. Lane of Oceanside, Calif., and Bobby Lane of San Marcos, Calif. Miss Lamborghini, 31 years old, is a project manager at Gunther International Ltd., a manufacturer of business-automation systems in Mystic, Conn. The prospective bridegroom, 30, is a physician at Balboa Naval Hospital in San Diego.

title: Laura Ioachim To Wed in July
description: Dr. and Mrs. Harry L. Ioachim of Teaneck, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Laura Ioachim to Dr. Martin Reichel, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Reichel of New York. A July wedding is planned.

title: Correction
description: A report in the Headliners column on March 4 about the Rev. Jesse Jackson's decision against running for mayor of Washington misstated the year of Walter F. Mondale's Democratic candidacy for President and the length of time since the Democrats last won the Presidency. Mr. Mondale ran in 1984, not 1980; the Democrats won 14 years ago, not 20.

title: Nepal Closes Some Schools In Effort to Curb Protesters
description: The Government closed all high schools in the capital and two suburbs today to try to curb student demonstrators demanding multiparty politics, the state-owned radio reported.

title: MALLING THE NORTHEAST
description: MANY MALL DEVELOPERS VIEW NEW ENGLAND as overly regulated and environmentally troublesome. But the partners of the Pyramid Companies, the largest shopping-mall developer in the Northeast, see only untapped potential. No site is too complicated, no downtown too powerful, no citizen opposition too strong, no environmentally sensitive area too sensitive to deter Pyramid from a site on which it wants to build.

title: Wilson's 'Burn This' in Island Premiere
description: A PLAY can open on Broadway with a perfect cast, a director tuned to the script's most subtle nuances and technical and design elements that are the best money can buy.

title: Having Babies: Another Viewpoint
description: Regarding Elizabeth G. Wardell's essay, ''Whose Baby Is It Anyway?'' (Opinion page, March 4): I did not read the article to which she was responding, but I deduce that the parents in question have children of childbearing age and are itching for that hypothetical child to be borne.

title: Rita Chabot Weds
description: Rita Jayne Elizabeth Chabot, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond J. Chabot of Danielson, Conn., was married yesterday to Alan David Maude, a son of Dr. and Mrs. David L. Maude of Johnstown and Eagle Bay, N.Y. The Rev. Harris Riordan performed the ceremony at the First Unitarian Church in Brooklyn. The bride, 29 years old, will keep her name. She is an assistant managing editor in the book division at the Raven Press in New York. She is a graduate of Bard College. The bridegroom, a senior underwriter at Reliance National Risk Specialists in New York, graduated from Michigan Technological University in Houghton.

title: The New Wave Directors
description: ELLEN R. MARRAM, PRESIDENT AND C.E.O. of the Nabisco Biscuit Company, drives to her office in East Hanover, N.J., from her apartment on Manhattan's Upper West Side in a 1990 Lincoln Continental. One of the perks of being a director of the Ford Motor Company - Marram is the only woman on the Ford board - is having the use of late-model cars to evaluate each year. Marram, 43, a Wellesley College economics major who went on to earn an M.B.A. from the Harvard Business School in 1970, runs a $2.5 billion segment of RJR Nabisco. She is also a director of the K Mart Corporation, one of two women on the board of the huge discount chain.

title: Holocaust: Memories Never Fade
description: LEAD: ONE of the reasons Joseph Grabczak of Queens joined the Holocaust Survivors Group at the Greater Five Towns Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. in Cedarhurst was to find familiar faces who bore his concentration camp number.

title:
Style Makers;

Gianni Cavalier, Putti Carver
description: LEAD: The conversation eventually takes the same turn at Gianni Cavalier's tiny shop in a corner of Campo Santo Stefano not far from the San Marco side of the Academia bridge. Mr. Cavalier is a restorer and gilder, but his best-selling items are angels. Sooner or later, new customers want to know the difference between a putto and a cherubino, an angelo and an amorino.

title: BEST SELLERS: April 1, 1990
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 3 THE BOURNE ULTIMATUM, by Robert Ludlum. ((Random House, $21.95.) Jason Bourne plans to inflitrate the ruthless Medusa Bridage as part of a plot to trap his archenemy, Carlos the Jackal. 2 2 6 OH, THE PLACES YOU'LL GO! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $12.95.) The memoirs of a former Presidential speechwriter. 6 6 28 IT WAS ON FIRE WHEN I LAY DOWN ON IT, by Robert Fulghum. (Villard, $17.95.) A new collection of inspirational essays. 7 3 PARTING WITH ILLUSIONS, by Vladimir Pozner. (Atlantic Monthly, $19.95.) The autobiography of a man, raised in New York, who became a commentator on Radio Moscow. 8 8 9 THE CUCKOO'S EGG, by Clifford Stoll. (Doubleday, $19.95.) An astrophysicist tells how he stalked a computer hacker. 9 7 74 ALL I REALLY NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, by Robert Fulghum. (Villard, $17.95.) A memoir of the comedian's boyhood, written in the form of letters to his long-deceased father. 14 10 16 THE TEMPTING OF AMERICA, by Robert H.Bork. (Free Press, $22.95.) A critique of the relationship between politics and the law by Ronald Reagan's Supreme Court nominee. 15* 13 9 HEAD FIRST, by Norman Cousins. (Dutton, $19.95.) How the brain affects the body's endocrine and immune systems.
