Ways by which women can mprove their relationships with men. 2 2 6 BEWARE THE NAKED MAN WHO OFFERS YOU HIS SHIRT, by Harvey Mackay. (Morrow, $19.95.) Advice on how to get ahead in business. 3 3 59 WEALTH WITHOUT RISK, by Charles J. Givens. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) A Florida entrepreneur's financial advice. 4 4 16 THE GREAT WALDO SEARCH, by Martin Handford. (Little, Brown, $10.95.) A book of illustrations in which the game is to find a ubiquitous chap named Waldo. 5 5 2 THE POWER OF THE FAMILY, by Paul Pearsall. (Doubleday, $19.95.) A psychologist's account of how familial relationships can provide comfort and healing in times of crisis.

title: AS THE VOLUME RISES IN THE LABELING DEBATE, DISTORTION RULES
description: It's time for a reality check. In a matter of months, rhetoric about the content and purported dangers of popular music has escalated beyond all reasonable bounds, as distortion feeds sensationalism that feeds real parental concerns about children.

title: MINNEAPOLIS: NO MORE MR. NICE GUY
description: THE HEADHUNTERS SAY that nobody ever wants to come to Minneapolis, and that once here, nobody ever wants to leave. It's inarguably cold, this distant outpost - a remote corner of flyover land in the heart of the heart of the country. But Minneapolitans do not merely endure this American Siberia, they thrive in it.

title: Faltering Knicks Drop Another
description: It's getting so that expansion teams and those in desperate need of a victory need only play the Knicks.

title: Georgia A-Plant Accident Getting Sharp U.S. Scrutiny
description: An accident that occurred at a Georgia nuclear power plant on March 21 is focusing renewed attention on one of the most worrisome potential problems at nuclear plants: the loss of electrical power to run the plant and cool its reactor fuel.

title: Airplane Seats
description: To the Editor: Thanks to Betsy Wade for warning us sardines who fly economy class that seating will be even more cramped than before. This is a special problem for me, because I am 6 feet 4 and and long legged.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

Vanilla for Phone Bills, Cinnamon for Electric?
description: LEAD: LATELY, half of my mail has been arriving opened. At first I suspected malicious tampering, but then I realized there is probably a revolt afoot against foul-tasting glue.

title: WHAT'S DOING ON: The Eastern Shore
description: Maryland's Eastern Shore stretches some 150 miles from the upper tidewaters of Chesapeake Bay to the sand dunes at Assateague where the Free State meets Virginia on the Atlantic. For generations the peninsula - which includes nine of Maryland's counties - was as insular as any island, removed from the mainland, remote, rural, primarily agricultural. Today, within easy driving distance of several of the nation's largest cities, the Shore has become a major resort area.

title: Racing Speed Boats Shatter the Calm
description: With the arrival of spring one begins to think of warmer days. For those of us fortunate enough to live close to Long Island Sound, that should include hours of quiet enjoyment on the local beaches.

title: STREETSCAPES: Flushing's RKO Keith's;   A Magnificent, but Mutilated, Palatial Landmark
description: A DESIGNATED landmark that is one of the few surviving palatial theater interiors in New York City has been mutilated. Can the Landmarks Preservation Commission (a) order that the work be restored; (b) fine the owner repeatedly until the damage is undone or (c) do nothing except wait until the owner requests a permit for unrelated work?

title: Balloons' Effect On the Environment
description: In response to the recent letter to the New Jersey editor by Erwin Lewis, I am writing to pour cold water on his arguments that balloon releases are safe. There have been several other letters that say balloons are not safe, but the debate still rages.

title: 'Leaders Meetings' Proliferate As Albany Budget Work Lags
description: Some participants compare the Albany institution known as leaders' meetings to the United Nations Security Council, a mechanism through which the diplomats of state government can negotiate behind closed doors rather than wage a war of rhetoric in the press.

title: For Mexico, Freedom Before Free Trade
description: LEAD: The decision by Mexico's President, Carlos Salinas de Gortari, to consider a free-trade agreement with the U.S. should not divert attention from the salient problem facing Mexico: the status of the Institutional Revolutionary Party as one of the last remaining authoritarian political systems in the world.

title: TERRORIST ON THE MOUND
description: ''Any baseball is beautiful. . . . It is a perfect object for a man's hand,'' Roger Angell wrote. Don Drysdale, who pitched baseballs with fearsome efficiency for 14 years for the Brooklyn and Los Angeles Dodgers, would agree, judging by his autobiography, ONCE A BUM, ALWAYS A DODGER (St. Martin's, $18.95). Written with Bob Verdi, a Chicago Tribune columnist, the book starts in Brooklyn, full of wonder and anecdote from the rookie right-hander who arrived in 1956, the year after after Brooklyn won its only World Series and two years before the team's owner, Walter O'Malley, took it to the West Coast. The best of the book is Mr. Drysdale's description of how he played the game. Until Orel Hershiser broke it two years ago, Mr. Drysdale held the record for consecutive scoreless innings pitched (58Z in 1968); he still holds the National League record for hit batsmen, 154; he won 209 games (without a no-hitter), a career good enough to get him into the Hall of Fame. He tells how he threw spitballs for years to the consternation of sluggers like Ted Williams and Henry Aaron, and how he felt about his reputation as a terrorist on the mound, with the perfect object turned into a weapon. Once when an umpire warned him not to throw at a batter, he responded, ''If you fine me, I'll get a lawyer . . . and I'll sue the entire National League. How can you tell me what I was thinking, what my intent was?'' The brushback worked; there was no fine. ''I always believed that it was them or us, and nothing was going to stand in my way.'' An athlete who saw many bad and good bounces, Mr. Drysdale is always aware of luck. His career began when he was an infielder with an American Legion team in the early 1950's. A Dodger scout named Goldie Holt happened to show up at a game. The team's starting pitcher did not, so the author's father, the coach, told him to pitch. He won and Mr. Holt asked, ''You ever thought about pitching?'' ''No, not really,'' he said, but his ability to throw aspirins changed that.

title: Beyond the Strike Zone
description: Perhaps all too soon for some in this besmirched baseball season, George Steinbrenner is again in a legal rhubarb. The Yankees' owner has admitted paying $40,000 to Howard Spira, a former radio reporter and self-described gambler, for giving him information in his dispute last year with the outfielder Dave Winfield over the player's foundation for children. Mr. Spira claimed that foundation funds were being misappropriated, among other assertions. When Mr. Spira requested more money, Mr. Steinbrenner called Federal authorities. Mr. Spira has been charged with extortion and threatening Mr. Steinbrenner and Mr. Winfield. An arraignment is scheduled for Thursday. The Yankees' owner has offered his own reasons for paying the money, saying he did it ''out of the goodness of my heart'' and to squelch embarrassing information about former Yankee employees. Some Yankee observers, aware of the owner's efforts to trade Mr. Winfield, believe that Mr. Steinbrenner wanted something negative to pressure Mr. Winfield into accepting a trade.

title: Miss Lawrence To Wed in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Lawrence Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., have made known October wedding plans for their daughter Angela Helene Lawrence and James Ewers Lineberger Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lineberger of New Canaan, Conn.

title: POSTINGS: Clinton Hill Renovation;   8 Duplex Condos
description: A turn-of-the-century terra cotta-and-brick apartment house in the Clinton Hill Historic District of Brooklyn has undergone a total renovation into eight modern duplex condominium apartments. The project, at 201 St. James Place between Gates Avenue and Fulton Street, is in an area noted for its architecturally distinctive neo-Renaissance rowhouses. The four-story building is one of nine on the block designed by Axel S. Hedman in 1905.

title: A Private Couple, A Private Family
description: Regarding the Feb. 24 article on Pat LaFontaine, I was wondering, at first, why you didn't publish a photo of Pat, his wife and possibly their dogs. Then I thought could it be that this private couple really does want to remain private?

title: Driving Abroad
description: To the Editor: Having shipped a car from the United States to Antwerp, I know that if you arrive carrying only a USA sticker and an international driver's license, as suggested in the Q & A column on March 4, the car will remain impounded. You omitted that most important of documents, both at ports of entry and at border crossings: the green card carried by all European drivers, as proof of insurance coverage. You can get a green card from a company in the United States that sells insurance for travel in Europe or from a local company once you arrive abroad.

title: Nina Fastenberg, A Student, Weds
description: The Park East Synagogue in Manhattan was the setting last evening for the marriage of Nina Fastenberg, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William Fastenberg of New York, to Mitchell Evan Auerbach, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jeffrey Auerbach of Boca Raton, Fla. Rabbi Arthur Schneier officiated.

title: TV Cash Can Give Colleges High Marks
description: The business of televised sports has undergone dramatic changes over the last two decades and will continue to evolve as we look ahead into the 1990's. What was once a stable, structured and predictable marketplace is now one of unparalleled growth and transition, resulting in a far more complex and uncertain economic environment.

title: Nuclear Plant Recycled
description: To the Editor:

title: Farmer's Gift of 74 Acres Delights His Neighbors
description: LEAD: AT a time when land acquisition has become too expensive for most towns, Madison residents have been surprised and delighted by the gift of a 74-acre tract that holds special memories for many of them.

title: Time to Care for Outdoor Decks
description: OUTDOOR decks are built to withstand exposure. Nevertheless, to look their best and remain sturdy, they should be cared for when necessary and inspected in the spring and fall.

title: Volunteers Get a Look Inside Prison
description: THE speaker was describing the moment of imprisonment. ''Your whole life changes,'' he said.

title: The Grip Of the Liquid Diet: A special report:   Dieters, Craving Balance, Are Battling Fears of Food
description: Joy Segal's desk on the second floor of Zabar's was a fortress of envelopes full of chocolate-flavored formula diet powder. The aroma of bread and pastries rose from the store below, but Mrs. Segal was immune to its temptation. She smiled triumphantly.

title: Devils Continue Surge by Winning 5th in a Row
description: The Devils will be going into the last game of the regular season Sunday without any worries. They are playing their best hockey of the season and have clinched second place in the Patrick Division and the home advantage in the first round of the playoffs next week.

title: 'Super' Support For Arizona Site
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: PERSPECTIVES: Office Construction;   As Building Slows, So Will Tax Growth
description: LOOKING east and looking west in Manhattan, it is hard to find new office projects starting. That foreshadows low figures for completions in 1992 and 1993. For New York City, this is one sign of the impending slowdown in the remarkable rate of growth in tax revenues from Manhattan office buildings - sobering news for fiscal managers.

title: Understanding de Klerk, Party Man With a Twist
description: Before F. W. de Klerk was chosen to succeed P. W. Botha as President, he was asked if he would be the Mikhail S. Gorbachev of South Africa, a loyal party man who overturns much that the party once held inviolable. Mr. de Klerk had a quick reply: ''The only thing Gorbachev and I have in common is this!'' he said, slapping the top of his head.

title: Sarah B. Schwab, Student, Is Wed
description: Sarah Baldwin Schwab, the daughter of Julia Edge Bowers of Cambridge, Mass., and Walter P. B. Schwab of Providence, R.I., and Quechee, Vt., was married yesterday to Roger Raymond Ambrogi, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond R. Ambrogi of Corning, N. Y. The Rev. James A. Newman performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Redondo Beach, Calif.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If the voice of reason is not heeded now, developments could have grave consequences for all of us.''

title: PANDEMONIUM IN PINSTRIPES
description: DAMNED YANKEES

title: Question Of the Week;   Should Basketball Use Instant Replay?
description: Basketball should have instant replay because the referees are only human and the machines capture more than what the eye can see. A lot of times the wrong calls by referees cause the wrong outcome of a game.

title: Question Of the Week;   Should Basketball Use Instant Replay?
description: Never. Too many replays slow down the play of the game and take the fun out of it. Let the refs call them as they see them; it all equals out by the end of the season.

title: HERE'S LOOKING AT YOU, BILLY THE KID
description: SILVER LIGHT

title: Campus Life: Chicago;   A Professor Whose Father Helped Shape Soviet History
description: In Sergo Mikoyan's Soviet history classes, which began at the University of Chicago last week, the history being taught is in many ways a personal one. The professor is the son of Anastas I. Mikoyan, the close associate of Stalin and Khrushchev and member of the Politburo during events from the purges of the 1930's to the Cuban missile crisis.

title: Review/Opera;   New Principals Join 'La Boheme' at the Met
description: Brian Schexnayder, who sings Marcello in ''La Boheme'' at the Metropolitan Opera, has kept his place in Franco Zeffirelli's garret. But he had different friends and roommates on Wednesday evening, when new singers joined the cast in the other principal roles.

title: Wall Street;   Riding Out the End-Quarter Calm
description: A sense of listlessness descended over Wall Street this past week as trading volumes sagged. The quiet dismayed brokers. And the low volumes made it harder for pundits to reach meaningful conclusions about gains and losses in various indexes. But a quick look at trading patterns over the past five quarters shows that the swoon is no cause for alarm. Indeed, the Big Board's 41 percent first-quarter volume decline - from a high of more than 222 million shares on March 16 to less than 132 million shares on Tuesday - was modest compared with the three-week periods prior to the end of the previous four quarters. The declines in the last 15 trading days of those quarters range from 44.6 percent at the end of September to 67.7 percent at the end of December. Analysts say the main reason for these declines is that before the quarter ends, major portfolio managers have usually achieved the desired mix in their portfolios. Then, if market conditions allow, they sit tight rather than take risks that could damage their performance results.

title: New Beginnings, Second Quarter And Fiscal Year
description: Traders are hoping that the arrival of the year's second quarter today will enliven the market, after last week's various departures - one clumsy, one graceful, the rest routine - gave Wall Street the meandering air of a mid-afternoon train station.

title: Old Enough to Kill?
description: Later this year, when the forsythia on the mountain slopes here has turned from yellow to green, Cameron Kocher will stand trial for killing Jessica Carr. Late May or early June, his lawyer says, unless there is some kind of plea bargain. The timing is fortunate; the defendant will not miss much of fifth grade.

description: LEAD:

title: A New Critique Of Homeless Policy
description: AS the County Board of Legislators moves to end a three-year debate by approving a 108-unit project for the homeless, a report to be released this week strongly criticizes the county's response to its homeless population.

description: To the Editor:

title: King Widens Lead to 5 Shots
description: After a three-under-par 69 in the third round today, Betsy King widened her lead to five shots in the Nabisco Dinah Shore.

title: GORBACHEV OFFERS CONDITIONAL TALKS WITH LITHUANIANS
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev offered to open a discussion with Lithuanian leaders tonight if they repealed their declaration of independence, and he warned the Lithuanian people that failure to comply with his request ''could have grave consequences for all of us.''

title: Receiving a Kidney, a Gift of Life
description: I AM a recent kidney-transplant recipient. I am also a physician. At the end of 1988, I developed end-stage renal disease and shortly thereafter required hemodialysis three times a week. Each dialysis session lasted about three hours.

title: New Rules Set for Sponsor Disclosures
description: WITH financial troubles deepening at some of New York City's residential cooperatives, Attorney General Robert Abrams has sent a new set of requirements for financial disclosure to the sponsors of more than 2,000 co-op buildings across the city.

title: Catholic Schools Faulted on Plan
description: I read with special interest the article by Bea Tusiani, ''Local Catholic Schools Closing'' (March 4). My two children attend one of the schools scheduled to close this June (St. Boniface Martyr, in Sea Cliff). I have been in St. Boniface Parish for nine years and active in school and parish activities since my oldest child began attending school five years ago. I am currently the vice president of the St. Boniface Home School Association.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: DR. JERRY M. ROSENBERG;

Looking Toward Greater Use of Robotics

So did the Random House Dictionary for its new edition. Dr. Rosenberg has supplied hundreds of definitions to the O.E.D. at $1.60 each, submitted on 3-by-5 cards.

title: Pastimes;   Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Even though spring is here, the ground is still too cold to do any major planting; peas, spinach, lettuce and other hardy vegetables can go into the ground, if it is dry and workable. Apply fertilizer to lawns and lime, if soil test shows its need. Scrape off egg cases of gypsy moth into a paper bag and toss into the fireplace or wood stove.

title: World Markets;   Assessing the Damage to Gold Markets
description: Last week's gold plunge did more than knock the bulls out of the market. The sudden, wrenching $23-an-ounce drop may also have driven away many investors and potential investors for some time.

title: THERE'S GOLD IN THEM THAR DIAMONDS
description: THE BASEBALL BUSINESS

title: 'Junk Bond' Dealers Are Betting on a New, Slimmer Market
description: Despite the painful dismantling of the ''junk bond'' market once ruled by Michael R. Milken, some dealers are betting that they can profit from a new, smaller one that is emerging. One month after the parent of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. filed for bankruptcy protection, firms like Salomon Brothers, Kidder, Peabody & Company, Jefferies & Company, and Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. are increasing their junk-bond staffs.

title: Technology;   The Software With Good Sense
description: Water flows downhill. A person can't be in two places at once. All animals live, die and stay dead. Such common-sense statements about the world are so basic that no encyclopedia bothers to include them.

title: Opposites Share a Final Goal
description: Colgate and Wisconsin, whose teams will play for the national championship on Sunday, represent opposite poles in the major league of college hockey, Division I of the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

description: Joseph (Seppi) Renggli, for 17 years the executive chef of the Four Seasons, the landmark restaurant in Manhattan, has left the helm of the kitchen.

title: The Talk of Middletown;   1950's Town Now Battles 1990's Woes
description: At first glance, this seems like an aptly named small city. It is in the middle of the state and midway between New York and Boston. It is still dotted with many of the symbols of middle-class, middle-American life from the mid-20th century: homes with big porches, a roadside diner and a Main Street complete with a striped barber's pole, an old movie marquee and an Art Deco-style Woolworth's.

title: German-Spain Phone Tie

The agreement also provides for establishing digital circuits between the countries and the linking of electronic mail systems, videotex data banks and toll-free numbers. Telefonica said the accord was intended to ease the creation of a single European market from the European Community's 12 member countries, which include Spain and West Germany. The single market is to take effect by the end of 1992.

The company said in December 1989, Kentucky West Virginia Gas Co., a pipeline subsidiary, reached a settlement in its 1986 general rate case which is pending approval by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission. The company also said the 1989 first quarter included $3.6 million of income from a rate settlement applicable to prior periods which had been reserved. title: Reviews/Television;   Koppel Explores Questions Of Romania's Revolution
description: The drama of the Romanian revolution, the only one of the upsurges in Eastern Europe that was attended by violence and the one whose triumph remains the most problematic, is graphically presented on tonight's ''Koppel Report.'' Using pictures that have not been seen before in America or for that matter in Romania, the hour captures the chaos of the few days in December that ended with the fall of Nicolae Ceausescu.

title: 48 Who Died in Bronx Fire Return Home

title: Colt May Make Assault Rifles

The former owners of the Hartford-based company stopped sales to civilians last year when the Government banned imports of similar weapons. The firearms division of Colt Industries, now called Colt's Manufacturing Company, was sold on March 22 to C. F. Holding, a group of investors, including the state of Connecticut and 1,000 striking Colt workers.

title: Review/Recital;   Supove's 'Exploding Piano'
description: One of the oldest cliches about the piano is the exhortation by teachers and critics to take what is essentially a percussion instrument and turn it into a singing one. Few songs were sung at Katherine Supove's piano program at Weill Recital Hall on Thursday, however. Indeed, its title - ''The Exploding Piano'' - prepared the listener for all the detonations along the way.

Herman Levin Is Dead; Jewish Lay Leader, 89
description: Herman Levin, a longtime lay leader of the Jewish Reconstructionist movement and the president of the Acme Dress Form Corporation of Brooklyn for 35 years, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 89 years old. Mr. Levin was an early exponent of Reconstructionism, which redefines Judaism not only as a religion, but also as a civilization that includes language, custom and culture. The movement, a small but influential group, was founded in 1922 by Rabbi Mordecai M. Kaplan, a professor at the Jewish Theological Seminary of America who died in 1983 at the age of 102.

title: United Insurance Cos. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Outdoors: Trout Opener on the Croton
description: MOVED, one surmises, by the force that through the green fuse drives the flower, fishermen celebrated the opening of the trout season yesterday in New York State.

title: Carmike Cinemas Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Photographic Sciences reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Huffman Koos Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: 2-Shot Victory For King
description: Betsy King played prodigally with a six-stroke lead in the Nabisco Dinah Shore today, but held on to win her third major title by two shots over Kathy Postlewait and Shirley Furlong.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Hooker Chief Faces Trial
description: The chairman of the Hooker Corporation was ordered on Friday to stand trial on corruption charges.

title: National Debt Becomes Beast That Ate America
description: To the Editor:

title: Cabletron Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The company said for the fiscal year ended Feb. 28, 1989, and for the short tax year ended May 31, 1989, Cabletron elected to be treated as an S Corporation under subchapter S of the internal revenue code. Under subchapter S, Cabletron did not pay Federal income taxes during those tax years. Rather, the income of Cabletron was treated as if it had been earned directly by the stockholders.

title: Critic's Notebook;   Choreographing the Past, Without Any Jokes
description: When the New York Theater Ballet revived ''Pas de Quatre'' recently at the Dimson Theater, the work looked quaint. In one sense, it should have. ''Pas de Quatre'' is Anton Dolin's conjectural reconstruction of a plotless work produced at Her Majesty's Theater in London on July 12, 1845, to display the talents of four of the period's greatest ballerinas: Marie Taglioni, Fanny Cerrito, Carlotta Grisi and Lucile Grahn. It created a sensation and a repeat performance on July 17 was attended by Queen Victoria and Prince Albert.

title: Chronicle
description: When GILBERT E. KAPLAN stepped up to the podium at Carnegie Hall seven years ago, people smiled indulgently. A rich man's fantasy, conducting Mahler's mammoth Second Symphony, the ''Resurrection,'' some thought.

title: M/A-Com reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $73,890,000. c-After income from discontinued operations of $105,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $131,000, or 1 cent a share, for the 6 months. d-Net income

title: Republic Automotive Parts reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''I don't want any handouts. If I can work, I can make it.''

title: Biomira Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Logic Devices Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $665,000, or 14 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of accounting changes.

title: Tyco Toys reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Midland Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MAI Basic Four reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Robert Breen, 80, Arts Executive And Theatrical Producer, Is Dead
description: Robert Breen, whose 1952 co-production of ''Porgy and Bess'' was considered the first postwar United States-Soviet cultural exchange and who helped bring Federal financing to the performing arts, died of Alzheimer's disease on Saturday at Brooklyn Veterans Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Kansas Power & Light reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A Choice in Idaho
description: Three cheers for Gov. Cecil Andrus, who rose above his personal predisposition and saw the Idaho abortion bill for what it was - faulty in its origins, overly restrictive in its provisions, thoroughly deserving of his veto.

title: A Chance for Lithuania
description: Tension has been mounting in Lithuania. So far, Mikhail Gorbachev has been ambiguous, playing brinkmanship. He is in a difficult bind, and he probably hasn't decided which way to go - to try to ease the pain and save face by wriggling out of the imperial problem gradually, or crack down, prove his power and damn the consequences.

title: Driver Licenses Take Aim At the Under-Age Drinker
description: As part of a campaign to curb under-age drinking, the state is issuing new drivers' licenses and nondriver photo identification cards that clearly indicate whether a person is under 21 years of age.

title: Judge Postpones Park Rape Trial Over Evidence
description: The first trial in the Central Park rape case was indefinitely postponed yesterday after the prosecution said it had found evidence that had been apparently overlooked by the police crime laboratory.

title: Bellamy and Spano Affirm Plans To Seek Comptroller Nomination
description: Two Democrats declared yesterday that they wanted to run for their party's nomination for New York State comptroller, a job that only two people have held in the last 36 years.

title: Energy Report Issued
description: Secretary of Energy James D. Watkins released a 230-page interim report today on a proposed energy strategy, listing possibilities that include strict conservation requirements and Government-financed development of renewable alternative fuels like solar power or hydroelectric power.

title: Farley Unit Misses Loan Payment
description: A division of Farley Inc. that was formed to acquire West Point-Pepperell Inc. said today that it had defaulted on a $796 million bank loan and would be unable to pay interest owed to holders of $705 million in ''junk bonds.''

title: Chicago Journal;   Gigantic Face Lift (Headache To Match)
description: When the Standard Oil Company began planning its headquarters building in downtown Chicago 20 years ago, the industrial giant envisioned an enduring showpiece with a distinctive face.

title: Ortega, a Lame Duck, Begins His Diplomatic Farewell
description: In his last regional conference of heads of state before leaving office this month, President Daniel Ortega Saavdra of Nicaragua began talks with four other Central American Presidents here today in what his aides say will be a final push for the quick disbanding of the contra army.

title: Mandela Agrees to Talk With de Klerk on Violence in Townships
description: Nelson Mandela said today that he had accepted an invitation to meet with President F. W. de Klerk on Thursday to discuss the growing violence in the country.

title: Executive Says Musburger Decision Was Made Week in Advance
description: CBS had decided to release Brent Musburger, its top sports announcer for the past 15 years, at least a week before it announced Sunday that his contract would not be renewed, a CBS executive said yesterday.

title: Bingo King Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. Intec reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,334,000 and $2,116,000, which included losses of $1,177,000 and $577,000 from disposal of discontinued operations, for 1989 and 1988, respectively. c-Net income

title: Difficulties in Real Estate Extend Even to Minneapolis
description: Even as the Trammell Crow Company solves some of its problems in the Southwest, it is struggling in a metropolitan area not widely associated with real estate troubles. The difficulties of the nation's largest developer here are one more indication of the extent of the national real estate slump.

title: Soviet Emigres to Israel Topped 7,000 in March
description: Despite terrorist threats and short-lived moves to curtail airline service from Hungary, Soviet Jews poured into Israel in record numbers last month, and even more are arriving in the first days of April.

title: Strike at 7 Hospitals in California
description: As many as 11,000 employees went on strike at seven hospitals and more than 40 medical offices in Southern California today after weekend talks failed to produce a contract.

title: On Horse Racing;   Summer Squall Balances Big Weight
description: rrIf Summer Squall ends up in the Kentucky Derby winner's circle on May 5, he had better be in a good mood: if he kicks out or even tries to turn around someone could get killed.

title: Blue Devils Struggle To Find a Meaning
description: As much as anything else, what made this evening so painful for the Duke Blue Devils, by the end of the most one-sided championship game in the 51-year history of the national collegiate basketball tournament, was that their hard-earned optimism seemed to make so little sense.

title: Hasty Hysteria on Aliens
description: According to Congress's investigating agency, employers subject to sanctions for hiring undocumented aliens under a 1986 law have engaged in a ''widespread pattern of discrimination'' against people who look and sound foreign. That finding has led critics of sanctions to demand their repeal.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Middletown, Conn., referred incorrectly to the role of the city's police chief in a Federal investigation of possible ties between his department and organized-crime figures. The chief, George R. Aylward, is not a focus of the investigation; he requested it. The article also misstated the number of students at Wesleyan University who are from Middletown. About 800 students are registered to vote in the city, but fewer than 20 have families there.

title: Ranger Quandary: Vanbiesbrouck or Richter?
description: The game didn't mean anything, and Roger Neilson decided it didn't matter where he watched it from. So Neilson, the coach of the Rangers, climbed through the Madison Square Garden crowd Sunday night to a seat amid the fans for the season finale against the Capitals.

title: Market Place;   Strange Calm After Tokyo's Fall
description: The world's stock markets have shown remarkable complacency in the face of Tokyo's collapse. After the 1,978.38-point drop in the Nikkei 225-stock index yesterday, the rest of the world's markets fell but did not panic.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This is the first time the U.S. has invaded a country and leveled it to arrest one man.''

title: Mandela In the Storm
description: Nelson Mandela spoke with respect of President F. W. de Klerk and two of his ministers. ''These three men to me are serious when they say they want a fundamental change in South Africa, and I deal with them on that basis.'' Then he added:

title: Dr. Robert H. Felix Is Dead at 85; Mental Health Unit's First Chief
description: Dr. Robert H. Felix, a psychiatrist who was the first director of the National Institute of Mental Health, died of complications of Parkinson's disease on Saturday at his home in Sun City, Ariz. He was 85 years old.

title: Trump Group Makes Bid For Bonwit
description: A consortium led by Donald J. Trump, the New York developer, and a French department store chain yesterday entered a spirited bidding contest for various parts of the Bonwit Teller fashion chain. But a bankruptcy judge said no decision would be made until May 18, giving the owner, the Hooker Corporation, the opportunity to review the offers.

title: Idaho Approves King Holiday
description: A holiday honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. won final approval in the Legislature on Friday, making Idaho the 47th state agreeing to adopt the Federal holiday. Senate passage of the measure on a 28-to-11 vote assured it of becoming law with Gov. Cecil D. Andrus's promised approval. The vote came four years after the state designated the third Monday in January as a commemorative day but not an official holiday for Dr. King. Arizona, New Hampshire and Montana have refused to designate a holiday.

title: Midday Nikkei Is Below 28,000
description: After a brief rebound early this morning, the Tokyo Stock Exchange slipped again and ended the morning session below 28,000 points.

title: CSX Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $51,000,000, or 52 cents a share. During the quarter, the company annouced the sale of the stock of CSX Energy Corp., its natural gas liguids processing unit, to Enron Gas Processing, a subsidiary of Enron Corp. This sale resulted in a net gain of $52 million, or 53 cents a share, which was included in discontinued operations. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $5,000,000, or 4 cents a share. Latest quarter's income from continuing operations of $26,000,000, or 24 cents a share, included a net charge of $33 million related to the previously announced restructuring of the company's container-shipping subsidiary, Sea-Land Service Inc.

title: Linpro Specified Properties reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said results for 1989 reflected a writedown of $6 million by Linpro Income Fund I Partnership of its investment in Academy Downs near Denver. The trust owns a 68 percent equity interest in the partnership. In accordance with the partnership agreement, the entire writedown has allocated to the trust.

title: How Schools Can Lure Good Minority Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: Nationwide Cellular Svcs reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income of $32,310 from redemption of debentures. The company said net income figures included an equity loss of an investment of $688,466 in the year and $180,073 for the quarter of 1989, compared with $204,336 for both respective periods in 1988.

title: Price Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 18
description: Certain amounts in the prior year financial statement have been reclassified to conform with the 1990 presentation.

title: A Storyteller For the War That Won't End
description: For the first time since his Army tour of duty in Vietnam ended 20 years ago, Tim O'Brien will be going back in June. The official reason for the trip is a conference of American and Vietnamese writers in Hanoi. A more personal one for Mr. O'Brien is to return to the area around the village of My Lai.

title: John Stiefel, 69, Dies; Nuclear Power Adviser
description: John T. Stiefel, a chemical engineer and former vice president of the Westinghouse Corporation of Pittsburgh, died of a brain tumor on Sunday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 69 years old and also lived in Sarasota, Fla.

title: Helen F. McGillicuddy; Illinois Judge, 73
description: Helen F. McGillicuddy, the first woman elected to the Illinois Appellate Court, died on Thursday at Evanston Hospital in Evanston, Ill. She was 73 years old and lived in Chicago.

title: Mark's Work Wearhouse reports earnings for Year to Jan 27
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $724,000, or 8 cents a share. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Random House Position
description: Rich Szefc has been named chief financial officer of Random House Inc., a new position, Alberto Vitale, chairman and chief executive of the company, announced yesterday. The appointment was effective immediately. Mr. Szefc (pronounced chef), who was also named senior vice president, will be responsible for all financial functions of the company and for the legal and contract department. He is a former partner of Arthur Andersen & Company, the accounting firm. Last year he left Andersen to join Omnicorp Holdings Inc., the United States arm of a Swiss investment group.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Amdura Corp., Denver, said it would file for Federal bankruptcy protection after it was unable to get additional credit from its banks.

title: U.S. Kin Press Case of 2 Killed in Guatemala in '85
description: Five years ago last Friday, a freelance journalist and a companion hiked through the Guatemalan highlands on their way into territory frequented by the Guerrilla Army of the Poor. They were never heard from again.

title: ETZ Lavud reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Racial Tension From Slaying Seen at Trial
description: Jury selection began yesterday in the Bensonhurst murder trial amid signs of the same racial tension that engulfed New York City after Yusuf K. Hawkins was killed in the predominantly white neighborhood last summer.

title: Syms Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
Auto Pollution Has Decreased for a Decade
description: To the Editor:

title: Construction Spending Aided by Mild Weather
description: Spending on residential, nonresidential and governmental construction projects all increased in February, helped for the second straight month by mild weather over much of the country, the Commerce Department reported today, The department said that construction spending rose by 2.6 percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $436.5 billion. That followed a revised 2.5 percent jump in January, which had first been reported to have been a 1.8 percent gain.

title: U.N.L.V. Applies a Defensive Clamp and It Works
description: The national championship rings were already sized and polished. The T-shirts and hats were already printed. The Nevada-Las Vegas players wrapped themselves up in their extra treats, each entrenched in the locker-room delirium that broke loose after U.N.L.V. won the championship here tonight by the largest margin ever in a title game, 103-73, over Duke.

title: Suspect in Stabbing of Wife Is Found Struck by Lightning
description: A man was struck by lightning over the weekend while he was being sought for questioning in the stabbing of his wife.

title: Impending Suspension
description: Henry Marsh, the world's leading steeplechase runner of the 1980's, said yesterday that he was about to be suspended for two years for failure to report for a drug test. Marsh said The Athletics Congress, the American governing body for track and field, had notified him of the impending suspension after the organization's hearing board did not accept his explanation.

title: Voit Corp.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 29
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $80,000 from a pre-payment penalty on early extinguishment of debt. The latest year's income before extraordinary item included a $189,451 writedown of latex glove inventory and a $125,000 settlement of a legal suit.

title: Universal Holding Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Y & A Group Inc. reports earnings for 12mo to Dec 31
Drug Reduces Cholesterol in Eggs
description: RESEARCHERS have lowered the cholesterol content of eggs in a small laboratory study by feeding hens a drug commonly prescribed for humans with high cholesterol.

title: Talking Business; with Cook of Atlantic Richfield;   Oil Industry's Environment Role
description: Lodwrick M. Cook is chairman of the Atlantic Richfield Company of Los Angeles, one of the nation's most profitable oil companies. He discussed environmental and other issues during a recent visit in New York.

title: Bradley Begins Campaign for 3d Term
description: Senator Bill Bradley announced his bid for a third term yesterday, bolstered by $9 million in campaign funds and by the prospect of running as a popular incumbent against a little-known challenger.

title: b-Impacted by additional bad debt expenses of $1,262,000 and costs asFsociated with the closing of the company's West Haven Center and its Canton,
description: c-Net income

title: In Northern Ireland, More Must Be Done
description: To the Editor:

title: Developer Skips Payment of Taxes
description: The cash-short General Development Corporation has failed to make more than $10 million in property tax payments and is considering filing for bankruptcy protection, the company said. The tax payments on the nine Florida communities built by the developer had to be sent on Sunday, but none were, a company spokesman, Otis Wragg, said.

title: Must Busing Go On Till Racial Balance Is Exact?
description: Outside the small, self-contained worlds of Shelly Bridgwater's and Donna Stover's classrooms rages one of the country's most complex and far-reaching desegregation battles.

title: Pratt Hotel Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After costs of $640,000 related to early extinguishment of debt. c-Net income d-After an extraordinary credit of $11,819,000, or 23 cents a share, from an arbitration award, net of related costs and state income taxes.

title: Discus Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Old Fashion Foods reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 24
description: b-Net income

title: How to Stymie Iraq - For a While
description: LEAD: President Saddam Hussein declared yesterday that Iraq has sophisticated chemical weapons and warned that if Israel attacked, Iraq would destroy half that country. And last week six people were arrested in Britain while attempting to smuggle California-made nuclear triggers to Iraq.

title: As Plan B Deadline Passes, N.F.L. Has a New, Albeit Indistinct, Look
description: Pro football's Plan B free-agency period has ended with unclear results.

title: Europe Plan On Patents
description: The European Community submitted a detailed proposal today for new international rules to protect rights to such intellectual property as patents, copyright and trademarks.

title: Southland Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a writeoff of goodwill of $946,974,000 for the quarter and year, and included income from discontinued operations of $20,076,000, or 10 cents a share, for the quarter, which included $21,146,000 gain from equity in earnings of Citgo and a loss of $1,070,000 on disposal of equity interest in Citgo; the year included income from discontinued operations of $69,410,000, or 34 cents a share, which included $70,480,000 gain from equity in earnings of Citgo and a loss of $1,070,000 on disposal of equity interest in Citgo; the year also included an extraordinary charge of $56,047,000 resulting from debt exchange. c-After income from discontinued operations of $29,063,000, or 14 cents a share, for the quarter and $69,001,000, or 34 cents a share, for the year.

title: N.C.A.A. May Still Try to Ban Tarkanian
description: Jerry Tarkanian, the 59-year-old Nevada-Las Vegas basketball coach, whose team won the national championship tonight, may face a suspension and his school may receive additional sanctions in connection with infractions by the basketball program that were cited in 1977.

title: Tabloid Plan In Kansas City
description: Stephen F. Rose, president and co-publisher of Sun Publications Inc., has announced plans to introduce on May 14 a five-day tabloid newspaper called The Evening News. He said the paper would fill a void created when the Kansas City Star Company closed its afternoon paper on March 1 and merged it with the morning Times.

title: Shearson Sees Loss of $917 Million
description: Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. announced yesterday that it will post a loss of as much as $917 million for the first quarter, the largest such deficit in Wall Street history.

title: Applied Power reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Gallimard Case In Higher Court
description: France's largest independent publisher, Editions Gallimard, faced an uncertain future today after a court failed to settle a damaging family dispute for control of the company.

title: Edward O. Curran, 87, Nestle General Counsel
description: Edward Owen Curran, former secretary and general counsel of the Nestle Foods Company, died after a long illness at a nursing home in Waterville, Me. He was 87 years old and lived in Waterville.

title: North Finds Security In Bulletproof Vests
description: Oliver L. North and Joseph F. Fernandez, comrades-in-arms in the Iran-contra affair, are back in business. They are manufacturing and selling bulletproof vests, which Mr. North says he wears himself.

title: Forum Retirement Partners reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Kerr Closing In on Records as He Reels Off the 3-Point Shots
description: The soft jump shots that once drove Arizona Wildcat fans into frenzied chants of ''STEEE-VEE KERRR!'' are once again finding the range at the Richfield Coliseum. With last September's trade to the Cleveland Cavaliers, the freckle-faced Kerr, a disappointing 1988 second-round draft choice who rode the bench for the Phoenix Suns, found a new basketball life. No longer the main man he was in college, he has settled in as a role player.

title: ATWATER ENTERS HOSPITAL IN BRONX
description: Lee Atwater, the Republican national chairman, entered the Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx yesterday for a specialized radiation procedure to reduce the potential growth of a brain tumor, his office said.

title: Purchasers Say Slump Is Slowing
description: The nation's economy continued to be in a slump in March, although the rate of decline slowed as production and new orders for export rose significantly, according to a report by an association of the nation's purchasing managers.

title: Staging a 'Grapes' of Dust, Fog, Fire and Blood
description: It was backstage, minutes before the opening performance of ''The Grapes of Wrath'' on Broadway, and the show's 35 cast members were staring nervously at Frank Galati, the play's director. ''John Steinbeck sat in this very theater and heard the language of Shakespeare,'' Mr. Galati said slowly, as the crowd buzzed beyond the curtain in the Cort Theater.

title: Landmark Land Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said 1989 results included writedowns of $4.6 million made on properties located in Louisiana and Oklahoma. The writedowns represent a revaluation by the company based onteh slowdown of the respective economies. The company also said the results for the latest fourth quarter included $42,900 revenue from large bulk land sales with $23,400 gros profit.

title: Dow Off Only 6.76 Despite Tokyo's Plunge
description: After shaking off another sharp decline in the Tokyo stock market, stock prices on the New York Stock Exchange bounced back yesterday in slow trading, with the Dow Jones industrial average ending the day at 2,700.45, down 6.76 points.

title: Salomon Office In East Berlin
description: Salomon Brothers Inc., the Wall Street investment house, announced it was opening an office through a subsidiary in East Berlin. The office will be run by West German professionals from the subsidiary, Salomon Brothers A.G. in Frankfurt, as well as executives from East Germany.

title: Conviction of Pathe's Chief Clouds Deal for MGM/UA
description: News that the head of the Pathe Communications Corporation had been convicted on bankruptcy fraud charges in Italy raised further questions yesterday about whether his pending $20-a-share, $1.22 billion acquisition of the MGM/UA Communications Company would go through.

title: Fire Tests Dinkins as Leader in Crisis
description: Responding to his first big emergency, the Happy Land Social Club fire, Mayor David N. Dinkins has displayed the doggedness and compassion that brought him political success, as well as the defensiveness and fuzziness that sometimes characterize his reaction to criticism.

title: Reviews/Dance;   Ballet of Los Angeles With 2 Soviet Guests
description: Just as actors need good plays, dancers need good ballets. On Saturday night at Queensborough Community College, the Ballet of Los Angeles revealed itself to be an attractive troupe trained to move in a vigorous, athletic but never exaggeratedly forceful manner. Provided it assembles a worthy repertory, the little company - it has only 10 regular members - might well become the balletic equivalent of a chamber-music ensemble.

title: Edward Fireman, 68, Astrophysicist, Is Dead
description: Edward L. Fireman, an astrophysicist who was an authority on the analysis of space debris, died of a heart attack on Thursday. He was 68 years old and lived in Newton, Mass.

title: Quake Jars Central England
description: An earthquake shook a broad swath of England and Wales today, emptying buildings and sending hundreds of frightened people into the streets. There were no immediate reports of injuries or serious damage. The quake, which geologists said registered 5.2 on the Richter scale, was believed to have been centered west of Nottingham in central England. It was felt from the outskirts of London to south Wales, and north through Birmingham, Coventry and Manchester to the Scottish border, police stations around the country reported.

title: Treasuries Fall in Light Trading
description: Prices of Treasury securities dipped slightly in light trading yesterday, despite the big drop earlier in Japanese equity prices.

title: HIGH COURT BACKS STAY OF EXECUTION
description: A California inmate has been spared the death penalty, at least temporarily, because the United States Supreme Court upheld a stay of execution in a 6-to-3 vote late today.

title: America's Catholic Bishops Move Closer to Pope on Women's Issues
description: A committee of Roman Catholic bishops in the United States, revising a major statement on the Catholic Church and women's concerns, has retreated from the liberal tone and content of important sections in a draft issued two years ago.

title: Winston Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Iraq Can Deliver, U.S. Chemical Arms Experts Say
description: American experts on chemical warfare said today that Iraq had chemical weapons and the means to fire them into Israeli territory, as President Saddam Hussein of Iraq said today.

title: Xerox Names President To Be Chief Executive
description: The Xerox Corporation yesterday named its president, Paul A. Allaire, to succeed David T. Kearns as chief executive on Aug. 1. Mr. Kearns will remain chairman.

title: Profit Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Oil Company Agrees to Buy Homes of Those Who Sued It
description: Conoco said today that it had agreed to buy the homes of 400 families here who sued the company, saying their underground water was contaminated by toxic chemicals from a nearby oil refinery.

title: Ecologists Act to Save Ancient Fores in Chile From Industry
description: FEARING that some of the oldest trees in the world are threatened by a burgeoning pulp industry, an international effort has begun to buy and preserve vast tracts of temperate forest in the south of Chile.

title: Magadan And Ojeda Demoted
description: Davey Johnson solved the ''numbers problem'' on the Mets today by relegating two of his most popular players to lesser jobs: Bob Ojeda to the bullpen, Dave Magadan to the bench. And both players admitted they were devastated by the moves.

title: No Decisions On Mark Yet, Kohl Says
description: Moving to stifle the rising furor over proposals for monetary union, Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany said today that no decisions had been made. He also appointed a leading official of West Germany's powerful central bank as his personal adviser on uniting the two nation's currencies.

title: Reviews/Music;   On 6 Strings and on Many
description: Julian Bream, the English guitarist who was also a pioneer of the early-music movement on the lute in the 1950's and 60's, set that instrument aside a decade ago, feeling, he acknowledged recently, that the movement's young lions had to some extent passed him by and that he needed to take stock of his achievement. On his current tour he is making a heralded return to the lute, playing a 10-course model (larger than his previous instrument), and he devoted the first half of his recital in Kaufmann Concert Hall at the 92d Street Y on Saturday evening to the instrument.

title: Reviews/Music;   Gilbert and Sullivan Yield To Gershwin and Ryskind
description: When the Gilbert and Sullivan Players decided to extend their repertory beyond the Savoyard classics that the company has performed exclusively for the last 16 years, they couldn't have made a more felicitous choice of a vehicle to make the break from tradition than ''Of Thee I Sing.''

title: Strober Organization reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Strategies Show Sharp Contrasts in Marcos Trial
description: The Government's case against Imelda Marcos will emerge in the fine print. There will be bank accounts and details of financial transactions and documents describing holdings around the world, from Switzerland to New York to Hong Kong.

title: Deliberations Start on L.I. Killing
description: The prosecutor in the Robert Golub trial said today that the defendant had both the opportunity and the means to kill Kelly Ann Tinyes after she had resisted his sexual advances.

title: Community Psychiatric Ceners reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Year-ago revenues included a gain of $747,000 atrributable to a skilled nursing facility in Louisiana; this facility was not in operation during the first quarter of 1990. Year-ago share earnings of 39 cents a share included 4 cents a share attributable to a capital gain on the sale of an old hospital physical plant net of a loss on the sale of a marketable security.

title: Comerica in Deal
description: Comerica Inc. said it had agreed to acquire Inbancshares, a bank holding company based in City of Industry, Calif., for $20.25 a share, or about $40 million. The acquisition, which is subject to regulatory approval, would add $242 million to Comerica's assets of about $12 billion. Inbancshares has four offices and 70 employees.

title: Maloney Playing on Other Side of Rivalry
description: When a player steps on the ice of Madison Square Garden in the uniform of the Islanders and faces the hostile crowd of Manhattan, ''You feel such animosity, such hatred,'' said Don Maloney, the only man on either current roster who has played for both teams.

title: Eastern Plan for Creditors
description: The president of Eastern Airlines is expected to outline a new proposal today aimed at persuading unsecured creditors to back away from their tough stand of last week, a person close to the creditors said.

title: Japonica Rejects Allegheny's Plan
description: Allegheny International Inc. said its bankruptcy reorganization plan had been rejected by Japonica Partners, which is seeking to acquire the Sunbeam appliance and lawn furniture company. Japonica had offered to buy the company for $650 million under the bankruptcy proceedings, but Allegheney advanced its own plan instead.

title: Ancient Relative
description: A crushed but nearly complete skull unearthed in Egypt appears to be the oldest higher primate specimen found to date that is closely related to humans.

title: H. F. Ahmanson Plans Expansion in New York
description: H. F. Ahmanson & Company moved to expand in New York today by agreeing to acquire the Home Savings Bank of New York in a stock deal valued at approximately $300 million.

title: Nucorp Inc.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Elsinore reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss from extinguishment of debt of $7,704,000. c-Net income and included an extraordinary loss from extinguishment of debt of $3,362,000 and an extraordinary tax credit of $4,259,000, or 31 cents a share. Year-ago results included operations from the Hyatt Lake Tahoe Hotel and Casino through July 31, 1988. Latest year's loss from continuing operations of $7,704,000 included provision for investment losses of $9,433,000. Year-ago income from continuing operations of $12,694,000, or 93 cents a share, included gain from sale of Hyatt Lake Tahoe Hotel and Casino of $28,757,000 and provision for investment losses of $25,438,000.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Avery International Corp., Pasadena, Calif., a manufacturer of office products and specialty chemicals, announced the retirement of Richard J. Pearson as president and chief operating officer, effective July 1. Charles D. Miller, chairman and chief executive, will take the additional title of president. Avery appointed Philip M. Neal executive vice president, responsible for worldwide operations.

title: Maynard Oil reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included $1,585,946 and $1,038,559 of gains from property sales for 1989 and 1988, respectively.

title: First Executive Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $55,829,000, or 66 cents a share, from a cumulative effect on prior periods of an accounting change. c-Net income The latest quarter and year's results included a charge of about $150 million from write-down of a subsidiary. Year-ago results are restated to reflect change in method of accounting.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Drive to Aid Children Has New Twist
description: WHEN Hal Donofrio learned about a new academic study suggesting that broad marketing campaigns were more effective than public service advertising in persuading people to change their behavior, he smiled and wondered what took the professors so long.

title: Las Vegas Hits Jackpot in a Record Runaway
description: All the pent-up fury of a season marked by injuries and marred by suspensions and implications about the character of the team exploded this evening as the University of Nevada-Las Vegas won its first national championship by demolishing Duke, 103-73, in an unrelenting exhibition of pressure basketball.

title: Barbara B. Gratwick; Teacher, 83
description: Barbara Burnett Gratwick, a teacher who was the widow of Dr. Mitchell Gratwick, former headmaster of the Horace Mann School in Manhattan, died of pneumonia on Saturday at the Saddleback Memorial Medical Center in Laguna Hills, Calif., while visiting her children. She was 83 years old and lived in Philadelphia and Vinalhaven, Me.

title: Bush Open to Space Voyages With Soviet Union
description: PRESIDENT BUSH has embraced the idea of cooperating with the Soviet Union in the manned exploration of the solar system, including voyages to the Moon and Mars, White House officials said yesterday.

title: Martin W. Juster, 71, Real-Estate Developer
description: Martin W. Juster, a real-estate developer in Manhattan and Westchester in the 1950's and 60's, died of a heart attack on Saturday at the United Hospital in Harrison, N.Y. He was 71 years old and lived in Boca Raton, Fla.

title: Tourism Rises in Israel
description: The number of tourists visiting Israel in 1989 rose by 9.7 percent despite the Palestinian revolt in the Israeli-occupied territories, the Tourism Ministry said today. It said 1,425,000 people visited the Jewish state last year, up from 1,299,000 in 1988. Foreign currency receipts, including Israeli airline income from foreigners, rose 9.1 percent, to $1.8 billion, in 1989, from $1.65 billion in the previous year.

title: Procyte Corp. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Heart Association Cancels Its Program to Rate Foods
description: Besieged by stinging criticism and threats of strong Government action, the American Heart Association announced yesterday that it was canceling its program to award a seal of approval, for a fee, to foods that meet certain low-fat, low-salt guidelines. The sharply debated program, Heart Guide, was made public only two months ago.

title: Presidio Oil Co. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said these results reflected less than a month of operating results from its acquisition of substantially all of the oil and gas assets of Home Petroleum Corp. on Dec. 31, 1989, for $157 million.

title: Auto Pollution Has Decreased for a Decade;   Raise Tax on Gas
description: To the Editor:

title: Chief's Patient Vision Faces Test at Cummins
description: Henry B. Schacht, once hailed as the ''king of the Rust Belt'' for patiently trying to make the Cummins Engine Company as efficient as its Japanese rivals, is under fire.

title: He's More George Than Sparky Now
description: rrOut near the right-field fence, Sparky Anderson, his white hair shining in the sun, was running his pitchers. Trotting by, each pitcher tossed the Detroit Tiger manager a baseball, then sprinted toward the foul line before turning to catch what resembled a short forward pass.

title: Careers;   Training With Focus On Service
description: WITH the nature of customer service changing, a new type of worker is needed - one who can make the most of the latest technology. That was the message of Sandra G. Tuck at a recent meeting held by the management consulting firm Booz, Allen & Hamilton Inc.

title: International Power Machines reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Harry S. Robinson 2d; Shoe Executive, 69
description: Harry S. Robinson 2d, a retired executive of the United States Shoe Corporation, died of cancer on Friday at his home in Cincinnati. He was 69 years old.

title: Charles A. Matthews; Politician, 72
description: Charles A. Matthews, a former Essex County (N.J.) Freeholder, died on Thursday at the Hospital Center of Orange, N.J. He was 72 years old and lived in Newark.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Walter Carl Kehm; Lawyer, 63
description: Walter Carl Kehm, a lawyer and conservationist, died of a heart attack on Saturday at his home in Rye, N.Y. He was 63 years old.

title: Review/Music;   New Works for New Ears
description: The Kronos Quartet made one of its regular stops at Alice Tully Hall on Saturday night and, in the process, gave the listener a chance to reconsider one of the concert business's success stories.

title: Corrections
description: The American League schedule in the Sports section on Sunday included several errors. A corrected version appears today on page B8.

title: Nostalgia Network reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a non-recurring charge of $671,853 for the quarter and year.

title: Tony Lama reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Patterns
description: The Lauren Girl

title: Matthews & Wright Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
General Devices reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Our Towns;   Stringed Jewel Or Fake Fiddle? Wait 4 Seconds
description: From all over the world they come, to an ordinary suburban street here full of high ranch houses, reverently ascending the steps of the one with green aluminum siding. A polite woman, Maria, greets them, leading them down to the basement, where her husband, the master, Dario D'Attili, sits at his desk, passing judgment on their violins.

title: Deal to Sell Padres
description: An investment group headed by the Hollywood producer Tom Werner signed a letter of intent yesterday to purchase the San Diego Padres, the club owner, Joan Kroc, said.

title: Research in 'Virgin' Amazon Uncovers Complex Farming
description: OVER thousands of years, scientists have discovered, ancient inhabitants of the Amazon and their present-day descendants have evolved a sophisticated blend of agricultural and forestry techniques to shape and reshape the region's vast forests, savannas and river valleys to their needs.

title: Chronicle
description: Delivering on a promise made 21 years ago, IDA CHAGALL has presented the Israel Museum with 103 works of art by her father, MARC CHAGALL. TEDDY KOLLEK, the Mayor of Jerusalem, brought them from Paris last week and they will go on exhibit in September at the museum, which Mr. Kollek founded.

title: Chronicle
description: The single constant in the career of MAURICE BEJART has been controversy. So the dance world awaits the premiere of his new work, ''Pyramide,'' with some anticipation. It is to be staged in front of the pyramids of Giza May 17-25.

title: L.I. Departure At Doubleday
description: Doubleday Book and Music Clubs Inc. will move its customer service operation from Garden City, L.I., to Indianapolis, beginning in August.

title: Vestro Foods Inc.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and after an extraordinary credit of $5,000.

title: Estonia Sends Firmer Signal to Moscow
description: The new Parliament of Estonia told President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today that the Soviet Constitution could not be the basis for realizing the republic's wish to be independent of the Soviet Union.

title: Triangle Home Products reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Savings-Unit Sales Pressed
description: Under pressure to move more quickly in cleaning up the ailing savings and loan industry, Federal regulators said today that they hoped to sell the Miami-based Centrust Bank and 10 other large savings institutions by June.

title: Happy Land Arrest Order Ignored in 1989
description: A warrant was issued last year for the arrest of the owner of the building that housed the Happy Land Social Club after he failed to show up in court to answer complaints about safety conditions in the club, city records show.

title: Business Digest
description: Companies

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-14

title: 27-Man Roster Approved Until April 30
description: The 27-man roster that was, then wasn't, will be.

title: Helene Curtis Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Franco Renzulli, 54, Played in Piano Duo
description: Franco Renzulli, of the Phillips and Renzulli concert piano duo, died on March 26. He was 54 years old and lived in East Patchogue, L.I.

title: Iraq's Murderous Threats
description: Brazen blackmail - that's how Iraq's President, Saddam Hussein, reacts to being caught red-handed trying again to build nuclear weapons. Now he threatens to destroy half of Israel with chemical-armed missiles if Israel attacks his weapons factories. The threat from a leader who already has mercilessly used chemical arms cannot go unanswered by civilized powers.

title: Charles Spain Verral, Adventure Writer, 85
description: Charles Spain Verral, a prolific author of books on adventure, sports and other subjects, died of complications from lung cancer on Sunday at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 85 years old and lived in Greenwich Village.

title: Noriega Defense Depicts Invasion as 'War Crime'
description: In a spirited pretrial hearing, defense lawyers demanded today that the drug trafficking case against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega be dropped because the United States invasion of Panama was a ''war crime'' that resulted in a ''holocaust'' among innocent civilians.

title: Iraq Chief, Boasting of Poison Gas, Warns of Disaster if Israelis Strike
description: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, boasting that he had acquired advanced chemical weapons, threatened today to annihilate half of Israel if it moved against his country.

title: GWIL Industries reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss of $598,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary credit of $2,623,000, or 38 cents a share. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, an article on Sunday about liquid diets omitted a passage in some copies from a paragraph about a scientific conference in Washington. The full paragraph should have read, ''In Washington tomorrow [Monday] , at a conference of the American Federation of the American Societies for Experimental Biology, Dr. Adam Drenowski, director of Human Nutrition at the University of Michigan, is to present findings that yo-yo dieting, cycles of rapid weight loss and gain frequently associated with liquid formula diets, creates a craving for calorie-dense mixtures of sugar and fat.''

title: Velazquez Show Closes; Dozens Turned Away
description: About 40 angry people pounded on the doors of the Prado Museum shortly after midnight Sunday in a futile attempt to see a wildly popular exhibition of 80 paintings by the 17th-century Spanish master Diego Velazquez.

title: Tofutti Brands Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 30
'Junk Bonds' Cause Loss At Insurer
description: The First Executive Corporation, one of the companies most heavily invested in ''junk bonds,'' today reported a larger-than-expected loss for the fourth quarter of last year, reflecting the turmoil in the market for the high-risk, high-yield securities.

title: A Question of Ethics: Should Alcoholics Get Transplanted Livers?
description: IN teaching a medical class about the ethics of organ transplantation, Dr. Calvin R. Stiller wanted to stress how biases affect the selection of recipients, particularly those needing new livers because of alcoholic cirrhosis.

title: Concord Fabrics Inc. reports earnings for 13wks to Mar 4
description: Year-ago results were for 13 weeks and 26 weeks ended Feb. 26, 1989.

title: Silence and the Sick in Albany
description: The ugly, continuing battle over New York State's overdue new budget is not the only reason to despair about the State Senate. Its truculence on taxes is matched by its indifference to the suffering of terminally ill patients.

title: Independents Offer an Education Aid Bargain
description: To the Editor:

title: Spartan Motors Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Albany Budget Standoff Starts, but 4 Emergency Spending Bills Pass
description: The Capitol settled in today for what many officials fear will be a long vigil as Democratic and Republican state leaders remained at a standoff over a new budget.

title: Torchmark Withdraws American General Bid
description: The Torchmark Corporation said today that it had withdrawn its $6.4 billion offer to acquire the much larger American General Corporation, but added that it would try to win a third of the seats on the company's board at the annual shareholders meeting on May 2.

title: Miami Names Hamilton
description: Oklahoma State's head coach, Leonard Hamilton, was named yesterday as the new basketball coach at the University of Miami.

title: Guam to Drop Abortion Charges
description: The prosecution dropped charges today against an American Civil Liberties Union lawyer accused of violating the new abortion law here by encouraging others to seek abortions.

title: Chess
description: Homework in chess is not just mastering yesterday's lessons. That's merely the starting point for the real effort - original thinking.

title: Ex-Police Chief Runs for Washington Mayor
description: Asserting that Washington was in governmental crisis and in need of new leadership, a former Police Chief, Maurice T. Turner Jr., announced today that he would run for mayor.

title: Oak Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $4,335,000 for the quarter and $6,387,000 for the year. c-Net income and after income from discontinued operations of $185,000 for the quarter and $468,000 for the year.

title: Nicaragua Devaluation
description: Nicaragua's central bank on Sunday announced a 1.3 percent devaluation of the cordoba against the United States dollar. The official exchange rate rose to 47,000 cordobas to $1, from 46,380. In addition, the departing Sandinista Government announced a 10 percent rise in the price of a gallon of gasoline, to 85,500 cordobas.

title: Cambex Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 3
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Mexico Selects Saatchi Again
description: The Mexican Government's search for a new ad agency concluded for the third time in four months yesterday with Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising in New York reappointed to do the nation's tourism ads.

title: In Bulgaria's Balkan Politics, Splits Even Within the Splits
description: A kind of bewilderment seems to pervade the life of the Bulgarians more than four months after the bloodless overthrow of a repressive Communist Government and two months before scheduled national elections.

title: Bobbie Brooks reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a full year of preferred stock dividend requirements of $2,525,000. c-Included five months of preferred stock dividend requirements of $1,021,000.

title: Results Plus
description: TENNIS

title: Trammell Crow Will Refinance 150 Properties
description: The Trammell Crow Company, the nation's largest commercial real estate developer, said today that one of the largest United States insurers had provided $456 million to allow the refinancing of more than 150 of its commercial properties, mainly in the Southwest.

title: Rig Count Springs Back
description: The number of working United States oil and gas rigs made a turnaround last week, increasing by 53, to a total of 946, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. The week's increase reversed a downward slide in the rig count - a historical occurrence in the first three months of the year. Baker Hughes's rig count, a widely watched industry index of drilling activity, reflects the number of rotary rigs actively exploring for oil and gas as of last Friday, not the number of wells in production. A year ago, the rig count totaled 779.

title: Q&A
description: The Buds of Spring

title: A Course For Typists Tailored To Fit
description: IN the age of the personal computer, knowing touch-typing is more important than ever. There are plenty of programs that turn a computer into a typing teacher and a new one, AXS Type Write 3 in 1, has a lot to recommend it.

title: U.S. Regains Export Lead
description: The United States regained its position last year as the world's leading exporter, passing West Germany, the International Monetary Fund said on Sunday.

title: Fannie Mae Offers Securities For Low-Interest Mortgages
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, yesterday introduced Fannie Mae Affordables, financial instruments intended to assist financial institutions that are members of the nation's 12 Federal Home Loan Banks and provide a new source of money for loans at below-market interest rates for home buyers of modest means.

title: Chronicle
description: In the revolving door: ANN GODOFF, vice president and executive editor of Atlantic Monthly Press, left that job on March 9 to go to Doubleday as executive editor. Three weeks later, she is back at Atlantic.

title: Dodgers Hope Samuel Can Be Their Spark
description: Not long after the Los Angeles Dodgers acquired Juan Samuel from the Mets last December, Tommy Lasorda made a good-will visit to the Dominican Republic. His diplomatic mission: make Samuel feel better -make him happy, if possible - about playing center field for the Dodgers, who desperately needed a center fielder.

title: German Union Instills Vision Of a Great Continent Reborn
description: When European business leaders describe their vision of Europe, they usually talk of building a bigger, more united, more dynamic continent. German unification fits neatly into that vision.

title: Herbalife International reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Books of The Times;   Going Home Again, and Finding You Can't
description: In a Father's Place

title: Publisher for Children A Canada Success Story
description: Nearly 10 years ago Valerie Hussey went to her first Bologna Book Fair for children. As the new publisher of Kids Can Press here, she was looking to buy more than sell. At this year's fair, being held this week, the opposite is true.

title: Top Officer for Operations Is Appointed by Booz, Allen
description: Booz, Allen & Hamilton Inc., the management consulting firm based in New York, has named William F. Stasior as its president and chief operating officer, whose role will be to oversee day-to-day operations.

title: Chrysler Urges Officials To Buy More of Its Stock
description: The Chrysler Corporation has asked 100 senior executives to invest a greater share of their wealth in the company's future by purchasing Chrysler stock.

title: Japan Acts To Raise Imports
description: In an effort to reduce trade tensions with the United States, Japan outlined proposals today to curb some of the more pervasive policy and cultural obstacles to American imports.

title: Concern Over 'Moral Values' Led To Family Murders, Lawyer Says
description: John E. List, a man of rigid religious principles, became so alarmed by the threat to the salvation of his family posed by societal changes that started in the 1960's that he killed them ''with love in his heart,'' his lawyer told a jury today.

title: Spill That Imperiled Water Passes Down the Allegheny
