description: The worst of a fuel spill that threatened the drinking water of a million people passed down the Allegheny River today and cities including Pittsburgh were preparing to end their water emergencies tonight.

title: Starving Children of Malawi Kill Leader's Boast of Plenty
description: For the 26 years of his authoritarian rule in Malawi, President H. Kamuzu Banda has insisted that human rights, white power in a black state and coziness with South Africa are minor matters compared with the full stomachs of his people. Now, as it turns out, many young and infant Malawians do not have full stomachs either.

title: U.S. Gaining Ground at U.N., State Department Study Says
description: The United States is winning greater support for its views on international issues as ideological rivalries ease, the State Department says in its annual report on voting trends at last year's General Assembly.

title: Unfair Smoke, S & L Fire
description: The problems of the savings and loan bailout are compounding, each mistake made worse by the one before:

title: Kurzweil Music Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said the share earnings reflect reductions for accrued dividends on its series E preferred stock.

title: Chronicle
description: In the land of Moliere, theater has never been less popular. So Mayor JACQUES CHIRAC of Paris, in a rare imitation of an American practice, is giving out two theater tickets for the price of one. Although Paris boasts 100,000 theater seats, attendance has plummeted in recent years, partly because of the increasing popularity of television and movies, and partly because of high ticket prices.

title: Johnson Ban to Go On
description: After his two-year international suspension for the use of steroids ends in September, Ben Johnson of Canada will be barred from Grand Prix and other invitational meets in England.

title: Transtech Industries reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and after income from discontinued operations of $22,436,909, or $4.61 a share.

title: Review/Television;   The New Days in Leningrad Are Freer, Not Easier
description: The ''National Geographic Specials'' end their 25th season tomorrow night with a thoughtful visit to Leningrad that combines an appreciation of the city's past with concern for its people's future. The glimpses of tradition in ''Voices of Leningrad'' include the first solo, in ''The Nutcracker,'' of 12-year-old Ira Novikova, a student at the Vaganova Choreographic Institute, once the school of the Imperial Maryinsky Theater, whose alumni include Anna Pavlova, Vaslav Nijinsky and Mikhail Baryshnikov. But a much bigger audience is seen screaming its admiration for Kino, a rock band that has been permitted to blast out of the underground in recent years.

title: Live Entertainment reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest sales included $52,202,000 from Strawberries, a music and video retail chain acquired last July. Included is other income of $6,236,000 versus $7,241,000. In 1989, this item was mainly comprised of the gain on teh sale of its videocassette manufacturing company.

title: Reviews/Dance;   Vignettes of Life and Death From the Juilliard Ensemble
description: The Juilliard Dance Ensemble examined some of the joys and sorrows of life on Friday night at the Juilliard Theater.

title: PC Quote reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Southland Reports Loss Of $1.01 Billion in Period
description: The Southland Corporation, the owner of 7-Eleven convenience stores, said today that it had lost $1.01 billion in the fourth quarter of last year and that it might seek bankruptcy if it could not restructure its debt.

title: Maxtor in Offer For Miniscribe
description: The Maxtor Corporation, a disk drive company, said today that it had offered to purchase most of the assets of the Miniscribe Corporation of Longmont, Colo., in a $40 million cash-and-stock deal.

title: Court to Decide Damage Award Issue
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a jury's award of punitive damages can be so excessive or disproportionate as to violate the Constitution's guarantee of due process of law.

title: Savings Chief Nomination
description: The Senate majority leader, George Mitchell, in his first comments on President Bush's nominee as the nation's top savings and loan regulator, said today that he and many other senators had doubts whether T. Timothy Ryan Jr. was qualified.

title: Roadmaster Industries reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary prepayment fee of $876,000 incurred upon refinancing.

title: Dinkins's Extra Taxes Add Up to $200 Million
description: Strapped by persistent revenue shortfalls and planned cuts in state aid, the Dinkins administration has suggested $200 million more in new or higher taxes on items from dry cleaning to automobiles. The potential increases come on top of $550 million in taxes it is already seeking, city officials said yesterday.

title: Devices Help Scientists Find Supernovas
description: ALTHOUGH supernovas are the most violent of all cosmic events visible from the Earth, most of these stellar explosions are hard to detect, either because they are enormously far away or because they are dimmed by intervening dust and gas clouds. But new devices that search the heavens automatically for faint new supernovas have begun to quicken the pace of discovery.

title: Dead, Too, for the Peris, Is the American Dream
description: On the same day Carlos Roberto Peri came home in a coffin from New York, another plane arrived with his American-born 5-month-old son, bringing tears of joy to a heartbroken family.

title: Pension Fund Rating Shift
description: The California Public Employees Retirement Systems, considered by some to be the nation's most influential pension fund, said today that it had started a system to evaluate corporate performance that will help it with investment decisions.

title: By Design;   The Big and the Bold
description: Accessories are getting bigger and bolder. And the drift is from the wrists to the throat and shoulders.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   A Magazine Is Coming Along With the Menu
description: A new venture owned by a specialty publishing concern and a company that owns restaurants is stapling menus inside a new general interest magazine called Knife & Fork. The magazine is being given to restaurant customers.

title: Auto Pollution Has Decreased for a Decade;   Let the Traffic Flow
description: To the Editor:

title: Congress Didn't Want to See. . .
description: I wheeled my way up to both houses of Congress in recent months to testify in support of legislation bearing my name: the Brady bill. It would require a national seven-day waiting period for handgun sales from gun dealers. The bill is intended to give police departments time to run a background check on the purchaser, to deny instant access of a concealable weapon to a known felon or to another John W. Hinckley Jr. I believe that if the bill had been law in March 1981, Mr. Hinckley would not have been able to purchase the handgun he used against President Ronald Reagan, and I would not have been wounded and disabled.

title: Weak Profits Seen for Banks Hurt by Real Estate Loans
description: With the almost daily reports of losses from bad real estate loans, many large banking companies are expected to report weak profits for the first quarter.

title: Hopper Soliday Corp. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain on early extinguishment of debt of $98,687, or 5 cents a share.

title: Ricoh Picks U.S. Chief
description: Hishashi Kubo, credited with the 1981 marketing strategy that gave Japan's Ricoh copy machines a toehold in the United States market, has been named chairman of the company's American subsidiary, the company announced today. The West Caldwell, N.J., copier unit's sales in the United States grew from $15 million in 1979 to $650 million in 1986, when Mr. Kubo moved back to the parent company's headquarters in Tokyo to become vice president of sales and marketing. Mr. Kubo replaces Keiji Endoh, who has been appointed managing director of the parent company in charge of commercial affairs.

title: INSIDE
description: Mandela to Meet de Klerk

title: Yale to Pay Millions in New Municipal Fees
description: Yale University agreed yesterday to pay $2.6 million to deficit-burdened New Haven and promised a loan of $7.5 million if the city raised $22.5 million from other donors.

title: Australian Merger
description: The Australia and New Zealand Banking Group announced it would merge with National Mutual Life Association, making it the biggest financial institution in Australia. A.N.Z. said it would pay $2.5 billion for a 51 percent stake in National Mutual. The merger, scheduled for Oct. 1, must be approved by regulators and National Mutual policyholders. The merger will give the group assets of $98 billion, compared with $89 billion held by Westpac Bank, currently Australia's largest bank.

title: Devils Enjoy Luxury Of Strong Goaltending
description: Having to choose between two hot goaltenders is a luxury for every coach in hockey and John Cunniff of the Devils is in that position going into the playoff series against the Washington Capitals.

title: Nepalese Police Reported to Fire On Political Dissidents, Killing 5
description: The police opened fire today on protesters demanding legalization of political parties in Nepal, killing at least 5 people and wounding 17, hospital workers and witnesses said.

title: Rite Aid Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 3
description: b-After income of $20,165,000, or 49 cents a share, from discontinued operations. c-After income from discontinued operations of $1,022,000, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and $3,094,000, or 8 cents a share, for the year. The latest year's income from continuing operations included one-time pre-tax charge of $22 million for video rental department closings and one- time after-tax gain of $18,370,000 from sale of interest in Super Rite Foods Inc. The latest periods were comprised of 13 weeks for the quarter and 52 weeks for the year, compared with 14 weeks and 53 weeks for year-ago periods, respectively. The year-ago periods were restated to reflect operations discontinued in fiscal 1990.

title: Hotel Investors reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $156,000, or 1 cent a share, and also included is a provision for loss of $55.8 million related to the Hotel portfolio, two gaming properties and goodwill. c-Net income and after an extraordinary credit of $2,619,000, or 22 cents a share.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the stock market's recent performance omitted a reason for the decline in the Incstar Corporation's share price. The company paid a large one-time dividend during the first quarter.

title: Told to Ignore Policy Questions, Jury Deliberates Poindexter Case
description: The jury in the trial of John M. Poindexter began weighing five criminal charges against the former national security adviser today after the judge instructed the jurors to disregard whether President Ronald Reagan's policies in the Iran-contra affair were ''wise or unwise.''

title: Auto Pollution Has Decreased for a Decade;   Tollbooth Syndrome
description: To the Editor:

title: Buffalo Settles Transit Dispute On Its 2d Day
description: A two-day shutdown of Buffalo's transit system caused by a dispute between the city and its suburbs over how to finance the system ended tonight.

title: Simcoe Erie Investors reports earnings for Year Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Gretzky Probably Out Of Playoff Opener
description: The Los Angeles Kings' coach, Tom Webster, said yesterday that Wayne Gretzky would probably miss the team's playoff opener tomorrow night against the Calgary Flames because of a back injury.

title: S. Zachary Swidler, Lawyer, 72
description: S. Zachary Swidler, a tax law specialist and a founder of Swidler & Swidler law firm, died of heart disease on Friday at New York Hospital. He was 72 years old and moved last year from Manhattan to Boynton Beach, Fla.

title: 'Cold Fusion' Claimants Review Puzzling Results
description: For believers, the central mystery surrounding ''cold fusion'' is what is happening in experiments that have been frustratingly erratic. For skeptics it is why the field does not die.

title: I.C.H.  Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $2,643,000, or 5 cents a share for both the quarter and year. c-Net income and included an extraordinary credit of $1,800,000, or 4 cents a share for both the quarter and year. Latest quarter and year's losses from continuing operations of $250,182,000 and $338,868,000, respectively, included pretax losses from the 20 percent interest in First Executive of $204.8 million for the quarter and $202 million for the year, and pretax realized investment losses of $57.7 million and $87.8 million for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also included a pretax loss on subsidiary sales of $118 million. The company said a pretax loss of $104 million from the sale of certain subsidiaries to Life Partners Group Inc., formerly HMS Acquisition Corp., is included in the 1989 results. These results also included a pretax loss of about $14 million from the December 1989 sale of Great Southern Life to Financial Holding Co. The year-ago quarter and year's income from continuing operations of $11,733,000 and $26,245,000, respectively, included pretax gains from stake in First Executive of $4.6 million for the quarter and $12 million for the year, and pretax realized investment losses of $13.5 million and $20 million for the quarter and year, respectively. Year-ago results are restated.

title: Seder's 5th Question: Why Do Holiday Prices Rise?
description: Fifteen hundred years ago the authors of the Talmud fretted over the high price of Passover goods in ancient Babylon. And if one listens to the talk in the aisles of supermarkets and butcher shops in and around New York City these days, it seems that little has changed.

title: Trips Through Geography and Time
description: AS the school year wanes, it is time to put two educational software programs on the honor roll of the class of 1990.

title: PARTY CHIEF QUITS IN EAST GERMANY
description: The founder and chairman of the East German Social Democratic Party resigned today, the second victim of allegations of a compromised past that have haunted East Germany's transition to democracy.

title: Seltz Journal;   Alsace: Its French-German Nerves Are Showing
description: The villages along this side of the Rhine all have German names, the architecture is pure Hansel-and-Gretel and, to the uninitiated at least, the local language sounds little different from that spoken in Berlin. Today, though, the population is as proudly French as it is Alsatian.

title: Rockwell Accord
description: LOS ANGELES, April 2 - COMPANY NEWS

title: KEY RATES
Israelis Report the Capture Of an Infiltrator From Jordan
description: Soldiers captured an armed Jordanian soldier today after he had infiltrated into the occupied West Bank, approached an Israeli collective farm and hidden near a Palestinian village, the army said.

title: LITHUANIA LEADER SOFTENS HIS TONE TOWARD MOSCOW
description: After three weeks of tension, discord and daily pressure from Moscow, the leadership of Lithuania softened its tone today, insisting that it never expected immediate independence despite declaring itself free of Soviet rule on March 11.

title: Blass Isn't Looking Over His Shoulder
description: Bill Blass opened a week packed with fall designer shows with a collection that points up the different ways Europeans and Americans face the new decade in fashion. ''Ethnic is not my bag,'' said the dean of American designers, just two weeks after Yves Saint Laurent, Emanuel Ungaro and Valentino picked over fashion's past in search of contemporary images. ''I want women to look young, snappy and attractively dressed.''

title: Lebanese Christian Factions Now Hoping for Intervention
description: Leaders of Lebanon's warring Christian factions sought help today after 63 days of fighting that have failed to give either side a military victory.

title: Indian Youths Said to Lack Mental Care
description: THE Federal Government is failing to meet the mental health needs of American Indian adolescents, a Congressional agency said.

title: Aldo Fabrizi, 84, A Character Actor In Italian Movies
description: Aldo Fabrizi, an Italian actor who sprang to international fame in the 1940's with his portrayal of a courageous priest executed by Nazis in Roberto Rossellini's film ''Open City,'' died on Monday. He was 84 years old.

title: S.E.C. Chief Criticizes Bill to Thwart Takeovers
description: The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission today strongly criticized an anti-takeover law pending before the Pennsylvania Legislature, saying it would disenfranchise shareholders and leave incompetent managers ''free to run a company into the ground.''

title: Graf Back Next Week
description: Steffi Graf, who has been sidelined since suffering a chipped bone in her right thumb on Feb. 6, will return to tournament play next week.

title: Japan Isn't Even Playing the Same Game
description: To the Editor:

title: United Systems Technology reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Bridge
description: New York City has a crop of brilliant young players, several of whom made their presence felt at the Spring Nationals in Forth Worth. One was 26-year-old Lapt Chan, who won two second-tier events: the 0-2000 Knockout Teams, with Andrew Moss, 17, Ronnie Evron, 30, and Mike Chelst, 19, and the Flight A Stratified Pairs with 21-year-old Jeff Ferro.

title: Twin Sisters Accused of Bilking Elderly Blind Man
description: Identical 25-year-old twin sisters endeared themselves to an elderly blind Brooklyn man and then bilked him out of his life savings, the police have charged.

title: Recession Coming? Ask the Consumer
description: When the United States economy succumbs to recession, as it sooner or later must, it is a good bet that Dr. Richard T. Curtin and his colleagues here at the University of Michigan will have seen it coming before almost anyone else.

title: ZG Energy Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We've known for a long time that the Soviets were a military superpower but not an economic one. I wonder if we are as aware of how much our own world power has depended on our military strength.''

title: Moscow's Reforms: Turning Radical
description: The Soviet economy is sliding downhill so fast that Mikhail Gorbachev must jettison milquetoast reforms in favor of radical change. That will bring pain to Soviet workers. And that, in turn, will exact a political price. Even then, the economic outcome is uncertain.

title: Real Estate;   South Bronx Will Revive, Builder Says
description: DON'T quote Ogden Nash -''The Bronx? No Thonx!'' - to Bernard J. Rosenshein.

title: C.D.'s and Bank Funds Post Mixed Yields for the Week
description: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts at commercial banks and savings institutions were mixed for the week ended yesterday.

title: Congress May Consider Liquor Ad Warnings
description: Senator Albert Gore, Democrat of Tennessee, and Representative Joseph P. Kennedy 2d, Democrat of Massachusetts, are expected to introduce legislation today that would require all advertisements for alcoholic beverages to include health warnings, similar to those that accompany ads for cigarettes.

title: Lessons
description: When it comes to education, Kentucky has rarely made much of a splash. Centre College in Danville upset mighty Harvard in football in 1921, and Sherleen Sisney, a Louisville high school teacher, became National Teacher of the Year in 1984. But by and large the Bluegrass State has been content to paddle the backwaters of American public education.

title: The Scene: A Family Table The Script: A Tale of Freedom
description: ON Monday at sundown Jews around the world will usher in Passover and repeat a story told for thousands of years. That story, about the Jews' Exodus from slavery in Egypt, is far more than just a tale about freedom or an excuse to sit down to bowls of matzoh ball soup. It is a journey that Jews are directed to take as they follow the words of the Haggadah and are instructed not only to say its prayers and carry out its rituals but to feel as if they actually were slaves in Egypt, so they can taste anew the joy of being free.

title: Book Notes
description: More From Hemingway

title: Reuters Seeks Stock Buyback
description: Reuters Holdings P.L.C., the British information services company, said on Monday that it would seek shareholder approval to buy back up to 10 percent of its stock and increase its borrowing power.

title: Haves Top Have-Nots With 5 Runs in the 9th
description: They were like the city mouse and the country mouse as they met today, less than one week from the delayed start of the season: The Mets, so rich in talent that they could afford to send Bob Ojeda to the bullpen, and the Montreal Expos, so threadbare that they they offered a tryout to a 37-year-old pitcher from the Senior League.

title: Rowe Furniture Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 4
Bridge
description: The steadiest partnership in sight in the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship final in Fort Worth two weekends ago, in the view of many, was that of Ron Gerard of White Plains and Mike Kamil of Bergenfield, N.J., members of the winning team.

title: Sale at SmithKline
description: The SmithKline Beecham Corporation has sold three British food businesses to CPC International Inc. for $255 million in its plan to pare debt. The businesses - Ambrosia desserts, Bovril beef extracts and Marmite bread spread - had combined sales of $145 million last year, CPC said. The proceeds will help the company reduce the $3 billion in debt incurred when the SmithKline Beckman Corporation merged with the Beecham Group P.L.C. of Britain last year.

title: So You Want to Move to North Carolina?
description: To the Editor:

title: McDonald's Disputes Weight Labeling Law
description: McDonald's, which was challenged years ago on the weight of its Quarter-Pounder, now faces a challenge for the way it sells salad.

title: Upheaval in the East;   LITHUANIANS MEET GORBACHEV'S AIDE; SEEK TO EASE CRISIS
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's closest political ally conferred with a delegation of officials from Lithuania this afternoon amid signs that both sides were seeking a way out of the impasse created by Lithuania's declaration of independence and Moscow's refusal to accept it.

title: PEC Israel Economic Corp. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
People
description: * Paul Basile, an art director, and Jim McKennan, a copywriter, have been named senior vice presidents at Backer Spielvogel Bates.

title: Hal Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $5,143,000 gain in 1989 from sale of equipment, and a $309,000 loss due to sale of equipment. c-Net loss

title: Review/Theater;   Soviet Georgians' Essential 'Lear'
description: Robert Sturua's extraordinary production of ''King Lear'' is so unyielding in its intensity that one can see why the Rustaveli Theater Company from Soviet Georgia might regard Shakespeare as its national playwright. This distinguished company began an all too brief one-week engagement on Monday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Majestic Theater.

title: Washburn Arrested
description: Chris Washburn, a former forward-center with Golden State and Atlanta in the National Basketball Association who was banned from the league in 1988 for repeatedly failing drug tests, was being held in the DeKalb County Jail without bond yesterday after being arrested on Monday in Decatur, Ga., on drug-possession charges. Dan Bankhead, a spokesman for the Georgia Bureau of Investigation, said that when agents went to the apartment of Kimberly Greene, a friend of the 6-11 Washburn, to interview her on behalf of authorities in North Carolina, they found Washburn there. Both were charged with possession of cocaine and marijuana, Bankhead said. (AP)

title: Topics of The Times;   The Chancellor's Duty
description: By superseding a local school board in Brooklyn's District 17, the New York City Schools Chancellor, Joseph Fernandez, encourages critics who charge that he has become a dictator. In fact, the takeover is less a grab for power than an attempt to reassure the public about the school system's integrity. Last October the central Board of Education sent a management team to help the long-troubled district sort out its finances. The auditors found about $2 million received but not spent on some 20 programs with state and Federal funding. As a result, schoolchildren were deprived of remedial reading, drug education and other services.

title: Long Lake Energy reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Miller (Herman) Inc.(O) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 3
description: b-After income of $3.3 million, or 13 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for deferred taxes (SFAS No. 96). The latest 9 months was comprised of 39 weeks, compared with 40 weeks for the year-ago period.

title: Billboard Owners Switching, Not Fighting
description: Three weeks ago, the billboard at the corner of 138th Street and Lenox Avenue advertised Salem cigarettes. It now wishes a happy 85th birthday to Mother Hale, the founder of Hale House and the adoptive grandmother to innumerable abandoned and abused children.

title: The Shark Has Swum A Long Way
description: For Duke, even their entrance into the McNichols Sports Arena Monday night was not auspicious. A cluster of University of Nevada-Las Vegas fans, wearing the red school sweaters, waited in the dusk for the Duke team bus to arrive, and when it did, the fans greeted the debarking with a chant that sounded very much like: ''Air Ball! Air Ball!''

title: BRIEFS
description: * Airbus Industrie, Paris, the four-nation European consortium, said Turk Hava Yollari, the Turkish airline, would order five Airbus A340-300's and would take options on five more. Terms were not disclosed.

title: 5 Central Americans Call for Disbanding Of the Contras Soon
description: Five Central American Presidents called today for the full demobilization of the contra army by April 25 and urged that United States aid for resettling the rebels be offered only to those who give up their weapons.

title: Heresy, Perhaps, but Some Seders Won't Include Gefilte Fish
description: IT may seem heretical to some, but there is no commandment stating that the Passover seder has to begin with gefilte fish and matzoh ball soup. Indeed, the Book of Exodus calls only for eating a roast lamb, bitter herbs and matzoh or unleavened bread. Today, an increasing number of Jews are finding fresh ways of varying their traditional seder menus.

title: Economic Scene;   Cellular Phones: Room for Three?
description: EVER wonder why cellular mobile telephones, the communications miracle of the 1980's, cost so much to use? One corporate maverick, Federal Digital Cellular, claims to know the answer: monopoly power. It is asking Federal regulators to make room for a third cellular phone competitor in each city.

title: Bettors Angry at Late Casino
description: Thousands of gamblers, angered when the opening of the gaming floor was delayed for six hours, milled about outside Donald Trump's new Taj Mahal Casino today, clogging hallways and chanting, ''Tell Donald to open the door!'' The billion-dollar casino, which opened with a test run on Monday, finally opened for low-level wagering today at 4:18 P.M. The betting limit on game tables was $5. Slot machines took real coins from the beginning Monday, and the large total bet - at least $600,000 Monday - delayed today's opening.

title: Ford Motor Credit Sells 10-Year Notes
description: The Ford Motor Credit Corporation yesterday priced $200 million in 10-year notes through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Of Fetuses and Safety In the Workplace
description: To the Editor:

title: The Stress of Being an Author And Married to Salman Rushdie
description: ''We were jubilant,'' Marianne Wiggins said of the June morning last year when she and her husband, Salman Rushdie, learned that the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini had died.

title: Hillenbrand Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 3
CHRONICLE
description: April Fool's Day came late. A hastily arranged ''news conference'' was held yesterday at the Ritz Carlton Hotel in Boston, where a woman in a revealing green suit presented herself as MARLA MAPLES, who has been linked romantically with DONALD TRUMP.

title: ANOTHER BUS SHOT IN DRIVERS' STRIKE
description: At least five shots struck a Southeastern Trailways bus today as it traveled along a Greyhound Lines route from Nashville to Louisville, the state police said.

title: Islanders Hoping to Keep LaFontaine Healthy
description: It's one of those memories recalled often and with a note of resentment by fans and others around the Islanders, the one about how, the last time they were in the Stanley Cup playoffs, they lost to New Jersey in part because the Devils roughed up Pat LaFontaine, New York's small but dynamic superstar.

title: Refinery's Neighbors Count Sorrows, and Riches
description: After reaching one of the largest settlements ever recorded in a lawsuit over environmental contamination, the people on the south side of this oil refinery city today counted their sorrows as well as their riches.

title: Corning Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 25
description: b-Included extraordinary tax benefits of $400,000 which included non-operating after-tax gains of $4.7 million for the latest quarter and $700,000, or 1 cent a share, which included non-operating after-tax gains of $2.6 million for the year-ago period. The company said effective with the latest first quarter, it began to consolidate the results of Siecor Corp. into its financial statements. Siecor, which manufactures optical-fiber cable, is a venture with Siemens AG of West Germany. In the latest first quarter, the company sold its investment in the stock of Genencor Inc., recognizing an after-tax gain of $2.1 million.

title: G.E. Names a Lawyer To Environment Post
description: A former Justice Department lawyer who specializes in the enforcement of environmental laws was named yesterday to the top environmental position at the General Electric Company.

title: Ernst Freese, 64, Dies; A Molecular Biologist
description: Ernst Freese, a scientist who was an expert on chemical influences on reproduction and cancer, died of a cerebral hemorrhage on Friday at the Frederick (Md.) Memorial Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived in Bethesda, Md.

title: Digital Shows New Products
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation today introduced work station products that analysts say will increase the graphics capabilities of its machines. Digital, based in Maynard, Mass., introduced its DEC station 5000, Model 200 desktop work station and other products at a news conference here.

title: Market Place;   Bailout Agency Stirs Small Crisis
description: A GOVERNMENT agency threw a corner of the financial markets for a loop two weeks ago when it announced that it had the authority to withhold interest payments on mortgage-backed bonds issued by savings and loans that have since gone into receivership.

title: Columbia S&L reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Upheaval in the East;   Nothing but Nice Things to Say of Gorbachev
description: A week after the Kremlin barred foreign correspondents from the crisis in Lithuania, they were invited today to get their news directly from the new office of the presidential press secretary and its inaugural occupant, Arkady Maslennikov.

title: Tridel Enterprises reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $36 million, or $3.20 a share, which consisted of gains on the sale of residential property and tax credits. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: One-Shot Funds Backed For Connecticut Budget
description: The General Assembly's tax committee has approved a series of one-year revenue-raising measures that would shore up the state's worsening finances without a major election-year tax increase.

title: Safety Improvements Are Planned for Central Park
description: More recreation programs to draw young people into the north end of Central Park will be started this summer, volunteer patrols will be stepped up and better paths and signs are planned to make the park safer, New York City officials and a private group that supports the park said yesterday.

title: Savings Rules On Disclosures
description: The agency that regulates savings and loan associations said on Monday that it was drafting new rules to cover the release of customers' financial records by federally chartered savings institutions.

title: INSIDE
description: Treatment for Chicken Pox

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Lee Atwater, the Republican national chairman, misquoted a spokeswoman's description of his brain tumor. The spokeswoman, Leslie Goodman, said the tumor was ''non-malignant'' and had ''the potential to behave aggressively.'' She did not call it benign.

title: Rehoboth Journal;   Fearful Namibian Tribe Raises Flag of Freedom
description: Johannes Gerard Adolph Diergaardt likes to tell how his pioneer forebears wandered across the desert 120 years ago to found the community that he now heads.

title: Y.&R. Makes A Hollywood Comeback
description: YOUNG & RUBICAM re-entered the business of movie marketing yesterday with its appointment to plan and buy newspaper, radio and local television advertising for the 20th Century Fox Film Corporation. The studio spends about $45 million a year on local media.

title: A Treasure From the Seas, but Whose?
description: When the submersible robot Nemo surfaced from the depths of the Atlantic one day last summer, its mechanical arms clutching a gleaming batch of gold coins and bars, the salvagers of the 132-year-old wreck of the S.S. Central America figured their dream of fabulous riches - perhaps a billion dollars or more - had at last come true.

title: Topics of The Times;   Trade Secret
description: Neiman Marcus, the upscale Texas department store, set an unbeatable standard for lavish Christmas presents several years ago by offering ''his'' and ''hers'' airplanes. Now the spring catalogue of New York City's upscale gadget emporium, Hammacher Schlemmer, offers the latest in how to flit from here to there - without being detected: the B-2 Stealth bomber.

title: 28,000 People Bilked of $1 Million in Fraud
description: More than 28,000 people in 21 states and Canada were bilked of more than $1 million in a pyramid scheme that offered to turn a $105 investment into a $46,700 profit, the Federal Bureau of Investigation has reported.

title: U.S. Urged to Emphasize Economic Strength
description: Promoting a new foreign policy that is not rooted in rivalry with the Soviets, the chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, David L. Boren, warned today that the United States risks losing its pre-eminence unless it adjusts to a world order based on economic, not military, might.

title: China Ties New Demand to Dissident's Fate
description: Stiffening resistance to American efforts to free the dissident Fang Lizhi, China has made new demands on the United States in discussing terms for his release, American officials said today.

title: A van Gogh Recovered In a Ransom Attempt
description: A painting by Vincent van Gogh, missing since last month, was recovered when three men tried to pick up $1.3 million in ransom and were arrested, the police said today.

title: Eating Well
description: DURING a recent visit to a bookstore, I watched as a woman foraged through the aisles of the health section, filling her shopping basket with books on diet and nutrition. A few books she gathered were calorie- and fat-counters, but most were books offering suggestions for healthful eating. Her total bill must have been close to $70.

title: Topics of The Times;   Racism, to Gus Savage
description: Representatives William Gray and Charles Rangel now condemn anti-Semitic remarks made by Representative Gus Savage of Illinois at a campaign rally they attended on his behalf. So have numerous other House colleagues. But instead of apologizing, Mr. Savage has acted to reinforce his reputation as a bigot.

title: Study Shows That Antiviral Drug Aids Children With Chicken Pox
description: A widely used antiviral drug can significantly shorten the course and severity of chicken pox infections in normal children, researchers reported yesterday.

title: Arrests in Computer Break-Ins Show a Global Peril
description: Three Australians have been arrested on charges of tampering with computers in the United States and Australia in a case that computer specialists say raises troubling questions about the vulnerability of technology to intruders operating beyond American borders and laws.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-13

title: At the Nation's Table
description: IT appears that little has changed at the Blue Benn Diner since the railroad car-style diner was installed in the early 1940's on a main thoroughfare about four miles from Bennington College and from Southern Vermont College. Small jukeboxes still preside over the plastic and stainless steel tables flanked by worn wooden booths. The original decor from which the diner takes its name - blue vinyl counter stools, blue floor tile and blue wall trim - still infuse the interior with an azure haze.

title: House Approves Latin Aid; Senate Troubled by Priorities
description: The House approved a special spending bill today that provides nearly all the money President Bush requested for Panama and Nicaragua, including $30 million to demobilize and resettle the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Thomas F. Daly, 87, Retired Law Partner
description: Thomas F. Daly, a retired partner in the New York law firm of Lord, Day & Lord, now known as Lord, Day & Lord, Barrett & Smith, died on Monday at Riverview Hospital in Red Bank, N.J. He was 87 years old and lived in Rumson, N.J.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Gartner Gives Rangers New Offensive Spark
description: It had got to the point where Mike Gartner could have been forgiven if his belief in predestination had been shaken a bit. Gartner, who had contributed a decade's worth of consistent production on the ice and solid citizenship off it to the Washington Capitals, was all of a sudden spending as much time talking to real estate agents as church groups.

title: Met Opera Reaches Pact For Summer Attractions
description: The Metropolitan Opera Association has chosen the Entertainment Corporation U.S.A. to present summer attractions at the Metropolitan Opera House beginning in 1991. The four-year agreement, announced yesterday at the Met by representatives of the two organizations, is the first long-term arrangement between the Met and an outside presenter of international dance and music attractions since the days of Sol Hurok in the 1970's.

title: Wilkins and Jackson Help Knicks Revive
description: There is nothing wrong with the Knicks that an unselfish effort on offense and an excellent half-court defense won't cure.

title: New Hampshire Lawmakers Approve Abortion Rights Bill
description: The state Legislature passed a largely symbolic bill today intended to insure that women can continue getting legal abortions until the fetus is able to live outside the womb.

title: Citizens Utilities Co.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Concern Abates as Oil in River Passes Pittsburgh
description: Concern about the petroleum that gushed out of a burst pipleline into the Allegheny River has diminished almost as suddenly as the pollutant appeared last weekend.

title: Iran-Contra Judge Orders Jurors Sequestered After Press Contacts
description: The Federal judge in the Iran-contra trial of John M. Poindexter today angrily ordered the jury sequestered during its deliberations after two jurors reported contacts with reporters.

title: A Basic Pact On Satellites With Japan
description: American and Japanese officials announced today that they had reached a basic agreement to allow foreign producers to compete for the satellite business of the Japanese Government and its public-sector entities.

title: Finding Success in Movie Niches
description: The last few years have been trying ones for the independent movie studios as they struggled with the rising costs of making and marketing movies. But recently things have gone strikingly well for the New Line Cinema Corporation. Last weekend, ''Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles,'' a film about the four turtles made famous in comic books and on television, opened to the ninth-biggest audience in history, grossing $25.4 million.

title: Arthur Houghton Jr., 83, Dies; Led Steuben Glass
description: Arthur A. Houghton Jr., a former president of Steuben Glass and an arts patron who had been chairman of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the New York Philharmonic, died yesterday in Venice (Fla.) Hospital after a brief illness. He was 83 years old and maintained homes in Boca Grande, Fla., and Queenstown, Md.

title: Energy Development Partners reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Grants to Schools Aim at Innovation
description: In an effort to help schools with innovative educational programs, the RJR Nabisco Foundation announced the first recipients of its Next Century Schools grants today.

title: KEY RATES
Authors Warn on Gallimard
description: The heirs of three of France's best-known 20th-century authors and 55 other writers threatened today to switch publishers if a corporate raider gained control of Editions Gallimard, France's largest independent publisher.

title: Xerox Sets A Write-Off
description: The Xerox Corporation said today that it would take a pretax write-off of nearly $400 million in the first quarter because of its investment in VMS Realty Partners.

title: TV Networks Start Ad Group
description: Putting their common interests ahead of competition, CBS, NBC, and ABC yesterday announced the formation of a new organization, the Network Television Association, to promote network television to advertisers and agencies.

title: New York Court Sets a Standard For Housing Aid
description: New York State's highest court ruled today that the state must pay welfare recipients a monthly shelter allowance that bears ''a reasonable relation'' to the cost of their housing.

title: United Payment
description: The UAL Corporation said its United Airlines unit had agreed to pay $77.5 million to settle several lawsuits filed by affiliates of the Texas Air Corporation, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. The lawsuits contended that United and American Airlines had illegally monopolized or tried to monopolize the computer reservations system in various markets.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on March 24 about the emigration of Soviet Jews to Israel misstated the extent to which they are being resettled in the West Bank. Only a small number of the Soviet Jews - about 1 percent of the 30,000 who have arrived in Israel in the last few months - have moved to the occupied territories.

title: U.S. Easing Disk Curbs
description: The Commerce Department moved on Monday to free exports of hard-disk drives for personal computers.

title: Star Rookie Is Unawed by Masters
description: Conventional wisdom says that first-time starters at the Masters are basically fodder for the field. If the quicksilver putting surfaces don't get them, the tournament's mystique will.

title: Navratilova Motivated After Losing to Zvereva
description: Martina Navratilova sounded unperturbed during a phone conversation Monday when she said her best-laid and hitherto unspoiled plans to win every match in 1990 were shattered last Saturday at the Virginia Slims of Houston after Katerina Maleeva beat her in the semifinals.

title: Japanese Plan On Southland
description: Ito-Yokado, the giant Japanese supermarket operator that agreed last month to buy a big share of the Southland Corporation, said today that it had no plans to bail out the financially pressed operator of the 7-Eleven convenience stores.

title: Thanks for Attacking the N.E.A.
description: LEAD: It's a pleasure to come down to Washington and speak in support of the National Endowment for the Arts, one of the wisest and happiest pieces of legislation ever to come through Congress. I'm grateful to those who have so ably attacked the Endowment over the past year or so for making it necessary to defend it.

title: From Calvin Klein, Winning Simplicity
description: THE Calvin Klein collection was quiet, wonderful and just about perfect. The models wore no makeup. The colors were never explosive. The cut was always masterly, and there were no ruffles or any other extraneous decoration. As a superbly but simply dressed woman often makes others at a social gathering look overdressed, Mr. Klein's fall collection, shown yesterday, tends to make most others look overdone.

title: Stocks Rally in Busy Day; Dow Up 36.26
description: Stock prices rallied yesterday in brisk trading on the New York Stock Exchange in the wake of a strong recovery in Japanese stocks, with the Dow Jones industrial average advancing 36.26 points, to 2,736.71.

title: Bernard J. Miller, 76; Founded GQ Magazine
description: Bernard J. Miller, an advertising and public-relations executive who was founding publisher of Gentlemen's Quarterly magazine, died of liver cancer yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 76 years old.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Dual Bluffs On Lithuania
description: Eduard A. Shevardnadze, the Soviet Foreign Minister, arrived in Washington today for meetings with President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, and Administration officials said he faces some tough talk on Lithuania later this week.

title: Leading Indicators Plunge by 1%
description: The Government's main gauge of future economic growth plunged by 1 percent in February, its steepest drop in nine months, the Commerce Department said today. But analysts said the decrease was misleading.

title: Rebels No. 1, at Last; No Replays Needed
description: Nevada-Las Vegas is the national basketball champion. There are no doubts about it, no calls for instant replay, no reflections on a missed foul shot that may have turned the tide, no excited chatter about a last-second shot that may or may not have beaten the buzzer. All there is are hushed and, in some corners, grudging accolades for a team and a performance that ranks among the best in the 51-year history of the national tournament.

title: In Texas Race, a Charge of 'Himmler' Tactics
description: Former Gov. Mark White, who placed third in the Democratic gubernatorial primary last month, today accused State Treasurer Ann Richards, the front-runner, of tactics like those of the Gestapo chief Heinrich Himmler.

title: Devils' Playoff Appearance Is Not a Surprise This Time
description: Unlike their first trip to the Stanley Cup playoffs two years ago, the Devils are not going to be the surprise team this time. They are a talented club with plenty of depth and experience that clinched its playoff berth convincingly rather than in overtime on the last day of the season.

title: Norman Patterson, 73, Designer of Hospitals
description: Norman W. Patterson, an architect who designed the Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington, died March 28 after suffering a heart attack at his home. He was 73 years old.

title: Court Urges Easing on Phone Curbs
description: A Federal appeals court in Washington ruled yesterday that a more lenient legal standard should be applied in determining whether the seven ''Baby Bell'' telephone companies are allowed to create information services like electronic shopping and home banking.

title: Tyco Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Cascade Corp. reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
Review/Rock;   Eric Clapton: Performer Vs. Star
description: Pop musicians, like actors who perform all week long, month after month, have to emote; it's their job. A good pop musician has developed complex codes meant to prove to an audience exactly how much the artist cares about what he or she is doing, and how much creativity and passion are being produced on stage.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES

title: Bonnett Back Home
description: Neil Bonnett, suffering from severe amnesia as a result of a race-car accident on Sunday, was back at home in Birmingham, Ala., yesterday, but his wife, Susan, said full recovery may take days, a month or years.

title: In U.S. School Spending, Question Is How Much
description: The poster in the Senate subcommittee room portrays several children clamb ering over a Jungle Gym, with the legend: ''It Will Be a Great Day When Our Schools Get All the Money They Need, and the Air Force Has to Hold a Bake Sale to Buy a Bomber.''

title: Unifirst Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 24
7 Girls Guilty In Pin Attacks On 45 Women
description: Seven black girls have been convicted of jabbing scores of white women in what prosecutors described as a series of racially motivated pin attacks that frightened residents of the Upper West Side last October.

title: Neuville Molds the 60's for Modern Use
description: CHARLOTTE NEUVILLE'S show yesterday started with a Pow! Her black and white checks and bold black and white stripes woke up the audience on a rainy morning. She then lulled them with soft beiges and mossy greens and ended with jazzy dance dresses dripping with beads for a final Pow!

title: Reviews/Music;   Debussy From a Duo And Friends
description: For their concert at Town Hall on Monday evening, the flutist Linda Chesis and the harpist Sara Cutler decided to look beyond the duo repertory they have been playing since 1982, and to offer an evening of richly textured chamber music. To that end, they invited some colleagues to collaborate on an evening of works by Claude Debussy.

title: Clean Air Act: The Senate Bill
description: AIRBORNE CHEMICALS

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: IF you consider the cuisines of the world, particularly those of the Middle East, Eastern Europe and Central Asia, lamb is one of the major sources of protein. Beef-loving Americans may forget that has been true for centuries.

title: Offer by American To Frequent Fliers
description: American Airlines said it would broaden its frequent-flier program to allow members to turn in their accumulated miles for discounts on cars, sailboats, watches and other products. ''We have taken mileage awards in an entirely new direction,'' Michael W. Gunn, senior vice president of marketing at American, said. Frequent fliers in the American program will be able to get a break if they buy a 1990 Toyota Supra automobile. After negotiating with a dealer, they can redeem 75,000 advantage miles for a $1,500. Other products included in the program are ski boats, solariums and computers.

title: TCG International reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $3.2 million, or 15 cents a share, for the latest year and $8,211,000, or 41 cents a share, for 1988. The latest year included the results of Glenayre Electronics Ltd. since Aug. 1. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Official Faults Charter-Linked Money Pleas
description: New York City's budget director said yesterday that some elected officials and agencies were using their revised duties under the new city charter as an excuse to ask for money that they do not need.

title: The Political Stampede on Execution
description: From one end of the country to the other, political candidates this year are competing to persuade voters that if elected, they would be more vigorous, more vigilant and more relentless than their opponents in the application of the death penalty.

title: Vote-Machine Lobbyist Is Said to Report a Bribe
description: A lobbyist for a voting-machine company seeking a contract with the Board of Elections has told investigators that a board member asked him for a bribe, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Supercollider Stands at the Frontier of Science
description: To the Editor:

title: Wheelabrator Deal On Merger Is Set
description: Waste Management Inc. has reached an agreement with Wheelabrator Technologies Inc. to take control of the company for about $500 million. Waste Management said it would increase its Wheelabrator stake to 55 percent, from 22 percent. Wheelabrator shareholders will receive 0.469 share of Waste Management stock and 0.574 share of Wheelabrator stock for each Wheelabrator share.

title: Anti-Takeover Proposal Gains in Pennsylvania
description: The Pennsylvania House passed the nation's toughest anti-takeover measure yesterday by an overwhelming vote of 182 to 10. The bill, which has already passed the Senate, is expected to be approved quickly by a conference committee, and the Governor has said he will sign it.

title: So You Want to Move to North Carolina?;   Accentuate the Positive
description: To the Editor:

title: China Protest Leader Escapes
description: Chai Ling, one of the top student leaders of last year's democracy movement in Beijing, made a television appearance today to announce her escape to the West after 10 months as a fugitive in China.

title: Getty Petroleum reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Shares outstanding are adjusted to give retroactive effect to the 5 percent stock dividend declared yesterday, payable April 26 to stockholders of record April 13. The company said the decrease in net income for the year was primarily due to the effect of tight margins experienced during the second quarter of the current fiscal year, a LIFO pretax charge of $2.1 million recorded in the fourth quarter, and the reduction in the company's share of earnings of Slattery Group Inc.

title: 34 Killed in Bomb Blast at Hindu Rite in Punjab
description: At least 34 people were killed in Punjab State today when a bomb believed to have been set by Sikh radicals exploded in the middle of a Hindu religious procession.

title: Fernandez Seeks Stricter Budget Rules
description: With several local districts in fiscal disarray, Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez is moving to require all New York City schools to prepare budgets for public scrutiny and is setting tougher standards for hiring district business managers.

title: Standard Brands Paint reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $681,000 for the quarter and $1,135,000 for the year; the year also included an extraordinary credit of $1,145,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Provigo Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $20.5 million and after an extraordinary loss of $62.1 million, which included a $60 million provision for a loss resulting from the sale of two interests and the proposed sale of a third interest, and a $2.1 million writedown of an investment. c-Included income of $7.7 million, or 9 cents a share, from discontinued operations and an extraordinary loss of $2 million. d-Net income and included a loss of $3.6 million from discontinued operations and an extraordinary loss of $8.7 million. The company said certain year-ago figures have been restated to conform with the current presentation. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Cuomo and G.O.P. at Work On Income-Tax Cut Accord
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and legislative leaders sketched a possible compromise on the state budget today that would freeze income-tax rates for this year and then phase in a scheduled cut. But after a three-hour meeting that broke shortly before midnight, state leaders still appeared to be far apart on the details of the plan.

title: Treasury Prices Rise in Slow Day
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds moved marginally higher in very sluggish trading yesterday, as dealers moved to the sidelines in advance of March employment data on Friday.

title: KILLINGS OF ARABS BY ISRAELIS DROP
description: Israeli soldiers shot and killed fewer Palestinians in the first quarter of 1990 than in any three-month period since the Palestinian uprising began 28 months ago.

title: Landlord of Burned-Out Club Surrenders
description: The owner of the building that housed the Happy Land Social Club surrendered on a year-old arrest warrant relating to safety violations yesterday as the Dinkins administration reversed a previous position and said it would move immediately to padlock 38 social clubs operating illegally.

title: Super Valu Stores reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 24
Wines From Czar Are Sold At Auction
description: Wine collectors from around the Western world spent more than $1 million on Monday bidding for 13,000 bottles of Crimean dessert and fortified wine produced from the 1830's to 1945 and never before available in the West.

title: Relief for the AIDS Disaster
description: In a recent heartfelt speech, President Bush called for more compassion and less discrimination against victims of AIDS. That was welcome moral leadership, but AIDS, now pushing health care systems of big cities into crisis, demands much more from Washington. A bill pending in Congress recognizes the urgent need.

title: U.S. and Japan Agree On Satellite Contracts
description: American and Japanese officials announced yesterday that they had reached an agreement allowing foreigners to compete for the satellite business of the Japanese Government and state-run companies.

title: Williams-Sonoma reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
Rocket May Open A New Era
description: A small company, working with the Pentagon and NASA, is scheduled to launch a 50-foot winged rocket from a B-52 flying over the Pacific Ocean today in a pioneering effort to provide a new way to send spacecraft into orbit.

title: Supercollider Stands at the Frontier of Science;   Major Discoveries Seen
description: To the Editor:

title: About New York;   At 78, the Doctor Still Gives Them Chills and Fever
description: Yesterday morning, 8 sharp. The white-haired professor in the crisp blue suit approached the lectern. The packed crowd leaned forward.

title: New Owner Will Keep Lynne Palmer on Track
description: The Lynne Palmer Agency, one of the gatekeepers to employment in New York's publishing world, has a new owner, Susan Gordon.

title: Union President to Head Voter Commission
description: A union official was elected chairman of New York City's Voter Assistance Commission yesterday.

title: Hartmarx Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Lebanon's Currency Hits All-Time Low; Mediation Bid Ends
description: Lebanese saw the value of their money sink to a new low today as mediators trying to end more than two months of Christian fighting ended their mission without success.

title: Bailey Financial Bids for Durham
description: An investment group led by the Bailey Financial Group Inc. has offered to buy the Durham Corporation for $30 in cash and notes valued at $7.50 for each common share. The total price of Durham's 8.4 million common shares is about $315 million. Durham, based in Raleigh, N.C., is a holding company with interests in insurance, broadcasting and real estate.

title: South Africa Sends Army to Halt Strife
description: The South African Government began deploying army troops in Natal's strife-torn black townships today as Nelson Mandela and some other black leaders voiced misgivings but not outright objections over the move.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Bulgaria Adopts Election Laws and Names Leader
description: Parliament adopted legislation today for free elections and elected Petar Mladenov, who initiated democratic reforms, to a newly created presidency. Communists also renamed their disgraced party the Bulgarian Socialist Party.

title: Maybelline to Be Sold In a $300 Million Deal
description: Seeking to disentangle itself from the financially unpredictable beauty-products business, the Schering-Plough Corporation agreed today to sell its Maybelline unit for $300 million to a group including the division's management and the Playtex Family Products Corporation.

title: Intergroup Filing
description: Walker Street Associates L.P., which owns 8.4 percent of National Intergroup Inc., said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that it had moved to try to raise its stake in the Pittsburgh-based distribution company to more than 10 percent. Walker, controlled by a New York investor, Steven M. Mizel, has filed a separate complaint in a Delaware state court seeking to overturn Intergroup's ''poison pill'' anti-takeover plan. The plan effectively blocks stock purchases above 10 percent by issuing additional shares and diluting the value of the investor's holding. The limit for Intergroup's poison pill was lowered to 10 percent, from 20 percent, after another investor group, Centaur Partners L.P., said it had bought a 16 percent stake.

title: New Mail Sorters Planned
description: The Postal Service Board of Governors today approved spending $379.3 million on new letter sorting machines, which will lead to bar-coding of all mail by 1995. Bar codes are the series of lines like those used in supermarket pricing. They are already used to sort much business mail. The money will buy 1,349 machines that read the codes and sort mail automatically.

title: Reviews/Music;   Bach Sung In Concert, Not Church
description: Bach's ''St. Matthew Passion'' is a very different work in the concert hall and in the churches for which it was intended. For the composer, it was an instrument of worship. His Leipzig parishioners not only listened, they also sang the chorales -providing their own commentaries on Christ's suffering, death and resurrection.

title: Outlet Communications reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The latest periods included a tax credit of $4,635,000, or 71 cents a share. The 1989 net income primarily resulted from a non-recurring gain on the sale of two radio stations in the 1989 first quarter. The latest quarter and year included non-recurring gains of $10,423,000 and $38,262,000, respectively; year-ago periods included non- recurring losses of $2,252,000.

title: Ichan Sets USX Value
description: A group led by Carl C. Icahn, the New York investor who is proposing to spin off the steel holdings of the USX Corporation, said yesterday that such a separation would yield about $48 a share for stockholders.

title: A Bonanza For Trump Shuttle Users
description: For many travelers on the Northeast's air shuttles, clouds now do have a silver lining.

title: Upheaval in the East;   East German Parties Aim for Cabinet by April 15
description: East Germany's main political groups agreed today to try to form the nation's first non-Communist government before April 15 and resolve lingering differences over unification with West Germany.

title: New Tunes for Whistle Blowers
description: Beginning next season college basketball games will be shorter, players will be allowed to play longer and officials will crack down on the sort of baiting and taunting that has become prevalent in the game.

title: American Medical Internaional Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income The company said year-ago income from continuing operations of $29,675,000 included $13 million in additional malpractice insurance provisions and $11 million in lease buyout costs.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Aetna Life and Casualty Co., Hartford, the insurance company, named Gary G. Benanav, the head of its international insurance operations, a senior vice president.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ''Last week was the first week without seeing double,'' BARBARA BUSH said yesterday, talking about her radiation treatment for Graves' disease. The disease is an immune system disorder that affected her thyroid and caused the First Lady to lose weight last year. It also caused eye irritation and double vision.

title: Home Pork
description: LEAD: The ending of the cold war, budgetary pressures and mothballing of the battleship Iowa give New York's political leaders an opportunity to strengthen their call for a peace dividend by helping cut local political fat from the military budget.

title: American Schools Abroad Find a Global Niche
description: Until two years ago, a small pear-shaped room at the 1,160-student American School in London housed the nurse's office. Today, on any weekday morning, a cluster of children can be found there studying English as a second language. On the wall is a large map of the world, and every time a child joins the class a colored pin is placed on the spot where that child was born. The placement of the pins reads like a roster from the United Nations: Yemen, Brazil, Pakistan, Saudi Arabia, the Netherlands, France.

title: SENATORS APPROVE CLEAN AIR MEASURE BY A VOTE OF 89-11
description: After a decade-long stalemate over clean-air legislation, the Senate passed a compromise bill tonight intended to reduce acid rain, urban smog and toxic chemicals in the air. The vote was 89 to 11.

title: Mattingly Sets Opening-Day Deadline for a New Yank Deal
description: Don Mattingly's quiet and uneventful spring took a sudden turn today when the Yankee first baseman, upset that there have been no talks about a new contract for him, said he would probably file for free agency when the season ends.

title: Valvano Almost Out?
description: Jim Valvano is all but out as the head coach at North Carolina State, and all that remains is for the two sides to work out a financial settlement, his attorney Wayne Webb said yesterday.

title: Cubans Parade Hardware to Jam TV Marti
description: President Fidel Castro has opened his country up to the foreign press this week for a glimpse at what Cuban officials describe as a nascent war of the airwaves.

title: New AIDS Experiments Stir Hope and Wariness
description: Kenya's chief medical scientist has reported that the symptoms of AIDS can be alleviated within a few weeks with small amounts of a licensed drug taken in a novel way. His findings are viewed skeptically by top American experts, but follow-up studies are being planned in the United States and six other countries to determine within a few months whether the results can be repeated.

title: Food Notes
description: Takeout for Seders

title: Music Played in 1971 as Police Found Bodies of 5
description: As two police officers made their way through John E. List's darkened house toward the bodies of his wife, mother and three children, they were greeted by a recording of funereal organ music, one of the officers testified today.

title: Review/Rock;   Raw, Weary, Dank, Dreary
description: Elemental rock intensity and willful posturing are inseparable with the Jesus and Mary Chain, the English band that gave two shows last weekend at the Ritz. The songs are no-frills three-chord rock, stomping in classic structures (from the Velvet Underground, the Rolling Stones and the Beach Boys) that are topped with raw guitar noise; they carry lyrics that are bleak and dank, despairing and slightly threatening. The songs tersely sketch an emotional landscape of unending need and unwavering distrust - the aggressive side of mope-rock - sung in a weary, distanced scowl by Jim Reid, yet pounded home by the familiar beat and chords.

title: $1.5 Billion in Debentures Are Offered by Fannie Mae
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, priced two debenture issues yesterday, totaling $1.5 billion, through its regular selling group.

title: Leo van Munching, 88, Heineken Beer Trader
description: Leo van Munching, the importer who brought Heineken beer to the United States, died of complications of Alzheimer's disease yesterday at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 88 years old and lived in Greenwich.

title: Pesticide Compliance Uneven, Report Finds
description: Some foreign fruit and vegetable producers try to observe bans on certain pesticides imposed in the United States, but others are often unaware of restrictions, according to a report prepared for Congress by the General Accounting Office.

title: Binks Manufacturing reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Simmons Ends Bid For Georgia Gulf
description: The Dallas investor Harold C. Simmons has ended his $1.1 billion tender offer for the Georgia Gulf Corporation, deciding instead to back the chemical company's recapitalization plan at the April 19 annual meeting. But Mr. Simmons's NL Industries, which owns almost 10 percent of Georgia Gulf, left open the possibility of another tender offer if shareholders reject the plan.

title: L.I. Neighbor Found Guilty In Girl's Death
description: In a case that generated fear and anger in the block where both victim and suspect lived, Robert Golub was convicted today of murdering 13-year-old Kelly Ann Tinyes and stashing her body in a sleeping bag in his family's basement in Valley Stream.

title: CHRONICLE
description: A two-time world figure skating champion, AJA ZANOVA defected from Czechoslovakia 40 years ago, while defending her title in London. She attempted to return several times, most recently in 1978 upon the death of her father, but she was always denied permission.

title: Supercollider Stands at the Frontier of Science;   Pound Foolish
description: To the Editor:

title: Just Good Drinking: Reds, $10 or Less
description: THERE are two worlds of wine. One is the world of the collectors and connoisseurs, people to whom wine is terribly important, people who will pay almost anything to get the rare bottles they want. The other is the world of everyday consumers, people who think of wine the way they do television and an occasional thick steak, as something that adds to the quality of life, but in a low-key, unobtrusive way.

title: I.B.F. Says It Will Rank Taylor Above Chavez
description: Julio Cesar Chavez must defend against Meldrick Taylor within six months the junior welterweight title he took from Taylor in a disputed ending last month, the International Boxing Federation ruled yesterday.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DOUGLAS A. PARKER and his 2-year-old son were shopping in a store in their neighborhood in Manhattan. In addition to newspapers and candy bars and greeting cards and such, the store has an impressive display of stuffed dolls, a fact that did not go unnoticed by the youngster. It was not until they returned home that Mr. Parker realized his son had swiped one, an addition to his collection of Sesame Street characters.

title: If the Bread Is Getting Better, Can the City Be Far Behind?
description: FOR 73 years, Louis Orwasher, the patriarch of Orwasher's Bakery in the Yorkville section of Manhattan, has charted the relationship between the quality of bread and the quality of life in his home town. The bread has got better lately in New York and Mr. Orwasher wouldn't be surprised if the city follows suit.

title: Eastern Creditors Reported To Reject Latest Debt Plan
description: The unsecured creditors of Eastern Airlines yesterday voted to reject the carrier's latest proposal to emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy and they agreed to seek the appointment of a trustee to sell the airline, two people close to the creditors' committee said.

title: Gretzky Out of Lineup
description: A bad back will keep Wayne Gretzky, the league's leading scorer, out of the Los Angeles Kings' lineup in the first two games of the National Hockey League playoffs in Calgary tonight and Friday night. It will be the first time in Gretzky's 11-year N.H.L. career that he has missed a playoff game.

title: Reviews/Music;   Guitar Trio Plays Classics In Transcription
description: In the days before recordings turned music into a spectator sport, most orchestral works were available in piano duet reductions for home consumption. Musicians still enjoy them, and by extension one can understand that three excellent guitarists might want to get together and play, say, a symphony for their own edification. But why anyone except perhaps a few fellow guitarists would want to hear it is a mystery.

title: Katharine Balfour, 69, An Actress and Writer
description: Katharine Balfour, an actress and writer, died of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, also called Lou Gehrig's disease, at her home in Manhattan yesterday. She was 69 years old.

title: Israel Puts a Satellite in Orbit A Day After Threat by Iraqis
description: Israel successfully launched its second experimental satellite this afternoon, a day after President Saddam Hussein of Iraq threatened to destroy ''half of Israel'' with chemical weapons if this nation becomes involved in an attack against Iraq.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: From Nobody to Somebody in Art
description: Being an art star at the age of 58 makes John Baldessari slightly nervous. ''It's a bit scary to have acceptance,'' the artist said the other day. ''You wonder what you're doing wrong.''

title: Hills Department Stores reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 3
PEN Gala Raises Money, but Some Wonder at What Price
description: As authors and the very wealthy prepare to gather today at the PEN-Mont Blanc Gala Dinner, some people in the book world are asking whether writers and the rich should become accustomed to rubbing shoulders in this way and for such ends.

title: Stealth's Panama Mission Reported Marred by Error
description: As the Defense Department today disclosed new information about its Stealth fighter plane, senior Pentagon officials said the aircraft's first combat mission in Panama was marred by pilot error and a critical target was missed by hundreds of yards.

title: U.N.L.V. Journal;   Campus Put on the Map by a Team
description: The morning after the Runnin' Rebels of the University of Nevada-Las Vegas won the national collegiate basketball championship, the subject in Sociology 101 today was Emile Durkheim's concepts of the sacred and the profane.

title: Books of The Times;   Beauvoir's Life: Feminism's Wellspring, Sartre's Lover
description: Simone de Beauvoir

title: Ruddock-Dokes Matchup Headlines Card at Garden
description: Big-time boxing returns to Madison Square Garden tonight with a card headlined by a pair of world-ranked heavyweights.

title: Bored by Annual Reports? Try Time Warner's
description: Wall Street, meet MTV.

title: Armed Sanitation Police Are Wrong Approach to Recycling
description: To the Editor:

title: Peters (J.M.) Co.(A) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Rebate Plan By Chrysler
description: To drum up business for its most important product, the Chrysler Corporation promised today that current buyers of its mini-vans would be guaranteed any rebates that are offered on the vehicles between now and Sept. 30, when the current model year ends.

title: Riot in London: Angered and Alienated, Youths Find Target in a Hated Tax
description: Brimming with anger and despair, a growing number of alienated young Britons who feel passed over by the Thatcher era seem to have found a target for their rage in an unpopular new Government tax.

title: Reviews/Music;   Classical Light, Romantic Heat And a Dazzler
description: Gavin Martin, a pianist who gave a debut concert at Weill Recital Hall on Sunday afternoon, is a doctoral candidate at the Manhattan School of Music, and has already started to make his way in the musical world. Mr. Martin's achievements are founded on a secure technique, good pianistic instincts and an interpretive spirit that shows the influence of two of his teachers, Jorge Bolet and Gary Graffman.

title: Review/Music;   Bach's B-Minor Mass In Period Rendering
description: Any discussion of Bach's Mass in B minor must start with the understanding that there is no such work. The four parts of the piece that goes by that name, composed separately over more than 20 years, were apparently never performed as a unit in Bach's lifetime. They may not have been intended for liturgical service but rather as his summing up of the Latin contrapuntal tradition, just as in the ''Art of the Fugue'' he showed what could be done in the old fugal style.

title: Rates Decline At Citicorp Sale
description: Interest rates declined at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper yesterday for the third consecutive week and are at their lowest levels since the beginning of March.

title: Paralyzing Polls
description: We have come to a dead halt here. Polls are being taken.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: LEAD: EACH spring on Florida's Atlantic coast, thoughts turn to the crack of ball against bat and this year's crop of rookie phenoms. But even baseball players have to eat.

title: The Pop Life
description: New Inspiration

title: MCorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $11,708,000 for the quarter and $12,306,000 for the year. c-Net loss d-After losses from discontinued operations of $397,808,000 and $785,105,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Kemp's Choice Is Ruled Out for a New Post
description: The White House said today that it would not nominate Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp's choice to lead a new housing agency. Mr. Kemp's selection, Mary K. Bush, is under investigation for awarding no-bid contracts to friends.

title: Iraq Raises Its Volume, and Arab Hopes
description: When a cease-fire stilled Iraq's war with Iran two years ago, the wisdom or peril perceived by many in this region was that, having disposed of the menace from Teheran, Iraq would return to an older agenda: its establishment as the region's heavyweight in the contest with Israel.

title: Accounts
description: * Lexus Dealer Association, to Team One Advertising.

title: Lawyers Begin Marcos Trial In Air of Raucous Contention
description: With raucous, contentious opening statements in a Federal courthouse in Manhattan, prosecutors said yesterday that Imelda Marcos had committed crimes of ''theft, fraud and deceit on an incredible scale,'' but defense lawyers argued that she had acted with the knowledge and even encouragement of the United States Government.

title: G.M. Picks Its Next Chairman
description: Directors of the General Motors Corporation, in a widely expected move, announced today that they had chosen Robert C. Stempel, the company's president and chief operating officer, as the next chairman and chief executive. He will succeed Roger B. Smith, who will retire this August after nearly a decade in office.

title: Besieged Vermont Governor Rules Out Race for 4th Term
description: Vermont's Governor, Madeleine M. Kunin, faced with budget problems and a backlash against a tough environmental planning law, announced today that she would not seek a fourth two-year term this fall.

title: Magazine Closings
