description: Continuing to pare down its titles, A/S/M Communications, the publisher of Adweek, said yesterday that it was closing two of its trade magazines that were started this year. The magazines are Media Week and Imaging Retail News, an offshoot of Photo District News.

title: Fairfield Communities reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $19,430,000 and $22,962,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net income and after income of $2,789,000, or 26 cents a share, for the quarter and a loss of $325,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations, and extraordinary tax credits of $579,000, or 6 cents a share, and $1,134,000, or 11 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Manville Payments
description: The Manville Property Damage Settlement Trust has completed a review of 14,000 claims for asbestos exposure and has paid $68 million to some of the claimants, the trust announced on Monday.

title: A Worry in West Germany: Indolence in East Germany
description: At a construction site on the Leipziger Strasse in downtown East Berlin, a workman is cutting plywood on a table saw. The blade's high-pitched whine echoes through the brick-and-concrete shell of the unfinished six-story structure. No other human life is visible.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: FOR lovers of couscous, pastilla and other delicacies from Morocco, a too-well-kept culinary secret is the highly personalized version of a Moroccan meal served on special request at Jean-Pierre restaurant. Larbi Dahrouch, Jean-Pierre's chef of one year, started offering Moroccan dishes after he was asked to prepare a Moroccan menu for a private party. For $50 Mr. Dahrouch presents an eight-course menu of Moroccan cooking.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on the Education page yesterday about grants given by the RJR Nabisco Foundation misstated the size of the grant to Nathan Hale Intermediate School 293 in Brooklyn. It was $222,886.

title: Western Wind Across Urban Plains
description: BY the time Thomas Molesworth opened the Shoshone Furniture Company in 1931, the myth of the American cowboy was laced into the American mindset.

title: Rosario Journal;   An Ousted Argentine Rambo Storms the Hustings
description: Residents of one of Rosario's poorest neighborhoods had just strung up a banner that said ''Aldo Rico for President'' when the cashiered army officer strode into the packed union hall to standing applause and the beat of a drum.

title: Expos Scramble for Pitching Help

title: Youths in Estonia Defying the Soviet Military Are Finding Eager Helpers
description: Three young men clustered around a wobbly table in a ramshackle office here in the Estonian capital, filling out questionnaires that could change their lives and threaten their republic's relationship with Moscow.

title: PROTEST FOCUSES ON ABORTION ISSUE
description: The Planned Parenthood Federation of America has started a nationwide campaign to protest A.T.&T.'s withdrawal of longstanding support of the federation's teen-age pregnancy prevention programs because of its advocacy of abortion rights.

title: Senate Roll-Call On Nomination
description: Following is the 62-to-37 roll-call by which the Senate voted today to confirm T. Timothy Ryan Jr. as director of the Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision. A yes vote was a vote to confirm Mr. Ryan while a no vote was a vote to reject the nomination. Voting yes were 17 Democrats and 45 Republicans. Voting no were 37 Democrats and no Republicans. Senators not voting are denoted by xxx.

title: Northrop May Sell Additional Assets
description: The Northrop Corporation, the military contractor, is weighing further asset sales because of flat sales so far this year, the company said. It expects this year's sales to be even with the $5.25 billion in 1989, but down from 1988's $5.79 billion, it said in its annual report.

title: New Peril Seen on Earth Warming
description: Chemicals counted on as substitutes for chlorofluorocarbons, widely used substances that are destroying the Earth's protective ozone layer, could contribute significantly to long-term global warming, scientists say.

title: Industries Are Wary About Clean-Air Bill
description: Industrial corporations are reacting with disappointment to the clean-air legislation passed by the Senate on Tuesday. While some companies are resigned to paying the additional expenses, estimated at $20 billion by the Bush Administration, they warn that those costs will be passed on to American consumers.

title: Texan Declines to Apologize After She Is Likened to Nazi
description: State Treasurer Ann Richards is offering no apologies for her tactics in the Democratic gubernatorial campaign after former Gov. Mark White likened her behavior to that of the Gestapo chief Heinrich Himmler.

The bureau said that spending on ads for legal services on local television rose to $82.3 million in 1989, up 28.7 percent from 1988, when $63.9 million was spent.

Besides painting the traditional flowers and baskets of fruit, she has silk-screened blueprints onto tiles, created tiles with bas-relief designs like seashells and made an impression of a paint tube in raw clay.

title: Review/Television;   'Outsiders,' a Drama of Socioeconomic Divisions
description: If ''The Outsiders'' movie worked for Matt Dillon, Patrick Swayze, Rob Lowe, Emilio Estevez, Tom Cruise and Ralph Macchio, can ''The Outsiders'' television series make stars of Jay R. Ferguson, Rodney Harvey, Boyd Kestner, Robert Rusler, David Arquette and Harold Pruett? Francis Ford Coppola certainly hopes so. He directed the film and, with Fred Roos, is co-executive producer of the series. Currently taking an enormous financial gamble in making a new addition to ''The Godfather'' saga, Mr. Coppola and his Zoetrope Studios are in the market for all the hits they can get.

title: Gordon Braislin, 89, A Retired Chairman Of the Dime Bank

The suits, he said, would be filed in about two weeks. Fagel, speaking at a news conference in Beverly Hills, Calif., said Loyola Marymount would be named as a defendant.

Dickerson Not Kidding

''I told Jimmy last week that I didn't want to talk to any more teams and that I had no desire to play for anyone,'' Dickerson said, referring to Jim Irsay, the Colts' general manager. Dickerson had been given permission to talk to the Giants, the Raiders, the Redskins, the Eagles and the Oilers. (AP)

description: The Bush Administration said today that it was considering offering support to a new bill intended to relax immigration restrictions on people infected with the AIDS virus.

title: Inrad Inc.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
German State Chief Wants U.S. Troops Cut
description: Premier Walter Wallman of Hesse has requested that United States soldiers be withdrawn from the West German state as part of any European arms cuts.

title: Simmons Wins Award As Outstanding Player
description: Lionel Simmons of La Salle, the third-leading scorer in National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I history, was named yesterday as the winner of the 14th annual John Wooden Award as college basketball's outstanding player.

title: Edgar G. E. Moss; Dog Breeder, 83
description: Edgar G. E. Moss, a dog breeder and former publisher of The New Brunswick Spokesman, a weekly newspaper in New Jersey, died of cancer on Tuesday at the Hunterdon Medical Center in Flemington, N.J. He was 83 years old and lived in Lebanon, N.J.

title: Environmental Diagnostics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about liquid diets, and a correction in this space on Tuesday, referred incorrectly to the director of human nutrition at the University of Michigan. He is Dr. Adam Drewnowski.

title: International Banknote Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included $1,023,000 for the quarter and $3,690,000 for the year, in proxy and other expenses. The expenses included various professional fees and expenses incurred in connection with the contested proxy solicitation for the 1989 annual shareholders meeting, expenses in connection with settlement of related litigation and expenses incurred in connection with the completed tender offer and pending merger agreement with U.S. Banknote Co. c-Included $11,488,000 gain on sale of 20 percent interest in subsidiary.

title: Oklahoma Faces Suit
description: Saying he had ''a slam-dunk case'' against the University of Oklahoma, a Washington-based lawyer demanded yesterday that the school reinstate its women's basketball program or face a Federal lawsuit. Arthur Bryant of Trial Lawyers for Public Justice, a public-interest law firm, said last week's decision by Oklahoma officials to eliminate the women's basketball program was in violation of the Constitution and Federal law.

title: General Communications reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included earnings of $22,043,000 from settlement of certain anti-trust litigation.

title: U.S. Securities Advance Sharply
description: Waves of speculative buying pushed prices of Treasury securities sharply higher yesterday. One impetus for the buying was rumors that a Japanese financial institution would disclose serious financial problems when the markets opened for business in Tokyo today.

title: United Stationers reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: To conform with current year presentations, certain reclassifications have been included for year-ago periods.

title: When Those Nice Kitties Are Jaguar Cubs
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: FOR fall, Ralph Lauren returned to the military theme that has proved so successful in his spring collection. But instead of an admiral's navy blue and gold braid, he turned to the Army's traditional khaki and olive fabrics mixed with brown leather.

title: After 4 Years, an Aftershock
description: A moderate earthquake hit the San Diego area today, and scientists said it was an aftershock from a larger quake that occurred four years ago. A spokesman for the California Institute of Technology said today's tremor measured 4.2 on the Richter scale. No damage was reported, but residents said they were shaken from their beds. The original quake, on July 13, 1986, measured 5.3 on the Richter scale and caused only minor damage. The spokesman said an aftershock four years later was unusual but not unknown.

title: Germania Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income In the latest quarter the bank established $7.7 million in additional provisions to cover credit losses, losses on real estate owned and changes in the market value of non-investment grade corporate bonds. Major components of the provisions were $4.4 million for loan losses and $2.6 million for real estate losses.

title: Sensormatic Electronics Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,434,000 for the quarter and $5,055,000 for the 9 months. The 1989 periods were restated.

title: Collaborative Research Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 3
High School Press Needs Revitalizing
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place;   Surprise Hurts Oracle Systems
description: WALL STREET hates a surprise. So when the Oracle Systems Corporation unexpectedly announced late on March 28 that earnings in its most recently completed quarter were flat, analysts dropped their recommendations and investors dumped a record volume of shares in the company, which is the leading producer of software for managing large data bases.

title: Sea Galley Stores reports earnings for 16wk to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $162,000, which consisted of a charge from extinguishment of debt and a reversal of tax loss carryforwards. c-Net income and after an extraordinary charge of $62,000 from extinguishment of debt and a gain from tax loss carryforward.

title: Prosecution Rests in Slaying of New Jersey Family
description: The prosecution rested its murder case against John E. List today after putting into evidence autopsy, ballistics and handwriting reports and about two dozen pictures, including some that were characterized as inflammatory by Mr. List's lawyer.

title: Group of 7 Meeting Is Expected to Be Quiet
description: The top economic policy makers from the United States and its six main industrial allies, when they meet in Paris Saturday, will discuss the momentous political and economic changes that have swept the world since their last meeting in September: the moves toward free markets in Eastern Europe, the German unification effort and the battering of the Japanese financial markets and the yen.

title: Great American CommunicaFtions Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $326,000 and $4,046,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and extraordinary credits of $2,732,000, or 9 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,927,000, or 6 cents a share, for the year. c-After income from discontinued operations of $551,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and $6,932,000, or 23 cents a share, for the year. The company said the extraordinary credits included a $4.4 million gain on the issuance of common stock in exchange for debt and a $2.5 million loss on the prepayment of other obligations.

title: Bank of New England Plans to Cut 5,600 Jobs
description: The Bank of New England Corporation announced a drastic plan yesterday to cut expenses and return to profitability by eliminating about a third of its payroll, The banking company, which had already begun to reduce its size by selling loans, said it planned to cut 5,600 jobs. About 1,700 workers would be notified within a few days, it said, and other jobs will be cut by the end of the year through attrition, sales of businesses and consolidations.

title: Catholics' Dilemma
description: To the Editor:

title: All American Semiconductor reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Year-ago share earnings are adjusted for a 5-for-4 stock split effect in February 1989. The company said the loss in 1989 is primarily due to expenses and losses incurred in connection with the acquisition and operations of Qar Industrial Electronic Sales Inc. in June 1989.

title: Bonn Investigates 2 Concerns in Libyan Deal
description: West German authorities are investigating two companies suspected of violating the nation's export laws by trying to purchase a computer system used in industrial processes and ship it to a Libyan chemical plant.

title: Baruch-Foster reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a net charge of $873,850 from writedown of oil and gas properties for both the quarter and year.

title: Chronicle
description: MARC CHRISTIAN was awarded $5.5 million from the estate of ROCK HUDSON a year ago because he had not been told of the actor's infection with AIDS during their two-year relationship. Now he has filed a $22 million libel suit against the authors and publisher of a new biography of the late movie star, ''Rock Hudson: Friend of Mine.''

title: Conan in Comics? Yes. Hulk? Sure. But Fafner? Wotan?
description: ''GRONNK'' cries Alberich the toad as Wotan steps on him. ''AROOOOOOOOO'' echoes Hunding's horn as he pursues Siegmund and Sieglinde with murderous intent. ''HARRARG'' howls Fafner the dragon during his fight with Siegfried. ''KTHOMP'' goes his mighty claw as it slams into the ground.

title: Thomas Baird; Art Professor, 66
description: Thomas Baird, a professor emeritus of fine arts at Trinity College in Hartford and a novelist, died of a heart attack in his car on March 28. He was 66 years old and lived in Hartford.

title: New Jersey Offers Top-Rated Debt
description: New Jersey, one of the few states whose general-obligation debt is still rated triple-A by both Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation, is offering $350 million of the securities through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Outdoors;   Fishing Guides Help Mark Favorite Runs
description: rrUnless you are totally familiar with the stream you plan to fish, a map of it should be part of your angling equipage. Such a map will enable you to identify and mark - for future reference - the pools and runs where you have your best luck. And when you are discussing the stream with a fellow angler, you'll be able to do so with precision.

title: How the West Was Done
description: The South Fork of the Shoshone River moves languorously through the hills, past cottonwood groves and whipped-cream peaks dotted with sagebrush and elk. Here, not far from the eastern border of Yellowstone Park, geography is measured not in tidy streets and avenues, but in bluffs, basins and gnarled nubs of rock.

title: Gemco National reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge from a loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $750,000. c-After income from discontinued operations of $4,000 for the quarter and $560,000 for the year, and extraordinary charges from a loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $436,000 and $938,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: International Broadcast reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Money-Fund Yields Mixed
description: Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were mixed for the week that ended yesterday, with yields for taxable funds down and those for tax-exempt funds higher.

title: Dionics Inc.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Czech Holds a Mirror Up to Canada
description: It is a substantial assignment anywhere to use words to knit a national fabric of nonfiction heroes and fables. It is a gargantuan assignment to take on that task in Canada, a vast collection of disparate regions that have traditionally lacked unifying heroes and villains.

title: Mutual Funds Outpace the Market
description: After years of weak performance, mutual funds that invest in technology stocks bounced back and were the best performers in the first quarter. And the break in the Japanese stock market hurt funds that invest in the Pacific region, making these securities the worst performers in the period.

title: Jet Makes Emergency Landing
description: A Boston-bound Eastern Airlines jetliner made an emergency landing at National Airport today after the rear stairway of the Boeing 727 popped open, an airport spokesman, David Hess, said. No injuries were reported.

title: Review/Dance;   Japanese Distillation In 3 Works At the Joyce
description: Eiko and Koma, choreographers and performers who left their native Japan for New York, where they have presented their work for the last 15 years, offered three new fables for our time on Tuesday night.

title: Transtector Systems Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Most Units Of Bonwit Will Close
description: Most of the Bonwit Teller specialty retail chain, including the main store in Trump Tower in Manhattan, will go out of business by June under several arrangements announced in bankruptcy court yesterday.

title: Hershey Oil reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a charge of $838,000 related to writedown of an Australian joint venture for both the quarter and year. c-Net income d-Included a writedown of U.S. oil and gas properties of $2,050,000. Year-ago results certain revenue items have been reclassified to conform with the 1989 presentation.

title: Industry Wary of Clean-Air Bill
description: Industrial companies across America reacted with varying degrees of pessimism to the clean-air legislation passed by the Senate on Tuesday. They are resigned to paying billions of dollars in additional pollution-control costs but warn that those costs will be passed on to consumers.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Friday on the obituary of Isidore Adler, a scientist, educator and researcher, referred incorrectly to his research on the moon.

title: GORBACHEV WARNS ESTONIA ON MOVES FOR INDEPENDENCE
description: The Estonian president said today that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev had personally warned him that Estonia should not follow Lithuania in declaring independence.

description: Year-ago results are restated to reflect a change in method of accounting for income taxes.

Righetti Will Get Relief Help
description: When the day was done, the game did not seem so important. Pascual Perez pitched for the first time this spring and the principals in the Don Mattingly contract negotiations conferred for the second time in two days, but the most startling development concerned Dave Righetti.

title: Laidlaw Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Latest figures included the results of Tricil Ltd. since Jan. 1.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Pro Bono
description: * Backer Spielvogel Bates has produced a dozen public service television commercials to mark the 25th anniversary of the New York Landmarks Preservation Commission.

title: Talking Deals;   Lockheed's Moves In Proxy Fight
description: COMPANIES have long been willing to pay a high price to maintain their independence when faced with corporate raiders and disgruntled minority shareholders. But when challenged with a proxy fight started by the Dallas investor Harold C. Simmons, the Lockheed Corporation decided to make major concessions to the institutional investors that own the majority of its stock.

title: Christian Factions Trade Fire In Battles in Beirut and Hills
description: Rival Christian factions traded artillery shells and rockets today in Christian East Beirut and the Kesrouan hills northeast of here, and a five-story building in the militia-held quarter of Nabaa was set ablaze.

title: Julius Granirer; Lawyer, 86
description: Julius Granirer, a lawyer and the president of the Peninsula Hospital Center in Far Rockaway, Queens, died of a heart attack on Tuesday at Huntington (L.I.) Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived in Rockaway Park, Queens.

title: Alliance Well reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income c-Included an extraordinary charge of $6,000 in the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $970,000 for the year. The company said the extraordinary charge and extraordinary gain resulted from acquisition.

title: Bangkok Talks on Cambodia Are Proposed by Sihanouk
description: Prince Norodom Sihanouk said today that he had proposed a meeting of all four warring Cambodian factions in Bangkok on April 15.

title: Allegheny Sues Japonica on Votes
description: Allegheny International Inc., a Pittsburgh-based maker of small appliances, said it had sued Japonica Partners L.P., seeking to disallow its votes on Allegheny's plan to reorganize under Chapter 11 bankruptcy. In the suit, Allegheny said a bankruptcy court had the right to rule that the vote on a reorganization plan by certain parties was not in good faith and could be disallowed.

title: Results Plus
description: N.B.A.

title: Ascot Investment reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said Revenue Properties Co. now owns 37 percent of Ascot shares, fully diluted, after purchasing 25 million Ascot shares at 15 cents a share. Year-ago results are restated. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: We Are Warned
description: Once more we have been clearly warned and once more we have a choice.

description: b-Net loss

description: b-Net loss Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Rangers Have Edge in Round One
description: When the Rangers play the Islanders in the first round of the Stanley Cup playoffs, which begins tonight in Madison Square Garden, the Rangers' obvious advantages should lead any rational observer to choose them to win in four or five games, or six at the most.

title: Smartcard International reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Seeds of Arab-Israeli Hope Bloom in the Desert;   Jerusalem Solutions
description: To the Editor:

title: Heritage Financial reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Contel to Combine Telephone Groups
description: The Contel Corporation, a telecommunications company based in Atlanta, said it would eliminate about 600 jobs across the country in its telephone operations division. It said the cutbacks, which represent about 4 percent of the telephone operation's staff, would take place in the next two years and are expected to be achieved largely through attrition and voluntary separation programs.

title: DISPUTE EMERGES IN BOSTON MURDER
description: In a bitterly contested move, prosecutors investigating the Charles Stuart murder case are trying to force Mr. Stuart's lawyer, to whom they believe he confessed killing his wife, to testify before a grand jury.

title: Textile and Shoe Import Bill
description: A bill to restrict textile and shoe imports to the United States was introduced today in Congress with more than 250 House and Senate sponsors.

title: Clarus Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: M.D.C. Holdings Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $22,002,000, or $1.38 a share, for the quarter and $58,456,000, or $3.67 a share, for the year, both from repurchase of senior subordinated and subordinated notes. c-After extraordinary credits of $12,859,000, or 78 cents a share, and $55,306,000, or $3.20 a share, for the quarter and year, respectively, both from repurchase of senior subordinated and subordinated notes.

title: Find-SVP Inc.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Maxtor Accepted In Miniscribe Bid
description: The Maxtor Corporation, a maker of computer disk drives based in San Jose, Calif., said its bid to acquire substantially all of the assets of the bankrupt Miniscribe Corporation, a disk maker in Longmont, Colo., had been accepted by the United States Bankruptcy Court in Denver. Under the bid, Maxtor will pay $21.5 million in cash and $20 million in stock, and Miniscribe's Hong Kong and Singapore operations will release $4.5 million in cash and acounts receivable to the court.

title: Medcross Inc. reports earnings for 12mo Dec 31
A New Buyout Firm Finds Salt to Its Liking
description: D. G. Harris & Associates, a leveraged buyout firm, has found a niche in the salt mines with the creation of a new company, the North American Salt Company. Michael R. Boyce has been named its president and chief operating officer.

title: International Mobile MaFchines reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Leisure Concepts reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Republicans Sidestep Cuomo Barbs
description: New York's budget is late and the state is in a crisis ''wrought by Republicans,'' said Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. ''Every day there's more pain,'' he told reporters in the Capitol earlier this week. ''Every day there's more shame.''

title: What Can Go Wrong in Census? 2.3 Million Undelivered Packets
description: Census Bureau officials said today that more than 2.3 million of the 88.5 million census forms that the bureau mailed out to households around the country could not be delivered.

title: North East Insurance reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a reversal of tax loss carryforward of $179,892. c-After an extraordinary tax loss carryforward of $92,000, or 3 cents a share. d-Net income e-After extraordinary credits of $163,000, or 6 cents a share, for the quarter and $578,000, or 20 cents a share, for the year.

title: Unity Healthcare Holdings reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-The company said it broke even in the year-ago period.

title: A Czech Cousin Haunts Budweiser
description: Anheuser-Busch, the brewer of Budweiser beer, is negotiating with the Czech producer of the 16th-century original of the same name to settle longstanding trademark differences. If they reach an agreement, European beer drinkers may soon confront the question: Which Bud's for you?

title: Precision Standard reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Comparable results for the fourth quarter was not available. The company changed to a calendar year in December 1988, from a fiscal year ended April 30.

title: Corona Strike Ends
description: The brewery that makes Corona beer was back in operation today after workers ended a seven-week strike for higher wages. Officials at the Cerveceria Modelo S.A. de C.V. brewery said workers returned after a new union was formed. Negotiations between the company and the old union, representing 5,200 workers, failed to resolve the dispute.

title: Amerihealth Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss of $904,000 from a cumulative effect on prior periods of an accounting change. c-Net income and no share earnings after preferred stock dividend requirements. d-Included an extraordinary charge of $111,000 reversal of tax-loss carryforward for the quarter and an extraordinary tax benefit from tax-loss carryforward of $267,000 for the year.

title: ICN Biomedicals reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $273,000, or 3 cents a share, due to the repurchase of debt. Year-ago results are restated to reflect 20 percent stock dividend paid in August 1989.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Ladies' Home Journal Goes to Lotas Minard
description: Lotas Minard Patton McIver picked up its third magazine trade account yesterday, when the Meredith Corporation gave it the assignment to advertise The Ladies' Home Journal, the venerable women's magazine.

title: Commercial Bank Growth
description: Allowing commercial banks to underwrite securities and to open branches nationwide are two crucial steps Congress can take to improve the global competitiveness of the industry, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board said today. Mr. Greenspan told a House subcommittee group that another essential step is to lower the cost of capital for United States banks by cutting the federal deficit. This would allow interest rates to fall and add to the amount of savings available for private investment, he said.

title: 2 Researchers Spell 'I.B.M.,' Atom by Atom
description: Hiram Maxim, the inventor of the machine gun, used to demonstrate his marksmanship by firing patterns of bullets into walls to spell out the initials of potential customers. In a similar vein, I.B.M. announced yesterday that its scientists had spelled out the company's initials by dragging single atoms into the desired pattern on the surface of a crystal of nickel.

title: Children's Discovery Centers reports earnings for Year to Dec 30
Study Backs Advice on Preventing Heart Disease
description: A study of more than 12,000 middle-aged men found that those given help to stop smoking, lower their blood pressure, lose weight and go on cholesterol-lowering diets substantially cut their risk of heart attack.

title: Lynam Is Major Weapon Behind 76er Success
description: An hour before a recent game, Jimmy Lynam, the Philadelphia 76ers' coach, was sitting quietly in his office at the Spectrum. Outside the coach's door, Charles Barkley was playfully slapping one of his teammates on the head. And Rick Mahorn, the 76ers' power forward, was laughing uncontrollably, telling a visitor that the necktie he was wearing was the ugliest necktie Mahorn had ever seen.

title: Springer's Medical Tribune To Start Publishing Today
description: Axel Springer Verlag A.G., Europe's largest newspaper publisher and fourth-largest media company, makes its publishing debut in the United States today with the revamped Medical Tribune, a national newspaper for doctors.

title: Review/Opera;   New Jersey State Troupe's 'Nabucco'
description: ''Nabucco,'' Giuseppe Verdi's third opera and his first major success, has been trying to break out of the ghetto of operatic rarities. Several points militate against its escape. One is that Verdi's late operas are so much richer than his early ones that ''Nabucco'' - a decidedly mature effort, with three-dimensional characters and some splendid music - is regarded as a stepping stone. Another is that the demands the work makes on singers are rarely met with complete success these days.

title: Steve's Homemade Ice Cream reports earnings for Year to Dec 30
description: b-Included a gain from the early extinguishment of debt of $424,000, or 3 cents a share.

title: Architecture Gallery Honors an Innovator
description: UNTIL now, New York City did not have a permanent gallery for architecture. The New Gallery at Buell Hall opened on the campus of Columbia University on Tuesday, and its first show, ''The Filter of Reason: Work of Paul Nelson,'' comprises some 200 paintings, photographs and models. It will be on view through May 11.

title: Willie Musarurwa; Journalist, 62
description: Willie Musarurwa, a veteran journalist who spent 10 years in jail for his political activities, died on Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack, hospital officials said. He was 62 years old.

title: Banco Popular de Puerto Rico reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Europe Prices Up 0.5%
description: Consumer prices in the European Community rose five-tenths of 1 percent in February, the same monthly rate as in January, the European Community statistical office, Eurostat, said on Tuesday. The annual inflation rate held at 5.2 percent for the third month. Portugal again recorded the biggest monthly increase, 2.3 percent, while living costs in Greece and Luxembourg rose the least, a tenth of 1 percent.

title: Deals
description: YANKEES (AL) - Optioned Clay Parker and Dave Eiland, pitchers, to Columbus of the International League. Assigned John Habyan, pitcher, and Jeff Datz, catcher, to Columbus. Sent Jimmy Jones, pitcher, outright to Columbus.

title: Circle K Debt Plan
description: The Circle K Corporation, the nation's second-largest chain of convenience stores, said today that it had reached an agreement with lenders to restructure part of its $1.3 billion debt. It said the agreement was with its bank lenders, holders of $200 million in senior secured notes and the American Financial Corporation, Circle K's largest shareholder and a creditor. Circle K agreed to buy back at least 90 percent of its $510 million in subordinated debt by Oct. 31 at undetermined terms. Last week, the company reported that it lost more than $40 million on operations during the quarter ended Jan. 31.

title: New Hewlett Lab
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company, America's third-largest computer maker, said it was setting up a research laboratory in Tokyo as part of a global expansion of its research operations. The company's president, John A. Young, said the lab would focus on applied research in photonics, integrated-circuit testing and low-temperature electronic devices. Employment is expected to grow to 50 in five years from five this year, he said. The company announced the formation of science centers last year at Stanford University in California and at the University of Pisa in Italy. The company's first overseas laboratory was set up in Bristol, England, in 1984.

title: U.S. Hotel Project Includes Japanese
description: A group of four Japanese companies and one from the United States will jointly build an $88 million resort hotel in a San Diego suburb, the Japanese concerns said. The Kumagai Gumi Company, the Kawasaki Steel Corporation, the Marubeni Corporation and the Tekken Construction Company will participate in the project with the United States developer Joelen Enterprise.

title: Vehicle Sales Increased By 2.9% in Late March
description: Sales of American-made cars and light trucks rose by 2.9 percent in late March, compared with the weak selling levels of a year earlier, leading some automobile executives to express hope that sales are gaining strength as the important spring season draws near.

title: Mayor and a Councilman Are Indicted in Hialeah
description: The Mayor of Hialeah, Florida's fifth-largest city, has been indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges that he conspired with a City Councilman to extort payoffs from developers in exchange for approving zoning changes. The Councilman was also indicted.

title: Tokyo Stocks Drop Sharply And Recover
description: The Nikkei index of 225 stocks fell nearly 4 percent here Thursday morning, but then scored a stunning recovery, regaining almost all its loss in the last hour of trading.

title: Witness Tells of Marcos Co-op Deal
description: Imelda Marcos was determined to go to extraordinary lengths to conceal her attempts to buy a Park Avenue co-op apartment and millions of dollars of artwork and she used a close friend as a front in carrying out the transactions, a former employee of Sotheby's auction house testified yesterday.

title: Books of The Times;   When an Illness Binds and Defines
description: Love and Other Infectious Diseases

title: Ireland Is Expected to Scrap The Death Penalty This Year
description: Ireland is to formally abolish the death penalty and introduce automatic jail sentences of at least 30 years for certain convicted killers, the Government said in a bill published today.

description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $18,798,000, or $3.78 a share. c-Net income d-After income from discontinued operations of $17,102,000, or $3.45 a share, and $14,762,000, or $2.98 a share, for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Personal Health
description: A listing of information sources about diabetes on Thursday, with the Personal Health column, misstated the address of the American Diabetes Association. It is 1660 Duke Street, Alexandria, Va. 22314.

It said operating and equipment problems hindered production resulting in high wastage and reduced sales. The company also said it took a writedown of $4.2 million, mainly due to deferred costs. Results are in Canadian funds.

description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $112,789 for the quarter and $134,431 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $83,335 for the quarter and $234,997 for the year; the quarter also included an extraordinary reversal of tax loss carryforward of $113,679. The latest year's income from continuing operations included pre-tax gains of $2.6 million from favorable court decision and $1.1 million from sale of assets and unrealized loss of $1.1 million on ownership position in Kirschner Medical.

title: CLOSE TO HOME
description: I USED to do it a lot, stand in line I mean, listening to the people ahead of me ask for four seats in the center of row H for June 18. How do they know they'll be alive on June 18, I wondered, and why does it have to be row H? Given good eyes, good ears and no appointments that I couldn't change at the last minute, I always asked for whatever was available.

Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the experimental use of the drug alpha interferon to treat AIDS misidentified the newsletter that reported the findings. It was Biotechnology Newswatch, not Biotechnology Newsletter.

title: Underdog to Front-Runner in Connecticut

description: Sometimes tardiness has its rewards. At Public School 94, it means the opportunity to be taken in hand by Barbara Williams. Moments after the 8:35 buzzer, at her post just inside the entrance, she is greeting, admonishing and encouraging, always encouraging, the latecomers and their parents.

title: Bridge
description: The final of the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship, played in Fort Worth two weeks ago, featured a plethora of hands in the slam zone: 15 in the first 32 deals. The team led by Zia Mahmood of Manhattan, which eventually lost the title, got the worst of most of them, and two early in the second half dealt the team a blow from which it did not recover. On one of them the Zia team reached a hopeless grand slam, only to find that its opponents, headed by Dan Morse of Houston, had rested in game. The Zia players could have won 13 instead of losing 13 if they had rested in a small slam.

title: Why Tax Apartment Dwellers More?
description: With New York City's budget gap widening, a painful rise in the real property tax rate becomes inevitable. Property valuation under present law makes the pain much worse for apartment house dwellers and commercial tenants than for homeowners. The impending increase can force attention to the need for reform.

title: Kings Rally to Beat Flames In Opener of Playoffs, 5-3

title: East Germany's Mass Graves Prompt Inquiry by Moscow
description: The Soviet Union said today that it had opened an investigation into mass graves where thousands were buried after World War II in Soviet-occupied East Germany.

The 68-year-old former director of the Ford Foundation, recuperating from heart surgery, was presented the Distinguished Grantmaker Award for career achievement in philanthropy by DWIGHT L. ALLISON and JAMES A. JOSEPH, chairman and president, respectively, of the Council on Foundations.

To Ease Harsh Drought, Greeks Try Prayer

title: Exhibit of the Best 80's Fabrics
description: TEXTILES that look like pleated aluminum, black lacquer or marble are among more than 150 exhibited at ''Color, Light, Surface: Contemporary Fabrics.'' The show, which opened Tuesday at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum, the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of Design, is a retrospective of the most avant-garde fabric design of the 1980's from Europe, the United States and Japan. There is not a cabbage rose in sight. ''I chose to ignore anything based on history, including 18th-century chintzes, cabbage roses and Frank Lloyd Wright's designs,'' said Milton Sonday, curator of textiles at the museum. ''And if you cut out all this, you are left with fabrics that had color, light and surface.''

title: Overkill in Panama
description: On the same day the U.S. invaded Panama last December, the Lithuanian Communist Party declared its independence from the overall Soviet party. In an article on Dec. 22, 1989, I pointed out that the news from Lithuania had been ''little noticed among the headlines'' about Panama.

title: A Hard Road For Mandela;   Doubt About Support Is Clouding Prospects

title: King Robert of Zimbabwe?
description: As a result of a repressively conducted election, the way is now clear for President Robert Mugabe to scrap multiparty democracy in Zimbabwe. Not only did Mr. Mugabe win re-election last weekend by a lopsided 78 percent; his party took 116 of 120 elected seats in Parliament. If he acts on this ''mandate'' for one-party autocracy, the people of Zimbabwe will be the losers.

The change decreased the net loss by $6.2 million, or 44 cents a share, and reflected $4.8 million gain from disposal of a license. It's a huge improvement over current law, and tougher than George Bush's proposals. It reconciles regional differences, and will encourage technology. If matched by the House, it will let the nation breathe easier.

Schacht, said that Cummins would report a moderate profit for the first quarter despite a decrease in sales from the fourth quarter and that the earnings trend could continue if North American truck sales recoveredafter a sharp drop in demand last year.

title: Review/Film;   Peter Greenaway's Elegant and Brutal 'Cook'
description: If the most crass and sadistic people gained power, what would happen to the social order, to art and, above all, to love? This is the question Peter Greenaway explores in his elegant, stylized and brutal new film. ''The Cook, the Thief, His Wife and Her Lover'' may sound like another civilized marital minuet. But Mr. Greenaway turns this tale of a bullying criminal and his unfaithful wife into something profound and extremely rare: a work so intelligent and powerful that it evokes our best emotions and least civil impulses, so esthetically brilliant that it expands the boundaries of film itself.

Rumors spread that the comet could alter the magnetic field and electrocute bystanders. A doctor hypothesized that the comet's gas could ''trigger a vast array of neurological disorders.'' Hotels and bars served a drink called the Comet Cocktail.

Retailers, many in bankruptcy court, wanted a warranty that the clothes they ordered would be sure to sell. Designers were sticking mainly to what they considered safe styles. So there were lots of neat suits, short evening dresses and easy coats. Often there was an outburst of color, as if designers finally exploded.

description: It is hard to say whether American politics can actually be improved, but there sure are a lot of people talking about what is wrong. In fact, talking about politics has become a cottage industry.

description: The Eastman Kodak Company, Rochester's largest employer and taxpayer and one of its major civic benefactors, today admitted two criminal violations of state anti-pollution laws and was fined $1.15 million.

title: Massachusetts Acts to Permit Homosexual Foster Parents
description: Five years after virtually barring homosexual men and women from serving as foster parents, the State of Massachusetts has proposed new regulations to reverse the policy.

title: Tokyo Stocks Up Sharply
description: Share prices soared on the Tokyo Stock Exchange today, encouraged by the dollar's retreat against the yen. In late trading the Nikkei average of 225 stocks was up 989.44 points, or 3.5 percent, to 29,238.50.

title: Adviser to Selectronics Is Chosen Its President
description: Selectronics Inc., a developer and manufacturer of handheld electronic reference products, has named James Finke, a longtime executive in the electronics industry, as its president and chief operating officer.

title: A Wealth of Oratorios
description: The concerts listed are free unless otherwise noted.

title: The Lamentation And the Joy: Music for Easter
description: THE relationship between music and religion goes back further than can be traced, except through legend and surmise. It has not always been an easy marriage: from at least the time of Pope Gregory the Great, in the late sixth century, churches have periodically issued decrees that defined the kinds of music appropriate for both sacred and secular use.

title: A Skewed Vision of a Small Town In 'Twin Peaks,'
description: Welcome to Twin Peaks, says the road sign. Population: 51,201. Well, make that an even 51,200. A young woman named Laura Palmer, the high school homecoming queen, is about to be found murdered, her body wrapped in plastic. So begins ''Twin Peaks,'' the new ABC series that is bringing the distinctively skewed vision of the film director David Lynch (''The Elephant Man,'' ''Blue Velvet'') to weekly television. This is event television given a memorably wicked spin. Nothing like it has ever been seen on network prime time. A special two-hour premiere is being broadcast Sunday at 9 P.M. Weekly hourlong episodes will follow on Thursdays at 9 P.M.

title: Buck Calls CBS Games
description: Five days after refusing to renew Brent Musburger's contract, CBS announced yesterday that Jack Buck, for 40 years the voice of the St. Louis Cardinals, would replace Musburger as the play-by-play announcer for its first team on the network's baseball coverage this season. Buck will team with Tim McCarver. The second team will pair Dick Stockton and Jim Kaat.

title: Restaurants
description: Cafe des Artistes, in a historic turn-of-the-century building off Central Park West, hardly needs promotion. Despite its reputation over the years for unpredictable food, getting a table on short notice is harder than booking weekend tickets to Broadway's ''Cat on a Hot Tin Roof.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: ECONOMY

title: Quarterly Net Loss For Businessland
description: Businessland Inc., the computer retail chain, said it would announce lower-than-expected earnings and revenues for the quarter ended March 31. The company expects operating income to be at break-even, creating a net loss, and to report revenues of about $320 million, compared with $293.3 million in the similar period last year. Businessland shares closed today at $8.875, down $1.50, on the New York Stock Exchange. Its 14.5 percent decline was the third worst of the day.

title: States Drop Record-Labeling Bills
description: Bills that call for mandatory labeling of record albums with explicit lyrics have been dropped by most of the states that had been considering them, a trade group for record retailers and two parent groups announced today.

title: Rowland H. S. Bedell; Ophthalmologist, 55
description: Dr. Rowland Holbrook Smith Bedell, an ophthalmologist who formerly headed two medical units of the Federal Aviation Administration, died of a heart attack on Wednesday at his home in Bethesda. Md. He was 55 years old.

title: Galvest Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Man Charged in '71 Slayings Is Called 'Confused'
description: John E. List, accused of killing five members of his family in 1971, has diabetes and is suffering some memory loss, a doctor who examined him in his jail cell testified today.

title: On Stage
description: Vocal Minorities

title: High-Detail TV Faces Fund Cuts
description: The Defense Department has quietly proposed diverting $20 million of the $30 million intended for research on high-definition television, a technology that has become a symbol in the debate over how the United States can best compete with the Japanese.

title: AIDS Dominates Nonfiction Series OF Film and Video
description: ''WHEN I was told that I'd contracted this virus, it didn't take me long to realize that I'd contracted a diseased society as well,'' declares the artist, poet and experimental film maker David Wojnarowicz in the scorching AIDS documentary film ''Silence Equals Death.'' ''I'm carrying this rage like a blood-filled egg. There's a thin line between the inside and the outside, between thought and action.''

title: JAPANESE PLEDGE TO LOWER BARRIERS TO TRADE WITH U.S.
description: In a sweeping agreement with Washington to reduce trade barriers, Tokyo pledged today to take actions intended to make it easier for foreigners to invest in Japan and do business there.

title: Mestek Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Sanchez Vicario Fails To Stop Capriati's Ascent
description: She kept herself under control as she walked off the court, but let loose with a whoop as soon as she was out of earshot of her victim. Still more girl than woman, 14-year-old Jennifer Capriati continued to bulldoze her way to the top of women's tennis today by demolishing Arantxa Sanchez Vicario, the French Open champion, 6-1, 6-1, to advance to the quarterfinals of the Family Circle Cup.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a study of a treatment for chicken pox misidentified the scientific journal in which the study was described. It was The Journal of Pediatrics.

title: Guardian Capital reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $753,000, or 13 cents a share. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Monkey Virus Infects 4 Workers But None Are Sick, U.S. Reports
description: Four animal handlers have become infected with a virus carried by laboratory monkeys but none have become sick, Federal health officials said today.

title: Northrop Stakes
description: The Northrop Corporation, the builder of the B-2 bomber, said two investment firms had purchased large amounts of its stock. The firm of Sanford C. Bernstein has acquired 8.1 percent of Northrop's 47 million common shares, and the Delaware Management Company has acquired 6.3 percent, the company said. It was unclear whether Mr. Bernstein and Delaware Management were holding the shares in trust. Northrop's stock finished today at $15.625, up 62.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Old and New Masters Pass In the Light
description: Arnold Palmer's long drive had rolled down almost to the base of the hill on the ninth fairway. And now, up behind the green of the 435-yard hole, a tournament announcer intoned, ''I do want to give this next man his due.'' Moments later, Palmer's ball landed on the green but rolled onto the fringe. And as the four-time Masters champion was introduced, the applause erupted.

title: Mandela and de Klerk Announce Agreement on New Date for Talks
description: President F. W. de Klerk and Nelson Mandela agreed today to reschedule formal talks between the Government and the African National Congress on a political settlement on South Africa's future.

title: Auctions
description: The Modern Art Museum of Fort Worth is auctioning Thomas Eakins's ''Swimming Hole,'' from about 1885, at Sotheby's on May 24. Art dealers yesterday criticized the sale of the painting, was bought from Eakins's widow for $700 in 1925, because it is the only major work by Eakins owned by a Texas museum, Questions were also raised about the museum's choice of Sotheby's to auction the painting because the chairwoman of the museum is Anne Windfour Marion, who is the wife of John L. Marion, chairman of Sotheby's North America.

title: People
description: * Linda C. Seale has joined Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising as executive vice president and human resources director for North America. Perry Davis, the agency's director of technology management, has been appointed a senior vice president.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Sax by Sonny Rollins

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums

title: Chronicle
description: As a neuropsychiatrist at the Harvard Medical School and Massachussets General Hospital, DR. ROBERT PORTNEY will lecture tomorrow on prescription-drug abuse at a psychiatric conference in Orlando, Fla. And as a concert violinist, he will play Bach and Paganini tomorrow night at a benefit in Orlando for Snowbabies, a group there that aids children of drug-addicted mothers.

title: Central Banking System reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bushes See Michael Jackson
description: White House employees, including secretaries and maintenance men, gathered under the Rose Garden portico, straining their necks and clicking cameras. On Pennsylvania Avenue, curious crowds gathered at the fence awaiting his departure in a white stretch limousine. A visiting head of state? No, it was the elusive megastar Michael Jackson, come to see the President.

title: A Streamlined Morgan Stanley
description: Its Wall Street competitors may be suffering - laying off thousands, reporting huge losses and even collapsing altogether - but at Morgan Stanley & Company the tune is strikingly upbeat.

title: Review/Film;   Music, Musicians and a Louisiana Rollick
description: Early in ''J'ai Ete au Bal'' (''I Went to the Dance''), an exuberant tribute to the continuing vitality of Louisiana's Cajun and zydeco music, Marc Savoy, an accordionist, tells a story about two Cajun musicians who worried that there might not be anything for them to do in heaven.

title: Winged Rocket Launched Into Orbit by Plane
description: A winged rocket built by a private company was launched into orbit from a B-52 aircraft over the Pacific Ocean today, marking an important step in the nation's efforts to develop a low-cost and reliable way to send small satellites into space.

title: Review/Music;   'Passio,' Arvo Part's Interpretation of the St. John Passion
description: Arvo Part is a name already familiar to American record collectors, many of whom seem to have been drawn to his work because of its reliance on a radical austerity that rejects the tortured complexity of much contemporary music. An audience eager to hear his ''Passio,'' a setting of the Passion According to St. John, therefore filled Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday evening. Fervent Part disciples were in evidence, as well as some skeptics curious to investigate a much-publicized composition in its first New York performance.

title: Books of The Times;   Suffocating in Society And Unable to Escape
description: The Stories of Edith Wharton

title: Crownamerica Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 3
description: b-Included exchange gains of $190,000, or 18 cents a share. c-Included gain of $319,000, or 30 cents a share, from the sale of the company's U.K. subsidiary and exchange gains of $387,000, or 37 cents a share.

title: At the Bar
description: In the opening scene of ''Mountain,'' William O. Douglas is on his deathbed, marshaling his dwindling energies to defend his career. ''The law must be about life!'' he rails. ''About the people and their lives! How can you sit in judgment on them if you haven't lived? If you haven't taken those journeys?''

title: Biomagnetic Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Dixie Carter as Herself

title: Lionel Is Urged To Sell Big Stake
description: An investment group led by a Florida brokerage, which controls a 5 percent stake in the Lionel Corporation, has asked the New York toy retailer to set up a committee to consider the sale of a large stake in the company.

title: Review/Art;   A Brazilian Explores Loss and Exploitation
description: Cildo Meireles's ''Oblivion'' was shown in last fall's Sao Paulo Bienal as part of a large Brazilian section. Now the installation has been brought to the Museum of Modern Art as part of the ''Projects'' series of contemporary art. It is more self-contained in New York, and the national context of the work - particularly the large scale and love of offbeat materials that Mr. Meireles shares with many other Brazilian artists - is lost. But its polemical and visual strength are clearer.

title: S. Gershon Levi, 81, A Former President Of a Rabbis' Group
description: Rabbi S. Gershon Levi, a former president of the Rabbinical Assembly and a former editor of the quarterly publication Conservative Judaism, died of heart failure yesterday at his home in Jerusalem. He was 81 years old. Rabbi Levi, an ardent Zionist who retired to Israel in the mid-1970's, was a translator of Yiddish and Hebrew classics, among them ''Gates of Bronze'' by Haim Hazaz (The Jewish Publication Society, 1975). He also translated and edited a two-volume work by Gedaliah Alon, ''The Jews in Their Land in the Talmudic Age'' (Magnes Press of the Hebrew University, 1980 and 1984).

title: Deal-Making in Israel Spurs Demands for Reform
description: Their voices are difficult to hear above the din of promises, threats and warnings that characterize politics here, but the Israeli people are once again demanding that their Government reform itself.

title: France Offers NATO Model for United Germany
description: To the Editor:

title: CFS Group Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Card Tel Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said the reduction in loss for 1989 is a result of an increase in revenues, an extraordinary gain on the extinguishment of debt of $291,547, or 4 cents a share, with various unsecured creditors, and a reduction in the number of employees, professional fees and other expenses.

title: Why Tolerate Campus Bigots?
description: LEAD: In recent years, life on the American campus has become ruder, less civil - nastier. It has turned with the general social tide toward a more anxious self-assertiveness that harbors little respect for the strange or different. Ominously, campuses have proven fertile ground for a renascent bigotry, with an increasing number of racial incidents and serious crimes.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Menu for Newspaper Editors: Criticism and 60's Headliners
description: The nation's newspaper editors have received a thorough scolding at their annual convention here this week, most of it self-administered.

title: Upheaval in the East;   East Europe Considers Cutting Aid to Indochina
description: The collapse of European Communism and the withering of Comecon, the Eastern-bloc trading association, have led Eastern European countries to consider reducing their diplomatic representation and aid to Cambodia and Vietnam.

title: New Neil Simon Play to Close Before Reaching Broadway
description: Neil Simon's new play, ''Jake's Women,'' will close in San Diego and not come to Broadway this month as scheduled, the playwright announced yesterday. It will be the first time that a Broadway-bound play by Mr. Simon has folded out of town.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The cordial nature of the discussions and the concessions that had been made by both sides gave us the impression that we are correct in sitting down with the Government.''

title: Addendum
description: * TVSM Inc., the publisher of The Cable Guide, has merged with Cable Publications Inc., the division of the Crosby Vandenburgh Group that publishes TV Entertainment magazine. The company will retain the TVSM name and will continue to publish both of the monthly television listings guides.

title: A Calendar of Music for the Easter Season
description: rd's ''Easter Antiphon,'' the Hallelujah Chorus from Handel's ''Messiah'' and other works; Timothy Smith, organist; James A. Simms, director, 9 and 11:15 A.M. Information: 602-0800.

title: Hornets Sign Littles
description: Gene Littles, who took over as the interim coach of the Charlotte Hornets in January, got the job on a permanent basis yesterday when he was given a multiyear contract by the owner, George Shinn. The Hornets are 8-25 under Littles, who took over when Dick Harter was dismissed Jan. 31. ''My heart has always been in coaching,'' said Littles, who joined the Hornets' front office when the team was being formed and later took on the additional role of a assistant coach. (AP)

title: Dean of New School Picked To Head Planning Agency
description: Filling the most important vacancy left in his administration, Mayor David N. Dinkins has chosen Richard L. Schaffer, dean of the Graduate School of Management and Urban Professions at the New School for Social Research, as chairman of the city's Planning Commission.

title: Browning To Drop Waste Unit
description: Browning-Ferris Industries, the nation's second-largest waste-disposal company, said yesterday that it was abandoning its efforts to turn around Cecos International Inc., its struggling hazardous-waste subsidiary.

title: Accounts
description: * Turkish Tourist Board, to Young & Rubicam Europe and Burson-Marsteller Europe, for advertising and public relations in Europe and North America.

title: Real S O S Is Obscured By Hoax, and 2 Are Lost
description: The call, on a marine hailing frequency, was urgent: A ship off Massachusetts was transmitting a plea for help. A minute later there was another call. That one seemed to be a hoax, so the Coast Guard decided not to start searching the waters.

title: South Africa: Not Black and White
description: If the events of the last week in South Africa prove anything, it's that things there aren't as simple as black and white. That means outsiders will have to show patience as new leaders jockey and jolt each other toward a settlement.

title: B&H Ocean Carriers reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago results are not comparable because the company began operations on Aug. 17, 1988.

title: Southwestern Public Service Co. reports earnings for 12mo Feb 28
Communications World reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income Year-ago share earnings were not given because they were less than one cent a share.

title: KEY RATES
Picket-Fence America, As Seen by John Waters
description: Not content to watch old Presley movies on television, John Waters has made a brand new one, and made it in the manner of a teen-crazed Cecil B. DeMille. ''Cry-Baby,'' Mr. Waters's epic vision of mid-1950's high-school Americana, has a sweeping scale not usually associated with so dopey a subject, and for a while, almost enough exuberance to make that scale seem right. It also has droll costumes, elaborate musical numbers and a cast that's less a dramatic ensemble than a collection of found art. What it doesn't have, unfortunately, is enough true conviction to rise above novelty status. Nor does it really have a plot.

title: Former Savings Executive Sentenced to 30 Years in Jail
description: In the harshest punishment for any executive convicted of fraud in the collapse of a savings institution, the former chairman and chief executive of the Vernon Savings and Loan Association was sentenced today to 30 years in prison.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Kremlin Troops Move In to Evict Lithuania Aides
description: Continuing its campaign of pressure, the Kremlin sent troops on another foray in the Lithuanian capital today and repeated its refusal to hold formal talks with separatist leaders until the Baltic republic voids its declaration of independence.

title: Seagram Shifts Account
description: The Seagram Beverage Company, has awarded the advertising account for its Seagram's Coolers to Wells, Rich, Greene. The advertising budget was not disclosed, although the company said it spent about $15 million to advertise the wine cooler in 1989. A new campaign is scheduled for later this spring. The account had been at Ogilvy & Mather, which will continue its work for the House of Seagram's spirits brands.

title: Chronicle
description: PIERRE BERGE came to New York yesterday wearing his opera hat. At a discussion series formally known as the Arts Forum at the Equitable, Mr. Berge, the president of the the Bastille Opera, which opened March 17 in Paris, talked about the new opera house.

title: Ending of Beckett Play Preserves the Meaning
description: To the Editor:

title: Hope, the Beloved Country
description: The euphoria of two months ago has subsided. Violence has brought troops into Natal Province. Talks between the Government and the A.N.C. were postponed.

title: Paging Concern's Stock Halt
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission on Wednesday suspended the trading of Southland Communication Inc. for 10 days, citing uncertainty about a possible undisclosed change in control at the small paging company, based in Santa Ana, Calif.

title: Upheaval in the East;   East German Parliament Opens; No Cabinet Picked
description: East Germany's first freely elected Parliament held its inaugural session today, but with the major parties still negotiating a coalition, no government was installed.

title: Coeur D'Alene Mines reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Court Bars Torchmark From a Proxy Fight
description: A Federal judge barred the Torchmark Corporation today from waging a proxy fight to gain a foothold on the board of the American General Corporation.

title: Review/Architecture;   A Ubiquitous Modernist Of Zelig-Like Elusiveness
description: Given the zest with which our age goes about searching out forgotten architects and reviving their reputations, it is a wonder that it took until now to rediscover Paul Nelson. Nelson, the subject of an intriguing exhibition that opens the new Arthur Ross Gallery at the Columbia University School of Architecture, was a most remarkable figure. American by birth, French by choice, he seems to have been at the center of everything that went on in the 1920's, 30's and 40's on both sides of the Atlantic, yet to have barely left a trace.

title: After 21 Seasons, Evans Fears Career Is Over
description: He has played 21 years in the major leagues and hit 414 home runs, more than any other player scheduled to open this season. But yesterday, Darrell Evans said he feared his season would not open and his career had come to an end now that he has been released by the Atlanta Braves.

title: Food Lion Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 24
Whalers Surprise Bruins, 4-3
description: The Hartford Whalers scored on four of their first eight shots tonight and upset the Boston Bruins, 4-3, in the opener of their Adams Division semifinal series.

title: Man Charged in Death of Suspected Burglar
description: A 19-year-old East Harlem man was arrested yesterday and charged with murdering an alleged intruder who was shot before falling to his death from a fifth-floor apartment window, the police said.

title: John J. Fisher 3d, 39, Writer and Editor, Dies
description: John Jacob Fisher 3d, a writer and editor in the child-development field, died of AIDS-related illnesses Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 39 years old.

title: Mott's Holdings Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $2,442,491, or 94 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,451,248, or 56 cents a share, for the year. c-After income of $477,094, or 18 cents a share. d-Net loss and after a loss of $525,161 from discontinued operations. Included as part of discontinued operations were pension credits of $2,443,950 in 1989 and $364,039 in 1988.

title: Poindexter Jury Ends 4th Day
description: The jury in the Iran-contra trial of John M. Poindexter today completed four days of deliberations on the five criminal charges against him. It will resume deliberations Friday. Mr. Poindexter, a retired Navy rear admiral who served as national security adviser in Ronald Reagan's Administration, is accused of five criminal charges in the affair, including conspiring to mislead Congress about the arms sales to Iran and efforts to aid the Nicaraguan rebels at a time the aid was forbidden by Congress.

title: Avcorp Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $7.7 million loss on the sale of two divisions and a $2.9 million loss from discontinued operations. c-Net loss Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: G.M.A.C. Prices A 10-Year Issue
description: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation a unit of the General Motors Corporation, priced a $300 million issue of 10-year notes through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation yesterday.

title: Campeau Chains Expect Recovery
description: Federated and Allied department stores projected no sales growth for the quarter beginning in May but said they were recovering under Federal Bankruptcy Court protection. ''We clearly are doing better in Chapter 11 than we expected,'' James M. Zimmerman, the president of Federated Department Stores Inc. and the Allied Stores Corporation, said at a meeting of the retailers' unsecured creditors on Wednesday.

title: Board of UAL Meets To Study Unions' Offer
description: The board of the UAL Corporation met late into the evening yesterday to consider a bid for United Airlines of about $200 a share, or a total of $4.36 billion, by the airline's three unions, which would end up owning 75 percent of the company.

title: Sooner Women's Program Reinstated After Protests
description: A week ago, the University of Oklahoma, citing a lack of interest, dropped women's basketball. Yesterday, after strong protests from players, legislators and others, the sport was reinstated.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-10

title: Washington Scientific Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 11
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $77,000, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and $226,000, or 9 cents a share, for the 6 months.

title: G.E. Shows Bright Side of East Europe
description: AMERICAN advertising's fickle relationship with Eastern Europe will take another turn toward sweetness - and most definitely light - this weekend with the release of a General Electric Company commercial that celebrates G.E.'s venture to produce light bulbs in Hungary.

title: Review/Theater;   Cariou in 'Mountain,' As Justice Douglas
description: William O. Douglas spent his life on the edge, as an outspoken maverick on the Supreme Court (more than one-third of his 1,306 judicial decisions were dissents) and as a mountaineer and adventurer. From childhood through old age he courted danger, and during his 36 1/2 years as an associate justice, he was often embroiled in controversy. He would seem to be a most likely candidate for dramatization.

title: Cuomo and Top Legislators Agree on Delaying Tax Cut
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and legislative leaders said today that they had agreed on a tentative plan to postpone an income tax cut scheduled for this year and then phase it in over the next three years.

title: Thumb Injury For Newman
description: Johnny Newman, the Knicks' backup small forward, has a fractured right thumb, but it is not expected to affect his availability for the game tonight against the Philadelphia 76ers at Madison Square Garden.

title: Hispanic Residents Rally Against Closing of Social Clubs
description: As New York City clamps down on illegal social clubs, the Hispanic community is rallying to pressure the Dinkins administration to avoid sweeping away clubs that the community says serve vital cultural, economic and educational needs.

title: Why Protect Inept Corporate Managers?
description: The greed that drives hostile corporate takeovers repels much of the nation. It also gives cover to state legislatures to serve their own interests -at the expense of the rest of the nation - by passing anti-takeover legislation. That is exactly what happened this week in the Pennsylvania. The House approved a bill, previously passed by the Senate, which would strip shareholders of their fundamental right to replace inept managers.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the death penalty as a campaign issue referred incorrectly to the position of John Van de Kamp, the California Attorney General, on abortion. Mr. Van de Kamp says he supports abortion rights. That position is unrelated to his position on the death penalty, which he says he opposes.

title: Condominium Conversions;   New Jersey Developer Offers a Lease-Purchase Plan
description: The soft New Jersey real estate market has led the sponsors of a condominium conversion to offer potential buyers a lease-purchase program, which state officials say might set a trend. Although many publicly financed projects offer similar programs, the Commons at Princeton Landing in Plainsboro Township is apparently the first privately financed condominium development in the state to offer such terms.

title: Airline Partnership
description: StatesWest Airlines and the USAir Group Inc. agreed to an operating partnership. The agreement provides USAir, a national carrier, with a stronger base in the West Coast market while lending StatesWest, a regional carrier, the resources it needs to survive, the companies said. StatesWest will become the first USAir Express operator in the West starting July 15.

title: Review/Jazz;   Gentle Surprises When a Duo Becomes a Trio
description: The guitar and bass duo of Frank Vignola and Frank Tate has been joined at the Fortune Garden, 209 East 49th Street, by Herman Foster, the happiest pianist since Erroll Garner, forming a trio whose members are still in the process of discovering one another.

title: Nsanje Journal;   Torrent of Refugees: Will Malawi Shut Its Door?
description: This small country, lush with green hills but struggling to feed its own malnourished people, is host to nearly 800,000 refugees, the largest concentration in Africa.

title: You Can't Die in Peace in a New York Hospital
description: To the Editor:

title: Our Towns;   A Family Bakery Finally Gets Its Pie in the Sky
description: rrKimberly Sunkins has the same problem every time at Mendoker's bakery. ''It's hard to think about everything so fast,'' she said. She was fluctuating between a banana cream pie and a chocolate seven-layer cake. She motioned toward the banana cream, the counter woman moved that way and Ms. Sunkins shouted, ''Wait!'' She needed time.

title: Vornado Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-Amounts previously reported for the 9 months ended Oct. 28, 1989, have been restated to reflect recognition of rental revenue on a straight-line basis; capitalization of interest expense during construction, and capitalization of asbestos removal and other environmental charges as betterments. The effect of this restatement was to increase net income by $1,267,000, or 55 cents a share.

title: China Seals Off Beijing Square
description: The authorities sealed off Tiananmen Square again today, the second time this week, to prevent people from holding quiet rallies to remember the pro-democracy protesters killed by army troops in June.

title: France Offers NATO Model for United Germany;   The Two Neisse Rivers
description: To the Editor:

title: Alatenn reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $2,856,000 and $3,663,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net income and after losses from discontinued operations of $307,000 for the quarter and $335,000 for the year. Latest quarter and year's losses from continuing operations included a charge of $6.4 million for provision for estimated unrecoverable take-or-pay expense.

title: Market Place;   First Chicago Action Questioned
description: Last Thursday's announcement by the First Chicago Corporation that a small number of its major real estate loans had gone bad further depressed the bank-holding company's stock. It closed today at $29 a share, down from $49 less than a year ago.

title: Wilshire Oil Co. of Texas Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Catholic Bishops Hire Firms To Market Fight on Abortion
description: The nation's Roman Catholic bishops announced yesterday that they had engaged a major public relations firm and a politically connected polling concern in Washington to conduct a nationwide campaign to persuade both Catholics and non-Catholics to oppose abortion.

title: Upheaval in the East;   U.S.-SOVIET SUMMIT IS PLANNED MAY 30 WITH BUSH AS HOST
description: President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union will hold a five-day meeting in the United States beginning on May 30, the White House and the Kremlin announced today.

title: Asiamerica Equities Ltd.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Reflected $566,567 income from discontinued operations.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY

title: Computer Consultant Named Wharton Dean
description: Thomas P. Gerrity, a consultant on information technology who once taught at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, has been named dean of the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, one of the nation's top business schools.

title: Study Finds Little Lasting Distress From Abortion
description: Legal, voluntary abortion in the first trimester of pregnancy does not threaten most women's mental health or cause them great emotional distress, a panel of experts has concluded after assessing leading studies.

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: The assets of the nation's 507 money market mutual funds decreased by $293.6 million, to $390.49 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 159 institutional funds rose by $50.5 million, to $91.47 billion. The assets of the 246 general-purpose funds were up by $226.0 million, to $133.23 billion. The 102 broker-dealer funds decreased by $570.1 million, to $165.79 billion, the institute said.

title: Review/Dance;   Pilar Rioja, Flamenco And Falla
description: Pilar Rioja is back in New York, at the Repertorio Espanol, and her new program, ''Falla and Flamenco,'' is one of her best. There is a somewhat harder edge to her performing, though the graciousness that attracts so many of her devoted fans is still very much present. That edge is welcome. And Miss Rioja has lost nothing of the sense of theater that so distinguishes her Spanish dancing.

title: Penwest Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
