description: All share earnings and shares outstanding adjusted for 3-for-2 stock split on March 21, 1990. The 1989 periods restated to reflect the sale of Great Western Malting Co. on March 13, 1989.

title: Our 'Open Doormat'
description: In the Shanghai Communique of 1972, the United States and China - whose leaders could never have agreed on a credible ''joint'' communique - used an ingenious method of making parallel but often contrary statements that broke new ground without seeming to give an inch on principle.

title: DINKINS FORECASTS WIDER BUDGET GAP AS REVENUES SLIP
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that New York City was facing an additional $105 million revenue shortfall for the fiscal year ending June 30. He also said he would seek $309 million in higher taxes to balance the city's budget in the coming fiscal year, on top of the $550 million it is already seeking.

title: Chronicle
description: At its 20th annual awards luncheon at the Waldorf Astoria yesterday, New York Women in Communications honored six women with its Matrix Award: LOUISE McNAMEE, the president of the advertising agency of Della Femina McNamee; LYNN SHERR, an ABC News correspondent for ''20/20''; TINA BROWN, the editor in chief of Vanity Fair; MARIAN BURROS, a food writer for The New York Times; MICHELLE H. JORDAN, a senior vice president of the public-relations firm of Hill & Knowlton, and PHYLLIS E. GRANN, the president of the Putnam BerkleY publishing group.

title: American Greetings Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included pretax restructuring charges of $2,688,000 in the quarter and $23,591,000 in the year.

title: Canadian Manoir reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $592,000, or 12 cents a share. c-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $94,000. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Ninjas, Ha! Come See Our Turtles
description: So which is it, art imitating life or life imitating art?

title: EDAC Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included writedowns of $797,777 related to the company's disposition of preferred stock and a $1.9 million note related to its Time Engineering subsidiary, as well as losses of $1,298,378 related to the disposition of the assets and businesses of its Florida operations.

title: Edward E. Carlson Is Dead at 78; Former Leader of United Airlines
description: Edward E. Carlson, former chief executive of UAL Inc., the hotel and airline holding company, died of cancer on Tuesday at Virginia Mason Hospital in Seattle. He was 78 years old and lived in Seattle.

title: Deals
description: Baseball

title: Equipment Co. of America reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Spearhead Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
WorldCorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income c-After income from discontinued operations of $3.2 million, or 28 cents a share. WorldCorp said latest quarter and year figures included extraordinary engine maintenance charges, writedowns in its high-yield investment portfolio and amortization of compensation charges.

title: Spira Enters a Not Guilty Plea to Extortion
description: Howard Spira pleaded not guilty at his arraignment here today on charges of threatening and trying to extort money from George Steinbrenner, the owner of the Yankees.

title: FNW Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AC&R's Aruba Work Stresses Distinctions
description: AC&R Advertising's first campaign for the Aruba Tourism Authority has much that is standard to island advertising: beautiful scenery, an attractive couple in bathing suits and a narrator who speaks with a Caribbean lilt. What sets the campaign apart is its attempt to set Aruba apart.

title: Gen. Frank Tharin, War Hero, Dies at 79
description: Frank Tharin, a retired Marine Corps lieutenant general who as a pilot was a hero of the battle of Wake Island in 1941, died on March 21 in San Rafael, where he had been hospitalized for eight months. He was 79 years old and lived in Laguna Beach.

title: Panel Says Sessions Tolerates F.B.I. Discrimination
description: Members of Congress today accused the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, William S. Sessions, of tolerating what one lawmaker described as a ''living hell'' experienced by the bureau's black and Hispanic employees.

title: Treasury Prices Dip in Slow Day
description: Prices of Treasury securities dipped in sluggish trading yesterday. Dealers sold securities after a rumor that swept the credit markets on Wednesday - that a major Japanese institution would disclose serious liquidity problems when trading began in Tokyo - proved to be unfounded.

title: Ciccarelli Scores in Overtime to Lift Capitals
description: Dino Ciccarelli's third goal of the game, 5 minutes 34 seconds into overtime, gave the Washington Capitals a 5-4 victory over the Devils tonight in the opening game of the Patrick Division semifinal series at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Canadian Natural Resources reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $2,167,716, or 19 cents a share. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Port Authority Drops Plan For Rise in Tolls and Fares
description: Facing opposition from Trenton, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has dropped plans for an immediate $1 increase in its bridge and tunnel tolls and a 25-cent fare hike on PATH trains later this year, the executive director of the bistate agency said yesterday.

title: The Court Rules for the Homeless
description: For more than a decade, New York's real estate markets, housing policies and welfare rules have conspired to manufacture homeless families, thereby inflicting immense social and financial costs. A ruling by New York's highest court now opens the way to reform.

title: Touring the World On Wings of Song (Folk Song, That Is)
description: POPULAR music serves more purposes than a fully loaded Swiss army knife. It sets dancers in motion, smooths conversation at parties, speeds the work day, exorcises frustrations, annoys parents; it brings groups together and consoles the lonely. In a city like New York, where the diaspora of the world collect, traditional music tied to a specific place and time can offer a glimpse of faraway lands or, for some audience members, a memory of home.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the reasons for tax rioting in London on Saturday omitted the definition of homeless people used by Shelter, a British organization for the homeless.

title: Review/Film;   Kevin Kline as an Amorous Pizza Maker
description: Kevin Kline received one Oscar for ''A Fish Called Wanda.'' If rewards always matched the services rendered, he deserves at least two for his tour de force in Lawrence Kasdan's new comedy ''I Love You to Death.''

title: At the Armory, a Weekend To Study 'Works on Paper'
description: Though it lacks the Rockettes, the Seventh Regiment Armory, at Park Avenue and 67th Street, has become the Radio City Music Hall of the art and antiques trade. A dozen elaborate productions a year devoted to vintage material - as many as can be handled by the armory, which is also used for military purposes - whirl in and out of its vast Victorian depths. Tomorrow, another extravaganza, ''Works on Paper,'' will open there, on the heels of last week's turn-of-the-century ''Beaux-Arts'' show.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Support for German Unity Found Growing in U.S.
description: While Americans seem uneasy about whether the change in Europe is permanent, support for the unification of East and West Germany has grown and two out of three Americans say they do not fear that a united Germany would threaten peace in Europe, according to the latest New York Times/ CBS News Poll.

title: When We Awake From Our Dream World
description: To the Editor:

title: USX Expects To Top Ichan
description: The chairman of the USX Corporation, Charles Corry, said today that he was confident that he would win a proxy fight with the financier Carl C. Icahn for control of the company's destiny.

title: Morton J. Goldman; Camp Founder, 78
description: Morton J. Goldman, the founder and for 42 years the head counselor of Camp Takajo, a summer camp for 400 boys on Long Lake outside Naples, Me., died on Tuesday of heart disease at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 78 years old.

title: Weekend Film Times
description: The 1990 Documentary Festival of New York continues at two places - the New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, and the May Theater, the New School for Social Research/ Parsons, 66 Fifth Avenue, at 13th Street. Tickets to each screening are $6 ($5 for students and the elderly). The festival runs through April 22. Information: 741-5357 or 598-7150. Here is a schedule of weekend screenings.

title: U.S. Gold Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest year included a writeoff of $7.7 million primarily associated with start-up delays at the Tonkin Springs Mill and writedowns on other mining properties, exploration costs and other investments totaling $5.3 million. There were also higher operating costs during 1989 at both the White Pine and Dee Mines compared with 1988. These writedowns were partially offset by $2 million in tax benefits associated with 1989 results.

title: An Asian Plan for East Europe
description: LEAD: It is widely accepted that free-market shock therapy is the best treatment for Eastern Europe's sick economies. Yet, as the success of the tightly controlled East Asian economies attests, companies in less-developed nations may need to be shielded from market forces while they struggle to make up lost ground.

title: Du Pont Note Sale
description: A $300 million note sale by the Du Pont Company was priced yesterday through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. The notes, which are due April 15, 2000, were given a 9.15 percent coupon and priced at 99.831 to yield 9.176 percent, or about 60 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. The notes, which are noncallable to maturity, are rated Aa-2 by Moody's Investors Service and Aa by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

title: Chartwell Raises Avon Stake to 16%
description: Chartwell Associates L.P. has raised its stake in Avon Products Inc. to 16 percent from 7.5 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Chartwell reported purchases of 3.4 million Avon shares between March 27 and Wednesday for prices ranging from $33.625 to $36 a share. The purchases include a block of 3.1 million Avon shares purchased on Wednesday for $36 a share.

title: Cycare Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Upheaval in the East;   Restive Yugoslavs Weigh Options
description: Halfway across Europe from the restive Baltic republics, another fragile union will be put to the test on Sunday when the republic of Slovenia casts the first multiparty vote held in Yugoslavia in 45 years.

title: Bethlehem Steel Penalized $1 Million on Benzene Fumes
description: The state has fined the Bethlehem Steel Corporation $1 million and ordered it to end benzene emissions from its coke ovens here by August, officials said today.

title: Field Narrows for Envoy to Managua
description: A career United States Foreign Service officer emerged today as the leading candidate to be Ambassador to Nicaragua, Administration officials said.

title: Dionne Textiles reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Review/Film;   A New-Age Comedy, Crystals And All
description: The beneficial power of crystals has done nothing for ''In the Spirit,'' a nervous new-age comedy much more notable for good intentions than good luck. A rare appearance by Elaine May, who co-stars with Marlo Thomas in what proves to be an unexpectedly mundane caper story, and a directing credit for the respected acting coach Sandra Seacat give ''In the Spirit'' a lot more curiosity value than it would otherwise have.

title: Rocking Horse Child Care Centers of America Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title:
LAW;

Leaps of Science Create Quandaries on Evidence
description: LEAD: Prosecutors and defense lawyers in criminal trials are increasingly marching into courtrooms with arsenals of bewildering technological data and jargon-speaking experts meant to bolster a case. And it is up to the judge, who may have no scientific training, to decide whether something like ''mass spectrometer analysis of hair samples'' should be admitted as evidence.

title: Upheaval in the East;   D'Amato on the Road
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato said today that he would try to drive across the border into Lithuania to show that Congress supports the Baltic republic's drive for independence.

title: Seaway Food Town Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 24
description: The share earnings for the 6 months were restated to reflect the 100 percent stock dividend paid Nov. 4, 1989.

title: INSIDE
description: Warning on Latex Paint

title: Teachers Union Chief Vows Fight on Layoffs
description: The president of the public school teachers union in New York City said yesterday that her members would ''fight to the death'' any attempt to lay off teachers as a means of reducing spending by the Board of Education.

title: Joe Fox; Track Coach, 79
description: Joe Fox, the track and field coach at Fordham Prep for 30 years before his retirement in 1976, died Wednesday at New Rochelle Hospital after a brief illness. He was 79 years old.

title: Yanks Try to Relieve Feelings in the Bullpen
description: The Dave Righetti-Greg Cadaret bullpen situation did not get much better today, but the Yankees tried to defuse things.

title: Tandem Shares In 17% Tumble
description: The stock of Tandem Computers Inc. tumbled after the company said early indications for the quarter ended March 31 are that its revenues and earnings will be above the previous quarter but below the company's operating plan. Tandem's shares dropped $4.625 today, to $22.625, on the New York Stock Exchange. The decline of 17 percent was the second worst on the Big Board, and the trading volume of almost 4.8 million shares was the highest of the day.

title: Car Import Sales in Japan
description: Sales of imported vehicles in Japan surged more than 60 percent in March from a year earlier, to a record of 25,943, the Japan Automobile Importers Association said today. West German manufacturers continued to lead in overall sales among importers, the association said. Volkswagen A.G. and its Audi subsidiary scored the biggest total, selling 7,264 cars in the month, up nearly 40 percent from a year earlier. The sales of American-made cars were up 41 percent, to 2,554, but this included almost 600 cars made by Japanese companies producing in the United States.

title: Rev. Virgil Blum, 76; Founded Rights Group
description: The Rev. Virgil C. Blum, a Jesuit priest and educator who was the founder and president of the Catholic League for Religious and Civil Rights, died at his home yesterday after a short illness. He was 76 years old and lived in the Jesuit residence at Marquette University in Milwaukee.

title: Stocks Edge Up as Japan Worries Persist
description: Stock prices barely managed to stay in the plus column yesterday after fighting off rumors of new financial troubles among Japanese stock market speculators.

title: Corel Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included tax credits of $97,000. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Jeffrey Nussbaum Is Wed To Dr. Joan Feigenbaum
description: D. Joan Feigenbaum, the daughter of Joyce and Harry Feigenbaum of Valley Stream, L.I., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Nussbaum, a son of Dorothy and Eli Nussbaum of New Hyde Park, L.I. Rabbi Lawrence Pinsker officiated at the home of the bridegroom's parents.

title: Triton Group Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $3,278,000. c-Net income and included income from discontinued operations of $25,387,000, or $2.34 a share, and an extraordinary credit of $34,226,000, or $3.15 a share, from tax loss carryforward.

title: Medchem Products Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included after-tax charge of $1,406,000 related to the preliminary injunction effected on Feb. 1, 1990 against further U.S. use, manufacture and sale of the company's Amvisc product line.

title: Detrex Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Losses resulted from a pretax charge of $3.1 million used to establish a reserve for anticipated expenditures in connection with various environmental matters for both the quarter and year. c-Net income

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Extra Events
description: The performances listed are free unless otherwise noted.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   Nationalism, Uncorked
description: Rapidly, nationalism has emerged as a potent force in Eastern Europe after Communism. In every place that elections have been held this year, from the Baltics to Budapest, parties sounding nationalist themes have prospered. Even Mikhail Gorbachev has enlisted two Russian nationalists to broaden his new Presidential Council.

title: Military Role Is Urged for New TV
description: An advisory panel to the Pentagon is preparing to recommend that the Defense Department vastly increase its efforts to help American industry develop high-definition television displays.

title: Alpnet reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Rangers Win as Opener Closes With Brawl
description: The game, rich in emotion and scintillating for so long, was with one crushing, controversial hit transformed into a frightening scene with Pat LaFontaine flat and unmoving on the ice. And then - with the sorry sense of inevitability that so often colors National Hockey League games -the events turned ugly and dangerous.

title: ENVIRONMENT BILL SENT TO THE HOUSE
description: After agreeing on the difficult issue of how to curb acid rain, the House Energy and Commerce Committee voted tonight to recommend sweeping legislation to strengthen the Clean Air Act. The vote was 42 to 1.

title: Producer Signs Disney Deal
description: Dawn Steel, the former president of Columbia Pictures, has signed a long-term agreement to produce films and television shows for the Walt Disney Company, Disney said yesterday.

title: Marcos Role in Big Investments Is Recounted
description: Imelda Marcos's lawyers have portrayed her as a woman who was unfamiliar with the business dealings of her husband and certainly had little grasp of high finance.

title: Call for Black Militia Stuns Milwaukee
description: A Milwaukee Alderman has stunned and divided this quiet, no-nonsense city with his efforts to revive the Black Panthers and build a black militia that he says will take violent action if his demands for racial parity are not met within five years.

title: Economic Scene;   Lessons for Japan In Stock Plunge
description: THE drop of almost 30 percent in the Tokyo stock market has provoked widespread fears among the Japanese that their economic miracle is ending.

title: Boston Educator Offers A Bold Campaign Style
description: John R. Silber is not a conventional candidate for the Democratic nomination for governor of Massachusetts.

title: Carolina First Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Audrey Resources reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $444,000, or 4 cents a share. c-Included an extraordinary credit of $152,000, or 2 cents a share. The company said 1989 net income was reduced by $2,768,461 and 1988 net income was reduced by $284,110 after it adopted retroactively the deferral method of mining tax allocation. The company also said 1989 revenues reflect 3 months of production at the Mobrun mine, compared with 5 months of production in 1988. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Service for Edward Ennis
description: A memorial for Edward J. Ennis, a former chairman of the American Civil Liberties Union, will be held at 5:15 P.M. tomorrow at the City Bar Association in New York, at 42 West 44th Street. Mr. Ennis, who headed the A.C.L.U. from 1969 to 1976, died on Jan. 7 at the age of 82.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Grazing at Holiday Inn

title: Suspect in Brooklyn Slaying Had an Order to Stay Away
description: A Brooklyn man, wanted by the police in the fatal stabbing of his estranged companion, had been arrested, charged with her rape and then released on his own recognizance two weeks ago with a court order to stay away from her, court officials said.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bidermann Industries, New York, a clothing manufacturer, appointed Peter C. Kells executive vice president and chief financial officer.

title: Bonn Works on Money Plan Amid Protests in East
description: As hundreds of thousands of East Germans marched in protest today against Bonn's proposed currency conversion, the West German Government took the first legal steps toward monetary union for the two nations but did not discuss the conversion rate, senior Government officials said.

title: Bernard Glemser, 81, An Author of 30 Books
description: Bernard Glemser, the author of 30 books of fiction and nonfiction, died of emphysema Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 81 years old.

title: CPI Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 3
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $2,246,000. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $399,000 and $1,602,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. Year-ago income from continuing operations of $31,919,000, or $1.91 a share, for the year included a non- recurring $1.8 million after-tax charge related to renegotiation of the Copymat agreement.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Avondale Industries, New Orleans, a marine fabricator, was awarded a $104.4 million contract from the Navy to build an oceanographic survey ship.

title: Lectures on the History Of Maritime New York
description: ''The Archeology and History of Maritime New York,'' the 10th annual symposium presented by the Professional Archeologists of New York City and the Museum of the City of New York, will take place tomorrow at 1 P.M. in the museum auditorium, Fifth Avenue at 107th Street.

title: Ban Is Sought on Mercury in Latex Paint
description: Alarmed at growing evidence of potential health dangers from mercury in latex paint, Federal health officials have urged Government regulators to consider banning it from the paints.

title: Gamelan Ensemble
description: Gamelan Son of Lion, a new music ensemble that performs on its own versions of Indonesian gamelan instruments, will give the first performance of ''Round Robin,'' a collaborative work by the ensemble's nine composer-performers, at Washington Square Church, 135 West Fourth Street, tomorrow at 3 P.M. The program also includes Denise Rightmire's ''Circles,'' David Demnitz's ''Graffiti Removal,'' Peter Griggs's ''Currents,'' and the premiere of Philip Corner's ''Through the Mysterious Barricade (After Couperin).'' Tickets are $8. Information: 874-4645.

title: Tranquilizers Form Part Of Addiction Complex
description: To the Editor:

title: Playoffs Are Ciccarelli's Prime Time
description: Nine years ago, Dino Ciccarelli set a National Hockey League record for a rookie with 14 playoff goals in leading the Minnesota North Stars to the 1981 Stanley Cup finals, where they lost to the Islanders in five games.

title: In SoHo, Giltless Fashion
description: Seventh Avenue moved to SoHo late Wednesday for fall shows by some of fashion's Young Turks, who rented big white lofts in keeping with their contemporary attitudes. Not for them the gilded splendor of the Plaza or the Pierre.

title: Two Masters Newcomers Carve Up Augusta National
description: Player debuts at the Masters tournament are usually memorable more for penalty strokes and three-putts than for superlative scores. But such notions were shattered in today's first round as first-time players dominated the scoreboard and favorites faltered.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Reprising 'Young Guns'

title: Pinnacle Unit Sells Resort to Japanese
description: The Pinnacle West Capital Corporation said its Suncor Development Company subsidiary had sold an Arizona resort to a Japanese company for $70 million. Suncor said that Kabuto International Phoenix Inc., a subsidiary of Kabuto Decom Inc. of Japan, had purchased the Wigwam Resort and Country Club in Litchfield Park, Ariz.

title: It's 'Themed,' It's Kitschy, It's Trump's Taj
description: Perhaps the toughest job at the Trump Taj Mahal casino here is that of the telephone operators, who have been answering the thousands of incoming calls, ''Thank you for calling the Trump Taj Majal, where wonders never cease.'' The repetition of that sentence, over and over, like a mantra, tells much about this casino hotel, a place where pleasure is not so much encouraged as decreed.

title: Commoner for a Day, Long Live the King!
description: A day or so after it began, Belgium's royal crisis ended this afternoon when a special session of Parliament declared by a vote of 245 to 0 with 93 abstentions that King Baudouin I was once again capable of reigning.

title: 2 G.O.P. Senators Would Double Military Cuts Backed by President
description: Breaking with the Bush Administration, two senior Republican Senators called today for Pentagon spending reductions that are twice as great as those offered by the President.

title: Chad Says Its Troops Killed 730 Guerrillas
description: Chad said today that its troops had killed 730 Libyan-backed guerrillas and captured 315 in fighting near the eastern border with the Sudan.

title: Under Fire, Nepal's King Ousts Cabinet
description: As demonstrators began a general strike, King Birendra dissolved his five-day-old Council of Ministers early today and appointed a new Prime Minister to negotiate with leaders of the pro-democracy movement that is challenging his Government.

title: Pagurian Corp. reports earnings for Year Dec 31
description: b-Included a $53,930,000 disposition and dilution gain. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: QVC-Damark Deal Canceled
description: QVC Network Inc., which sells merchandise through cable television home-shopping programs, said its planned sale of its C.O.M.B. mail-order business to Damark International Inc. had been terminated.

title: Consumer Credit Rise Slows a Bit
description: Americans took out $3.4 billion more in consumer credit than they repaid in February, but the pace slowed because of slackening demand for car loans, the Government said today.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: $200 Million in Notes Offered By Private Export Funding
description: The Private Export Funding Corporation, which is owned by a number of commercial banks involved in export financing, industrial companies exporting United States products and a few financial service companies, is offering $200 million in secured notes that are due 1996 through underwriters led by Citicorp Securities Markets Inc.

title: Raphael Marchand; Accountant, 95
description: Raphael Marchand, an accountant and a retired bank officer, died of cardiovascular disease on Tuesday at Mount Vernon (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 95 years old and lived in Mount Vernon.

title: Review/Film;   An Officer Becomes The Other
description: From the opening sequence, ''Impulse'' is so generic you can practically sing along. This is the one about a sexy-looking but emotionally repressed detective who works undercover disguised as a prostitute. She walks those just-rained-on streets that seem to exist every night in grade-B movies.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MARGARET THATCHER has just become the least-popular British Prime Minister in 50 years. A Gallup poll that appeared yesterday in The Daily Telegraph said that only 24 percent of the people interviewed were satisfied with her performance.

title: Islanders Never Did This Stuff
description: Back when the Islanders were the Islanders, they didn't have any Vukotas or Baumgartners lurching onto the ice to start fights after the game.

title: Larry Lee, 48, Dies; Television Producer, Wrote Biographies
description: Larry Lee, an award-winning television and radio producer and co-author of biographies of the writers Jack Kerouac and William Saroyan, died of AIDS on Thursday at Children's Hospital in San Francisco. He was 48 years old.

title: Stereotypes of Women Cloud Drug Discussion
description: To the Editor:

title: In France, Day Care Is Every Child's Right
description: Ten years after the U.S. started talking about ''family values,'' many wonder why we are still unable to provide decent education, health care and opportunity for all of our children.

title: Bitterness Lingers Over Treatment of LaFontaine
description: After spending a night in Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan with what team officials called a moderate concussion, Pat LaFontaine of the Islanders returned home to Long Island today. But his participation in Saturday night's second playoff game against the Rangers was in doubt.

title: Tele-Optics reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Resulted from a delay in Boresight shipments, a January 1990 cancellation of a $5 million contract for television sensor guidance systems and a writedown for obsolete inventory related to discontinued products. c-Net income

title: Mortgage Rates Are Up
description: Fixed-rate home mortgages are averaging 10.26 percent, up from 10.22 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.56 percent this week, unchanged from the previous week.

title: Sports People: PRO BASKETBALL;   Tarpley Suspended
description: The Dallas forward Roy Tarpley was suspended indefinitely without pay for missing practice and a daily counseling session yesterday morning.

title: Review/Film;   Ernest Again, Invulnerable To Life's Inanimate Objects
description: Any adult who fidgeted through the inane ''Ernest Goes to Camp'' and ''Ernest Saves Christmas'' had reason to fear the news that those children's films made truckloads of money. It was almost too painful to think about a sequel, much less wonder why Ernest had become a movie star. This is the irritating, rubbery-mouthed character who became famous pitching appliances, mattresses and soft drinks on television commercials by yelling ''Hey, Vern!'' at his neighbor. But ''Ernest Goes to Jail'' so resembles a high-spirited cartoon that it is likely to be more amusing to children and less painfully obnoxious for parents than its predecessors.

title: The Invisible Man in 'A Chorus Line'
description: ''Different'' is nice, but it sure isn't ''pretty.'' ''Pretty'' is what it's about. I never met anyone who was ''dif ferent'' Who couldn't figure that out. The man who wrote those crisp, telling lines for ''A Chorus Line'' is the Theatrical Invisible Man. A private, publicity-shy person, he would cross a room to get away from a reporter or photographer. In these times of the Trumps and George Steinbrenner, The Publicity Is The Message. Who would be so idiosyncratic as to avoid publicity?

title: Family Looked Typical, But the Drug Lab Didn't
description: Max and Liza Marx unlocked the door of their house in the hills of Westchester County last fall after two years overseas and stared in dismay. Paint spattered the floors, new electrical outlets studded the walls, and the tap water smelled. The furnace had been disconnected. Black gook oozed across the yard.

title: Dr. Norman T. Crane, Pediatrician, Dies at 88
description: Dr. Norman T. Crane, a New Jersey pediatrician for more than four decades, died of a blood clot on the brain on Thursday at a nursing home in Green Brook, N.J. He was 88 years old and lived in Plainfield, N.J.

title: Your Money;   Extra Time to File 1989 Tax Returns
description: For the millions of taxpayers who have waited until the last minute to wrestle the beast to the ground, a visit to the public library is in order. It's the place most likely to have income tax forms, and Form 4868 for an automatic four-month filing extension, along with the equivalent state form, is not in the packets mailed out by the I.R.S.

title: Poindexter Jury Is Still Out
description: The jurors in the Iran-contra trial of John M. Poindexter completed their fifth day of deliberations today without reaching a verdict, and Judge Harold H. Greene ordered them to continue their deliberations on Saturday. The eight women and four men on the jury will remain sequestered, as they have been since Tuesday after two jurors reported calls from news organizations.

title: First Interstate
description: First Interstate Bancorp said its California subsidiary, First Interstate Bank, would begin offering annuities for sale by branch managers and banking officers. The move comes in the wake of Proposition 103, a voter initiative approved in 1988 that allowed California banks to sell insurance products. California banks have offered insurance before but only through outside vendors or separate subsidiaries. First Interstate said it had entered into an agreement with the Essex Corporation of New York to train bank employees to sell the annuities, primarily to customers over 50 years of age interested in retirement income.

title: Paloma Petroleum reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: CHRONICLE
description: YVES MONTAND, 69, whose companion bore his child last year, says that now many women are haunting him. Mr. Montand has been ordered by a French magistrate to submit to a blood test to determine whether he is the father of a 14-year-old girl.

title: Sports People: BASEBALL;   Postema Files Suit
description: Pam Postema's bid to become the first woman umpire in the major leagues ended last winter when she was let go as a minor league umpire. On Thursday in Los Angeles, she filed a Federal sexual discrimination in employment claim against the American and National Leagues with the United States Equal Employment and Opportunity Commission.

title: Patents;   A Detergent to Prevent Wrinkles in Clothes?
description: Laundry detergents already include bleaches and fabric softeners. Now Procter & Gamble has patented an experimental silicon-based additive that would prevent wrinkles in clothes. Officials said the compound was still being investigated.

title: 4 Slain Execution-Style in Manhattan
description: Three men and a 2-year-old boy were slain execution-style in an apartment living room in lower Manhattan late Thursday in what investigators believe was a drug-related robbery, police officials said.

title: Devils Receive Scare, But Take It in Stride
description: The Devils have made such a commitment to the Stanley Cup playoffs that not even a bomb threat prevented them from completing a day's work this afternoon.

title: Knicks End Sixers' Streak and Clinch
description: The Knicks clinched a playoff berth last night, which had been expected. More important, after a disastrous month of March, in which they went 4-12, the Knicks have discovered new life and may be a team to be reckoned with in the post-season.

title: BARRY WELCOMED BY BLACK MAYORS
description: Mayor Marion S. Barry of Washington briefly stole the show from the Rev. Jesse Jackson today when he walked into an anti-drug meeting and was given a standing ovation while Mr. Jackson was speaking.

title: New Style In Transit: Stooping To Conquer
description: On a recent tour of subway and bus centers in Brooklyn, Alan F. Kiepper, the new president of the Transit Authority, did something so unusual that it generated stares from some passengers waiting for the A train - he picked up litter and a penny on a subway platform.

title: T/SF Communications reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said 1989 earnings dropped due to an increased interest expense of $1,650,000 and increased depreciation and amortization of $1,550,000. The net loss, the net income figures and the shares outstanding were reflected when the company said it declared its per share earnings and shares outstanding on a pro forma basis because of the public stock offering in middle of 1989, the formation of the company as a carve-out from its parent company and the acquisitions that occurred during mid-1988.

title: Topics of the Times;   A Sufficient Warning
description: The recording industry has agreed to put a uniform warning label on potentially offensive records.

title: Mining Rights In Venezuela
description: Venezuela began to open mining to private investment today, and it expects to attract $140 million from foreign and domestic sources.

title: Jury Supports Genentech In Patent Infringement Case
description: In an important victory for Genentech Inc., a jury in United States District Court in Delaware ruled today that the company's patents for tissue plasminogen activator, or T.P.A., its main product, were valid.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Divisions Bedevil Hungary Parties
description: As the Hungarian elections enter their final round on Sunday, the two main political parties, once allied in opposition to the former Communist Party, find themselves far apart, separated by clashes in style and personality that have long echoes in Hungarian history.

title: Stake in Gallimard Is Sold; Fear of Takeover Revived
description: The continuing power struggle within France's largest independent publisher took an unexpected turn today when a member of the family that controls the publisher, Editions Gallimard, announced that she was selling her shares to the Banque Nationale de Paris.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping;   With Outdoor Music
description: Now that spring is here, it's time to take music outdoors. The ways are many: pocket portables with headphones, ''boom-box'' portables with speakers, temporary hookups to indoor stereos and permanent outdoor installations.

title: 3 Elderly People Die And 21 Are Injured In Miami Beach Fire
description: At least 3 people were killed and 21 injured early today as a fire destroyed a residential hotel filled largely with elderly retired people.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost;   Banks and the Elderly
description: Many banks are trying to lure older Americans' deposits by offering a variety of benefits that are not available to the other customers. Such depositors are viewed as a source of stable funds and a ready market for estate planning services. Some banks require fairly large balances for these accounts; others set no minimum, but depositors have to pay monthly fees. And some banks may require depositors to sign up for direct deposit of Social Security, payroll or pension checks. There is no national listing of banks that offer these special accounts; the American Association of Retired Perosns generally recommends using banks that are close to home and suggests phoning them for information. Here are some of the requirements, charges and services to consider in deciding on one of these accounts:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about a meeting between Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, misstated the date of the Helsinki Final Act on European security and human rights in some copies. It was signed in 1975.

title: Hugoton Sale Halted by Mesa
description: Mesa Limited Partnership, the energy company headed by T. Boone Pickens, pulled its Hugoton Royalty Trust holdings off the market, saying prices were too low to sell the prime properties in the nation's largest natural gas field. Mesa said in December that it would package its Hugoton holdings into a separate trust and sell shares. The proceeds were to pay down some of the partnership's $1.5 billion in long-term debt, much of it left over from the $715 million purchase of natural gas properties from Tenneco Inc. in 1988.

title: Debt Seen as Negating Gains in United Deal
description: United Airlines has been looking for a way to recapture the No. 1 position in the domestic airline industry from American Airlines. But industry experts think the tentative agreement reached yesterday for an employee buyout will not by itself be the answer.

title: If It's Legal, City May Try Complex Bond Refinancing
description: New York City hopes to help plug an unexpected gap in its current budget with a highly technical financial maneuver intended to free up excess money that has accumulated since early in this century to pay off rapid transit bonds.

title: News Summary
description: International 3-7

title: Ex-Bank Officer Says He Got Marcos Interest
description: A former Philippine bank official who had testified on Thursday that Imelda Marcos's personal secretary had withdrawn as much as $14.5 million in cash from the New York branch of the Philippine National Bank, said today that he was given the interest on two bank accounts held by the secretary as perquisites.

title: Allied Research Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
3 Senators Offer Campaign Financing Bill
description: Three Democratic Senators have introduced a bill that would extend public financing of Presidential campaigns to Congressional races.

title: Presidential Realty reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss of $2,235,000 from writedown of loans and after an extraordinary net gain from sales of properties and investments of $146,000, or 4 cents a share. c-After an extraordinary net gain of $1,507,000, or 46 cents a share, from sales of properties and investments.

title: AFGHAN CEREMONY ENDS IN BLOODSHED
description: Afghan rebels turned a reconciliation ceremony into a deadly ambush today, killing at least 10 people, including 2 generals, and wounding many other Government officials, witnesses said.

title: Jurors' Vanity Press Review: Publisher Defrauded Authors
description: Never mind that their books had titles like ''The Sex Life of a Football Referee,'' ''Letters I Wish I'd Mailed to the Man Who Divorced Me to Marry a Waitress'' and ''Sunday and Monday Were Cold Chicken Days,'' one man's memories of his mother. All they were asking for, the authors of Vantage Press said, was a chance to be treated as any writer should be - granted, for a fee.

title: Wisconsin Southern Gas reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a credit of $307,064 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. The year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding were adjusted to reflect 5 percent stock dividend paid in July 1989.

title: At Foundations, the Voice of Women and Minorities Remains Faint
description: Although securing a bigger role for women and minorities has been a professed goal in the philanthropy field, most boards of American foundations continue to be dominated by white males.

title: Harold L. Stults, Lawyer, 84
description: Harold Leland Stults, a retired partner in the law firm of Curtis, Morris & Safford in New York, died of cancer last Saturday at his home in Short Hills, N.J. He was 84 years old.

title: Valdez Sister Ship Grounded
description: A sister ship to the tanker Exxon Valdez, carrying more than 1.2 million barrels of crude oil, ran aground in Long Beach Harbor on Thursday, but no oil was spilled. The 950-foot Exxon Long Beach was refloated and taken to a harbor anchorage, where a diver found no damage to her hull, the Coast Guard said. The Exxon Valdez spilled nearly 11 million gallons of crude oil after running aground in Alaska's Prince William Sound in March 1989.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Anne R. Squiccimarro, Science Professor, 55
description: Anne Rice Squiccimarro, a professor and an administrator of Mercy College in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., died of breast cancer on Thursday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. She was 55 years old and lived in Hastings-on-Hudson.

title: Oilers Defeat Jets in Overtime to Tie Series at 1-1
description: Mark Lamb's goal 4 minutes 21 seconds into overtime gave the Edmonton Oilers a come-from-behind 3-2 victory over the Winnipeg Jets tonight, tying their Smythe Division semifinal series at one victory each.

title: Mixed Signals
description: While the unemployment rate dipped in March, the number of private-sector jobs fell for the first time in four years. Page 9.

title: National Income Realty Trust reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said it had a $1 million provision for losses in 1989, compared with a provision of $31.5 million in 1988.

title: Beene, as Usual, Forges Fashion's Path
description: What makes Geoffrey Beene great? Is it the sophistication of his cut that makes the most bulky fabric seem airborne? The curved lines that give a graceful femininity to clothes without dipping into banality?

title: U.S. Indicts Iraqi In Plot to Kill 2
description: A former driver for the Iraqi Mission to the United Nations in New York has been indicted on charges of plotting with an Iraqi agent to kill two opponents of the Iraqi Government who were in the United States, Federal prosecutors announced today.

title: A Roundup for the Great Society
description: They gathered tonight for what Lady Bird Johnson called ''a Texas-size roundup of the Great Society.''

title: Museum Visitor Damages a Rembrandt
description: An unemployed man sprayed ''The Night Watch,'' the 17th-century Rembrandt masterpiece, with an unidentified chemical today, but an official at the Rijksmuseum said the damage did not ''seem to be too bad.''

title: Digital Communications reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included gains on disposal of assets of $505,000 in the quarter and $4,372,000 in the 9 months. c-Included an unusual charge of $12,579,000.

title: Conceived to Save Her Sister, a Child Is Born
description: A baby girl was born Tuesday to a couple who conceived the child to serve as a bone marrow donor for their cancer-stricken daughter.

title: Army in Nepal Opens Fire, Killing Demonstrators
description: The Nepalese Army and police opened fire Friday on a procession of 200,000 pro-democracy demonstrators. Hospital officials said that at least nine people were killed and several hundred wounded as crowds tried to surge past police cordons toward the royal palace. Witnesses and other reports said the death toll was much higher.

title: Judge Releases Man in Killing Of an Intruder
description: An East Harlem man charged with killing a man who the police said was threatening a pregnant woman with a knife was released without bail yesterday as the woman wept with joy and called him ''my good Samaritan.''

title: Preferred Homecare reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included one-time charge of $145,833 related to preferred stock dividends and accretion. c-Net income

title: Trade Pact Under Fire In Japan
description: Some members of Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu's Liberal Democratic Party said today that the party would have to brace for enormous political losses if it pushed through legislation to carry out the revisions in trade barriers sought by Washington and accepted by Tokyo on Thursday.

title: Marble Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-After an extraordinary tax loss carryforward of $543,000, or 17 cents a share.

title: INSIDE
description: Islanders Draw Fines And Suspensions for Melee

title: Patents;   Using Superconductors For Circuits on Chips
description: Two professors at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology have patented an approach for making switches with high-temperature superconductors, which could prove useful in making ultra-miniaturized circuits.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Two Olympic gold medalists, FLORENCE GRIFFITH JOYNER and her husband, AL JOYNER, are expecting their first child in November. Ms. Griffith Joyner, a sprinter, won three in 1988 and Mr. Joyner won the triple jump in 1984. (AP)

title: Horn & Hardart Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-Included one-time expenses of $839,000 related to restructuring activities and an income tax charge of $300,000. c-Net income and included $1,510,000 gain on sale of securities and income tax benefit of $410,000. d-Included $17 million restructuring charge.

title: Metall Mining reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $1,385,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and $2,501,000, or 7 cents a share, for the year. c-After extraordinary credits of $4,060,000, or 11 cents a share, and $10,664,000, or 19 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. Results for all of 1988 included a 15- month contribution from Teck Corp., due to a change in Teck's fiscal year- end. Earnings for both years have been restated to reflect the court judgment last August, awarding the Page-Williams gold mine at Hemlo, Ont., to Corona Corp. and Teck Corp. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: 4 in Texas Accused of Using Bus Crash to Get Law Clients
description: Three lawyers and an employee of a law firm were indicted today on charges that they illegally sought clients at hospitals and funeral homes after a school bus wreck killed 21 high school students and injured 60 last fall.

title: Granada Foods Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $2,154,000, or 97 cents a share, for cumulative effect of accounting change.

title: Asset Investors Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an accrual of $1,300,000, or 9 cents a share, for the anticipated settlement of the stockholder class action lawsuits against the company for both the quarter and year.

title: Reliable Life Insurance reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Science Management reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $28,000 for the quarter and $311,000 for the year, and an extraordinary charge of $17,000 for the quarter from a reversal of tax loss carryforward and an extraordinary tax loss carryforward of $41,000, or 1 cent a share, for the year. c-Net income and included losses from discontinued operations of $150,000 for the quarter and $222,000 for the year; the year also was after an extraordinary tax loss carryforward of $94,000, or 3 cents a share. The company said that the loss in 1989 resulted primarily from decisions made at year-end to write off certain goodwill, establish a reserve for expected future losses on a lease, and provide for deferred rent on another lease, together with operating losses in several businesses in the fourth quarter.

title: Lawsuit Mixes Cash, Concrete, Koch and, Yes, McGovern
description: A businessman who was trying to win an exclusive New York City contract to produce concrete asserts that he gave $10,000 in cash to former Senator George S. McGovern in 1985 to be passed on to city officials as a campaign contribution to Mayor Edward I. Koch.

title: Roderic Swenson, 71, Retired Bank Executive
description: Roderic Burwell Swenson, a former vice president of Citibank in Manhattan, died of kidney disease on Thursday at Danbury (Conn.) Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived in Ridgefield, Conn.

title: Creaky I.R.S. Is at a Crossroads
description: The Internal Revenue Service is enjoying what it calls a ''highly successful'' filing season, with taxpayers filing earlier and their returns containing fewer mistakes than in the past.

title: New Estimate on Savings Bailout Says Cost Could Be $500 Billion
description: The cost of the Government's savings and loan bailout could grow to as much as $500 billion, roughly twice as high as previous official estimates, the head of the General Accounting Office said today.

title: Pan Atlantic reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Hitachi-Motorola
description: Hitachi Ltd. said today that it was eager to reach an out-of-court settlement in its patent infringement suit with Motorola Inc., but the United States company appears to be unwilling to settle. A Hitachi spokesman said, ''Settling out of court would be best for our customers, but we can't seem to get Motorola to the table,'' adding that the judge had asked the companies to settle amicably. Last week a United States district court in Texas ruled that both companies had infringed the other's patents and ordered each to stop United States sales of the microprocessors in question. Subsequently he granted a stay of the injunction while Motorola appealed.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the annual meeting of the American Society of Newspaper Editors misidentified the editor of the Journal-News in West Nyack, N.Y. He is Paul Janensch.

title: Vitran Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The company said gains from the sale of property in the latest quarter equaled 5 cents a share. There were no similar gains in year-ago period. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: U.S. Issues Steady After Early Moves
description: Prices of Treasury securities made a series of sharp moves early yesterday on a mixture of conflicting economic news and rumors, but ended the day basically unchanged.

title: NEPAL: At a Glance
description: Government

title: Cuomo Aides Say Budget Gap May Hit $1.8 Billion
description: Making a bad situation worse for weary negotiators, the $1.5 billion gap in the state's 1990-91 budget may grow to $300 million because of a continuing slump in tax revenues, state officials said today.

title: Move by Savings Agency
description: The Government agency charged with selling failed savings and loan associations has adopted a policy requiring its employees to maintain a log of all telephone inquiries made by or on behalf of public officials. The Resolution Trust Corporation action was announced on Wednesday in response to policy directives in the savings and loan bailout legislation enacted by Congress last August. The action also calls for establishing a special committee to conduct formal reviews when Resolution Trust employees believe they have received inappropriate requests from public officials.

title: Nancy Lady Keith Is Dead at 73; A Socialite Known for Her Wit
description: Nancy Lady Keith, a legendary beauty and participant in the social scene of New York and Hollywood, died of heart failure yesterday at New York Hospital. She was 73 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Eastern Deal Advances
description: The Transportation Department today tentatively approved the sale of several of Eastern Airlines' international routes to American Airlines. The route sale is expected to bring Eastern about $350 million as it tries to consolidate its operations under bankruptcy protection. Pan American World Airways and Eastern's unions are expected to express opposition. Opposing comments are due by next Friday, and rebuttals will be accepted until April 16. The routes include flights to Central and South America and flights from Miami to Madrid. American would also buy the Miami-London route of Continental Airlines, which like Eastern is owned by the Texas Air Corporation.

title: BNH Bancshares Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary tax credits of $206,930 for the latest year and $55,900 for the year-earlier period.

title: Upheaval in the East;   D'AMATO STOPPED AT POLISH BORDER
description: Soviet border guards refused today to allow Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato to enter Lithuania, which has been locked in a war of wills with the Kremlin since declaring independence on March 11.

title: Mattingly Talks Delayed for a Day
description: On the last day of their lockout-shortened Florida camp, the Yankees lost one more exhibition game today before winging their way home for a weekend series with the Mets that opens at Shea Stadium on Saturday. But they did not leave without making a bit more news.

title: Viratek Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The year-ago quarter reflected $2 million one-time gain related to reduction in anticipated costs associated with completion of certain studies.

title: 2 Professors Awarded Bancroft History Prizes
description: Columbia University awarded its 1990 Bancroft Prizes in American history on Wednesday night to the authors Dr. Neil R. McMillen of the University of Southern Mississippi and Dr. James H. Merrell of Vassar College.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Excerpts From News Conferences in Washington
description: Following are excerpts from the news conferences today by Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, as provided by the Federal News Service, a transcription company:

title: A Jump on Garden Bugs
description: Even though they are not easily seen, they are there: eggs of psylla, mites, scales and aphids, clinging to twigs and tucked into the crevices of the bark of trees and bushes. Now is the time to get rid of them, and the easiest and safest way is to spray them with dormant oil, available at garden and hardware stores.

title: Measurement Specialties reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: New Odors From the H.U.D. Swamp
description: Maybe there's something in the water at the Department of Housing and Urban Development. Or maybe it's in the air. Whatever and wherever it is, it seems to make the agency peculiarly susceptible to cronyism and conflicts of interest in contract awards. And it doesn't seem to matter who is in charge.

title: MOSCOW REPORTED TO YEILD ON NEUTRALITY OF GERMANY; NO BREAKTHROUGH ON ARMS
description: The United States and the Soviet Union have significantly narrowed their differences over the place of a united Germany in Europe but have apparently failed to make much progress on major arms control issues, the two sides indicated today.

title: 42 Warrants For Owner Of Fire Site
description: The owner of the building that housed the Happy Land Social Club was wanted by the police on 42 separate arrest warrants charging with him with serious building violations at a dozen Manhattan locations, including the sites of three social clubs, city officials said yesterday.

title: William Boone Nauts, Banker, 87
description: William Boone Nauts, a retired banker, died of pneumonia on Thursday at the Wolcott Hall Nursing Home in Torrington, Conn. He was 87 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Patents;   Using an Ion Beam To Paint Car Pinstripes
description: M.I.T. researchers also recently patented a method of painting customized pinstripes on automobiles by bombarding metallic paint with ion beams.

title: A Nervous Cincinnati Awaits Exhibit Today
description: This city is bracing nervously for the opening on Saturday of a museum exhibit of photographs that have been branded obscene by the local law-enforcement authorities.

title: U.S. Is in Middle of 33 Nations in Death Rates
description: The United States ranks in the middle of 33 developed nations in terms of life expectancy and death rates, according to new figures from the Federal Centers for Disease Control.

title: Barringer Labs reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $325,000 and $234,000 for the latest year and year-earlier periods, respectively. The company said comparable year-ago share earnings results are not available as Barringer, which went public on Dec. 28, 1989, was previously a part of Barringer Resources Inc.

title: Practical Security For Europe
description: East and West are flailing around for a European security system that can transcend the cold war balance of terror without falling back into the dangerous prewar national balance of power.

title: Puerto Rico Is Seen Facing Economic Troubles as State
description: Puerto Rican statehood could undermine the island's economy and cost as many as 100,000 of its 900,000 jobs by the end of the decade, a new study by the Congressional Budget Office has found.

title: Sports People: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;   Coach Quits Oklahoma
description: Valerie Goodwin-Colbert, the Oklahoma women's basketball coach, resigned yesterday, a day after university officials, pressured by fans and legislators, announced that they would reinstate the program, which was dropped last week.(AP)

title: Waterhouse Investor Servces Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Reflected non-recurring loss of $364,162 from the writeoff of its investment in a commercial bank.

title: U.S. Jobless Rate Edges Down to 5.2%
description: The unemployment rate edged down one-tenth of a point to 5.2 percent in March, but the number of payroll jobs in the private sector declined for the first time in four years, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Topics of the Times;   Mr. Nixon Tapes Again
description: Former President Nixon has made another tape. Driven from office by the Watergate secrets revealed by his Oval Office tape recorder, he has returned to the medium to record his new book, ''In the Arena.'' The book, Mr. Nixon's eighth, is a memoir of the painful aftermath of his resignation and political humiliation. The book and the three-hour taped abridgment are being released this month.

title: Patents;   Switches Improved In Optical Computers
description: Researchers at Bell Laboratories obtained a patent this week on a key feature in the light-activated switches used in the company's recently introduced optical computer.

title: Transit Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $84,000 for the quarter and $346,000, or 14 cents a share, for the year. c-Net income Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Lawrence Stayer, 49, Met Auditions Director
description: Lawrence F. Stayer, the executive director of the Metropolitan Opera National Council Auditions, died yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 49 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Anxiety Rises in Eastern Europe Over Safety of Nuclear Reactors
description: The spread of democracy in Eastern Europe has combined with memories of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster to produce a surge of popular anxiety about the safety of the region's mainly Soviet-designed reactors.

title: Facts About Jaguars
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush to Formalize Shield for Chinese in U.S.
description: President Bush said today that he would issue an executive proclamation to formalize and broaden the measures he ordered late last year to help Chinese students extend their stays in the United States.

title: Social Club Landlord Named in Other Cases
description: Alex DiLorenzo 3d, the owner of the building that housed the Bronx social club where 87 people died in a fire last month, surrendered in Criminal Court in Manhattan yesterday on 42 separate arrest warrants.

title: Covenant House Needs Its Board to Stay On
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A short Company News article in Business Day yesterday misstated a request by a group of Lionel Corporation shareholders. The shareholders, led by Trendex Capital Management, are asking the board to examine the propriety of the sale of a block of Lionel stock in January to a separate investor group with ties to Lionel's management.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Western Historians Join Russians to Dissect Past
description: With the official history of the last 70 years now discredited as a pack of Stalinist lies, the Soviet academic establishment this week took the unusual step of inviting about 50 leading Western Kremlinologists and historians to come and help them wrestle with the truth.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It looks as if we have spent the peace dividend.'' - Senator Larry Pressler, on the cost of the savings-and-loan bailout. [1:2.]

title: Circuit City Stores Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Shaver Victory By Windmere
description: A Federal jury today awarded about $100 million to the Windmere Corporation in an antitrust suit that accused NV Philips of monopolizing the rotary shaver market.

title: In Indonesia, 25 Years of Injustice
description: LEAD: Six forgotten elderly men, in a Jakarta prison for more than 20 years, will be executed shortly unless the Indonesian Government can be persuaded it is making a mistake.

title: Techdyne Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included pre-tax expenses of $717,581 incurred in plant closings.

title: Buffett Acquires 5.8% Rorer Stake
description: Warren E. Buffett, the billionaire investor, disclosed he had amassed a 5.8 percent stake in Rorer Group Inc., a pharmaceutical concern based in Fort Washington, Pa., for a total purchase price of $143 million. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Buffett said he had purchased the Rorer shares as an investment.

title: KEY RATES
Jay Johnson, 39, Dies; Specialist in Folk Art
description: Jay Johnson, a Manhattan gallery owner and scholar of American folk art, died of AIDS on Thursday at his home in Piermont, N.Y. He was 39 years old.

title: Come Back and Let's Try to Work It Out
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: BJORN BORG, the five-time Wimbledon champion, has been ordered to pay up to $2 million to Swedish creditors of his failed retailing business. A Stockholm court said yesterday that half the estimated total of $1.65 million to $2 million must be paid by June 1.

title: L.I. Youth Stabbed to Death
description: A 15-year-old boy was killed and his 12-year-old sister seriously wounded after being stabbed numerous times Friday night in their home in the upper-middle-class community of Herricks, L.I., the Nassau County police said.

title: Sports People: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;   Valvano's $1 Offer
description: Jim Valvano volunteered yesterday to remain at North Carolina State and coach the men's basketball team for $1 next year, but the university refused the offer, one of Valvano's attorneys said.

title: Major Realty reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Reflected real estate sale which contributed sales revenue of $24.7 million and gross profit on sale of real estate of $2,826,000. The loss also reflected March 1989 gain of $5,830,000 pursuant to settlement of certain condemnation quick-taking proceedings relating to a land parcel in Tampa, Fla., held by the Major Pru Development joint venture. c-Net loss

title: Outline of a New Europe
description: The talks between the Soviet Union and the United States this week appear to have opened the door at least part of the way for what Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d calls a ''new architecture'' for Europe.

title: Louis Nelson, 87, A Jazz Trombonist Of Preservation Hall
description: Louis Nelson, a jazz trombonist who was the last surviving musician from the original Preservation Hall bands, died Thursday from injuries suffered in a car accident 10 days earlier. He was 87 years old.

title: More Drug Charges in the Texas Campaign
description: Two Texas newspapers today reported accusations that State Attorney General Jim Mattox, who is running for governor, smoked marijuana on at least two occasions in the 1970's.

title: About New York;   Odd Man Out: Helping Big Boys Feel Like Fathers
description: ''I don't want her to call anybody else daddy, even if I despise the mother,'' Robert C. said. ''She's my kid.'' The teen-age father knows he will never have a future with his former girlfriend, but he wants to be a positive part of his daughter's life. He plans always to have a couch where the child, or even her mother, might sleep if things get rough.

title: Teller's Charges Discredited Oppenheimer
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Film;   Dead Killer Who Keeps Cropping Up
description: Somebody down there likes muscular, strong-jawed Patrick Channing (Jeff Kober), who is so good-looking that he could be an actor but has become a serial killer instead. After he dies in the gas chamber, Patrick returns to his Los Angeles turf to carry on his work.

title: Pristina Journal;   Albanians' New Way: Feuds Without Blood
description: Libibe Dragacina extended his hand to Beslim Betushi, and when the handshake was concluded, a group of witnesses broke into happy applause.

title: Dow Slips 4.05 in Sluggish Trading
description: Stock prices fell yesterday and the Dow Jones industrial average lost 4.05 points to end the day at 2,717.12. For the week, the Dow was up 9.91 points.

title: U.S. to Look at Admissions at Berkeley Law School
description: The Federal Department of Education has decided to investigate to determine whether certain admissions policies at the law school of the University of California at Berkeley violate civil rights laws, officials said yesterday.

title: South African Draft Evader Is Granted Asylum in U.S.
description: A white South African, who has refused to serve in his country's military because it enforces the system of white minority rule, or apartheid, has been granted political asylum in the United States.

title: Review/Dance;   Fireworks From Soviet Georgia
description: In the Rustavi Company, swordsmen clash and shout, dagger after dagger is thrown frenziedly into the ground and sparks fly accelerando through the air. But this sensational new song and folk dance ensemble from the Soviet republic of Georgia has a range that goes beyond mere pyrotechnics.

title: G.M. a Good Neighbor in North Tarrytown
description: To the Editor:

title: Richard G. King, 67, Educations Executive
description: Richard Gordon King, an educator who helped to develop college financial aid procedures, died of a heart attack on Tuesday at St. Joseph's Hospital Center in Milford, N.H. He was 67 years old.

title: Cambodian Guerrillas Report Offensive to Retake Territory
description: Thousands of Cambodian guerrillas staged major attacks today in a bid to recapture territory seized by Government forces in recent weeks, senior guerrilla officials said.

title: Nets Voyage to the Bottom of the League
description: Harry Weltman, the Nets' general manager, was in Portsmouth, Va., tonight, scouting talent for this year's National Basketball Association draft. Weltman was lucky. He did not have to watch the first half here.

title: OWNER BACKS SALE OF UNITED AIRLINES TO WORKER GROUP
description: Directors of the parent of United Airlines agreed yesterday to sell the company to its employees for $4.38 billion, or $201 a share. The agreement came nearly six months after a deal for the airline's pilots and management to buy the company collapsed for lack of financing, helping to touch off one of the biggest stock market plunges in history.

description: Cuba's Supreme Court has upheld prison sentences against two human-rights campaigners jailed for discrediting the Cuban state by spreading false information, the Cuban press agency Prensa Latina said today.

description: Harry Goodridge, whose friendship with Andre the seal captivated a wide audience for 25 years, died Wednesday at a hospital here. He was 74 years old.

description: Nothing magical happened for Jennifer Capriati on the tennis court at the Family Circle Cup today: the winning shots she likes to flash past her opponents like yellow missiles were unreliable, so she had to rely on a much plainer weapon, a fighting spirit.

description: Leaders of the Maryland Legislature reached agreement today on a plan to provide $5.4 million in the next year to end the financial crisis that has threatened the Peabody Conservatory's existence.

title: Richard M. Lubell, 84, Former School Official
description: Richard M. Lubell, a former deputy superintendent of the New York City schools, died of a heart attack on Thursday at his home in Stamford, Conn. He was 84 years old.

title: Bridge
description: A traditional trick question is to ask a man: ''Have you stopped beating your wife? Answer yes or no.'' Substitute ''mother'' for ''wife,'' address the question to Jill Blanchard of Manhattan, and the answer would be an unhesitating negative.

title: With Spring Comes Pollen, And Inaccurate Spore Counts
description: Dr. Harriet A. Burge has been counting pollen for about 25 years, but it was not until 1987 that she began looking closely at the American Academy of Allergy and Immunology's annual statistical report. She realized then, she says, that the profession was doing a poor pollen-count job.

title: Doctorow's 'Bathgate' Wins Faulkner Award
description: ''Billy Bathgate'' by E. L. Doctorow won the 10th annual PEN/Faulkner Award as the best work of fiction published in 1989. The announcement was made this week by the Folger Shakespeare Library in Washington, which administers the $7,500 prize. The presentation will be made at the Folger Library on May 12.

title: Review/Theater;   Distillation of 'A Tale of Two Cities'
description: In what is perhaps the most familiar opening paragraph in all English literature, Charles Dickens observed that the best and worst of times just preceding the French Revolution ''was so far like the present period that some of the noisiest authorities insisted on its being received, for good or for evil, in the superlative degree of comparison only.'' Indeed, one of the main reasons epic literature holds its perennial appeal, whether in print or on stage, is the parallels a modern reader can trace to his own time.

title: Sports People: BASEBALL;   Cubs' Sutcliffe Goes On 21-Day Disabled List
description: Rick Sutcliffe, who has pitched five straight home openers at Wrigley Field for the Chicago Cubs, will not be doing it this year. The 33-year-old right-hander has an inflamed right shoulder, and though he will not have to undergo surgery, he was placed on the 21-day disabled list yesterday, retroactive to March 31. Sutcliffe, who won the Cy Young Award in 1984, finished with a 16-11 record last season.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Religion Notes column on March 10 about rating movies summarized incorrectly the listing for the film ''Cinderella'' from Ted Baehr's ''Christian Family Guide to Movies and Videos.'' The book says the film is ''recommended with the caveat that children need to be informed that Jesus is the answer to evil, not Prince Charming nor a fairy godmother.''

title: Slaying Suspect Saw 2 Choices, Doctor Testifies
description: A psychiatrist testified today that John E. List saw only two choices when financial and health problems burdened his family in 1971: go on welfare, or kill his wife, his three children and his mother and send their souls to heaven.

title: More Trade With Japan, Maybe

America says it will become more competitive. Neither will happen overnight, and some undertakings won't be fulfilled. But the fact of a broad understanding may help calm the two nations' increasingly contentious relations.

title: Review/Television;   How the Schools' Failure Is a Business Crisis, Too

The nine educators and corporation executives gathered Monday night at 8 o'clock on Channel 9 concentrate on the failure of America's schools to teach young people to read, spell, add and speak English well enough to staff America's businesses. They agree that cooperation between workplace and schoolplace is essential. ''A'' for good intentions.

title: Commodity Trader Plan
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission proposed a rule today that would require traders to disclose any informal relationships among one another on the floor of the nation's futures exchanges. Under the plan, traders who work with each other, even if informally, would have to register as ''broker associations.'' The exchanges would monitor the associations. Brokers have long shared expenses. But Federal agents found many instances in which customers were defrauded by brokers and traders who worked together after a two-year inquiry.

title: IN SHORT: SCIENCE BOOKS
description: IN CONFIDENCE: Four Years of Therapy. By Roberta Israeloff. (Houghton Mifflin, $18.95.) Can a book about someone's sessions in psychotherapy be of interest to anyone else? Yes, if the writer is Roberta Israeloff and the book is ''In Confidence: Four Years of Therapy.'' Ms. Israeloff, the author of ''Coming to Terms,'' sought counseling to become a better parent for her newborn son. She soon realized that she faced a more crucial issue: in 30 years, she had virtually never asked herself what she wanted or needed. Her therapist specialized in treating adult children of alcoholics, and Ms. Israeloff exhibited several of their characteristic compulsions: to please others; to continue achieving, nonstop, as if by reflex; to control and orchestrate every situation; to keep rage, envy, anguish and other dangerous emotions submerged, venting them only as attacks against herself. Others have tried to document the path to a healthy psyche, especially in self-help recovery manuals. But jargon-laden treatises cannot match Ms. Israeloff's fresh descriptions and striking analogies. Perceptive about her own and other people's behavior, she uncloaks intense emotions and juxtaposes stories so that the reader enjoys new insights along with her. We come to know her spouse, son and parents well through scenes drawn in the present tense, then analyzed with her therapist a few pages later. Her changing thoughts and nightly dreams provide as much action as exterior events. Though the interplay of all these elements could have been chaotic, they make instead an exhilarating portrait of the therapeutic process as a way to discover life's abundance. We rejoice with the writer when, at the end, she dreams: ''I am in a shower, the water is coursing down over me, a fountain of life . . . I am doused with happiness.''

title: The Executive Computer;   Remember: Printing Requires Paper as Well as Hardware
description: Some companies spend tens of thousands of dollars on powerful personal computers, high-resolution laser printers, advanced desktop publishing software, scanners and other high-technology printing components. They invest countless hours of expensive staff time in training and countless more in designing attractive documents. And then, either because they want to save a few cents or because they simply do not think about paper technology, they load the laser printer with stuff intended for use in typewriters or photocopiers.

Catch up. Rake the lawn; feed it. Spread lime, if needed. Prune roses. Mend fences. Use dormant oil sprays. Indoors pot seedlings individually so they are strong enough to be planted outdoors in May.

title: Currency;   April in Paris for the Yen
description: The weak yen gained a little ground last week as traders waited for the results of the Saturday meeting in Paris of the finance ministers from the United States and its economic allies in the Group of Seven. The dollar was little changed against other major currencies. The impact of the meeting - the group's other members are Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada - will be tested as foreign exchange markets open today in New Zealand (in the early afternoon hours, New York time) and then in Tokyo. The yen is likely to fall further without some statement of support and central bank intervention. Meanwhile, the mark could be buffeted this week if the dispute continues over what exchange rate to use in merging the economies of the two Germanys.
