description: Just when it seemed as if black had completely eclipsed every other color for evening, little shoots of navy blue began sprouting up at parties. When you think about it, there's a reason. Deep blue has the plus of black in that it is a dense defusing shade making, every size of woman look a little smaller. It's a splendid background for gems - especially sapphires. Midnight blue also has the added advantage of giving all complexions a glow, something that black lacks. These newly blue-hued women attended the Council of Fashion Designers of America's awards dinner in February.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: 'COTTAGEY'

title: Helen Young Wed to Henry Savage Jr.
description: At Trinity Presbyterian Church in Atlanta, Helen Elizabeth Young, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Cass Young of Fripp Island, S.C., was married yesterday to Henry Lyttleton Savage Jr., a son of Mary Radclyffe Savage of Princeton, N.J., and the late Dr. Savage. The Rev. Allison Williams performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Thomas G. Speers 3d, a cousin of the bridegroom. M. J. Thorne, the bride's sister, was her matron of honor, and Charles C. Savage, the bridegroom's brother, was the best man.

title: Michaela Murphy Planning to Wed
description: September wedding plans for Michaela Margaret Murphy and Jay Crandall Hoag, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Hoag of Naples, Fla., have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Vincent B. Murphy Jr. of Bedminster, N.J.

title: Review/Music;   Chinese Tradition Preserved
description: The National Taiwan Academy of Arts established a Chinese-music division in 1971 to keep performance on traditional instruments alive. An outgrowth of the division is the Chinese Orchestra, a student ensemble of about 40 players, which made its New York debut at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday evening.

title: POSTING: East Orange Plan;   Campus Link For Condos
description: A 24-story rental apartment house near the campus of Upsala College in East Orange, N.J., is being converted into a condominium with an unusual amenity for buyers - access to the college's programs and facilities. Of the 227 apartments in the building, 100 are vacant and available immediately at prices ranging from $64,500 to $199,000. The others are occupied, and the tenants have the option of buying at a discount of 20 percent or leaving within three years.

title: Searching for the Survivors in Tokyo World Markets
description: In the rubble of the Tokyo stock market - now down 24.8 percent for the year - there are stocks that are doing well. They resisted the downturn and some of them, especially electronics stocks, are now recommended by analysts in Tokyo and elsewhere as the way to beat an otherwise miserable market.

title: Fringe Groups Swaying Athens Vote
description: By one calculation, the balance of power in Greece after elections on Sunday could be held by a mix of ecologists and fringe groups that include Pavlov's Dogs (anti-vivisectionist), Flowers of Evil (anarchist) and a third faction pressing for transvestite rights.

title: Priscilla A. Hook, Teacher, Is Wed
description: Priscilla Ann Hook and Kevin Joseph Holleran were married yesterday at the Bryn Mawr (Pa.) Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Stephen D. Michie performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Charles J. Sullivan, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Floyd Leads Masters By 2
description: Raymond Floyd, armed with his old short game and a new attitude, today took a two-shot lead going into the final round of the 54th Masters with a fist-pumping back nine.

title: New York Ethics Law Limiting Lobbying Is Upheld
description: New York State's three-year-old ethics law, which restricts many former state employees from lobbying the agencies they had worked for, was upheld by the state's highest court this week.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: JACKSONVILLE, FLA.;

Plans Advance For Downtown
description: LEAD: AFTER years of seeing their downtown core deteriorate, officials of Jacksonville Beach, about 25 miles east of here, now believe they are on the right track to redevelop it.

title: DAN KLORES: THE MAN BEHIND THE IMAGES
description: You know how they say that you must have a light on in the room when you're watching television? Well, the expert who first declared that was not an ophthalmologist, but Edward Bernays, ''the father of public relations,'' who was representing General Electric light bulbs at the time. He told me so himself, and he wasn't confessing, he was bragging.

title: Foundation Names 143 To Receive Fellowships
description: The John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation has named 143 artists, scholars and scientists as winners of its 66th annual competition for awards totaling $3,783,000.

title: Alfred L. Morse, 87; Headed Shoe Concern
description: Alfred L. Morse, retired head of a chain of shoe stores, died of a heart attack Friday at Mount Auburn Hospital in Cambridge, Mass. He was 87 years old and lived in Cambridge.

title: Parental Roles: Proper Subject
description: The observation that ''growing numbers of Long Island school districts are incorporating parental education into their curriculums on elementary, junior high school and high school levels,'' (Pupils Learning About Parental Roles,'' March 4) leads one to hope that within a couple of years one can write that ''all Long Island districts currently mandate parenting education at all grade levels.''

title: The Bond Between Doctor and Patient
description: THE influx of medical technology, combined with the high expectations of patients and the threat of malpractice suits, have placed unprecedented strains on the doctor-patient relationship in recent years. To ease these tensions, says Dr. Dale Matthews, an assistant professor of medicine at the University of Connecticut School of Medicine, physicians need to be more attentive to the personal concerns of their patients.

title: Votes in Congress;   Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York
description: Senate

title: Women Are Still Scarce as Police Officers
description: LEAD: WOMEN may have come a long way in the last several decades, but their march into police work has been a slow one. That is especially true at the local level, where a majority of New Jersey municipalities still have no women in their departments.

title: A.L. East: Imperfect Blue Jays Best in a Weak Division
description: The American League preview was reported and written by Murray Chass. Teams are listed in the order of predicted finish, with the Yankees picked for second in the East.

title: Algae Periling Ponds In Huntington Station
description: LEAD: FROM afar, the view off Lenox Road, a thoroughfare in Huntington Station, is idyllic: geese, ducks, gulls and a quaint wooden bridge over three interconnected ponds. It is a virtual picture-book setting on private property, and all but obscured from public sight. At water's edge, however, a different perspective emerges.

title: Gathers Had Some Choices
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: GAY SOLDIERS: THEY WATCHED THEIR STEP
description: COMING OUT UNDER FIRE

title: THE AUTHENTIC CID
description: THE QUEST FOR EL CID

title: All the Answers
description: 1. Chaucer, prologue to ''The Canterbury Tales''

title: Giving Meaning To the Word Life
description: TWENTY students at Yeshiva University's Stern College for Women in Manhattan are helping to replace the self-indulgence of the 80's with a better symbol for the 90's: volunteerism. Through the Chai Lifeline program, the students visit terminally ill children and their families, offering emotional and practical support.

title: Look And Listen
description: TELEVISION AND BOOKS are more often considered contenders for children's attention than allies in education. No one knows that better than Alan J. Shalleck, who began his career in television production 40 years ago at CBS and more recently has been developing animation techniques for children's books.

title: Still Serving The Children
description: Maria H. O'Connell, in her article ''Recognizing Old Age When It Rounds the Corner'' [Westchester Opinion, March 4] , mentions having known in the 1930's of a child-care institution established by the philanthropist John E. Andrus. We would like your readers to know that the Julia Dyckman Andrus Memorial, established as a tribute to Mr. Andrus's wife, is still serving children from Westchester and the surrounding area in a comprehensive residential treatment program.

title: U.S. and Soviets Differ Over Ban On Multiple-Warhead Missiles
description: The United States last month secretly proposed a ban on land-based missiles with multiple warheads, but President Mikhail S. Gorbachev replied this week that the plan was too limited, Administration officials said today.

title: POINDEXTER IS FOUND GUILTY OF ALL 5 CRIMINAL CHARGES FOR IRAN-CONTRA COVER-UP
description: John M. Poindexter, the enigmatic rear admiral charged with deceiving and lying to Congress as part of an effort to conceal the Reagan Administration's actions in the Iran-contra affair, was convicted today of all five criminal charges against him.

title: Throngs Rally in Lithuania To Back Independence Call
description: At least 200,000 people crowded into a city park today in the Lithuanian capital, Vilnius, to back their Parliament's defiance of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, witnesses who saw the rally in the neighboring republic said.

title: IN SHORT: SCIENCE BOOKS
description: LEAD:

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;

Employers Take a Role in Housing Staffs
description: LEAD: TWO employers, Spectrum Healthcare Solutions of Hauppauge and the Long Island Jewish Medical Center in New Hyde Park, recently have found solutions for the housing problems of their work forces.

title: Wave of Conversions Slows to a Ripple
description: THE wave of conversions that moved across New York City in the 1980's and transformed some 300,000 rental apartments into cooperatives and condominiums has slowed dramatically.

title: Behind Scenes of College Admissions
description: LEAD: SIGNS of spring abound, with longer days, budding trees, crocuses. It is the time when the attention of many high school seniors turns toward thoughts of college acceptance.

title: 2 Derby Favorites Gain in Stature
description: Mister Frisky and Summer Squall emerged from yesterday's round of prep races as stronger favorites than ever for the Kentucky Derby May 5, even though only one of the two colts went to the races.

title: Spawning Grounds
description: VIVIAN PALEY'S research is about as fundamental as education research gets, and original enough to win her a MacArthur Foundation grant, the so-called genius awards: she is trying to teach children to think - to come up with an idea and develop it in a logical way.

title: Then There Is the Other Side Of Misha Dichter
description: Whatever self-image an artist may hold privately or attempt to project to the world, the public will ultimately form its own image of that artist, which may be entirely different. This appears to have been the case with the pianist Misha Dichter. Many, including this writer, have tended to see Mr. Dichter as a one-sided performer, perhaps excessively devoted to the flashy virtuoso literature of the late 19th and early 20th centuries. But a recent recital of Beethoven, Schubert, Schumann and Brahms suggested that such a view is unjust - indeed, doubly so, for it overlooks what, on the evidence of those performances, may be his better side.

title: Annexing Farmland
description: THIS dairy-farming and agricultural town dating from the 17th century has annexed four farms totaling about 500 acres where development could triple the current population of 3,700.

title: Police Find 4th Body In Miami Beach Fire
description: A fourth body was found today as the authorities continued a search of the three-story residential hotel that was destroyed by fire early Friday.

title: Hong Kong's Mystery Chicken
description: THE classic recipe for Beggar's Chicken, a traditional Chinese dish as popular with tourists as with Far Eastern gourmets, calls for a chicken, two lotus leaves and ''six pounds of pond mud.'' And while the chicken is packed with a delicious stuffing, it is the lotus leaf and mud wrapping that makes this bird so tasty, tender and intriguing.

title: Corrections
description: An artical last Sunday about William Belcom misidentified the singer who iis to play the female lead in the forthcoming opera. ''McTeague'' is Catherine Malfitano.

title: WHAT MAKES NEW YORK WORK, REALLY!
description: This issue of New York, New York is not about the Trumps or the Tisches, the Rockefellers or the Rohatyns. It is not about how politicians get elected, how large corporations get larger or how slow-grinding bureaucracies get slower.

title: Of Concerts And Consorts
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Doubts on Gorbachev
description: Moscow's hard line in Lithuania and tough arms-control stance in last week's talks have revived doubts in Washington about Mikhail S. Gorbachev's future. News analysis, page 15.

title: Campus Life: Princeton;   Arboreal Protest: Hug a Tree And Save a Forest
description: Princeton University students embraced trees last week in a display intended to persuade the university to convert to the use of recycled paper.

title: Q and A
description: Closing a Vault

title: WHEN THINGS DON'T WORK: WHO TO CALL
description: AMERICAN SOCIETY FOR THE PREVENTION OF CRUELTY TO ANIMALS (718-257-6000) can be contacted about stray animals or an animal ambulance service, also for reports of cats trapped in trees, etc.

title: HEAVY METAL INVADES THE GARDEN
description: Robustly sculptured stone and cast-metal lions, dogs, pigs, eagles, dolphins, cherubs and mermaids are proliferating in gardens and parlors across America. The trend is part of the revival of interest in the heroic statuary, fanciful fountains, grandiose urns and weighty furniture produced on both sides of the Atlantic between the Civil War and World War II.

title:
PROFILE: Herb London;

Right Radical
description: LEAD: HERB LONDON apologizes for arriving late from a fund-raising meeting. ''Sometimes I feel that I'm still going around with a pishke for my mother,'' he says, using the Yiddish word for charity collection can. But the dean of New York University's Gallatin Division is quick to add that the experimental college is running far ahead of projections in its latest capital campaign.

title: N.L. WEST: PADRES SHOULD POWER THEIR WAY TO THE TOP
description: The National League preview was reported and written by Murray Chass. Teams are listed in the order of predicted finish, with the Mets picked for first in the East.

title: Beating Time Warner at Its Own Game
description: I didn't have any money,'' said Robin Wolaner. ''I thought, 'Who would invest in me? I don't even have an M.B.A.' I had never heard the term venture capital. My husband said, 'So what that you don't have any money?.' ''

title: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: A Baltic Chill On Relations;   Momentum Is Slower In Superpower Talks
description: During this week's talks between Soviet and American officials, the Kremlin's problems in Lithuania kept intruding on the discussions like an uninvited guest to a dinner party.

title: Review/Music;   Soloists Team Up in the New York Rock and Soul Revue
description: At a time when rock concerts are putting an increasing emphasis on spectacle and choreography, it is refreshing to attend a show at which genuine interplay among musicians is the main attraction.

title: THE DIFFERENTS THAT MAKE THE DIFFERENCE
description: Who are the eccentrics of New York? You know who you are - everybody, in a way. The alien gravity of eccentricity is always at work in New York. It is a force that skews behavior, bends thought and pulls people in unexpected directions, not all of them bad. New York is an eccentricity machine.

title: N-W Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Reflected gains from debt extinguishment of $1.62 million for the quarter and $2.141 million for the year. Regarding the latest year's figures, the third quarter results had been previously restated to remove realized benefits from utilization of tax loss carryforwards. Subsequently, the company said it requested and received approval from the Securities and Exchange Commission to reverse the statements and now reports benefits from utilization of tax loss carryforwards in the statements of operations.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Coradian Corp.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Stocks Rise 3.93% in Tokyo
description: The primary index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange surged nearly 4 percent this afternoon, helped by the yen's rebound against the dollar.

title: Royal Gold Enterp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company said the 1989 first quarter included a $138,000 loss from discontinued operations. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Review/Music;   Moscow Philharmonic
description: The Moscow Philharmonic was best known in the West between 1960 and 1975, when Kiril Kondrashin was its conductor and it toured with some regularity. Dmitri Kitayenko became its music director in 1976, and the orchestra visited the United States with him in 1979. Since then, until Friday evening's concert at Carnegie Hall, the orchestra had not been heard here.

title: Rethinking Foreign Aid
description: It's time to rethink foreign aid. America no longer needs to view countries through the distorting ice of the cold war. Instead, it can shift emphasis and resources toward building a less fortified, more truly secure world. Such a shift would also serve U.S. interests in a new era in which weapons count less than economic success.

title: Albany Leaders Say a Budget Accord Is Near
description: After a two-hour meeting in the Capitol tonight, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and leaders of the state Legislature described themselves as on the way toward reaching final agreement on the state's budget, now eight days overdue, but they declined to release any details.

title: Man Charged in Gang Rape Of a Mute Brooklyn Woman
description: A 28-year-old mute, retarded woman who wandered from her group home in Brooklyn early yesterday morning was raped in a school yard by three men, one of whom was caught and arrested, the police said.

title: Roth's Publishers: The Spurned and the Spender
description: A poster of a man's hand grasping the naked flank of a shapely woman currently adorns many book stores, and thereby hangs a contemporary publishing tale involving a bitter clash between two of the industry's lions.

title: Awaiting His Fate, His World Closes In
description: On a rooftop overlooking the tenements of East Harlem, Kenneth Mendoza kicked at a blood-stained syringe yesterday, one of dozens that lay everywhere. For years, the 19-year-old said, he had used the roof to practice karate. But he stopped coming when the heroin and crack users moved in.

title: Guidance or Censorship? New Debate on Rating Films.
description: The designation of two new films as X-rated has rekindled debate over the 21-year-old movie-classification system of the Motion Picture Association of America.

title: Spate of New Offerings Undercuts Bond Prices
description: Credit market analysts say a heavy schedule of new Treasury borrowings over the next month is likely to offset any positive effect of a slowing of economic growth and inflation.

title: Lisa Brauer Wed to Scott McLaughlin
description: The marriage of Lisa Brauer, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Earle W. Brauer of New York, to Francis Scott McLaughlin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. McLaughlin of Brigantine, N.J., took place yesterday at the Boston Harbor Hotel. Betty Brown, the town clerk of Marblehead, Mass., officiated.

title: Emerson Greenaway; Librarian, 83
description: Emerson Greenaway, who as director of the Philadelphia public library system from 1951 to 1969 supervised the construction of several branches and the introduction of bookmobiles, died yesterday after a brief illness at a nursing care center in New London, N.H., where he lived. He was 83 years old.

title: Reviews/Television;   On the Art of Being a Spokesman
description: A pride of former Presidential press secretaries purr and growl their way through ''The Presidency, the Press and the People.'' Prompted by the bantering questions and comments of John Chancellor, 10 men who served occupants of the White House from John F. Kennedy to Ronald Reagan indulge in anecdotes and analysis at 8 tonight on Channel 13, in a two-hour get-together that moves like a fast-paced press conference. Their faces, though showing the impositions of the years, will remind viewers of many Administrations past and provide reason to be on guard against those present and still to come.

title: Mets and Yankees Go Separate Ways
description: The games begin today, and while the Yankees and the Mets insist they are ready, the only barometer will be the season itself. But if yesterday stood for anything, it was this: the Mets seem set; the Yanks, who left the Florida sun on Friday, are as cold as an April day in New York.

title: B&H Maritime Carriers reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company began operations on Feb. 3, 1989; therefore 11 months and not a full year.

title: Review/Theater;   Lloyd Webber's 'Aspects of Love'
description: Andrew Lloyd Webber, the composer who is second to none when writing musicals about cats, roller-skating trains and falling chandeliers, has made an earnest but bizarre career decision in ''Aspects of Love,'' his new show at the Broadhurst. He has written a musical about people.

title: Sizing Up Rules On Bats, Gloves
description: DON'T be surprised if you see more home runs this season or if you have to look twice to see what kind of bats are being used to hit them. You can also expect to see more passed balls, not to mention bits of measuring tape hanging out of umpires' pockets.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   The Guns of Managua
description: Nicaragua is locked in civil war. Washington is deeply involved. Rebels remain in the hills, refusing to disarm. Power in Managua is fiercely contested, as is the wisdom of U.S. involvement.

title: Gale Alone Sank Burmese Ferry, Paper Says
description: The Burmese ferry accident that may have claimed more than 200 lives on Friday is only the latest in a series of sinkings along this country's southern waterways in recent years.

title: PC Etcetera reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: CBS Is Said to Get 10 Films To Show Before Cable TV
description: Universal Pictures has agreed to license 10 films that were released in 1989 to CBS for about $55 million, industry executives said.

title: President Not Meddling In Cuomo Election Fight
description: While Republicans in Washington relish Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's problems in balancing the state budget and acknowledge that he may be a Presidential contender in two years, they are not helping to select an opponent to run against him this year.

title: Winston Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Kyoto Journal;   As High Priests of Tea Meet, a Cool Breeze Builds
description: Because it was such an outstanding cultural event, the 400th anniversary of the death of Sen no Rikyu, the greatest Grand Master in the history of tea, offered an unparalleled opportunity to conduct a truly perfect tea ceremony in his honor.

title: In the West, High Noon for Lakers
description: WHEN the Los Angeles Lakers open the morning paper and look at the National Basketball Association standing, it motivates them.

title: Penobscot Shoe reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 23
description: b-Net income

title: Adage Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-Included income of $550,000 for the quarter and a loss of $4,353,000 for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations. c-Net loss and after a loss of $1,690,000 from discontinued operations. d-Net income and included income of $4,327,000, which included a gain of $2,255,000 from disposal of discontinued operations, and an extraordinary tax benefit of $1,818,000.

title: CHRONICLE
description: THE AMAZING KRESKIN says no deal on that turreted turn-of-the-century Victorian house in Nyack, N.Y. - the one the owner says has ghosts.

title: LOBBYING STEPS UP ON MILITARY BUYING AS BUDGET SHRINKS
description: Military contractors, threatened as never before by shrinking Pentagon budgets, are responding with aggressive lobbying to protect weapons programs worth hundreds of billions of dollars.

title: The Media Business;   Grey Advertising's Parts Add Up to Big Sums
description: For years, the word on Madison Avenue was that Grey Advertising was a little like its name: a dull agency that created nondescript advertising. But these days, Grey is anything but drab.

title: Page 1 News: A Color Picture
description: The front page of yesterday's Washington Post included a four-color rendering of a painting of the Hubble Space Telescope.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''When he first came, a lot of people were really scared. But Ryan helped all of us to understand. He didn't want people to feel sorry for him. He hated that. He just wanted to be a regular kid.''

title: Quality Book Publishing Shifts to Small Presses;   Why Errors Abound
description: To the Editor:

title: Wiener Enterprises Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
description: b-Net income

title: Review/Opera;   Norman and Lakes in 'Walkure'
description: When ''Die Walkure'' was unveiled in 1986 as the first installment of the Metropolitan Opera's Wagner ''Ring'' cycle, the director Otto Schenk's concept for the whole was described as romantic realism. To this observer, the ''Walkure'' production in particular has always fallen somewhat short of that ideal. If Gunther Schneider-Siemssen's sets offered a bit more fancy to engage the eye over the vast temporal expanses, or if a compelling drama were being convincingly played out on those sets, the mind might be slower to reduce them to papier-mache.

title: Mor-Flo Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included charges of $151,000 in the quarter and $4,135,000 in the year reflecting an increase in the provision for the infringement damage award against the company. c-Included charges of $53,000 in the quarter and $1,921,000 in the year related to the infringement damage award, and a net gain of $5,044,000 in the quarter and year on sale of the company's recreational product line business.

title: Second Trial Begins in Child Molestation Case
description: The Virginia McMartin Preschool child molestation case will be revived Monday as jury selection begins for the second trial of one of the original defendants.

title: Heavy Schedule of Government Securities
description: New issues will substantially increase the supply of debt obligations this week in the Government securities market.

title: Soviet Georgians Rally, Demanding Independence but Revealing Disunity
description: Tens of thousands of Soviet Georgians packed the streets of Tbilisi tonight for a mournful protest that laid bare the republic's increasing hunger for independence but also its badly fragmented politics.

title: A Tale of Two Priorities
description: All right, George Bush fans, let's reconcile the following two news items:

title:
ON YOUR OWN;

Bobby Jones's Reputation Still Growing
description: LEAD: IN a game of many secrets but few revelations, golfers were recently surprised to learn that the all-time best player, best teacher and best writer may have been the same person: Bobby Jones.

title: When You're Hot, Maybe You're Not
description: LEAD: After a season of discontent, baseball opens its real season today. And that means another year of streaks and slumps that will be treated, by fans, players and everyone else connected with the game, as remarkable and inexplicable coincidences and runs of luck.

title: A Departure From the Past
description: In this, the most hopeful of Prague springs in 22 years, life moves at a giddy pace, even if toward uncertain destinations. The revolution of recent months has brought changes everywhere, and changes have created choices where none before existed.

title: Telescope Is Set to Peer at Space and Time >
description: On the clearest of nights, high in the cool, dry mountain air, the unaided human eye can glimpse perhaps 6,000 objects in the sky: individual stars, a few planets and a multitude of galaxies composed of millions of stars but so far away that they appear as single points of light.

title: Abortion From Persuasion to Prohibition
description: To the Editor:

title: Greeks and Peruvians Give Leads to Rightists
description: Greece's main conservative party won half the seats in Parliament, failing to secure an absolute majority but hoping to win independent support to form a government.

title: Oilgear Co.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Blues Defeat Leafs in Overtime
description: Sergio Momesso's second goal of the game at 6 minutes 4 seconds of overtime tonight gave the St. Louis Blues a 6-5 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs and a three-game lead in their Norris Division semifinal series.

title: Liability Laws Are Criticized
description: United States companies are becoming less competitive because of the threat that they may have to pay huge damage awards in product liability suits, Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher said last week.

title: Bob and Ray's Courage
description: To the Editor:

title: Cherry Blossom Time? Gone With March Wind
description: It rained on Dave C. Williams's parade. It also snowed and sleeted. Then the sun came out.

title: 'Cosby Show' Buys Producer Big-League Field of Dreams
description: SOME American boys fulfill their dreams and make it to the major leagues by learning how to hit. Tom Werner is getting there because he knows how to make hits -on television.

title: Jane Rosenthal, Physician, Weds
description: Dr. Jane Lisa Rosenthal, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Rosenthal of Pompton Lakes, N.J., was married yesterday to Bruce Brian Cahan, a son of Bernard Cahan of Marco Island, Fla., and Joan Cahan of Philadelphia. Rabbi Hyman Krantz officiated at the Preakness Hills Country Club in Wayne, N.J.

title: Ryan White Dies of AIDS at 18; His Struggle Helped Pierce Myths
description: Ryan White, the Indiana teen-ager who put the face of a child on AIDS and served as a leader for gaining greater understanding and compassion for those with the deadly disease, died today. He was 18 years old.

title: CHRONICLE
description: TOMMY LEE, a drummer for the heavy metal group Motley Crue, was hospitalized with a mild concussion suffered when he fell during a concert on Saturday at the New Haven Coliseum, The Associated Press reported.

title: Sodarcan Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Scott Instruments reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $9,937 for the latest year and $74,211, or 1 cent a share, for 1988.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Stock Exchange, New York, appointed Christopher Finn executive vice president, responsible for marketing, research, communications and government relations. Philip Steele was named senior vice president, responsible for strategic planning and special projects.

title: When School Offers Refuge To Homeless
description: Jessica was homeless, but in some ways life was better for her than when she had a home, especially her life as a third grader.

title: Pubco Corp.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Senator Defends Help For Lincoln
description: The chairman of the Senate Banking Committee yesterday defended his intervention with Federal regulators in 1987 on behalf of a Phoenix developer, Charles H. Keating Jr., saying that Mr. Keating was a business constituent in Michigan, his home state. The chairman, Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., said he had received no indication that Mr. Keating had done anything improper.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-9

title: Home Builder In Chapter 11
description: The General Development Corporation filed for Federal bankruptcy protection on Friday, less than a week after revealing a severe cash shortage and agreeing to a $100 million repayment program for victims of a scheme to sell overpriced homes.

title: Telling the Seder's Story In the Voice of a Woman
description: Twenty-seven women gathered in a downtown loft this weekend for a seder. They celebrated the deliverance of the Jews in Egypt from slavery more than 3,300 years ago, they prayed over the four cups of wine and the matzoh, they ate the ritual foods of bitter herbs and haroseth that symbolize suffering.

title: 47th Street Photo Official Plans Software Business
description: Robert Orbach, director of business development for 47th Street Photo, is leaving to start a new business in the software industry.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   International Trade Group Reorganizes
description: IN an effort to raise its profile to the level of other advertising trade groups, the International Advertising Association announced a management reorganization on Friday that will bring the group its first full-time professional leadership.

title: Discovery West reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Ports of Call Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Newark Publishes Sex and Drug Arrests
description: For the last two weeks, the hottest paper in this city has been an eight-page scandal sheet. Copies have become so scarce that even members of the City Council, which publishes the tabloid-sized quarterly, The Council Monitor, have to scramble to find one.

title: Pepsi Will Be Bartered for Ships And Vodka in Deal With Soviets
description: In the largest deal ever between an American corporation and the Soviet Union, Pepsico expects to sign an agreement today to barter Pepsi-Cola for ships and vodka. The accord is valued at more than $3 billion.

title: NEPAL'S KING LIFTS BAN ON POLITICKING
description: Bowing to unrelenting pressure from a pro-democracy movement, King Birendra of Nepal announced tonight that he was lifting a 29-year ban on political activity, opening the possibility of multiparty rule in this Himalayan land.

title: Fur Vault reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 3
description: b-Net income

title: Casual Male Chapter 11
description: The Casual Male Corporation said last week that it was filing a voluntary petition for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws. The company cited increased competition and costs associated with an aggressive store expansion program in the men's wear retail market as the principal factors contributing to the company's cash shortage.

title: M.D. - Mired in Debt
description: LEAD: It's a standard lament: selfish, money-conscious medical students would rather go into a lucrative specialty like radiology or ophthalmology than into primary care, with its long hours and relatively small returns.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When BARBARA J. SABOL is sworn in as New York City's Human Resources administrator on Thursday, she will take her oath on the Bible of Harriet Tubman. Mrs. Sabol, 51 years old, borrowed the Bible because Harriet Tubman is one of her childhood heroines.

title: Baseball Today!
description: RESILIENT as ever, baseball opens its season today, proving it can overcome man-made disputes as well as natural disasters.

title: Visx Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company, which was incorporated in 1987 and began operating as a functional entity in spring 1988, said it had no fourth quarter and yearly revenues for 1988.

title: Shriver Leaves 2 Spots As NBC News Anchor
description: NBC News announced yesterday that Maria Shriver has given up her assignments as a co-anchor of ''Sunday Today'' and anchor of the Saturday edition of NBC ''Nightly News,'' effective immediately. Ms. Shriver, who recently returned to the programs after a four-month maternity leave, is to serve as the anchor of an occasional series of prime-time news specials, said Michael G. Gartner, the president of the news division. No executive producer for the programs has been named, nor have any other staff members for the programs, which may be seen every few months.

title: Farm Aid Raises $1.3 Million
description: The fourth Farm Aid concert, intended to help American family farmers, raised at least $1.3 million, a spokeswoman said today. The 14-hour concert, held Saturday in the Hoosier Dome, attracted about 45,000 people. A final figure on donations for the event will be released Monday, a spokeswoman said. Farm Aid said the concerts had raised more than $12 million, and that $9 million had been distributed in 41 states.

title: U.S. Wins In Soccer
description: Eric Wynalda scored two first-half goals today as the United States beat Iceland, 4-1, in a tuneup for the country's first World Cup appearance in 40 years.

title: CRIMES OF VIOLENCE ARE UP 5% IN U.S.
description: Violent crime in the United States rose 5 percent last year, while serious property crimes like theft and burglary rose only 2 percent, according to figures released today by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Stephanie Magdziak Weds Ronald Berlin in Princeton
description: Stephanie Jo Magdziak, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thaddeus J. Magdziak of Levittown, Pa., was married yesterday in Princeton, N.J., to Ronald Hugh Berlin, the son of Hilda Berlin of Forest Hills, Queens, and the late Milton Berlin. The Rev. David McAlpin, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at Prospect House on the Princeton University campus.

title: Altex Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: His Lucky Day
description: JEFF DINUZZO was contemplating his pitching assignment against Connecticut last Monday as he parked his car on the Seton Hall campus in South Orange, N.J. DiNuzzo opened the car door and spotted a penny on the ground. The coin was lying heads up.

title: Proffitt's Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 3
Carolco Pictures reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Unico Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Taj Mahal's Slot Machines Halt, Overcome by Success
description: Less than a week after they began to swallow coins in record numbers, the slot machines of Donald J. Trump's new monument to casino glitz, the Taj Mahal, were paralyzed today, apparent victims of their own success.

title: JUDGE BARS ACTION AGAINST EXHIBITION
description: A Federal district judge barred local law-enforcement officials today from shutting down or interfering with an art center's showing of photographs by Robert Mapplethorpe.

title: Vargas Llosa Leads, but Faces a Runoff
description: The novelist Mario Vargas Llosa appeared to have finished in first place today in a presidential election clouded by terrorist threats and charges of vote fraud, unofficial projections indicated. But a dark-horse challenger, Alberto Fujimori, cut deeply into support for the internationally known writer and appeared to have forced a runoff election between the two men.

title: 'Country of Concern'
description: Undeterred by the Bush Administration's appeasement of Iraq's bloodthirsty regime, Federal grand juries have recently brought two indictments against Saddam Hussein's agents:

title: In Bulgaria, Hard Times Are Harder
description: The economy of Bulgaria is in bad shape.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Below are the major economic indicators to be released this week.

title: Review/Dance;   Aftershocks of Vietnam
description: A great gap can exist between artistic aspiration and achievement. When Michiyo and Dancers presented ''The Elevator'' on Thursday night at the Dia Art Foundation on Mercer Street, that gap became a chasm.

title: Canadian Foremost reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Secom General reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Lebanese Christians Ravaged, Now by Lebanese Christians
description: The Christians of Lebanon, once the country's unchallenged and affluent rulers, are now a minority bleeding to death under civil war. Since the end of January, fighting for control of the country's 300-square-mile Christian enclave has killed more than 900 people, wounded 3,000 and forced about 300,000 to flee abroad.

title: Ocean Bio-Chem reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Careplus Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary tax credits of $283,000, or 5 cents a share, for the quarter and $693,000, or 13 cents a share, for the year. The company said year-ago quarter and year's income from continuing operations of $599,000, or 12 cents a share, and $1,433,000, or 29 cents a share, respectively, both included a non-recurring gain of $204,000, or 3 cents a share.

title: Scholars Acclaim de Gaulle as a Man of Vision
description: Although he was a thorn in the side of successive American Presidents, General Charles de Gaulle was portrayed this past weekend as a visionary statesman who restored France's faith in itself and peered beyond the cold war to foresee the collapse of the Soviet domain.

title: Books of The Times;   Nixon's Battles and the Aftermaths
description: In the Arena

title: Higher Fares Increase Lines And Evaders
description: The recent increase in New York City's subway and bus fare, which rose to $1.15 from $1 on Jan. 1, has resulted in longer lines at token booths, a rise in fare evasion and a decline in ridership that could eventually cost the Transit Authority millions of dollars.

title: Man Killed at $3-a-Head Party in Brooklyn
description: A man was shot and killed and a woman was wounded in the leg shortly before 2 A.M. yesterday following an argument at a party in a Brooklyn basement apartment, the police said.

title: Medicaid Gives Excellent Treatment to New York State's Poor;   Mental Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Arms Talks: Fresh Twist
description: The Bush Administration's latest initiative on strategic arms poses difficult military planning and spending questions for Moscow as well as Washington.

title: Outdoors: Tackle For High Rollers
description: SOME people pursue fine and venerable fishing tackle and associated equipage as avidly as a dedicated angler goes after trout or striped bass, and one of the events that gives collectors a good idea of the going price for such items is the annual R. W. Oliver Gallery's High Roller's auction.

title: W. Harold Flowers, 78, Arkansas Rights Figure
description: The Rev. W. Harold Flowers, a patriarch of the civil rights movement in Arkansas and its oldest practicing black lawyer, died Saturday at a hospital here. He was 78 years old and had been suffering from cancer.

title: Showing Italian Flights Of More Than Fancy
description: Ever since Leonardo da Vinci's first drawings of a flying machine, Italy has made significant contributions to aerospace design and technology. The history of Italian aviation is the subject of an exhibition at the Intrepid Sea-Air-Space Museum through April 30.

title: East Germany Agrees on New Coalition
description: East Germany's new political leaders said today that they had agreed on the basic outlines of a coalition government and expected to have it ready by the next session of Parliament, on Thursday.

title: Yugoslavia Holds Free Vote For First Time Since 1940's
description: Slovenes lined up patiently at polling stations in a cold rain today to vote for a new President for their republic, members of a new collective presidency and representatives to two of three parliamentary chambers. The voting marked the first free multiparty elections in Yugoslavia since Tito took power here after World War II.

title: Nina Zakin Wed To James Essey
description: Nina Elizabeth Zakin and James Andrew Essey were married yesterday at the Lotos Club in New York by Rabbi Shira Stern.

title: No More Cold Golf Balls
description: For golfers seeking a quick boost in performance, a company in Tarrytown, N.Y., suggests heating your golf balls before the round.

title: S. Dana Snyder Weds James F. Grant
description: S. Dana Snyder and James F. Grant were married yesterday in Sharon, Mass., at the home of the bride's sister and brother-in-law, Dr. and Mrs. Bruce L. Katcher. Ann Taubes Warner, a justice of the peace in Belmont, Mass., performed the ceremony.

title: Trico Products reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-After extraordinary credits of $115,000, or 6 cents a share, for the quarter and $2,266,000, or $1.22 a share, for the year, both from utilization of tax loss carryforwards.

title: Healed, Avid Graf Returning to Court
description: This has been an interesting winter for Steffi Graf.

title: Question Box
description: Tops in Runs Batted In

title: Legislator Slain in Colombia
description: A Colombian politician from a faction of the governing party that opposes negotiations with drug traffickers was shot to death today, the police reported. Jose Humberto Hernandez Rodriguez, 45 years old, a Liberal Party alternate member of Parliament, was shot several times at point-blank range as he left a meeting in Bogota, a police spokesman said. Colombia's drug traffickers pledged on Friday to step up their war against politicians and business leaders.

title: Rescue of Gdansk Shipyard Stalls
description: Ten months ago, it seemed that a capitalist fairy tale was unfolding at this city's famed shipyard, the birthplace of Poland's Solidarity trade union movement. But today, the hoped-for revival has become a case study of the difficulties of turning state-run companies in Eastern Europe into private enterprises.

title: Scuba Class: A Journey Under and Within
description: DESPITE the cold of the early April spring morning, the black rain clouds looming ominously overhead and three-foot swells, the chartered boat headed out of the marina in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, toward the open sea. This was to be the final step in a demanding eight-week scuba diving certification program, and all 10 students were ready, rain or shine.

title: Abortion From Persuasion to Prohibition;   But Condemn Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: Marketing Systems of AmerFica reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $515,000, or 8 cents a share, from operating loss carryforward. c-Net loss

title: Texas Campaign Tests Limits of Politics
description: Texas politics is often described as a contact sport, but even veterans of the game say they have never seen a campaign rougher than the race for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination between the Attorney General, Jim Mattox, and the Treasurer, Ann Richards.

title: Capriati Earns Respect In Defeat
description: Martina Navratilova used her racquet like a pointer and the tennis court like a blackboard this afternoon to deliver 14-year-old Jennifer Capriati a heady lesson in comeuppance in the final of the Family Circle Cup.

title: Halton Reinsurance reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Mister Frisky's Next Date Is the Derby
description: Mister Frisky, who scored his 16th victory without a defeat in the Santa Anita Derby on Saturday, will make his next start in the Kentucky Derby on May 5. He is a virtual cinch to be the favorite at Churchill Downs, regardless of what happens in the remaining prep races over the next three weeks.

title: Neilson May Try The Goalie Shuffle
description: John Vanbiesbrouck, stuck at the end of the bench because he has been denied the privilege to start in goal, has watched Mike Richter take the stage and steal the thunder by winning the first two games against the Islanders. Richter, the Ranger rookie who if he isn't yet a playoff phenom has certainly been fairly fabulous, has won a lot of hearts in the process.

title: Integrated Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Market Place;   Browning-Ferris's Strategic Retreat
description: NO one disputes that hazardous-waste disposal is a huge, lucrative market destined to become much larger. Nevertheless, Wall Street's first reaction was decidedly upbeat when Browning-Ferris Industries said after trading ended Thursday that it would bail out of the business.

title: Frank Kozin, 60, Dies; Engineering Professor
description: Frank Kozin, a professor of electrical engineering at the Polytechnic Institute of New York in Brooklyn who developed techniques of applied probability, died of a brain tumor on Thursday at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 60 years old and lived in Huntington, L.I.

title: Exhausted Sailors Heading to Florida
description: After a grueling seven-month trip, the first of 22 boats still competing in the Whitbread Round the World Race was expected here early Monday.

title: Review/Theater;   'Balcony': The Fantasy Within A Fantasy
description: More than three decades after it was written, ''The Balcony'' no longer seems so outrageous. In the interval, too much has happened in the world and in art. But Jean Genet's play retains its diabolical originality, and if properly presented on stage, it should still have the power to disturb and even disorient an audience.

title: Greek Conservatives Finish First But Fail to Win Majority of Seats
description: After a count that lasted far into the early hours today, Greece's main conservative party, New Democracy, secured exactly half of Parliament's 300 seats, failing to secure a majority to lead the nation out of political paralysis. The elections were the country's third in 10 months.

title: Rio Alto Exploration reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $775,000. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Susan Ross Is Married
description: Susan Ross, a vice president of the Republic National Bank in New York, and Dr. Jeffrey Martin Factor, a fellow in allergy and immunology at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, were married yesterday at Sans Souci in Sea Cliff, L.I. Rabbi Charles Agin officiated. Mrs. Factor, 29 years old, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred M. Ross of Forest Hills, Queens. She is a cum laude graduate of Queens College. Dr. Factor, 30, is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Factor of Cranston, R.I. He graduated magna cum laude from Brown University, where he was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, and the Mount Sinai School of Medicine.

title: Sports of The Times;   Splash! The 7-Iron That Got Away
description: FOR the rest of his life, whenever Raymond Floyd thinks about the Masters, he'll see the 7-iron that got away.

title: Coronet Carpets reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $1,813,000. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Mastercard's Shift From Glamour
description: Something risky is happening at Mastercard. After years of me-too marketing that emulated Visa and American Express, the credit card is now pitching itself to Middle America and away from the affluent professionals depicted in the advertising of its rivals.

title: Despite Heat Rally, Nets Win, 102-101
description: The Nets and the Miami Heat entered tonight's game with the two worst records in the National Basketball Association. And for much of the game, they played like it.

title: U.S. Is Urged to Keep Pressure on Japan
description: Despite Japan's recent pledges to open its markets to more foreign products, leading business groups and influential lawmakers are warning the Bush Administration against letting up on the pressure they say is responsible for the positive results.

title: Review/Recital;   Paul Plishka Adds Drama To Songs
description: The American bass Paul Plishka, who spends much of his time these days at the Metropolitan Opera, gave a song recital at Weill Recital Hall on Friday evening, and at times he virtually turned the auditorium into a mini-Met.

title: Deerfield Federal S&L reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Residential Mortgage InvestFments Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-Net income

title: Deals
description: Baseball

title: Machine Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Metro Matters;   For Friedman, Koch Becomes An Unlikely Ally
description: Stanley M. Friedman, barred forever from politics by a Federal judge, is quietly waging the most important campaign of his life.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Nancy Antell and Hayim Nitka Have Wedding
description: Her father is a presiding judge of the Appellate Division of New Jersey Superior Court. Her mother, Bebe Antell, is an interior designer in Millburn. The bride is the vice president and her husband is the president of Nitka Graphics, a commercial printing company in Paterson and Elmwood Park, N.J. The bridegroom is a graduate of the Bezalel Art Institute in Jerusalem. His father, who is retired, owned a supermarket in Ramat Gan.

title: Results Plus
description: Golf

title: Airline Fares Are Defended
description: United States air passengers are being offered more flights at lower fares than in the mid-1980's even though there are fewer airlines, a Transportation Department official said last week.

title: Review/Dance;   Mixed-Media Ecology
description: For part of the time during ''Against the Earth,'' hearing was believing. What could be seen in this mixed-media creation by the Thunder Bay Ensemble on Friday night at La Mama E.T.C. usually prompted profound skepticism. And before the hourlong production was over, both sights and sounds grew equally pretentious.

title: Former GTE Officer Is Chief of Telecharge
description: International Telecharge Inc., which specializes in operator-assisted long-distance phone services, has named Allan L. Rayfield, a former top executive at the GTE Corporation, to the posts of chairman and chief executive.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation, which has come under criticism for discrimination against its Hispanic employees, will bestow its first Medal of Valor on a Hispanic agent. The F.B.I. Director WILLIAM S. SESSIONS will present the award tomorrow to special agent EDMUNDO MIRELES for his ''heroic actions'' in what the bureau called one of the most violent gun battles in its history. Mr. Mireles was wounded in a shootout on April 11, 1986, during a bank robbery surveillance in South Florida that ended in the death of two fellow agents and two armed suspects. The ceremony is to be held at F.B.I. headquarters in Washington.

title: Cable Viewers Begin Season of Almost Daily Baseball
description: America's love affair with baseball enters a new stage this year: For much of the country, there will be almost daily televised games from spring through summer through fall, including Sunday nights and weeknight doubleheaders.

title: 2 More Bodies Uncovered In Florida Hotel Fire Rubble
description: Searchers using dogs and heavy equipment found two more bodies and looked for others today in the charred hulk of the Fontana Hotel.

title: Continental Mortgage & EqFuity Trust reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: All share earnings figures reflect the 1-for-3 reverse split effective March 26. The company said that a $1 million decrease in net rental income was attributable to the sale of five properties during the year. It said the Trust recorded a $3.9 million provision for losses in 1989, compared with a provision of $12.7 million in 1988.

title: Review/Television;   The People Who Report and Edit the News
description: Several years ago MTM Enterprises had a bumpy but respectable television run with ''Lou Grant,'' starring Ed Asner, formerly employed by the television station on ''The Mary Tyler Moore Show,'' as a newspaper editor. On ABC tonight at 9, MTM returns to print journalism with a special two-hour premiere of ''Capital News,'' in which the fictitious Washington Capital, an influential newspaper based in Washington, is given a sort of ''Hill Street Blues'' spin. Television prime time has a tendency to turn back in on itself.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   McDonald Group Loses A Copywriter Partner
description: A comeback by the co-founder of Atlanta's first nationally esteemed ad agency may be in peril by the defection of one of two creative partners.

title: 7 Weeks Later, No Answers in Killing
description: Seven weeks have passed since a Suffolk County narcotics detective was killed by a car bomb outside his home here. There have been no arrests, and the police refuse to discuss details of the investigation.

title: Right-Wing Christian Party Takes Clear Lead in Hungarian Voting
description: The Hungarian Democratic Forum, a conservative party, emerged today with a decisive lead in the final round of elections for Hungary's Parliament, guaranteeing it the dominant role in the country's first freely elected government in more than four decades.

title: Tough Call for Bush: A Presidential Pardon for Poindexter?
description: John M. Poindexter's conviction on five felony charges seems likely to thrust President Bush once again into the discomforting limelight of the Iran-contra affair, this time over the possibility of a Presidential pardon.

title: Seeing Is Not Believing for Caps' Coach
description: When the Devils escaped with a 6-5 victory over the Washington Capitals at Byrne Meadowlands Arena on Saturday night to even their Patrick Divison semifinal series at one game each, Terry Murray stood by himself on the bench and stared at the ice in disbelief over what had transpired.

title: Cold Cash
description: THIS may become known as the era of the yuppie snowboarder, which appears to be the youngest, fastest-growing athlete-entrepreneur segment in sports.

title: INSIDE
description: Hard Questions on Arms

title: Lakers Rally to Beat Nuggets, 116-109
description: A. C. Green had 26 points and 18 rebounds and Magic Johnson scored 5 of his 19 points in a 19-3 fourth-period run that gave the Los Angeles Lakers a 116-109 victory over the Denver Nuggets tonight.

title: Beeba's Creations reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
P.A.M. Transportation Svcs reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included $2 million loss on retirement of property and equipment.

title: Jo Shifrin, a Hospital Administrator,Is Married to Jethro K. Lieberman
description: Jo Shifrin and Jethro K. Lieberman were married yesterday aboard the yacht Cabaret at Pier 62 in Manhattan by Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman.

title: Cupertino National Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Per share earnings and shares oustanding are adjusted to reflect a 5 percent dividend payable on May 3, 1990.

title: Standard Oil & Exploration of Delaware Inc.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Parking Rules
description: Because of Passover, alternate-side parking rules will be suspended in New York City tomorrow and Wednesday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Ronald E. Evans, 56, Astronaut Who Piloted Apollo 17 Mission
description: Ronald E. Evans, the Apollo 17 astronaut who exclaimed ''Hot diggety dog!'' upon taking his first steps in space in December 1972, died of a heart attack in his sleep on Saturday at his home in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 56 years old.

title: Medicaid Gives Excellent Treatment to New York State's Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: A Stronger Outlook for Germany
description: Surging demand from East Germany is giving West Germany's economy unexpected strength and is bolstering the Bonn Government's claim that the monetary union of the nations can be financed without raising taxes.

title: Business Scene;   Low U.S. Profits For Foreigners
description: FEW issues raise more of a fuss these days than foreign ownership of American businesses. European and Japanese companies are elbowing their way into manufacturing, retailing and other fields, and they are capturing profits that otherwise would have made Americans wealthy. Or so goes one popular theme in the debate. The problem with this theme is that foreign operations here are not showing much profit.

title: Quality Book Publishing Shifts to Small Presses;   Who Gets Free Ride?
description: To the Editor:

title: Daimler-Benz Sued by G.E.
description: The General Electric Company has filed a $1.15 billion lawsuit against Daimler-Benz of West Germany, contending that Daimler's new alliance with the United Technologies Corporation breached an agreement it already had with G.E. to develop jet engines.

title: One Buck Finally Stops
description: When John Poindexter told Congress ''the buck stops here with me'' in 1987, he rescued his President from investigators of the Iran-contra scandal. His testimony that he kept Mr. Reagan in the dark on key matters effectively froze the Congressional investigators in their tracks. As a jury's verdict now makes clear, the former national security adviser was also defining his own criminal role. He stands convicted, on compelling evidence, of five Iran-contra cover-up crimes.

title: Labor Overcame Differences To Hammer Out a UAL Bid
description: The agreement announced on Friday to buy the UAL Corporation for $4.38 billion was born in a series of informal meetings three months ago between the leaders of the machinists' and pilots' unions at the company, which is the parent of United Airlines.

title: VIGIL BY KRISHNAS PROTESTS AWARD
description: Members of the International Society of Krishna Consciousness have begun a 24-hour vigil outside the National Archives to publicize their contention that a multimillion-dollar damage award threatens their right to freedom of religion.

title: Marine Holding Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Quality Book Publishing Shifts to Small Presses
description: To the Editor:

title: Trimel Corp.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included the results of IWF Research since its acquisition in November 1989 and undisclosed tax credits and proceeds from the sale of assets. The company said earnings from operations was 20 cents a share in 1989. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Devils Find Series Offensive
description: The Devils and the Capitals are concerned because each team has given up a total of 10 goals in the first two games of their Patrick Division playoff series.

title: Classified Documents Not Left in Vietnam
description: To the Editor:

title: Pacers Bring End To Knicks' Streak
description: The Knicks did everything right in the closing seconds today but lost the game on a couple of bounces of the ball.

title: Review/Music;   Orpheus Chamber Orchestra
description: The highlight of the concert by the chamber orchestra Orpheus at Carnegie Hall on Saturday evening came early, with a rousing performance of the Overture to Rossini's ''Italiana in Algeri.'' For a group (41 players on this occasion) premised on the challenge of playing conductorless, technical hurdles must prove a constant seduction, and Orpheus sometimes runs the risk of simply pushing speed to the limit as a substitute for meaningful interpretation. Still, that approach works well enough for a composer given to technical display of his own in his overtures, and the Rossini, fast and furious, swept the listener in nicely.

title: Community Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Full year 1988 figures included a gain of $747,000 from the sale of Tennessee Bank & Trust Co.

title: Chorus of Coyotes Gets Closer to Cities
description: Sometimes, when Emily Crowfoot lies in bed at night, the stillness is broken by a forlorn chorus of coyotes.

title: Rexworks Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Reflected tax credits of $1,017,000 for the quarter and $994,000 for the year. c-Reflected tax credits of $542,000 for the quarter and $280,000 for the year.

title: Link Sought in North Sea Ferry Fires
description: Opening an arson investigation into the ferry fire on Saturday that killed as many as 135 people, the Norwegian police said today that they were checking for links between the predawn blaze and earlier North Sea ferry fires, at least one of which was deliberately set.

title: Faldo Repeats as Masters Winner
description: With a tempered-in-steel game so strong it broke one of the toughest competitors in golf, Nick Faldo today won his second consecutive Masters by beating Raymond Floyd on the second hole of a sudden-death playoff.

title: Designatronics Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Bridge
description: Two teams of New York City experts battled in the district final of the Grand National Teams at the Cavendish Club in Manhattan yesterday, breathing hard after surviving close semifinal struggles Saturday night. After 16 deals Debbie Zuckerberg of Flushing, Queens, and her team led by 5 imps against Saul Bronstein of Manhattan and his squad.

title: France is New Front in Battle Over Tobacco Ads
description: With the anti-smoking movement gathering momentum throughout the European Community, cigarette manufacturers, ad agencies and some of the French media have quickly mobilized to fight a Government plan to ban all tobacco advertising by 1993.

title: Arlene W. Stern, Writer, Is Married
description: Arlene Williams Stern of New York and Ralph Warner Stern of New York and East Hampton, L.I., were married yesterday at the Stanhope in New York by Rabbi Dennis Math.The couple were not previously related.

title: Money Isn't Everything in Greyhound Strike
description: With almost daily episodes of sniper fire, windshield smashing or threats to the substitute drivers, the Greyhound strike is about as nasty as strikes get these days, and it does not seem that it should be.

title: Dinkins Acts to Protect City's Upstate Water Supply System
description: New York City is taking measures to protect its upstate water supply system, which has given the city what Mayor David N. Dinkins describes as ''the champagne of municipal waters.''

title: Gooden's Return Perks Mets
description: The baseball season, one week late because of the labor lockout of the spring training camps, will open with flourishes this afternoon in Shea Stadium with Itzhak Perlman rendering the national anthem on his renowned violin, Commissioner Fay Vincent throwing out the first ball and the Mets and Pittsburgh Pirates treading on new sod and bouncing off newly padded outfield fences.

title: Foreman of the Jury In Poindexter's Trial Discusses the Case
description: The foreman of the jury that convicted John M. Poindexter on Saturday said today that ''there was simply an overwhelming set of facts in support of the prosecution's allegations.''

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of April 8:

title: No Quick Recovery For LaFontaine
description: The Islanders' chances to get back into their Stanley Cup playoff series with the Rangers were diminished today when the condition of Pat LaFontaine was listed as doubtful for Game 3 on Monday night at the Coliseum.

title: Further Staff Cuts At Home Builder
description: The General Development Corporation further trimmed its work force as the troubled real estate company considered expanding its Federal bankruptcy filing to include its subsidiaries. The company, which pleaded guilty last month to a scheme to sell overpriced homes, laid off 239 construction workers at some of its nine Florida communities. Last week, it laid off about 1,100 employees.

title: Male Violence the Real Cause of Bronx Fire;   Check Liquor Licenses
description: To the Editor:

title: Taiwan Concern Plans To Acquire Huffington
description: The national oil and gas company of Taiwan agreed today to acquire the Huffington Corporation in Houston, including a stake in large energy fields in Indonesia.

title: New Evidence for Climate Shifts
description: EXAMINATION of a core drilling extracted from the bottom of the North Atlantic has provided strong evidence that during the last ice age, and perhaps during all of them, there were drastic shifts of climate at intervals of about 1,000 years.

title: DEALS
description: BASEBALL

title: Canyon Resources Corp. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: A Ripping Little Yarn
description: To the Editor:

title: Schulman (A.) Inc.(O) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Marcos Said to Have Wept for Gift Of Skyscraper From Her Husband
description: A former Philippine bank official testified yesterday that he had been told by a confidante of Imelda Marcos that she had begged her husband in tears to buy a Manhattan skyscraper for her as a gift.

title: Business and Health;   Cutbacks Sought In Retiree Benefits
description: AS Eastern Airlines tries to trim health-care benefits promised over the years to thousands of retired workers, its moves are being watched closely by benefits executives, labor union officials and bankruptcy lawyers.

title: State May Prosecute
description: An Alabama state prosecutor said yesterday that a grand jury in Montgomery, Ala., has issued subpoenas in its investigation of a report that a relative of the Alabama linebacker Keith McCants may have received money from the agent Lance Luchnick.

title: Review/Music;   A Protege Conducts Messiaen in Brooklyn
description: In his handful of performances in New York, the conductor Kent Nagano has left the impression that he is happiest and most inventive in 20th-century music. He fortified that impression in a performance with the Brooklyn Philharmonic on Saturday evening at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Included on the program was a recent work by Olivier Messiaen, a Stravinsky classic and a Chopin concerto. The Chopin was decidedly the odd man out.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a conference on Charles de Gaulle referred incorrectly in some copies to the date of his return to power, to the conference organizers and to the meeting site. De Gaulle returned in 1958, not 1957. Besides Columbia and New York Universities, the organizers included Harvard; the sessions were at Columbia and N.Y.U., not the United Nations.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Leaders of 3 East Europe Nations Seek to Improve Ties With West
description: Leaders of Czechoslovakia, Poland and Hungary met here today with other European officials to discuss how best to integrate the three formerly Communist countries into the rest of Europe.

title: Divi Hotels reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included an unrealized loss on properties of $4,447,000 for both the quarter and 9 months, and the 9 months also included a partial net gain on the sale of properties of $2,420,000. c-Included a gain on the extinguishment of debt of $150,000, or 3 cents a share. The company said its loss was due to a decrease in recognized sales of timeshare units caused by delays in construction, the effects of hurricane Hugo on operations in St. Maarten and St. Croix and general softening of the tourism market in the Caribbean.

title: Not Just the Inner City: Well-to-Do Join Gangs
description: In suburban Hawthorne, social workers tell of the police officers who responded to a report of gang violence, only to let the instigators drive away in expensive cars, thinking they were a group of teen-agers on their way to the beach.

title: One Player Doesn't Make a Team
description: Michael Jordan scores 69 points against the Cleveland Cavaliers and his coach, Phil Jackson, said he would have preferred that Chicago's offense was more diverse and not so dependent on one player. Jackson is not alone in his thinking, as many coaches in the National Basketball Association are learning just how much difference one player can make between winning and losing.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Victor in Hungary Sees '45 as the Best of Times
description: Jozsef Antall, the next Prime Minister of Hungary, said today that the results from Sunday's elections show that a majority of the country's people are now ready for a center-right coalition, bonded together by anti-Communism and a shared faith in Hungarian and Christian values.

title: Greek Right Gains One-Seat Majority
description: The leader of the New Democracy party, which emerged victorious from the Greek election, won the backing of an independent rightist today to secure narrow parliamentary support for the country's first conservative government in nine years.

title: OBSCURE ENGINEER NOW THE FAVORITE TO LEAD PERUVIANS
description: Alberto Fujimori, an once little-known obscure agricultural engineer who campaigned in traditional Japanese robes, displaced the novelist Mario Vargas Llosa today as the favorite to become Peru's next President.

title: N.Y.C., True to Form
description: Last year, I fulfilled a long-standing dream by quitting a job at The New York Times to take a position at half the pay as a caseworker with New York City's Child Welfare Administration. I had a calling; it was that simple. I wanted to help.

title: Devils Take 2-1 Lead in Playoffs
description: The Devils took the lead tonight in their playoff series against the Washington Capitals with a 2-1 victory that employed effective team defense, the part of the game that brought them success in the last month of the regular season.

title: United Vermont Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The per share earnings reflected 5-for-3 stock split effected in the form of a dividend on April 4, 1989.

title: Corrections
description: A drawing with the Home Improvement column in The Home Section on Thursday, about repairs to a pressurized toilet flush valve, omitted the adjusting screw mentioned in the caption. As described in the text, the screw is on the pipe that joins the valve body to the water supply plumbing.

title: 1989 Claims Set a Record
description: Natural and man-made disasters made 1989 a ''year of catastrophes'' for insurers, forcing them to pay record claims, according to a study published last week.

title: Audiovox Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss

title: Bridge
description: The final of the district Grand National Team Championship, played on Sunday at the Cavendish Club in Manhattan, proved less exciting than the semifinals. The team headed by Debbie Zuckerberg of Flushing, Queens, which had survived a playoff to win on Saturday night, led throughout and won by 101 imps against a squad led by Saul Bronstein of Manhattan.

title: KEY RATES
Designing an SST: Noise, Sonic Booms and the Ozone Layer
description: AS the United States quietly pursues a new effort to develop a plane to carry passengers over long distances at twice the speed of sound or faster, it is focusing unusual attention on environmental problems that could ground the plane before it takes off.

title: Ex-Morgan Executive To Join CS First Boston
description: Archibald Cox Jr., a former chief executive of Morgan Stanley International, will join CS First Boston in New York as a member of senior management, effective May 1, First Boston said yesterday.

title: U.S. Bishops Are Highly Critical Of Vatican Proposal on Teaching
description: A committee of Roman Catholic bishops in the United States has issued a report highly critical of a text proposed by the Vatican as a guide for church teaching worldwide.

title: Revenge or Reconciliation?
description: ''If there is a general amnesty and it brings democracy and peace to our country,'' Albie Sachs said, ''I would be thrilled. Even if the amnesty extends to the people who tried to kill me.''

title: Fans' Lungs Outlast Mets' Arms
description: Spring training continues at regular-season prices. The way it looks right now, the Mets' fans are working themselves into midseason form a lot faster than some of the players.

title: 9 Fewer Rigs Working
description: The number of working American oil and natural gas rigs declined last week by 9, to a total of 937, Baker Hughes Inc. said today. The rig count showed a modest decrease after posting a gain of 53 rigs the previous week. A year ago, 778 rigs were working. Baker Hughes's rig count, the industry index of drilling activity, reflects the number of rigs actively exploring for oil and gas as of last Friday, not the number of producing wells.

title: Vikings Drop Kramer
description: Tommy Kramer, ranked either first or second in every major passing category for the Minnesota Vikings, was released by the team at his request yesterday. Kramer said General Manager Mike Lynn told him that he probably would be no better than the team's third-string quarterback next season. Kramer said in a statement that he hoped to sign with another team. (AP)

title: KREMLIN HESITATES AS DEADLINE FALLS FOR ECONOMIC PLAN
description: On the day he was to submit a package of ''radical'' economic proposals to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Deputy Prime Minister in charge of the program was still talking today of ''drafts'' and ''possible alternatives,'' not a clear plan of attack against what he acknowledged is a severe crisis.

title: Space Shuttle Is Ready For Liftoff
description: The space shuttle Discovery underwent final preparations today and was declared ready for its scheduled launching Tuesday morning to haul the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope into orbit.

title: 2 Killed by Train on Bridge
description: Two fishermen caught on a railroad bridge by an oncoming freight train were struck and killed Sunday when they tried to outrun it, officials said. The men were struck 60 feet from the east end of the trestle, said Vicki DeGeus, chief deputy coroner of Canyon County.

title: False Fears About Japanese Stocks
description: Tokyo's financial markets are reeling. Since the beginning of the year, Japanese stocks have dropped almost 30 percent, the yen about 10 percent. Worried that the chaos would spread, the finance ministers of the U.S. and six other industrialized powers, meeting in Paris last weekend, put the issue at the top of their agenda.

title: Of Size, Power and Longevity: New Solutions for Laptops
description: WHEN it comes to portable computers, some people are willing to sacrifice power to get the smallest size possible, while others are willing to sacrifice smallness to get the most power possible. Many people would prefer not to sacrifice anything, however, and so several computer makers have developed battery-powered portables that use the Intel 386SX microprocessor.

title: Pepsico Signs Soviet Deal
description: Pepsico Inc. signed a $3 billion agreement yesterday, as scheduled, with the Soviet Union to barter Pepsi-Cola for ships and vodka.

title: Books of The Times;   A Triple-A Hero: Ambitious, Arrogant and Awful
description: Titmuss Regained

title: Vilnius to Moscow:
description: LEAD: Although I have yet to set foot on Lithuanian soil, I spoke its language before I spoke English.

title: 2 Rival Computer Groups Break Off Talks on Merger
description: Two rival computer-industry groups trying to set software standards said today that they had broken off merger talks.

title: John Henry Faulk, 76, Dies; Humorist Who Challenged Blacklist
description: John Henry Faulk, a Southern humorist and raconteur whose successful libel suit against Aware Inc. in 1962 broke the stranglehold of McCarthy-era blacklisters on the entertainment industry, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Austin, Tex. He was 76 years old.

title: CHRONICLE
description: In 1968 CAROLYN COCHRAN CLARK graduated from the Harvard Law School, 15 years after the first woman was admitted.
