In 1977 she became the first woman to become a partner at the prestigious Manhattan law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy. Last Saturday she added another first, as she became the first woman elected to the 104-year-old Harvard Law School Association, an alumni group, in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Male Violence the Real Cause of Bronx Fire
description: To the Editor:

title: Norton Hurt In Crash Against Endboards
description: For the Islanders, the scene was familiar and frightening: one of their players flat on his back, medical personnel dashing onto the ice, players on the bench standing in concern.

title: Dr. Howard D. Abramowitz, 59; Fought Army's Discharge Policy
description: Dr. Howard D. Abramowitz, a sociology professor who in the 1950's sued to overturn an Army policy of giving draftees less than honorable discharges because of their political activities before induction, died of lung cancer yesterday at his home in Pittsfield, Mass. He was 59 years old.

title: Accounts
description: * Puerto Vallarta Tourism Board, to Grey Advertising, for the United States and Canada, with a budget of $6 million.

title: Roadway Services Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 24
Hillcrest Resources reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: b-Net income The company said the 1989 loss results from a $235,000 writedown of a long-term investment while 1988 earnings included a one-time gain on the redemption of minority interest of $400,000. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Drug for Shock From Infection Advances
description: A new treatment can significantly reduce the death rate of patients who go into shock from bacterial infections, potentially saving tens of thousands of lives each year, a research report to be released this week shows.

title: Sallie Mae Prices Floating Notes
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, priced $500 million in short-term floating-rate notes yesterday through a regular selling group led by the Government-sponsored private corporation.

title: Exercise and Cancer
description: Energetic rats appear to be more resistant to cancer-causing agents than sedentary rats, preliminary laboratory studies show.

title: Haruoki Inoue, Garden Designer, 61
description: Haruoki Inoue, a designer and builder of Japanese gardens on scores of estates in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, died of pancreatic cancer on Sunday at his home in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I. He was 61 years old.

title: Treasury Prices Dip in Slow Day
description: Prices of Treasury securities dipped in lethargic trading yesterday, as credit market participants chose to ignore potentially favorable developments in other markets.

title: Abbott Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Industrial Nations to Create Bank to Aid Eastern Europe
description: After four months of hard bargaining, the United States, Japan and the European Community reached broad agreement here today on the creation of a regional development bank to help Eastern Europe's new democracies make the transition to market-oriented economies.

title: Ford to Switch British Investment
description: The Ford Motor Company said it would switch an investment of $:225 million, or $369 million, planned for British plants to West Germany, partly because of unreliable supplies from the British factories. The American car giant's British unit said it had made the decision to move the investment from factories in South Wales to Ford's Cologne plant after evaluating the company's manufacturing plans in Europe.

title: Cellular Products reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Frederick's of Hollywood reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
First Federal Savings of P.R.  reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Latest quarter included results of First Florida Savings Bank, acquired in April 1989, and First Truck Lease Corp., acquired in July 1989. Year-ago quarter results included a gain of $1,280,000 on the sale of part of the bank's holdings of Freddie Mac preferred stock.

title: Puns, Tales and Lunacy In Oxford Humor Book
description: ''I feel like a mastodon who has had a calf after 17 years, and now feels very empty and a little sad and unlikely to have another quite yet.''

title: BRIEFS
description: * AMRE Inc., Dallas, said a management group that owned about 56 percent of its shares had decided not to proceed with a $8.75-a-share bid for the remainder. The group said it was in AMRE's best interest to remain publicly held.

title: Bailout Cost Rise Is Seen
description: The Bush Administration conceded today that the bailout of the savings and loan industry would cost taxpayers more than previously estimated.

title: Prime Bancshares Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-There are no historical per share earnings or shares outstanding for periods prior to the bank's conversion from a mutual to a stock-owned corporation on July 26, 1989.

title: Insurers Liable on Asbestos
description: Insurance companies are liable for $960 million in damage and injury claims against Owens-Illinois Inc. arising from the use of its products containing asbestos, a New Jersey superior court has ruled.

title: Drexel's 'Junk Bond' Files Are Purchased by Salomon
description: Salomon Brothers Inc. said yesterday that it had bought the exclusive rights to important information on thousands of ''junk bonds'' underwritten by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., enabling Salomon to expand its own junk bond operations.

title: Belgians and Arabs Hold Talks in Beirut On Deal for Captives
description: The radical Palestinian group led by Abu Nidal began talks today with an official Belgian delegation on exchanging a Palestinian jailed in Brussels for four Belgians held by the group since 1987.

title: RTI Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Stake Technology reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $417,000 for the latest year and $807,000 for 1988. Results are in Canandian funds.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-9

title: Herman Jessor, 95, New York Architect For Co-op Buildings
description: Herman J. Jessor, an architect who helped build more than 40,000 units of cooperative housing in New York City, died Sunday at the Jacob Perlow Hospice of Beth Israel Hospital. He was 95 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: By Design;   The Look of Leggings
description: Watch out below! At last week's shows of the American fall collections, the leg looks were riveting, both on and off the runway. Sometimes it seemed as if every other model had her legs encased in opaque leggings.

title: Islanders Come From 3-1 Down To Defeat Rangers in Overtime
description: Brent Sutter scored his second power play goal of the game after 59 seconds of the second overtime to give the Islanders a 4-3 victory over the Rangers tonight in a Stanley Cup playoff game that lasted for more than four hours and included an impressive home-team comeback, occasional brawling in the stands and another serious injury to an Islander star.

title: Panama Journal;   Trafficking in People: Was It One More Racket?
description: No sooner do the doors of Panama's Department of Immigration and Naturalization open for business than the waiting room fills to overflowing with dozens of anxious Chinese, accompanied by lawyers or interpreters and talking nervously among themselves in Mandarin, Cantonese or Hakka.

title: Chess
description: The greatest players in the tradition of what might be termed the Belligerent Defense have always had the sort of defiance expressed by Samuel Reshevsky's laconic, ''What's he got?''

title: Jones Intercable Investors reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Jones Intercable Inc. is general partner of Jones Intercable Investors L.P. The company said share earnings represent units and are on a per class A and class B unit basis.

title: Consolidated Papers reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Jazz Festival Concentrates On Playing, Not Singing
description: The lineup for the JVC Jazz Festival, which is to be held from June 22 through July 1, was announced yesterday by the impresario George Wein for Festival Productions. This is the 35th year that the festival has been held; in 1972 it moved from Newport, R.I., to Manhattan, where it has been held ever since.

title: Stereotypes Of the Sexes Persisting In Therapy
description: PSYCHOTHERAPY and psychiatric diagnosis are still often used to enforce conventional standards of masculinity and femininity and sometimes to brand as mentally ill people who depart from the norm, several new studies show.

title: Bid to Prosecute Rushdie Is Rejected
description: England's High Court today rejected a Muslim group's request to prosecute Salman Rushdie and the publishers of his novel ''The Satanic Verses'' on charges of blasphemy and seditious libel.

title: Silicon Valley Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Scorned Thalidomide Raises New Hopes
description: THALIDOMIDE, the notorious tranquilizer that was pulled from the market when women who took it gave birth to severely deformed infants, is finding new life. Researchers have discovered that it is a spectacularly effective agent for combatting rejection of foreign tissue and for alleviating the symptoms of several diseases in which the immune system turns against the body.

title: National Bancorp of Alaska reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Per share earnings reflected 33 1/3 percent stock dividend payable May 4.

title: The Questions of Summer
description: Baseball arrived yesterday, bringing joy after all. For a moment there, during the 32-day lockout, it was touch and go whether the public would summon any real enthusiasm for the well-paid players and their well-fed bosses. But it took only one pitch at Shea - Gooden to Backman, a fastball down the middle - to settle the issue. Baseball's back, and not a moment too soon.

title: Kleinert's Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 3
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain from net operating loss carryforward of $33,000, or 2 cents a share.

title: Dow Rises 4.95 in 2d-Slowest Day of Year
description: Stocks rose slightly yesterday, and trading slowed to its second-lowest level of the year.

title: Passport Travel reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Washington at Work;   To Stay Ahead of History, How Fast Must Jackson Run? And for What?
description: The walls of the Rev. Jesse Jackson's office testify to a career on the cutting edge of history and to a man who sees that as his proper place.

title: Sarah Vaughan Is Eulogized in Church Where She Sang as a Child
description: Family members, musicians, friends and more than 1,000 admirers gathered today at Mount Zion Baptist Church here to bid farewell to Sarah Vaughan, the hometown girl who became one of the country's most beloved singers. Miss Vaughan, who died of lung cancer at the age of 66 on April 3 at her California home, had asked that her funeral be held at the church where she sang in the choir when she was 11 years old.

title: Consensus for Fall: Short Is Classy
description: In the end, it turned out not to be the kind of season that will unhinge cartoonists, editorial writers, taxi drivers and other astute observers of the fashion scene. It will, in fact, be reassuring to the women who wear the clothes. Reassuring, that is, if they can accept the basic concept of fall dressing: the exposed knee.

title: Suffolk Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Leary's Varied Path Leads to Big Opening
description: There have been so many stops along the way that Tim Leary doesn't seem to mind them anymore. In a career that is now in its sixth season, he has spent time in New York, Milwaukee, Los Angeles, Cincinnati and New York again, his life looking more like a traveling show than like the life of, say, an insurance salesman.

title: Southern Union Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $2,298,000 for the quarter and $4,298,000 for the year. The share earnings reflected the effect of payment of preferred stock dividends.

title: Allstate Sues to Block New Jersey Law
description: The Allstate Insurance Companies asked a Federal District Court today to stop Gov. Jim Florio from trying to punish the insurer for its opposition to New Jersey's new automobile insurance law, which would charge the insurance industry more than $1.3 billion.

title: New Europe: The Armies;   As Germany Reunites, East and West Seek A System for Future Security on Continent
description: If current thinking prevails, a year from now a NATO country might be paying Soviet troops to stay on its soil alongside American forces.

title: Masters Provides A Cruel Reminder
description: Like Greg Norman's misfortune at the hands of Larry Mize and his wedge in 1987 or Scott Hoch's tragic miss from 2 feet in 1989, Ray Floyd's stomach-wrenching loss at the 54th Masters was the latest proof that golf is the cruelest of games.

title: Albany Budget Talks Stall Over Environmental Bond Issue
description: Negotiations over the largest environmental bond act in the state's history have hit new obstacles, officials here said today. They cited disagreements over how the money would be spent and an insistence by some lawmakers on a veto power over specific land purchases.

title: Dream, Yes, but Restore Rights
description: Just as President Bush was telling a Washington audience that he dreamed of the day when a black would occupy the White House, his Attorney General and press spokesman were threatening a veto of a civil rights bill now ready for Senate action. These late and lame threats are what passes for civil rights policy in the Bush Administration. The wobble is worse because it is profoundly misguided about a careful bill.

title: H.W. Kaufman Financial reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Mercantile Bankshares reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Glendale Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Thespian Doings In Style
description: It was a nice surprise: a benefit party at Bloomingdale's that was relaxed and drew lots of people but wasn't uncomfortably crowded.

title: Softech Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 23
Leniency Due as 5 Whites Plead Guilty in Racial Attack in Queens
description: Five white men pleaded guilty yesterday to assault or riot charges stemming from what the authorities said was a racial attack on a group of black people last July 4 in Rosedale, Queens.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Muslim Area of China Is Reported in Ferment
description: Ethnic disturbances have taken place recently in Muslim areas on China's far western frontier, a Western diplomat said today.

title: Saks Grows by a Third on 5th
description: At 10 o'clock yesterday morning, shoppers at Saks Fifth Avenue suddenly had 110,000 more square feet to browse through. The store opened five floors of its new tower, which is east of the main store, between 49th and 50th Streets.

title: CVB Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The year-ago per share earnings and shares outstanding were adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in November 1989.

title: BayBanks Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Net income

title: New Iran-Contra Prosecution Is Being Considered
description: Prosecutors in the Iran-contra affair are assessing leads from the trials of John M. Poindexter and Oliver L. North to decide whether they should try to find out if other officials of the Reagan Administration concealed their knowledge of the affair from Congress.

title: Soviet Oil Strike Delayed
description: Workers in the Soviet Union's largest oil field have postponed until late April a planned strike over living conditions and improvements to the industry, a trade union leader said today. The leader, Nikolai Trifonov, who represents 700,000 oil workers in Tyumen, western Siberia, said his union had decided not to begin the strike on Sunday although they had not yet received a government response to their demands. He said union leaders would confer later this month on the possibility of calling a strike around April 20 if they received no satisfactory response from the authorities.

title: First National Bancorp (Ga.) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Mega Group reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Share earnings not available; company changed from a fiscal year to a calendar year reporting schedule.

title: Chicago Journal;   Memories Of a Park To Outlive Its Bricks
description: From her seat in Section 131, not far from the White Sox dugout, Billie Burke scanned Comiskey Park today, and slowly counted out the memories. ''That's where my husband and I sat in 1945, on our honeymoon,'' she said, gesturing toward the lower deck, closer to home plate. ''It was a doubleheader with the Yankees.''

title: Cellular Information Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Article 628090 -- No Title
description: It was not quite 4 o'clock when Don Mattingly pulled on his sport coat and began walking toward the Yankee clubhouse door and the news conference in which he would be declared the richest player in the game. One by one, teammates shook his hand and offered their congratulations.

title: Advanced Medical Technoloies reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said it became operational in March 1989 when it acquired Fidata Corp. and Controlled Therapeutics Corp.; on April 2, 1990, the company announced its purchase of Imed, an infusion pump company, from Fischer Scientific Group. The company also said that on March 29, it received net proceeds of $3.8 million from settlement of certain claims of its Fidata subsidiary in connection with its action against Lion Capital.

title: Lincoln Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Mets Open With a Big Thud, Losing by 12-3
description: The baseball season finally opened yesterday, one week late because of the 32-day labor lockout of spring training, and the Mets opened it with glitter and glitz before a sellout crowd of 47,919 fans in Shea Stadium. But, except for Itzhak Perlman, who rendered the national anthem on his renowned violin, there was very little virtuoso playing in the ball park on this shining April afternoon.

title: Leslie Combs, Horse Owner, Is Dead at 88
description: Leslie Combs 2d, the founder of Spendthrift Farm and a leading owner and breeder of thoroughbred horses, died of cancer Saturday at the University of Kentucky Medical Center in Lexington, Ky. He was 88 years old.

title: Bush Picking the Kind of Judges Reagan Favored
description: Faced with the opportunity to name dozens of Federal judges, President Bush is quietly but steadily continuing to fill the nation's courts with judges expected to construe laws narrowly, side more frequently with the police and defer to Congress, according to a wide range of monitoring groups and Bush Administration officials.

title: Myers Opposes Needle Projects To Curb AIDS
description: New York City's new Health Commissioner said yesterday that he opposes many of the strategies proposed to curb AIDS infection among drug addicts.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES

title: Market Place;   London Is Trying To Keep Its Lead
description: THESE are nervous times for the London International Stock Exchange. The exchange's computerized trading system is one of the most advanced in the world. But officials there are deeply worried about competition from other markets in Europe and about investors' ability to bypass the exchange and trade among themselves -and their tendency to do so because of the exchange's cumbersome and costly settlement operation.

title: Industrial Acoustics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CHRONICLE
description: In the heady upper reaches of Government, attention must be paid to the most sensitive diplomatic issues, like who throws out the first ball at a baseball game between American and Canadian teams. The problem has been resolved for PRESIDENT BUSH, a former Yale first baseman who is now the First Southpaw, as the Toronto Blue Jays and the Texas Rangers play their American League opener in Toronto tonight.

title: Dow Jones & Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included an after-tax gain of $164.1 million, or $1.63 a share, from the sale of an investment in a cable- system operator.

title: Officials Say Deaths In Danish Ferry Fire Could Rise Past 176
description: The bodies of victims of the North Sea ferry fire began arriving here today for identification as the Norwegian police said the death toll could rise to more than 176.

title: EXXON IS DENYING GUILT IN OIL SPILL
description: Exxon and its shipping subsidiary pleaded not guilty in Federal District Court today to criminal charges stemming from the nation's worst oil spill.

title: Another Top Officer Resigns at Shearson
description: Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., the Wall Street firm that recently announced a major restructuring in response to a serious contraction in its business, has lost another top executive.

title: Wonder Of Metness: Day at Shea
description: Finally, it was time for what Robert Derbabian calls ''the wonder of Metness.''

title: NEC Application For Sale to China
description: The NEC Corporation said it would apply to Cocom for permission to export a work station to China as part of a contract to develop software there. The Paris-based Coordinating Committee for Multilateral Export Controls oversees exports of high technology from the West and Japan to Communist nations.

title: George Strawbridge, 80, a Leader Of Philadelphia Stockbrokerage
description: George Strawbridge Sr., a stockbroker, suffered a heart attack on April 3 at a business meeting at the Union League in Philadelphia and was pronounced dead at Thomas Jefferson Hospital there. He was 80 years old.

title: Time Warner Will Help Pathe-MGM/UA Deal
description: Time Warner Inc., evidently eager to insure it has a substantial library of films, announced yesterday that it has an important role in the negotiations for the sale of the MGM/UA Communications Company to the Pathe Communications Corporation.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about Browning-Ferris Industries' discontinuation of a hazardous-waste operation misidentified the company that pleaded guilty to violation of Ohio's environmental laws. It was a subsidiary, Cecos Internation= al, not Browning-Ferris itself.

title: Charter Power Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss and the year included a loss of $2,700,000 from a cumulative effect on prior periods of an accounting change. Year-ago results are reclassified for comparative purposes.

title: Taylor Devices Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Savings Chief Is Sworn In
description: T. Timothy Ryan Jr. was sworn in today as director of the Office of Thrift Supervision, formally ending a period of legal uncertainty that had threatened to halt the Government's huge bailout program for savings and loan associations.

title: Iraq, in Retaliation, Ousts an American Envoy
description: Iraq announced today that it was expelling an American diplomat in retaliation for the United States' expulsion last week of a United Nations-based Iraqi diplomat linked to a plot to kill opponents of President Saddam Hussein's Government.

title: Melcor Developments reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Cutting Blood Pressure Reduces Heart Risk
description: FOR the first time, researchers have found evidence that reducing blood pressure reduces the risk of heart disease.

title: Q&A
description: Orange Juice

title: Immigration Raids on Bodegas Hit a Nerve in Washington Heights
description: Federal immigration raids on small groceries and other businesses in the predominatly Hispanic Washington Heights section of Manhattan are seizing large sums of cash and illegal weapons and causing widespread concern among shopkeepers and customers.

title: Pamrapo Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share earnings are not presented because of the limited period of post-conversion operations. Pamrapo shares began trading Nov. 14, 1989, and previously it had been a mutual savings and loan.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of Easter music in Weekend on Friday misstated the program and time for an event tomorrow at Corpus Christi Church, 529 West 121st Street. The program, at 8 P.M., consists of a traditional service with Gregorian chants, psalms and lessons.

title: Sutton Top Candidate At Oklahoma State
description: Eddie Sutton, who resigned the Kentucky head-coaching post under pressure a year ago, appears to be heading home, to Oklahoma State where he played and started coaching. The regents governing the school scheduled a special meeting for tomorrow to hear the president of the school, John Campbell, make a recommendation for a new coach. A news conference to announce the selection was scheduled for later in the day.

title: Pondering Transition At Backer
description: DEAN SCAROS was asked about a recent article in Advertising Age about the future of agencies whose influential leaders face retirement. ''That's one of the reasons I wanted to speak with you,'' said Mr. Scaros, the president of Backer Spielvogel Bates Inc.

title: A Huge Bomb Kills Four British Soldiers in Ulster
description: Four soldiers were killed in Northern Ireland today in a bomb attack on a two-vehicle British Army patrol about 30 miles south of Belfast, the police said.

title: BancTexas Group Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The amounts included the operating results of all of the company's subsidiaries, including BancTexas Dallas N.A., for the entire year. The company's results for the year included previously announced losses as well as adjustments for two events which have occurred subsequent to the fiscal year-end but have an effect on the 1989 financial statements, the disposition of BancTexas Dallas by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. and the entry of a judgment against BancTexas Group by a Dallas court. The failure of BancTexas Dallas and the F.D.I.C.'s transfer of its assets and liabilities are reflected, in accordance with applicable accounting principles, in BancTexas Group's financial statements as if those events had occurred prior to Dec. 31, 1989. BancTexas Group also recognized in the latest fourth quarter a loss of about $2.8 million as a result of a judgment rendered on March 16, 1990 in favor of Bear, Stearns & Co., in a lawsuit which had been pending since 1987.

title: On Horse Racing;   Risky Idolatry at Aqu: SA and GP and Etc.
description: Three days ago at Aqueduct, New Yorkers bet nearly half a million dollars on a colt named Burnt Hills, who finished third as the 8-5 favorite in the $306,000 Gotham Stakes. It was money sacrificed in the worship of a false idol.

title: Grumman in Talks On Japanese Deal
description: The Grumman Corporation, the aerospace company in Bethpage, L.I., that also links supercomputers in large networks, said it had started talks with Japanese supercomputer makers to bring the Japanese machines to America. Political opposition had blocked nearly all sales in the United States of Japanese supercomputers, used mainly in large research projects to design weapons, aircraft and cars. Last week, Tokyo agreed to open its markets to American-made supercomputers.

title: CBS Television Cancels 'The Pat Sajak Show'
description: CBS canceled ''The Pat Sajak Show'' yesterday and announced a plan to replace the late-night talk show temporarily with action-adventure movies. Rod Perth, the CBS vice president for late-night programming, said the network was developing original programming for introduction in the fall.

title: Associated Communications reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Amnesty at the Point of a Gun Isn't Genuine
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Weighs Trust Action
description: The Justice Department is weighing antitrust action against the American subsidiaries of foreign companies engaged in bid-rigging and other activities that hurt American exporters, James F. Rill, an Assistant Attorney General, said today.

title: Chip Index Shows Gains
description: The semiconductor industry's leading indicator showed continued strength in March, as United States semiconductor orders and shipments increased, a trade group reported today.

title: Gorbachev's Line on Lithuania Grows Stricter but Less Specific
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and his new presidential council decided today to take unspecified ''additional economic, political and other measures'' against Lithuania after rejecting the rebel republic's latest attempt to explain its declaration of independence.

title: Kirschner Medical Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $13,207,000 for the quarter and $14,845,000 for the year. c-Net income and after losses from discontinued operations of $603,000 and $1,205,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said the latest year's results reflect the restructuring of the company including the treatment of the chic surgical tables and light business as a discontinued operation.

title: 15 Nations Seek Policy
description: A group of 15 developing nations wants to set a common policy on world debt and trade that could serve as the basis for talks with industrialized countries, Malaysia's Foreign Minister said today. The group consists of Algeria, Argentina, Brazil, Egypt, India, Indonesia, Jamaica, Malaysia, Mexico, Nigeria, Peru, Senegal, Venezuela, Yugoslavia and Zimbabwe. The Foreign Minister, Abu Hassan Omar, said representatives of the 15 countries will meet here June 1 to try to reach agreement on key economic issues.

title: PATTERNS
description: 'Nothing Revolutionary'

title: Hiding in Uniform; Homosexuals in the Military;   For Gay Soldiers and Sailors, Lives of Secrecy and Despair
description: Barred from military service by Defense Department regulations and threatened with investigation, interrogation and discharge, gay men and lesbians in the Armed Forces lead desperate, furtive lives reminiscent of those led by homosexuals throughout the country a generation ago.

title: Compudyne reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $877,000 for the quarter and $1,150,000 for the year. c-Included losses from discontinued operations of $704,000 and $1,225,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Rocky Start for Gooden With Signs for Hope
description: When the 1990 baseball season started yesterday, it was, in terms of the calendar, a week late because of the owners' lockout of the players. For the Mets' Dwight Gooden, the season started perhaps a week too soon in terms of preparedness.

title: A Swift and Hard Fall for Brazil
description: Three weeks after Brazil's new President ordered a radical program to contain rampant inflation, a recession is surging through Latin America's largest economy.

title: INSIDE
description: Greek Right Gains Majority

title: Light in El Salvador
description: Peace talks are an old, sad story in El Salvador. But there's a new ingredient in the forthcoming round between the Salvadoran Government and its guerrilla adversaries. The talks will be mediated directly by the shrewd, careful United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar. He is not addicted to lost causes. His involvement is also important because both sides are agreed on U.N. verification of a truce.

title: MCI to Acquire Telecom USA
description: The MCI Communications Corporation, the nation's second-largest provider of long-distance telephone services, announced a $1.25 billion agreement yesterday to buy Telecom USA Inc., the No. 4 company.

title: I.B.M. Said to Aid Project On Computers and Writing
description: The International Business Machines Corporation is reported to be a major supporter of the Go Corporation, a new company in Foster City, Calif, that is working on a portable computer that recognizes handwriting.

title: Computer Data Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Latest quarter and 9 months share earnings included 5 cents a share from interest on tax refunds.

title: New Plastic in Heinz Bottles To Make Recycling Easier
description: Responding to consumer pressure for more environmentally friendly packaging, the H. J. Heinz Company said yesterday that it would replace its plastic ketchup bottle with another type of plastic that it said was much more likely to be recycled.

title: Report on OPEC Production Sends Oil Prices Skidding
description: Crude oil prices plunged yesterday, largely on a report that OPEC's production had soared to its highest level since 1981. Global demand for oil has also been declining because of the uncommonly mild winter in the Northern Hemisphere as well as softening in the economies of industrial countries.

title: Tee-Comm Electronics reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,663,391 for the latest year and $2,441,861 for 1988. The losses from discontinued operations resulted from the decision to close its satellite equipment manufacturing plant and tool and die operations in Canada and a move to sell Tee-Comm products through exclusive distribution rather than company-owned distribution in the U.S. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Wendell G. Earle, Marketing Professor, 66
description: Wendell G. Earle, professor emeritus of marketing at Cornell University, died of cancer Tuesday at Tompkins Community Hospital in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 66 years old and lived in Ithaca.

title: Honesty's Small Victory In Councils of Beijing
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Theater;   The Personal Side of Life in Harlem
description: Street people, some distraught, others with dreams intact, populate Gus Edwards's ''Lifetimes,'' a gentle anthology of monologues about life today in Harlem. The view is personal rather than political. The wistfulness of Mr. Edwards's play (presented by the Negro Ensemble Company at Theater Four) is represented by a married woman named Mavis who returns to Harlem to look for the sanctuary of a distantly remembered beauty salon and stays to drift into a love affair that becomes increasingly less casual.

title: Church Burns as Renovation Nears End
description: A few hours after workers put the finishing touches on a new roof for the Church of the Holy Apostles yesterday, it caught fire, heavily damaging the Chelsea landmark and destroying several irreplaceable stained-glass windows, fire and church officials said.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on March 27 described a conflict among homosexuals over the practice of unmasking prominent people who are said to be secretly gay. The article included comments from Nan Hunter, director of the Lesbian and Gay Rights Project of the American Civil Liberties Union. It then quoted the A.C.L.U.'s executive director, Ira Glasser, who said that his organization had no official position on the issue and that Ms. Hunter's views were her own.

title: Whalers Top Bruins
description: Dave Babych scored the tie-breaking goal 36 seconds into the third period and Pat Verbeek had two goals tonight as the Hartford Whalers beat Boston, 5-3, in Game 3 of their Adams Division semifinal series.

title: Four in Mississippi Join A Switch to the G.O.P.
description: Four Democratic state legislators announced today that they were switching to the Republican Party, earning them praise from President Bush.

title: CHRONICLE
description: New York University's fund-raising alumnus par excellence is LAURENCE A. TISCH, class of '42, who, when not occupied as chairman of N.Y.U.'s board, is the chief executive and largest stockholder of CBS Inc.

title: Star Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said that it restated the prior quarter and 9 months' results. The company also said that it has restated fiscal year 1989 results to a loss of $7,389,000, from a loss of $4,393,000.

title: Keating Links Regulators To Savings Industry Woes
description: Charles H. Keating Jr. testified today that the savings and loan crisis and the collapse of the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, which he had headed, resulted from a regulatory system that failed to anticipate the effects of deregulation in the early 1980's.

title: Global Resources reports earnings for Year to Mar 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Pick-6 Winner Sets Record
description: One bettor cashed the largest Pick-Six payoff in New York racing history yesterday when he was rewarded with $767,998 for selecting the winners of the third through eighth races at Aqueduct Race Track.

title: Red Sox Start Off Right By Defeating Tigers, 5-2
description: The new season looked just like the old one at Fenway Park: Wade Boggs got three hits, Roger Clemens won and the Detroit Tigers lost.

title: Soviet Union Hires Bechtel
description: The Soviet Union has hired Bechtel Group Inc. to help convert a Government research center near Moscow into a Silicon Valley-style center for commercializing technologies.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Economic and Social Council

title: CHRONICLE
description: On his 64th birthday yesterday, HUGH HEFNER, founder of Playboy magazine and guru of the sexual revolution, became a father as his 27-year-old wife, KIMBERLY CONRAD, gave birth to a boy. MARSTON GLENN HEFNER, 8 pounds, 13 ounces, was born at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles, said a Playboy spokesman, Bill Farley.

title: Grease Monkey Holding reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said comparable results were not available; the company recently changed its year-end to Dec. 31 from Nov. 30.

title: Budgeting What You Already Have
description: TEN or so years ago, the most powerful personal computers had 64 kilobytes of memory, the equivalent of 64,000 characters. Not all of that was available for the user's words and numbers, though; most of the instructions for manipulating those words and numbers had to be stored in the same space. Still, the memory seemed ample.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Upheaval in the East;   From a Harvest of Grief, Georgia Culls Its Pride
description: The Georgian way of grief has always included wine and tears.

title: New Phillips Fuel
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company has joined a growing number of oil companies introducing a reformulated gasoline intended to be less harmful to the environment than existing grades. Phillips's reformulated fuel, blended to reduce certain hydrocarbon emissions, will be tested in St. Louis, one of more than 100 cities that fall below the Environmental Protection Agency's minimum standards for air quality, the company said. The reformulated gasoline is blended to reduce the amounts of certain hydrocarbons, like aromatics, benzene and olefins, that react with the atmosphere and produce ozone, a main component of smog.

title: Turner Deal With Tribune
description: The Tribune Broadcasting Company will discontinue its nightly ''USA Tonight'' newscasts and use Cable News Network at six of its televison stations under an agreement announced today with Turner Broadcasting System Inc.

title: First Virginia Banks reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Bonuses Slide at Ford; Those at G.M. Just Slip
description: The country's two largest auto companies released their annual proxy statements today and both showed declines in executive bonuses for 1989, although at markedly different levels.

title: Royce Labs reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Upheaval in the East;   East Germans Form 'Grand Coalition'
description: East Germany's new political leaders reached agreement today on a ''grand coalition'' government whose major task will be to lead the nation to union with West Germany.

title: Santa Monica Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Hipotronics Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 3
The Human Side of Harlem Troupe's Crisis
description: Cheers and whistles filled City Center as the curtain fell after a recent performance by Dance Theater of Harlem for the city's public-school pupils. The children at City Center's Young People's Dance Series roared with laughter at the wry guide to the history and technique of ballet provided by Eddie J. Shellman, a principal dancer with the ballet company. They marveled at the height of the ballerinas' leg extensions and the men's leaps and at their daring one-handed lifts.

title: Greyhound Sues Union, Pointing to Violence
description: Greyhound Lines filed a $30 million civil lawsuit today against union officers representing striking drivers, alleging that violence in the five-week-old strike was an attempt to ''disrupt interstate travel by criminal means.''

title: Chairman Sees Gains for G.M.
description: The head of the General Motors Corporation said today that dramatic technological improvements would enable the auto maker to increase its United States and European market share despite intense Japanese competition.

title: The Red Grime Line
description: Along with the other problems of uniting Germany, there are mountains of garbage. Literally, garbage. During those years behind the wall, East Germany indulged in a sneaky form of cooperation with West Berlin: waste disposal.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The sun was shining. The grass was green. The sky was blue.''

title: Funnel, Don't Flood, Aid to Panama and Nicaragua
description: To the Editor:

title: Kelly Fights Charges
description: The lawyer for the Buffalo Bills quarterback, Jim Kelly, said yesterday that Kelly has no intention of offering a settlement to a woman in Buffalo who claims he threw a beer balloon that injurerd her mouth and is asking for $200,000 in damages.

title: AIDS Volunteers Deserve Praise Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Premier Financial Services reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Assad Tells Visiting Senators He Wants Better U.S. Ties
description: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria told a visiting delegation from the United States Senate today that his nation wants better relations with the United States and a peaceful and just settlement of the Arab-Israeli conflict.

title: Pinnacle Banc Group reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The per share earnings reflected 5-for-4 stock split effective Jan. 31, 1990.

title: RCA Sentences On U.S. Papers
description: Two RCA Corporation employees who pleaded guilty to obtaining and transporting classified Pentagon budget documents were sentenced on Friday to two years' imprisonment, with all but a few months suspended.

title: Power Surge Snarls Trains On L.I.R.R.
description: A power surge knocked out crucial signals and switches on two miles of bottleneck track in Queens yesterday and threw the Long Island Rail Road into turmoil on the first night of Passover, one of the busiest days of the year on the nation's largest commuter line.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in SportsMonday this week about television coverage of this baseball season misstated the availability of Sunday night Met and Yankee games on ESPN for viewers in the New York area. They will be available, not blacked out.

title: Provident Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Weak Effort to Aid Yen;   The Group of Seven Shows Less Urgency When the Dollar Is Not Directly Involved
description: The United States and its allies in the Group of Seven industrial nations are making only a modest defense of the weakened Japanese yen, and this means the effort may have little impact.

title: Granada Biosciences Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the decling net loss was due to a $16 million reduction in provisions for amortization and impairment expense of its purebred cattle herd and a $2.9 million combined reduction in selling and administrative costs and research and development costs.

title: Dow Jones Net Tumbled By 87.6% in First Quarter
description: Dow Jones & Company, the publisher of The Wall Street Journal, said yesterday that losses from forming a currency trading service and profit declines at its community newspapers group sharply reduced first-quarter earnings.

title: Tandem Acquires A Software Maker
description: Tandem Computers Inc. acquired the Array Technology Corporation, a private company in Boulder, Colo., for an undisclosed amount. Array produces software and hardware for memory systems using a computer storage technology called redundant arrays of inexpensive disks, or RAID.

title: Shareholders Propose Plan For Eastern
description: The preferred shareholders of Eastern Airlines submitted a reorganization plan to the bankruptcy court yesterday aimed at keeping the airline flying and averting a liquidation.

title: No Headline
description: Hundreds of thousands of Nepalese, their faces smeared with vermilion powder, waved the red flags of the Nepalese Congress Party and the Communist Party today as they flooded the streets of this city and others in an explosion of joy at the end of a nearly three-decade ban on political activity.

title: Careers;   Managing A Diverse Work Force
description: SENSITIVITY training for managers has been around for years, but it has recently evolved into something more timely - training in the management of a diverse work force.

title: Outlay Rise Abroad Seen
description: United States companies plan to increase their overseas capital spending by 13 percent this year, up substantially from a 2 percent increase projected six months ago, the Government said last week. The Commerce Department said a survey in December showed that foreign affiliates of United States companies planned to spend $54.9 billion, after increases of 14 percent in 1989 and 24 percent in 1988. Manufacturing affiliates said they planned a 17 percent increase, to $27.4 billion, in 1990, up from 2 percent in the survey that was conducted last June.

title: Review/Cabaret;   Dixie Carter As a Madcap Miss Scarlett
description: When Dixie Carter made her New York cabaret debut five years ago at Freddy's Supper Club, which has closed, she immediately established herself as one of the most vivid and endearing performers in a field already crowded with idiosyncratic personalities. The character she brought to the stage was an original for New York: a proper Southern woman with a streak of hellfire who almost kicks over the traces but never quite loses her dignity.

title: Lazare Kaplan International reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included extraordinary tax credits of $296,000, or 9 cents a share, for the quarter and $920,000, or 29 cents a share, for the 9 months. c-Included extraordinary tax credits of $35,000, or 1 cent a share, and $141,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Networked Picture Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Standard Microsystems reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss

title: For a Space Visionary, Persistence Nears Payoff
description: At 75, Dr. Lyman Spitzer Jr., professor emeritus of astrophysics at Princeton University, has a string of scientific accomplishments behind him. He had a leading role in the development of sonar in World War II and of in early concepts for controlled fusion energy.

title: County Bank reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit from repurchase of notes of $1,798,000.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Colt Industries, New York, a diversified manufacturing company, named Robert M. Snow president of its Chandler Evans Control Systems division. He replaces Karl F. Storrie, who remains a group president.

title: New York State Accuses 14 Lawyers of Income Tax Evasion
description: Baring its teeth in a continuing campaign to improve tax compliance by lawyers, the state announced today that it has charged 14 of them with failing to file personal income tax returns.

title: Amserv Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Pentagon Investment Made in Chip Company
description: The Defense Department, through its advanced research arm, has for the first time made what is essentially a venture capital investment in a young Silicon Valley company.

title: Medicore Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
ACC Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The company said year-ago revenues included revenues of $1,878,253 from discontinued operation.

title: As Gridlock Mounts, Region Buys More Cars
description: The number of motor vehicles registered in the New York metropolitan region has risen more than 25 percent since 1980, planners say, and some suburbs will soon approach the unenviable position of having as many vehicles as people.

title: The Daily News Terminates Contracts With 10 Unions
description: The Daily News, paving the way to put more pressure on its 10 unions, told them yesterday that it was terminating contracts that expired March 30.

title: Advanced Micro Expects Flat Sales
description: Advanced Micro Devices Inc. said it expects to report first-quarter revenues below expectations. The company said its sales would be flat compared with both the previous quarter and the comparable quarter last year, when it had revenues of $269.6 million. Advanced Micro said, however, that it expected higher earnings because of an extraordinary gain realized from a sale, leaseback and technology transfer transaction with the Sony Corporation. Shares in Advanced Micro closed today at $8.50, down 37.5 cents each, in New York Stock Exchange trading.

title: James G. E. Smith, 63, Social Anthropologist
description: Dr. James G. E. Smith, a social anthropologist and curator at the Museum of the American Indian-Heye Foundation, died of brain cancer on April 2 at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: Pacific Inland Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included $205,900 reversal of tax benefit from operating loss carryforward.

title: Sabine Royalty Trust reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Share earnings are in units.

title: Ford Recalling Aerostar Vans
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it was recalling about 101,000 Aerostar vans of the 1986 model year to install new seals between fuel tanks and the fuel tank filler pipes. A Ford official said fuel might seep between the seal and the fuel tank when the tank was full or nearly full, creating a risk of fire.

title: Premier Bancorp (La.) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Net loss

title: 3d Hispanic Network Seeks Viewers
description: The competition is heating up in the Hispanic television market. Galavision, the newest entrant, is threatening to steal viewers and advertising from Univision and Telemundo, the two struggling Spanish-language television networks.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Passover, alternate-side parking rules will be suspended in New York City today and tomorrow. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 2 about local controversies in Middletown, Conn., misstated the enrollment of Wesleyan University. There are 2,700 undergraduates and 150 graduate students.

title: Acquisition Of B.A.T. Is Set Back
description: California insurance regulators today delivered a severe setback to Sir James Goldsmith's $21 billion bid to acquire B.A.T. Industries by denying the proposed sale of Farmers Group Inc., the insurance subsidiary of B.A.T.

title: Delay Seen In Publicizing Spinal Drug
description: A public interest health group criticized the Government today for not sending detailed information about a promising new treatment for spinal cord injury to emergency rooms and trauma centers.

title: In Alchemists' Notes, Clues to Modern Chemistry
description: AN alchemist's illustration published more than four centuries ago shows a gray wolf devouring a king and then mounting a flaming pyre that consumes the wolf and restores the king to life.

title: JB's Restaurants reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 12
Benefit for Renovation At Theater for New City
description: Theater for the New City, an experimental theater company founded in 1971, will hold a benefit on April 18 at 7 P.M. to raise money to renovate its new $1.75 million performing-arts complex at First Avenue and 10th Street. The center, in the former First Avenue Retail Market building, will include four theaters ranging from 65 to 250 seats, an exhibition space, and a restaurant and cabaret. It is to open this fall.

title: Goldfarb Corp. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Latest year included the operating results and financing costs associated with the equity investment in Speedy Muffler King Inc., undertaken in September. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: BSD Medical reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income

title: Our Towns;   Allies of Nature Fight for Rabbits Amid the Refuse
description: As Louis Cardenas walked toward the creek, all around him high marshy foxtail grass swayed in the breeze and he could see the late afternoon sun peeking through. Sunday was one of the first fine days of spring. Mr. Cardenas reached the creek and whispered, ''Look, sofas.''

title: Judge Narrows Verdict In Jersey Family Murder
description: The judge presiding over the murder trial of John E. List will not allow the jury to consider manslaughter when it begins deliberating the fate of the 64-year-old defendant, who has admitted killing his wife, mother and three children in their Westfield house in 1971.

title: Ancient Japanese Classic Suddenly Turns Sexy
description: For more than 1,200 years, the anthology of poems known as the ''Collection of 10,000 Leaves'' has been studied and revered by Japanese as a storehouse of their nation's soul.

title: Why This Year Fashion's Thinking Green
description: To the Editor:

title: Sterivet Laboratories reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Morton Sunshine, 74; Directed Variety Clubs
description: Morton Sunshine, the former executive director of Variety Clubs International and a show-business impresario, died of cancer yesterday at the Hospice of Palm Beach County in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 74 years old.

title: A Hit Songwriter Is About to Become A Cabaret Performer
description: When Sheldon Harnick opens this evening at Rainbow and Stars, performing a four-decade retrospective of his songs, the veteran lyricist who has not had a new show on Broadway in 14 years will offer samplings from three recent works that have yet to find their way to the New York stage.

title: Doubts Arise on a Test To Detect Cancer Signs
description: Four years ago, a test that seemed to detect all forms of cancer from tiny blood samples appeared destined to revolutionize the way doctors screen people for the disease.

title: Planters Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Sacramental Wine: Lowest Profile of All
description: SACRAMENTAL wine may be the lowest-profile wine in the United States. Though drunk daily, primarily by Roman Catholics, Episcopalians and Lutherans, it is rarely discussed and almost never seen in bottles.

title: Disney Cites Survey on Theater Ads
description: The Walt Disney Company today defended its policy of banning commercials on movie screens before its pictures are shown by releasing a study that concludes that 90 percent of moviegoers do not want commercials in theaters.

title: F&M National Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Sunair Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
MICROWAVE COOKING
description: AN observer at any toy store or video arcade is privy to children's delight in pushing buttons. Increasingly, the buttons they like to push are those of the microwave oven.

title: Aegon Insurance Group reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in U.S. dollars; dollar amounts have been translated at the average rate of Dfl 2.12 equals $1.00.

title: Work Force Failing To Meet Math Needs
description: Although the fastest-growing occupations require a mathematical background, a new report contends that a growing number of people entering the work force will not have the required training.

title: Oce-van der Grinten NV reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The results are in U.S. dollars and have been converted from Dutch florins at Dfl 1.9105 equaled U.S. $1.00.

title: New England Bank
description: The Bank of New England Corporation said today that it would sell $665 million in assets of a subsidiary, New England Commercial Finance Corporation, to the National Bank of Canada for an undisclosed price. The move is part of an asset sales program at the bank, which reported $1.11 billion in losses in 1989, mostly because of bad real estate loans. The deal is expected to close by the end of April, and the assets are being sold at a premium, said Thomas Lavelle, a bank spokesman.

title: KLLM Transport Services reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 1
Celtics Top Nets, 112-96
description: A crowd of 17,515 showed up at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight for the last visit of the Boston Celtics, perhaps thinking that not much else disastrous could happen to the Nets. Then something did. Sam Bowie, the Nets' 7-foot-1-inch center, who has suffered broken legs three times in his career, left the game limping with a sore right foot in the third quarter and his status is now day to day.

title: Dinkins Asks U.S. To Halt Development of S.I. Naval Port
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins has asked the United States Defense Department to stop development of the Navy port that has brought one cruiser to Staten Island and may bring several other ships there.

title: Signs of Plywood Trouble
description: One of the first signs of degrading fire-retardant plywood is a darkening of the plywood's color from the normal light tan to a dark brown on the underside, or attic side, of the roofing.

title: New York to Return to Court to Contest Census Count Rules
description: A group of big cities and states, including New York and California, will return to a Federal court today, asking it to strike down the Commerce Department's guidelines for adjusting the 1990 census to compensate for expected undercounting of minorities and the poor.

title: Traders to Get Ethics Classes
description: More than a year after allegations of fraud in the Chicago futures markets, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange has ordered its 2,500 members to enroll in ethics classes.

title: Summit Savings Assn reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Johnson Returns to Devils' Lineup
description: A knee injury to Pat Conacher will force the Devils to break up their most consistent and effective line for perhaps the remainder of their playoff series with Washington.

title: Republic Bancorp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Eight Players Sue N.F.L.
description: In a long-expected new effort to establish the right of players whose contracts have expired to negotiate with any National Football League team, eight players filed an antitrust suit against the league and its 28 clubs yesterday. The suit accuses them of violating Federal antitrust laws by imposing a series of restrictions on the movement of players.

title: Arab Militants Release 3 After Qaddafi Intervenes
description: A Frenchwoman, her Belgian companion and their daughter were released in Beirut today, more than two years after being taken hostage by a Libyan-supported militant group as they cruised the Mediterranean on a pleasure boat.

title: Chronicle
description: WILLIAM G. McGOWAN, the chairman of the MCI Communications Corporation who had a heart transplant in 1987, was in fair condition yesterday at Presbyterian-University Hospital in Pittsburgh after undergoing exploratory chest surgery. An MCI spokesman, JOHN R. HOUSER, said the operation was unrelated to Mr. McGowan's heart, which he received in a transplant operation two years ago. Mr. Houser would not elaborate.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   WCRS Earnings Up In New Fiscal Year
description: The WCRS Group P.L.C. said yesterday that it earned $:40 million, or about $66 million, in pretax profit in 1989, up from $:24 million, or $40 million, in the 14 months before the end of 1988. The time periods are not identical because the company changed its fiscal year.

title: House Democrats Challenge Bush By Seeking to Reduce Aid to Zaire
description: In a challenge to the Bush Administration's Africa policy, House Democrats are moving to cut aid to Zaire to protest the reported corruption and human-rights violations of President Mobutu Sese Seko.

title: Portsmouth Bank Shares Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: There were no per share earnings in year-ago first quarter because the company went public in February 1988.

title: Hallador Petroleum reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1989 results included a writedown of $1,111,000 in the carrying value of the company's oil and gas properties attributable primarily to reduced development potential in a major property and significant declines in gas prices since January 1990.

title: Bank Yields Mixed in Week As a Rate Drop Is Expected
description: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts at commercial banks and savings institutions were mixed for the week ended yesterday.

title: GOVERNOR VETOES BILL ON ABORTION
description: As he had promised, Gov. Judd Gregg vetoed an abortion rights bill today only hours after it had reached his desk.

title: French Suspects Held in Basque Terror
description: A routine identity check on a highway near Seville has led to the arrest of a band of French terrorist suspects who reportedly carried out at least 33 killings over the last 12 years on behalf of the Spanish Basque separatist group E.T.A.

title: Ford in Australia
description: The Ford Motor Company of Australia, the country's biggest car maker and a subsidiary of the Ford Motor Company of the United States, said it planned to spend $1.2 billion (Australian), or $916 million in United States currency, in the next five years to improve its products and factories. The announcement came as the company said earnings had slid to $124.1 million (Australian) in 1989 from $126 million in 1988, despite a 16 percent increase in new car sales.

title: Arcus Inc.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
IP Timberlands Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Book Notes
description: Publishing waters have been roiled in recent days by a dispute between James Webb, a former Secretary of the Navy, and Prentice Hall, which published his first two novels.

title: American Locker Group reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,224,822. c-Net income and included income from discontinued operations of $80,712, or 6 cents a share. The company said that the sale of its furniture subsidiary, Signore Inc., resulted in an after-tax loss in 1989 of $1,704,000. This loss reflects the effects of the uncertainties arising from the environmental problems as well as the depressed margins realized by the subsidiary in recent years.

title: Student Loan Marketing Assn reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Dr. Allen Tanney, 79, Physician in Baseball
description: Dr. Allen D. Tanney, a physician who practiced as a consultant to manufacturers, hotels, a newspaper and several baseball teams, died of heart failure yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 79 years old and lived in Harrison, N.Y.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about homosexuals in the military misidentified the woman shown.

title: Interco Posts Quarterly Loss
description: Interco Inc., the maker of Converse footwear and Broyhill furniture, today reported a $23.3 million loss for the fourth quarter and a 50 percent drop in profits for the year.

title: Mitsui Bank Expansion
description: The Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank Ltd. announced plans yesterday to create a new company to specialize in interest-rate and currency swaps and options.

title: Lockheed Claims Victory Over Simmons
description: The Lockheed Corporation said today that it had successfully beaten back an attempt by the Dallas financier Harold C. Simmons to gain control of the company.

title: Gateway Bancorp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The company said where applicable, per share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted to reflect the 10 percent stock dividend declared on March 13.

title: Ames's Rocky Retailing Marriage
description: Ames Department Stores Inc. had visions of greatness when it acquired nearly 400 Zayre discount stores in October 1988. Overnight, Ames would be transformed from a little-known variety chain operating primarily in New England into the nation's fourth-largest discounter, after K Mart, Wal-Mart and Target. And Ames, which had steadily increased its sales and profits, would use its acclaimed management techniques to revive business at Zayre, which was sagging.

title: Chronicle
description: FRED ROGERS is celebrating the 35th anniversary of his television debut in ''Children's Corner,'' his first show before he became known nationally as the gentle host of ''Mister Rogers's Neighborhood.''

title: Lockheed Plans To Cut 500 Jobs
description: The Lockheed Corporation has confirmed that it will lay off 500 white-collar employees at its Marietta plant. The layoffs, which will come by the end of June, will include workers in engineering, finance and information systems, said Richard Martin, a spokesman for the Lockheed Aeronautical Systems Company-Georgia.

title: Gorbachev Envisioning Market Steps by Decree
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that he was prepared to use his new executive powers to speed the transition to a regulated market economy.

title: Dime Savings Bank of New York reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included extraordinary net operating loss carryforwards of $6,209,000, or 27 cents a share, for the latest quarter and $4,329,000, or 19 cents a share, for the year-earlier period.

title: Eight Sentenced In 1980 Protest At Nuclear Unit
description: In a case that seems to bridge the years between the antiwar turmoil of the 1960's and the current easing of the cold war, eight peace advocates were sentenced today for a 1980 protest in which they poured their blood on blueprints at a nuclear weapons plant.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Edible Easter Menagerie

title: Ruddock Recalls Some Good Advice
description: Michael Dokes can blame Rico Rossi for the loss he suffered Wednesday night at Madison Square Garden.

title: R. Dixon Herman, 78, Judge at Berrigan Trial
description: R. Dixon Herman, the Federal judge who oversaw the conspiracy trial of the Harrisburg Seven, died of a heart attack on Friday at Harrisburg Hospital. He was 78 years old.

title: Yevgeny Y. Savitsky, Soviet Flying Ace, 80
description: Yevgeny Y. Savitsky, a World War II flying ace who shot down 22 enemy planes in 216 missions against the Nazis over the Soviet Union, Poland and Germany, died on Friday after a long illness. He was 80 years old.

title: Volvo-Renault Link Advancing
description: The Swedish car maker Volvo A.B. said it planned to sell up to 5 billion crowns, or $820 million, of assets to finance its link with the state-owned French company Renault S.A. A spokesman, Hans Renstrom, said Volvo would probably sell part of its stock portfolio, which was valued at about 12.5 billion crowns, or $2.4 billion, at the end of 1989.

title: New York Budget Cuts Will Swell Ranks of Homeless on Streets;   Empty Days
description: To the Editor:

title: A.T.&T. Selling Computer Unit
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said it was selling a subsidiary that makes peripheral and communications equipment for I.B.M. mainframes.

title: Biogen Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Stocks Edge Upward as Dow Gains 9.01
description: Stocks prices rose slightly yesterday in dull trading. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 9.01 points to end the session at 2,731.08.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Structural Dynamics Reearch reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Japan Keeps Up the Big Spending To Maintain Its Industrial Might
description: At a time when some Americans are worrying about how much Japan is investing to buy real estate and companies from New York to Honolulu, the bigger concern for the United States may be how much Japan is continuing to invest on its industrial prowess at home.

title: West Mass Bankshares Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Rogers Is Suspended
description: George Rogers, the former running back and Heisman Trophy winner, was suspended yesterday from a two-month-old job at the University of South Carolina following his arrest on cocaine charges last Saturday.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Landowner Linked to D'Amato Gives In on Pipeline
description: A landowner in Dover, N.Y., who lobbied to have the route of a natural-gas pipeline moved off his empty field and angered his neighbors when a new route was planned for their front yards, has volunteered to take the pipeline back.

title: Soviet Wheat Purchase
description: The Soviet Union has bought an additional 125,000 metric tons of United States wheat at subsidized prices for delivery through mid-May, the Agriculture Department said today. The sale was the first since Jan. 19, when the Soviet Union's authority for buying subsidized wheat was virtually exhausted. A new allocation of one million tons was announced on Feb. 23. About 12,950 tons were left over from a previous allocation.

title: Prices Drop After Refcorp Auction
description: A second unsuccessful auction of 40-year bonds by the Resolution Funding Corporation pushed prices of Treasury securities lower in fairly thin trading yesterday.

title: Lessons
description: Do men get more for their money than women do when they slap down $50,000 to $100,000 for a college education? Based on her analysis of thousands of hours of college teaching, Catherine G. Krupnick says the answer is a resounding yes.

title: Officer Kills Teen-Age Boy In Teaneck
description: A 15-year-old youth who the police said was carrying a gun was shot to death by a Teaneck police officer near a school playground Tuesday evening, police officials said.

title: Smith (A.O.) Corp.(A) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Execufirst Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Net loss

title: 1 1/2 Tons of Cocaine Seized
description: Four Federal agents on patrol along the Mexican border on Monday followed a trail of footprints to a trailer, where they arrested three men and confiscated more than a ton and a half of cocaine, the Border Patrol said. The agents seized 3,192 pounds of cocaine near Naco, 100 miles southeast of Tucson, said Jacqui Parker, a spokeswoman for the Border Patrol. The case was turned over to the Drug Enforcement Administration, Ms. Parker said.

title: Falcons Have Designs On Illinois Quarterback
description: Unless a major trade opportunity arises, the Atlanta Falcons have decided to make Jeff George, the quarterback at the University of Illinois, the No. 1 pick in the National Football League college draft on April 22. George will give up his senior year to turn professional.

title: Chronicle
description: Usually they compete rather than cooperate. But 19 leading international fashion designers will join in a fashion show on May 16 to benefit Carnegie Hall. LIZA MINNELLI will be the host of the evening, the first time Carnegie Hall has actually presented a fashion show.

title: B&H Bulk Carriers Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Suntrust Banks Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
A Top Line for Rangers Struggles to Find Touch
description: Perhaps it is because their superb synchronization seemed so effortless that their struggle right now seems so pronounced. Kelly Kisio, Brian Mullen and John Ogrodnick, the three components in what has been a sensational line for the Rangers, are now three pieces of a productivity puzzle.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of information sources about diabetes on Thursday, with the Personal Health column, misstated the address of the American Diabetes Association. It is 1660 Duke Street, Alexandria, Va. 22314.

title: Allegheny Opposed On Reorganization
description: Japonica Partners L.P. said it would file suit in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Pittsburgh to block Allegheny International Inc.'s reorganization plan. Japonica contends Allegheny's plan was set up to allow a group that includes the company's senior management to seize control of Allegheny. Japonica last week filed its own amended cash plan of reorganization, which increases the price it is offering for Allegheny by $5 million, to an aggregate of $655 million.

title: Fan Mail
description: The U.S. Postal Service has done it at last -produced the stamps you love to buy! They were issued a few weeks ago: Clark Gable and Vivien Leigh in ''Gone With the Wind,'' Gary Cooper in ''Beau Geste'' (why that one?), John Wayne in ''Stagecoach'' and Judy in ''The Wizard of Oz.'' What's a quarter when it's Rhett and Scarlett in the top right corner of the envelope?

title: Great Country Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income Results in the latest third quarter included a provision for loan losses of $3.3 million, compared with $120,000 in the year-ago quarter. This action was taken in response to the weak Connecticut real estate market. Loss in the latest 9 months included provisions of $11.8 million for possible loan losses, against $360,000 in the year-ago period.

title: Prosecutor Drops Hint to Jury Of Confession in Racial Case
description: A prosecutor said yesterday that a major witness in the Bensonhurst street slaying is a ''con man'' with a long criminal history, including convictions for robbery and rape.

title: Breaking Oil Industry Ranks, Conoco Buys 2-Hulled Ships
description: Conoco Inc. said yesterday that it was ordering two new oil tankers with double hulls, designed to reduce the likelihood of oil spills like that of the Exxon Valdez last year. The Conoco move represents a break with most United States oil companies, which so far have resisted ordering such tankers.

title: Continental Adds Nicaragua Route
description: Continental Airlines announced it would add nonstop service to Nicaragua from Houston's Intercontinental Airport, giving it flights to each of the seven Central American countries. The nonstop service to Managua is scheduled to begin on July 1.

title: Paragon Petroleum reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Sex 'n' Drugs 'n' Wagner
description: Now that the major record companies have agreed to stamp warning labels on offensive rock albums, the public should be alerted to an even greater danger that has not been acted upon.

title: Tributes to a Think Tank
description: Among the luminaries at last week's 20th anniversary dinner of the Joint Center for Political Studies were President Bush and Douglas Wilder of Virginia, the nation's first elected black Governor. Mr. Bush's presence was testimony to the center's importance as the premier think tank devoted to black issues. Mr. Wilder's presence offered evidence of the progress achieved by the 7,400 black elected officials who have profited from the center's work.

title: Review/Dance;   A 13th-Century Mystic Takes Flight in Boston
description: Johannes Eckhardt, a 13th-century German mystical theologian known as Meister Eckhart, would be a worthy hero for the flower children and new agers of the 1990's. Or so one might suspect from the innocent piety of ''Airborne: Meister Eckhart,'' a theater-dance piece presented by Dance Umbrella on Friday night at the Boston Center for the Arts Cyclorama. But Robert Davidson, who conceived and directed the piece, and Dance Umbrella, which made the inspired selection of performance space, created theater that also had something to say about the glory of human movement - a message close to Eckhart's preaching.

title: Hospital Workers in California Approve Pay Offer, Ending Strike
description: Workers at the nation's largest health maintenance organization voted on Monday to approve a reworked contract offer, ending a weeklong strike by 11,000 nurses, technicians and maintenance workers.

title: 2 Iowa Editors Ousted For Anti-Abortion Role
description: Two editors active in anti-abortion causes have been dismissed by a newspaper for violating a policy that forbids employees to serve as officers of politically active groups that receive news coverage.

title: United and Boeing Held At Fault in Deaths on Jet
description: Federal investigators said today that improper maintenance by United Airlines and a flawed design by the Boeing Corporation were responsible for the accident last year on a jet whose cargo door blew open over Hawaiian waters, killing nine passengers.

title: Joyce Carol Oates Wins Short-Story Award
description: Joyce Carol Oates is the winner of the annual $25,000 Rea Award for the Short Story, it was announced yesterday by the Dungannon Foundation.

title: Westinghouse Profits Are Up 11.1%
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said today that its first-quarter profit increased 11.1 percent in part because of the sales of two radio stations and a minority interest in a nuclear power project.

title: A Plywood Used in Many Homes Is Found to Decay in a Few Years
description: A fire-retardant plywood that has become a standard building material in town house developments in the last decade has now been found to decompose after only a few years, leaving homeowners and builders with leaky and unsafe roofs and large repair bills.

title: KEY RATES
Washington Talk;   Learning to Say 'No' To Some Constituents
description: The word Representative Gary L. Ackerman uses is ''gun-shy.''

title: Soviets Assail Radicals
description: The Soviet Communist Party Central Committee sharply attacked a group of party radicals agitating for drastic changes and said today that if they did not conform they had no place in the party organization.

title: Pilsen Journal;   G.I.'s or Russians? Time to Show the Snapshots
description: With lots of American flags and the beer that made this Bohemian city famous, Pilsen is cheerfully preparing to celebrate a truth that it holds dear but has rarely been able to tell. The last time was 22 years ago, during the brief spring of freedom in 1968.

title: Interco Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 24
description: b-Included a loss of $5,454,000 for the quarter and a gain of $86,082,000, or $2.15 a share, for the year, both from discontinued operations. c-After income from discontinued operations of $36,225,000, or 94 cents a share, and $74,432,000, or $1.95 a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. Latest quarter and year's share earnings reflected preferred dividend requirements of $21 million, or 53 cents a share, and $83.8 million, or $2.10 a share, respectively, and the year-ago quarter and year's share earnings both reflected preferred dividend requirements of $11.8 million, or 30 cents a share.
