Fiscal 1989 loss from continuing operations of $4,282,000 included one- time nondeductible restructuring expense of $14 million.

title: INSIDE
description: Dinkins Faults Home Port

title: Guatemala to Investigate Nun's Kidnapping
description: President Vinicio Crezo Arevalo has agreed to form a commission to investigate the kidnapping last November of an American Ursuline nun, a presisdential spokesman said today.

title: To Chinese, Genghis Tomb Is No Mystery
description: To the Editor:

title: Cadence Acquires Software Company
description: Cadence Design Systems Inc., a leading producer of software for designing integrated circuits, agreed to acquire Automated Systems Inc. of Milwaukee, which produces printed circuit board design software. The deal, which is structured as a stock swap, is valued at about $23.8 million.

title: Stieb Helps Blue Jays Set Back Rangers, 2-1
description: Dave Stieb and three Toronto relievers allowed five hits tonight as the Blue Jays beat the Texas Rangers, 2-1.

title: Marcia R. Richman, Lawyer, 55
description: Marcia R. Richman, a lawyer who specialized in juvenile justice, died of cancer on Monday at her home in Short Hills, N.J. She was 55 years old.

title: At Easter, Classic Greek Fare, Made Anew
description: AT St. Paul's Greek Orthodox Cathedral in Hempstead, L.I., precisely at midnight on Saturday, all the lights will go out and members of the congregation, each holding a white candle, will watch in the darkness as the priest lifts one solitary flame and proclaims: ''Receive ye the light from the light that never wanes and glorify Christ, who has risen from the dead.''

title: Study Finds the Will to Live Can Work
description: Willpower can delay death briefly when people want to go on living to celebrate major events in their lives, researchers say.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: PROSCIUTTO DI PARMA, the air-cured ham from Italy that was approved for importing to the United States last fall, is now available in most major cities. To my taste prosciutto di Parma has a leaner and more buttery texture than domestic prosciutto. It is also more moist, which can make it tricky to slice, so make sure it is done on a slicing machine.

title: BUSH NAMES ENVOY FOR MANILA TALKS
description: President Bush today named Richard L. Armitage, a former Defense Department official, to be the chief American negotiator in talks on the future of United States bases in the Philippines.

title: The News of Lithuania, But With Kremlin Spin
description: When it comes to reporting on the situation in Lithuania, Soviet news organizations have reverted to the one-sided, polemical style of the pre-glasnost era.

title: Norton Recovering From Injury as N.H.L. Reviews Incident
description: Jeff Norton, recovering from a concussion, left the hospital today but is listed by the Islanders as doubtful for Wednesday night's fourth game of their Stanley Cup playoff series against the Rangers.

title: Injury Layoff Over, Graf Is in Fine Form
description: She didn't play like a person who has ever had a sore thumb.

title: Midwesco Filter Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Metro Datelines;   Man Held in Shooting Is Linked to a Killing
description: A man was charged yesterday with shooting his brother during the morning's rush hour at Pennsylvania Station, the police said. The man is also suspected of killing a friend in a dispute in Brooklyn hours earlier.

title: For New York: More Than Money
description: The new team at City Hall in New York has rapidly proved it can manage scarcity. Mayor David Dinkins and his colleagues are facing up responsibly and unflinchingly to one shortfall after another in tax revenues. Even so, there's more to leadership than fiscal management and there's more to the quality of life in New York City than money.

title: 2d Inmate Stabbed at Prison
description: A prison inmate was recovering in a hospital today after his lung was punctured when he was stabbed by another prisoner Sunday night in the gymnasium of the maximum-security Dannemora state prison. It was the second stabbing of an inmate in four days at the prison, near the Canadian border north of Albany. The latest victim, Johnny Linsey, 26 years old, was at the Champlain Valley Physicians Hospital in Plattsburgh in fair condition, state authorities said.

title: Crompton & Knowles Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Lotus Introduces Apple Software
description: The Lotus Development Corporation introduced a market analysis product for Apple Computer Inc.'s Macintosh called Lotus Marketplace. The software includes data bases stored on CD-ROM, or compact disk read only memory, with data on United States businesses and households as well as software for pinpointing customers, analyzing markets and business prospecting. It is scheduled to be priced at $695 and shipped this summer.

title: Superior Industries Intl reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Pacific Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * R. R. Donnelley & Sons Co., Chicago, a commercial printer, appointed Robert J. Coleman a senior vice president in its magazine group. Richard V. Thursby was named a senior vice president in its financial printing services group.

title: Motorola Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Better Ways to Make Electricity
description: The gas turbine, which has been called the ''neglected stepsister'' of electricity-generating equipment, is becoming the utility industry's main hope for the next decade.

title: AEL Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 23
description: b-Net income The latest quarter figures included a charge of $3 million from reversal of an income tax benefit. Latest full year figures included special contract provisions of about $10 million representing investments in several new programs that offer ''significant future large scale production potential.'' The company said tax credits had been recorded in earlier fiscal 1990 quarters in anticipation of offsetting current year operating losses against an expected gain from disposition of a foreign investment that did not materialize.

title: California Opens All-Out War On Tobacco and Its Marketing
description: In one of the nation's most aggressive anti-smoking efforts, the State of California today began a multimillion-dollar advertising campaign that will be paid for by the smokers themselves through cigarette taxes.

title: WALESA DECLARES INTENTION TO SEEK POLISH PRESIDENCY
description: Lech Walesa, leader of the Solidarity trade union, today declared his intention to run for the presidency of Poland, the first step in an apparent campaign to force President Wojciech Jaruzelski from office.

title: Bitter Race in Texas Ends With Richards As Democrats' Pick
description: Ann Richards, the Texas State Treasurer, won the Democratic nomination for Governor here tonight, defeating Jim Mattox, the Attorney General, after an extraordinarily bitter primary campaign that revolved around allegations of drug use and personal attacks.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Plan to Sell Puerto Rico Utility Becomes Law
description: Gov. Rafael Hernandez Colon signed into law today a measure clearing the way for the Commonwealth to sell the Puerto Rico Telephone Company, despite the protests of workers.

title: New York Starts Legal Action To Stop Home-Repair Fraud
description: New York has begun taking legal action against 112 of the 10,000 unlicensed home-improvement contractors it believes are operating in the city, Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday.

title: Peres Appears Certain to Lead Israel
description: Shimon Peres and the Labor Party seem almost certain to form a new, left-leaning government on Wednesday, unencumbered by a paralyzing coalition with the rightist Likud party.

title: New Salary Won't Affect Mattingly
description: Back home in Evansville, Ind., where he was born and still lives in the winter, Don Mattingly keeps a green 1962 Ford truck parked in the driveway. It is the only thing he drives, perhaps the only thing in his possession that does not shout about Mattingly's wealth.

title: Mattingly: Yankees' Last Tradition
description: On the morning after signing a $19 million contract, somebody else might have awakened with a champagne hangover. Or fluffed the pillow and slept until noon. But if you're wondering why Don Mattingly deserves to be baseball's highest paid player and why all that money isn't likely to change him, consider the guest book near the weight machines and stationary bicycles in the health club of Stouffer Tower City Plaza hotel where the Yankees are lodged.

title: Greenman Bros.  reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 3
Third Driver Is Killed In Bronx Cab Robbery
description: Three cab drivers have been killed in three separate incidents in the Eastchester secton of the Bronx in the last five weeks by a gunman after someone telephoned for car service, then shot and robbed the drivers, the police said.

title: Sharing of Power Lines Is Proposed
description: New England's largest electric utility has promised to allow other regional electric companies access to its transmission lines if the Federal Government approves its $2.3 billion plan to purchase the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, the troubled power company that built the Seabrook nuclear plant.

title: Quality Food Centers reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 24
A Gas Burner Converts Light Into Electricity
description: rrGetting electricity from natural gas has almost always meant burning the gas for heat first. Usually more than half the energy is lost, including the energy given off as light.

title: David M. Robb, Art Historian, 86
description: David M. Robb, an art historian and a teacher, died on Monday at his home in Scituate, Mass. He was 86 years old.

title: Pickens Seeks Japan Inquiry
description: The Boone Company, an investment company owned by the United States takeover specialist T. Boone Pickens, asked Japan's Fair Trade Commission today to investigate possible violations of antimonopoly laws by Japanese auto makers and parts suppliers. A commission official, Yoshiro Sekine, said the panel would study Boone's contentions.

title: Review/Film;   Dudley Moore Acts Up In Tony Bill's 'Crazy People'
description: ''Let's face it, Steve,'' says Emory Leeson (Dudley Moore), ''you and I lie for a living.''

title: About Education
description: The shaping of child-care legislation is made difficult by long neglect. How can this nation catch up with care that should have been provided years ago and that has long been available in other industrial societies? The problem is compounded by a similar backlog of other unmet social needs, like health insurance and care for the elderly. the issue boils down to money; creating a new child-care structure is expensive.

title: Books of The Times;   Privilege, the Right Hand Of Soviet Censorship
description: Inside the Soviet Writers' Union

title: DEALS
description: BASEBALL

title: Market Place;   A Way to Hedge On 'Junk Bonds'?
description: ROBERT GORDON, president of Twenty-First Securities in New York, thinks he has found a way to permit those who own ''junk bonds'' to sleep better at night. His proposed sedative is a hedging strategy, a hybrid of stock and bond-futures trades, that he says will offset some of the risk of investing in the volatile, unrated debt issues.

title: Mars Graphic Services reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The company said results for the latest year included those of its Dimark Inc. unit, for the period from Aug. 4, 1989, (the date of the business combination) through Feb. 28, 1990.

title: Washington Bancorp (N.J.) Inc.(O) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Washington Federal S&L reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
ENLARGED HEARTS TIED TO JOB STRESS
description: Job stress among men can cause potentially dangerous physical changes in the heart as well as high blood pressure, a new study has found.

title: Economic Scene;   Socialist Eggs, Market Omelet
description: HUNGARY'S voters sent their Communist leaders to metaphoric Siberia this week, electing a nationalist coalition loosely cast in the image of the Christian Democratic parties of Western Europe. But the Communists' economic baggage, two decades of central planning followed by two decades of botched reforms, remains behind. And while the economic strategy of the newly elected Democratic Forum is not yet known, the path of least political resistance is clear: a slow relaxation of Socialist controls along with a gradual privatization of publicly owned enterprise.

title: Talks Urged In Drug Suit
description: A Chicago arbitration judge has ordered Amgen Inc. and its leading marketing partner, the Ortho Pharmaceutical Corporation, a unit of Johnson & Johnson, to negotiate quickly their dispute regarding the sale of genetically engineered erythropoietin, or EPO, a hormone used to treat anemia.

title: Sharon Steel Corp. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included environmental charges of $18.1 million. c-Included an extraordinary credit of $17,731,000, or 21 cents a share, and after a loss of $92,337,000 from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the Exxon Valdez oil spill referred incorrectly in some editions to the number of dead birds held in evidence. Federal biologists say they have at least 36,000 dead migratory birds and 100 eagles stored in freezer vans.

title: The Flag and a Few Punks
description: There has been no epidemic of flag burning. Most of the people who like the idea - all seven or eight of them - are now involved in the Supreme Court case testing the constitutionality of the new law against flag burning. But legions of posturing public officials stand ready to scrap the Bill of Rights, all to show how sternly they would punish a handful of vandals.

title: Review/Jazz;   Rap Group Releases Album That Includes Disputed Song
description: The rap group Public Enemy has released a new album, ''Fear of a Black Planet.'' The album includes a song that was attacked by religious groups as anti-Semitic on its release as a single in February The single, ''Welcome to the Terrordome,'' includes lines like ''Crucifixion ain't no fiction/So called chosen frozen/Apology made to who ever pleases/Still they got me like Jesus.''

title: Edward O. Kallmann, Financier, 89
description: Edward O. Kallmann, a financial consultant and adjunct finance professor at Pace University for 30 years, died in his sleep on Saturday at his home in East Williston, L.I. He was 89 years old.

title: Tax Revolts and Cuts in Aid Batter Schools
description: Local school districts across the metropolitan region are facing some of the stiffest financial pressures in years, just as their states, also struggling to balance budgets, are cutting aid to them.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Why Not a Secondhand Arms Treaty?
description: Hi, there! Wanna buy a used tank? Kick the treads. Not a lot of mileage. Look at that gun -clean as a whistle. Hardly fired a shell. Or how about some brand new helicopters? Big discounts if you order now.

title: Why Not a 'Solvency Dividend'?
description: With all the talk in Washington about a peace dividend, we're in danger of overlooking another kind of windfall, one that's enjoyed by Michigan and other prudently managed states.

title: Japanese Children To Sing at Carnegie Hall
description: Members of Otowa Yurikago Kai, a chorus of Japanese youngsters, will make their United States debut on May 2 at 8 P.M. at Carnegie Hall. The concert of traditional and contemporary children's songs will feature 30 members of the troupe, which in its entirety numbers 200 singers from 3 to 17 years old.

title: Errors Created L.I.R.R. Delays, Amtrak Reports
description: A series of mishaps by Amtrak technicians caused the power surge on Monday that disabled track signals in Queens and delayed more than 150,000 riders on the Long Island Rail Road, an Amtrak official said yesterday.

title: Dinner and Concert To Benefit the Kitchen
description: The Kitchen, the experimental performing-arts center, will hold its fourth annual spring benefit concert on May 9 at 7:30 P.M. at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street. Performers are to include the Kronos Quartet, the performance artist Ann Magnuson, and the dancer and choreographer Molissa Fenley, performing ''The Floor Dances - Requiem for the Living,'' a piece composed in memory of wildlife killed by the 1989 Alaskan oil spill.

title: Power-Play Goal Gives Jets 4-3 Victory in 2d Overtime
description: Dave Ellett's power-play goal at 1 minute 8 seconds of the second overtime gave the Winnipeg Jets a 4-3 victory over the Edmonton Oilers last night, lifting the Jets within a game of winning the Smythe Division playoff series.

title: Chronicle
description: After a five-month search for a house that meets the tastes of JOSEPH and LILY FERNANDEZ, New York's Schools Chancellor and his wife, a city fund plunked down nearly $1 million yesterday for a town house in Brooklyn Heights. A state agency acquired title to the house, which it is giving to the city, which is in turn transferring it to the Board of Education, which is how these things work in the metropolitan maze.

title: Nepalese Opposition Demanding Control of an Interim Government
description: Leaders of the opposition movement denounced representatives of the nonparty system today for seeking to remain in power as ''an interim government.''

title: AST Offers PC in Japan
description: AST Research Inc., a small American computer maker, is invading Japan with a clone of that country's most popular personal computer.

title: New York Budget Cuts Will Swell Ranks of Homeless on Streets
description: To the Editor:

title: Bank of New Hampshire reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Shuttle Liftoff Postponed Because of a Bad Valve
description: A defective valve in the steering system of the space shuttle Discovery halted the countdown within four minutes of the planned liftoff today and forced an indefinite postponement of the mission to carry the Hubble Space Telescope into orbit.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-11

title: Keane Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Nuns Help Prisoners Find Freedom Within Walls
description: Willis Walker is so tall and broad-shouldered he seems to fill the stone corridor as he strides toward a classroom deep inside the United States Penitentiary here, but the inmate confesses a touch of awe at several small, soft-spoken women who also spend a lot of time in the prison.

title: And Yet They Rise
description: The President's no-new-taxes promise is malarkey, of course.

title: WINE TALK
description: LAST week's column set out to show that despite all the hand-wringing over high wine prices, it is not at all difficult to drink well for $10 a bottle or less. That list dealt only with red wines; this one will deal with whites.

title: A Cake With a Rich History (and a History of Being Rich)
description: LEAD: THE artistry of Sicilian pasticcieri, or pastry chefs, is renowned throughout Italy. But it is at Easter, when they create the queen of Sicilian desserts, cassata siciliana, that the full extent of their virtuosity is apparent.

title: Wedgestone Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Beyond Salad: Greens in Cooked Dishes
description: LEAFY greens are now available year round, but from mid-spring through early July, produce markets around the nation boast a welcome array of locally grown lettuces and their kin. Not only are these greens fresher and crisper because they have been shipped over shorter distances, but they are also much cheaper than those raised out-of-season in Florida and California.

title: Rev. Dale S. Alexy, 57; Fought for Bus Service
description: The Rev. Dale Stewart Alexy, an Episcopal priest who led demonstrations last year against the curtailment of bus service in Jamaica, Queens, died of cancer on Monday at the rectory of St. Stephen's Church, where he lived. He was 57 years old.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allied-Signal Inc., Morristown, N.J., an aerospace and electronics company, said it had received an eight-year, $99 million contract to manage the United States space station center in Houston. The contract includes a two-year option at $41 million.

title: Inquiry Into Stealth's Performance In Panama Is Ordered by Cheney
description: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has ordered an inquiry into why the Air Force failed to inform him that one of its Stealth fighter planes missed its target during the Panama invasion, the Pentagon's chief spokesman said today.

title: Soviet Diplomat Found Slain By a Main Road in Suriname
description: The Soviet Union's second-ranking diplomat here was found shot to death in a gutter in this South American country, the police said today.

title: GORBACHEV SPEAKS OF LITHUANIA MOVE
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that he might use his newly strengthened powers to impose Moscow's control over Lithuania as an extreme measure in case of civil conflict there, the official press agency Tass reported.

title: Football Cases Are Fun For Asbestos Lawyer
description: Andrew T. Berry, who just won a big asbestos-liability case for Owens Illinois Inc. over its insurance companies, has also won a few for the New York Giants football team.

title: Fraternity Rebuff Stirs Whirlwind in Vermont
description: Winston D. Brathwaite 2d had never envisioned the rigors of Hell Week when he pledged to join the Acacia fraternity at the University of Vermont last fall. On the first night of the weeklong initiation, each pledge, head covered with a pillowcase, was led to the attic where the brothers spelled out his faults.

title: Oil Prices Off Sharply as Supplies Rise
description: Oil prices continued to tumble yesterday as mounting surpluses of petroleum caused increased waves of selling here and overseas. The May contract for crude oil settled at an eight-month low of $17.68 a barrel, down 76 cents, on the New York Mercantile Exchange, the largest energy market.

title: 'Midlife Crisis' Seen by Doctor In Family Killer
description: A psychiatrist for the prosecution testified today that John E. List was suffering from nothing more than a ''midlife crisis'' when he shot his wife, mother and three children to death in their Westfield house on Nov. 9, 1971.

title: Home Federal S&L Assoc. of The Rockies reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After gains of $543,000, or 99 cents a share, for the quarter and $743,000, or $1.35 a share, for the year, both from an accounting change. c-Net income

title: Motorola-Hitachi Ruling Postponed
description: Motorola Inc. said a United States district judge in Texas has delayed until June 18 his decision on Hitachi Ltd.'s motion to lift a stay on an injunction in a patent infringement suit between the two electronics companies. Motorola said it would continue to sell its 68030 microprocessor, which has been at the center of the litigation. Judge Lucius Bunton of the Federal District Court of Western Texas ruled on March 29 that each company had infringed the other's patents.

title: David C. Cook 3d, Publisher, 77
description: David C. Cook 3d, retired chairman of the D. C. Cook Publishing Company in Elgin, Ill., an international publisher of religious books and educational materials, died Friday at Humana Hospital in Hoffman Estates, a suburb of Chicago. He was 77 years old and lived in Bartlett, Ill.

title: The Pop Life
description: The Sea and Mysticism

title: A Church Celebrates Its First Century Of Creative Growth
description: By all rights the Judson Memorial Church, which is celebrating its centennial this year, should have become a congregation for the sort of moneyed men and women who populate the fiction of Edith Wharton and Henry James. Instead, it became a home to outcasts of all kinds, from turn-of-the-century immigrants to prostitutes, political refugees and avant-garde artists whose work no one else would present.

title: IN CANADA'S WEST, MORE PROTESTERS
description: Western Canada has long been a breeding ground for political protest movements. Quietly, another one of them, the Reform Party of Canada, is gaining western strength and national attention, with implications for this country's political order and its relationship with the United States.

title: Blount Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $6,671,000, or 55 cents a share, and $3,754,000, or 31 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. c-After a loss of $562,000 for the quarter and income of $113,448,000, or $9.43 a share, for the year, both from discontinued operations, and the year also included a loss from an accounting adjustment of $10,834,000.

title: Cavazos Criticizes Hispanic Parents on Schooling
description: But when asked at a news conference what solutions he would propose, Mr. Cavazos, a sixth-generation Texan who is of Mexican descent, leveled his criticism at Hispanic parents. Hispanic cultures long placed a high value on education, he said, but "somewhere along the line we lost that."

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Accounts
description: * Nestle S.A., to Lintas: Europe, for undisclosed confectionary brands, with billings of $20 million.

title: Reserve Industries Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $23,000, or 1 cent a share, from tax loss carryforwards, for the quarter and 6 months. c-After an extraordinary credit of $447,543, or 22 cents a share, from extinguishment of debt.

title: Checkpoint Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 1
description: b-Net loss

title: A New Generation Begins Computing
description: Hugh Bell decided he was behind the times when he saw his great-grandson, who is in elementary school, using a computer. ''I watched that little guy last Christmas and he was making Christmas cards,'' said Mr. Bell, an 83-year-old retired marine engineer. ''I looked and I thought to myself, 'You should learn this too.' ''

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: BEWILDERED

title: Idaho Plans King Holiday
description: Gov. Cecil D. Andrus signed into law today a bill that makes Idaho the nation's 47th state to honor the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. with an official holiday. The new law creates a Martin Luther King Jr.-Idaho Human Rights Day on the third Monday in January.

title: Hospital Staffing Services reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Review/Music;   Comparing and Contrasting A and B
description: Hearing the Baltimore and Atlanta Symphonies play at Carnegie Hall in the space of a few days has been an instructive exercise not so much in comparative skills but in comparative esthetics.

title: UConn Seeks Prospect
description: Coach Jim Calhoun of the University of Connecticut said yesterday he planned to meet today with Chris Corchiani of North Carolina State to discuss the possibility of the point guard transferring to Connecticut for his final year of college eligibility.

title: Harrison Winter, 69, Federal Appeals Judge
description: Harrison L. Winter, former chief judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, died of cancer yesterday at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore. He was 69 years old and lived in Baltimore.

title: Male Population Rises Faster Than Female
description: The Census Bureau reported today that the number of men grew faster than the number of women in the United States during the 1980's, something that had not happened since the first decade of this century.

title: Court Trustee Urged for Eastern
description: The unsecured creditors of Eastern Airlines asked the bankruptcy court yesterday to appoint a trustee to take over the airline.

title: Atnn Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Reader's Digest Starts Monthly
description: Reader's Digest Association Inc. said yesterday that it would start its first new magazine in 10 years with Budgets Famille, a French monthly magazine to help families manage their finances.

title: Oil-Fueled Fire Razes a Plant In a Town Outside Milwaukee
description: A fire feeding on tens of thousands of gallons of outboard motor oil, kerosene and insecticide destroyed a plant in this Milwaukee suburb today and raged out of control for seven hours until a foam spray doused the flames.

title: Bandag Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Billboards in War on Drugs Bring Criticism and Lawsuit in Carolina
description: Sheriff Gene Taylor of Anderson County was only trying to catch drug dealers when he erected billboards promising to pay informers. But the program has generated criticism, and he has been sued for $40 million by an informer.

title: Holnam Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Piedmont: Italian Gift for America's Palate
description: TUSCAN olive oil and crostini, pesto from Genoa and lusty Neapolitan spaghetti puttanesca have become as American as French fries. But if asked to name one dish from Piedmont, a largely rural province in northwest Italy, most Americans would be at a loss.

title: Lithuanian Independence Deserves Recognition;   Support for Gorbachev
description: To the Editor:

title: NHI Nelson Holdings Intl Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After utilization of net operating loss carryforwards of $3,670,000, or 90 cents a share. c-Net loss and the year included income from discontinued operations of $3,310,000, or $1.15 a share, and after an extraordinary gain on debt extinguishment of $22,836,000, or $7.96 a share. The share earnings were reduced for preferred dividend requirements.

title: Farmstead Telephone Group reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Correction
description: A recipe for Hungarian hazelnut torte in The Living Section last Wednesday, with an article about Passover cooking, omitted parts of two steps. Step 5 should have said: ''While baking, make the icing. Boil the sugar in the water until dissolved. Continue boiling slowly. Test the thickness of the syrup by dropping a small amount into a glass of cold water until it holds its shape.'' Step 6 should have said, ''Beat the 8 additional egg yolks at medium speed until thickened, about 3 to 4 minutes.''

title: Real Estate;   Church Plans To Expand Its Holdings
description: THE parish of Trinity Church, which has owned extensive tracts of land in Manhattan for almost 300 years, is re-entering the New York real estate market to acquire properties that can increase the income the parish spends on charity.

title: UAL Buyout Proposal Gets Formal Approval
description: The UAL Corporation said today that it had formally agreed to sell the company, the parent of United Airlines, to its employees for about $4.38 billion.

title: Computer Research Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Help the Poor, but Don't Call It Welfare
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Chronicle column yesterday about Carolyn Cochran Clark misstated her role in the Harvard Law School Association. She is the first woman elected president of the 104-year-old association, not the first female member.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Ed McCabe's Big Return: A Small Step
description: THE copywriter who married a tough man to a tender chicken to build the Perdue poultry empire and the Scali, McCabe, Sloves advertising agency, Edward A. McCabe, said yesterday that he was returning to the advertising business.

title: Kenneth Robinson, 73, Former House Member
description: J. Kenneth Robinson, a Virginia Republican who served in the House of Representatives for 14 years, died of pancreatic cancer on Sunday at his home in Winchester, Va. He was 73 years old.

title: United Park City Mines reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $1,444 on disposal of assets for the quarter and year. c-After an extraordinary gain of $353,591, or 4 cents a share, from land condemnation.

title: Westinghouse Electric Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included $266 million in gains from major business disposition and joint venturing and $261 million provision for restructuring.

title: Banks Gain On Wall St.
description: A Federal appeals court today upheld the right of banks to underwrite certain securities, giving banks another victory in their attempt to dismantle Depression-era restrictions on their activities.

title: Coach Suspends Season
description: Coach Don Axtell of the State University of New York at Oneonta has suspended 22 players and cancelled the rest of his team's games this spring for a violation of campus drinking rules, college officials said yesterday. The 22 missed games will be recorded as forfeit losses for the Division III school.

title: FEAR IS TORMENTOR OF BURMESE IN U.S.
description: One day a man speaking Burmese left a threatening message on the answering machine of U Kyaw Win, an emigre professor who is an outspoken critic of the Government in Myanmar, formerly Burma.

title: Comstock Resources reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said share earnings are adjusted to reflect the 1-for-4 reverse stock split on March 15.

title: Harding Associates reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Washington Bancorporation reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Net income

title: Fast Food Chains Try to Slim Down
description: AMERICA'S fast-food chains are hardly paragons of nutritional virtue, but they are beginning to respond to criticism by health professionals that they are nutritional wastelands. Those in search of low-fat meals, who have stayed away from chains like McDonald's, Burger King, Wendy's, Hardee's and Roy Rogers, convinced there was nothing there they could possibly eat, are in for a surprise.

title: Mongolia's Communists Mapping Changes to Keep Grip on Power
description: Hoping to keep its 70-year grip on power in the face of a growing pro-democracy movement, the Communist Party opened a hastily convened congress today with a call for widespread change.

title: Concord Journal;   Wherein Public Art Doesn't Please
description: In recent years this city 25 miles east of San Francisco has been sucked inexorably into the Los Angelization of the Bay Area. Once a sleepy backwater, it is now a city of 112,000 people, its freeways clogged with commuters, its downtown of genteel covered walkways dominated by looming office buildings.

title: International Paper Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
2 Strikers Charged in Greyhound Shooting
description: Two striking drivers for Greyhound Lines were arrested by Federal agents here today and charged with one of more than two dozen shooting attacks against the company's buses since the drivers' union went on strike March 2.

title: Mazda and Hertz In Rental Venture
description: The Mazda Motor Corporation formed a joint car rental venture in Japan with the Hertz Corporation, the world's largest automobile rental company.

title: Metro Datelines;   Private Citizen Lends $110,000 to County
description: A retired postal worker outbid four banks to lend $110,000 to Genesee County - the first time in at least 24 years that the county has borrowed money from a private citizen, officials said.

title: First Commercial Bancorp of Sacramento reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Per share earnings for the latest quarter is fully diluted.

title: Conservative to Form Government in Greece
description: The conservative party leader Constantine Mitsotakis received a mandate to form a government today after working out a deal with a small party to achieve the necessary parliamentary majority.

title: War of Words Misfires On Drugs in Capital
description: To the Editor:

title: Top S.E.C. Counsel To Join Private Firm
description: John H. Sturc, who played a leading role in many of the insider trading cases pursued by the Securities and Exchange Commission, is leaving to join a Washington law firm, the agency said yesterday.

title: Exposure to Reactor Radiation Is Reported Up
description: A consumer advocacy group said today that more nuclear power plant workers than ever before were exposed to measurable radiation in 1988, the last year for which data are available.

title: Lithuanian Independence Deserves Recognition
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Television;   The Perils and the Benefits Of Nature's Internal Clocks
description: ''The Living Clock,'' tonight's offering on ''Infinite Voyage,'' is an absorbing report on research into humankind's sensitivity to the hours of the day and the seasons of the year. You can catch it at 8 P.M. on Channels 13 and 49 and at 9 P.M. on Channel 21, the hours that nature has apparently set aside for peak viewing.

title: Review/Television;   An Earnest Teen-Ager in the Big City, on ABC
description: On Wednesday nights, ABC is doing nicely with one teen-ager, an unbelievably precocious all-American type named ''Doogie Howser, M.D.'' So what's the next logical step? Go find another teen-ager, of course, perhaps just reasonably precocious. So now, at 9:30, immediately following Doogie, ABC is offering ''The Marshall Chronicles.'' Marshall Brightman is a New York high-school student and a one-boy compendium of Jewish family jokes. If you're looking for major influences, start with Woody Allen.

title: Monterey Capital reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss of $512,000 from discontinued operations, and after an extraordinary credit of $353,000, or 16 cents a share. c-Net loss and after a loss of $1,353,000 from discontinued operations. The company changed its name from Laduboro Ltd. last November. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Infodata Systems Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Metro Datelines;   Mayor Seeks Answer On Missing Chlorine
description: Mayor James D. Griffin says he is not satisfied with his former parks commissioner's explanation for what happened to 10 tons of swimming-pool chlorine.

title: Judge Asks U.S. to Say How It Valued Lincoln
description: In a sign that he may find fault with the way regulators handled the takeover of the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, Federal District Judge Stanley Sporkin today asked Government lawyers to provide him the basis of their estimate of taxpayer losses stemming from Lincoln.

title: Moscow's New Worry: Its Army
description: Mikhail Gorbachev has strong grounds for worrying about the impact of Lithuania on the widening fault lines in the Soviet military. This worry adds to his major concern about the ''domino effect'' of letting Lithuania have its freedom: It could trigger the rapid disintegration of the Soviet Union and end his rule and perestroika.

title: Daniel Aldrich Jr., 71; Was Irvine Chancellor
description: Daniel G. Aldrich Jr., a chemist who became the first chancellor of the Irvine campus in a 50-year career with the University of California, died of colon cancer on Monday at the Irvine Medical Center. He was 71 years old.

title: Bridge
description: A great American player, Lou Bluhm of Atlanta, died on Thursday after a long battle with cancer. Two weeks earlier, he had been in Fort Worth, helping his teammates try to defend their Vanderbilt Knockout Team title. They reached the semifinal, and then fell to a strong group headed by Zia Mahmood of Manhattan. Four months before that, Bluhm had been named by the American Contract Bridge League as its first ''Distinguished Member.''

title: Carbide Review Is Delayed
description: A Supreme Court review of the Government's $470 million settlement with the Union Carbide Corporation for the 1984 Bhopal gas disaster was adjourned today until July, a news agency said.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Economic and Social Council

title: Auberges des Gouverneurs reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Universal Health Realty Inome Trust reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included loss of $360,000 due to continuing interest-payment default on mortgage investment.

title: About New York;   A 3-Ring Census: The Circus Folks Want to Count
description: The show was about to go on, and the backstage scene at Madison Square Garden was dizzy.

title: For a Burned Church, Help Pours In
description: All day long, donations and expressions of sympathy poured in for the Church of the Holy Apostles, the Chelsea landmark heavily damaged by fire Monday night.

title: Kleer Vu Industries reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $1,059,000 for the latest year and $2,257,000 for the year- earlier period.

title: American Pacesetter reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and the year is after a loss from discontinued operations of $516,000. The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The objective is to change the image that the tobacco industry has created for smokers -that it's sexy, glamorous, youthful - to it's dumb, dirty, dangerous.''

title: Star Banc Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Air Travel Gridlock Seen for Europe
description: Air travel in Europe will come to a ''near standstill'' by the end of the decade if radical improvements are not made, a study released today predicts.

title: Citicorp Deal Seen as Possible
description: Citicorp is considering the purchase of United Savings Bank of Tysons Corner, Va., in a move that would sharply increase the size and reach of its consumer banking business in the Washington area, it was disclosed yesterday.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Passover, alternate-side parking rules will be suspended in New York City today. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Mexican Inflation Slows
description: Mexico's consumer price index rose 1.8 percent in March, continuing a downward trend that held inflation in the first quarter to 9.1 percent, according to figures released by the Banco de Mexico on Monday. The index rose 4.8 percent in January and 2.3 percent in February. The Government has set an inflation target of below 20 percent for 1990.

title: Separatist Coalition Takes Lead In Voting in a Yugoslav Republic
description: In the first free multiparty elections in Yugoslavia since World War II, a center-right opposition coalition appears certain of a majority in the main chamber of the Slovenian Parliament.

title: Knicks Are Mastered By the Pistons Again
description: Whenever the Knicks solved one problem last night, the Detroit Pistons created another one.

title: Cal Rep Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Pioneer Hi-Bred Intl reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income and after income from discontinued operations of $3,151,000, or 10 cents a share, for the quarter and $15,367,000, or 48 cents a share, for the 6 months.

title: SOVIETS FLESH OUT VIEW ON GERMANY
description: Providing the first details of a proposal broached last week, a top adviser to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev says the Soviet Union would accept a united Germany's membership in both NATO and the Warsaw Pact for a five- to seven-year transitional period leading to a new European security system.

title: Credit Suisse Parent to Buy Stake in Oldest Swiss Bank
description: The parent of Credit Suisse, Switzerland's third-largest bank, will take a big stake in the nation's oldest bank, Bank Leu Ltd., the companies said today.

title: A New Museum's Bright Future Grows Dim
description: Once a bright gleam in the cultural future of Massachusetts, the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art, a projected $86 million complex for contemporary art, has lost much of its luster. Some in this financially strapped state are calling it ''the miracle that's become a mirage.''

title: Mets Ready to Put Ball Into the Hands of Viola
description: Under sunny skies at Shea Stadium yesterday, all was well for the Mets again. Gregg Jefferies fielded grounders without a miscue, Keith Miller snared fly balls easily in the outfield and Darryl Strawberry laughed as he belted a few balls over the right-field wall.

title: 'Nonpartisan' Council Race on S.I. Shows It Isn't
description: New York City's first nonpartisan election campaign under the new City Charter - a special election for the City Council on Staten Island - has got off to a highly partisan start.

title: Article 878290 -- No Title
description: The Mitsubishi Metal Corporation and the Mitsubishi Mining and Cement Company surprised market analysts late today by announcing plans for a $2 billion merger.

title: First Federal Savings Bank (Alabama) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included pretax gain of $273,000 on the sale of investment securities.

description: The bank said its latest first quarter results included a non-cash expense in the amount of $312,000 on an after-tax basis, for the amortization of the deposit premium paid for the former First Service Bank for Savings.

title: Kaydon Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Omens of Intolerance Among Cairo's Muslims
description: At dusk the streets are empty and the traffic dies down and a calm settles on this most rambunctious of cities, for this is Ramadan, the Muslim month of daytime fasting that represents one of Islam's sacred duties.

title: Neworld Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Security Pacific's Net Increases 5%
description: The Security Pacific Corporation, the nation's fourth-largest banking company, reported today that first-quarter earnings increased 5 percent, to $188.4 million, from $179.3 million in the period a year earlier.

title: Review/Jazz;   A Niche for Moonlighting
description: For the last 20 years Lew Anderson, an alto saxophonist, composer and arranger, has been leading an ad hoc big band made up of musicians moonlighting from steady jobs in recording studios and the pit bands of Broadway musicals. He has recently found an ideal time and place for his 15-piece ensemble to play - from 5:45 to 7:45 P.M. on Fridays at the Red Blazer Too, 349 West 46th Street, in the heart of the theater district. This allows his musicians to get to their theater jobs for the 8 o'clock curtain.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bertelsmann Music Group, the music and video subsidiary of the West German media company Bertelsmann A.G., named Lou Maglia president of its new music label, still unnamed, which will be based in Los Angeles.

title: Craig Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said it restated its previously announced earnings for the first quarter to reflect its share of a non-recurring loss of $278,000 at Reading Co. in December 1989.

title: BF Enterprises reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and included an extraordinary tax credit of $3,000.

title: Guardian Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Teledyne Canada reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Eric Mower To Buy Firm
description: Eric Mower & Associates, a marketing communications agency based in Syracuse, has reached an agreement to acquire Levy, King & White, an advertising and public relations firm based in Buffalo.

title:
Man in the News;

New Leader Of the Greeks: Constantine Mitsotakis
description: LEAD: His political career may be said to have its origins in the mid-19th century, when his grandfather founded the Komma Xipoliton, the Party of the Bare-Footed Ones, liberals who opposed the right-wing establishment then in power.

title: Celanese Canada reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Devils Beaten by Capitals
description: The Devils failed to match the intensity of the Capitals, were ineffective on the power play again and suffered a 3-1 loss tonight in the fourth game of their Patrick Division semifinal series.

title: Bob Woodward, The Washington Post And His Many Books
description: After two years of burrowing, Bob Woodward says he is about to start writing what may well be his sixth best-selling book. This time his subject is the Pentagon. Mr. Woodward, whose 19-year career with The Washington Post includes a Pulitzer Prize for his Watergate coverage, now carries the title of assistant managing editor for investigations at the paper.

title: Upheaval in the East;   British Question Soviet Suggestion On a Status for a United Germany
description: The British Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, said today that he found it difficult to imagine how to carry out a Soviet suggestion that a united Germany should belong to both NATO and the Warsaw Pact until a new all-European security system is developed.

title: Tracking the Life Of the New Father
description: FOR the 16 people seated around a horseshoe-shaped mahogany table in their company's conference room here, lunch was sandwiches and park-bench talk. As they ate, they shared worries about a deep concern in their lives: how to pursue a demanding career yet be an involved parent. Here is what some of them had to say: ''I have so little time with my child. I feel so guilty.''

title: Federal National Mortgage Assn.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
D&N Financial reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bank of South Carolina reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Yanks: Another Opening, Another Snow
description: On their second attempt at opening night, a few things went right for the Yankees: Dave Winfield seemed to put a troublesome spring behind him with a single that drove in the first run of the season, Don Mattingly hit a double and scored a run and Tim Leary struck out three batters in his debut with his new team.

title: Currents;   Knockoff! Knockoff! Price Wars Are No Joke
description: THE furniture knockoff wars escalated in March when Atelier International, which has licenses to reproduce many classic designs, announced that it had reduced prices up to 40 percent for more than 200 items in its Atelier International/Cassina Master's Collection. Major competitors, like Palazzetti, gloated.

title: H.W. Kaufman Financial Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DRUG IS PROMISING IN SICKLE-CELL TEST
description: An experimental drug treatment for sickle-cell disease may be the first to affect the disorder itself and not just the symptoms, researchers said today. They said promising results in preliminary human trials warranted larger trials.

title: Q&A
description: Cracked Floor Tiles

title: Snagged Freighter Leaks Fuel
description: A freighter ran aground yesterday off Nassau County in Long Island Sound and spilled about 1,000 gallons of its diesel fuel, officials said. They said most of it was dissipated by choppy waters, but cleanup crews were trying to contain a small slick near Hempstead Harbor, about two miles east of where the 570-foot freighter, registered in Chile and carrying timber, went aground about 6 A.M. less than a mile off the Sands Point peninsula.

title: Currents;   Bringing The World To Paramus
description: THE store is billed as a place for ''world-class home dressing'' and, indeed, Kalkin & Company, in the Fashion Center on Route 17 in Paramus, N.J., offers shoppers an enormous selection of trappings for the home.

title: N.B.A. Hands Out $10,500 in Fines
description: Mike McGee, a Phoenix Suns guard, Charles Barkley, the Philadelphia 76ers' star forward, and Charles Oakley of the Knicks were among seven players fined a total of $10,500 yesterday for fights in three different National Basketball Association games.

title: Suspect in Killing of Trooper Says 'Fat Guy' Gave Him a Gun
description: A man charged with killing a New York State undercover narcotics officer has told New York City police detectives that ''some fat guy from Brooklyn'' gave him a gun and was going to pay him $3,000 to ''rip off some guys who wanted to buy drugs.''

title: Hawkeye Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Farley Seeks Revision In Debt of Pepperell Bid
description: William F. Farley, the majority shareholder of West Point-Pepperell Inc. who failed last year to acquire all the textile maker for $1.56 billion, has proposed to revise the debt of the company he created to finance the takeover.

title: Gregg Gets Dual Role
description: Doug Single, who was hired three years ago as athletic director at Southern Methodist University to rebuild a scandal-scarred program, resigned yesterday to head the Special Olympics International program, beginning on Monday.

title: U.S. Pilots in Peru Join Battle Against Forces of Coca Trade
description: American civilian helicopter pilots who are part of the anti-drug effort at this Peruvian jungle base took part in a fierce two-hour firefight Saturday with guerrillas supporting coca growers, American officials said today.

title: French-Libyan Hostage Deal Draws Fire in Press
description: France came under sharp criticism today for its decision to normalize relations with Libya after French officials said they had negotiated the release of three hostages Tuesday in direct talks with the Government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: After the Feast: Repairing Damage to Table Tops
description: LEAD: During the Easter and Passover season, the one piece of furniture that probably views the festivities with the most apprehension is the dining table - or any finished wood surface from which food is served or partaken. Not only are these surfaces vulnerable to heat and spills, but any damage they suffer may escape notice and timely attention.

title: Adm. Petar Simic, Yugoslav Official, 57
description: Adm. Petar Simic, a Politburo member and the political chief of the armed forces, died of a brain hemorrhage in Belgrade today, the official Tanyug press agency reported. He was 57 years old.

title: Colombia Blast Kills 16; Drug Cartel Blamed
description: A car bomb killed 16 people and wounded 73 today in Colombia in what appeared to be swift retaliation from drug traffickers for a new crackdown on their multibillion-dollar business.

title: How to Protect New York's Future
description: Gov. Mario Cuomo's proposed $1.9 billion bond act to protect New York's environment has many more friends than enemies. The danger that the act would be torpedoed by the general budgetary turmoil in Albany is now receding. But the proposal's considerable promise could still be corrupted by narrow, local interests.

title: Review/Dance;   Philadelphia Troupe Makes Its New York Debut
description: Philadanco breezed into town like a fresh spring wind on Tuesday at the Joyce Theater, where it is performing in its New York debut season through Sunday. Now 20 years old, the Philadelphia-based company has the verve and brightness of new paint. The performers move with the clarity and the pulled-up look of ballet dancers, the stretch and the direct emotional commitment of modern dancers and the sharp attack of jazz dancers.

title: 2 Right-to-Die Groups Merging for Unified Voice
description: The nation's two largest right-to-die groups are moving toward a merger.

title: Currents;   A Silver Anniversary Of Landmark Status
description: THIS month the New York Landmarks Preservation Commission, the agency devoted to preserving the city's architectural heritage, is celebrating the 25th anniversary of its procreator, the Landmarks Preservation Law. The Urban Center is helping with a monthlong photography exhibit of the city's landmarks.

title: Upheaval in the East;   5 Kosovo Province Officials Quit, Citing Serbian Pressure
description: The Prime Minister and five other Cabinet members in Kosovo province have resigned after four months in office, citing pressure from Communist leaders in the republic of Serbia, the official news agency reported today.

title: Israeli Coalition Cracks at Last Minute
description: The Labor Party failed to present a new government for parliamentary approval this morning after two members of the prospective Labor-led coalition from religious parties said they were withdrawing.

title: Pioneer Federal Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and included one-time charge for restructuring of investments and borrowings in the after-tax amount of $14,789,000.

title: Reviews/Music;   Two Brazilian Visitors
description: More than a few fans of Brazilian music created a double bill for themselves on Friday night by attending rare New York shows by the pianist, guitarist and composer Egberto Gismonti at Town Hall and the singer Elba Ramalho at the Palladium. Both Mr. Gismonti's jazz and Miss Ramalho's pop are self-conscious attempts to make modern Brazilian music that is both cosmopolitan and rooted, fusing the local and the international. Although both concerts were showcases for impressive technique, Miss Ramalho's performance came closer to that ideal.

title: Bridge
description: One of the greatest female players in the history of the game died in January, just short of her 88th birthday. She was Margaret Wagar, an Atlanta resident most of her life, who retired from the game in 1978.

title: Gibson (C.R.) (A) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Ex-PTL Minister Cleared of Perjury Counts
description: A Federal district judge has dismissed perjury charges against a former clergyman of the television ministry PTL for lack of evidence.

description: To the Editor:

Walsh Leaves the Door Open For New Iran-Contra Cases
description: Lawrence E. Walsh, the independent prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair, said today that he was at least several months away from completing his three-year-old inquiry, and he left open the possibility of still further indictments of Reagan Administration officials.

title: F.B.I. Seeks Broad Powers to Seize Documents Without Subpoenas
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is seeking broad new powers to seize documents and other evidence in criminal investigations without the use of grand jury subpoenas, bureau and Congressional officials say.

title: Helio Smidt, Leader Of Varig, the Airline Of Brazil, Dies at 64
description: Helio Smidt, the president of Varig Brazilian Airlines, died of cancer yesterday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital in Manhattan. He was 64 years old and lived in Rio de Janeiro.

title: Soybean Order Is Held Proper
description: The Chicago Board of Trade acted within ethics rules when it declared an emergency and ordered traders to reduce soybean holdings last July, Congressional investigators said on Tuesday.

title: School Stars Are Honored
description: The 1990 Kodak Metropolitan High School All-Stars were honored at a dinner last night at the Downtown Athletic Club along with La Salle's Lionel Simmons, the winner of the Eastman Award as the outstanding basketball player in the country.

title: Onbancorp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Is 'Outing' Gays Ethical?
description: LEAD: In more polite times, gay organizers and journalists generally agreed that homosexuals in the closet had a right to stay there if they didn't choose to publicly acknowledge their sexuality. It was an unspoken rule.

title: Howtek Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Why Risk Start Now, Needlessly?
description: At the eleventh hour, Washington and Moscow have introduced ill-timed complications into their strategic arms reduction talks. Both sides are now reaching for a lot more than they can quickly resolve. Maybe they believe they're doing the right thing, though belatedly. Maybe they're just bargaining or maneuvering for internal political reasons. Whatever the various motives, they're inviting needless risks.

title: Where Paper Planes Fly, Census Plan Crashes
description: This was supposed to be the easy part: counting people by sending them 1990 census forms in the mail, which they would fill out and return.

description: * Angostura International Ltd., to Campbell-Mithun-Esty, for several condiments.

title: Davis Gets Save No. 1 for Royals
description: Mark Davis, the National League's Cy Young Award winner last season, got his first American League save tonight, pitching a perfect ninth inning to preserve the Kansas City Royals' 2-1 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.

title: Reporter's Notebook;   Case Against Sharpton: An Insomniac's Dream?
description: It has been three weeks since the Rev. Al Sharpton went on trial in Manhattan.

title: Review/Dance;   A 'Cinderella' Sprinkled With Sugar
description: Paul Mejia, who was a soloist at the New York City Ballet until he and his wife, Suzanne Farrell, resigned from that company in 1969, became interested in choreography a few years later while dancing in Europe.

title: Cuban-American Is Apprehended In Slaying of Chilean Exile in '76
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested a Cuban-American in Florida today on charges that he detonated the car bomb that killed Orlando Letelier, a Chilean exile leader, in Washington in 1976.

description: b-Net loss

title: De Klerk and Tutu Talk On Ending Black Strife
description: President F. W. de Klerk met today with Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu and other church leaders to discuss how to end black warfare in Natal province that has killed 400 people in the last two months.

title: Philadelphia Utility Sees Cut in Payout
description: The Philadelphia Electric Company will not be able to prevent a decrease in its dividend, the company's chairman, Joseph F. Paquette Jr., said at the annual meeting. Later, in answer to a shareholder's question, he said the size of the cut will be set at the board's meeting on April 23. The company paid a quarterly dividend of 55 cents on March 30. Mr. Paquette said he did not expect the dividend to be eliminated.

title: Artist Challenges Design Boundaries
description: Is it furniture or sculpture? When the piece in question was designed by Wendell Castle, the answer is sometimes ambiguous.

description: b-Included a $66,000 gain from sale of lease rights. The latest per share earnings adjusted to reflect 5 percent stock dividend payble April 18.

description: LEAD: In reading about the controversial firing of Andre Schiffrin, the longtime managing director of Pantheon Books, by the minions of S. I. Newhouse, I noticed a comment by Helen Wolff, who is widely regarded as a distinguished editor and publisher. The meanest comparison she could make in criticizing Mr.

title: KEY RATES
Guy Simoni, 62, Dies; Construction Executive
description: Guy P. Simoni, a founder and executive vice president of MacLean Grove & Company, a construction concern based in Greenwich, Conn., died of lung cancer yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 62 years old and lived in Tenafly, N.J., and Vero Beach, Fla.

title: Trouble All Over
description: Forms lost or not delivered.

title: Upheaval in the East;   In a Shuttered Museum, Stalin's Ghost Is Stirring
description: Sergo Tshaudobavi cracked the door open into the dead museum, eerie as a pillaged tomb, and pointed toward a bit of glint in the darkness over in the corner, the barely enduring smile of Stalin.

title: Martin Case Puzzling
description: William Reedy, the Detroit bar owner who told the police he was driving Billy Martin's pickup truck on Christmas Day when it crashed, killing the former Yankee manager, has given a different story to The Detroit Free Press. Reedy, who suffered a broken hip in the wreck at Martin's rural home near Binghamton, N.Y., was quoted in an article published yesterday as saying that he had lied to the police. He told the newspaper that Martin was at the wheel and that he had lied to protect his friend, who he did not realize at that time was fatally injured. But in another interview, also published yesterday in The Detroit News, Reedy denied making the statement to The Free Press.

title: WHITE HOUSE BARS A UNITED GERMANY IN BOTH ALLIANCES
description: In its first detailed comment on a Soviet proposal that a unified Germany belong to NATO and the Warsaw Pact, the Bush Administration rejected the idea today as a guise for making a united Germany neutral.

title: Loan Bank Office Cancels Offering
description: The finance office of the Federal Home Loan Banks said today that its regular debt offering, scheduled for Monday, was being canceled because of record levels of liquidity and a decline in the amount of advances being made to member institutions.

title: Shell Offers a New Gasoline In 10 Cities to Aid Air Quality
description: The Shell Oil Company announced yesterday that it had introduced a reformulated gasoline to reduce tailpipe and evaporation emissions from automobiles in 10 cities, including New York, where air quality is a problem.

title: Electro Rent Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Close to Home
description: THE crazy quilt was not one of the craft's beauties, and some of its patches shredded at a finger's touch. But a slip of paper pinned to a corner read ''Your grandmother made this out of family clothes, 1890's,'' and I could not bear to let it go to the ragman.

title: Washington Bancorp N.J.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a pre-tax gain of $613,000 on sale of real estate.

title: N.J. Transit Proposes Raising Fares
description: N.J. Transit today proposed raising rail fares by 10.9 percent and bus fares by 9.9 percent for transit riders in northern New Jersey, where most of the system's 291,600 daily commuters live.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:
