description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the JVC Jazz Festival, to be held June 22 to July 1, misstated the address for information. It is JVC Jazz Festival Productions, Box 1169, Ansonia Station, New York, N.Y. 10023.

title: DEALS
description: BASEBALL

title: Penn Central Yield at 10.691%
description: The Penn Central Corporation yesterday priced $150 million in subordinated debentures, due in 2000, through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.

title: Newmark & Lewis Hires Outsider as a Top Executive
description: Newmark & Lewis Inc., a discount retailer of consumer electronics and home appliances in the Northeast, said yesterday that it had hired Ron Fleisher as president and chief operating officer.

title: Group Holds 6.6% Of Pic 'N' Save
description: An investment group led by David H. Batchelder, a former top adviser to T. Boone Pickens, said that it had acquired a 6.6 percent stake in the Pic 'N' Save Corporation and that it would solicit consents from shareholders for control of the company's board. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the group, called Girard Partners L.P., said that if it gained control of the board it would ''solicit offers for Pic 'N' Save.'' Girard said it would also propose its own buyout offer.

title: Osborne K. Taylor, Executive, 88
description: Osborne K. Taylor, a retired assistant deputy treasurer of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, died of heart disease on Monday in a nursing home in Montclair, N.J. He was 88 years old and lived in Caldwell, N.J.

title: Prices Inch Higher; Trading Light
description: Prices of Treasury securities inched higher in light trading yesterday, as dealers cautiously bought securities in advance of reports on retail sales and producer prices.

title: Why Not Just Ban All Political Ads From TV?;   For More Discourse
description: To the Editor:

title: Personal Health
description: Although most childhood ailments are minor, they are often sufficiently bothersome to prompt parents to try some form of drug treatment to relieve symptoms or foster a rapid recovery.

title: Surgery Would Help More Epileptics, Panel Says
description: Recent advances in monitoring the brain and a better understanding of how it functions mean that many more epilepsy patients with persistent seizures could benefit from surgery, specialists say.

title: First Union Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a $1 million after-tax gain from the final payment on the 1988 sale of the factoring unit and a $2 million tax benefit from previously expensed alternative minimum tax. c-Included a $6 million after-tax gain from the sale of mortgage servicing rights and a $1 million after-tax loss from the sale of investment securities.

title: Boeing Still Negotiating Japanese Tie
description: Negotiations are continuing between the Boeing Company and three potential Japanese equity partners in its proposed 767-X aircraft, the company said today in response to reports in the Japanese press that an agreement was imminent.

title: Metro Matters;   Sadly, a Far Cry From the City He Helped Save
description: Felix G. Rohatyn, the investment banker, was briefing young executives on Tuesday about New York City's future when one asked him to measure conditions today against 15 years ago, when Mr. Rohatyn helped rescue the city from bankruptcy.

title: People
description: * Anthony Brescia, Margaret Evans and William Katz have been given the new titles of senior account directors at BBDO New York, and Glen Gilbert, Tony LaMonte and John Lucci have been named senior vice presidents.

title: Reporter's Notebook;   Nepal's Mix: It's Protests And Tourists
description: Komal Lamichane, a sturdy 31-year-old farmer, lay on the bed, his right leg in a cast, and told a visitor to this Buddhist town near Katmandu how he was detained by the local police and kicked and beaten last week for backing the pro-democracy movement.

title: Horn Fits Right In With Oriole System
description: The Baltimore Orioles derived remarkable results last season from their collection of youngsters and reclamation projects. This season is only days old and already their system is working again.

title: Duratek Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and included extraordinary tax credits of $73,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and $87,000, or 2 cents a share, for the year.

title: An Appointment That Stirs the Pot
description: As one of their first major exports since the fall of the Berlin wall, East Germans have sent New York a music director.

title: Development Brings Discord to Flushing
description: From the busy corner of Northern Boulevard and Union Street in Flushing, Queens, signs of the distant past, vibrant present and uncertain future of this changing polyglot area can be seen in a glance.

title: Raytheon Profit Rises
description: Raytheon Inc. said today that gains in its military electronics, aircraft and energy divisions helped push earnings up by 8.4 percent in the first quarter on a 7.3 percent rise in sales. Earnings in the period rose to $130.9 million, or $2 a share, from $120.8 million, or $1.83 a share, in the first three months of 1989. Sales rose to $2.23 billion from $2.07 billion.

title: Jockey Banned 10 Years
description: Sylvester Carmouche was banned yesterday from racing in Louisiana for 10 years because he allegedly took a fog-shrouded short cut to win a race at Delta Downs aboard a 23-1 long shot named Landing Officer. The vote to suspend Carmouche was 7-1.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about the recent strength of Morgan Stanley & Company misstated the company's relationship to Capital International. In 1985 Morgan acquired the rights to the research firm's market indexes, not the firm itself.

title: SICK SAVINGS UNITS RIDDLED BY FRAUD, F.B.I. HEAD ASSERTS
description: The Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that fraud in the savings and loan institutions seized by Federal regulators was ''pervasive'' and warned that pursuing the hundreds of cases would be a costly effort stretching out over several years.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bechtel Group Inc., San Francisco, won a contract from the Hong Kong government to manage a $16 billion construction project scheduled for completion in 1997, which is to include a new airport, the world's longest suspension bridge, a harbor tunnel and a rail transit system.

title: First Federal Savings Bank (Salt Lake City) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss The bank attributed the rise in earnings to an increase in net interest income. Net interest income before provision for loan losses for the current third quarter was $1,461,000, up from $1,000,000 in the year-ago quarter.

title: FEDERAL OFFICIALS REPORT THE CENSUS LAGS SIGNIFICANTLY
description: With hundreds of thousands of census forms not delivered to the proper addresses and with millions of people not returning the completed forms, Federal officials said today that the 1990 count of the United States population is lagging significantly.

title: INB Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CBS Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $200,000 from an extinguishment of debt.

title: Nissan Car Priced
description: The Nissan Motor Corporation's Infiniti division said its new four-door luxury sports sedan will cost about $20,000 when it is offered for sale this fall in the United States. The public today got its first look at the car, called the G20, at the New York Automobile Show. The front-wheel-drive sedan is intended as a less-expensive alternative to Infiniti's M30 and Q45 models, which sell for $23,500 and $38,000, respectively. William Bruce, vice president and general manager of the Infiniti division, said the G20 was intended to compete with less-expensive models of European makes like BMW, Volvo and Mercedes-Benz.

title: New Strategies for Military Suppliers
description: During the last round of military budget cuts, in the 1970's, the nation's military contractors diversified into everything from canoes and buses to coffins and solar energy. Now that a new round of cuts is likely, the companies are staying closer to home. They are scrambling to repackage and find new outlets for products once thought attractive primarily for fighting the cold war.

title: Profit Up 68% At Fannie Mae
description: The nation's largest investor in home mortgages, the Federal National Mortgage Association, today reported a record first-quarter profit of $277 million, a rise of 68 percent from the comparable period last year.

title: An Exciting Ground Cover Needn't Rip the Shingles Off
description: THE dullest word I can think of in the gardener's vocabulary is ground covers - those plants, other than turf grasses, that fill in spaces where weeds would otherwise grow or the sight of dirt might offend the tidy eye.

title: Miller Expanding Brand
description: The Miller Brewing Company announced this week that it would expand sales of its new low-calorie Genuine Draft Light beer into 10 states. Genuine Draft Light, which capitalizes on the success of Miller's fast-growing regular Genuine Draft brand, was introduced in several test markets last July. Milwaukee-based Miller said the beer would be sold statewide in Alaska, Arizona, California, Colorado, Hawaii, Idaho, Nevada, Oregon, Utah and Washington.

title: New Agency Planned For Moosehead Beer
description: The Guinness Import Company said yesterday that it would soon name a new agency for its Moosehead brand beer, which had been advertised by McCann-Erickson. Guinness acquired the brand earlier this year when it bought All Brand Importers from Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. A spokeswoman for McCann-Erickson said the account had billed $3 million to $4 million.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Higgins to Join N.B.A.
description: Sean Higgins, who helped the University of Michigan win the national championship a year ago, said yesterday that he had withdrawn from school and would make himself available for the National Basketball Association draft. Higgins, a 6-foot-9-inch junior, played both forward and guard during his three seasons with the Wolverines. During the 1989-90 season, he averaged 14 points and 3.6 rebounds a game.

title: Pepsico Out of South Africa Following Failure of Bottler
description: Pepsico Inc. is ending its small soft-drink business in South Africa, following the failure of its Cape Town bottler.

title: Artfully Built Nests Await Feathering
description: LAURA FOREMAN has designed a series of whimsical houses for leafy sites around Manhattan. The city is a second home for a couple of her prospective clients, the house wrens that fly in seasonally on business or on pleasure. Others, like the house sparrows, have their primary residence in New York. This being spring, the birds are house hunting, which is where Ms. Foreman and a gardening group called the Green Guerillas come in.

title: L. Luria & Son Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 3
description: Results in the latest fiscal year ended Feb. 3, included an extraordinary credit of $806,000, or 15 cents a share. The company said in the fiscal year ended Jan. 28, 1989, an accounting change increased net income by $357,000, or 6 cents a share. Results in the 1989 fourth quartet and fiscal year included an extraordinary loss of $1,444,000.

title: Bond Corp. Reports Big Loss
description: Alan Bond's beleaguered flagship company, Bond Corporation Holdings, today reported a loss of 758.15 million Australian dollars ($580 million in United States currency) for the second half of last year.

title: Brazil Reform Seen Hurting U.S. Earnings
description: Brazil's new economic reform program, which in three weeks has brought Latin America's largest economy to a near standstill, is expected to have a significant impact on American companies as well.

title: 'Smart' Cars and Highways To Help Unsnarl Gridlock
description: Predicting a doubling of traffic in the next three decades, Federal highway officials are actively promoting a major program of computerization and automation that would fundamentally alter the designs of vehicles and highways.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY

title: Richard M. Kain, an Authority On James Joyce, Is Dead at 81
description: Richard M. Kain, an authority on James Joyce, died on April 5 at his home in Louisville, Ky. He was 81 years old.

title: U.S. Trust Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Wang to Sell Unit
description: Wang Laboratories Inc. agreed in principle to sell its Wang Financial Information Services Corporation unit for an undisclosed amount. Wang said it expected to record a book loss on the transaction, which would be reflected in third-quarter results. The buyer is a new corporation formed by Infotechnology Inc. in conjunction with Financial News Network and United Press International. Proceeds will be used to reduce Wang's bank group debt and to increase the company's cash position. The unit includes the Shark professional market quotation business. Wang said it continues to actively negotiate the sale of other nonstrategic assets.

title: Employee Benefit reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After an extraordinary tax loss of $310,136 for the quarter and an extraordinary tax credit of $626,586, or 11 cents a share, for the 9 months, and both the quarter and 9 months included a charge of $10.9 million related to the discontinuance of a business line. c-Net income and included extraordinary tax credits of $104,000, or 2 cents a share, and $197,000, or 5 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Review/Art;   An Eccentric With a Direct Line to the Soul
description: In the famous 1913 Armory Show in New York City, Albert Pinkham Ryder, then 66 years old, was the only American artist whose work was hung in the honored Old Masters gallery. His small visionary landscapes and marine paintings shared the walls with works by Cezanne, van Gogh, Gauguin and Redon, as well as by Ingres, Delacroix and Manet, the French fathers and grandfathers of the modern movement. By then Ryder was a legend in the nascent Manhattan art world, an eccentric who kept collectors and patrons at bay while he reworked canvases for years, sometimes until the their paint-laden surfaces threatened to disintegrate. He was also profoundly admired as someone who had lived a solitary, impoverished life devoted to art alone.

title: Fluff 'n' Stuff on Opening Day
description: It was the opening of the baseball season, the sun shone - except, of course, in Chicago, where it was a typically gray, windy, mitten-required opening day - the players ran to their positions, the fans ran to their seats, or to shelter under the stands, and the air was filled with cries of ''Play Ball!'' and other glorious nonsense.

description: The Justice Department said today that it had filed a lawsuit against the Northrop Corporation, accusing the company of overbilling the Navy for work on the F/A-18 fighter-bomber.

title: Port Authority Set to Name Ex-Byrne Aide as Chairman
description: Richard C. Leone, a former New Jersey State Treasurer, is expected to be elected today to head the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, the far-flung agency that runs everything from the World Trade Center to its own rail line under the Hudson River.

title: RJR Nabisco Bonds Jump
description: Prices of some bonds of RJR Nabisco Inc. jumped more than three points yesterday on heavy volume amid rumors that Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company was planning to buy back an entire issue of the bonds.

title: Beijing Journal;   Painting America: The Unbeautiful and Damned
description: The Chinese press has been writing of late about a pugnacious but morally decrepit nation that wantonly invades other countries, a land where citizens kill family members for insurance money and dogs can serve as elected officials.

title: Graf Routs Temesvari
description: Steffi Graf, who seems able to live without her sport as easily as she dominates it, said tonight that the only thing she missed about tennis during her two months away from it was the competition. Ironically, she did not get much of that from Andrea Temesvari today in their third-round match at the Bausch & Lomb championships. Graf decimated Temesvari, 6-0, 6-1, in the time it took for the sun to set behind the west bleachers.

title: A Proposal And An Idea
description: President Bush at last has seized the lead in arms control negotiations by proposing the ultimate abolition of land-based missiles with more than one nuclear warhead. It's to be hoped that the Soviet Union's first, negative reaction will not turn Congress and the Administration in the other direction.

title: Sutton Is Hired
description: Eddie Sutton, out of basketball for a year after his forced resignation from Kentucky, was hired yesterday as the Oklahoma State coach. The board of regents met for almost 90 minutes and then voted by 7-1 to hire Sutton as the school's 16th basketball coach.

title: Kurt Masur to Head New York Philharmonic
description: The East German conductor Kurt Masur has been appointed to succeed Zubin Mehta as music director of the New York Philharmonic, starting with the 1992-93 season. The appointment, which surprised many in the music world, was announced yesterday by Stephen Stamas, the chairman of the Philharmonic's board. The decision ends a search that has lasted almost two years.

title: Soviets Buy More Wheat
description: The Soviet Union has bought an additional 175,000 metric tons of United States wheat at subsidized prices for delivery through mid-May under a long-term grain supply agreement, the Agriculture Department said today. F. Paul Dickerson, general sales manager for the department's Foreign Agricultural Service, said the wheat had been sold by three private companies, which would receive subsidies under the department's Export Enhancement Program.

description: The Army said today that it had charged a paratrooper with premeditated murder and aggravated assault during the invasion of Panama. It was the first time since the Vietnam War that a soldier was charged with murder in a combat situation.

title: Market Place;   Rulings May Aid Waste Companies
description: IN the next few months, the Environmental Protection Agency is expected to set stiff new standards for the nation's 6,000 landfills, which store 160 million tons of municipal solid waste, mostly household trash, every year. That could be good news for the handful of publicly traded companies that have invested in high-tech holes in the ground, including Waste Management Inc., Browning-Ferris Industries, the Chambers Development Company and Laidlaw Inc.

title: Violence in Kashmir Intensifying; India-Pakistan Relations Worsen
description: The Muslim campaign for the independence of Kashmir from India spread to Bombay today with a bomb attack that wounded 34 people and brought Indian relations with Pakistan to an angrier level.

description: Space agency officials met today to discuss the problems that prevented the launching of the space shuttle Discovery on Tuesday, but they did not reschedule the mission.

title: Allied Bankshares reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A Georgian House Comes Of Age Again
description: LEAD: THE parish of Fitzrovia in the West End has been home to artists and exiles since the 18th century, when much of it was built. Many of its buildings face north and make ideal studios. The White Tower Cafe on Percy Street is a well-known meeting place for artists. And along the street, there is a terrace of Georgian houses where Augustus John, Wyndham Lewis, Duncan Grant and Vanessa Bell once lived.

title: Ames Layoff Plan
description: The troubled Ames Department Stores Inc. said it planned to lay off about 50 employees at its headquarters. The company also said an additional 150 vacant positions would not be filled. Ames, which is based in Rocky Hill, Conn., near Hartford, announced earlier this week that it expected to lose $228 million for the year that ended on Jan. 27 and that it planned to reduce expenses. The company also suspended its dividend payment. Ames's share price rose 12.5 cents yesterday, to $2.50, on the New York Stock Exchange, where it was the most active issue, with almost 2.3 million shares traded.

title: Stake in Renault Nearer for Volvo
description: The French Cabinet cleared the path for a new law that would allow Volvo of Sweden to take a 25 percent stake in the state car maker Renault. It approved a legal framework strictly limiting the opening of Renault's capital to 25 percent and stipulating that the state should retain 75 percent of its voting rights, a Government spokesman, Louis Le Pensec, said.

title: Novellus Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
The Fame Lives On (In Fact, It Lives Here)
description: FINDING a suitable, affordable place to live in New York is a job to be approached with caution: land mines of all kinds lurk in unlikely corners; awful woes are discovered only after one has moved in.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Romania Advises King Michael to Forgo His Visit
description: The Government said today that the return of King Michael to Romania on Thursday could ''exacerbate existing conflicts'' here, and it advised him not to make the trip.

title: Freed Rapist Accused of Theft
description: Lawrence Singleton, a convicted rapist whose release from prison caused a furor in California when several communities chased him out of town, has been arrested and accused of trying to steal a $10 camera. Mr. Singleton, 62 years old, was not jailed after his arrest on Sunday at a drugstore in Brandon but was given a notice to appear in court May 2 on the misdemeanor charge of petty theft, the authorities said.

title: Two Enter Guilty Pleas In Tax-Fraud Scheme
description: Two businessmen have pleaded guilty to engaging in a tax-fraud scheme that involved more than $4 billion in rigged and bogus transactions in Treasury bills and other Government securities, the United States Attorney in Manhattan announced yesterday.

title: Bush Bars Deportations
description: President Bush issued an executive order today barring the deportation of Chinese students from the United States to spare them possible punishment at home. Mr. Bush promised last week to issue the order, which is effective immediately.

title: Brenco Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Washington Talk;   Execution Case Poses Classic Test for Court
description: If a panel of Hollywood screenwriters - or law professors, for that matter - set out to create a case to test the premises of the current debate over death penalty appeals, they could hardly top the case of Robert Alton Harris.

title: Pathe Getting More Loan Aid
description: The Pathe Communications Corporation said yesterday that Time Warner Inc. had agreed to help it raise $200 million for film production.

description: American businesses plan to increase spending on plant and equipment by a strong 7.6 percent this year, the Government said today in a report reflecting renewed optimism about the economy.

title: Corrections

title: James McConnell, Psychology Teacher And Researcher, 64
description: Dr. James V. McConnell, a retired professor of psychology at the University of Michigan who wrote ''Understanding Human Behavior,'' a textbook used widely in college psychology courses, died of a heart attack on Monday at St. Joseph's Mercy Hospital in Ann Arbor, Mich. He was 64 years old and lived in Scio Township, Mich.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   Learning From Japan
description: On the high-definition television screen in Sony's Shinagawa studio, a wine glass shimmers with spectacular clarity. In Fanuc's canary yellow plant at the foot of Mount Fuji, an aisle of new robot arms twist and turn in the disjointed calisthenics of their test program. In Nissan's vast automated warehouse at Oppama, a computer sends Maximas and Infinitis to a waiting cargo ship.

title: Reviews/Music;   Branford Marsalis Band
description: The saxophonist Branford Marsalis's show at the Miller Theater on Saturday night confirmed several things that were suggested at his recent engagement at the Village Vanguard. For one, he's leading one of the best groups in jazz. And for another, the jazz audience is rapidly getting younger.

title: Jury Gets Family-Slayer Case
description: The jury in the John List murder trial deliberated for six hours today before being sent home for the night by Judge William L'E. Wertheimer of Superior Court.

title: Reviews/Music;   Power vs. Idealism in Bolcom's 'Cinema Paradise'
description: The composer William Bolcom in a recent article talked of the continuing evolution of a musical comedy: ''It never stops. Everybody comes in and has got something to say.''

title: Calendar: Where Radicalism Took Root
description: A report in the Calendar column of The Home Section on Thursday about two lectures on bookbinding at the Place des Antiquaires misstated the time. The lectures, on Wednesday and on April 25, begin at 2 P.M., not 6. Section C; Page 7, Column 1; Home Desk

title: Harold Ballard, 86, Feisty Owner Of Toronto Maple Leafs, Is Dead
description: Harold Ballard, the owner of the Toronto Maple Leafs of the National Hockey League and a man described by his team's fact book as ''one of the most loved and hated men in Canada,'' died yesterday in Toronto. He was 86 years old and had spent most of the last two years in and out of hospitals because of diabetes-related heart problems.

title: 1,500 Attend Funeral of Courageous AIDS Fighter
description: More than 1,500 friends and admirers, including Barbara Bush and Michael Jackson, attended the funeral today for Ryan White, the 18-year-old AIDS patient who taught the nation a lesson in courage.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I believe that most musicians who know me know that in rehearsal I am quite tough. But I am still a friend.''

title: CHRONICLE
description: ANTONINA TUMKOVSKY, a strict but beloved teacher at the School of American Ballet, has been appointed to the Mae L. Wien Memorial Chair. The chair, awarded for one year to a distinguished teacher at the school, was established by LAWRENCE WIEN in honor of his wife, a patron of the dance. Mrs. Tumkovsky began teaching at the school in 1949, when she emigrated from the Soviet Union. She had been a soloist with the Kiev State Theater of Opera and Ballet.

The Justice Department's response to the $1.25 billion deal, in which the nation's second-largest long-distance company would buy the No. 4 company, is widely seen as a test case of the Bush Administration's antitrust policy. ''If you're going to challenge a merger, this would be the one,'' said a former regulator who asked not to be identified.

description: Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were unchanged to slightly up for the week ended yesterday.

title: An Old Liberal, a New Sermon
description: Robert B. Reich is on the stump again. His audience is a cross section of the Washington establishment: nearly 80 lobbyists, politicians, businessmen, economists, union leaders and journalists. description: b-Net income

title: Big Dipper Combines Punk With Melody
description: Big Dipper, a rock-and-roll quartet from Boston that will perform tonight at the Knitting Factory, pulls its inspiration from sources as varied as punk-rock, American history, the Billboard charts, romantic poetry and PBS. Its members are musical contortionists: they love to toy with extremes, juxtaposing ferocious guitar noise with celestial vocal harmonies or planting a delicate melody in jagged rhythm. Already established favorites on the club circuit and college radio stations, the band makes its major-label debut later this month with ''Slam,'' a sonic romper-room of colliding dynamic extremes and witty, irreverent lyrics.

title: All-Mozart Concert
description: Jens Nygaard will conduct the Jupiter Symphony in an all-Mozart program, tonight at 8 at Alice Tully Hall. The program includes the Overture to ''La Finta Giardiniera'' (K. 196), the Divertimento in D (K. 251), German Dances and the Piano Concerto No. 9 in E flat, with Claude Frank as soloist. Mr. Frank is replacing the pianist Constance Geanakoplos, who was to have made her New York debut at this concert but had to cancel because of a hand injury. Tickets are $10. Information: 362-1911.
