title: UAL to Cut Some Fares
description: United Airlines said on Wednesday that it was reducing its discount fares between points in the Northeast and California by an average of 15 percent for travel on May 1 through June 11. The new round-trip fares will be $358 from noon on Mondays through noon on Thursdays and $398 for the rest of the week. Those are reductions of $60 and $70 from current fares, United said.

title: Review/Film;   Romance Blooms in a Yogurt War
description: On the evidence of several recent films, the world is full of button-down businessmen ready to turn weak as kittens when the right woman comes along. Or the wrong woman - and the more wrong, the better, as in ''Pretty Woman'' and ''Too Beautiful for You,'' in which a prostitute and a plain-looking secretary are the respective temptresses. The latest in this line is ''Mama, There's a Man in Your Bed,'' which finds the chief executive of a French yogurt company becoming enamored of the woman who cleans his office. He is white. She is black.

title: Hilton Hotels reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Former Teacher Is Charged In Abuse of Pupils in Bronx
description: A former elementary school teacher was arrested yesterday and charged with fondling six students at a Bronx public school, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article on the Company News page of Business Day yesterday about a struggle for control of the Del Webb Corporation referred incorrectly to a newly nominated director, Hugh F. Culverhouse Jr. He is a director of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers football team. His father is the owner.

title: Karen S. Druckman, a Lawyer, Weds
description: Karen Sue Druckman, the daughter of Muriel Topaz Druckman and Jacob Druckman of Milford, Conn., was married yesterday in a civil ceremony at the Municipal Building in New York to Patrick Jeanneret, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Willy Jeanneret of Geneva.

title: Iomega Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
Changes Urged to Cut Delays at Airports
description: Alarmed by the growing number of flight delays in the New York area, airlines are pressuring the Government to revise the region's air traffic control system, much the way it did in Chicago last year. But some of the proposed changes are already meeting resistance from controllers.

title: DH Technology reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Against the Grain
description: The Soviet Union, which has always promptly paid hard cash for the commodities it purchases in the West, seems to have fallen almost one half-billion dollars behind in payments due to grain exporters in the past month.

title: Review/Photography;   Fashion and Glamour in 3 Shows
description: AS if egged on by increasing doses of sunlight, exhibitions of photography seem to have sprung up like so many rogue narcissus this month. Appropriately, many of the shows that are on view this weekend are fashionable blooms, in that they take their cues largely from fashion and its amiable cohort, glamour.

title: George Haslerud, 83, Psychology Professor
description: George M. Haslerud, a retired psychology professor at the University of New Hampshire, died Tuesday at Wentworth-Douglas Hospital in Dover, N.H., after a short illness. He was 83 years old and lived in Durham.

title: Computer Networks Open New Worlds
description: To the Editor:

title: Goodrich Net Slides In Quarter
description: The B.F. Goodrich Company, now a specialty chemical company and a major producer of resins, yesterday reported a 69.4 percent drop in first-quarter earnings, a result of lower prices and higher costs for raw materials.

title: U.S. Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums

title: Gordon F. Vawter, 67, Pediatric Pathologist
description: Gordon Fuller Vawter, a pediatric pathologist, died of lymphoma on Wednesday at a cancer center in Gloucester, Mass. He was 67 years old and lived in Newton, Mass., and Gloucester.

title: A Gunshot in the Dark Links 2 Disparate Lives: Officer Gary Spath
description: George Spath, a township police officer for 26 years, sat with neighbors in his living room today and remembered how he had told his son, Gary, that being a policeman could be tough.

title: Entronics Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income The company said the continuing revenue gains are due to their June 30, 1989 acquisition of Inotek and its subsequent acquisitions of Pacific Indicator Co. of Chicago on Aug. 4, 1989 and Sesco, on Nov. 3, 1989.

title: Kentucky Utilities reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $11,470,000.

title: At Last, Yankees Open Season, and Win, Too
description: After a lockout, a rainout and a snowout, the Yankees stepped into their season with a 6-4 victory over the Cleveland Indians yesterday before 50,114 fans at the Stadium.

title: Door Revolves Again At Top of Winnebago
description: The revolving door at Winnebago Industries turned again yesterday, and out went Richard D. Conner as president and chief executive.

title: DEALS
description: BASKETBALL

title: Restaurants
description: Paper Moon Milano

title: Note to Readers
description: The Op-Ed page welcomes unsolicited manuscripts. Because of the volume of submissions, however, we regret that we cannot acknowledge receipt of or return articles unless they are accompanied by a self-addressed, stamped envelope. If manuscripts are accepted for publication, authors will be notified within two weeks.

title: Marshall & Ilsley Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: All figures have been restated to account for the acquisition of M&I First National Bank of Cudahy in October 1989 and accounted for on the pooling of interests basis.

title: TV Weekend;   Recalling Tudor's Dance Mastery
description: One of the most influential figures in the history of 20th-century dance, the choreographer Antony Tudor achieved maximum impact through remarkably few masterworks. His two greatest ballets - ''Jardin aux Lilas'' (1936) and ''Dark Elegies'' (1937) - were created five decades ago. They are being performed with adoring care in tonight's ''Tudor Evening With American Ballet Theater.'' The ''Dance in America'' production is being presented on ''Great Performances'' at 9 P.M. on Channel 13.

title: 'Piano Lesson' Wins Drama Pulitzer as 21 Prizes Are Given
description: ''The Piano Lesson,'' August Wilson's Broadway-bound play about the black experience in America as seen through a prism of conflict between a brother and sister over their family's slavery-era heirloom piano, won the 1990 Pulitzer Prize for drama yesterday.

title: Sweet Nothings, for Spring or Anytime
description: EASTER weekend invites the indulgence of a leisurely late-morning or late-afternoon pastry with a coffee or tea. While New York cannot boast the number of eat-in bakeries or pastry shops found in European cities, it nonetheless has its share. Here is a sampling, divided geographically; shops on the West Side and East Side of Manhattan are listed from north to south.

title: Review/Film;   Things That Can Happen When People Fall in Love
description: Love that blooms in Murky Springs, Mo., may be no more predictable than it is anywhere else, but it is positively more apocalyptic. Elaine, a petty thief, is the daughter of country-and-western singers who emigrated from central Europe, and Joe is a gun-carrying young man who seems descended from James Dean. That's not the strange part. When these two get together, the stars are so jolted out of alignment that the results include tornadoes, a tidal wave, a solar eclipse that lasts 23 hours and a meteor that smashes through a car's windshield, allowing easy access to a swarm of locusts.

title: Sherwin-Williams Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Savings Bank, White Plains, said it had authorized Kropschot Financial Services, Philadelphia, a merger and acquisition advisory firm, to solicit offers for Amsave Credit Corp., its wholly owned unit that specializes in commercial and leasing finance.

title: Garrison Aims to Shape Up
description: For Zina Garrison, tennis has become a balancing act. She wants to enjoy life as a newlywed, but she doesn't want to be assigned a crash diet before every important tournament. ''My husband,'' she explained, ''is thin. And when we go out to dinner, I try to eat everything he eats.''

title: Time for Change
description: To return to the United States from a visit to South Africa is to experience a drastic difference in political climates. In South Africa, the most profound assumptions of the society are changing. In the United States, the political system is frozen.

title: Poindexter: Disclosure With Justice
description: The successful prosecution of former national security adviser John Poindexter is a triumph for valued but often conflicting principles. One is the public's right to know, which is keenest when a scandal like Iran-contra erupts. Another is the need to bring wrongdoers to justice. A third is the constitutional protection against self-incrimination.

title: Nicklaus Leaves Field Behind in Senior Championship
description: The pressure of winning his first senior event is off. His game is in tune. He designed the course, and his chief 50-and-over competitors have gone off their games.

title: Review/Film;   'Vital Signs,' On Doctors In Love And Conflict
description: Martians watching ''Vital Signs'' would surmise that doctors are earthlings who look cute in blue jeans, stalk purposefully as they talk and are careful to have every hair in place, especially around the eyebrows. They might also imagine that medicine is an offshoot of the military, since this film's doctors often engage in supercompetitive tough talk - that is, when they aren't flirting madly or indulging in operating-room humor. ''The tension is so thick in here I don't know whether to cut it or the patient!'' is an example of the latter.

title: Frederick K. Daniel, Chemist, 79
description: Frederick K. Daniel, a chemist who founded Daniel Products, a paint manufacturing company in Jersey City, died of complications of Parkinson's disease on March 27 at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 79 years old.

title: Walker and Ryan Are Dropped As Jets Move in New Direction
description: The Jets, who have a new coach and new general manager, will have a new look on the field, too. Yesterday, they cut loose 34-year-old Wesley Walker, their outstanding wide receiver for his 13 pro seasons, and 34-year-old Pat Ryan, their mostly backup quarterback for his 12 pro seasons.

title: Lilly Ends Output Of 60 Products
description: Eli Lilly & Company has discontinued manufacturing 60 products and versions of products, according to a notification letter sent to drug wholesalers around the country. Representatives of several pharmaceutical wholesaling companies said that the products involved were either old or slow-selling and that the manufacturing halts would have little or no financial impact. Lilly's stock rose 87.5 cents a share today, to $68.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: King World Productions reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $2,905,000, or 11 cents a share. The company said net income for the latest quarter was affected by non-cash charges for amortization and depreciation from the acquisition of WIVB-TV, which decreased earnings by $2.1 million.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Parliament admits joint responsibility on behalf of the people for the humiliation, expulsion and murder of Jewish women, men and children. We feel sad and ashamed and acknowledge this burden of German history. We ask the Jews of the world to forgive us,''

title: The Secret Sex Life of the Skunk Cabbage
description: To the Editor:

title: Trial to Begin For 2 in Killing In Bensonhurst
description: A computer programmer from Park Slope and a secretary from Williamsburg were chosen to fill the last two seats in a Brooklyn jury box yesterday, clearing the way for the start of the Bensonhurst murder trial on Monday.

title: A Clarification
description: A recent editorial said Senator Jake Garn had ''demanded'' that last year's savings and loan bailout legislation include the appointment of his longtime aide M. Danny Wall as director of the new Office of Thrift Supervision, and that ''the White House didn't fight him.'' The editorial incorrectly implied that the proposal came from Senator Garn. It was originated by Treasury officials, without consulting the Senator.

title: First Wachovia Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: At the Movies
description: Hutton's Other Hats

title: Unrest Reported in Muslim Areas of China; Foreigners Are Barred
description: Reports of unrest in Muslim areas of western China and of a ban on visits by foreigners to the area continued to circulate today, but the Foreign Ministry declined to comment.

title: Why Langston Left
description: Even the lure of a no-hitter against his former team could not keep Mark Langston from taking himself out of the game.

title: Vincent Bans Rose From Phillies' Reunion
description: Pete Rose, the career leader in hits, will not be allowed to take part in the 10th-anniversary reunion of the Philadelphia Phillies' only World Series champions Aug. 3 and 4 because of his lifetime ban from baseball for gambling on several sports.

title: Cake for Sale to Keep Legal Aid Free
description: Public defenders here, whose job is to represent poor people, are unhappy with a Missouri state policy requiring them to ask clients for voluntary cash contributions. So this week they found another way to raise money, and to signal their displeasure: They held a bake sale outside the municipal courthouse.

title: Excerpts From East Berlin Statement of Apology
description: Following are excerpts from the statement approved today by the East German Parliament, as translated by Reuters:

title: Sale of Eakins Work Won't Be at Sotheby's
description: The Modern Art Museum of Fort Worth announced late yesterday that it had withdrawn Thomas Eakins's ''Swimming Hole,'' painted about 1885, from Sotheby's in New York, where it was to have been auctioned on May 24.

title: On Stage
description: After 'Sarafina!'

title: Islanders Evasive as Sutter Sits Out
description: Two days ago, after leading the Islanders to victory with two goals in an overtime game that lasted more than four hours, Brent Sutter practiced with as much energy as he had displayed the night before.

title: Stop the Shell Game With Pension Funds
description: To the Editor:

title: Profits Rise by 48% at Intel On Demand for Its PC Chips
description: Despite a continuing slump in the personal computer market, the Intel Corporation today reported record first-quarter earnings. Intel's strong earnings, which exceeded the highest Wall Street estimates, were driven by demand for its 32-bit microprocessors, the 80386 and 80486, which form the heart of the most powerful PC's available.

title: Retail Sales Fell by 0.6% In March
description: In the first back-to-back decline in more than three years, retail sales fell six-tenths of 1 percent in March, as business declined in virtually all sectors except for food stores, the Commerce Department reported yesterday. In February, seasonally adjusted sales had fallen three-tenths of 1 percent from January.

title: Quietly but Intensely, Bombing Inquiry Is Pursued
description: The investigation into mail bombings that killed a Federal judge in Alabama and a Georgia civil rights lawyer has become more low-keyed if no less persistent in recent weeks as investigators present evidence to two grand juries while quietly pursuing other leads.

title: Fans Salute Winfield And LaPoint
description: Dave Winfield and Dave LaPoint made conspicuous returns to the Yankees' lineup yesterday, and the fans acknowledged them with conspicuous salutes. For Winfield, the reception produced a ''surge of energy, surge of strength.'' For LaPoint, the fans' positive reaction provided relief.

title: EA Engineering, Science and Technology Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Gains Exceed Expectations At Chemical
description: The Chemical Banking Corporation surprised investors and analysts yesterday by issuing its first-quarter earnings report sooner than expected. The results were also stronger than expected, thanks to a decline in the level of problem loans and to a profit at its Texas bank subsidiary.

title: Southland Sees Losses
description: The Southland Corporation, the troubled owner of 7-Eleven convenience stores, said today that it did not expect to become profitable until the end of 1993 even if its bondholders agreed to forgo about $1.6 billion in interest payments through 1997.

title: Rubbermaid Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Ewing Is Too Much For Pacers to Handle
description: Patrick Ewing has been the Knicks' inspiration all season. At times his play is so dominant, he is what winning and losing are all about.

title: Automatic Data Processing reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
The Grande Bande
description: Frederick Renz will conduct the Grande Bande, an early-instruments orchestra, in an Easter program that includes Haydn's ''Passione'' Symphony and Mozart's Symphony No. 40 and Piano Concerto No. 17 (K. 453), tomorrow evening at 8 o'clock at Alice Tully Hall. John Gibbons will be the fortepiano soloist in the concerto. Tickets are $16.50 and $18.50. Information: 874-6770.

title: Marriott Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 23
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $8,000,000, or 7 cents a share. There were no discontinued operations in the latest first quarter. Results for the 1989 first quarter included the airline catering operations divested in December 1989, as well as lodging transaction gains. Excluding the impact of these items, earnings per share from continuing operations were up 23 percent in the 1990 first quarter.

title: Bush Suffers Early Glaucoma In His Left Eye, Doctors Say
description: President Bush was found to have ''an early glaucoma of his left eye'' in a routine physical examination yesterday at Bethesda Naval Hospital, the White House said in a statement.

title: Stop the Shell Game With Pension Funds;   Mostly Employee Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Intel Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company attributed the improved results to strong demand for its 32-bit microcomputer components.

title: Auctions
description: A Racy Red Ferrari

title: Dancer's Death Inspires Creation of Crisis Fund
description: Monika Beerle came to New York City from St. Gallen, Switzerland, to become a dancer. She had been studying at the Martha Graham School of Contemporary Dance in New York for about a year when she moved into an apartment on the Lower East Side. Two months later, last August, she was killed. A roommate she hardly knew has been charged with her murder.

title: Estonian Parliament Votes To End All Military Service
description: The Estonian Parliament has voted overwhelmingly to end all military service in the republic, in a move certain to increase tension between Moscow and the independence-minded Baltic republics, Estonians said today.

title:
Conversions in the Ladies' Mile;

Condos Built in 100-Year-Old 20th St. Structure
description: LEAD: The fashionable place to shop in Manhattan below 23d Street in the late 19th century was an area known as the Ladies' Mile. The major department stores moved uptown after World War I and retailing was largely replaced by manufacturing. Now the area recently designated as the Ladies' Mile Historic District, roughly from 15th Street to 24th Street and Broadway to the Avenue of the

title: Japan Trade Surplus Up
description: After 11 months of decline Japan's trade surplus climbed in March, but economists said it was because the month's imports were being compared with an unusually large amount of imports in March 1989.

title: NEW YORK AGREES TO END BORROWING FOR ROUTINE COSTS
description: The Governor, the State Comptroller and New York's legislative leaders said today that they had agreed to abandon the state's longstanding practice of borrowing billions of dollars each spring to cover routine expenses like tax refunds and payments to local school districts.

title: Theme Park For California
description: A British and American group said this week that it would develop in Northern California a $2 billion resort and theme park that is a cross between Disneyland and Williamsburg, Va., the re-created Revolutionary War community.

title: Oil Worries Increasing For OPEC
description: A number of OPEC oil ministers expressed anxiety today at the sharp fall in oil prices over the last few days, hinting at the possibility of holding a special meeting to look into ways of propping prices up.

title: Gap Provides Disclosure Respite
description: The top 11,000 employees in the executive branch of the Federal Government, who have previously been required to file financial disclosure forms, have been told that they might not have to do so this year.

title: Youth Is Killed By Theft Victim In Subway Car
description: One of four youths attempting to rob a man at gunpoint on a subway train in Brooklyn was shot and killed last night when the robbery victim pulled out a pistol and fired several shots at the youths, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: An art review in Weekend on March 16 about the installation by the artists' group General Idea at the Koury-Wingate Gallery misidentified the materials used to make the figures of three baby seals. As a letter from the gallery has pointed out, they were synthetic fibers, not lambskin.

title: Lecture With Music
description: The pianist Dick Hyman will give a lecture program called ''And Then I Wrote . . . '' at the 92d Street Y, on Lexington Avenue, tomorrow evening at 8. Among Mr. Hyman's works are the scores for the films ''Moonstruck,'' ''Zelig'' and ''The Purple Rose of Cairo'' and several ballet scores. Mr. Hyman will be joined by the pianist Derek Smith for a demonstration of two-piano jazz improvisation. Tickets are $15. Information: 996-1100.

title: Treasuries Slip in Thin Trading
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds dipped in extremely thin trading yesterday, as dealers ignored a weaker-than-expected report on retail sales and focused on a long holiday weekend instead.

title: The New York Times Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $1,975,000, or 2 cents a share. Discontinued operations reflected the sale of NYT Cable TV, which was sold in August 1989. The company attributed the earnings decline to lower advertising linage at The New York Times due to continuing weakness in the New York region's economy, a 5-cent-a-share reduction in earnings from the July 1989 McCall's acquisition, and 8-cent- a-share reduction in earnings due to increased depreciation and interest expense related primarily to the completion of the building for The New York Times's new automated color production and distribution facility in Edison, N.J., and a newly constructed facility for the Gwinnett (Ga.) Daily News.

title: THE EAST GERMANS ISSUE AN APOLOGY FOR NAZIS' CRIMES
description: As it formally installed the country's first democratic Government, the East German Parliament also ended 40 years of official denial today by accepting joint responsibility for Nazi crimes and expressing willingness to pay reparations to victims and seek diplomatic ties with Israel.

title: Nepal's King Invites Head of Opposition To Engage in Talks
description: In an effort to end a four-day political stalemate, King Birendra invited the leader of Nepal's opposition to join him in direct talks today, apparently on the formation of a new transitional government.

title: Stocks Rise And the Dow Gains 22.07
description: Stock prices advanced yesterday to their best gain in more than a week, with the Dow Jones industrial average climbing 22.07 points, to 2,751.80.

title: Lakeland Industries reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: Order for Hughes
description: Hughes Communications International Inc., a unit of the Hughes Electronics Corporation, a subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation, received a $155 million contract from Brazil to build the country's second-generation telecommunications satellite system. The contract includes two satellites, improvements to a ground control station and training. The satellites will be launched in 1993 and 1994.

title: SHL Systemhouse reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included a $6.9 million provision against amounts receivable from Kinburn Corp. and Kinburn Technology Corp., plus a $25 million writedown of assets. c-Net income Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Japan Banks Face Credit Rating Cut
description: The credit ratings of several major Japanese banks may soon be downgraded because of their exposure to real-estate loans, Moody's Investors Service said today.

title: Derby Contenders in Action This Weekend
description: Mister Frisky heads almost every list of favorites for the Kentucky Derby on May 5 off his victory in the Santa Anita Derby last Saturday and his 16-for-16 record. Just about everyone's next four choices will be racing today and tomorrow.

title: Hostile Bidder Drops Offer for Bond Assets
description: Alan Bond, whose huge Australian business empire has been tottering under a heavy debt burden, escaped today from a difficult situation when the billionaire Kerry Packer withdrew a takeover bid for Mr. Bond's media assets.

title: Year's Best Named
description: Curtis Middleton of St. Thomas Aquinas College was named player of the year and Darrell Halloran of Pace was named coach of the year for the New York-New Jersey area in Division II of the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Akiyoshi Orchestra

title: McDonald's Opens 2d Budapest Unit
description: Hungary's second McDonald's fast-food restaurant opened in an airy railroad station that was built by the company that put up the Eiffel Tower. ''Without exaggeration I can say it is the most beautiful McDonald's in Europe,'' said Endre Fazekas, managing director of the United States-Hungarian joint venture.

title: Collapsing Housing Market Is Taking an Emotional Toll
description: Across the metropolitan region, thousands of people who bought homes during the long housing boom of the 1980's are suffering wrenching emotional and financial hardships as the value of their single largest investment slips away.

title: Electronic Technology Group reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Service Merchandise reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the increase in net losses resulted from expenses associated with the company's recapitalization, which totalled $21.2 million, or 25 cents a share, in the latest quarter.

title: 'Dial-a-Porn' Industry Battles U.S. Restrictions
description: Companies offering telephone lines that specialize in sexually explicit recordings and conversations are challenging a new Federal law that is meant to restrict them.

title: Unaffordable Pork
description: New York State's gaping budget deficit is forcing painful tax increases and cuts in services. An unselfish Legislature would share the pain by forgoing ''member items'' - the annual grab-bag of pet projects for members' home districts.

title: Potlatch Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Captain Admits Sinking Lobster Boat in Plot
description: The captain of the Stonington lobster boat Sophie G, which sank in deep waters south of Long Island in December 1988, pleaded guilty today to charges that he had scuttled the 56-foot vessel in a scheme with the boat's owner to collect $220,000 in insurance.

title: Jose De Vega Jr., Actor and Choreographer, 56
description: Jose De Vega Jr., an actor and choreographer who worked to eliminate ethnic stereotypes from show business, died of AIDS on Sunday at Veterans Memorial Hospital in Westwood. He was 56 years old.

title: Ex-West Virginia Governor Admits Corruption Schemes
description: Former Gov. Arch A. Moore Jr. has been indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges of extortion, mail and tax fraud and obstruction of justice and has agreed to plead guilty in a bargain with the Government.

title: Detroit Drops Convention Bid
description: Debt-ridden Detroit, one of five finalists as the site for the 1992 Democratic National Convention, has withdrawn from consideration, leaving Cleveland, Houston, New Orleans and New York still in the running. The Democratic National Committee has asked that a city seeking the convention commit itself to spending $15 million, said Dorothy Brodie, an assistant to Mayor Coleman Young, and Detroit, which faces a $50 million deficit, cannot afford it.

title: Review/Music;   An Austrian Composer in 1933 and 1951
description: One of the happier ideas for cultural exchange has been the three-year-old Ensemble for Viennese Music New York, which promotes Austrian composers in this city while its sister organization, the American Music Ensemble Vienna, provides corresponding services abroad.

title: Felton L. Gibbons, 60, Art History Professor
description: Dr. Felton Lewis Gibbons, an art historian who taught at Princeton University for more than 20 years, took his own life on Tuesday at his home in Hopewell, N.J., family members said. He was 60 years old.

title: Soviet Military Is Reported To Reassert Itself at Kremlin
description: The Soviet military, unhappy over President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's reforms and its diminished status, is trying to reassert itself in Moscow, specialists from the Rand Corporation said today.

title: How Can Taxi Courts Be Just if Accusations Are Anonymous?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about King Michael's plan to return to Romania misstated his age and the date of his forced abdication. He is 68, not 67, and abdicated on Dec. 30, 1947, not 1945.

title: Brazil Congress Passes Anti-Inflation Plan
description: Brazil's Congress gave a major victory to President Fernando Collor de Mello late Wednesday by passing intact the heart of his Draconian anti-inflation plan. Economists said a severe recession was a certainty.

title: Mongolia Cuts 'Communism'
description: The world's second-oldest ruling Communist Party dropped the word communism from its constitution today and set a new goal of building ''democratic humane socialism.'' An extraordinary congress of the Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party adopted a new party constitution and platform to reflect its recent acceptance of democratic changes and opposition parties. ''Our party remains Marxist-Leninist,'' a spokesman said, however. The party is seeking a new image to keep power in free elections.

title: SmithKline To Sell Yardley
description: SmithKline Beecham P.L.C. said that it had agreed to sell its British-based Yardley-Lentheric Cosmetics business to the Old Bond Street Corporation of the United States for $180 million.

title: CPC International reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earings are based on net income reduced by ESOP preferred stock dividends net of taxes in 1990.

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: The assets of the nation's 508 money market mutual funds decreased by $667.60 million, to $389.86 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 160 institutional funds decreased by $246.20 million, to $91.27 billion. The assets of the 246 general-purpose funds were up by $285.10 million, to $133.52 billion. The 102 broker-dealer funds decreased by $706.50 million, to $165.08 billion, the institute said.

title: NBD Bancorp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Per share amounts have been adjusted to reflect the 3-for-2 split in June 1989.

title: Maxwell Harrison, Surgeon, 76
description: Dr. Maxwell Harrison, an eye, ear, nose and throat surgeon who helped pioneer the use of microsurgery in Queens in trying to restore hearing loss, died of coronary artery disease on Sunday at Long Island Jewish Hospital in Queens. He was 76 years old and lived in Woodmere, L.I.

title: Hull Scores 2 Goals As Blues Win Series
description: Brett Hull had two goals and Peter Zezel a goal and two assists as the St. Louis Blues beat the Toronto Maple Leafs by 4-3 tonight to win the first-round series.

title: 3 Companies to Stop Selling Tuna Netted With Dolphins
description: The nation's three largest sellers of canned tuna announced today that they would stop buying tuna that is caught in nets that also trap and kill dolphins.

title: New Jersey Builder Defaults on Debt
description: The Union Valley Corporation, the troubled New Jersey-based home builder, said it did not expect to make interest payments due May 15 and has defaulted on a $967,000 debt payment to a mortgagee. The company also said it was planning auctions to dispose of about 180 partly completed homes in New Jersey and would probably seek to restructure its debt.

title: Britain Beginning Prison Inquiry As Inmates' Unrest Winds Down
description: As the unrest that has swept Britain's prison system winds down, Government officials are turning to the task of assessing the causes and taking steps to prevent new outbreaks.

title: Against the Sea And the Odds
description: From day one, the odds that the Soviet yacht Fazisi would make it round the world were slim.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   People
description: * Roger W. Yost has been appointed vice president for advertising and sales promotion at Jantzen.

title: Family Slayer Found Guilty Of Top Counts
description: Eighteen years after methodically killing his wife, his mother and his three teen-age children in their Westfield house, John Emil List was convicted today of five counts of first-degree murder.

title: Review/Theater;   After 11 Years, Easter Returns to Radio City
description: The Easter show has returned to Radio City Music Hall, after an 11-year absence, with all the splendor inherent in both holiday and locale. The brisk and awesome 90-minute ''Easter Extravaganza'' accords the holiness of the occasion cathedral-like attention at the outset but then goes its own jolly way, celebrating the holiday in particularly New York terms.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Newspaper Ad Growth
description: Expenditures for newspaper advertising rose 3.8 percent, to $32.37 billion, in 1989, according to preliminary estimates of the Newspaper Advertising Bureau. The increase last year was smaller than in 1988, when newspaper advertising rose about 6 percent from the previous year. For 1989, retail advertising was up 4.4 percent, to $16.88 billion; classified ad spending increased 2.8 percent, to $12.24 billion, and national advertising rose 3.7 percent, to $3.24 billion.

title: 3 Plead Guilty In Bolt Testing
description: A military contracting company and three individuals pleaded guilty this week in Federal court to charges of failing to test bolts for use in combat aircraft, including the F-16 fighter and the B-1B bomber.

title: Jusco Buys Rights For Chain in Japan
description: The Jusco Company, a supermarket operator, agreed with Britain's Body Shop International P.L.C. to set up a chain of franchised shops selling Body Shop toiletry products in Japan. Jusco will set up a subsidiary to manage Body Shop franchises and plans to open its first outlet in Tokyo this fall, it said in a statement.

title: Books of The Times;   Sisters in Hollywood and Art Too Much Like Life
description: His Little Women

title: Article 476390 -- No Title
description: A Federal court awarded more than $2.7 million for damages on Wednesday to the family of a man who died with his son in the crash of an Aeromexico jet after it collided with a small plane over Southern California in 1986.

title: A Century of Cincinnati Esthetics: From Fig Leaves to Fines
description: LEAD: In the 19th century, a certain Mr. Fazzi was once hired to fashion fig leaves for statues that the Ladies' Academy of Art in Cincinnati had imported from Europe. Thus, today's nonstop brouhaha over Robert Mapplethorpe's photographs of nude children and homosexual acts - Cincinnati again - might not amaze the historians of

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday

title: Review/Theater;   50's 'Fanny' Is Revived With All Due Sentiment
description: ''Fanny,'' Harold Rome's musical adaptation of Marcel Pagnol's dramatic trilogy, ''Marius,'' ''Fanny,'' and ''Cesar,'' is a quintessential 1950's musical of the more solemnly romantic sort.

title: New President Named At Software Toolworks
description: Software Toolworks Inc., a five-year-old software company in Chatsworth, Calif., has named Elizabeth Barker as president and chief operating officer.

title: Lippincott Sale Seen By Harper
description: Harper Collins, the publishing subsidiary of Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, announced yesterday that it would sell its J. B Lippincott unit as part of an effort to raise about $500 million to reduce Harper's debt.

title: Havana Journal;   When Castro Talks, the Generation Gap Yawns
description: As Fidel Castro ended a 30-minute speech here recently, aimed primarily at Cuba's youth, many young people in the audience leaped from the seats to shout, ''Socialism or death!''

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Age Hasn't Mellowed This Agency
description: CONTROVERSIAL advertising campaigns are typically the province of young, upstart agencies trying to distinguish themselves in the cluttered precincts of Madison Avenue. The brash ''. . . And she drinks Johnnie Walker'' campaign, whose slice-of-life dialogues have managed to outrage feminists and intrigue gay organizations, may be the older folks' revenge.

title: Alcan's Net Falls Off by 36%
description: Alcan Aluminum Ltd., the world's largest producer of aluminum, said yesterday that lower prices and reduced demand had contributed to a 36 percent drop in first-quarter earnings.

title: For Polonia, A New Leaf And Season
description: The Milwaukee County House of Corrections wasn't that bad, Luis Polonia said: ''Never a jail, never behind bars. It was like a medical center.''

title: Estonia Defies Moscow
description: The Parliament of the Baltic republic voted to bar compulsory service by Estonians in the Soviet armed forces. Page A6.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Described by his doctor as ''in fighting trim,'' LEE ATWATER, the Republican Party chairman, was released from Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx yesterday, after 10 days of treatment for a brain tumor.

title: New Leader Looks To Past At American Symphony
description: ''I DON'T put together programs to show off an orchestra,'' said Catherine Comet, the new music director of the American Symphony Orchestra. ''I hope that the orchestra will be showed off by the program, yes, but it is the music that really comes first.''

title: Par Plans to Buy Rest of Quad Stock
description: The generic-drug maker Par Pharmaceutical Inc. said it would buy the 40 percent of Quad Pharmaceuticals Inc. it does not already own. The deal would make Quad, based in Indianapolis, wholly owned by Par. Par's stock slipped 12.5 cents today, to $5.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Economic Scene;   Why Gorbachev Delays Reforms
description: EMBROILED in the political crisis initiated by Lithuania's bid to secede from the Soviet Union, which hard-liners and anti-reformers are exploiting for their own purposes, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has deferred the decision on whether and how to carry out a ''radical'' reformation of the Soviet economic system.

title: Net of Times Co. Halved in First Quarter
description: The New York Times Company reported yesterday that its net income in the first quarter of 1990 dropped by 50 percent, to $16.6 million, or 22 cents a share, from $33.5 million, or 42 cents a share, in the 1989 period.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Chefs on the Move

title: In Capital, Vows to End Drug War Finger-Pointing
description: William J. Bennett, the national drug policy adviser, and city officials in Washington have informally agreed to end their public quarreling out of fear that it could undercut their already failing showcase effort to curb drug abuse in the nation's capital, Federal and city official say.

title: Our Towns;   The Big Audition: Gotta Sing! Gotta Study!
description: The third and fourth grade boys waiting to audition for the Newark Boys Chorus School were so nervous their synapses were popping out loud. Chris Wiggins had produced a tub of surplus adrenalin and could not sit down. ''I got to walk around,'' he said.

title: KEY RATES
Crash Kills Son, Officer Finds
description: A California Highway Patrol officer responding to a traffic accident on Tuesday found that his 16-year-old son had been killed in the crash, the authorities said. The victim, Timothy Brown, was killed when the truck he was riding in overturned outside this village in Santa Barbara County, said Kevin Dougherty, a Highway Patrol spokesman.

title: Review/Art;   By Jackson Pollock, With and Without Drips
description: In 1950, Jackson Pollock was riding high, widely considered the leader of Abstract Expressionism, America's first truly international art movement. His exhibition that year at the Betty Parsons Gallery included such classic ''drip'' paintings as ''Autumn Rhythm'' and ''One,'' works that now occupy pride of place, respectively, in the permanent collections of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Britain's Inflation Spurts
description: Britain's inflation rate, the scourge of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Conservative Government, rose sharply in March, to 8.1 percent, from 7.5 percent in the previous month, the Government announced today. The annual increase in the retail price index, Britain's main measure of inflation, was the highest since last summer.

title: Business Digest
description: The Economy

title: Blacks' Views of Bush
description: Adults Who...

title: Gambling Profits Give Lift To Earnings at Hilton Hotels
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation reported yesterday that gambling profits had nearly doubled its first-quarter earnings to $25.1 million, or 52 cents a share, compared with $13.1 million, or 27 cents a share, for the corresponding period last year. Revenues rose 18.4 percent, to $266.5 million from $225.1 million.

title: Industrial Funding Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Review/Theater;   Just a Song at Twilight (of the Gods)
description: As an irrepressible recycler of other people's art, Charles Ludlam rewrote ''The Ring of the Nibelung'' to suit the Ridiculous Theatrical Company's purpose. Everett Quinton's revival of ''Der Ring Gott Farblonjet,'' a tragedy turned into a comedy, is the funniest ''Ring'' cycle one is likely to see. The show, which opened last night at the Charles Ludlam Theater, is a tribute to Ludlam's parodistic virtuosity and to the interpretive alchemy of Mr. Quinton, his successor as artistic director of the Ridiculous company.

title: The Pulitzer Prizes
description: THE ARTS

title: How Can Taxi Courts Be Just if Accusations Are Anonymous?;   'Oh, That's Too Much'
description: To the Editor:

title: No Form? What to Do
description: Those who have still not received census forms should call the Census Bureau hot line, 1-800-999-1990, give a name and an address and report failure to receive a form.

title: Americans Find Many Excuses For Not Being Part of the Census
description: From Los Angeles to Des Moines to Boston, one in four people questioned today in an informal sampling around the country told of either not receiving a census form or receiving one but finding it too intrusive, too long and too complicated to fill out.

title: New Taiwan Chief: Signal of Change?
description: When he is inaugurated in May, Lee Teng-hui will step into a six-year presidential term that could oversee a dramatic transformation of this nouveau riche island.

title: Goaltending Looming As Crucial for Devils
description: Since neither the Devils nor the Capitals have been consistently prolific offensively, goaltending will probably decide their playoff series.

title: Umpire Opens Door And Pirates Walk In
description: Barry Lyons, the catcher for the Mets, thought it was a strike. Sid Fernandez, the pitcher, did not want to comment. Neal Heaton, the Pirates' batter, said it was ''right down the middle.''

title: Market Place;   Air Bag Maker A Big Wall St. Hit
description: OEA Inc. makes a small explosive device that triggers the inflation of an automobile air bag milliseconds after a crash, and the Denver-based company's stock price has shot up nearly as fast.

title: Mellon Bank Adds Automated Tellers
description: The Mellon Bank Corporation purchased a regional automated-teller-machine network from the Ameritrust Corporation, Cleveland, for undisclosed terms. Mellon will process transactions for the 19 financial institutions and their 171 machines in the Instanet network. The deal adds 650,000 to 700,000 transactions a month to Mellon's current total of more than 11 million at about 350 institutions nationwide.

title: Medellin Mayor Urges Talks To End Drug War After Blast
description: The Mayor of Medellin called for negotiations to end Colombia's drug war today, a day after a car bomb explosion near the city that the Red Cross said killed 21 people.

title: CBS Sets Role for News Technicians
description: CBS will allow technicians assigned to its news division to continue working exclusively on news programs, a CBS executive said yesterday.

title: GOOD FRIDAY
description: NEW YORK

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bertelsmann Music Group, the music and video subsidiary of the West German media company Bertelsmann A.G., named Lou Maglia president of its new music label, still unnamed, which will be based in Los Angeles.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Accounts
description: * Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Co. of Canada Ltd., to Bozell Palmer Bonner, Toronto, with a budget of $3 million to $4 million.

title: Peripatetic Mayor Barry Is Back, but What's Up?
description: Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. is running.

title: Oakland Journal;   Raiders Now Find Welcome Mat Thin
description: The city that fought so bitterly to keep the Raiders from moving to Los Angeles nine years ago is no longer sure it wants the swaggering football team back.

title: One Brooklyn Rabbi's Long Shadow
description: The last-minute failure of the Israeli Labor Party to form a new government has again focused attention on the role of a charismatic Brooklyn rabbi who asserts an unusual amount of influence in Israel.

title: Daniel P. A. Sweeney, Lawyer, 85
description: Daniel P. A. Sweeney, a retired lawyer and former chief of the New York City Police Department's legal bureau, died on Wednesday at his home in Breezy Point, Queens. He was 85 years old.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Common Stock

title: Corrections
description: The Sports of The Times column on Wednesday about the Yankees' signing of Don Mattingly referred incompletely to the legal status of Howard Spira and his relationship with with George Steinbrenner. Mr. Spira has been indicted, but not yet tried, on charges of extortion.

title: Witness for Prosecution Praises Sharpton for 'the Good Things'
description: A prosecution witness in the criminal fraud case against the Rev. Al Sharpton lauded the minister yesterday for helping poor people in times of crisis and grief.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the expected merger of the nation's two largest ''right to die'' groups misstated the address where they have started joint operations as the National Council on Death and Dying. It is 250 West 57th Street in New York.

title: Black Factions Continue Combat Despite Pretoria's Efforts to Halt It
description: Despite recent promises of action by President F. W. de Klerk, the South African Government has yet to show significant progress in stopping factional fighting that has pushed black communities in Natal province to the brink of civil war.

title: Digital Sound Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Chemical Banking reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included pretax restructuring charge of $52 million and a pretax gain of $115 million from the sale of investment in Florida National Banks of Florida Inc. The bank said its first-quarter 1990 earnings reflected further improvement in credit quality as nonperforming assets declined by $265 million and net charge-offs decreased by $21 million from March 31, 1989. The bank also said earnings benefited from a decrease in operating expenses, which were reduced by $61 million from the fourth quarter of 1989.

title: Winners of the 1990 Pulitzer Prizes in Journalism and the Arts
description: Public Service

title: Savings-Fraud Cases Seen Clogging U.S. Courts
description: The Federal court system, already overloaded with drug-related cases, will be burdened further in the years ahead with the hundreds of criminal cases now being prepared against former executives of failed savings institutions, Government officials said today.

title: Glatfelter (P.H.) (A) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Syracuse Player Quits
description: Tony Scott, Syracuse's best 3-point shooter, has quit school for academic reasons and is expected to transfer, Coach Jim Boeheim said in Syracuse yesterday.

title: Weis Markets reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Lydall Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A Lawyer With AIDS Wins a Legal Victory, and Gives His Employer Some Unwelcome Publicity
description: Hyatt Legal Services Inc. provides more legal advice to more Americans than any other law firm. But if the company's behavior in a recent AIDS discrimination case is any indication, Hyatt's own legal judgment isn't always so sound.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Promotions Announced By Jordan, McGrath
description: Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor yesterday announced the promotion of eight employees to executive vice presidents.

title: Jerusalem Melee With Christian Prelates
description: Twenty Orthodox Jewish families moved into a vacant complex in the Christian quarter of the Old City of Jerusalem overnight, setting off a protest today by hundreds of Christian clerics that ended when the clerics were sprayed with tear gas by soldiers guarding the settlers.

title: Hill Injury Cancels Bout
description: Virgil Hill, the World Boxing Association light-heavyweight champion, broke his hand in training and will not fight Guy Waters of Australia as scheduled April 29, promoters said yesterday.

title: Keating Blames U.S. Delays for Lincoln's Seizure
description: Charles H. Keating Jr. asserted in court today that Federal regulators held up approval of two transactions that would have brought the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association into compliance with the Government's capital requirements in December 1988, four months before regulators seized it.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-7

title: The Bushes' Tax Bill: $101,382
description: President Bush and his wife, Barbara, paid $101,382 in 1989 Federal income taxes, about 22 percent of their income of $456,780 for the year, according to a copy of their tax return released by the White House today.

title: Franco-Nevada Mining reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Britain Seizes Pipe Going to Iraq
description: A big forged-steel tube ordered by Iraq was seized by British customs officers today after military experts determined that it could be used to build a gun capable of hurling a warhead hundreds of miles.

title: The Magic of Hollywood Math
description: ''Coming to America,'' the Eddie Murphy film that was one of the top-10 grossing films in 1988, has brought in worldwide revenues of more than $275 million, including at least $125 million to Paramount Pictures, which made and distributed the movie.

title: Stop the Shell Game With Pension Funds;   A Better Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: After serving 15 1/2 months of a six-year sentence in the State Park Correctional Center in Columbia, S.C., a new public awaits the soul singer JAMES BROWN. Instead of giving concerts, the Godfather of Soul will be giving talks to young people on the dangers of drug and alcohol abuse as he completes the work-release terms of his sentence.

title: Review/Music;   A Lyricist Gives Voice To Words Of His Own
description: Although Sheldon Harnick has been writing lyrics for Broadway musicals for almost 40 years, including one of the most memorable shows of the last quarter-century, ''Fiddler on the Roof,'' and a Pulitzer Prize winner, ''Fiorello!,'' his name does not usually bring immediate recognition. But in the program of his songs that opened on Tuesday night at Rainbow and Stars, 30 Rockefeller Plaza, his scope as a lyricist working within a dramatic context - from comedy and romance to high drama - is made stunningly clear.

title: Jesse Helms Museum Drive Draws Quiet Support and Loud Criticism
description: Senator Jesse Helms, whose outspoken views about what constitutes art has put him at odds with museum curators around the country, is now being honored with a museum of his own.

title: Shuttle Launching Is Planned For April 25, a 15-Day Delay
description: Another attempt to launch the space shuttle Discovery with the Hubble Space Telescope will not be made until April 25, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said yesterday.

title: New York Police Need a New Academy
description: The Koch administration wisely approved a plan for a new police academy to replace the cramped, outmoded one in Gramercy Park. It also hoped that putting the academy in the South Bronx would improve the area. Now the Dinkins administration asks whether the city can afford the project. The issue involves more than money. The existing academy, dating back to the 60's, comfortably accommodates about 84,000 student-days per year. The need has grown to six times that figure. The academy copes by cramming 40 students into classrooms built for 20 and running a costly night shift. Inadequacies of the building inhibit modern training programs and continuing education of experienced officers.

title: Hunt (J.B.) Transport (O) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Carl Karcher Enterprises Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: b-Net income Fiscal 1990 results included a one- time charge of $14.5 million for the planned restructuring of the company's Arizona operations. As a result of the reserve for the Arizona restructuring, the company sustained a net loss in the latest fourth quarter.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: 3 Seized in Killing of Envoy
description: Three Surinamese men have been arrested in connection with the slaying of a Soviet diplomat, apparently in a robbery, the police said. The three were captured Wednesday while trying to sell the diplomat's car. Stasis Obukauskas, 41 years old, the consul and second secretary in the Soviet Embassy, left home Monday night in the car, and his body, with three bullet wounds in the head, was found Tuesday in a gutter. The three men, who were not identified, reportedly confessed to the killing.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Executive Changes listing of Business Day on Wednesday misstated the ownership of the Joseph & Feiss Company, a clothing manufacturer. It is owned by Hugo Boss A.G. of West Germany, not by Phillips-Van Heusen.

title: Cash Found, Spending Ensues
description: Residents of this coastal community found large amounts of money in steel drums buried in a farmer's field, probably by drug traffickers, the United States attorney said today.

title: Dinkins Offers Reward In Killing of Cabdrivers
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins announced a $10,000 reward yesterday for information leading to the arrest of what the police say is a serial killer who has robbed and killed three livery-cab drivers in the Bronx in the last five weeks.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Latin Double Bill

title: After 11 Games, Tigers Top Red Sox
description: Lou Whitaker hit his 150th career home run and Tony Phillips had four hits today as the Detroit Tigers ended an 11-game losing streak against the Boston Red Sox with an 11-7 victory in their home opener.

title: Soviet Intransigence on Arms Control? No, Just Sensible Negotiating
description: Until last week's meetings between Secretary of State James Baker and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze, the talks on limiting strategic arms seemed a succession of triumphs for our side. Agreement has already been reached on a series of restraints tailored to fit our force structure while constraining that of the Soviet Union.

title: Police Officer Is Suspended; Tougher Response Is Vowed
description: The white police officer who fatally shot a 16-year-old black youth here Tuesday night was suspended from duty today. And the authorities, reacting to a protest vigil that turned violent Wednesday night, vowed a tougher police response to further lawlessness.

title: GORBACHEV BRIEFS VISITING SENATORS
description: Visiting American senators said today that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev had talked to them of making radical plans to reform the stagnant economy, but that he had also indicated he had no hard timetable for making such critical changes as price reform.

title: A Gunshot in the Dark Links 2 Disparate Lives; Phillip C. Pannell
description: On good days, Phillip C. Pannell's friends say, he was an easygoing young man, a movie buff and sports fanatic whose dream was to be a sports star. On bad days, they said, he was a fighter in turf battles between teen-agers from Englewood and Teaneck whose nightmare was being shot by the police.

title: INSIDE
description: Soviet Military Rumblings

title: Review/Film;   Sequel to South African's 'Gods Must Be Crazy'
description: Jamie Uys, the South African film maker, broke into the world market in a big way in 1984 with ''The Gods Must Be Crazy,'' a small, beguiling comedy about Xixo, an African bushman, and the Coke bottle he finds in the middle of the Kalahari Desert.

title: Suitor of Norton Hints at Higher Bid
description: BTR P.L.C., a British maker of industrial products, indicated it might be willing to sweeten its $1.64 billion hostile bid for the Norton Company if the plastics and ceramics company based in Worcester, Mass., could demonstrate it was worth a higher price. The London-based conglomerate said in United States Government filings that it had asked for confidential information and was prepared to meet with Norton, which so far has resisted the $75-a-share cash bid.

title: Air Force Accuracy in Panama
description: Truth, it is often remarked, is the first casualty of war, but the Air Force has massacred the facts with unusual abandon in the matter of the Panama invasion. It let the Secretary of Defense announce last December that two F-117A Stealth fighters had bombed their targets with perfect accuracy. But Michael Gordon of The New York Times recently photographed a bomb crater way off target, and Mr. Cheney now wants the Air Force to explain its considerable economy with the truth.

title: Prenatal Nightmare
description: A Bette Davis fan who had longed to see ''The Great Lie'' found it recently in a video store. She thought she was renting a romantic drama; what she got was a horror movie. Every time Sandra Novak, the hard-as-nails concert pianist played by Mary Astor, pulled out another cigarette, the fan shrank. When Sandra drank her nightly brandy, the fan shuddered. When Maggie, the good-as-gold horse fancier played by B. D., rebuked her for wanting a ham and cheese sandwich, the fan shivered.

title: A Schuller Premiere
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center is to give the world premiere of Gunther Schuller's ''Impromptus and Cadenzas'' on Sunday afternoon at 5 o'clock at Alice Tully Hall. The five-movement work is to be performed by Stephen Taylor, oboist; David Shifrin, clarinetist; Frank Morelli, bassoonist; Robert Routch, hornist; Ida Kavafian, violinist, and Leslie Parnas, cellist. The program also includes the Beethoven Wind Quintet in E flat (Op. 16) and the Brahms Piano Trio in B (Op. 8). Tickets are $20. Information: 874-6770.

title: BUSH AT G.O.P. HIGH IN BLACK APPROVAL
description: After more than a generation of unswerving loyalty to the Democratic Party and its leaders, black Americans have given George Bush the highest level of sustained approval for any Republican President in 30 years, according to a New York Times/CBS News poll and a series of follow-up interviews.

title: After Racial Melee, Teaneck Questions Its Proud Self-Image
description: ''This is a good town, a model town,'' Drew McPherson was saying this afternoon. ''I feel very patriotic about Teaneck. But we've got to speak to these racial problems. Things are just getting out of hand. Things are at the boiling point.''

title: Lin Seeks Change In Cellular Deal
description: The Lin Broadcasting Corporation said it had entered talks with the Metromedia Company to modify the terms of Lin's pending acquisition of Metromedia's 46 percent interest in the cellular telephone system serving New York City. Under the proposal, the $1.9 billion that Metromedia would receive would consist of $1.05 billion in cash and $850 million of stock in a subsidiary of Lin that holds its cellular interests.

title: 3 Nominated for Expanded Board To Consider Conflicts of Interest
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday nominated three lawyers to serve on the New York City Conflicts of Interest Board, the five-member body that considers questions of ethical conduct involving city officials and employees.

title: A Broken Arm Ends the Season for Nilan
description: Chris Nilan, his bluff having lasted nearly two full periods, finally called a halt to the charade early in the third period of the Rangers' 6-1 triumph over the Islanders on Wednesday night.

title: BUCHAREST BLOCKS KING FROM VISITING
description: King Michael, who was forced from his throne by the Communists in 1947, was barred from the country today after the Romanian Government withdrew his visa.

title: American City Business Jourals Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss The company said income in the latest first quarter included a one-time gain of $3,236,000 from the sale of assets.

title: General Motors Is Recalling 65,200 Cars Over Fuel Hose
description: The General Motors Corporation is recalling 65,200 Pontiac Grand Am, Oldsmobile Cutlass Calais and Buick Skylark automobiles to repair a faulty fuel hose that has caused fires in engine compartments.

title: India-Nepal Accord on Ending Trade Dispute Is Near Collapse
description: An agreement to end a yearlong trade dispute between India and Nepal is in danger of falling victim to the unsettled political situation in Katmandu and to India's preoccupation with a steadily worsening crisis in Kashmir.

title: Tiananmen Protest Leader Credits 'Lots of People' for Escape to West
description: A leader of the Chinese student movement that was crushed in Tiananmen Square in June said here today that she was able to avoid arrest for 10 months thanks to the help, protection and encouragement of ordinary Chinese citizens.

title: Arbour Shuffles to Insufficient Avail
description: Coach Al Arbour, with his Islander team one defeat away from Stanley Cup playoff elimination, took some drastic measures last night.

title: Creditors at Eastern Pressing for a Trustee
description: The unsecured creditors of Eastern Airlines pressed ahead yesterday with their effort to oust Eastern's management and have a trustee appointed to run the airline while trying to sell it.

title: Canadiens Take a 3-2 Lead in Series
description: Stephane Richer scored his fifth and sixth goals of the playoffs and Bobby Smith had a goal and an assist as the Montreal Canadiens beat the Buffalo Sabres by 4-2 tonight to take a 3-2 lead in their Adams Division semifinal series.

title: In China, Literature Continues to Suffer
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge
description: When a team trails substantially in a match, it has to swing a little, since routine results that match the other room will not help. There is an art in doing this: Outrageously optimistic bidding does not make sense, and neither do plays that go clearly against the odds. The experienced player will make bids, leads and plays that are likely to differ from the other room, but are almost equally attractive.

title: How to Achieve Fairness in Puerto Rico
description: To the Editor:

title: Introductory Fare By Northwest Air
description: Northwest Airlines said it would offer low introductory fares for round-trip travel between San Jose and other points through June 15. The carrier will start service in San Jose on May 15.

title: Suspect Held in Slaying of 6
description: A 22-year-old Kansas City man, Ray Shawn Jackson, was charged today with killing six of seven women strangled here since September and with the assault Monday night of another woman whose attack was interrupted by a passer-by. The Police Chief, Larry Joiner, said the six strangled women had all been lured to the midtown areas where they were slain by the promise of obtaining crack.

title: Standoff Ends, but Not Mohawk Defiance
description: When both sides put down their guns and took down their roadblocks earlier this week, an 11-day standoff between a community of Mohawks and a squad of investigators appeared to be at an end.

title: Mortgage Rates Decline
description: Fixed-rate home mortgages averaged 10.25 percent this week, down from 10.26 percent last week, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said today. One-year adjustable-rate mortgages averaged 8.50 percent this week, down from 8.56 last week.

title: From Zion, Not From Brooklyn
description: A Hasidic rabbi in Brooklyn -one of the few New York City rabbis never to have set foot in the Holy Land -has again obstructed the formation of a government in Israel.

title: Exxon Trial Set for June
description: The Exxon Corporation and its shipping subsidiary are scheduled for trial on June 18 on Federal charges stemming from the Alaska oil spill of March 1989. The date was set in an order filed Wednesday in United States District Court. Exxon and the Exxon Shipping Company pleaded not guilty to the charges on Monday.

title: Utah Medical Products reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Dallas Semiconductor reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
Ex-Senator Ends Retirement And Faces an Election Issue
description: Former Senator Lawton Chiles came out of retirement on Thursday to enter the Democratic race for governor and was immediately confronted with a new disclosure that he was taking medication for depression.

title: A Big Hit for Marshall As Mets Win in 10th By JOSEPH DURSO
description: Like everybody else, the Mets were still groping for answers to baseball's shortened spring training today. The hitters, who were supposed to be ahead of the pitchers, were hitting .194. And the pitchers, who were supposed to be hurting for more work, were keeping the team in games waiting for the hitters to hit.

title: Dolphins and Double Hulls
description: It may be no more than an effort by big companies to shine up their image as Earth Day, April 22, approaches. But friends of the earth can surely cheer two corporate decisions this week. The first was Conoco's announcement that it would order two new oil tankers with double hulls. The second was the declaration by the three largest sellers of canned tuna that they would stop buying tuna trapped by nets that kill dolphins.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST:
description: Companies

title: Hard-Hitting Rangers Reach Patrick Final
description: The Rangers, playing against a backdrop of often heartbreaking history but in front of one of the National Hockey League's more astonishing acoustic accompaniments, last night overpowered and outlasted the Islanders, 6-5, sending Madison Square Garden into a prolonged fit of joy and advancing themselves to the Patrick Division final.

title: Claude Bolling Concert
description: The French composer and jazz pianist Claude Bolling will give a free concert at 7 P.M. Thursday in the Winter Garden at the World Financial Center in Battery Park City, bordered by the Hudson River and West, Vesey and Liberty Streets. The concert will be Mr. Bolling's only New York appearance this season. Appearing with him will be Vincent Cordelette, drummer; Eric Franceries, guitarist; Pamela Sklar, flutist, and Pierre-Yves Sorin, bass player. The concert is part of a free series at the Winter Garden. Information: 945-0505.

title: Dorset Exploration reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $348,000. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Upheaval in the East: Moscow Journal;   U.S. Passport Takes Gulag Survivor Halfway Through the Looking Glass
description: Wary as only a gulag survivor can be, Morris Hershman stands alone and theoretically triumphant amid the throngs of Soviet citizens who wait outside the American Embassy these troubled days, taunted by the hope of emigration.

title: Israelis Are Reported to Sink Dinghy Carrying 4 Guerrillas
description: The Israeli Navy sank a dinghy carrying four Palestinian guerrillas trying to enter northern Israel from the Lebanese coast, members of the Lebanese and Israeli security forces said today.

title: An Extra Day for the Mad Tax Rush
description: If you have not filed your Federal and state income tax returns yet, there is a little extra time this year. Because April 15 falls on a Sunday, you have one more day to file. But if you are not ready now, plan a concentrated session with your papers because things are not the same as they were last year.

title: Patents;   Efforts to Help Players Perfect Basketball Shots
description: Two inventors patented devices this week to help aspiring basketball players improve their aim. Bob J. Ackerman, who coaches women's basketball at Spoon River Junior College in Canton, Ill., has invented a device that automatically rebounds the ball to players every time they sink a basket. The device is intended to reward shooters for good throws, as well as to help a person practicing alone to perfect the motion of a particular shot through repetition.

title: Visa Rules Eased for Foreigners With AIDS
description: The Bush Administration today further eased restrictions on foreigners infected with the AIDS virus who want to attend conferences in the United States, but opponents of the restrictions said the move fell short of the changes needed.

title: Unilab Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The company said year-ago results do not include two acquisitions made since that time.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Poles Urge Charges in Katyn Massacre
description: Poles called on the Soviet Union today to prosecute the perpetrators of the Katyn massacre, and several said the Soviet admission of guilt was not enough to redress more than 50 years of lies.

title: Upheaval in the East;   On Forgiving the Germans
description: Invoking the spirit of Good Friday and Easter, President Bush said today that people ''ought to forgive'' Germans for the Holocaust but should not forget history's lessons.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Other constituent republics are asking quite aptly why they should continue supplying products to Lithuania at the expense of their own needs.'' - President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. [1:6.]

title: U.S. Care for Chernobyl Hero
description: A Soviet hero in the struggle to stop radiation that spewed from the Chernobyl nuclear reactor four years ago has arrived here for a life-saving bone-marrow transplant after developing early symptoms of leukemia.

title: Upheaval in the East;   New Soviet Threat 'Disturbing' to Bush
description: Speaking with unusual force about the Lithuanian crisis, President Bush said today that he and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain found reports of a Kremlin ultimatum to the Baltic republic ''deeply disturbing.'' Mr. Bush said imposition of economic sanctions against Lithuania would violate Moscow's stated policy of seeking to resolve the stalemate over Lithuania's desire for independence without force.

title: Champagneforashley Wins by 12 1/2
description: Champagneforashley would probably have had to fall down to lose the DeWitt Clinton Handicap yesterday at Aqueduct, but he won it even more impressively than anyone expected.

title: Criticare Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said net results were affected by a non-cash loss for the 9-month period of $480,000 due to its investment in an historic structure in Milwaukee.

title: Rev. Virginio Rotondi, Vatican Adviser, 78
description: The Rev. Virginio Rotondi, a Jesuit who helped handle the Vatican's postwar relations with Italian politicians, died today. He was 78 years old. The cause of death was not disclosed. Father Rotondi, who wrote several books, was the host of two radio shows and often contributed to newspapers and magazines, suffered a stroke about a year ago. He died at his residence near the Pope's summer palace here.

title: Nunn Favored in Bout
description: The oddsmakers in Las Vegas, Nev., have made Michael Nunn a 6-1 favorite to retain his International Boxing Federation middleweight title against Marlon Starling tonight at the Mirage.

title: Baker Presses Lawmakers to Back A Strategy of Talks in El Salvador
description: Hoping to prevent Congress from cutting aid to El Salvador when lawmakers return to work next week, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d is lobbying Democratic leaders to give the Administration time to encourage peace negotiations between the Salvadoran Government and leftist guerrillas.

title: Graf Is Tested but Prevails
description: There are days when Steffi Graf disposes of challengers the way a shark disposes of its dinner, in one silent gulp. This wasn't one of them.

title: CHRONICLE
description: As president of the J. M. Kaplan Fund, JOAN K. DAVIDSON is more accustomed to giving than receiving. The fund, founded by her late father, gives several millions of dollars annually to such diverse causes as the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund, the New York Botanical Garden and dozens of New York City preservation and social-service programs.

title: Merrimac Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 24
Theater Club Benefit
description: Members of the casts of ''City of Angels,'' ''Gypsy,'' ''Closer Than Ever'' and ''Forbidden Broadway'' will take part in a special performance at 9 P.M. April 30 at the New York Hilton, 1355 Avenue of the Americas, at 53d Street. Proceeds from the show will benefit the Manhattan Theater Club, which is in its 19th season. Tickets range from $50 to $600. Information: 675-7596.

title: BOEING TO FINANCE NEW 767-X AIRLINER WITHOUT JAPANESE
description: The Boeing Company said today that it would finance by itself the development of its proposed 767-X aircraft. Three Japanese aerospace companies will be substantial suppliers for the 300-seat twin-engine plane but will not be partners, Boeing said after months of industry speculation about possible Japanese participation.

description: b-Net loss

title: Thomas Higginson, 70, A Corporate Lawyer
description: Thomas Lee Higginson, a partner in the Manhattan law firm of Shearman & Sterling who specialized in corporate and securities law, died yesterday at his home in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., after a long illness. He was 70 years old and also lived in Manhattan.

title: George Theodore Golding, Urologist, 83
description: Dr. George Theodore Golding, a urologist in Queens for almost 50 years, died of an aneurism on Tuesday at his home in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 83 years old.

description: b-Net income

description: b-Included a write-off of deferred development costs of $1.4 million. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * California State Bank said it would acquire Empire Bancorp, Cucamonga, Calif., through an exchange of common stock.

title: Graziano: The Brawler As Artist
description: Everyone knew Rocky Graziano was dangerous. There was a time, for example, several summers ago when the former pugilist broiled hamburgers on a grill on the patio of a friend's brownstone in Manhattan. Rocky found a chef's hat to wear, and, in loafers without socks - he rarely wore socks because he had developed gout and his feet were happier sockless - he proceeded to cook up a storm. Not so much a storm as a smoke, big clouds of smoke into which he disappeared for long moments at a time.

title: Profiles From Cincinnati: Cutting Edge of Art Scrapes Deeply Held Beliefs;   Sheriff: When a Crusade Is a Career
description: There is a reason why Cincinnati has no adult bookstores and no peep shows, why you cannot buy Hustler or an X-rated video here, why the Playboy Channel was run out of town and why, after uneventful showings from Hartford to Berkeley, an exhibition of photographs by Robert Mapplethorpe is a criminal matter here.

title: Simple Request by Zaire's Leader Spurs Troubling Torrent by Critics
description: It all seemed innocuous enough. In January, President Mobutu Sese Seko announced that he would hold a series of public hearings throughout Zaire, ''a direct dialogue with the people,'' to better gauge their concerns.

title: How Boiled Is That Egg?
description: Coloring eggs may be synonymous with Easter, but boiling them is often a matter of trial and error.

title: Capitals Defeat Devils and Lead Series
description: The Devils played without much urgency or fear at crucial times tonight against an inspired Washington defense and suffered their second consecutive loss to the Capitals.

title: Injury to Leg Muscle Sidelines Tartabull
description: Danny Tartabull, who was the Kansas City Royals' hottest hitter in spring training with a .443 batting average, will be lost to the team for at least 15 days after suffering a freakish injury before a game Wednesday night. The outfielder was shagging flies in the outfield when he tore the plantaris muscle, which connects the calf muscle with the Achilles' tendon, in his right leg.

title: Campeau Store Plan Approved
description: The Federated and Allied retailing companies, operating under Federal bankruptcy court protection, won approval on Thursday for a two-year, $25 million plan intended to keep key managers from leaving. Federal Bankruptcy Judge J. Vincent Aug Jr. approved the plan, which seeks to benefit about 2,300 managers of Federated Department Stores Inc. and of the Allied Stores Corporation, nationwide. It would provide about 400 key executives with performance bonuses, job security assurances and employment and severance agreement terms.

title: Hallmark Extends Offer
description: Hallmark Cards Inc. said yesterday that it had extended its cash tender offer for $270 million worth of Univision Holdings Inc. ''junk bonds'' because 85 percent to 90 percent of bondholders have tendered their securities.
