title: THE MAN BEHIND THE GETTY'S GETTING AND SPENDING
description: Right now, the most envied man in the American museum world is probably George Goldner, curator of both paintings and drawings at the J. Paul Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif. His mandate in both departments - and, by the way, they are quite separate from one another - is to hunt down the best and buy it. Proposed purchases are discussed every two months with the museum's director, John J. Walsh Jr. - ''George is wonderful at passing the ammunition,'' said Mr. Walsh the other day - and they have to be approved by the museum's trustees. But to a degree rarely rivaled by any other curator, either in the United States or anywhere else, Mr. Goldner's is a very happy situation.

title: Pastimes;   Coins
description: ''Then one of the twelve, called Judas Iscariot, went unto the chief priests and said unto them, 'What will ye give me, and I will deliver him unto you?' And they covenanted him with 30 pieces of silver.'' What were the 30 pieces of silver?

title: Andrea S. M. Linz to Wed Capt. Scott A. Wyckoff
description: Dr. and Mrs. Andrew M. Linz of New York have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Andrea S. M. Linz and Capt. Scott A. Wyckoff, U.S.A.F., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Wyckoff of Clearwater, Fla.

title: A Journey Into Silesia
description: IN MID-NOVEMBER 1989, IN THE YEAR OF REVOLUTION, audiences around the world woke with a start to a banner held aloft in a tiny village. It bore the following awkwardly lettered phrase: ''Helmut you're our Chancellor too.''

title: Youths' Lesson: War Knows No Limits
description: The young men and women came from South Africa, Northern Ireland, El Salvador, Lebanon and the Soviet Union, members of a group called Children of War. And what surprised them when they spoke to New York City high school students, they said, was that the students seemed unaware that they, too, were living in a ''war zone.''

title: Lifestyle;   Yes, It's Too Late to Call Peter Rabbit
description: Easter is a fine day for hunting eggs that presumably were hard-boiled before they were hidden between the cushions of the new sofa. It's also a good day for bonnets and banquets and song, sacred and secular. But it's a sad day for Peter Rabbit: he no longer has a telephone listing of his very own.

title: Owner Kills Intruder at an Auto-Body Shop
description: The owner of a Brooklyn auto-body shop shot and killed a knife-wielding intruder early yesterday after two of the shop owner's employees were accosted, the police reported.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: INDIANAPOLIS;

Market Future For Section 8
description: LEAD: MORE than 400 federally subsidized apartments here are to be renovated and returned to the private market under a plan that, if it succeeds, could be copied elsewhere in the country.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Spontaneous Combustion

title: Devils Feel Loose Despite Big Challenge
description: The Devils were loose and in good spirits at practice today before they boarded a charter flight for Washington to face the Capitals Sunday night in what could be New Jersey's last game of the season.

title: Proposal for Jobs and Homes Fought
description: LEAD: AN advocacy group for the poor is seeking to go beyond finding a place for the destitute and anguished to stay.

title: Pubs in Prague
description: To the Editor: Joanne Furio's article on Czech and Slovak beer pubs (Travel, March 4) brought back many happy memories, since for two years I was a Fulbright lecturer on American literature at Charles University in Prague.

title: Fashion;   The New Summer Basics
description: Of course you can slide through the summer wearing the same kind of stuff you've always worn - T-shirts, black or khaki pants, blue jeans, a sheath dress, a short black skirt, white shirts, an oversized sweater or jacket, maybe a seersucker suit. There's nothing wrong with any of these. This season, though, it's possible to dress in just as basic a manner, but with a fresh kick of fashion to every item. Jeans, for instance, can be sky blue, apple green or pale peach - if they come from the house of Escada. The newest T-shirts can fit like skin and expose the shoulders. Some white shirts now stretch down to become jackets. Sweaters are woven of glittering Lurex threads. The simple sheath shift looks like a slip. Unexpectedly, sequins coat a slim skirt. Lace looks racy in narrow pants. And shorts finish off a seersucker suit. Here, and on the following pages, are just a few of the coming summer's twists on the familiar basic shapes.

title: Review/Dance;   Fort Worth Company's 'Cinderella'
description: Maria Thomas's wonderfully jaunty innocence stood her well when she stepped into the title role of the Fort Worth Ballet's ''Cinderella,'' choreographed by Paul Mejia, the company director, on Friday afternoon at City Center. But Ms. Thomas brought more than that to her portrayal, dancing with the clean line and simplicity required by the pas de deux and offering a nicely modulated characterization in which physical and emotional exultation gradually replaced timidity as Cinderella at last felt loved. The strong and sensitive partnering of Todd Edson, the prince at each performance of this weeklong run, offered a secure springboard for her interpretation.

title: About Cars;   Some Expensive Toys at the Auto Show
description: Year after year, the New York Automobile Show breaks its record for attendance, and the exposition that opened at the Javits Center in Manhattan yesterday will probably be no different. Yet it is surprising how many people say they have never been to a show, no matter that they are keenly interested in the latest four-wheeled toys.

title: Data Bank/April 15, 1990
A MUSEUM FOR THE BRAND-NEW
description: REBELS ON EIGHTH STREET

title: Jonna Godley to Wed Keith E. Scharf in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. William H. Godley Jr. of Frenchtown, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jonna L. Godley to Keith Elliot Scharf, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank D. Scharf of Guilford, Conn., and New York. A May wedding is planned.

title: THE MISTAKES IN THIS ESSAY ARE MY OWN
description: To crack open a new book and read its dedication and acknowledgments is typically an occasion for me to relive an experience years ago, when I was a midshipman. One night I was assigned to stand watch on the fantail of our ship with a young enlisted man. While we looked over the inky Pacific, illuminated by a long strip of moonlight, he poured out a story of his sad youth, especially of his unloving parents. Though barely able to make out the sailor's face, I felt a bond born of sincere self-revelation. Then, several days later, we happened to meet in a passageway. I noticed the sailor had a large tattoo on his arm, a heart with the inscription ''Mother.''

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Alone at the Audit: 'I Felt Like a Bootlegger'
description: LEAD: WE often hear about the tax woes of rich and famous people, like the comedian Redd Foxx, whose jewelry, cars and furnishings were taken by the Internal Revenue Service because he owed the Government $900,000. How often, however, do we hear the story of an ordinary person who has become the target of an audit?

title: Part Replaced That Delayed Hubble Launch
description: Technician opened the cargo bay of the shuttle Discovery today and replaced a part that delayed the launching of the Hubble Space Telescope. The workers also removed the telescope's batteries for recharging in preparation for an April 25 liftoff.

title: Why is the Boss Wearing a Hula Skirt?
description: To the Editor:

title: Campus Life: Harvard;   Bitter Debate Ignites Over Social Sciences
description: Disagreement over different approaches to the social sciences has flared into public debate at Harvard, with professors from two rival programs exchanging bitter criticisms and accusations.

title: Q and A
description: Sublet Fees in A Co-op

title: Color Imaging, Step by Step
description: At $700 for each new color photograph, last-minute additions of new products in The Hobie Catalog, published by the Hobie Cat Company of Oceanside, Calif., seemed out of the question - at least until Hobie Cat discovered ''color photo imaging.''

title: States Find Income-Tax Checkoffs Aren't Such Easy Money Anymore
description: LOUISIANA, which used to have 12, now has only one. Oregon is threatening to drop any that bring in less than $50,000, which has the state arts council worried after falling $2,000 short last year. One in Ohio is down, too, but the one in New York is a sure source of $1.7 million.

title: Meyer to Try Again
description: Since his 1983 victory in the Boston Marathon, Greg Meyer has suffered a stress fracture of the foot, a torn Achilles' tendon, a phantom leg problem that turned out to be a back ailment and a series of injuries that included a separated shoulder and dislocated ribs.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   Is the Peace Dividend at Risk?
description: ''It looks as if we spent the peace dividend,'' lamented Senator Larry Pressler after the General Accounting Office doubled the estimated cost of the savings and loan bailout to as much as $500 billion.

title: WHEN WILL THE BOOK BE DONE?
description: I'M ALWAYS MAKING SUGGESTIONS to my husband that I later regret. On Friday afternoon, June 16, 1972, I telephoned Neil at the Washington bureau of The New York Times to ask him about the funeral he had attended at Arlington National Cemetery that morning. A week earlier, a good friend and influential source from his years as a correspondent in Vietnam, John Paul Vann, had been killed in a helicopter crash there. I listened for half an hour while Neil described the funeral in captivating detail and spoke emotionally about Vann, the civilian-soldier whose death had caught him by surprise, because Vann had spent 10 years in Vietnam beating the odds that claimed the lives of other, more cautious men. ''It sounds as if there's a book in Vann,'' I said, before we hung up.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our house has a den whose walls are covered with vertical 1-by-8-inch, beveled-edge pine boards with quarter-round molding over each of the joints. The ceiling consists of exposed joists with the 1-by-6-inch subflooring exposed from the room above. Dark-brown stain has been used on all the woodwork, making the room dark. We want to lighten this wood and have considered whitewashing the walls. What would you suggest?

title: Fashion;   Lighthearted Dresses With a Sense of Ease
description: As the weather warms up, women will want to escape from trousers and tight skirts into airy dresses or culottes that just skim the body. Some of these lighthearted dresses are inspired by the loose, bias-cut dresses of the 20's and 30's. Others are variations on the sun dress or sheath. But what makes these designs modern are their clean silhouettes and sense of physical ease.

title: Style Makers;   Junichi Arai, Textile Designer
description: Fashion designers like Issey Miyake, Rei Kawakubo and Ronaldus Shamask have made clothes from Junichi Arai's fabrics. Interior designers have turned his fabric into canopies. But for Mr. Arai, 58 years old, textiles are not just functional materials but also a medium for art. Mr. Arai, Japan's pre-eminent textile designer, has woven silk to look like a gossamer spider's web and, using computer-aided technology, has woven wool and nylon to make fabric with squares on one side and triangles on the other.

title: Art-School Consortium To Show Student Work
description: Twenty artists from nine art schools around the country will exhibit their work on Wednesday at 5:30 P.M. at an open house sponsored by the Alliance of Independent Colleges of Art at its loft at 451 Greenwich Street. The exhibition is a showcase for students who have participated in a 16-week program sponsored by the alliance, a Washington-based consortium of art schools. The program, which is offered in New York City, features independent work and may include work done with other artists.

title: Blue Collars Amid White
description: Croquet, once exclusively a sport of the privileged, still requires all-white outfits. But it has begun to attract an occasional blue-collar player.

title: Court Hears Appeal of $5.3 Million Libel Award to Wayne Newton
description: NBC News urged a Federal appeals court Friday to reverse the $5.3 million libel judgment won by the singer Wayne Newton, saying a 1980 broadcast linking him to organized crime figures was a product of nothing more than aggressive journalism.

title: How Cuisinart Lost Its Edge
description: IT IS THE SORT OF FABLED BRAND name that marketers usually only dream about. If you were in the copier business, you would wish your name were Xerox. If tissues were your product, it would be nice to be named Kleenex. But if you were going to make your fortune in food processors, you couldn't do better than to possess the name Cuisinart.

title:
A LA CARTE;

New Managers at Rene Chardain
description: LEAD: A RECENT flurry of press releases announcing radical changes at Rene Chardain's restaurant (533-6200) in the South Salem/Lewisboro area took us back to witness ''relaxed, almost playful foods with moderate prices'' and a clientele invited to ''come as you are,'' the new policy of the new managers, Jean-Louis and Linda Gerin of Restaurant Jean-Louis of nearby

title: Alive to the Rhythms of Veracruz
description: IMAGINE New Orleans 40 years ago, before its plethora of skyscrapers and the disfigurement by the Superdome. That will give you some sense of Veracruz: alive to rhythms day and night; slightly seedy around its elegant Latin edges; redolent of coffee, flowers and fish. And like New Orleans, this city that was the Old World's first beachhead on the mainland of the new one, wears the burden of its history with a negligent and charming grace.

title: Rebecca Gaskin to Wed Yorke Lawson
description: The engagement of Rebecca Louise Gaskin to Coleman Yorke Lawson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ferd O. Lawson Jr. of Darien, Conn., has been announced by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Lewis J. Gaskin of Raleigh, N.C. An August wedding is planned. Miss Gaskin, 24 years old, graduated from St. Mary's College in Raleigh and Wake Forest University, and received a law degree from Emory University. She is a research assistant to Prof. Louis Lowenstein, the director of the Columbia University Center for Law and Economic Studies. Her father is an anesthesiologist and the founder of Raleigh Anesthesia Associates. Her father and mother, Patricia Gaskin, own a Christmas tree farm in Laurel Springs, N.C.

title: More Nicaraguans in U.S. Going Back Home
description: Confident that the inauguration on April 25 of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro will usher in an era of peace for Nicaragua, a growing number of Nicaraguan exiles are restarting their lives and businesses there.

title: Miss Concannon Plans to Be Wed
description: Carol Anne Concannon of Manhasset, L.I., has announced the engagement of her daughter Margaret Anne Concannon to Timothy Michael Joyce, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Michael Joyce 3d of New Rochelle, N.Y. A June wedding is planned.

title:
MUSIC;

Before a Concert, Students Learn All About It
description: LEAD: WHEN the Brunswick Symphony Orchestra performs at the State Theater next Sunday afternoon, some of the best-prepared audience members are likely to be a group of students from 10 to 13 years old who have been involved in a pilot educational project since the beginning of February.

title: Despite the Lockout, Pitchers Are Far Ahead of the Hitters
description: Three weeks of spring training might be enough time for hitters to get ready for the season, the prevailing thinking went at the end of the lockout, but pitchers would most likely need more time.

title: A TABLOID LIFE
description: PANIC BLOOD

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: MELLON EXHIBITION

title: Catherine Eisler Becomes a Bride
description: Catherine Lea Eisler and Scott Dee Ackerson were married yesterday at the Quaker Ridge Golf Club in Scarsdale, N.Y., by John M. Friedman, a retired town and village justice of Scarsdale.

title: HE KILLED HER BECAUSE HE COULD
description: THE BOOK OF EVIDENCEBy John Banville.

title: Plays Unfetter Inmates' Creativity
description: LEAD: SPORTING a green cap, his back to a stage, JaJa Safi Akair sized up the audience as the auditorium of East Jersey State Prison filled with about 130 fellow inmates who had chosen to spend a Saturday night watching a play he had written.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Disabled Driver Coasts to the Exit
description: LEAD: AS a slow-lane, 55-mile-an-hour, accident-free, no-violations wimp, I expected that the renewal of my Connecticut driver's license would be sure as death and taxes. Instead, I was headed for the breakdown lane.

title: No More Room in the Budget For the Homeless Mentally Ill
description: WHEN the losers and winners stagger from this year's fight over the state budget in Albany, those who represent the mentally ill people living on New York City's streets may be unsure which side to join.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our house has a den whose walls are covered with vertical 1-by-8-inch, beveled-edge pine boards with quarter-round molding over each of the joints. The ceiling consists of exposed joists with the 1-by-6-inch subflooring exposed from the room above. Dark-brown stain has been used on all the woodwork, making the room dark. We want to lighten this wood and have considered whitewashing the walls. What would you suggest?

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: ELISABETH F. LOCKWOOD;

Maintaining a Sense of Independence
description: LEAD: AS people live longer, they and their relatives face choices that didn't exist in earlier times. One of those is where the older person will live.

title: Question of the Week;   How Can the N.H.L. Clean Up Its Act?
description: All physical penalties, from hooking to fighting, are cumulative for the lifetime of the player. When the penalty time reaches and exceeds 60 minutes, the player may not suit for a game until his penalty has been served.

title: Building a Better Air Grinder, Faster
description: To the Editor:

title: Taxpayers Just Say No to Campaign Fund
description: To the Editor:

title: Tech Notes;   Here Comes the High-Altitude, Long-Flying Condor
description: An unmanned aircraft, built by the Boeing Company's advanced systems division, has set a high-altitude record for a piston-powered airplane. The plane, called the Condor, was designed by a team headed by Neil Arntz at Boeing. The Condor reached an altitude of 66,980 feet above sea level in February in a flight lasting 29.4 hours. The computerized Condor is not a remote-piloted vehicle. It is capable of flying programmed missions, without human intervention, that can last several days without refueling. It needs no human assistance for taking off or landing. The Condor is powered by two liquid-cooled 175-horsepower turbocharged engines which drive large-diameter composite propellers. The aircraft has a wingspan of 200 feet, longer than a Boeing 747-300. The wing is designed for low drag and is built entirely of lightweight bonded graphite and epoxy composite materials.

title: Struggles Over The Ancient Trees Shift to British Columbia
description: THE biggest trees in Canada, some more than 300 feet high, cling to the spongy depths of the forest floor in the Carmanah Valley just north of here. They were ignored for centuries, but now the Sitka spruce in the isolated basin are being treated like the last bison herds of the West.

title: Youngsters On Stage And in the Audience
description: LEAD: ''AN entire weekend for, by and with kids,'' is how Thea Eichler describes an event that will unfold Saturday and next Sunday in New Rochelle. Mrs. Eichler is the program chairwoman of the New Rochelle Council on the Arts, one of the sponsors of the event, ''Look What Kids Can Do!''

title: Some Chessmen Don't Make a Move
description: Chess came out of Persia around the sixth century A. D., invaded medieval Europe and assumed its modern form early in the 19th century. Scholars believe that it originally was a game of war. Perhaps it still is, but the war is psychic, in which one strong mind strives to dominate and conquer another strong mind.

title: The Hope of Easter
description: Easter commemorates Christ's resurrection, Passover the deliverance of the Jews from Egypt. In harmony with nature's cycle, these principal festivals in the Christian and Jewish calendars occur at the coming of spring, offering in the world's regreening a further cause of celebration. Yet on this Easter, as on so many before, the past continues to disturb the present.

title: Black History Properly Stated
description: In an article about Councilwoman Lois Bronz ['The Politics of Personal Involvement,' April 1] , it was incorrectly stated that she was the first black elected official in Westchester County. It went on to say that she was first elected in 1975.

title: Twachtman's Paintings of His Greenwich Years
description: SINCE its statewide revival in 1980, American Impressionism has become a staple of the scene. In the last few years, for example, Leonard Ochtman and Childe Hassam have had personal attention, notably at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich and the Florence Griswold Museum in Old Lyme. Currently, Hassam's ''Isle of Shoals'' landscapes are on view at the Yale University Art Gallery while at the Wadsworth Atheneum there is a selection of works by John Twachtman.

title:
Pastimes: Gardening;

Cool Flavors To Grow Outdoors
description: LEAD: Cucumbers have been cultivated for at least three thousand years. They have been hybridized and improved so much that today's cultivars have disease-resistance and fruits suitable for specific uses.

title: A Feminist Takes Stock
description: LAST YEAR I TAUGHT AT A SMALL liberal-arts college in the West. The students were intelligent, the teachers conscientious and the town quiet to the point of death. Among the faculty was a historian with whom I fell into friendship. This man found my hunger for the larger world interesting and was amused that I possessed it while he did not. We had long talks about work and love, as people do nowadays, and he startled me by announcing that intimate love had become a paramount value of his. He explained that years ago in pursuit of tenure at a famous university he had ignored the needs of his first marriage and then, when he didn't get the job, saw that he had put real life on hold while he fulfilled the deadly requirements of work. I listened but failed to respond sympathetically. I said work was real life; his problem was that academic success did not necessarily equate with real work. We provoked one another. He said worshipfully that intimacy was everything. I said recklessly that I could do without. Then we both stared. It wasn't what was being said that astonished, it was who was saying what. Here was a man in his 40's romanticizing love, and a woman in her 50's romanticizing work.

title: Campus Life: Bowdoin;   Students Angered By Vote to Change Grading System
description: The Bowdoin College faculty voted last week to change the distinctive four-level grading system it instituted in 1967 to the traditional A, B, C, D and F system. The action met with immediate protest from students.

title: Can Harcourt Brace Survive Its Debt?
description: There's a big question facing the publishing house of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. these days: What price victory? Publishing legend William I. Jovanovich built one of America's biggest book empires over a span of nearly four decades and then, three years ago, fended off a raider's attack by borrowing nearly $3 billion. This maintained the company's independence, but gave his son Peter, who became chief executive in December, a company so laden with debt that many question whether it can survive.

title: THE U.S: STILL ON ITS FEET
description: BOUND TO LEAD

title: The Revolution Is Today; Bureaucracy Is Forever
description: FOR any politician who cannot deliver on a promise, ''the bureaucracy'' is a wonderful scapegoat.

title: Antiques Show Offers Help at Home and Abroad
description: LEAD: WHEN a group of women at Trinity Church in Southport began to send clothing and food to war-torn Europe in 1946, it was simply a gesture that was reccurring all across America. But their efforts have evolved into one of Fairfield County's most elegant social events.

title: Lori J. Owings Is Wed To A. Robert Below Jr.
description: Lori J. Owings and A. Robert Below Jr. were married yesterday in Wichita, Kan. The Rev. Max Clayton, a Methodist minister, officiated at the Botanica gardens.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Freeport, Me.;   House Prices Take a Tumble
description: WHEN a homeowner here decided to sell her waterfront house a year ago, two appraisers encouraged her to ask $269,500. Last month she accepted an offer based on her most recent asking price, $169,000.

title: 50 YEARS ON THE ROAD
description: Eric Newby has written extensively on his 50 years of traveling; from 1963 to 1973 he was the travel editor of London's Sunday newspaper The Observer. WHAT THE TRAVELLER SAW (Viking, $30) is a collection of photographs, most of which Mr. Newby took during those 50 years, and a collection of essays. Each is a gem. He takes us on a trip around Cape Horn on a four-masted bark with wonderful action photographs of sailors; to Italy, where he was once a prisoner of war and later went back and married the young woman whose family helped harbor him when he escaped; to India, where he photographed the inside of the Taj Mahal Hotel; to Turkey (Istanbul is his favorite city); to England, where he photographed McCaig's Folly, a strange edifice that is a copy of the Colosseum in Rome in comparatively midget form; to Africa and Bali; and to China, where in 1973 he photographed cyclists wearing masks in below-freezing weather to protect themselves against Peking throat, a condition brought on by winds from Siberia. There are 21 essays in the book, and the black-and-white photographs that accompany them are striking. Mr. Newby feels that worthwhile photographs are not familiar tourist shots, but those that feature real people going about their work and worship. The essays and captions are entertaining, informative and witty and make one wish for more - in particular, they make one want to re-read Mr. Newby's other books, such as ''A Short Walk in the Hindu Kush,'' ''A Book of Traveller's Tales'' and ''Love and War in the Apennines.''

title: HISPANIC CRITICISM OF EDUCATION CHIEF
description: Hispanic educators and community leaders across the country have sharply criticized Secretary of Education Lauro F. Cavazos for saying that Hispanic parents bear much of the blame for the high dropout rate among their children.

title: Jane Holcombe To Wed in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Browning Holcombe Jr. have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Jane Hilliard Holcombe and Joseph Alexander Tranfo, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph C. Tranfo of Greenwich, Conn.

title: THE OFFICER IS A JUNKIE
description: RUSH

title: Sadists in Their Midst
description: A MIRACLE, A UNIVERSE

title: The Tape Is Still Red In Prague
description: I WAS naive, I guess, when I went to Prague in January. Somehow I imagined that not just a government but a society would be miraculously transformed as well. The first inkling this wasn't true came when my friend and I tried to book a room at the Evropa, the most expensive hotel listed in our Frommer's guidebook. Normally we watched our budget, but we had just read in The International Herald Tribune that the Czechoslovak crown - officially 9 to the dollar - was going to be devalued to its black market rate of 38 to the dollar on Monday, two days away. The way we looked at it, we could afford the best room in Prague.

title: Evening Hours;   Faceless Buildings, Faceless No More
description: Guests at the Beaux Arts Ball of the Architectural League of New York let their imaginations take over. The result? Inventive headdresses inspired by famous buildings, from ancient Greece to Battery Park City. Easy to wear? Not exactly. But fun? Yes.

title: Broken Leases
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Music;   Evening of Works for Brass By Bach and Some Moderns
description: Except for a palate-clearing pair of Contrapuncti from Bach's ''Art of Fugue,'' the Meridian Arts Ensemble devoted its program last Sunday afternoon at Weill Recital Hall to recently composed works. The ensemble - a brass quintet that comprises Richard Kelley and Jon Nelson, trumpeters; Daniel Grabois, hornist; Benjamin Herrington, trombonist, and Raymond Stewart, tubist - was formed in 1987.

title: Review/Dance;   Ghoulish Wit in Bill by Nina Martin
description: Nina Martin's ''Date With Fate'' turned tough luck into grim fun. With its ghoulishly witty text and ingeniously macabre choreography, this mixed-media creation presented by Nina Martin/Performance last Sunday night at Performance Space 122 suggested that life is governed by the whims of fate.

title: Linda J. Kelly to Wed Frederick H. Bentzel Jr.
description: Linda Joan Kelly and Frederick H. Bentzel Jr. are planning a May wedding, the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Frank T. Kelly of Chatham Township, N.J., have announced. Mr. Bentzel is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bentzel of Lakeland, Fla.

title: Campus Life: Smith;   Student Senate Approves Group Opposing Abortion
description: A new support group for abortion opponents was granted a charter last week by the Student Senate at Smith College. But the Senate then voted to deny the group financing from student activities fees, agreeing with opposition arguments that it was a partisan group.

title:
FARE OF THE COUNTRY;

In the Bahamas, A Meal in a Mollusk
description: LEAD: SOME people liken it to a chewy piece of rubber. Some dismiss it as simply tasteless texture. But aside from the relatively few who haven't acquired the taste, there are countless others who rhapsodize over its subtle sweetness, comparing it to abalone, scallops or clams.

title:
The View From: The Mall at SUNY Purchase;

Is a Work of Visual Art Meant to Be Drummed?
description: LEAD: THE mall at the State University of New York's college here is swinging into its busy season. In spring, the vast expanse of tan brick that the school's president, Sheldon N. Grebstein, calls ''a quadrangle without grass'' swarms with students. They are strumming guitars, tossing Frisbies, taping notices to bulletin boards, roller skating, and sitting on bench-like structures - also tan brick - studying.

title:
Your Own Account;

A Squeeze on Home Equity Loans
description: LEAD: In recent years, marketing blitzes for home equity loans have accompanied the tax season as faithfully as daffodils and the gnashing of teeth. After all, what better time is there to herald the significant tax advantages of these loans?

title: Undefeated by Storm, Spoleto Open to in May
description: Leonard Bernstein is to open the 14th Spoleto Festival U.S.A. in Charleston, S.C., with a performance of the Beethoven Seventh Symphony offered in celebration of Charleston's rebuilding after Hurricane Hugo, which devastated parts of the city last September. The opening concert, on May 25, also includes a performance of Mr. Bernstein's ''Arias and Barcarolles'' and Samuel Barber's First Symphony, to be conducted by Mark Stringer.

title: Census Problems Linked to New Methods
description: Census Bureau officials, facing a sharp decline in voluntary cooperation with the once-a-decade national head count, say that some changes they made to correct the problems of the 1980 census have contributed, at least in the short run, to the troubles of the 1990 effort.

title: Bedrosian Leaves To Be With Son
description: The San Francisco Giants have granted indefinite leave to their top relief pitcher, Steve Bedrosian, whose 2 1/2-year-old son, Cody, has been diagnosed as having leukemia.

title: How to Desert A Friend
description: When you are deserting a friend, the first step is a little difficult. But pretty soon it gets easy.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis

title:
ART;

2 Show Themes: Domesticity and the Grid
description: LEAD: HAPPY families, Tolstoy observed, are all alike, while unhappy families are unhappy each in their own way. While surveying ''Hand, Body, House'' at the Ben Shahn Galleries of William Paterson College, this viewer thought of Tolstoy, although not in terms of happiness or unhappiness.

title: Suffolk Park Rangers Fear for Their Jobs
description: LEAD: ''WE are losing natural Long Island, and for people like me who love the outdoors the parks are the last refuge,'' said Dennis R. Mueller, a Suffolk County park ranger since 1971. ''There couldn't be a more important job than protecting them.''

title: Wall Street;   When Zero-Coupon Bonds Point the Way
description: Many traders think zero-coupon bonds, which sell far below their maturity value but pay no annual interest, are a good barometer for the broader ''junk bond'' market. If so, recent developments may signal a slight warming trend that could send junk bond prices higher.

title: Summer Squall Fights Back to Win Blue Grass
description: Summer Squall confirmed both his talent and his toughness while winning the $284,625 Blue Grass Stakes today at Keeneland in his final prep for the Kentucky Derby.

title: Untamed Lake Pepin
description: DENSELY wooded bluffs tower 400 feet over one of the world's great rivers; timber rattlesnakes nest in rocky outcrops while bald eagles soar overhead; hidden behind the bluffs, small farms nestle among green hills, shady pastures and clear trout streams. To people who think of the Midwest as endless cornfields under a flat horizon, Lake Pepin, on the upper Mississippi River between Minnesota and Wisconsin, is a stunning surprise.

title: PETER LORRE DOES A HANDSTAND
description: ROOM TEMPERATURE

title: Film Maker is Subject Of Queens Symposium
description: A free daylong symposium on Pier Paolo Pasolini, the Italian film maker and writer, and his advocacy of dialects in Italy will be held on May 7 at Queens College, Kissena Boulevard and the Long Island Expressway, in Flushing. Pasolini, who died in 1975, felt strongly about the survival of dialects and made use of them in his films and poetry.

title: Player Leads by 5 at PGA Seniors
description: Gary Player has always found a way to insinuate himself into golf's elite, and he showed today that at 54, he hasn't forgotten how.

title: Rio de Janeiro
description: To the Editor: Two things were omitted from the report on Rio de Janeiro (Travel, March 4). In addition to the warning about crime on the beaches, riders of the funicular to the top of Corcovado Mountain should be careful of cameras, jewelry and handbags while seated near the open windows. The view is spectacular, but street urchins loiter inconspicuously along the tracks and platforms, make a quick grab for valuables and disappear into the slums where they live.

title: NEW HISTORIANS AND THE OLD WEST
description: Joyce Carol Oates is credited with coining the word ''pathography'' to describe the work of biographers who choose to emphasize the personal faults of their subjects at the expense of a more balanced consideration of their contributions to society (''Unsettling the Old West,'' by Richard Bernstein, March 18). Can the anti-establishment scholars described by Mr. Bernstein be doing the same thing in the field of history?

title:
IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut;

Yonkers Stigma Fails to Deter Builders
description: LEAD: DESPITE the cloud of an ongoing battle over a court mandate on housing integration, several developers have embarked on low-profile commercial projects in Yonkers that are expected to revitalize older neighborhoods a block at a time.

title: Long Island Journal
description: Home Movies

title: Suzanne Vega Keeps Her Distance
description: In ''50-50 Chance,'' the most compelling song on Suzanne Vega's third album, ''Days of Open Hand'' (A & M 7502; all three formats), the narrator pays a hospital visit to a woman who is near death. ''I tell you/ I love you/ I sing to you/ bring to you/ anything,'' she implores softly at her friend's bedside. Then in the last four lines, the tone abruptly changes. ''She's going home/ tomorrow at 10/ the question is/ will she try it again?'' the singer curtly observes, without apparent emotion.

title: Pastimes;   Bridge
description: The furor about gender-based events in national tournaments was almost, but not quite, laid to rest five months ago. After five years of legal maneuvering in California, the Board of Directors of the American Contract Bridge League modified its schedules: All men's events disappeared at national level and were replaced by open events run in parallel with women's events.

title: Foreman Bides Time
description: When James (Buster) Douglas decked Mike Tyson in Tokyo, George Foreman took it on the chin. The 41-year-old former champion, whose comeback campaign had been aimed at a title fight against Tyson this fall, suddenly found himself without a clear route to the top.

title: Mission Continuing
description: Sometimes the saints go marching out. Mother Teresa, the Roman Catholic nun who received the Nobel Peace Prize in 1979 for her work among the sick and dying, announced her retirement last week as head of the Missionaries of Charity, the religious order she founded in 1950. A Vatican spokesman said that the 79-year-old nun, who had a pacemaker implanted after she suffered a heart attack in September, was stepping down for health reasons. She is reported to rarely leave her home near the slums of Calcutta, which is also the headquarters of the Missionaries of Charity. The Vatican spokesman said that Pope John Paul II had accepted her resignation and that her successor is to be elected in September. The announcement of Mother Teresa's resignation prompted praise from around the world for her work and that of the Missionaries, an order that has grown to include 3,000 nuns working in 87 countries. Said Vi Collins, a member of the International Board for Co-Workers of Mother Teresa in Washington, D.C., ''She's just a living saint, she is a living saint of the gutters.''

title: Aging Can Be An Active Time
description: Paul Levine's article [''Gray Hairs and Creaky Limbs: Benchmarks of Aging,'' Opinion Page, March 25] presents a glum and depressing picture of a natural phenomenon - growing older. Although I am four years older, I cannot share Mr. Levine's dim view of life.

title: Leslie Hotchkiss To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Winchester F. Hotchkiss of Bernardsville, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Leslie Ellsworth Hotchkiss to John Ewins Arndt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. S. Arndt of Southport, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: Has Case Peaked With Poindexter?
description: IF the Iran-contra prosecution is, as it appears, petering out, its lack of resolution is no less frustrating for having been predictable. It is like a celebrated murder case in which several people have been found guilty of hiding a body that no one has been charged with killing.

title: For Youths On the Edge of Trouble
description: A GROUP of youngsters, from 16 to 21 years old, will take part in a weeklong job-training program this month that leads to a one-day job fair with potential employers. What is unusual about these youngsters is that they all have been involved with the juvenile-justice system.

title: Miss Marek to Wed M. Q. Armstrong
description: The engagement of Suzanne Marek to Matthew Q. Armstrong, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Q. Armstrong of Greenwich, Conn., has been announced by her parents, Jessica Ford Marek of Saddle River, N.J., and Zdenek R. Marek of New York. A June wedding is planned.

title: Fashion;   For Men, Colors in Sun-Washed Shades
description: Sun-bleached colors are this season's way for men to ease into warm-weather dressing, retailers in the New York area say.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey;   Recent Sales
description: Glen Rock $220,000

title: The Executive Computer;   Bragging Rights Aside, What Did Lotus and Novell Merge?
description: The proposed merger of the Lotus Development Corporation and Novell Inc., announced earlier this month, will unite two companies that dominate their respective fields. Assuming the deal goes through, Lotus, which makes the 1-2-3 financial analysis program, and Novell, which makes the Netware operating system for networked computers, will have combined 1990 revenues of nearly $1.2 billion. That would make the merged company almost the same size as the powerful Microsoft Corporation, which until now has been nearly twice the size of its nearest rival, Lotus, in the personal computer software industry.

title: An Insightful View Of U.S. Education
description: As a foreign citizen who has recently graduated from one Westchester college (Manhattanville) while also taking a few courses at another (the State University of New York at Purchase), I dispute the popular belief that education in America is fast declining in comparison to that in other countries.

title: Point Counter Point
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Fanny' Is Staged With Elegance
description: If only to reaffirm one's faith in the power of the musical theater to stir and move us, a fine revival of ''Fanny'' - no, it's not the one about Fanny Brice - opened at the Paper Mill Playhouse during the same weekend that ''Aspects of Love,'' with its $11 million advance sale, had a long-awaited Broadway premiere.

title: POSTING: Who Can Do What?;   Co-op Board Law
description: A two-year battle between a plastic surgeon and the co-op board of 1 Fifth Avenue, at Washington Square North, has resulted in a New York State Court of Appeals decision that strengthens the powers of a building's directors, including their right to control renovations in shareholders' apartments. The two sides came to legal blows over a kitchen steampipe.

title: Combined Impact In Central Nassau
description: The article ''Assessing Impact Of New Projects on Environment: How Hard a Look?'' [March 18] deals with an issue of the utmost importance for central Nassau civic leaders.

title: Ms. James to Wed Kevin J. Abrams
description: Dr. and Mrs. David Fred James of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Wendy Susan James and Kevin Jay Abrams, a son of Eileen Abrams of Riverdale, the Bronx, and Stuart Abrams of Great Neck, L.I.

title: Again, the Right U.S. Stance on Jerusalem
description: The mail has brought welcome news.

title: POSTING: Bay Ridge Project;   From Rectory to Condos
description: A 14-unit condominium apartment development is nearing completion on the former site of the rectory of Christ Church of Bay Ridge in Brooklyn near Shore Road Park and the Narrows. Called the Ridge Terrace Condominium, the $2.3 million project at 228 74th Street near Third Avenue is due to be completed next month.

title: Who Is the M.V.P. In the N.B.A.?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or return unpublished letters.

title: Deirdre Corcoran to Marry Ray Foote 3d Next Month
description: The engagement of Deirdre Mary-Charlene Corcoran to Ray Palmer Foote 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Foote Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., has been made known by her parents, Irene Corcoran and Dr. Joseph R. Corcoran of Moorestown, N.J. A May wedding is planned.

title: Timothy Higginson, a Law Student, To Marry Sally Schwartz, a Teacher
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alan G. Schwartz of Highland Park, Ill., have announced the engagement of their daughter Sally Roslyn Schwartz to Timothy Bowditch Higginson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Higginson of Cohasset, Mass., and Washington. A May wedding is planned.

title: A Slowdown for Soviet Joint Ventures
description: Kaj Hober, a partner in the Stockholm office of White & Case, an international law firm, has taken part in negotiations for 45 joint ventures between Soviet and Western companies. Mr. Hober, who teaches Soviet and Eastern European law at the University of Uppsala, is concerned about the Soviet economy but still sees opportunities for more joint ventures. He discussed the Soviet Union with Joel Kurtzman of The New York Times.

title: Summer Problems For L.I.R.R. Riders
description: IN the opening scene of the movie ''Married to the Mob,'' two dapper hoodlums have just rubbed out an enemy on a crowded Long Island Rail Road passenger train. As the two men squeeze through the crush of morning commuters to flee undetected, one says to the other:

title: IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut;   Recent Sales
description: New Rochelle, N.Y. $440,000

title: THE CHURCH IS STILL RESTLESS
description: LIBERATION THEOLOGY AT THE CROSSROADS

title: BETTER TIMES IN BEIJING
description: LEGACIES

title: Reinstatement Drive
description: Almost 70 years after he was banished from baseball for offering to quit the game if rival players would pay him enough to sabotage his team's chances of winning another pennant, a campaign is under way to win posthumous reinstatement for Phil Douglas, the spitballer who led the Giants to victory over the Yankees in the 1921 World Series.

title: Birth Defects and Pollution: Issue Raised in Texas Town
description: An unusual number of Down syndrome births in this industrious little city has propelled an investigation of pollution and set up the country's first legal test of an emerging medical theory that toxic chemicals could cause the birth defect.

title: THEIR MONEY WASN'T ENOUGH
description: ALFRED I. DU PONT

title: A Tiny but Fashionable Spot for Dinner
description: PRACTICALLY before Paul L'Abbee could say the word restaurant, he had one. What opened in New Canaan early last year as a deli-pastry shop and showcase for a Pound Ridge, N.Y., catering business, quickly accelerated into a modest dining spot, with a few tables for lunch, tea and sampling.

title:
Style Makers;

Willy White, Entrerpreneur
description: LEAD: When British Telecom announced in 1985 that its regal red telephone kiosks would be replaced with modern American-designed phone boxes, many people were outraged. Willy White, 30 years old, an Essex entrepreneur, was inspired.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: EASTER STROLLS

title: George Wyner to Wed Barbara Perkins
description: June wedding plans for Barbara Diane Perkins and George Michael Wyner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Justin L. Wyner of Chestnut Hill, Mass., have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. James W. Perkins of Dummerston, Vt.

title: Dinkins, in Switch, Urges Landlord Cost Index
description: In an apparent reversal of the position he took three years ago when he was Manhattan Borough President, Mayor David N. Dinkins is now pressing the Board of Estimate to approve a city contract for an annual cost survey that is an important feature of the rent-stabilization system. The board is scheduled to vote on the issue at a special meeting on Wednesday.

title: POSTING: Covering 17 Acres;   Chain Warehouse
description: ShopRite stores, a rapidly expanding supermarket chain with 178 stores in the Northeast, has entered into a joint venture to build a 700,000-square-foot warehouse on a 56-acre site near the New Jersey Turnpike in South Brunswick, N.J. When completed 16 months from now, the $50 million facility will have more than a mile of computer-controlled conveyor belts that will transfer containers of merchandise from storage to trailer trucks for distribution.

title: An Unpredictable Playwright Reverses Himself
description: George C. Wolfe is a man in the midst of transition. A playwright (''The Colored Museum,'' his 1986 satire of black American life) and director of the forthcoming ''Spunk,'' Mr. Wolfe says he's been feeling different lately. At first he thought it had to do with turning 35 last September. But he's more inclined to pin his current state of mind on New Year's Day 1990 and his annual gumbo party.

title: Panel Supports a Plan On Striped Bass Fishing
description: A plan to lift a four-year ban on the commercial fishing of striped bass in New York State has been given preliminary approval by an interstate fisheries commission.

title: Mental Health And Politics
description: The New York State Office of Mental Health is terminating aftercare services for some 700 Suffolk County patients to save $1.6 million, while spending that much on 25 privileged patients in two Nassau County residences, including a new one in East Hills, Roslyn.

title: Miss DeAngelis To Wed in May
description: A May wedding is planned by Kimberly Lynn DeAngelis and Martin Gerard Glavin, the prospective bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. John DeAngelis of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., have announced. Mr. Glavin is a son of James E. Glavin of Cranberry Lake, N.Y., and the late Helen Hartnett Glavin.

title: Disa Johnson Engaged to Charles S. Cheston 3d
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard F. Johnson of Carlisle, Mass., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Disa Johnson and Charles S. Cheston 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Cheston Jr. of Topsfield, Mass.

title: THE 70'S REVISITED: THE NOSTALGIA TRAIL HITS ROCK BOTTOM
description: Slower than sunspot cycles and as inexorable as the tides, pop-music nostalgia trails the present by about 20 years. ''Grease'' and Sha Na Na brought a 1950's revival in the 1970's, and in the 1980's rockers from the Dream Syndicate to Terence Trent D'Arby revived the 1960's. With the awful inevitability of arithmetic, the dawn of the 1990's threatens to bring a wave of music and apologia fondly recalling the early 1970's. I'm bracing myself - it was bad enough the first time.

title: Article 886790 -- No Title
description: One of two winners who will share last Wednesday's $35 million New York Lotto jackpot has turned in his ticket to claim his prize, state lottery officials said today.

title: N.B.A. Could Pay For Educations
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: When a Shipment of Plants Arrives
description: NURSERY orders that were mailed a few months back are now being filled. Cartons packed with live plants are arriving apace. The thing to do, of course, is open the cartons and plant the plants immediately? Right? Wrong. Opening the cartons as soon as possible is essential. The plants have been smothered for many days, and upon arrival, they will need to receive some air. This deed is important, but planting immediately is not. It may even be a bit hasty.

title: Defining Terms
description: To the Editor:

title: Pastimes;   Chess
description: There are chess players who do not play - the problemists and creators of end-game studies. To be sure, at some time in their youth they would have had to play the game, if only because it cannot be learned any other way. Yet at some point they became fascinated either by the composed problem - usually the task is to find the mate in two, three or four moves - or by the remarkable possibilities in the limited clusters of pieces that make up end games.

title: Catherine Carver To Wed in June
description: Dr. and Mrs. George A. Carver Jr. of Great Falls, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter Catherine Ruth Carver to Robert Cuyler McCurrach, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John C. McCurrach of Lincoln, Mass. A June wedding is planned.

title: Pictures and Letters Trace Burke's History
description: LEAD: BACK in 1915, the innovative Burke Foundation in White Plains was known for its new convalescent hospital, built ''for the deserving poor in a simple but dignified manner,'' as its architect put it at the time. Now the Burke Rehabilitation Center is celebrating its 75th anniversary, with two exhibitions about its work and history.

title: HIS YEAR OF LIVING DANGEROUSLY
description: TRIBES WITH FLAGS

title: Fighting Just Doesn't Pay
description: This article was excerpted from ''Home Game: Hockey and Life in Canada'' (McClelland & Stewart Inc., 1989) by Ken Dryden, the Hall of Fame goalie, and Roy MacGregor.

title: Ballet at The Met: A British Bundle Of Fresh Ideas
description: Imagine the unimaginable - the Metropolitan Opera House in the summer without companies like the Royal Ballet from Britain, the Royal Danish Ballet, the Paris Opera Ballet, the Kirov Ballet, the Bolshoi Ballet, the Netherlands Dance Theater, the London Festival Ballet, the Stuttgart Ballet, the National Ballet of Canada, Roland Petit's National Ballet of Marseilles and so on.

title:
ART;

Iceland Inspires Look to the Future
description: LEAD: IN Iceland, where the elements play a vital role in daily life, storytelling has been an essential part of cultural development for centuries.

title: Carol Dadakis to Wed P. T. McKeever
description: Mr. and Mrs. Constantine Dadakis of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Carol Coleman Dadakis to Peter Thomas McKeever, the son of Mrs. Paul B. McKeever of New Canaan, Conn., and the late Mr. McKeever. A June wedding is planned.

title: Some Missing Facts About Ducky the Swan
description: The story of Ducky the one-winged swan [''A Wing and a Prayer,'' Opinion, March 18] is very poignant and garners lots of sympathy for the case of saving critically disabled wildlife. But there are a few facts missing from this romantic story.

title: A Bantam Greenhouse Where Easter's in Bloom
description: AT Connecticut Cut Flowers in Bantam, the Easter season starts well before Christmas, with the planting of hundreds of bulbs so that, by today, there will be hundreds of Easter lily plants all in full bloom. A few weeks earlier, John and Joanne Creedon were busy, arranging for their delivery to churches, other florists, or for customers who had come in searching for the perfect Easter plant.

title:
DOVER JOURNAL;

Warner-Lambert Adopts a School, With No Strings Attached
description: LEAD: ON Saturday mornings at the Dover Public Library, there are the usual browsers and readers, but in the basement a more complex activity is taking place.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our house has a den whose walls are covered with vertical 1-by-8-inch, beveled-edge pine boards with quarter-round molding over each of the joints. The ceiling consists of exposed joists with the 1-by-6-inch subflooring exposed from the room above. Dark-brown stain has been used on all the woodwork, making the room dark. We want to lighten this wood and have considered whitewashing the walls. What would you suggest?

title: Success Stories Inspire Cancer Patients
description: LEAD: RAY BERTE had never lifted weights until he was told the sport would threaten his life.

title: Miss Ambrose Plans Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. John F. Ambrose of Pinehurst, N.C., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Nancy J. Ambrose and Scott G. Armstrong, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald S. Armstrong of Manhasset, L.I.

title: Gorbachev Tries to Develop Radical Economic Program
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev met today with his chief advisers in an attempt to craft his long-promised plan for ''radical'' prescriptions to cure the Soviet economy.

title: A Surrealist Who Was a Prism For Her Times
description: Compared to other photographers of World War II, Lee Miller was not necessarily the most driven, daring or talented, although she possessed all of these attributes. But she surely ranks as the most dazzlingly beautiful, sophisticated and colorful photojournalist ever to wear a war correspondent's patch on an olive-drab breast pocket.

title: Review/Dance;   A Melange in 'Characters' by Mark Franko's Novantiqua
description: Mark Franko is a Renaissance-dance scholar and a modern-dance choreographer and performer. He has named his five-year-old company Novantiqua. And so his newest piece, ''Characters of Dance,'' presented on Thursday at the Douglas Dunn Studio, seemed likely to be a blending of two very different styles of dance - or, as Mr. Franko described another piece, a collage or evocation of style.

title: Elizabeth C. Fleming, an Economist, Is Married
description: Elizabeth Cary Fleming, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Cornish Fleming of Mendham, N.J., was married yesterday to Malcolm Lauder Macpherson Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Macpherson of Short Hills, N.J. The Rev. Martha Robson officiated at the First Presbyterian Church in Mendham.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

Unexpected Treasures of the Heart
description: LEAD: BEING hopelessly ill is one thing. Being hopelessly ill and alone is another, but being hopelessly ill, alone and attracted to someone, heartrending.

title: Pastimes;   Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Plant lettuce, spinach, peas, onion sets, radish and set out seedlings of cabbage, broccoli and other hardy vegetables. It is much too early to set out seedlings of other vegetables and bedding annuals; wait for a month. Hunt the egg masses of gypsy moth, which resemble tan suede; scrap them off stones, shingles, fences and other places where found and either burn the bags in the fireplace or soak the egg masses in a coffee can filled with a strong dilution of laundry bleach. Indoors, keep seedlings moist, but do not overwater; these young plants will need applications of weak dilutions of water-soluble fertilizer.

title: Tamsin Mayers, Banker, to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul H. Mayers of Rowayton, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Tamsin Mayers to Timothy J. Sickinger Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sickinger of Omaha. A June wedding is planned.

title: About Men;   In Search of Bruce Lee's Grave
description: IT'S SATURDAY MORNING in Seattle, and I am driving to visit Bruce Lee's grave. I have been in the city for only a couple of weeks and so drive two blocks past the cemetery before realizing that I've passed it. I double back and turn through the large wrought-iron gate, past a sign that reads: ''Open to 9 p.m. or dusk, whichever comes first.''

title: Question of the Week;   How Can the N.H.L. Clean Up Its Act?
description: If a deliberate, injury-causing act occurs, the victimized player should be compelled to file an assault complaint with the local police department. Even though the complaint may later be dropped (at the victim's discretion), it will at minimum put these people on notice that more is at risk than a 20-minute stay in the penalty box.

title: For Thomas Hampson, Singing Is a Single Art
description: ''I am a juicy, lyric baritone, and I am not an opera singer who sings lieder. I am a singer!'' That vocal self-description comes from a big-boned, 6-foot 4-inch 34-year-old man with a shock of longish brown hair and Paul Newman blue eyes. He suggests, rather than a self-confident Mozartean in the opera house or Mahlerite on the concert stage, a member of the New York Rangers front line, except that his teeth are too good.

title: Painting a World in Words and Art
description: LEAD: AS Bijou Le Tord sits on a stuffed chair in her airy Noyac living room, she opens her newest book for children, ''The Deep Blue Sea,'' and reads it aloud to an adult visitor.

title: A Railroad Seating Primer
description: LET'S start with a basic truth. No one likes it when someone sits in the middle. Still, there are limits. The other night on a rush-hour Metro-North train boarding at Grand Central Terminal, a woman stretched herself across two-and-a-half of the three connected seats, sneakers proudly planted on the seat cover.

title: Brass Quintet to Offer John Cage's Silent Work
description: BRASS RING may give the most convincing sampling of the sound of silence since Simon and Garfunkel when the group invades New Haven's rock and roll sanctuary, Toad's Place, for an evening of contemporary classical music. On the quintet's program at 7:30 P.M. tomorrow is ''4'33'','' the celebrated piano composition by John Cage in which the performer sits in front of the keyboard for 4 minutes and 33 seconds without playing a note. It should be fascinating to see how well it works for brass instruments.

title: Campuses See a New Spirit of Involvement
description: Joseph Hilliman says he is not too familiar with the writings of Eldridge Cleaver, but he nonetheless ascribes to the slogan attributed to the former Black Panther: ''You're either part of the solution or part of the problem.''

title: Clemens Fans 10 And Gains 2d Victory
description: Roger Clemens struck out 10 batters in six and two-thirds innings today and won his second start of the season as the Boston Red Sox rallied to beat the Milwaukee Brewers, 4-3.

title: Earth Day: The Word Is Spreading
description: LEAD: A HUGE surge of energy is surrounding Earth Day 1990 in the Westchester area, with dozens of events on April 22 and the days before and after. There will be exhibitions, demonstrations, cleanups, nature walks, a fitness race, talks, music and vegetarian food.

title: Lifestyle:Sunday Dinner;   Places Where Dreams of Soft-Shell Crabs Come True
description: This is a summary of reviews of New York restaurants that offer good soft-shell crabs. The reviews, by Bryan Miller, appeared in The New York Times. Ratings are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current.

title: On Contributions Of Other Cultures
description: It is quite sad that an Irvington High School social studies teacher is so uninformed about the contributions of other cultures to western civilization and the history of mankind [''Why Study History?'' Westchester Opinion, March 25] . And he wishes others to remain so.

title: 10 Years of Support and Aid From Female Entrepreneurs
description: TEN years ago, two dozen female entrepreneurs started a support group to explore the problems facing women in business. Now more than 250 members strong, the Westchester Association of Women Business Owners is able to help other entrepreneurs. It is making five grants to area colleges and one to the Junior Achievement Program.

title: Europeans Warn Sihanouk on U.N. Seat
description: The 12 European Community countries have warned Prince Norodom Sihanouk that they will oppose the usual practice of giving Cambodia's United Nations seat to his coalition government-in-exile, because it includes the Khmer Rouge, which brutally ruled Cambodia from 1975 to 1978, European and Asian diplomats say.

title: Mutual Funds;   Questions for the Eleventh Hour
description: Tomorrow is the deadline for filing 1989 taxes, and many last-minute filers are spending the weekend putting the final touches on their returns. In fact, so many people drag their feet that April 15 traditionally is the biggest day of the year for investors' telephone calls at the New York-based Oppenheimer Management Corporation, one of the largest mutual fund groups.

title: All About/Texas Real Estate;   A Glut of Office Space Turns Enticing
description: Texas real estate people, dazed after the debacle of the 1980's, are now daring to brag of a rebound. The office market in the Northeast came back, so why not Texas, they ask. ''I really believe that great fortunes will be made over the next decade in Texas real estate to rival when Olympia & York made their big hit in New York in the 1970's,'' said Charles G. Dannis, president of Crosson Dannis Inc., a Dallas real estate appraiser.

title: Groups Helping Soviet Emigres Resettle
description: LEAD: WITH 2,000 Jews from the Soviet Union expected to resettle in New Jersey next year, Jewish organizations across the state are mounting a broad-based effort to assist the newcomers in starting new lives. Two major obstacles faced by the emigres are finding suitable jobs and affordable housing.

title: COMPOSERS WHO HAD TO TRIUMPH OVER PREJUDICE
description: Mention black American music, and most people will probably think of Ella Fitzgerald or Duke Ellington, of James Brown or Public Enemy. But few will think of William Grant Still, or of a host of black American classical composers. Their achievements are an integral part of the black musical heritage, however, and they have played a significant role in American music - even if they have been relegated to footnote status by the history books.

title: MUTILATED IN THE NAME OF TRADITION
description: PRISONERS OF RITUAL

title: Looking Into Accounting's Heart of Darkness
description: Chris Campos finds adventure in a retailer insisting he sells women's coats at full price in February. He can grow rhapsodic over learning of someone who can shamelessly bilk the boss's son. Somebody blows up a factory? Hold on, he'll be right there.

title: Canadians Cross Falls for U.S. Prices
description: Canadians are coming by car, by van and even by busload to buy brand-name goods at bargain prices compared with what they pay in Toronto and its suburbs.

title: Question of the Week;   How Can the N.H.L. Clean Up Its Act?
description: The N.H.L. should adopt rules similar to the National Basketball Association's. For fighting, the players should be ejected and fined. Subsequent fighting should be cause for suspension, and with intent to injure should be cause for expelling a player for the season.

title: Beth Wang and William H. Nast Are Engaged
description: Beth Amy Wang, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Wang of Newton, Mass., and William Henry Nast, a son of Alice Cycleman Nast of Mission Hills, Kan., and the late Nat Nelson Nast Jr., plan to marry in July.

title:
IN SHORT;

NONFICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Making Himself Useful
description: In his 12 years as governor of West Virginia, Arch A. Moore Jr. proved to be a rather industrious fellow. In addition to his official duties, he apparently found time to work on behalf of all manner of lobbyists, coal companies and others whose business could benefit from the intercession of the state's chief executive. Federal investigations of Mr. Moore go back to the early 1970's, but it wasn't until last week that the authorities were able to wrap up a case against him. Mr. Moore was indicted on and agreed to plead guilty to a raft of charges including extortion, mail and tax fraud and obstruction of justice. In one case, he helped a coal company get a refund of more than $2 million from the state's black lung fund and pocketed about 25 percent of it. He has admitted evading taxes on his extracurricular income. Mr. Moore said that while some would greet his indictment with ''great joy,'' others would be saddened. The latter referred to friends and family members but may well include some of his former associates. As part of his plea bargain, Mr. Moore has agreed to help in prosecuting other corruption cases.

title: Linda Cooper Is Engaged
description: May wedding plans for Linda Sue Cooper and Jenkins Cromwell Marshall, a son of Maria C. Marshall of Baltimore and Linton S. Marshall of Ocean City, Md., have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Marie M. Naisby of Annapolis, Md., and Earle F. Cooper of Avenel, N.J. Miss Cooper, 26 years old, is a vice president at Chase Manhattan Bank in New York. She and her fiance, who has an M.B.A. from New York University, are graduates of Dartmouth College. The prospective bridegroom, 28, is an international equity sales trader at the New York office of the Union Bank of Switzerland.

title: Round Five for a Theatrical Heavyweight
description: Sitting in a wooden booth at a restaurant across from the Yale University campus, chain-smoking and sipping cup after cup of black coffee, a 44-year-old bearded playwright is talking about success.

title: NONFICTION
description: SPARKY! By Sparky Anderson with Dan Ewald. (Prentice Hall, $18.95.) George (Sparky) Anderson has managed in the major leagues since 1970. He is the only manager to win more than 800 games with two different teams and to win a World Series in both leagues. Mr. Anderson also suffered a physical and emotional breakdown in May 1989, which he says was brought on by the daily stress of managing in the big leagues. This episode and his subsequent recovery are candidly discussed by Mr. Anderson, the manager of the Detroit Tigers, and his collaborator, Dan Ewald, the Tigers' public relations director, in ''Sparky!'' The book, however, is not merely a chronicle of a man's self-discovery and return to health; it is a fine baseball book filled with anecdotes and insights. Mr. Anderson's style is as direct and down-to-earth as a hard, clean slide into second. He writes of Pete Rose's gambling problems: ''He competed in everything. . . . That's why it doesn't surprise me that he did wager on football and basketball games.'' On managing: ''The problem comes up when managers try to show people they're smarter than everyone else.'' Mr. Anderson calls his former power-hitting, base-stealing second baseman Joe Morgan ''the greatest all around offensive player I ever managed.'' Ozzie Smith of the St. Louis Cardinals is labeled ''Harry Houdini with a glove.'' Mr. Anderson calls baseball a ''make-believe world'' and adds: ''The guy carrying the lunchbox, taking the bus to work so that he can feed a houseful of kids - he's in the real world. The wife going to work after sending the kids to school - she's in the real world.'' ''Sparky!'' gives us not only a vivid portrait of baseball's most successful manager but also a refreshing view of a guy who has his head screwed on right.

title: Adventures in Cooking;   A RAFT OF CHOICES
description: IT WAS 110 DEGREES ON THE BANKS OF THE RIO GRANDE , and I was struggling with the finishing touches on a birthday cake. Diane Lord, one of the guides on our river-rafting tour, had prepared a chocolate cake from a package mix she had brought along to celebrate the birthday of one of the tour participants. She pulled the cake out of the Dutch oven and passed it on to me. I started easily enough by joining the layers with the contents of a jar of strawberry jam. Then my troubles began. After heating together a quart of cream and a pound of bittersweet chocolate for a ganache to frost the cake, I was unable to get the mixture to harden enough in the extreme heat - even though I cooled it over ice - so that it was spreadable. We ended up serving the unfrosted cake in wedges with spoonfuls of ganache ''sauce'' on top and alongside. As we toasted the birthday celebrant with Champagne and tequila, we all agreed that we'd never had a piece of chocolate cake that tasted any better than this one.

title: Why Jeff Bloemberg Turned the Other Cheek
description: The finest moment in the opening round of the hockey playoffs has been supplied by neither a supple-wristed scorer nor a quick-handed goalie, but rather by a quiet man named Jeff Bloemberg, hunkering down and taking a flurry of punches to his head and body.

title: U.S. Prepares to Reduce Spying Posts in Germany
description: As a result of the political upheaval in Eastern Europe, American intelligence officials are preparing to close down expensive electronic listening posts and to conduct a major re-evaluation of United States operations in the region.

title: Despite Sanctions, Steel From Pretoria Is Entering the U.S.
description: The Bush Administration has allowed thousands of tons of South African iron and steel into the United States because of the way it has interpreted a 1986 sanctions law intended by its sponsors to ban such imports.

title: In Morris County, a Changing Outlook on Development
description: LEAD: TOWERING above the suburban landscape, the seven-story glass and granite office building under construction in a less developed part of Morris County is indicative of a changed outlook on commercial development in the county.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: RECENT RELEASES
description: CLASSICAL

title: PAN AM 103: THE GERMAN CONNECTION
description: At the same time that I was reading your article, I was watching ''Sunday Morning,'' with Charles Kuralt reporting on the first free elections in East Germany since that country elected Adolph Hitler. Forty-five years ago, that independent country's political and military establishments led the German people to slaughter 12 million people in a quest for European domination. Forty-five years has not allowed even one generation to pass since that nightmare. The indifference and subsequent cover-up by the present German Government to the activities of known terrorists, which led to the tragedy of Flight 103, illustrates that there yet remains a German mentality lacking in sensitivity to the fate of individuals and nations other than its own.

title:
IN SHORT;

NONFICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Miss Cairns to Wed Christian Sampson
description: The engagement of Megan Clifton Cairns to Dr. Christian Edward Sampson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Sampson of Carlisle, Mass., has been announced by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Arthur C. Cairns of Montreal. A June wedding is planned.

title: Revival Houses In the Era Of Videocassettes
description: The film '' 'Beat the Devil' is directed by John Huston, written by Truman Capote and stars Humphrey Bogart, Peter Lorre, Gina Lollobrigida and Jennifer Jones. It deals with a remarkably odd assortment of Iranian-speaking travelers [sic] . The formula is that everyone is slightly absurd, according to Huston.''

title: Question of the Week;   How Can the N.H.L. Clean Up Its Act?
description: Since the overall speed of the game has increased tremendously, the N.H.L. should compensate by employing three referees. This setup (with a senior official and two partners who also perform the duties of linesmen) will help cut down on the many minor infractions that are catalysts for major brawls.

title: 2 Suspects in a Trooper's Slaying Were Free on Bail, the Police Say
description: Two New York City men accused of killing a Maryland state trooper were free on bail and awaiting sentencing for assault and handgun convictions when the trooper was shot to death on March 29, the authorities say.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: CHESTER;

Despite Tough Times, Main Street Finds Some Optimism
description: LEAD: NOBODY can remember when Chester did not have a grocery store - until mid-February, when Lyman's Village Market closed. But the store will not be shuttered much longer. Its previous operators, Charlene and Bill Janecek, recently completed negotiations to reopen the market. The couple, who run the Lunch Box sandwich shop on Main

title: The Naming of Newark And Helmetta
description: Abraham Resnick's recent Opinion page article, ''Where Did This Name Come From?,'' said: ''But Newark was apparently not named after England's Newark, as many people have thought. A number of scholars have returned to an earlier theory that the New Jersey city was originally named New Ark, or New Work, by the Puritan Congregational Church.''

title: THE NATION: Texas Primary;   Higher Aspirations From Low Campaign
description: THE fate of Western civilization probably does not hinge on the Texas gubernatorial race, but political pros were taking no chances. After Ann Richards won the Democratic primary last week, the experts looked forward to her fall contest against Clayton Williams, a conservative oilman, as a test of the political significance of gender, the impact of suspected drug use by a candidate, the temper of the electorate on abortion, the future of liberalism and the potential for a Democratic Presidential victory in 1992.

title: How John Sayles Shuffled 'Shannon's Deal'
description: When the writer John Sayles and the producer Stan Rogow first collaborated nearly a decade ago, the result was memorable in ways neither man had intended. A project they deemed commercially lucrative and artistically intriguing - a film adaptation of ''The Clan of the Cave Bear,'' Jean M. Auel's best-selling novel about prehistoric tribes - failed spectacularly on both counts. While bringing in a paltry $1.9 million at the box office, the movie reaped an abundance of ridicule, both for its spectacle of Hollywood stars in animal skins and its dialogue of grunts and gestures, translated in English subtitles.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: The Swiss Bank Tower;   A Building Designed to Suit Needs and Neighbors
description: WHEN the architect Lee Harris Pomeroy gives a tour of the Swiss Bank Tower, nearing completion behind the Saks Fifth Avenue flagship store, he begins a block away, in the middle of Rockefeller Center.

title: The History of 'Everyday People'
description: JEREMY BRECHER is working to fill in some large gaps of Connecticut history. For 10 years now, the social historian has traveled across the state collecting oral histories from people who rarely appear in history books, including local ethnic pioneers and former labor union organizers.

title: 3-Day Festival to Celebrate G.B.S.
description: HE was interested in everything, he knew it all, or was convinced he did, and he kept changing his mind.

title: Review/Rock;   Australians and Texans In Industrial Variations
description: Machines played most of the music and video screens had all the best images when Severed Heads, from Australia, and M.C. 900 Foot Jesus with D.J. Zero, from Texas, shared a bill on Tuesday night at the RAPP Arts Center. Each group plays its own hybrid of industrial rock, music that uses a booming dance beat to carry cynical or dire lyrics amid dense, clashing rhythms and noises. The music simultaneously imitates and denounces modernity, using machines to protest against their brutalizing effect.

title: There Is A Method To Walesa's Meandering
description: LISTENING to Lech Walesa talk politics is like staring at an Impressionist painting from two inches away: It doesn't make much sense unless you take a few steps back and view the whole canvas.

title: Bulgaria Reports Discovery Of Mass Grave From 1940's
description: A mass grave in which 40 people were buried has been found in southwestern Bulgaria, and the authorities believe that it dates from the Soviet invasion in World War II, the official news agency B.T.A. said today.

title: Lori Josephson Is Married
description: Lori Josephson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Denny Josephson of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and John C. Dodd 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dodd Jr. of Westlake, Ohio, were married last evening at the Georgian Suite in New York by the Rev. Orlanda Brugnolo, a Unitarian minister. Mrs. Dodd, 28 years old, is a manager of gift wares in Chelsea Passage at Barneys New York. She graduated from Florida State University. Mr. Dodd, 30, is the president and the creative director of H2O Advertising and Design in New York. He graduated magna cum laude from Kent State University.
