description: LEAD:

title: Paid Time and Working Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Looking Ahead
description: MONDAY: I.B.M. reports first-quarter earnings.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Menu;   Mussels, Done the Easy Way, With Rice
description: The first time I ever saw a Greek recipe for mussels with rice, pine nuts and currants, it seemed so complicated that I put it aside in the recipe file where it lay for 20 years before being discarded. The recipe called for cooking the mussels, cooking the rice, stuffing each cooked mussel shell with the pilaf and tying each shell with thread to hold it closed while the whole was reheated.

title: As Assessments Shrink, School Taxes are Rising
description: LEAD: SCHOOL officials in the county, preparing to submit 1990-91 budgets to voters next month, say a shrinking tax base and other factors beyond their control are to blame for the higher-than-normal proposed tax increases in some local districts.

title: Stephanie R. Maggart To Wed Philip Johnson
description: Mr. and Mrs. James Richard Maggart of Houston have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Stephanie Ruth Maggart and Philip Davies Johnson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul H. Johnson of Guilford, Conn.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;

New Approaches to Controlling Termites
description: LEAD: FOR many homeowners on Long Island whose houses have termite infestation, new products on the market could mean that an end is in sight to years of being told their houses could either not be treated at all, or could only be partially treated, allowing termite problems to recur.

title: DIGITAL SIGNALS FROM THE SKY ENLIVEN RADIO
description: New ways of sending music through the sky are being developed in an effort to upgrade the quality of radio transmissions. Receivers designed for home reception of digital satellite signals have just made a successful debut in Europe.

title: THEN THE SPOON SPEAKS UP
description: SKINNY LEGS AND ALL By Tom Robbins. 422 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $19.95. By Joe Queenan WITH the retirement of Ronald Reagan, the demise of Drexel Burnham Lambert and the collapse of the Japanese stock market, it is generally agreed that the 1980's are over. The 1960's, however, are still very much with us - not only in the presence of porky, recidivist rock stars but in the continuing literary efforts of Tom Robbins, who is back with yet another surrealistic, phantasmagoric, free-association novel that makes you want to dust off those old Firesign Theater records and don those frayed, tie-dyed bell bottoms one last time.

title: Nancy Reagan Astrologized
description: To the Editor:

title: A Drive to Help Needy Campers
description: LEAD: GOING to summer camp will always be out of reach for some youngsters unless they are given financial assistance. So for 33 years, the New Rochelle Campership Fund has been raising money for needy campers.

title: Make That 50,000,001
description: A report on the Headliners page last Sunday about historians' views of Charles de Gaulle misstated the year of de Gaulle's resignation as President of France. It was 1969, not 1968.

title: THE IMPORTANCE OF BEING MACHO
description: MANHOOD IN THE MAKING

title: Campus Life: Claremont McKenna;   Gay Student Wins Bid to Revise Anti-Bias Policy
description: After months of debate, a gay student at Claremont McKenna College has claimed victory in his effort to persuade the school to include sexual orientation in its nondiscrimination policy.

title: J.L. Neisloss to Wed Miss Conyngham
description: Alison Hillard Conyngham and James Louis Neisloss plan to marry in June. Miss Conyngham is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John N. Conyngham of Shavertown, Pa. Mr. Neisloss is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley L. Neisloss of Oyster Bay, L.I.

title: Review/Piano;   Beethoven, Schumann, Fischer
description: With the 97-year-old Polish-born pianist Mieczyslaw Horszowski scheduled to perform soon in Carnegie Hall, one needn't dwell too much on the age of his Hungarian colleague Annie Fischer, who gave a stirring recital at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Thursday evening. Strong and vigorous at 75, Miss Fischer richly displayed the benefits of experience, playing with serene authority and assurance. Even the defects could not automatically be attributed to age.

title: Currency;   Little Help From the Group of Seven
description: After the meeting in Paris a week ago of the finance ministers of the Group of Seven industrialized nations, central banks in Japan, the United States and Europe sold dollars to support the weak Japanese yen. But the intervention had little impact because the Group of Seven seemed only lukewarm in its concern. By week's end, the dollar had risen against the yen and fallen against the West German mark.

title: Melinda Highley to Wed in December
description: The engagement of Melinda de Wees Highley to Thorson Rockwell, a son of Ramona Thorson Rockwell of Denver and Dwight Rockwell Jr. of New York, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Anne Bobst-Highley of New York and Milan, Italy, and Richard Beard Highley of Nassau, the Bahamas. A December wedding is planned.

title: When the Rich And the Powerful Were Riding High
description: I am trying to create television for the 1990's. I'm not sure I'll be as good at it as I was 13 years ago, when I didn't know anything. Tapping into the pulse of the times is easier to explain in hindsight than to plan.

title: TALKING: Default Sales;   Foreclosed Property Bargains
description: A GROWING number of residential properties are being offered at below-market prices by lenders who have foreclosed on defaulting homeowners and troubled developers. The Dime Savings Bank of New York, for example, has 600 foreclosed homes available, and other banks also have large stocks of seized houses that they want to sell quickly.

title: Savor Rangers' Division Title
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;

FINGERTIP WISDOM
description: LEAD:

title: A Model of Self-Reliance Asks for Help
description: HIGH WATCH FARM is known for the serenity it provides for recovering alcoholics. But these days the place is less serene than usual. Along with the chirping of birds and the rustling of daffodils, the occasional sound of the hammer is heard, as the rural treatment center undergoes the first major building renovation in its 50-year history.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: DETROIT;

50-Story Tower For Downtown
description: LEAD: GERALD D. HINES INTERESTS of Houston and the Kawasaki Steel Corporation of Tokyo have begun work on a 50-story office tower that will be the largest downtown project here since the building of the Renaissance Center in the mid-70's.

title: Sanchez Vicario And Graf in Final
description: If Steffi Graf were really the tennis machine she is so often accused of being, she would simply have broken down this afternoon when things began to go awry in her semifinal match against the Soviet Union's Natalya Zvereva in the semifinals of the Bausch & Lomb championships.

title: Youth Held in Attack on Subway Killer
description: A 17-year-old Brooklyn youth was charged yesterday with being one of four men who tried to rob a subway rider Thursday night, just before the victim pulled a gun from his waistband and shot one assailant to death.

title: A MOZARTEANMUSE OF A DIFFERENT FEATHER?
description: Most books about Mozart are silent about the death of his pet starling. ''Mozart in Person: His Character and Health'' by Peter J. Davies does not include the event in a seven-page chronology of his career. Even the New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians does not let out so much as a chirp on the subject. Only a few bio-fantasists like Wolfgang Hildesheimer have raised the possibility that the premature shuffling off of this talkative bird influenced Mozart's creative output during the crucial year of 1787.

title: On the Trail of the American Cowboy
description: LEAD: COWBOYS have a bad track record in Westchester. During the Revolutionary War, they rustled cattle, kidnapped colonists, burned homes and churches for the British and made a general nuisance of themselves. We all know what happens to bad cowboys. They have to leave town by sundown. The Westchester cowboys saddled up and rode off to Ontario and Nova Scotia.

title: POSTING: A Package for Patterson;   Shops, Offices and Movies at One Site
description: A proposal to build one of the largest shopping centers in Putnam County, N.Y., is under review by the Town of Patterson. The $20 million project would be built on Route 22 about two miles south of the hamlet of Patterson, near the boundary with the Town of Southeast. It would contain a 30,000-square-foot office building and an eight-screen movie theater as well as 145,000 square feet of retail space. Parking for more than 1,000 cars would be included.

title: Betting History Offers a Lesson
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Outing;   Not a Backyard Garden: 400 Acres and a Mansion
description: William Robertson Coe was a wealthy insurance broker and an avid horticulturist who for 40 years cultivated the trees, plants and flowers at his 400-acre estate in this North Shore town.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

Health Care Is Everyone's Problem
description: LEAD: NOT too many decades ago, a favorite saying of older folks began, ''As long as you have your health. . . .'' This pious hope pretty well summed it up as far as health care went; there wasn't much else to do.

title: THE HAPPY SLUMLORD
description: MEN UNDER WATER. By Ralph Lombreglia (Doubleday, $17.95.) This powerful first collection of stories is mostly about young men on the cutting edge of failure. Bright, sensitive and reasonable, Ralph Lombreglia's affecting protagonists hurt profoundly as they are forced, time and again, into making barbarous contracts with a mad and maddening world. Their love lives are always tentative, often explicitly on trial (in ''Monarchs,'' the narrator and his friend June are on ''relationship probation''). Work, if more colorful, is equally problematic, as the minds of employers grow more eccentric and impenetrable by the moment. A vague notion of escape hovers constantly about these narratives (in ''Goodyear,'' a famous blimp becomes a seductive, horizon-filling image of simply floating away). Yet in the end it is not escape that provides release, but a kind of inexplicable, stunning illumination that shines suddenly on life and transforms it forever in a welling, irrational joy. Such an epiphany is central in ''Monarchs,'' where human troubles are subsumed into the spectacle of infinite clouds of butterflies, and also in ''Purification,'' a beautifully wrought story in which a young painter is informed by his father-in-law - an unlikely source for such a remark - that his paintings are about a kind of glory. Yet the most intractable and best-realized material is left for the title story. Gunther, an obese and whining slumlord, dreams of writing blockbuster film scripts; his young handyman, who thought he was hired to fix toilets, is eventually beguiled into helping Gunther on his dubious road to fame. The young man is in continual despair, Gunther is implacably vulgar and stupid, yet in the last scene the two are underwater in Gunther's pool, happily sharing the mouthpiece from a single scuba tank. Communion, ''Men Under Water'' seems to say, is not always a meeting of hearts and minds; it can be as simple as floating, or breathing the same air.

title: World Markets;   Europe's Hot Place to Bet on Stocks
description: First it was Austria and then West Germany. Norway got some notice. Now it's springtime in Paris.

title: In Connecticut, Whoever Wins Will Be a Switch
description: MORE than six months before Election Day, the race to succeed Gov. William A. O'Neill of Connecticut has already turned out to be the state's most tumultuous political contest in 20 years. No matter who wins, it will undoubtedly mark the end of the moderate-conservative Democratic Party establishment that has occupied the top state offices in Hartford since the election of Gov. Ella T. Grasso in 1974. The leading candidate in most polls, former United States Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., is a liberal Republican running as an independent. If elected, he would likely strip power away from both political parties. He often fought with both parties when he held office as a Republican.

title: The Grand Antiques Shops of Florence
description: THE antiques dealers of Florence reign over shops filled with artifacts that reflect the city's medieval, Renaissance and 19th-century past and include some of the finest examples of such material found anywhere in the world. These merchants have such abundant holdings in the decorative arts for which Florence is famous -majolica, furniture, decorations, architectural sculpture or arms and armor - that their businesses occupy two or more premises or several floors in a palazzo.

title: Ex-Senator's Comeback Confuses Race in Florida
description: Florida Democrats, sensing vulnerability in a first-term Republican Governor, sought to avoid the usual intra-party wrangling this year. But their plan to unify early behind one candidate to unseat the Governor, Bob Martinez, has gone awry.

title: Jackson Assails 'Outrage' in Teaneck
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson and a lawyer representing the family of Phillip C. Pannell, the black teen-ager who was fatally shot last week by a white police officer in Teaneck, N.J., yesterday called for the appointment of a special prosecutor to investigate the killing.

title: Rough-Hewn Melodies From Texas Romantics
description: Texas is so vast that entire musical careers can get lost in it. But since interest in regional sounds runs high now, small labels are bound to keep uncovering Lone Star favorites like the songwriter Butch Hancock and the accordionist Steve Jordan. Both are seasoned romantics with a flair for melodies and sentiments at once rough-hewn and delicate.

title: Another Kid in the Kitchen
description: It is crowded in the kitchen. In a corner the baby leans back in her walker, gumming a biscuit. In another a toddler is eating Alphabits. A teen-age boy, a skyscraper to the little ones, passes through with that sullen silence teen-age boys own. A teen-age girl, her hair a corn-colored tail down her back, scoops ice cream at the counter.

title: Students Train For Broadcasting
description: LEAD: ''WHEN Howard Stern or Scott Muni kick off, I want to take over for them,'' said Glen Adams, director of the New Jersey branch of the Connecticut School of Broadcasting, in describing student attitudes when they first enroll in the school to become disk jockeys. But, Mr. Adams said, there is a lot more to it than that.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: IT is snowing. What a funny thing - snow so late in the season. Snow falling on daffodils, on the phoebe; melting on Scherman-Hoffman Sanctuaries Drive but sticking to the wintered grass. Maybe the smart money this year wasn't on the groundhog after all.

title:
DINING OUT;

A Good Start on Fulfilling Promises
description: LEAD: SIX months ago, the gentrification of what was little more than a hamburger and sandwich place called the Mount Kemble Inn into an upscale restaurant renamed Harding House was viewed by local diners with a mixture of excitement and skepticism.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-11

title: Single-Lever Faucets
description: SINGLE-LEVER faucets like those found in many kitchens vary greatly in design. Rotating-ball faucets are one common kind, distinguishable by the dome-shaped base of the handle.

title: Ominous Embers From the Fire of 1989
description: A silence has settled over China a year after a few fragile white flowers appeared at Tiananmen Square to ignite the student democracy movement, but it is an eerie calm and a potentially explosive one.

title: Some Areas Showing Surges of Growth
description: ALTHOUGH Long Island's population has grown only slightly since 1980 and the economy appears to be flagging, some areas are experiencing surges of growth and expansion.

title: Pornography and Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Boomerang
description: To the Editor:

title: Oilers Tie Series By Beating Jets, 4-3
description: Jari Kurri scored the game-winner midway through the third period as the Edmonton Oilers beat the Winnipeg Jets, 4-3, tonight to keep their National Hockey League playoff series alive.

title: Nets' Fans Loyal In Loss to Pacers
description: From a Net fan's perspective, there has been little to cheer or smile about this season. Tonight, however, as New Jersey was being soundly trounced by Indiana, the 9,235 spectators at Byrne Meadowlands Arena finally had a chance to whoop it up.

title: Astros End Their Bid For Record of 0-162
description: After losing their first four games, the Houston Astros knew it would be tough to win against Orel Hershiser. They didn't beat up on Hershiser, but they did beat the Los Angeles Dodgers, 7-3, today to become the last major league team to win this season.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on page 1 of the Arts and Leisure section today discusses August Wilson and his new play, ''The Piano Lesson.'' On Thursday, after the section went to press, Mr. Wilson was awarded the Pulitzer Prize for the play.

title: Community Orchestras Offer Family Programs
description: UNLIKE avocational choirs, which often attain professional standards, community orchestras are not likely to be confused with the New York Philharmonic. Nonetheless, the players' enthusiasm in such ensembles can be quite infectious. When their concerts have the added benefit of being free, music lovers should take heed - and possibly take the children, too.

title: Africa
description: To the Editor: Having returned recently from Africa, I would like to acquaint your readers with certain problems with airline personnel. We were booked on South African Airways from Cape Town to Victoria Falls, Zimbabwe. The plane from Cape Town arrived slightly late in Johannesburg. After collecting our luggage, we presented ourselves at the check-in counter for the flight to Victoria Falls. It was 20 minutes before departure, and we were turned away. Having missed the only flight that day, we were charged an additional fare of $300 a person, which was more than the original ticket, and had to travel by way of Harare, stopping over there for the night before continuing to Victoria Falls.

title: Peru's New Frontrunner Vows Shake-Up on Coca and Rebels
description: Alberto Fujimori, the 51-year-old son of Japanese immigrants who displaced Mario Vargas Llosa last week as presidential frontrunner, is vowing to shake up Peru, attacking coca cultivation and guerrilla violence and pushing for the entry of this Andean land into the booming economy of the Pacific.

title: Hitler-Stalin Pact Involved More Than Poland
description: To the Editor:

title: Spies & Thrillers
description: Here are four nice, inoffensive, elderly, retired British spies, the last ones of their generation, affectionately treated by Bob Cook in PAPER CHASE (St. Martin's, $14.95). They have nothing left to do except to meet once in a while, gossip, talk about the good old days. Enter a tough agent of the new school. He warns them never to talk to the press or write their memoirs. Otherwise, they will be facing a stiff prison sentence. He treats them like dirt.

title: Modern Noahs Rescue Wildlife
description: LEAD: NO road signs point the way to the North American Wildlife Association in East Lyme. The turn off Walnut Hill Road is not marked, and the steep dirt road winds through the woods to a wire fence. Beyond the fence, narrow footpaths lead to more than 100 animal pens tucked among the trees.

title: Lisa Anne Kraus, Producer, to Wed
description: Dr. Joyce Aronson of New York and Madison, Conn., and Eric Kraus of Newbury, Vt., have announced September wedding plans for their daughter, Lisa Anne Kraus, and Edward G. Goldfinger, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Stephen E. Goldfinger of Newtonville, Mass.

title: Adventurous Composer Sees New Challenges
description: LEAD: HOW the approaching 21st century will regard the 20th-century concert music that John Lessard and his similarly adventurous colleagues have created in the name of ''contemporary music'' is something the veteran composer is reluctant to prophesy.

title: Burr's Descendants Challenge the Blots on His Reputation
description: LEAD: THE weatherworn headstone of Aaron Burr Jr. is nearly hidden from view by overgrown, untamed evergreens that shield it on three sides. The once deeply embedded epitaph has eroded, making the words illegible. Any flowers at the foot of the 154-year-old grave marker have long since withered and been blown away.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ended March 31

title: A Trout? No, It's a Tree
description: SOMEWHERE in the night a salmon rolled lazily across a pool in the Lyd River. Then a sea trout broke the surface and leaped close by, unseen but distinguished by the whirring of its powerful tail, before splashing back into the stream. A mist crept over the darkened meadows of England's West Country under the distant lee of Dartmoor. The stars fell cold.

title: Gooden Pounded A Second Time
description: Is Dwight Gooden tipping his pitches?

title: County and City at Odds in Mapplethorpe Case in Cincinnati
description: The latest dispute here over the Robert Mapplethorpe photography exhibit involves not so much whether the authorities should prosecute as which authorities should do so.

title: Senators Critical of Moscow For Threatening Lithuanians
description: The Senate majority leader and a delegation of Senate Democrats today condemned the Soviet Union's threat to cut off essential supplies to Lithuania, saying it amounted to intimidation and coercion.

title: Review/Opera;   'Giovanni' Principals Trade Roles
description: The impact of cast changes on a Metropolitan Opera production is measured less by the quality of individual voices than by the traumas inflicted on ensemble. At Wednesday's performance of the Met's new ''Don Giovanni,'' the Don and Leporello switched roles; and given the fact that Ferruccio Furlanetto and Samuel Ramey had been together, albeit in different parts, from the first rehearsals of this enterprise, they behaved very differently in their change of clothes.

title:
Style Makers;

Jean-Louis Menard and Daniel Rozensztroch, Design Consultants
description: LEAD: ''Too slick, too polished, too plastic is out,'' Jean-Louis Menard said. ''This is the beginning of the antimachine age,'' added Daniel Rozensztroch, his partner. The interior-design consultants believe the time is right for their new Filo di Ferro line, a 40-piece collection of handwoven iron wire objects like fruit bowls, egg baskets, cake trays, candlesticks and glass holders.

title:
The Executive Life;

It's 6 A.M., So That Must Be the Hairdresser
description: LEAD: Meet Carlo. Every morning at about 6, the star hairdresser from the Pierre Hotel's beauty salon rings the doorbell at the Upper East Side apartment of Linda J. Wachner, chief executive of Warnaco Inc. Once inside, he accompanies the bleary-eyed Ms. Wachner down the hall to her bathroom, where he washes and dries her hair.

title: Amalie Moses Is to Wed in September
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alfred H. Moses of McLean, Va., have announced September wedding plans for their daughter Amalie Celeste Moses and William Mark Reichblum, a son of Mr. and Mrs. M. Charles Reichblum of Pittsburgh.

title: Q and A
description: Meditation Vacations

title: Question of the Week;   How Can the N.H.L. Clean Up Its Act?
description: The solution is simple: penalize the coach. Assess a game misconduct to any coach whose player instigates a fight.

title:
ABOUT LONG ISLAND;

Over the River and Through the Woods
description: LEAD: STANDING by an entrance to the Greenbelt Trail in Woodbury, Fred Feller looks concerned. Five members of the triathlon team he sponsors started their weekly two-wheeled ride 40 minutes ago, and are now long overdue.

title: Review/Opera;   Cast Changes In the Met's 'Fledermaus'
description: Johann Strauss's ''Fledermaus'' has returned to the Metropolitan Opera repertory after a 10-week hiatus. The current run, which closes on Thursday, features singers who have taken on the principal roles since the Otto Schenk production was last reviewed.

title: Just How Powerful Are Those Turtles?
description: Commenting on the limitations of his methods away from the couch, Sigmund Freud once said that pyschoanalysis might have to ''lay down its arms'' before the problem of understanding art. He then proceeded to interpret the works of Dostoevsky, Ibsen and Leonardo da Vinci anyway. So it seems viable for a modern analyst to hazard a few modest guesses about what young psyches make of Teen-Age Mutant Ninja Turtles, the subjects of a monstrously successful movie that had earlier incarnations in a comic-book spoof, toys and a children's television cartoon show. Of particular interest is the psychological basis for the Turtles' appeal, and whether Turtlemania should be a cause for alarm.

title: In Tight Quarters, One-Dish Meals
description: DO people who live in the country spend more time in their kitchens than city dwellers? Manhattan apartment kitchens are so often like mine - an afterthought tucked away in a hall closet, the brilliant coup of some architect determined to make two tight little apartments fit where one would have been perfectly comfortable.

title: Kristen Peterson To Marry in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. George Peterson 3d of Bernardsville, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kristen Bouvier Peterson, to William Brace Krag Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Krag of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich. A May wedding is planned.

title: Yale Heavyweights Win One for Coach
description: Yale's varsity heavyweight crew gave its new head coach his first victory today, defeating Cornell and Dartmouth in a triangular regatta on a blustery Housatonic River course.

title: Collective Farms in Czechoslovakia Score One Success for Communism
description: While all the talk these days is about the failures of Communism, this village's 10,000-acre farm cooperative, with its uninterrupted fields of wheat and alfalfa and dozens of powerful tractors, is testimony to one of Communism's few economic successes.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Miners' and Truckers' Strike In Mongolia Protests Layoffs
description: Truck drivers joined coal miners today in a strike supported by one of Mongolia's largest opposition groups, residents said.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Crowd Attacks K.G.B. Site in Armenia
description: About 1,000 protesters attacked the K.G.B. headquarters in the capital of the Armenian republic late Saturday, pelting the building with stones and torches, the official Soviet press agency said today. One man was killed in the violence.

title: Statewide Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income Latest first quarter results included a provision for loan losses of $13 million, bringing the total reserve to $20 million.

title: Business and the Law;   Biden's Challenge To Federal Courts
description: ''THE real problem here is that Federal judges have lifetime tenure,'' said a senior Judiciary Committee aide last week, lamenting Article III of the Constitution. ''That would make it difficult to make judges accountable and force them to follow the Biden Act.''

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of April 15, 1990: MONDAY Genuine Parts Co Pope & Talbot Inc B F Goodrich Co Russ Tog Inc Eli Lilly & Co Southern Co Lubys Cafeterias Inc TUESDAY AAR Corp Mellon Bk Corp American Cap Mgmt Reliance Group Hldgs Inc CSX Corp Smuckers J M Co Dana Corp Southern Ind Gas & Elec Co Eastern Utils Assoc Suntrust Bks Inc Hawaiian Elec Inds Inc Teco Energy Inc Honeywell Inc V F Corp ICM Ppty Invs Inc WEDNESDAY Alberto-Culver Co IMC Fertilizer Group Inc American Home Prods Mexico Fd Inc C R Bard Inc Mortgage & Rlty Tr Barnett Bks Inc PSI Hldgs Inc Cincinnati Gas & Elec Co Republic NY Corp Clorox Co Charles Schwab Corp Dun & Bradstreet Corp Tyler Corp THURSDAY Bearings Inc Delaware Oneok Inc Black & Decker Corp PPG Inds Inc Central & S W Corp Thiokol Corp Firstar Corp Thomas Inds Inc Gillette Co Trinova Corp GTE Corp Weyerhaeuser Co Health Care Ppty Invs Inc FRIDAY Borden Inc Du Pont Co. Central La Elec Inc Nat Med Enterprises Inc Comm Satellite Corp Twin Disc Inc Dominion Res Inc Va Unum Corp

title: Agency Uses Brain Power To Lure Prospective Clients
description: THE Deutsch advertising agency has taken on the toughest client it has ever had - itself.

title: 'Twin Peaks' May Provide A Ratings Edge for ABC
description: ABC, which already broadcasts the hottest new television show, ''America's Funniest Home Videos,'' has made a serious move toward taking over prime-time leadership next fall based on the unexpected success of ''Twin Peaks.''

title: Kidney Peril Found in the Pain Reliever Ibuprofen
description: The popular pain reliever ibuprofen can cause kidney failure in people with mild kidney disease, according to a new study.

title: Tides of Change Lap at Soviet Sports
description: Amid the economic crisis and political reforms in the Soviet Union, sports authorities are straining to preserve a costly system that has made the Soviet Union the leading country in the Olympics for almost 20 years.

title: Review/Pop;   The Spirit of Jane Siberry
description: In ''Bound by the Beauty,'' the title song of Jane Siberry's fifth album, the Canadian singer and songwriter imagines returning to life 500 years from now and plunging ecstatically into nature. The first thing she is going to do, she vows, is to find a forest, lie down in the leaves and listen to the birds sing.

title: N.F.L. Free Agency: How Free Is Free?
description: DON MATTINGLY of the Yankees, instead of waiting a year to become a free agent - but using the leverage of free agency -signs a five-year contract for more than $19 million. At the same time, 274 restricted free agents in the National Football League are eligible to sign with other teams, but not one receives an offer.

title: Runner's Shortest Path: Straight Line
description: POOR Pat Petersen. In the 1987 New York City Marathon he ran 26.2 miles in under two hours, yet lost to the winner, Ibrahim Hussein, by 60.02 seconds.

title: Evolution in Europe;   SOVIETS REBUFFED BY CHENEY ON PLAN CURBING SEA ARMS
description: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has rebuffed a Soviet suggestion that the Bush Administration's new strategic arms proposal be broadened to include constraints on sea-based missiles.

title: Antitrust Extension Is Weighed
description: The Administration is considering a significant extension of antitrust laws to strike at American subsidiaries of foreign companies that are found to engage in price-fixing, the carving up of markets and other anti-competitive practices in their home markets.

title: Row, Row, Row Your Bike
description: An inventor in Miami has devised a new attachment for bicycles that allows you to work your upper body as well as your legs.

title: The Economics of Popular Discontent
description: There is a subtle, subversive political force at work in China - economic discontent.

title: State Street Boston reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bensonhurst: A Weakened Murder Case Opens Today
description: In a blue flash from a .32-caliber pistol, Yusuf K. Hawkins was shot to death nearly eight months ago in predominantly white Bensonhurst. There are some who say that the shooting of the 16-year-old black youth made the Brooklyn neighborhood - like Selma, Ala., and Howard Beach, Queens, in their times - a national symbol of racism.

title: Exhibition on Titanic At South St. Seaport
description: On April 15, 1912, the Titanic sank on its maiden voyage from Southampton, England, to New York. Items retrieved from the ship and other memorabilia relating to the voyage will be on view beginning on Wednesday at the South Street Seaport Museum, 207 Front Street.

title: Town Gets Clean Water As Paper Gets a Pulitzer
description: William Coughlin, the editor of a tiny 81-year-old newspaper in North Carolina called The Washington Daily News, is known around town as a man who likes to read the fine print.

title: Cup Crews Courting Women
description: Female sailors are being recruited for key positions in America's Cup campaigns, opening up the possibility for the first time in yachting history that a woman could sail as skipper of a cup contender.

title: Outdoors: Wild Turkeys Test Patience and Senses
description: IF your hearing is excellent, your eyes sharp and you can sit motionless for hours at a time, you might be able to become a successful hunter of wild turkeys.

title: Dinkins Administration Bargains in Good Faith With City Unions
description: To the Editor:

title: Rifts Imperil Europe's No-Border Plan
description: The European Community's plan to remove all internal borders after 1992, long viewed as the most important symbol of new European unity, is being threatened by disagreements over how to deal with migration, asylum, drugs and terrorism.

title: Health Insurers Increase Rates For the Elderly
description: The cost of private health insurance for the elderly is rising sharply, straining the budgets of millions of people who live on Social Security checks and fueling demands in Congress and the states for tighter regulation of this insurance.

title: Critic's Notebook;   Professional Judgment vs. Visual Imperatives in TV News
description: Anyone who judges the newsworthiness of events by the pictures on the nightly news is likely to come away with a dim comprehension of recent goings-on in places like Lithuania, Nepal, the Natal province of South Africa, the Arab villages of the West Bank and other hot spots. It is a constant challenge to television journalists.

title: Question Box
description: Rangers and Circus

title: First Commerce Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bowing to Protests, King Dissolves Nepal Assembly
description: King Birendra dissolved Nepal's national assembly today and accepted the resignation of his Prime Minister after a weekend of increasingly angry protests here over the pace of democratic change.

title: A Humdrum Style Gives Nunn No. 35
description: Michael Nunn may have won again, but he continues to give action a bad name.

title: Market Place;   UAL Stock's Unhappy Past
description: WHY is the stock of the UAL Corporation trading around $160 a share, when both the company and its unions value it at $201 a share in their latest buyout agreement? The memory of last October may have much to do with it.

title: Earth Day's 'Planetism'
description: In celebration of the 20th recycling of Earth Day, the folk musician Glen McClure will perform a concert in Rochester on an instrument made entirely of garbage.

title: Cove Hoover, 67, Dies; Newspaper Publisher
description: Cove Hoover, former publisher of newspapers in New York, Illinois and Pennsylvania, died here on Friday at the age of 67. The cause of death was not given.

title: Saatchi Resigns CPC
description: Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising resigned its business with CPC International on Friday. CPC had taken its Skippy peanut butter and Hellmann's and Best Foods mayonnaise accounts from Saatchi in the past 14 months, leaving the agency with only its Mazola corn oil products and its television-buying assignment.

title: The Endowment That Has Stayed Out of Trouble
description: Lynne V. Cheney, who has been unanimously confirmed by the Senate for a second four-year term as chairwoman of the National Endowment for the Humanities, was reflecting not too long ago on the relationship between her agency and the arts endowment.

title: A New Role for the Anti-Apartheid T-Shirt
description: The war against apartheid is proving to be good business for manufacturers of the politically relevant T-shirt.

title: 'Fujimori Phenomenon' in Lima Slum
description: Up a sandy road, five blocks beyond the last street with electricity, behind a shanty's flimsy walls of cardboard and brown paper, Walter Trejo Malqui and two friends sat recently around a wooden table and talked politics.

title: Ryan, Ruth and Mr. Schneider
description: A NOTE was superimposed on the television screen while Nolan Ryan was pitching for the Rangers against the Yankees on Saturday. It said that Ryan, at age 43, is the oldest player in the major leagues, and to emphasize his antiquity, the individual in charge of such items added this fact: Ryan is so old he once faced Eddie Mathews in a major league game (and, it happened, struck him out, in 1966, one of the first of some 5,000 strikeouts over his 24-year major league career).

title: How to End Tax Welfare for the Wealthy;   Return to Old I.R.A.'s
description: To the Editor:

title: Physician From Mexico Arrested In '85 Slaying of U.S. Drug
description: Two news organizations reported today that one of the suspects in the 1985 torture and slaying of a United States undercover drug agent had been captured by bounty hunters in Mexico and turned over to the authorities in this country for a fee.

title: MOST OF SENATORS GO OUT OF STATE FOR CONTRIBUTIONS
description: More than half the senators seeking re-election this year are financing their campaigns largely from outside their home states, in a profound change from the traditional practice of politicians' relying on their constituents for contributions.

title: Marchers in Houston Protest 2 Killings by Police Officers
description: More than 200 people marched through downtown on Saturday to protest the killings of two blacks by Houston police officers.

title: Teaneck's Clergy Struggles to Mend Its Wounded Town
description: Just a few paces from the neat backyard where a black teen-ager was fatally shot last week by a white police officer, the Rev. Robert Merritt struggled today to inspire the unusually quiet congregation of the First Baptist Church of Teaneck.

title: Valley National Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Montreal Reaches Adams Final
description: The Montreal Canadiens, with Russ Courtnall scoring two third-period goals and Claude Lemieux another, beat the Buffalo Sabres by 5-2 tonight to wrap up their National Hockey League playoff series in six games.

title: Reds Crunch Braves for Fifth in a Row
description: Cincinnati won its fifth straight game under its new manager, Lou Piniella, as Eric Davis and Chris Sabo each hit three-run homers today to pace the unbeaten Reds to a 13-6 victory over the Atlanta Braves.

title: Hopefuls Closing In on D-Day
description: The two favorites for the Kentucky Derby are through prepping, but more than a dozen potential challengers will have a final tuneup over the next eight days.

title: Spark M. Matsunaga Dies at 73; Senator Led Fight for Reparations
description: Senator Spark M. Matsunaga of Hawaii, a longtime proponent of peaceful resolution of disputes and Soviet-American cooperation in space exploration, died of cancer early yesterday in Toronto General Hospital. He was 73 years old.

title: Player Holds On To Win by 2 Shots
description: Gary Player figured that holding onto a five-shot lead while being stalked at close range by both Jack Nicklaus and Lee Trevino today in the final round of the PGA Seniors Championship would take all the resources his 54-year-old body could muster.

title: Market Grows Competitive for Polish Papers
description: Naked bulbs illuminate the stretch of yellow rooms - a kindergarten just 16 months ago - that houses the Gazeta Wyborcza, the Solidarity newspaper. Rustic conditions - the photo lab is a converted lavatory and most reporters tap out their articles on manual typewriters - add to the newsroom's excitement.

title: Barnett Banks Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The bank-holding company said the decline in earnings was due to a previously announced strenthening of Barnett's reserve for loan losses, increasing by $66 million during the quarter to $316.6 million.

title: A Life in America for a 64-Year-Old Soviet Comedy
description: Arms outstretched, Bronson Pinchot is walking purposefully across the stage at Circle in the Square to greet an unexpected visitor at his cousin Zoya's apartment in 1920's Moscow. His peach-colored peasant shirt, his black pants and his longish black hair billowing as he walks, the star of the television comedy series ''Perfect Strangers'' looks very Russian as he tries to charm the visitor and smooth a situation that has begun to deteriorate because of his cousin's aloofness.

title: Century Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Pikeville National Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Metro Matters;   Society's Child Falls Victim To Its Frailties
description: Five weeks from today, the State of New York will hand Dwayne Gosso $40 and a bus ticket to nowhere. Wherever he goes, you'll pay.

title: National Penn Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Evolution in Europe;   Ban on Ukraine Church Falls
description: Priests from the Ukrainian Autocephalous Church were allowed to hold Easter services today for the first time since their church was banned by Stalin in 1930, the independent Rukh press service said. An all-night service attended by several thousand people was held in Kiev at Pokrovsky Cathedral, which was temporarily handed back to the church for the occasion.

title: Fraud Charges Rise as Many Aliens Seek to Use '88 Rulings
description: Thousands of aliens who do not have papers to stay in the United States are trying to take advantage of two openings in the legalization program that resulted from Federal court rulings. The issue has led to allegations of fraud and Government foot-dragging.

title: Indiana Journal;   In a Court For Youth, Judgment By Peers
description: As he sat in the jury box pondering the fate of the accused, Jason Woodcock thought about his last visit to Montgomery County Court. He was in the defendant's chair then.

title: Bush and the Blacks
description: Commenting on the strange popularity of President Bush among blacks, Prof. Lawrence Bobo of the University of Wisconsin argued that Mr. Bush ''hasn't done anything seriously damaging of the sort that seemed to happen repeatedly'' under Ronald Reagan.

title: Securities Loss for Japanese
description: The Yamaichi Securities Company, one of Japan's largest brokers, confirmed today that the bankruptcy of a customer in the recent stock market plunge had cost it about $45 million.

title: Lord Bruce-Gardyne, British Monetarist, 60
description: Lord Bruce-Gardyne, a former British Treasury Minister and fierce advocate of monetarism, died on Sunday after a long illness. He was 60 years old.

title: Falling Revenues and Rising Costs Force Counties to Trim More Services
description: Rockland County was surprised to discover recently that it was the only jurisdiction in the lower Hudson River Valley still operating patrol boats, at an annual cost of $300,000. Now the service is being ended, County Executive John Grant said, ''because we're looking everywhere to save money.''

title: In a Savings Move, the Army Is Proposing Increased Cuts in Troops
description: Responding to increased pressure to reduce the Pentagon budget, the Army has proposed cutting its active forces more than it had announced it would.

title: Yanks' Bullpen Does It All
description: The Yankees beat the Texas Rangers, 3-1, yesterday on a day that would have been the 27th day of spring training had baseball proceeded to have a normal-length spring training after the club owners' lockout ended.

title: U.S. to Study Ways To Combat Frailty Among the Elderly
description: The Government will sponsor a three-year, $2.9 million research project intended to reduce or prevent frailty in the elderly, two Federal agencies announced today.

title: Greta Garbo, 84, Screen Icon Who Fled Her Stardom, Dies
description: Greta Garbo, the enigmatic and elusive star of some of Hollywood's most memorable romantic movies of the 1930's and a 50-year focus of curiosity and myth, died yesterday at New York Hospital in Manhattan. She was 84 years old.

title: Team of Scientists Sees Substantial Warming of Earth
description: Assembled by the United Nations in an attempt to arrive at an international consensus on global warming, a team of scientists says it is a ''virtual certainty'' that the temperature of the earth's surface will rise substantially in the next century.

title: Progress Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Chronicle
description: SID CAESAR and IMOGENE COCA will be welcomed with a fan letter from Mayor DAVID N. DINKINS when they open their show tomorrow night at Michael's Pub in New York. In the show, they will recreate some of the pieces they made famous on ''Your Show of Shows,'' a comedy-variety program that was broadcast from 1950 to 1954. And they will improvise, as usual.

title: Bond Market Ignores Fall In Oil Prices
description: The bond market, usually sensitive to swings in commodity prices, has cast a blind eye to the recent decline in oil prices.

title: Smith Cools Mets As Expos Win, 3-1
description: The Mets continued to wander through the first week of the season without their bats, and tonight, they were tamed by Zane Smith, a pitcher who had lost 10 games in a row since his last victory last May 6.

title: Olympic Champion Taking On Boston
description: Gelindo Bordin is not your ordinary marathon runner.

title: Accounts
description: * Thomas J. Lipton Inc., to Ogilvy & Mather, for an undisclosed new food product.

title: Limited and May Promote Officers
description: The Limited Inc., the chain of specialty apparel stores, has named Thomas G. Hopkins vice chairman.

title: Mannes Concert Series
description: A three-concert festival of contemporary music will begin next Monday at the Mannes College of Music, 150 West 85th Street, at 8 P.M. The Mannes Contemporary Ensemble (Madeleine Shapiro, director) and the Mannes Percussion Ensemble (Howard Van Hyning, director) will be joined by the composers John Bergamo, John Cage, Tan Dun, Lukas Foss and Otto Luening. The opening concert will include works by Mr. Bergamo, Mr. Foss, Mr. Cage, Edgard Varese and Kazuo Fukushima. The series will continue on April 25 at 8 P.M. at the college, and April 26 at 6 P.M. at the New School for Social Research, 66 West 12th Street. Admission is free.

title: When Looking for Sin, Cincinnati Looks South
description: This small town across the Ohio River from Cincinnati is hardly as seamy as Times Square, but it is the closest thing to it in an area that has nearly gone into convulsions over a photography exhibition that shows images of homosexual acts and nude children.

title: Housing the Poor - Without Subsidies
description: While social, political and judicial pressures to construct new low-income housing are growing, there is no obvious way to do so. Tight budgets at all levels of government have made the return of large-scale subsidized housing construction, whatever its merits, extremely unlikely.

title: China Cuts Deposit Rates
description: Interest rates on bank deposits here have been reduced by 1.26 percentage points in a move intended to stimulate China's sluggish economy.

title: Wells, Rich, Greene Deal Shows Strength of French
description: The effort by French advertising companies to establish themselves as international marketers took a striking turn on Friday when Wells, Rich, Greene announced that it had sold a large minority interest to a French advertising conglomerate.

title: Trustmark Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Publicity Is Enriching Mapplethorpe Estate
description: Attacks by Senator Jesse Helms and, more recently, Cincinnati police officials on the touring show of photographs by Robert Mapplethorpe are making money for the artist's estate, the executor, Michael Ward Stout, said last week. The political pressure has given a strong lift to prices for the photographer's work.

title: Treasury to Auction Only Bills This Week
description: Treasury financings this week are confined to today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills.

title: Review/Theater;   Bearing the Tragedies of Old Age
description: Jo Carson's ''Day Trips'' is personal rather than issue oriented, but it raises troubling questions about family responsibility and about the prolongation of life by artificial means. Ms. Carson, a Texan storyteller and author, approaches her sensitive subject without sentimentality or its opposite, cynicism.

title: People's Savings Fincl reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Pennview Savings reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Pitching and Power Win Again for A's
description: Bob Welch allowed only one hit through the first six innings and Mark McGwire hit a two-run homer today as the Oakland Athletics beat the Seattle Mariners, 3-0, to extend the longest losing streak in the major leagues this season to five games.

title: Rain Alone Won't Ease Latest Drought in West
description: The plentiful and cheap water that made much of the West rich, powerful and populous has now turned scarce and ever more costly to find.

title: Graf Adds a Title, Trouncing Sanchez
description: Today Steffi Graf reminded herself and her challenger, Arantxa Sanchez Vicario, of the way a champion behaves upon reaching a final: like a demolitions expert.

title: First Illinois Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Life and Death in the Three-Four Precinct
description: Detective Sgt. Andrew Eanniello had spent the afternoon cruising the double-parked streets of Washington Heights, looking for a man and a woman suspected of robbing and killing two drug sellers.

title: Foreign Policy By Referendum
description: LEAD: Military cuts need not be the only peace dividend produced by the passing of the cold war.

title: Dr. Harold Fuerst, 80, Ex-Head Of Preventable Diseases Bureau
description: Dr. Harold T. Fuerst, who retired in 1967 as Assistant Commissioner for Preventable and Chronic Diseases after 27 years in the New York City Health Department, died on Friday at New York Hospital after a brief illness. He was 80 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Review/Opera;   The Pagan's Progress in 'Siegfried'
description: There was little acknowledgement of Good Friday at the Metropolitan Opera. Continuing this spring's re-enactment of last season's new ''Ring'' productions, the Met played the third of Wagner's four operas in the cycle, ''Siegfried.''

title: Livery Cars Are Like Taxis Where Few Taxis Are Found
description: Livery car companies, now apparently the targets of a killer or killers, grew out of the huge demand for car service across New York City.

title: First Executive In Bond Swap
description: The First Executive Corporation said Friday that it had sold a small portion of its faltering ''junk bond'' portfolio, agreeing to swap bonds with a face value of $40 million for several large Florida real estate projects owned by the FPA Corporation, a Pennsylvania real estate developer.

title: Study Finds Bias in Way Women Are Evaluated for Heart Bypasses
description: Women who have bypass surgery for heart disease are much sicker and slightly older than men who have the surgery, researchers said yesterday, adding that the finding could explain why those women were more likely to die as a result.

title: Kobe Journal;   How Much Golf Is Too Much at Clubhouse Japan?
description: More than the love of expensive German cars or baseball, the almost fanatical passion in Japan for golf, with its sense of open spaces and luxury, offers insight into the way wealth and the discovery of leisure are influencing this country.

title: Bridge
description: The player who can bring home a difficult slam will always be a popular partner and teammate. To find out whether you are entitled to plaudits, plan the play in six spades on the diagramed deal with the East-West cards concealed.

title: Talks on Manchester Prison Siege Break Off
description: Talks between inmates and officers have broken down in Britain's longest prison siege, which entered its third week today.

title: 'Epic Debate' Led to Heinz Tuna Plan
description: Until last week, it was easy to describe relations between the H. J. Heinz Company, the world's largest tuna canner, and environmental groups trying to save dolphins tangled in tuna nets. ''We were the bitterest of enemies,'' one defender of the dolphins said.

title: Soviet Anti-Semitism Survey Shows Bias
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: Head of Sara Lee Division Joining Maker of Pet Food
description: Thomas D. MacLeod Jr., president and chief executive of the bakery division of the Sara Lee Corporation, has resigned to join the Iams Company, a privately held maker of premium pet foods, as president and chief operating officer. Mr. MacLeod, 42, will report to Clay Mathile, chairman and chief executive.

title: Killed Book Is Haunting Time Warner
description: An abrupt decision by the publisher Little, Brown & Company, a subsidiary of Time Warner Inc., to cancel the publication of a book that addresses subjects of acute sensitivity to Time has set off a bitter dispute about who killed the book and why.

title: How to End Tax Welfare for the Wealthy;   Social Security Juggling
description: To the Editor:

title: Evergreen Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
First of America Bank Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results have been restated to reflect the Nov. 1, 1989 acquisition of Midwest Financial Group Inc.

title: Foreman Fights Jameson
description: George Foreman, the former heavyweight champion, returns to action Tuesday night in a 10-round bout against Mike Jameson at Caesars Tahoe.

title: Heritage Financial Services reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Citizens Banking reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Fifth Cabdriver Is Shot to Death in the Bronx
description: A livery-cab driver was shot and killed late Saturday night on a deserted street in the Fordham section of the Bronx, the police said.

title: Capitals Eliminate Devils, 3-2
description: The Devils were eliminated from the playoffs tonight as the Washington Capitals won, 3-2, to take their Patrick Division semifinal series by four games to two.

title: Killing the Messenger
description: Fifty-three journalists were killed worldwide in 1989, twice the previous year's toll. This grim news is contained in a survey prepared by the Committee to Protect Journalists, a monitoring group. It suggests that Iraq's recent execution of Farzad Bazoft, a British-based journalist, as an alleged spy, is only a dramatic instance of a disturbing trend.

title: How to End Tax Welfare for the Wealthy
description: To the Editor:

title: Patrick Is Filling Leetch's Skates
description: James Patrick can't remember if the dream happened when he was lost in sleep one night or lost in thought one day, but he can otherwise recall its details perfectly.

title: Sabicas, 78, Gypsy Solo Guitarist Who Began Performing as a Boy
description: Sabicas, the Spanish gypsy who took the guitar out of the flamenco troupe and established himself as one of the finest solo guitarists of his time, died early Saturday at St. Clare's Hospital in Manhattan after suffering multiple strokes and pneumonia. He was 78 years old and had lived in Manhattan for more than 30 years.

title: Surely, Webern Is Something to Sneeze At;   Misery Loves Company
description: To the Editor:

title: Special Schools Proposed Where Teachers Could Learn by Teaching
description: Administrators of America's leading education schools are proposing a radical redesign of teacher education, in which universities and public schools would join forces to train teachers the way medical schools use hospitals to train doctors.

title: First Peoples Financial Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $913,000, or 30 cents a share.

title: Pepsico's Spending Plan
description: Pepsico Inc., the giant food and beverage conglomerate, plans to spend $1.1 billion this year to expand its worldwide operations.

title: First Commercial Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Separatists Seized in Kashmir
description: Indian security forces clashed repeatedly with Muslim militants today in the capital of the northern state of Jammu and Kashmir, making dozens of arrests.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Passover, alternate-side parking rules will be suspended in New York City today and tomorrow. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Pirates Shine In Crystal Ball
description: THE Pittsburgh Pirates are hardly shoo-ins to win the National League pennant, but don't rule them out. By one persuasive pair of leading indicators, the best bet in baseball is that the Pirates will do better this year than their 74-88 record last season.

title: Evolution in Europe;   John Paul Says a Prayer For Lithuania's Success
description: Celebrating the revival of democracy across the globe, Pope John Paul II offered an Easter prayer today that Lithuanian hopes for independence would be realized through discussions with Moscow.

title: Comments by Pathe Chief
description: An attempt by the Pathe Communications Corporation to acquire MGM/ UA Communications has run into new and unfavorable publicity.

title: U.S. Bars Chinese Role At Talks on Air Pollution
description: To avoid violating sanctions imposed on China last year because of its crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators, the Administration has excluded Beijing from an international conference on air pollution and climatic change, even though the Chinese burn more industrial coal than any other country, officials said today.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Baroid Corp., Houston, a supplier of titanium and petroleum services and equipment, appointed Joseph S. Compofelice chief financial officer. He will remain president of Baroid's two oilfield equipment operations, Shaffer Inc. and Atlas Bradford.

title: Dianne Wallace Becomes a Bride
description: Dianne Wallace and Lowell M. Schulman were married yesterday at the Carlyle in New York by Justice Samuel G. Fredman of State Supreme Court in White Plains. The bride is a daughter of Stella Paul of Boca Raton, Fla., and the late Jacob Zwillich of New York. Her husband is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Louis Schulman of White Plains.

title: Review/Pop Salsa, Cumbia and Real Conviction
description: Joe Arroyo's packed show at the Palladium on Thursday night brought out the Colombian community to cheer on its home-grown star. Mr. Arroyo is becoming an increasingly important presence on both the salsa scene - traditionally dominated by New York and Puerto Rican bands -and in the Caribbean and world music markets as well.

title: Long Road Trip
description: TWO years ago, Dan Gallagher built new dugouts for Coffey Field and coached his Fordham baseball team to its second consecutive National Collegiate Athletic Association Regional appearance. Losses in the Regional to Clemson and the eventual national champion, Stanford, are just memories now. So are the dugouts.

title: A Champion-Turned-Critic
description: The signposts of his life were strewn all about in the old flat he and his wife moved into just days before. Along one wall were scores of unopened cartons, filled with books and papers, the necessities of almost two decades of writing. In a far corner sat a gleaming barbell, the kind he lifted to win an Olympic gold medal in 1960 and set four world records during an eight-year period in which he was known as ''the world's strongest man.''

title: Veteran of Earth Day 1970 Looks to a New World
description: Twenty years ago Denis Hayes wanted to change the nation. Now, dissatisfied with progress over the decades, he is trying to change the world.

title:
ON YOUR OWN;

The 'Dinker' Wields Some Fearsome Lobs
description: LEAD: BILL GREENSPAN, the New England Lawn Tennis Association's fourth-ranked player in the age-45-and-up bracket of men's singles, is the kind of opponent everyone hates to play. He is a moving backboard, the quintessential court character that the teaching pro Vic Braden affectionately calls ''the dinker,'' also known as ''the pusher'' or ''the lobber.

title: Metropolitan Federal reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The company attributed the loss to a $30 million addition to reserves for possible loan losses and for the writedown on real estate owned by the association.

title: In Old Jerusalem, Christians and Muslims Protest Settlement
description: Thousands of Christians celebrated Easter today at the Church of the Holy Sepulcher, while around the corner, protesters paraded outside the four buildings that 150 Jewish settlers occupied last week.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY

title: Amsouth Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
L.I. Opposition Blocking Weather Radar Station
description: Opposition from residents of Sayville, L.I., to a proposed weather radar station there has forced the National Weather Service to look elsewhere in Suffolk County for a site for its forecast office, now in Rockefeller Center.

title: New York's Debt, Unrolled
description: A wondrous idea has just burst from the financial swamp in Albany. It could, in a stroke, eliminate most of New York's huge accumulated deficit. It could reduce reliance on ever more fiscal gimmicks. It could impose future fiscal discipline. But hold the applause.

title: Southern National Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
INSIDE
description: Soviet Sports Officials Struggle to Save System

title: Shelton Bancorp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''Before on Easter, it was difficult. Many of my friends were in prison. Now it is not a time to be sad. Even though there is an economic crisis, things are not so bad. We finally have our own Government.''

title: U.S.-Canada Trade Border Blurs
description: The 16-month-old free-trade agreement between Canada and the United States, intended to eliminate virtually all tariffs and duties in that enormous trading relationship by 1999, is already having some unexpected grass-roots side effects, promoting a wide array of bilateral business and civic partnerships.

title: Chronicle
description: RICHARD DE GENNARO, director of the New York Public Library, returns to Harvard University as the Roy E. Larsen Librarian of Harvard College. On June 1, Mr. De Gennaro will succeed YEN-TSAI FENG, who is retiring after 10 years.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Citicorp Credit Card Trust 1990-4, a unit of Citicorp, has filed for a $250 million issue of credit card-backed securities through Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.

title: Evolution in Europe;   A Mood of Rejoicing Takes Over Warsaw At a Time of Rebirth
description: At the Church of the Carmelite Fathers the tableau depicting the tomb of Jesus is dominated by an Easter-egg-shaped globe suspended from the ceiling. Painted over the continent of Europe are two giant red chains, links burst apart, which are sinking into the oceans.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-9

title: Reebok Selects Hill, Holliday
description: Reebok International has selected Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos as its new domestic advertising agency, executives at agencies in the review said Friday. Reebok's former agency, Chiat/ Day/Mojo, initially resigned the $40 million account after it was placed in review in January, but then accepted an invitation to join the competition in March. Chiat's advertising for Reebok included a recent commercial that depicted people ''bungee jumping,'' or leaping off a bridge with elastic cords tied to their sneakers.

title: Eldorado Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Per share figures are adjusted for a 10 percent stock dividend paid in February.

title: Home Financial Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Mid-America Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Poverty Rate Is Up for the Very Young
description: At a time when poverty is on the decline among all other age groups in the United States, the poverty rate for children under 6 years of age is rising, an analysis of Federal population figures shows.

title: Faulty Power Unit Replaced In Space Shuttle Discovery
description: The space agency installed a new power unit in the shuttle Discovery today and began recharging the batteries of the Hubble Space Telescope.

title: Y.& R. Reorganizes
description: Young & Rubicam said Friday that it was reorganizing its New York office into a single, unified agency, dismantling the tripartite structure it adopted in 1987. John Glorieux and K. Jane Brite, each of whom was a group general manager, were named New York general manager and associate general manager, respectively. George Guimares, the third group general manager, will be taking a new position with Y.& R. outside of New York.

title: Bomb Near Hindu Temple Kills 5 in Northern India
description: A bomb hidden in a tractor exploded outside a Hindu temple in the Punjab town of Ludhiana today, killing 5 people and wounding 25 who were watching a popular television program at a nearby shop, the police in the northern area of India reported. The officers said militant Sikh separatists were responsible.

title: Chronicle
description: CHARLES DYSON has been appointed chairman of the trustees of the Ballet Theater Foundation, which runs the American Ballet Theater. Mr. Dyson succeeds MELVILLE STRAUS, who has been chairman since 1983. Mr. Dyson, 80, is the former chairman of Dyson-Kissner-Moran Corporation, a private investment company. He has served on the board of the ballet foundation since 1981.

title: Burlington Buyback
description: Burlington Resources Inc.'s directors authorized the repurchase of up to 10 million shares of the company's common stock on the open market. The company has bought about nine million shares at an average price of $41.67 a share under a 10-million-share repurchase program authorized in 1988. The company has about 146.3 million shares outstanding.

title: N.C. State Turns To Healing Process
description: LEAD: THE dogwoods are blossoming, yet spring has not brought the accustomed sense of renewal to the campus of North Carolina State University.

title: A New Era?
description: THE quarterfinal showing of Arthur Carrington 3d, a 16-year-old tennis player from Boston, in last week's Easter Bowl junior championships in Miami provided more evidence that young black players are making enormous strides in a sport that has long been dominated by white players.

title: Review/Television;   Starting Over in 'Shannon's Deal'
description: Meet Jack Shannon. In the Reagan 80's, he had what was supposed to be all - a beautiful wife and daughter, upscale perks and a powerhouse job as a lawyer representing corporations. Then Jack began to fall from grace. His addiction to poker put him heavily into debt with assorted mobsters. His wife left him. And he lost his job at the establishment firm of Coleman & Weiss. Now he can be found putting the pieces back together in ''Shannon's Deal,'' the new John Sayles series running Mondays at 10 on NBC. For the 1930's, Dashiell Hammett created Sam Spade, the private eye. With Jack. the Philadelphia lawyer, Mr. Sayles, the film maker and writer (''Matewan,'' ''Eight Men Out''), gets a crystal-clear bead on the 1990's.

title: Europe's New Home, Next to the Old
description: How can a soon-to-be-united Germany fit in a no-longer-divided Europe? Two sensible themes emerge from discussions by European and American leaders. title: Talking Business; with Krief of Bernard Krief Associates;   Consultant's Bid For Saatchi Unit
description: For more than a year, Bernard Krief, a French management consultant, has been trying to buy the Hay Group, Saatchi & Saatchi's consulting arm. The path has not been smooth. First Saatchi said Hay was not for sale; then it said the group was worth triple the $100 million to $200 million Mr. Krief was offering; then Mr. Krief refused to sign a confidentiality letter that Saatchi wanted before it would show him its books. Now several Hay managers are trying to buy Hay for about $90 million. Still, Mr. Krief, whose 150-person Bernard Krief Associates is a fraction the size of Hay, which has a staff of more than 2,000, is persevering.

Laying Down the Law For Business Letters
description: PROGRAMS that check a piece of writing against a standard are fairly common and frequently useful. The trouble is, their standard is not necessarily your standard. If you like long sentences, and the program hates them, or if you feel that the passive voice can be effective, and the program doesn't, it will pester you. Corporate Voice is different. You set the standard. It works this way: Say you are in charge of a department or company where a number of people turn out business letters or reports. You gather what you consider well-written examples and feed them into the program. From then on, the program compares each new document with the standard set by the ones you like and gives it a score. If the score is around 90 percent, the two are close enough in style, assuring a consistent companywide tone of voice. If the score is much lower, the writer can edit the document and try again.

title: Review/Music;   Little Outbursts by the Big Trombone

Joseph Alessi was the New York Philharmonic's soloist in Paul Creston's Fantasy for Trombone and Orchestra at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday evening. Ava Ordman played the Donald Erb Concerto with the American Symphony at Carnegie Hall on Sunday afternoon.

Tokyo, Where Fashion Is an Art
description: Japanese culture puts great emphasis on esthetics, from the famously precise gardens and parks to the artfully presented food - even to the hurly-burly of Tokyo traffic in downtown Tokyo, where, miraculously, none of the cars ever have a dent. In this milieu, it is no surprise that there is a nine-month wait on orders for Grace Kelly bags, the classic Hermes design, or that fashion has an honored place.

title: Review/Music;   2 Nights, 2 Ensembles And Much Mozart
description: Trevor Pinnock's 53-player Classical Band and Frederick Renz's 22-player Grande Bande, two New York-based period-instrument ensembles, had a face-off of sorts over the weekend, when they offered their final concerts of the season.

description: Producers of wool and mohair will receive about $100 million in Government subsidies because 1989 market prices fell below the Federal support level, the Agriculture Department has reported. The payments, which are to begin immediately, will be split equally between wool and mohair producers.

description: The Ford Motor Company said its 1990 profits could be substantially reduced because of Brazil's economic problems, which have forced the big auto maker to shut down its Autolatina operations serving Brazil and Argentina. Ford made the statement in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing.

title: Nintendo Files Copyright Suits

Nintendo, a subsidiary of the Nintendo Company of Japan, with 85 percent of the home video-game market in the United States, said it had filed four copyright infringement lawsuits in the United States and Canada against retailers and distributors who it says have been selling counterfeit cartridges.

description: Robert Morton Werner, a television producer and the head of programming at NBC from 1962 to 1972, died of kidney failure on Saturday at Kula Hospital on Maui, Hawaii, after a long illness. He was 73 years old and lived in Pukalani, on Maui.

He loudly denies that he's the dethroned heavyweight champion's manager. But the more Don King talks, the more he sounds like Tyson's manager. Which according to boxing law, he's not supposed to be while he's a promoter.

title: Brazil Inflation Drive
description: The president of Brazil's central bank said Friday that administering the first few weeks of the Government's anti-inflation plan had been ''infernal.'' The new Government of President Fernando Collor de Mello introduced a sweeping economic program on March 16 to arrest inflation. Mr. Collor froze most money in bank accounts for the next 18 months. The central bank president, Ibrahim Eris, told the newspaper O Estado de Sao Paulo: ''Administering what we did in these 20 days was infernal. We all worked 18 hours a day and were still criticized because the rhythm of implementing was not fast enough.''

P. Singh's Government to stem resurgent tides of secessionism in not one but two strategic border states, Punjab as well as Jammu and Kashmir.

description: The Chicago Blackhawks turned a negative into a positive, then turned the Minnesota North Stars into playoff spectators.

description: Weak demand for paper products coupled with higher prices for logs and wood chips sent the Boise Cascade Corporation's first-quarter net income plunging by 57 percent, the company said today.

title: Anger Lingers at Slain Youth's Funeral
description: Phillip C. Pannell, the black teen-ager fatally shot by a white policeman in Teaneck last Tuesday, was buried today after a funeral service marked by muted anger amid themes of reconciliation and reform.

title: Lusaka Journal;   All About What's Going On in Zambia, Slyly Told
description: For more than two decades, Kapelwa Musonda has been charming, amusing and occasionally provoking Zambians about the absurdities and frustrations of surviving amid the beleaguered economy and party politics of their African nation.

title: Southwest Media Sale
description: The American Express Publishing Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Southwest Media Corporation, the publisher of D Magazine. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed.

title: Veto of Abortion Rights Bill Is Upheld in New Hampshire
description: The New Hampshire House failed today to override Gov. Judd Gregg's veto of an abortion rights bill that the Governor said would have given this state the nations' most liberal abortion law.

description: Queens Farmers' Market

ALLIES STILL LAG ON ARMS, U.S. SAYS
description: The United States, which spent a larger share of its national income for the military budget in 1988 than virtually all its NATO allies and Japan together, criticized its friends today for not doing enough to close the military spending gap in recent years.

title: Lessons
description: Plenty of public school systems have recently begun delegating financial and educational decisions to principals and teachers. Now the Dade County school system has extended this notion of site-based management to its logical conclusion: Let them design and run their own schools.

title: Howard S. Tierney Jr., A Former Executive, 71
description: Howard Sherwood Tierney Jr., a retired Manhattan business executive, died of liver cancer on Monday at his home in Hobe Sound, Fla. He was 71 years old.

description: The year-ago per share earnings not available as the company converted to stock company in December 1989.
