Star Chefs Find Themselves On the Outside Looking In
description: BY the early 1980's, as restaurant mania began to build, chefs became celebrities. And like star baseball players, if a kitchen home-run king left one restaurant team, there was always a more lucrative contract waiting.

title: International Multifoods Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included a $3.7 million gain from sale of Canada specialty meats, $1.1 million loss from Canada reorganization costs and $4.7 million loss on grain subsidy claims. c-Included a $2.7 million gain from sale of U.S. flour milling, $1.8 million gain from sale of franchising rights in Pacific rim and $300,000 exchange gain on investments. d-Included $7.2 million gain from sale of U.S. flour milling, $1.8 million gain from sale of franchising rights in Pacific rim, $2.4 million gain on grain subsidy claims and $4.1 million exchange gains on investments. Year-ago periods' results were reclassified.

title: Rich Japanese Beef Barred From U.S.
description: AMERICANS will have to wait to sample $100 Kobe steaks, which come from hand-massaged, soybean-fed, beer-quenched cattle raised in Japan. The United States Department of Agriculture has rejected a New York restaurant's request to import Kobe beef, saying that Japanese slaughterhouses fail to meet the Government's standards.

title: Orient-Express Hotels reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and included an extraordinary credit of $1,189,000, or 12 cents a share. Results for 1988 included a pretax gain of $29,208,000 on the sale of assets and a $5,000,000 special provision relating to the writedown of real estate and other assets.

title: How Cincinnati Sees the Arts And Art Figures See the City
description: At the very center of downtown Cincinnati is a 109-year-old fountain, an ornate mid-Victorian fantasy that graces the area appropriately named Fountain Square. When it was restored in 1971, a bronze plaque was put next to it, Joseph Marioni, a painter who was born and brought up in Cincinnati, said the other day. ''It told the name of the fountain, who it was dedicated to, who paid for the fountain, who paid for the restoration, who did the restoration,'' he said. ''Only one thing was missing - the name of the artist.''

title: Review/Theater;   The Pursuits of Poets, Literary and Otherwise
description: One shudders at the thought that the future of American letters might in any way be influenced by the band of would-be poets that gathers at the writers' workshop that is the setting for ''Related Retreats,'' a new play by Eduardo Machado at the Theater for the New City.

title: Ad Council Award
description: The Advertising Council has chosen Richard L. Gelb, chairman and chief executive of Bristol-Myers Squibb, as the recipient of the council's 37th annual public service award. Mr. Gelb will receive his award at the council's annual dinner on Nov. 14 in New York.

title: American Electric Power reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Coca-Cola Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: In the latest first quarter, the completion of the sale of Coca-Cola Enterprises' food-service vending operations in Memphis, Tenn., resulted in a gain of $3.7 million, before taxes, equaled to 1 cent a share. In the first quarter of 1989, the company recorded a gain of $11 million, before tax, equaled to 4 cents a share, related to the sale of its Canadian bottling operations. Other deductions in the latest first quarter totaled about $3.6 million. In the year-ago quarter, Coca-Cola Enterprises recorded other income of about $6.2 million, including a gain of $2.6 million related to the repurchase of certain outstanding debt and a benefit of $4.4 million resulting from favorable resolution of certain liabilities established for previous acquisitions.

title: Baruch Chief Acknowledges Problem With Reaccreditation
description: The president of Bernard M. Baruch College has acknowledged that the school's reaccreditation had been deferred last month because of concerns over the low retention rate of minority students and the lack of minority representation on the faculty.

title: Springs Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
For Insider, Fine and 4-Month Term
description: Closing one of the most difficult criminal cases the Government has brought in its pursuit of corruption on Wall Street, a Federal judge in Manhattan yesterday sentenced a former stock speculator to four months in prison and fined him $1 million for a single incident of insider trading.

title: Warner Joins Walt Disney In Banning Ads at Its Films
description: Warner Brothers has followed the lead of the Walt Disney Company in banning commercials from movie screens where its pictures are shown.

title: Benjamin Adler, 86, An Early Advocate Of UHF Television
description: Benjamin Adler, an electronic engineer and inventor best known for his early work in ultrahigh-frequency television, died of pneumonia Monday at his home in Larchmont, N.Y. He was 86 years old.

title: Sunrise Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Modest University in Florida Is Blazing a Trail For Blacks to Careers in the World of Business
description: A bespectacled young man, beaming in a double-breasted suit, thrust out his hand at a reception here. ''Matthew Bowman,'' he said. ''I'm a business administration major at FAM U., and I'm from Fayetteville, N.C.'' Without pause, he produced a business card with his school address, his home address and his telephone numbers. ''What brings you here?'' he asked. At the School of Business and Industry at Florida A&M University, Mr. Bowman's attire and his welcoming speech are routine; only the card is optional. These and bigger things -like annual three-month internships at major companies and training in persuasion, adapting to change and jockeying for power - are a part of an unusual approach to teaching business at this predominantly black university, and one that some major American companies say the top business schools would do well to emulate.

title: A Benefit With Dance
description: The Trisha Brown Dance Company is to join Lucinda Childs, Sara Rudner and eight other leading dance and performance artists in a benefit at 8 P.M. on Monday for Movement Research at Ethnic Folk Arts, 179 Varick Street, in lower Manhattan. The event is to be the first in a series of benefits for the organization, which was founded to present and teach dance and performance-art skills. The proceeds from the benefits are to offset a loss of funds from the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs. Tickets are $25. Reservations: 691-5788.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * ANR Freight System Inc., Denver, a subsidiary of the Coastal Corp., Houston, announced the resignation of Joseph F. DeBella, its president. The company named Larry R. Jouett executive vice president and chief operating officer.

title: Nuclear Training Plan Upheld
description: A Federal appeals court ruled today that the Nuclear Regulatory Commission must set up training requirements for workers at nuclear power plants instead of relying on utilties to conform voluntarily with the commission's training guidelines.

title: Fernando Lay, U.N. Official, 51
description: Fernando Lay, First Counselor of the Italian Mission to the United Nations, died Sunday at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx, after a long illness. He was 51 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Bulgaria Party Officials Blamed for Camps
description: Senior Communist Party officials were to blame for the beating deaths and atrocities in at least two labor camps from 1959 to 1962 and should be punished, a Government commission said today.

title: Greece Threatens to Expel Syrian Envoy Over Terrorism
description: Greece's new conservative Government warned a Syrian diplomat today that it would expel him unless he gave a satisfactory explanation for a statement interpreted as supportive of terrorism.

title: Accounts Seized in Inquiry On Colombian Drug Profits
description: The Justice Department announced today that based on a review of bank records seized in Panama after the American invasion, as well as in other foreign countries, it had obtained a court order freezing hundreds of bank accounts in the United States suspected of having been used to hide nearly $400 million in Colombian drug profits.

title: Addenda
description: * Meredith Corp. has agreed to sell MMT Sales Inc. to the unit's management. The unit, which is based in New York, represents 30 television stations to national advertisers.

description: The Cleveland Browns' majority owner and president, Art Modell, underwent successful double bypass coronary surgery yesterday at Cleveland Clinic Hospital. Modell, 64 years old, underwent a quadruple bypass operation in 1983 after a heart attack. (AP)

title: How Youths Rallied To Dolphins' Cause
description: AS many as 10 million dolphins have died in the nets of tuna fishermen in the last 30 years. But it seems that only in the last six months has the magnitude of the slaughter sunk into the national psyche and prompted support for a boycott of tuna. The all-American food, popular in sandwiches and casseroles, was becoming associated with needless killing.

Louis J. Tullio, 73, Mayor of Erie, Pa.; Had a Rare Disease
description: Louis J. Tullio, the six-term Mayor of Erie, died at his home early today from amyloidosis, a rare disease that also took the life of Pittsburgh's Mayor in 1988. Mayor Tullio was 73 years old. Mr. Tullio, a Democrat, was credited with helping to slow Erie's decline as a manufacturing town and preserving it as a port city and commercial center.

description: The nation's industrial production rose by seven-tenths of 1 percent in March, the Federal Reserve reported today, in a second consecutive strong showing that led analysts to suggest that the manufacturing recession may have ended.

CHRONICLE
description: MELBA MOORE went to Washington yesterday seeking wider recognition for a favorite song, ''Lift Every Voice and Sing.'' It was the song's 90th anniversary. WALTER FAUNTROY, the delegate to Congress from the District of Columbia, read the words into the Congressional Record and Miss Moore was honored at a reception where she played her new recording of it, sung with STEVIE WONDER, DIONNE WARWICK and others.

title: Drugs, Torture - And Western Cash
description: LEAD: How can a President who devotes much of his State of the Union Message to the war on drugs close his eyes when U.S. companies prop up the most important drug-linked regime in the world?

title: Warner-Lambert Gains
description: The Warner-Lambert Company said today that its first-quarter earnings rose 19 percent, to $120 million, or $1.79 a share, from $101 million, or $1.49 a share, in the period in 1989. The health-care and consumer products company said sales rose 8 percent, to $1.1 billion, from $1.02 billion in the same period last year. Joseph D. Williams, chairman and chief executive, said all of the company's business segments contributed to first-quarter growth.

title: Unicorp American reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $34,756,000 for the quarter which represented an estimated loss on disposal of discontinued operations; the year included a loss from discontinued operations of $67,347,000 which consisted of income from discontinued operations of $653,000 and an estimated loss on the disposal of real estate of $68 million. c-Included losses from discontinued operations of $7,795,000 and $21,659,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Reynolds Net Declines 38%
description: The Reynolds Metals Company today reported a 38 percent drop in its first-quarter net income, reflecting a steep decline in prices for aluminum ingot and other aluminum products.

title: Deutsche Bank Sets Tie in East
description: Deutsche Bank A.G., West Germany's largest bank, announced today that it had agreed to form a pioneering joint venture in East Germany that would give it control over roughly one-third of the existing banking network in East Germany.

description: Year-ago first quarter included a $77 million gain on the sale of Tokyo real estate and $66 million of Brazilian interest payments that have since been suspended.

title: Fashion Students Win Parsons's Gold Thimbles
description: LAST night at the Parsons School of Design's 24th Fashion Critics Awards show, students showed big jackets, quilted in satin or velvet over miniskirted dresses or thigh-high denim rompers, a beaded dress depicting the Statue of Liberty, as well as a butter-soft goatskin coat whose shiny brass toggles came from the hardware store.

title: Loan Losses Up at Great American
description: The Great American Bank, the nation's seventh-largest savings and loan company, sharply increased its estimate of losses from soured real estate loans and investments today, making it another likely candidate for eventual seizure by Federal regulators.

title: Harvey Named Best In Metropolitan Area
description: Greg (Boo) Harvey, a senior guard, last night became the 16th player from St. John's to win the Haggerty Award as the finest college basketball player in the New York metropolitan area.

title: Strike in Oklahoma Gains Backing
description: The Oklahoma City School Board voted today to use a leftover snow day on Thursday to allow teachers to join a walkout in protest of the Legislature's rejection of a school financing bill that would have included money to raise teachers' salaries.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Amdura Corp., Denver, which is operating under Federal bankruptcy law protection, said it would solicit bids for its main hardware distribution business, thus putting all of its operating businesses up for sale.

description: JEANNE GALWAY flew into the role that her husband was to have played at the Opera Company of Philadelphia when JAMES GALWAY missed his opera debut Monday night because he was in the hospital with an intestinal tract inflammation.

title: Topics of The Times;   Shrinking Secrets
description: The U.S. Government is no slouch at manufacturing secrets. But discovering the exact number of them has been a statistician's nightmare, despite the best efforts of the Information Security Oversight Office, established in 1978 to oversee classified information.

title: 11 Killed in Strife Between Beirut Shiite Factions
description: Widespread clashes broke out between rival Shiite Muslim factions in mainly Muslim West Beirut and its southern suburbs today, and the police said 11 people were killed and 35 wounded.

description: President Bush called today for more research into the scientific and economic ramifications of global warming linked to pollution, but several European officials attending a conference here argued for more concrete and prompt action as well.

title: Scientists See a Link Between Alcoholism And a Specific Gene
description: A gene that puts people at risk of becoming alcoholics has been identified for the first time, scientists report in a study being published today.

description: Year-ago first quarter results included a gain of $8 million, or 16 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. Operating results for the 1989 period have been restated to reflect the formation of the Macmillan-McGraw- Hill joint venture as of July 1, 1989. For that period, revenue and expenses of the McGraw-Hill units contributed to the venture have been eliminated and share of profit of the venture represents the operating profit of those units.

title: F.D.A. CONTRADICTS A REPORT ON MILK
description: Contradicting an earlier news release, the Food and Drug Administration has issued a final report saying that five-sixths of the milk samples it tested were contaminated with a tiny amount of antibiotics.

title: Miami Officer Is Hospitalized In Reported Suicide Attempt
description: A white officer convicted of manslaughter in the deaths of two black men in an incident that touched off rioting last year was hospitalized tonight after what was reported as a suicide attempt, the police said.

title: Westchester to Sue On Rent Allowances
description: The County Executive, Andrew P. O'Rourke, said yesterday that Westchester would sue New York State for ''grossly inadequate'' rent allowances for welfare clients.

title: $263.4 Million Fuel Issue by Louisiana
description: A $263.4 million issue of tax-exempt Louisiana gasoline and tax revenue bonds was tentatively priced yesterday with a maximum yield of about 7.478 percent for a bond maturing in 2004.

title: San Francisco Sees Bonus in Quake If Reviled Freeway Becomes a Victim
description: When the devastating earthquake struck six months ago today, its 15 seconds of destructive power may have inadvertently rectified what many here believe to be one of this city's worst planning mistakes: the Embarcadero Freeway.

title: NBC's 'Hogan Family' Goes to CBS Television
description: CBS announced yesterday that it had purchased the rights to show ''The Hogan Family,'' a family-oriented weekly series that has been shown by NBC since the spring of 1986. The show consistently ranked first in the ratings in its time slot, Mondays at 8:30 to 9 P.M. An established show rarely changes networks.

description: The 1989 partnership income was positively affected by a gain of about $1.5 million, or 6 cents a unit, from the sale of an industrial building located in Orange County, Calif. Share earnings are in units.

title: Spread of AIDS In Rural Areas Testing Georgia
description: Since October, the number of AIDS cases in the area surrounding Macon has tripled to 76, catching health officials by surprise, confronting them with difficult choices on how to provide care and sorely testing community values.

description: The company said the lower earnings in 1990 are primarily due to an $800,000 increase in the allowance for loan losses and $450,000 charged to non-interest expense relating to costs associated with the proposed merger with Eagle Financial Corp., which was terminated by mutual agreement on April 6. These charges were partially offset by a $672,000 gain on sale of securities.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article and a picture caption on Monday about Easter celebrations in Poland referred incorrectly to four place names inscribed on a cross at a Warsaw church. Katyn is the name of the forest in which a mass grave of Polish officers was found; Kozielsk, Ostaszkow and Starobielsk are the Polish names for Soviet camps in which those officers and others were interned just before they disappeared.

description: Four of the nation's 10 largest providers of local telephone service reported modest increases in first-quarter sales and profits yesterday.

description: The Rev. John Atherton Bell, an Episcopal priest and the rector of the Church of the Incarnation in Manhattan for more than 30 years, died on Thursday at Forest Farm Inn, a convalescent center in Middletown, R.I. He was 80 years old and lived in Newport, R.I.

It rules that, to avoid the appearance of conflict, Mayor David Dinkins and City Council President Andrew Stein cannot vote on renewing cable television franchises for Manhattan. The board then said each could delegate someone to act in his place. But that's ducking the hard part.

title: Corrections

That plan is not more restrictive than those offered by Visa and Mastercard. All require that the consumer have a written warranty on a product before they will extend the warranty, and that the warranty be separate from the sales receipt.

description: For now, the Cincinnati Reds have an unbeatable combination: good play and good luck.

title: No Run for the Statehouse

Flynn sent community leaders a letter on Monday saying he would not run for governor and would instead focus on curbing this city's wave of violence, drug dealing and resulting ''despair that affects too many of our citizens.'' The Mayor's decision left four candidates in the Democratic gubernatorial race: John Silber, persident of Boston University; Lieut. Gov. Evelyn F. Murphy; former State Attorney General Francis Bellotti, and State Representative John Flood.

title: Corrections

According to the official Saudi Press Agency, those meeting were the oil ministers of Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates, not the OPEC monitoring committee, which has eight members. Action taken at the meeting is described today on page D13.

Polaroid Net Up 22.8%
description: The Polaroid Corporation said today that its first-quarter profit climbed by 22.8 percent but sales declined slightly in a lackluster business environment. The photography giant reported a net income of $31.8 million, or 43 cents a share, in the three months ended April 1, up from $25.9 million, or 29 cents, in the 1989 quarter. Polaroid said last year's first-quarter earnings were depressed because of expenses for fending off a hostile takeover bid by Shamrock Holdings Inc. Polaroid said sales in the quarter fell to $436 million from $442 million last year.

title: Nathaniel Frison, Chef, 79
description: Nathaniel Frison, head chef at the Old Original Bookbinders restaurant in Philadelphia for four decades and creator of many of its soups, died Friday at the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania. He was 79 years old.

title: Southwestern Bell Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Talk of a Puerto Rico Town: Buried Treasure, No Kidding
description: Most of the millions are still missing, sending F.B.I. agents scrambling for leads from villagers who won't admit to knowing very much about the buried treasure of Vega Baja.

title: SDNB Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
At the Nation's Table
description: THE listing in the 1989 Gault Millau ''Best of New England'' guide was not the first time Pasta Nostra has been called the ''best Italian restaurant in Connecticut,'' and it may not be the last.

title: Smith Corona reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included extraordinary charges of $1,600,000 and $4,600,000, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, which were related to a supplemental performance plan. Results for 1989 and for the 9 months of fiscal 1990 are pro forma, and are adjusted for the Aug. 3, 1989 public offering and a debt financing.

title: A Tyson Sparring Partner Falls in 4 Against Foreman
description: George Foreman, the 42-year-old former heavyweight champion, took another step in his comeback drive to another world title shot when he stopped Mike Jameson of San Jose, Calif., at 2:16 of the fourth round of a scheduled 10-round bout at Caesars Tahoe tonight.

title: Bronx Cabbie Killings: Night Holds New Fears
description: Piloting his battered Oldsmobile through a dark corridor of tenements, Jose Gonzalez clutched the wheel in his left hand, a steak knife in his right.

title: Instead of Special Prosecutor, A Middle Choice in Teaneck
description: In moving the grand-jury investigation into the fatal shooting of Phillip C. Pannell out of Bergen County, state officials chose not to appoint a special prosecutor for the case. Lawyers for both the Pannell family and Gary Spath, the Teaneck police officer who shot the youth, had requested such a prosecutor.

title: Nova Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: The Matinee Bus Crowd: As Broadway-Bound as Ever
description: On a Wednesday morning in Lake Ronkonkoma, L.I., commuters were driving to work, the bagel shop in the Portion Road mall was dispensing bagels, and across the parking lot, 40 or so people were boarding a bus bound for Broadway.

title: Review/Dance;   Exotic Motions With a Jolt of Presence
description: It is a paradox of dance that as performers grow more experienced and gain in dramatic artistry, their physical strength wanes. Much ethnic dancing allows performers to continue their development as performers, as was illustrated by a program of Near Eastern and Spanish dance on Saturday afternoon at the Nikolais-Louis Choreospace. Ibrahim Farrah, the New York teacher of Near Eastern dance, shared the program with Maria Alba, a fiery Spanish dancer and teacher, and Flower Hujer, whose three pieces were essentially exotically flavored modern dance with a strong jolt of her fascinating stage presence.

title: Topics of The Times;   Railroad Bridge
description: Long Island Rail Road commuters have a history of adapting to delays, fare hikes and a monotonous daily trip. Now one group of riders, bridge players, is forced to adapt again. A change in advertising signage requires them to find a new source of card tables.

title: John Henry and Velasquez Voted to Hall
description: John Henry, the ageless gelding who earned more than $6 million, and Jorge Velasquez, a leading New York jockey for more than 20 years, are among four horses and three people whose election to thoroughbred racing's Hall of Fame was announced yesterday.

description: Congenial Spirits

description: Transmitting business messages, leaking important documents and sending love letters across town are not the only uses for facsimile machines. Thanks to the Smith/Greenland advertising agency, they can now be employed for interactive advertising. The agency behind the ''. . . And he drinks Johnnie Walker'' Scotch whisky campaign has developed a novel extension of its billboard ads that featured the telephone numbers of swimsuit-clad young people that, when called, elicited a taped message for the Scotch.

title: Ex-Oklahoma Banker Joins New Jersey Bank
description: Fred M. Moses, a former Oklahoma banker, has been named president and chief executive of the United Jersey Bank, based in Hackensack, the bank said yesterday.

title: U.S. SEES QUICK END TO CONTRAS' CAMPS
description: Expressing Washington's continued optimism that the contra war is ending, a senior Administration official said today that the Nicaraguan guerrilla camps in Honduras should be totally dismantled by the middle of next week.

Dual-Trading Ban Proposed
description: Members of the Chicago Merchantile Exchange approved a ban tonight on so-called dual trading, a practice involving certain futures contracts.

title: After Years of Becoming Cleaner, New York City Air Grows Dirtier
description: After years of improvement, the quality of New York City's air is again on the decline, as growing numbers of automobiles spew rising amounts of carbon monoxide and smog-producing pollutants into the atmosphere.

title: DE KLERK ENDORSES SHARING OF POWER
description: President F. W. de Klerk said today that his Government would not agree to majority rule but was prepared to work out a formula for whites to share power with blacks in South Africa.

title: Equifax Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago share earnings restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split on Dec. 18, 1989.

title: Bruins Eliminate Whalers as Bourque Returns
description: Inspired by the return of their injured captain, Ray Bourque, the Boston Bruins triumphed, 3-1, tonight and eliminated the Hartford Whalers in the seventh game of their Adams Division semifinal series.

title: Rigged Shotgun Kills Youth
description: A teen-ager was killed when he broke into a warehouse last Saturday night and tripped a booby-trapped shotgun, the authorities said today. The youth, Michael McComb, was shot in the chest while leading three juveniles in a burglary attempt, the police said. They said the downtown warehouse, leased to Philip Connaghan of suburban Arvada, had been burglarized eight times since 1987. Mr. Connaghan denies knowledge of the booby trap, the police said.

title: National Mercantile reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Playboy Seeks New Agency
description: With its New York ad agency on the verge of closing, Playboy magazine has quietly begun talking to other agencies about its advertising account, which it previously valued at $2 million in print and broadcast billings. Michael Perlis, the magazine's publisher, confirmed yesterday that he had ''informally started a review, not a structured search,'' for an agency. Keye/Donna/Pearlstein in New York was hired last year to handle Playboy's account, but its parent agency in Los Angeles is scheduled to shut the office because of financial stresses.

title: Videotape Tells Of Youths' Role In Bensonhurst
description: In a videotaped interview played at the Bensonhurst murder trial yesterday, a defendant admitted that he and a group of white friends had gathered with baseball bats on the night Yusuf K. Hawkins was shot to death.

title: Cleaning Up Electronics
description: In an effort to prevent further depletion of the earth's ozone, the Digital Equipment Corporation has developed a system for cleaning sophisticated electrical equipment that eliminates the use of chlorofluorocarbons, a chemical blamed for damaging the protective layer of the atmosphere. The company said it would make the technology available without charge.

title: C-Cor Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
Mac Brier Dies at 73; Owned Clothing Firms
description: Mac Brier, a men's clothing manufacturer, died of a rare blood disease on Sunday at Bates Hospital in Oakland, Calif. He was 73 years old and lived in Oakland.

title: 2 OPEC Nations Reported To Agree to Cut Oil Output
description: Two influential ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed today to reduce production to try to restore oil prices to their benchmark level of $18 a barrel, oil industry executives said.

title: Xoma Awarded Drug Patent
description: The Xoma Corporation, a biotechnology company, received a patent covering a drug for bacterial infections. Xoma immediately filed a lawsuit against Centocor Inc., which is developing a similar drug.

description: Suffolk County hopes to balance its budget in part by encouraging its employees to stay home from work occasionally.

The contract, which begins on Oct. 1, calls for Raytheon to provide management, operating and technical services at various test sites.

Because of Ms. Roy, a bill to require labeling of produce that has been coated with wax has been passed by the New Hampshire Legislature.

title: NBC Wins Ratings for Season But Shows Signs of Weakness
description: NBC finished on top in the 1989-90 prime-time television ratings season, which ended Sunday, its fifth straight victory, but the results revealed an unexpected weakness in the front-running network and a shift in momentum toward its rival, ABC.

description: Consumer prices climbed five-tenths of 1 percent in March to make the annual inflation rate 8.5 percent for the first three months of 1990, the most rapid increase in a quarter in nearly eight years, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Bush Warns Moscow of U.S. Move Over Cut in Fuel for Lithuanians
description: President Bush warned Moscow today that he would retaliate for a cut in fuel shipments to Lithuania, and officials said possible responses ranged from canceling official meetings and educational exchanges to stalling talks on a variety of trade issues.

description: Representative Barney Frank of Massachusetts announced today that he would seek re-election even though the House ethics committee has yet to release a report on questions surrounding his relationship with a male prostitute.

description: With an impartiality that has been rare in contemporary Soviet theater, ''The Peace of Brest-Litovsk'' personalizes history and illuminates a turning point in its nation's past: the 1918 treaty that fixed its signers (post-Czarist Russia and imperialist Germany) on a course that was to have disastrous repercussions.

title: Gilmore Is Drafted

Yesterday, Artis Gilmore, still 7 feet 2 inches in height but now at least 15 pounds over his playing weight of 265, was drafted again - by the United States Basketball League.

description: One of the bizarre dynamics of team sports is that every team has one player who drives the coach nuts. Somebody the coach can unload on. Somebody who can take it. With the Knicks, that player is a soft-spoken reserve center named Eddie Lee Wilkins.

description: Fairleigh Dickinson University's 21-year-old West Indies Laboratory for Underwater Research, which was badly damaged by Hurricane Hugo last fall, may be closed and sold, depending on the recommendation of a committee of university trustees.

title: Shortage of Additive Limits Clean Gasoline
description: In recent months, four oil companies have followed ARCO's lead in introducing cleaner-burning gasolines in a limited number of markets, and more are likely to follow. But for all the marketing fanfare accompanying the new products, most Americans should not expect to see such lower-pollution gasolines at local pumps for at least three years.

Merrill has owned the division only since Jan. 10, when it paid $1.48 billion to RJR Nabisco Inc. for all of Del Monte's processed foods businesses.

title: Review/Rock;   Audience Is Part of Motley Crue Act
description: The audience is the thing at a Motley Crue concert. At the Meadowlands tonight the audience yelled loudly, then even louder. They waved their arms. They sang along with the songs. They pumped their fists in the air, and congratulated themselves on what a good performance the band was putting on. And the band, taking regular breathers from its calisthenics on stage, milked the audience for every scream.

title: Executive Is Hired By Weider Publishing
description: Weider Publishing Group has hired Michael T. Carr as executive vice president. The company's magazines include Muscle & Fitness, Flex, Men's Fitness, Shape and Moxie. The Bush Administration, which has been playing good cop to Congress's bad cop in the unfolding trade drama, emerged from the latest round of negotiations with a sheaf of commitments that should make it far easier for American consumer goods to break into the Japanese market.

Originally, he was to conduct as well, but that apparently proved too taxing, so the task was delegated to the able Alasdair Neale.

title: M.I.T. Provost Enters Dispute Over R.O.T.C.

title: Apple's Profits Rebound on Strong Foreign Sales

The Cupertino, Calif., company had notified analysts on March 15 that results would be better than expected after a disappointing previous quarter, but today's numbers exceeded even the most bullish of revised estimates.

title: John Reurs, 66, Head Of Cruise Ship Group
description: John H. Reurs, chairman of the International Committee of Passenger Liners, a trade organization for cruise ships, died of prostate cancer on April 12 at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 66 years old and lived in Rowayton, Conn.

title: Britain Is Convinced Its Customs Halted Giant Gun for Iraq
description: The British Government said today that it was convinced that Iraq was attempting to build a giant gun but that British customs officers set back the project by seizing eight steel tubes last week.

title: Heileman Seeking Equity for Banks
description: The G. Heileman Brewing Company, burdened by a heavy takeover debt, is seeking to negotiate an arrangement to give its largest creditors partial ownership in the company to discourage any move toward liquidation. A company spokesman, Bill Eiler, would not comment on the share of equity the banks might receive.

title: Safe Passage for Students
description: Violence that begins inside New York City's schools often continues after the bell rings, making the subways increasingly unsafe during after-school hours. Now relief may be in sight for law-abiding students who simply want safe passage.

title: KEY RATES
Timber Industry Outlook
description: United States timber harvests will increase 55 percent in the next 50 years, but industry employment will drop because of modernization, the Government said on Tuesday. The South will feel the biggest effect, losing about 36 percent of its timber jobs, the General Accounting Office told the House Ways and Means Committee. It said timber employment would probably fall 26 percent in the Rocky Mountain region, 23 percent in the North and 13 percent on the West Coast.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in Science Times on Tuesday about a heart surgeon, Dr. Viking O. Bjork, misstated his role in developing a heart valve. As the article said, he contributed concepts, tested the device and helped market it, but he did not design it.

title: Civic Sense Saves Dollars In Oakland
description: rrOver more than two decades, the Raiders were shut out in Oakland only once: 17-0 by the Denver Broncos in 1981, their last season there. But now the Raiders have suddenly been shut out there again: 6-0 by the City Council. Shut out of town. In a rare triumph for civic sense over sports dollars, Oakland's offer to retrieve the Raiders, sliced to $428 million from the original $602 million, was taken off the table Tuesday night by the City Council vote. And in a rare triumph for franchise-jumping justice, Al Davis was spurned by the city he spurned.

title: Review/Cabaret;   Characters In Song
description: ''I was born Terry Sue and brought up in Scarsdale,'' the actress Tovah Feldshuh sings to the tune of ''Born in a Trunk'' in the opening number of her cabaret act at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel. Written by Gerard Alessandrini, the creator of ''Forbidden Broadway,'' with additional lyrics by Jim Luigs and Robin Field, the song, titled ''Call Me Tovah,'' goes on to list the many names she does not want to be known by, including Tuna, Toe Shoe and Tora, Tora, Tora.

title: Stock Prices Slide as Dow Tumbles 32.89
description: Stock prices tumbled yesterday in the wake of weak corporate earnings, rumors of rising interest rates in Japan and signs that the American economy is much stronger than many people believed. The latest indication of that strength was the improvement in the nation's trade deficit announced yesterday.

title: Kansas City Rights Leaders Praise Supreme Court Ruling

title: Corrections

title: 'Your Bunny' and Wall Street Justice
description: On the afternoon of Jan. 8, 1987, Robert Freeman, chief of risk arbitrage at Goldman, Sachs & Company, was feeling anxious about a takeover of Beatrice Foods Company that hadn't yet gone through. He called Martin Siegel, one of the deal's promoters, and said his friend Bunny Lasker had told him the deal was in trouble. ''Your Bunny has a good nose,'' said Mr. Siegel. On that basis, Mr. Freeman promptly unloaded half a million dollars in Beatrice options.

title: Tudor Baffles Pirates
description: John Tudor continued his comeback from elbow and shoulder trouble by extending his two-season scoreless streak to 19 innings as the St. Louis Cardinals beat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 3-0, tonight.

title: A House Built To Be 'Healthy'
description: ON an island off the Atlantic coast, there is a house that exemplifies some recent thinking in architecture. Designed by Paul Bierman-Lytle of New Canaan, Conn., it has an indoor garden and a spiral staircase that wends its way up to a romantic lighthouse tower. It also contains insulation derived from a mineral mined from sea water, ''natural'' grout and wood finishes made from linseed oil, citrus peel oil, juniper berries and rosemary.

title: Volunteer Groups Join Those With Needs to Those With Time
description: LEAD: ''WHERE the Wild Things Are'' is a familiar book to the 3- and 4-year-olds who spend their days at the Child Day Care Center at the Courtland Gardens Retirement Home in Stamford, Conn. But the children have perhaps never experienced the story by Maurice Sendak as vividly as when it is read to them by Beatrice

Fox said that Ms. Boehm would work on the development of programming and would work with advertisers to develop campaigns that Fox considers appropriate for children.

title: CLOSE TO HOME
description: I DON'T think much about college. I went to one reunion, my 11th, and felt as if I were sleeping in a bed that was too short in a room that was too small in a place that was now too narrow to encompass me. I'd grown up, and could no longer find a space for myself in academe.

That was when the heirs of Eliza Jumel sold the laurel and arrow-bedecked wings to Adm. Richard Evelyn Byrd, the aviator and polar explorer.

description: Onstage in ''The Piano Lesson,'' the August Wilson play that won the Pulitzer Prize for drama last week, Charles S. Dutton is a study in perpetual motion. As Boy Willie, he has come to Pittsburgh from the South in 1936 to do battle with his sister over the right to sell a piano that has been part of their family history since slavery. In persuading, in cajoling, in just plain living, Mr. Dutton conveys an overwhelming presence; he is on his way to becoming, if he is not already, a major American stage actor.

title: Corrections

It occurred in 1978 at the Gene Frankel Theater in Manhattan; the current production is not a premiere.

As a result of restructuring, its balance sheet over the past year and its January 1990 conversion to stock ownership, stockholder's equity totaled $27.3 million at March 31, 1990 and book value was $14.57 a share.

title: Ciccarelli Stealing Post-Season Spotlight With Strong Work at Both Ends of the Ice
description: It is the diminutive, pesky and feisty Dino Ciccarelli - not Wayne Gretzky, Brett Hull, Mark Messier or Bernie Nicholls - who has been the most electrifying performer in the Stanley Cup playoffs thus far.

title: Metro Datelines;   Accord on Removing High School Principal
description: The Board of Education has agreed to settle disciplinary proceedings against a former principal of Eastern District High School, Sonia Rivera, Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez said yesterday.

title: Consolidated Rail Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Con Rail said that earnings for the year-ago quarter included $7 million in other income, but latest first quarter's earnings included $20 million in other expenses. Latest period also included $10 million in non-recurring litigation settlements.

title: Canada Works to Stop Money Laundering
description: To the Editor:

title: Capital Cities/ABC Profit Increases 28%
description: Capital Cities/ABC Inc. said yesterday that its first-quarter profit rose 28 percent, to $106.3 million, or $6.08 a share, from $82.8 million, or $4.59 a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose 13 percent, to $1.26 billion, from $1.12 billion a year earlier.

title: 2 Are Saved and 20 Missing In Plane Crash Off Panama
description: A twin-engine plane carrying 22 people crashed today shortly after takeoff from the Panamanian island of Contadora when birds were sucked into an engine, according to the airline, Aeroperlas. Twenty people were missing and two rescued, it said.

title: Kaman Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U.S. Assailed Over Trade
description: The European Community today accused the United States of undermining world trading rules through what it said was an array of unfair trade practices.

title: Computronix reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
Additional Area Code Is Planned In New York
description: New York Telephone Company officials said yesterday that they plan to introduce an additional area code to New York City within two to three years.

title: BAKER IS CAUTIOUS ON HOSTAGE OFFER
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d reacted very cautiously today to reports that a pro-Iranian group intends to release one of its American hostages and said there were no plans at present to send an American diplomat to Damascus, as the group has demanded.

title: Kelly Wins Court Case On Balloon Charge
description: Jim Kelly, the Buffalo Bills' quarterback, won a credibility contest yesterday when a judge in Buffalo said a woman who contended that Kelly hit her in the face with a beer-filled balloon failed to prove her case.

title: American Telephone & TeleFgraph reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Consolidated results for 1990 reflected the acquisitions of Istel Group Ltd. in the fourth quarter of 1989 and two divisions of a subsidiary of Pacificorp Financial Services in the first quarter of 1990.

title: Code-Alarm Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Boulevard Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Oilers Crush Kings, 7-0, To Open Division Series
description: Esa Tikkanen scored two goals and the goaltender Bill Ranford got his first-ever playoff shutout as the Edmonton Oilers beat the Los Angeles Kings, 7-0, tonight in the opening game of their Division playoff series.

title: Clorox Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $2,593,000, or 5 cents a share, for the quarter and $544,000, or 1 cent a share, for the 9 months. Clorox said discontinued operations represented the olympic paint and stain division sold in September.

title: Review/Television;   'Inside a Terrorist Bombing,' on HBO
description: American television doesn't have a monopoly on controversial docudramas. Just ask Granada Television of Britain, producer of ''The Investigation: Inside a Terrorist Bombing,'' which has been acquired by Home Box Office and will be shown as a Showcase presentation on the pay-cable service. The first HBO telecast is Sunday at 10 P.M.

title: McCants Facing Some Competition
description: Only a few months ago, Keith McCants's name intruded into the same sentence as Lawrence Taylor's. McCants, the University of Alabama linebacker, was the top pro prospect even though he was only a junior.

title: Society for Savings Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Big Net Gain For Northrop
description: The Northrop Corporation reported a sharp increase in earnings for the first quarter, largely because of a one-time gain of $67.1 million from the sale of its headquarters.

title: Norris Likes Comeback
description: Not bad, Mike Norris, for your second major league game in almost seven years: a perfectly pitched inning and a victory over California. ''I couldn't have come up with a better scenario,'' Norris said after Oakland beat the Angels, 7-5, at Anaheim Tuesday night in 12 innings. The victory was Norris's first in the major leagues since May 16, 1983, and the appearance was only his second in the majors since Aug. 6 of that year.

title: Capital Cities-ABC Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
House Bill Aids Price-Fix Suits
description: The House challenged a threatened veto by President Bush and voted today to make it easier for discount stores and local prosecutors to sue manufacturers and full-price retailers for price fixing.

title: A Painful Necessity, Deferred
description: With their states facing budget deficits that require higher taxes, Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey and Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York haven't rushed to endorse another unpopular but necessary step: a proposed $1 toll hike on Hudson River bridges and tunnels that are operated by the Port Authority.

title: Engraving a Single Letter or 10,000
description: ''NINETY-FIVE percent of what we do is by hand,'' said Richard Naimoli, who still engraves jewelry and silverware the old-fashioned way: with one of his 60 wooden-handled tools, a lot of patience and a steady hand. ''There are only a few of us left,'' he said.

title: G.M. to Begin Production Of a Battery-Powered Car
description: Responding to concerns about poor air quality, the General Motors Corporation announced today that it would proceed with commercial production of a battery-powered electric car for personal use.

title: State Acquires Most of Times Square Project Site
description: After a six-year legal battle, New York State acquired most of the Times Square development area yesterday, and officials said demolition to clear the way for the $2.5 billion project could begin as early as the fall.

title: American Business Products reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Loving Care for Camphorwood Chests
description: LEAD: Years before the manufacture of synthetic camphor mothballs and flakes was even thought of, there was the real thing: camphorwood. Chests made of it must have been a boon for seamen, whose wardrobe for cold and hot climates usually had to accompany them on their voyages.

title: U.S. Is Dropping Plan To Deploy New Missile
description: The Bush Administration is abandoning plans to deploy new short-range nuclear missiles in West Germany, American officials said.

title: Simmons Files Suit On Lockheed Proxy
description: Harold C. Simmons, the Dallas financier, filed a Federal lawsuit today challenging the legality of the proxy contest he lost last month for control of the Lockheed Corporation's board.

title: Despite Stock Holdings, Golden Says He Will Vote on Cable TV
description: In another twist involving the renewal of cable-television franchises, Borough President Howard Golden of Brooklyn disclosed yesterday that he owns stock in a corporation that is a partner in an unrelated venture with Time Warner, the parent of the two companies seeking renewals.

title: Dataflex Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Arvin Industries reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $433,000, or 2 cents a share.

title: 15 Killed in Attack on Beirut School Bus
description: A rifle-fired grenade slammed into a school bus and exploded today during Christian factional fighting, killing 11 schoolchildren and at least four other people, witnesses said.

title: Westport Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Tax Problem Disputed
description: The Chicago Bears said yesterday published reports had exaggerated the amount of taxes in dispute between the Internal Revenue Service and the team's owners.

description: Share earnings for both periods reflected a 2-for-1 stock split paid in October 1989.

title: Combining Metalwork And Glass
description: ANDRE DUBREUIL, a French designer who lives in London, is one of the stars of the European furniture world. Now working with Daum, the venerable French glass company, under the baton of its art director, Clotilde Bacri, Mr. Dubreuil has created a new collection that reinterprets traditional glass techniques using his fanciful metalwork.

title: Pepsi Signs Burma Deal
description: Pepsi said today that it signed an agreement to operate in Burma, despite calls by dissidents and human rights groups not to invest after a military crackdown. The agreement was signed last month with a private partner, and Pepsico International has a 35 percent share in the venture, said Barry Shea, company vice president for southeast Asia. The company will ship soft drinks to Burma and is building a $3 million factory on the outskirts of Rangoon, the Burmese capital, which should be completed by the end of the year, he said.

title: Metro Matters;   How Much Pity For a Dentist Turned Burglar?
description: Brace yourself. This is a story about crime, drugs, child abuse and wife beating that may yet have a happy ending.

title: San Francisco Journal;   And Yet Again, the Earth Trembles For a Tiny Band of 1906 Survivors
description: In the gloom before dawn, while most of the city slept on, undisturbed by memory or geology, a dwindling band of survivors of the 1906 earthquake assembled today to commemorate the day the earth shook and the sky burned.

title: MCI Communications reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $10,000,000 on early debt retirements, less applicable income tax benefits.

title: Shearson Loses $915 Million For a Record on Wall Street
description: The worst quarterly results in Wall Street's history were reported yesterday by Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., which said it had lost $915 million last quarter, compared with a loss of $15 million in the first quarter of 1989.

title: Trinova Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $1,087,000.

title: Montana to Seek Halt To Leaky Sect Shelter
description: State officials say they will ask a court to halt construction of a fallout shelter complex near Yellowstone National Park where more than 30,000 gallons of fuel has leaked from the builders' buried tanks.

title: Bonds Fall Sharply; Rates Soar
description: Long-term interest rates rose yesterday to their highest levels since last May, as prices of Treasury notes and bonds fell for the fourth straight day.

title: First Empire State reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $9,455,000 from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting principle. The latest period results included those of 11 branches of Monroe Savings Bank since Jan. 26.

Winn-Dixie Stores Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to April 4
description: The company said it plans to open 46 new stores in the current fiscal year.

title: Amgen Backed In Patent Case
description: A Federal appeals court has blocked a court order that would have required Amgen Inc., a drug maker in Thousand Oaks, Calif., to share patent rights for a lucrative new anti-anemia drug with a rival.

title: Coke's Profit Rises by 9.1%
description: The Coca-Cola Company said today that its first-quarter earnings increased 9.1 percent compared with the period a year earlier, with the biggest gains continuing to be made overseas.

title: A Paperback Meant to Fold
description: ALTHOUGH origami is a Japanese invention, Robert Penny, an American graphic designer, created his own version of artful paper-folding. Called ''American Home,'' it is a 10-page paperback that includes 43 precut and scored pieces of a typical suburban ranch house and its accouterments.

title: A.T.&T. Net Up 12.5%; MCI Gains
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company reported a 12.5 percent first-quarter earnings gain yesterday, and the MCI Communications Corporation, the second-largest long-distance telephone company after A.T.&T., reported a 22 percent increase.

title: Eldon Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 24
Dauphin Deposit Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
New York's Waters Cleaner, But Pollution Is Still Daunting
description: After spending billions of dollars in the last 20 years, New York City has made large strides toward cleaning up its polluted waterways. But daunting problems have to be overcome before New Yorkers can safely swim at most beaches and eat fish from local waters.

title: Multimedia Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Q&A
description: Taller Chimney?

title: A Venture Into the Heart Of Capitalism
description: On the hectic floor of the New York Stock Exchange the other day, a young man with a mild Russian accent, microphone in hand, addressed a bemused trader.

title: Review/Dance;   Paul Taylor, Serious, Not Solemn
description: Paul Taylor is often most serious as a choreographer when he is at his most comic, and it is this sense of humor, woven into a philosophical outlook on life, that has much to do with his indisputable popularity and wide appeal.

title: Dreco Energy Services reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28

description: The Bush Administration is developing an arms control initiative that would cancel deployment of new short-range nuclear missiles in West Germany, Administration officials said today.

description: Terry A. Anderson: Chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press; missing since March 16, 1985.

description: The year-ago quarter's earnings included non-recurring gain of 3 cents a share from the sale of a coffee business. The period also included income from discontinued operations of $439,000.

title: United Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Beginning in 1990, translation gains related to Brazilian debt have been credited to interest expense in order to approximate the real rate of interest on such debt. The company said that 1989 results have been restated to conform with 1990 presentation. The effect of the restatement on 1989 results was to reduce revenues, operating profit and interest expense by $7 million. Higher first-quarter earnings were primarily a result of strong performances by Pratt & Whitney and Otis.

title: Huntington Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago first quarter restated for acquisitions of First Macomb Bancorp Inc. and First Banc Securities Inc.

description: First Interstate Bancorp said today that profits fell 4 percent in the first quarter, but that its troubled Texas unit turned a $9.1 million profit and losses ended at its Arizona bank.

Banks of Mid-America Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $163,000, or 2 cents a share.

title: Legislators Tangle Over Trenton Budget
description: Republican legislators tangled repeatedly today with their Democratic colleagues and members of the Florio administration as hearings opened on an austere budget everyone agrees will cost taxpayers more and give them less.

title: Public Service Co. of Colorado reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Decades-Long Battle Between Paper And Ex-Official Is Refought in Trial
description: For 17 days over the last few weeks, the executive editor of Philadelphia's largest newspaper was on the witness stand here, testifying in a libel case that arose from articles published in his paper almost two decades ago and a killing that took place 27 years ago.

title: 'Free Space' Sculpture to Honor Free Speech
description: A mostly invisible sculpture that its creator says suggests the idea of ''free space'' has been chosen to commemorate the 1960's free speech movement.

title: DE KLERK STARTS INQUIRY ON CLASH
description: President F. W. de Klerk said today that he had appointed a judicial commission of inquiry to look into the shooting by the police of demonstrators in a black township on March 26.

title: Spending Falls in Britain
description: Britain's consumer spending fell last month, indicating that Government efforts to reduce inflation through high interest rates were beginning to take hold. The Central Statistical Office said today that provisional March retail sales fell by 1.4 percent. February's retail sales figures had shown a marked rise of 2.4 percent, which market analysts had described as a one-time abnormality.

title: Commercial Intl Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Chief's Son Moves Up At Eastman & Beaudine
description: Eastman & Beaudine, an executive search firm based in Dallas, has named Robert E. Beaudine, representing the second generation of Beaudines, as president and chief operating officer.

title: Inquiry on Agents
description: The embattled sports agent, Bruce Allen, the son of the former Washington Redskin coach, George Allen, lashed out at those he said had encouraged the Federal Bureau of Investigation to investigate him, and he threatened yesterday to file a defamation suit after the N.F.L. draft, which begins Sunday.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Vermont Financial Services Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Inmate Escapes From Prison Barge
description: An inmate broke the metal seals on the window of a prison barge moored at a Hudson River pier early yesterday, climbed out, swam ashore and escaped into lower Manhattan, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: The Eating Well column in The Living Section on April 11 about fast-food hamburgers made an invalid comparison between the fat in the hamburgers and the amount of fat in the diet recommended by most health professionals. The figure for fat, which ranged from 21.2 percent to 23.7 percent, was the percentage of the hamburgers' weight, not the percentage of their calories from fat.

title: Cavaliers Are Near Berth in Playoffs
description: With little left to cheer about, except for Chris Dudley to go to the free-throw line and miss another shot, a crowd of 11,985 showed up at the Byrne Arena tonight to see the Cleveland Cavaliers defeat the Nets, 100-93, and move a step closer to the Eastern Conference playoffs.

title: Taiwan May Face Sanctions
description: Washington will place Taiwan on a list of unfair trading partners next week, leading to possible United States trade sanctions against the export-driven nation, Taiwan newspapers reported this week.

title: Conversion Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
George Horne, 87, Shipping Editor For The Times in Heyday of Port
description: George Horne, who for more than 40 years covered the waterfront of New York, the world's busiest port, for The New York Times, died of congestive heart failure yesterday in Ardmore, Okla. He was 87 years old and lived in Ardmore.

title: Philip Morris's Profits Rose By 31.4% in First Quarter
description: The Philip Morris Companies, the world's largest consumer-products company, said its earnings in the first quarter rose 31.4 percent, to $775 million, or 84 cents a share, from $590 million, or 64 cents a share, in the quarter a year ago.

title: Laudner Is Ready
description: Three weeks after leaving the Minnesota Twins' spring training camp for personal reasons, Tim Laudner is ready to play baseball again. ''Tim is ready, willing and able to return to major league baseball,'' Laudner's agent, Ron Simon, said yesterday. ''The next move belongs to the Minnesota Twins.''

title: Michigan National reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $8,325,000, or 54 cents a share, representing the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: First Bank System reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The net income for the latest first quarter included $2.6 million in tax credits, compared with $6.9 million in similar benefits for year-ago period.

title: Jafta Masemola, 58; Began Armed Wing Of Pan-Africanists
description: Jafta Masemola, founder of the military wing of the black nationalist Pan-Africanist Congress, died of injuries suffered in a car accident on Tuesday, his sister said today. He was 58 years old.

title: James O'Donnell, 72, Reporter and Author
description: James P. O'Donnell, a former foreign correspondent whose 1978 book on the final days of Adolf Hitler, ''The Bunker,'' became a best-seller, died of lung and stomach cancer on Monday at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston. He was 72 years old and lived in Boston.

title: Lincoln Deal Is Questioned
description: Government lawyers charged today that Charles H. Keating Jr., chairman of the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, had used $13 million in federally insured deposits to buy loans from the Saudi European Bank in exchange for a $3.75 million loan for Lincoln's parent, the American Continental Corporation.

title: Computer & Communications Technology Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Marine Midland And Ford in Talks
description: The Ford Motor Credit Company said it was in talks to acquire the operations and certain assets of the automotive financing business of Marine Midland Banks Inc. Terms were not immediately available. Ford said the unit, called the Marine Midland Automotive Financial Corporation, provides private-label financing programs in the United States for Mazda, Jaguar, Saab and other companies.

title: Fama Was the Gunman, Bensonhurst Jury Is Told
description: Joseph Fama ''shot repeatedly and intentionally at Yusuf Hawkins,'' an assistant district attorney said yesterday as he opened the prosecution's case against the white Bensonhurst man charged with shooting the black teen-ager to death last summer.

title: Bonwit Teller Fills Top Post
description: As expected, Frank Doroff, chairman of Federated and Allied Merchandising Services, was named chairman and chief executive of the reorganized Bonwit Teller chain on Tuesday, the Pyramid Companies said. Pyramid, a mall-development company, purchased the Bonwit name and store leases in Buffalo and Boston at a bankruptcy court hearing on April 4.

description: Football

description: b-Included a $12.4 million provision for loan loss reserves and one-time gains totaling $7.4 million. c-Net income

The bank said the latest quarter included $34 million in gains from sales of real estate, compared with $17 million for year-ago period.

title: Occidental Petroleum reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included losses from early extinguishment of debt of $2,000,000 and $9,000,000 for the latest and year-ago quarters, respectively.

title: Blunders Cost Mets 2d Loss To Cubs
description: Except for the fact that Darryl Strawberry hit his first home run of the year in his ninth game in his 32d time at bat, the evening in Shea Stadium qualified as a total loss for the Mets.

title: Growing Pressure
description: After a confusing day of threats and denials, Lithuania reported tonight that the Soviet authorities had cut off the principal supply of oil to the republic as part of the Kremlin's campaign to force Lithuania to retreat from its declaration of independence.

title: Student Accuses 5 at St. John's Of a Sex Assault
description: Law-enforcement authorities said yesterday that they were investigating an accusation by a student at St. John's University in Queens that she was sexually assaulted by up to five students at an off-campus residence on March 1.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   People
description: * Howard Adler has been appointed group vice president and advertising director at Macy's Northeast Inc.

title: Nepal's Tense Days: Foreign Aid Reported at Risk
description: The World Bank and several nations that give aid to Nepal warned aides to King Birendra last month that financial help for this impoverished kingdom could be jeopardized if the King failed to respond to the democracy movement that has since started to take power, officials here say.

title: Phelps Dodge Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bush Denies Putting Off Action On Averting Global Climate Shift
description: President Bush, responding to criticism that the United States had delayed taking concrete steps to address the threat of global warming linked to pollution, said today, ''We have never considered research a substitute for action.''

title: American General Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Review/Music;   Rova Saxophone Quartet
description: The Rova Saxophone Quartet is an equivalent of the Kronos String Quartet: both are San Francisco foursomes devoted to new music with a vernacular twist. In Rova's case, the vernacular influence is overt, given the jazz connotations of the saxophone. But the Rova, like the Kronos, is a serious avant-garde ensemble, as a puzzled and rambunctious group of teen-agers, apparently expecting something different, discovered at the group's concert Tuesday night at Town Hall.

description: ''A court order directing a local government body to levy its own taxes is plainly a judicial act within the power of a Federal court.''

Publishing Plans of American Express
description: ''We want to develop magazines in the top 20 markets in the United States,'' said Thomas Ryder, president and executive publisher of the American Express Publishing Corporation. ''We are either going to start them or we're going to buy them. We are in the midst of building a major publishing company.''

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   NBC Shifts Executives For Sales Operations
description: NBC realigned its sales organization yesterday. It named Bob Blackmore executive vice president, television network, with oversight of sales and marketing at the NBC Television Network, CNBC and SportsChannel America, as well as for the 1992 Summer Olympics and international programming.

title: 2 OPEC Nations Are Likely To Seek Increase in Quotas
description: Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates are still likely to seek larger oil production quotas, despite their reported promise on Tuesday to decrease output, senior OPEC officials said today.

description: This is an astonished one-column look at a story of world importance that involves politics, war, race, national survival and lots of money.

In New York yesterday, a spokesman for Mr. Moon's Unification Church, Dr. TYLER HENDRICKS, said some 500 delegates from 60 countries, including 40 former heads of state and senior executives of newspapers founded by Mr. Moon, attended the 11th World Media Conference.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of Earth Day celebrations, 42d Street will be closed today to all vehicles except buses from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Prospect Park Drive and the East and West Drives in Central Park will be closed from 10 A.M. to 3 P.M. In addition, parking and loading will be restricted on the following routes to allow for bike lanes: Avenue of the Americas, from Eighth to 59th Streets; Broadway, from 24th to 59th Streets and from Chambers Street to Park Place; Fifth Avenue, from Washington Square to 24th Street; Chambers Street, from Centre Street to Broadway.

description: A 109-year-old water main broke early yesterday on the Upper West Side, halting service on four subway lines for six hours and closing five blocks of Central Park West to vehicles.

title: Court Overturns 16th Death Sentence
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court yesterday reversed a death penalty ruling because the prosecution did not prove the defendant intended to kill his victim, though he stabbed her 53 times.

title: Universal Health Services reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Review/Theater;   3 Zora Neale Hurston Tales Wrapped in a Bluesy Package
description: When writers with clashing personalities share the stage, the result can often be a tug of war. But in ''Spunk,'' the exuberant show at the Public Theater celebrating the fiction of Zora Neale Hurston, George C. Wolfe, the author of ''The Colored Museum,'' submerges his own irreverent sensibility to serve, and serve ingeniously, the spirit of a far different literary voice. When one recalls how much satirical devastation Mr. Wolfe inflicted on Lorraine Hansberry and Ntozake Shange in ''The Colored Museum,'' his selfless devotion to Hurston is all the more impressive.

title: Talking Deals;   No End in Sight In Norton Battle
description: THE bruising weeks-old fight for the Norton Company by BTR, a British conglomerate, is far from over. And the fight could grow nastier as Norton, a maker of abrasives based in Worcester, Mass., continues to throw obstacles in its opponent's path, and BTR sinks its teeth in and hangs on.

description: An eviction notice ordering 150 Jewish settlers occupying buildings in the Old City's Christian quarter to evacuate them by nine this morning was approved overnight by Israel's High Court.

description: The Chemical Financial Acceptance Corporation is offering $119.7 million in asset-backed securities with a final maturity date of April 15, 1994, through underwriters led by Chemical Securities Inc.

New Jersey's Rules Voided On Milk From Out of State
description: A Federal judge today struck down New Jersey milk regulations that effectively barred supplies from other states. The decision, which ends a two-year dispute between New York and New Jersey, is expected to mean lower prices for consumers.

title: New Drug Treatment Is Approved For Late Stages of Colon Cancer
description: A chemotherapy treatment that includes a drug used to remove worms from the intestines of farm animals was endorsed today by a panel of experts as a standard for patients who have undergone surgery for a late stage of colon cancer.

description: b-Included income of $2,853,000, or 19 cents a share, resulting from the sale of investment securities. Share earnings for 1989 have been restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split declared in June 1989. The company said gross earnings in the latest first quarter were $71,865,000, including $4,274,000 of profits on investment securities. This compares with gross earnings for the year-ago first quarter of $73,826,000.

description: The share earnings and shares outstanding reflected 2-for-1 stock split in February 1990.

title: Piniella Knows How to Please: 8-0
description: When Lou Piniella managed the Yankees, his strongest asset was his ability to fend off and survive the intrusion of his employer, George Steinbrenner. His weak point seemed to be the way he used his pitchers, yanking starters early and overusing or underusing Dave Righetti, his No. 1 reliever.

title: Cooker Restaurant reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
2 Stores Closed By Jordan Marsh
description: The Jordan Marsh division of the Allied Stores Corporation has announced the closing of its stores in Lowell, Mass., and Danbury, Conn. Allied Stores and its sister company, Federated Department Stores Inc., are operating under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. Both companies are owned by the troubled Campeau Corporation of Canada.

title: Life Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
