description: The net income and share earnings figures for 1989 reflected restatement for the effects of a change in accounting principle concerning incremental nuclear outage maintenance costs.

title: Tandem Net Rises 58.5%
description: Tandem Computers Inc. reported today that its second-quarter revenues and earnings were considerably above the comparable period a year earlier but below its own earlier expectations.

title: U.S. and Japan Will Discuss Allied-Signal's Trade Issue
description: In a compromise to avoid new confrontation with Japan, the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, announced today that she would begin special talks with Tokyo to try to resolve a complaint about barriers in Japan's $100 million-a-year market for amorphous metals.

title: Papp, Seeking Aid, Resists Signing Pledge on Obscenity
description: Joseph Papp, head of the New York Shakespeare Festival, has written to John E. Frohnmayer, chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, saying he is reluctant to sign an acceptance form agreeing to observe obscenity restrictions so the festival can receive a $50,000 grant for its annual Festival Latino.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Analog Devices Inc., Norwood, Mass., a maker of integrated linear circuits, completed a repurchase of 2 million shares of its common stock and said it might repurchase up to 2 million additional shares from time to time on the open market.

title: Quantum Chemical Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $3,900,000, or 16 cents a share. First-quarter results continued to be adversely affected by costs in excess of estimated insurance recoveries associated with the fires in 1989 at the Morris, Ill. plant, estimated at $15 million, or 59 cents a share, in the current quarter. The plant resumed operation on March 28.

title: Bridge
description: When the opponents put on the brakes at a low level, it is fair to assume that they cannot make a game. Occasionally, however, this assumption proves false with embarrassing results. A case in point is the diagramed deal played recently in a cut-in Imp game at the Cavendish Club in Manhattan.

title: Baltimore Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain on extinguishment of debt of $756,000.

title: Perrier to Bow to F.D.A. and Change Label
description: The ''eau,'' as Perrier promotions state, is expected to be back on American store shelves next week. But the mineral water's label claims are about to change.

title: Hurdle for Preventive Medicine: Insurance
description: At a time when physicians are increasingly likely to recommend preventive health measures from mammograms to cholesterol checks, patients are often faced with the discovery that insurers will not pay the bills.

title: New Drug Found Helpful in Treating Rare Cancer
description: A new cancer drug is proving remarkably effective in the treatment of hairy cell leukemia, a rare but often fatal malignancy of the blood and bone marrow, researchers say.

title: Guardsman Products Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   A Worldly Image for Della Femina
description: THE French are trying to do to their advertising what they once did for existentialism: give it international cachet. Having landed last year in downtown Manhattan, at the Della Femina, McNamee WCRS agency, they are beginning to make a difference.

title: Electromagnetic Sciences reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Telescope Shuttle Launching Is Now Planned for Tuesday
description: NASA today advanced by one day, to next Tuesday, the second attempt to launch the space shuttle Discovery and its payload, the Hubble Space Telescope.

title: Office Donor Linked to Figure in H.U.D. Inquiry
description: A foundation created by Representative Tom Lantos, head of a House investigation into the Department of Housing and Urban Development, has been receiving free office space for more than a year from a public relations company that represented a major subject of the inquiry.

title: Officer's Link To Social Club Under Inquiry
description: The lawyer who filed the papers incorporating the Bronx social club at which 87 people died in an arson fire last month is a New York City police lieutenant who was moonlighting from his job in the Police Department's prosecutor's office, the department said yesterday.

title: Racing's Brash New Yorker
description: When Howie Tesher got the word two years ago that the Track Barron-Champagne Babe colt he would be training had been named Champagneforashley, he cringed.

title: Personal Health
description: Remember those childhood days when you tried to walk without stepping on any cracks in the sidewalk? Or the times you lined up your toys in a particular order and became furious if anyone disturbed them?

title: Eastern Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
LaPoint Bears Brunt Of Defeat
description: By the time the Yankees had finally returned to the visitors' clubhouse today, Dave LaPoint had already showered, shaved, dressed and popped open a can of beer. But he had not yet swallowed the circumstances of the third inning at Tiger Stadium.

title: U.S. TRADE DEFICIT FELL IN FEBRUARY TO A SIX-YEAR LOW
description: The United States trade deficit took an unexpectedly sharp fall in February, the Commerce Department said today. At $6.49 billion, it is the smallest gap between imports and exports in more than six years.

title: Nice Gesture by Coles
description: Darnell Coles of the Seattle Mariners hit a home run Tuesday night, a night after his foul ball struck a little girl in the face and broke her jaw. The home run was something he could do for 9-year-old Michelle Taft, said Coles, who has felt terrible since her Monday night injury at the Kingdome. Coles, the Mariners' third baseman, visited Michelle in the hospital after the game on Monday night and again on Tuesday. Coles said he gave her a bat, two balls and a promise of free Mariners tickets behind the screen in back of home plate. And a promise of a homer? ''I'm not saying anything about that,'' Coles said. ''All I know is I hit one, there's the ball and I'm taking it to her tomorrow.''(AP)

title: UJB Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Oakland Moves to Block Deal Designed to Bring Raiders Back
description: It's back to square one for the city of Oakland and the National Football League's Raiders.

title: Living With a Heritage: Afrocentric Art and Design
description: DR. RICHARD A. LONG, an art historian, speaks as one might of old friends as he moves amid the African, Haitian and African-American art, textiles and furnishings in his spacious 18th-century house in Atlanta. ''Here are my Beardens,'' he said as a proud father might of his children. In a sweeping motion he pointed to six prints by the black American artist Romare Bearden in an upstairs study. Of an intricately carved wooden coffee table, Dr. Long said, ''She's Haitian.''

title: Japanese Drinking Rises
description: Alcohol consumption in Japan increased 3.7 percent in 1989 from a year earlier, to a record 2.3 billion gallons, the National Tax Agency said this week. The agency attributed the rise to increased beer consumption spurred by the introduction of many new brands. Beer consumption accounted for 70 percent of Japan's alcohol consumption in 1989. The previous alcohol consumption record was set in 1988.

title: Feathering Their Nests
description: BIRDHOUSE fever seems to have overtaken the imaginations of designers and collectors. Birdhouses are small. They are affordable (as works of art go). And they are proliferating.

title: Soviets Hold All the Cards
description: Lithuania is ill equipped to withstand an economic siege by Moscow, Eastern European analysts agree. The New Hampshire-sized republic is utterly dependent on energy purchased from the Soviet Government at bargain rates, Nor is there reason to believe that a retaliatory cutoff of Lithuanian exports would do much damage to the Soviet economy. While farms and factories do supply the other Soviet republics with a handful of critical products, Moscow could easily find alternative sources in European markets.

title: Imatron Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Caramoor Music Festival's 1990 Season
description: A performance of Schumann's ''Scenes From Goethe's 'Faust,' '' the premieres of a work by the Russian composer Nikolai Karetnikov and by the accordionist William Schimmel, a series of music by J. S. Bach and sons, and a 40th-anniversary recital by the soprano Roberta Peters are among the highlights of the 45th annual Caramoor Music Festival, which starts June 23 in Katonah, N.Y.

title: Dinkins Names Sanitation Head
description: Filling one of the last vacancies in his administration, Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday named Steven M. Polan, a 39-year-old lawyer who is the general counsel of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, as New York City's Sanitation Commissioner.

title: Snap-On Tools Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a net gain of $2.5 million, or 6 cents a share, on sale of real estate.

title: AMR Has Loss in Quarter; Higher Fuel Costs Cited
description: The AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines, yesterday reported its first quarterly loss since 1987, attributing it largely to sharply higher fuel costs. Wall Street analysts predicted that other airlines would report losses bigger than AMR's in the next few days.

title: Massbank Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DST Systems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

Antiques Worth Smiles (Hint: the Prices Help)
description: SHE'S back in town, and no one seems more pleased than she. Just a few weeks ago, Maya Schaper, the peripatetic antiques dealer with a taste for the esoteric, opened her newest shop on the second floor at 862 Lexington Avenue (65th Street).

title: Jacobs Engineering Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included earnings of $518,000, or 5 cents a share, from the sale of securities.

description: A New York State correction officer was arrested in East Harlem yesterday and charged with possession and intent to sell cocaine, the police said. The officer, identified as John M. Bright, 34 years old, of 957 Orlando Avenue, West Hemstead, L.I., was seized during a buy and bust operation by officers from the Police Department's tactical narcotics team. He was arrested at 4:25 P.M. in front of 2421 Second Avenue, said Officer Fred Weiner, a police spokesman.

description: b-Net loss

Thornburgh Aide Tied to News Report
description: A criminal investigation ordered by Attorney General Dick Thornburgh has concluded that one of his closest aides played a role in confirming a politically damaging news report about a House Democratic leader, William H. Gray 3d, Bush Administration officials said.

title: COURT SAYS JUDGE MAY ORDER TAXES TO ALLEVIATE BIAS
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that Federal judges may order local governments to increase taxes to remedy constitutional violations like school segregation.

The Contras Will Not Disarm Before Chamorro Inaugural
description: The Nicaraguan rebels and Sandinista army officials prepared to sign a cease-fire today, but rebel leaders said they would not lay down their arms before the new, pro-American Government of Violeta Barrios de Chamorro takes office next week.

title: Drew Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
PARENT & CHILD
description: SANDY S. remembers feeling embarrassed by her daughter's behavior. ''When she was a few months old, if she saw anyone else's face, including my mother or father, she would scream,'' Sandy recalled. ''My parents would say, 'Our granddaughter doesn't like us.' I felt terrible. I'd cry.'' Even though the child has not had such strong reactions to unfamiliar adults for more than a year, Sandy's family is still so embarrassed that she asked that her full name not be used. She wonders if she caused the problem by being overprotective.

title: A.T.&T. Chief Defends Decision on Abortion
description: The chairman of A.T.&T. today defended his company's decision to withdraw support from Planned Parenthood's teen-age pregnancy prevention programs, saying it did so because of the organization's advocacy of abortion rights.

title: American Maize-Products reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,890,000. Latest period's results restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: Brooklyn Bishop Is Installed
description: In a majestic ceremony that gingerly sidestepped controversy, Bishop Thomas Vose Daily was installed yesterday as the sixth Roman Catholic Bishop of Brooklyn.

title: Jacobs Ends Fight Over CML Board
description: CML Group Inc. said that the investor Irwin L. Jacobs had informed the company that he would not pursue his previously announced plan to conduct a proxy fight to replace CML's directors. CML's chairman, Charles M. Leighton, said the company had met with Mr. Jacobs to outline management's business plans and expectations of growth in the next 15 months.

description: THEY do windows. But not much else.

description: To encourage businesses and foundations to adopt programs that need money and manpower, Mayor David N. Dinkins named a committee of business executives yesterday to coordinate volunteer efforts in New York City.

description: The American General Corporation, an insurance company in a proxy fight with the Torchmark Corporation, today reported 10.2 percent growth in its first-quarter earnings.

title: Abortion Foe Seeks to Void Loss
description: A state lawmaker and outspoken opponent of abortion who narrowly lost her bid for re-election last month now says she won after all, and on Friday she will ask a Cook County Circuit Court to reverse the results.

title: Panama and the Press
description: The more one looks into President Bush's invasion of Panama, the more one should - and the more one wonders why those of us in the press have been so uncritical about both the ''justification'' and the consequences of this egregious misuse of U.S. military power.

title: Profits Up 19% at Merck
description: First-quarter earnings for the pharmaceutical giant Merck & Company increased 19 percent, aided by growth in new product sales, the company announced today. For the three months ended March 31, net income rose to $403.8 million, or $1.03 a share, from $340.4 million, or 86 cents a share, in the corresponding 1989 quarter, Merck said.

title: Gene Swap in Mice Offers Hope for Medical Gains
description: After years of half-steps, missteps and fears that it could never be done, researchers have fashioned a strain of mouse harboring a specified genetic alteration in every cell of its body.

description: Following is the text of a statement received today by a Western news organization in Beirut, as translated from the Arabic by Reuters. The statement was accompanied by a photograph of an American hostage, Jesse Turner.

description: The Consolidated Rail Corporation, the large Northeast railroad, said today that its earnings plummeted 58 percent in the first quarter.

title: Hiroshima Journal;   At Atomic Shrine, All the Horror, Nothing of Guilt
description: Millions of tourists have traveled to this western coastal city over the years, so it was logical for city officials to expand and renovate the museum and park that bear testimony to one of the greatest horrors of the 20th century.

I had told some jokes in America that were worth about 20 years apiece in Russia. Even though Mikhail Gorbachev's policy of glasnost seemed to be opening things up, I was still skeptical.

title: Takeovers Face New Obstacles
description: In Harrisburg, Pennsylvania's capital, a long-running battle is being watched in corporate board rooms across the country because it raises issues that will affect how American companies are managed in the 1990's.

description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $1,697,000, or 2 cents a share.

title: Advo-System Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Some Smog in Pledges To Help Environment
description: On the bottom of the paperboard container that McDonald's uses for its hash-brown potatoes is the three-arrow symbol that generally denotes a product made of recycled material, and the words ''Recyclable Paper.'' But McDonald's officials concede that the package is not made of recycled paper, is not being recycled and may not even be capable of being recycled because of a promotional label glued to the back.

title: Teaming Up Function and Imagination
description: IN Judith Sacks's living room, curtains never have to be sent to the dry cleaners because they are made of wood. In the kitchen, dishes never have to be dried because they can drip dry through a wooden rack directly into the sink. These design solutions are as functional as they are imaginative.

title: Review/Film;   Civilization Grinds Down in 'Twister,' a Comedy
description: The yellowy-gray clouds are ominous, but the weather is still trying to make up its mind. The winds are warm, gusty. A little girl, Violet, hauls a vacuum cleaner across the lawn toward the swimming pool. On a small knoll behind her stands an all-American mansion, part Mount Vernon, part suburban split-level. It looks both cheesy and expensive.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Change for Goya Foods
description: Citing creative differences, Angotti, Thomas, Hedge has resigned the $3 million advertising account of Goya Foods Inc. The agency picked up the account in January 1989.

title: Congress Returns to a Divisive Agenda
description: After a 10-day Easter recess, lawmakers returned to Capitol Hill today to face a legislative agenda that includes most of the divisive issues Congress managed to sidestep in its first three months.

title: Stormy Time in Sight For Rangers-Capitals
description: ''We're pretty even in toughness,'' Roger Neilson, the coach of Rangers, said when asked how his team matched up against the Capitals. ''And we're pretty even in goaltending, pretty even in defensive play,'' Neilson is pretty much right. ''Maybe,'' concluded Neilson, ''no one will win.''

title: Commerce Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Catholic Bishops' Big P.R. Blunder
description: America's Roman Catholic bishops have committed a blunder as big as the Ritz in hiring public relations and polling organizations to design campaigns against abortion.

New Twists in the Legend of Mao's Onetime Heir
description: For 20 years now, whatever it was that happened to Lin Biao, former Chinese Defense Minister and the heir apparent to Mao Zedong, has been among the great unresolved mysteries of the Communist world, one that remains shrouded in uncertainty even in these days of remarkable revelations.

Seamen's Bank Seized; Chase Buys Its Deposits
description: The Seamen's Bank for Savings, which was formed in 1839 to encourage thrift among seamen, was put under the control of Federal regulators at the close of business yesterday. All of its deposits were bought by the Chase Manhattan Bank, which will begin operating Seamen's 13 branches today.

title: Apple Computer reports earnings for Qtr to March 30

description: The Bush Administration, which has been trying to avoid becoming embroiled in the struggle between Lithuania and Moscow, said late today that until it could confirm reports that the Kremlin had cut off Soviet oil to Lithuania it would not have any response.

title: Dana Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago first quarter's net included the effect of the $15 million payment received in connection with the termination of a merger agreement. Offsetting the payment were expenses relating to the proposed and an increase in certain reserves. The net effect of these non-recurring items was to increase after-tax income by about $4 million, or 10 cents a share.

title: Portland's Artists Record Its History
description: Starting with little money but grand designs, the local arts commission in 1984 bought a few pieces of art that captured a slice of city life, then tucked them away in storage. Since then, as Portland's landscape has undergone rapid change, artists have recorded the evolution through an expanding art collection known as the Visual Chronicle of Portland.

Borland International reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

description: Following, in the official translation from Lithuanian, are the texts of a letter from the Lithuanian Parliament to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, and of a parliamentary resolution on relations with the Moscow Government:

title: Royal Trustco reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Preferred-share dividends were $21 million for latest period, compared with $16 million for year-ago period. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Ipalco Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Boeing Raises Pilots' Retirement Age
description: In a move likely to rekindle the debate over the age at which airline pilots should be forced from the cockpit, Boeing has agreed to raise the mandatory retirement age of its own test pilots to 63 from 60, provided the pilots undergo rigorous mental and physical tests.

title: Restaurants
description: At times, especially after 9 P.M., China Grill resembles a restaurant in which the adult proprietors have gone home and the teen-agers have taken over. On a recent Thursday evening, the sound system was cranked up until the percussive artillery of a Sting song hammered the towering marble walls; an animated young woman dressed in black hunched over the reservations desk, giggling on the telephone; a busboy dropped a service of coffee all over the Marco Polo inscription on the marble floor, and the bartender was so distracted he asked us for our order three times.

title: Topics of The Times;   Fabulous 42d
description: Yesterday at 9:59 A.M. a New Yorker emerged from the subway at Fifth Avenue and 42d Street to the usual tumult and shouting. Exactly one hour later she returned to the same corner and headed west. This time, she heard her high heels tapping the pavement, in itself a surprise. She could even hear herself think. What her head was saying was, ''This is wonderful.''

title:
VOICES OF THE NEW GENERATION;

Eggs, Twinkies and Ethnic Stereotypes
description: LEAD: Who am I?

title: Topics of The Times;   Oakland: Winning by Losing
description: The city of Oakland, Calif., is a city of sorrow, burdened with high unemployment, inadequate housing and bankrupt schools. Yet it was prepared to shell out $428 million to lure the Los Angeles Raiders professional football team back to the city where the Raiders played until nine years ago, when they moved south.

title: To Celebrate and Protect the Earth
description: NEW YORK CITY is barely a dot on the planet, occupying just 322 square miles of the earth's nearly 197 million, but this weekend it will overflow with outdoor performances, environmental exhibitions, street fairs, nature walks, cleanup projects and other activities on the 20th anniversary of Earth Day.

title: Marshall Field Deal By Dayton
description: In a deal announced today, Marshall Field & Company of Chicago, one of the oldest and grandest names in American retailing, is to be sold for $1.04 billion to another venerable retailer, the Dayton Hudson Corporation of Minneapolis.

title: Fruit of the Loom Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MCA Profit Is Up 15.8%
description: MCA Inc. reported today that its first-quarter earnings increased 15.8 percent to $31.6 million, or 42 cents a share, from $27.3 million, or 37 cents a share, in the year-ago period.

title: Benching Backfires for Capitals' Coach
description: Terry Murray, the coach of the Washington Capitals, criticized John Cunniff of the Devils severely when Cunniff benched his hot goaltender in the fourth game of their Patrick Division semifinal series last week.

title: Review/Film;   A Family That Could Drive You Crazy
description: The terms cult figure and midnight movie were made for Alejandro Jodorowsky. When ''El Topo,'' his 1967 symbolic extravaganza about a Christ figure, mysterious gunmen, Mexican bandits and resurrection, made its way to New York in 1971, it played for months at midnight to fanatical crowds convinced that the director was a visionary. A precursor of ''The Rocky Horror Picture Show'' in social impact if not in style, ''El Topo'' was also praised by critics who saw visual art of the first order in Mr. Jodorowsky's sensory overload of images.

title: Democrats Say A Failed Census Needs a Change
description: A group of Congressional Democrats today declared the first phase of the 1990 census a failure. They called on the Commerce Department to consider using statistical methods to adjust the totals to make up for people not being counted.

title: Chicago Journal;   Art and Ire Mix Again, This Time Over Race
description: It began with the best of intentions. City officials, a major bank and two museums, including the Art Institute of Chicago, would join to sponsor a spring exhibition showcasing the rich ethnic and racial diversity of the city's artists.

title: Komag Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $119,000, or 1 cent a share, from tax loss carryforwards. c-Net loss

Soviet Team Holds Talks With Afghan Rebels
description: Soviet negotiators seeking the release of prisoners of war in Afghanistan met for the first time today with an Afghan guerrilla organization.

title: TV Weekend;   One by Havel and One About Havel
description: Who exactly is this playwright who has become president of Czechoslovakia? In his official appearances, Vaclav Havel is modest and unpretentious to the point of being almost nondescript. This most public of dissident writers is a fiercely private man. But then there are his plays, revealing a supple, playful mind fascinated with paradox and irony. Here is a contemporary head of state whose formative influences range from Samuel Beckett to the Beatles. The man has become a quite extraordinary phenomenon.

title: Alex Brown Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: b-Net loss and included after-tax charge of $6.9 million related to anticipated expenses in eliminating excess office space.

title: New Chief at McCann
description: After a lengthy search, McCann-Erickson has found a leader for its New York office. John Fitzgerald is leaving his position as chairman of Ketchum Advertising U.S.A., the nation's 17th-largest advertising agency, to become vice chairman and chief operating officer of the New York office of McCann, the 13th-largest agency, starting May 16. Mr. Fitzgerald replaces John J. Dooner, who was promoted to president of McCann, North America in late 1988 but has continued to supervise the New York office.

title: Diamond Shamrock Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U S West Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Italian Teams Thrive in Soccer
description: The unprecedented qualification of four Italian soccer teams for the finals of the three European cups has raised fans' hopes for a historic triple triumph in the year the World Cup is held in Italy.

title:
Market Place;

Apparel Stocks Suffer for Fashion
description: LEAD: THIS summer, L.A. Gear Inc. will introduce its much-anticipated line of Michael Jackson athletic shoes, and analysts are already trying to assess whether the new line will top the sales charts as Mr. Jackson's recordings do or will flop.

title: Wilson Mothershead, Banker, 84
description: Wilson Mothershead, retired chairman of the Indiana National Bank and its parent organization, the Indiana National Corporation, died Tuesday at Methodist Hospital here. He was 84 years old and lived in Indianapolis.

title: MNC Financial Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: First quarter results included a $135 million provision for possible credit losses, which is an $83 million increase over the fourth quarte of 1989. Although the underlying earnings of the company remain strong, these results reflect our response to potential real estate loan problems. The company is continuing to move forward with the consolidation of Equitable Bancorp. into MNC Financial, providing the company with the opportunity to recover $40 million in costs in 1990 and $80 million in 1991.

title: SHORTAGE IS FOUND IN SHIP INSPECTORS
description: An internal Coast Guard study undertaken after a series of major oil spills says there is a severe shortage of trained Coast Guard inspectors and ''barely adequate'' inspections of oil tankers.

title: Weyerhaeuser Co. reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
Jule Gordon, 87; Executive Who Led A Cosmetics Group
description: Jule Gordon, a retired executive who founded the National Barber and Beauty Manufacturers Association, died of cancer on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 87 years old.

title: Professors' Theories on Race Stir Turmoil at City College
description: Clashing theories of racial superiority articulated by two tenured professors, one white and one black, have been stirring turmoil at City College and have prompted the college's president to ask for an inquiry into the limits of academic freedom. The inquiry panel will study the professors' conduct as well.

title: Peru Rebels Said to Kill 74 Peasants
description: Opening a new offensive, Shining Path guerrillas killed 74 peasants in two recent incidents, the police said today.

title: Oil Issue: How Much for Reserve?
description: The oil reserve established by the Government 15 years ago as an insurance policy against supply disruptions is coming under new scrutiny as imports rise and the budget-conscious Bush Administration looks for ways to cut costs.

description: b-Included a pretax gain of $3 million, or 2 cents a share, resulting from the early termination of a licensing agreement for the distribution of certain imported pipe tobaccos.

title: Frank DiLuzio, Johnson Interior Aide, 77
description: Frank DiLuzio, a civil engineer who worked on nuclear projects and became an Assistant Secretary of the Interior in the Johnson Administration, died of a heart attack on Sunday at his home in Santa Fe. He was 77 years old.

title: Sen. Nunn On Vision Of Military
description: Following are excerpts from the text of a speech about revising United States military strategy and forces that was delivered on the Senate floor today by Senator Sam Nunn, chairman of the Armed Services Committee:

title: Embassy Hotel Chain's Sale Set
description: Allied-Lyons P.L.C., the British liquor and food company, said today that it was selling its Embassy Hotels chain to Jarvis Hotels Ltd. for $331 million.

title: Gillette Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest quarter's share earnings reflected preferred dividend payments of $14.2 million. There were no such payments in the year-ago first quarter.

title: Businessman Held in Coercing Rivals
description: A New Jersey businessman who sent thousands of youngsters door-to-door selling candy in 30 states for more than two decades was arrested today by F.B.I. agents on charges he used terrorist tactics to eliminate competition.

title: Diner's Journal
description: French-Scandinavian Punsch

title: Article 184290 -- No Title
description: Federal officials proposed a fine of $5.7 million today against the Phillips 66 Company, saying that it had violated numerous safety standards in a fatal explosion last October at a petrochemical plant in Pasadena, Tex., in which 23 workers were killed and 130 hurt.

title: Mocking Peace And Law
description: Why are some people who ordinarily deplore brutal governments reluctant to hold China's tyrants to account? Is it cultural condescension, a feeling that Chinese suffering doesn't matter so much? Or a cynical calculation that one must stay on good terms with the old men clinging to power in that great country?

title: House G.O.P. Chiefs Assail Dole's Stance on Israel
description: House Republican leaders issued a stinging rebuke today to the Senate Republican leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, for comments on relations with Israel.

title: For Eastern's Public, Guarded Optimism
description: Passengers and travel agents responded with cautious optimism to the appointment of a trustee to run Eastern Airlines. But some expressed concern that the naming of Martin R. Shugrue, a former executive at Continental Airlines, might signal the beginning of liquidation for the airline.

title: Coghlan Busy
description: Eamonn Coghlan, the world indoor record-holder in the mile, plans a full weekend. Tomorrow, he will be the master of ceremonies for the Trevira Twosome, a 10-mile couples race in Central Park preceded by a two-mile run featuring Jim Ryun.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums

title: Bankers Trust N.Y.  Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bausch & Lomb reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
In Nigeria, Voiceless Victims of Debt
description: LEAD: Four old people have died since June of last year in the Nigerian village where I was born. Not many people in my village lingered in grief, for these elders had reached the average ripe age of 48.

title: Robert Brown, Professor, 56
description: Robert Brown, a professor of Spanish at Upsala College in East Orange, N.J., died of cancer on April 11 at the Hospital Center at Orange. He was 56 years old and lived in East Orange.

title: Hanna (M.A.) Co.(N) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said latest quarter figures included a charge of $8.6 million related to the bankruptcy filing by a major customer of Hanna's coal affiliate, Colowyo Coal Co.

title: Washington Talk;   First Fisherman Casts An Environmental Line
description: When President-elect Bush visited Islamorada in the Florida Keys after his election, he was just ''goin' fishin'.'' When he returns to Islamorada this weekend, he will be ''enjoying the splendors of our great outdoor heritage.''

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Holders Back Plan At Georgia Gulf
description: Shareholders of the Georgia Gulf Corporation approved a recapitalization of the company, a move management proposed three months ago to ward off a takeover bid by the Texas investor Harold C. Simmons. The company did not release the vote totals, but said if financing is completed as expected the recapitalization will take effect next Friday.

title: Avemco Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago quarter was restated to conform to 1990 presentation.

title: Cavalier Homes Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
Israeli Legislator Who Switched Switches Again
description: The religious-party politician who changed his mind at the last minute last week, depriving the Labor Party of the majority it needed to form a government, changed his mind again tonight and decided to rejoin Labor.

title: First Fidelity Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary tax loss carryforward of $3,150,000.

title: Review/Film;   Cop, Thief and Prostitute in Miami
description: An early scene in ''Miami Blues'' finds three characters sharing a hearty dinner: Susie Waggoner (Jennifer Jason Leigh), a good-hearted and very newly retired prostitute who just loves to cook; Junior Frenger (Alec Baldwin), a dashing, reckless sociopath who has latched onto Susie during the course of a crime spree, and police Detective Hoke Moseley (Fred Ward), who suspects Junior may have killed someone and has stopped by to ask a few questions. Which member of this trio is the most peculiar?

title: Two Banks Report Rise In Earnings
description: The BankAmerica Corporation, the nation's third-largest banking company, said yesterday that its first-quarter profits rose 1.1 percent, to $278 million, from $275 million a year earlier. It attributed the gain to steady growth of its consumer banking business and a rise in fees from arranging corporate financing.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Bush and Mitterrand Are Putting Moscow Ties Ahead of Lithuania
description: President Bush and President Francois Mitterrand indicated today that they put a higher value on improved relations with Moscow than on an immediate resolution of the situation in Lithuania.

title: 27 Philippine Muslims Killed
description: Government forces killed 27 Muslim guerrillas after driving them out of a remote town in the south, the military said today.

title: Westmoreland Coal reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Eastern Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
INSIDE
description: Albania Easing Its Isolation

title: MCA Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $1,054,000, or 1 cent a share. Latest quarter results included a $21,500,000 loss representing the company's equity shares of Cineplex Odeon's 1989 fourth quarter loss which compared to equity earnings from Cineplex of $5,200,000 in the 1989 first quarter.

title: Review/Art;   Nature as Subject and Substance
description: In the visual arts, designated Earth Day observances are few and far between, but no matter. Painters and photographers have long been concerned with nature as a subject and in the case of sculptors and so-called Earth artists, as raw material as well. Walter De Maria's New York Earth Room, for example, is celebrating its 10th anniversary this year. It is not surprising, in short, to find that among the many art exhibitions on view this weekend are several that address the state of the natural world with clarity, intelligence and immediacy. Hiroshi Teshigahara The bamboo glade that Hiroshi Teshigahara has erected within the 65 Thompson Street gallery in SoHo is a beautiful and trenchant reminder of the slippery divisions between nature and culture.

title: Hon Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Textron Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bear Stearns Companies reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: The share earnings are reflected by preferred stock dividend requirements that were deducted from net income in computing share earnings. The share earnings and shares outstanding were adjusted to reflect the 5 percent stock dividend declared yesterday.

title: TV and the Environment
description: TODAY

title: Reviews/Music;   From Arias to Show Tunes With von Stade
description: Trying to grade superstars is unedifying business. So rather than quibble about whether the mezzo-soprano Frederica von Stade qualifies as such, even buttressed by her ''special guests,'' the tenor Jerry Hadley and the bass Samuel Ramey, one will grant that their concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday evening was indeed a superstar event. Billed as ''Flicka and Friends: From Rossini to 'Show Boat,' '' and televised live, it made little sense on any other basis.

title: Pacific Telesis reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
New Soviet Czar
description: Vitaly Smirnov, head of the sports committee of the Russian republic, was elected president of the Soviet National Olympic Committee yesterday. Smirnov, who received 72 of the 110 votes cast, replaces Marat Gramov, who retired from the post he held since 1983.(AP)

title: Press Ban Held Improper
description: An appeals court in Brooklyn ruled yesterday that the judge presiding over the Bensonhurst murder trial should not have excluded reporters from two pretrial proceedings without granting a hearing.

title: Credit Extension Sought by Ames
description: Ames Department Stores Inc., plagued with finanacial problems, is seeking another extension in a credit agreement established when the company bought the Zayre Stores. The company received a waiver of the agreement several weeks ago from its creditors, but the extension expired on Tuesday, said Douglas K. Ewing, an Ames spokesman.

title: Board of Elections Will Investigate G.O.P.
description: The State Board of Elections voted unanimously today to investigate whether the state Republican Party intentionally filed incomplete financial reports to conceal its debt.

title: Group of 7 Asks Money-Laundering Curbs
description: Representatives of the Group of Seven industrial countries proposed a broad set of regulatory and banking reforms today to combat the growing problem of concealing illegal narcotics profits in banks and other financial institutions.

title: Sterling Bancorp (N.Y.) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: McCartney Tickets
description: Tickets for Paul McCartney's July 11 concert at Giants Stadium at the Meadowlands in East Rutherford, N.J., go on sale tomorrow at Ticketmaster locations and on Sunday at noon at the stadium box office. Tickets are $32.50 and are limited to eight per person. Information: 307-7171 or (201) 507-8900.

title: South African Police Kill 4 Demonstrators
description: The South African Police opened fire on demonstrators today, killing four black youths, in a black township about 100 miles south of here, the police and local residents said.

title: Mysterious Death of Owner, Then Arms Company Closes
description: A multinational arms company operated by a Canadian artillery expert who was shot to death at the door of his apartment here four weeks ago announced today that it was going out of business ''for security reasons.''

title: Rose Set to Admit in Court Today That He Filed False Tax Returns
description: Pete Rose, who was suspended from baseball for life eight months ago, has agreed to plead guilty in United States District Court in Cincinnati today to two felony counts of filing false Federal income tax returns, according to court papers released yesterday.

title: Flyrodders Rally Round the Podium
description: If you have toyed with the idea of going after saltwater species such as bluefish and striped bass with a fly rod, one way to help bring that urge to fruition would be to attend the 23d annual rally of the Salty Flyrodders of New York.

title: Inquiry Fails to Learn How Manufacturer Got Secret Report
description: New York City's Investigation Commissioner said yesterday that a five-month inquiry by her agency had failed to find out how a voting machine manufacturer obtained a confidential report that could have helped the company win a $50 million city contract.

title: Champion International reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest common share earnings are after dividends of $6,938,000 on preference stock. There was no allowance necessary for dividends on preference stock a year ago.

title: National Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Corrections
description: An entry in the Executive Changes listing of Business Day on Tuesday misstated the corporate structure of the Leslie Fay Companies. It is a publicly held company, not a subsidiary of Goldome and the New Lefco Corporation; New Lefco is Leslie Fay's former name.

title: Vista Chemical Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Marla Maples Talks on TV But Says Little of Trump
description: Several journalistic organizations reportedly offered large sums of money for an interview with Marla Maples, the model-turned-actress who has been romantically linked with Donald Trump. But Diane Sawyer got the scoop free this week.

title: Reviews/Film;   Visiting Martians Who Read Earthlings' Thoughts, and Reveal Them
description: One of the ideas behind ''Martians Go Home'' is that Mars is inhabited by green-faced creatures who sound like second-rate, mildly obnoxious stand-up comics. Take a screeching comedian like Sam Kinison, tone down his act and paint him green, and you'll have a fair idea of this movie's quaint notion of alien humor.

title: Accounting Group Urged To Admit Non-C.P.A.'s
description: A special committee of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants has urged the organization to admit people other than certified public accountants for the first time.

title: Colgate-Palmolive Up
description: The Colgate-Palmolive Company said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings rose 20.8 percent as its revenue increased 8 percent. The consumer products company said it earned $81.2 million, or $1.16 a share, up from $67.2 million, or 98 cents a share, in the quarter. Revenue totaled $1.3 billion, up from $1.2 billion. The company reported increases in its domestic and international businesses.

title: SCE Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: SCE Corp., the parent of Southern California Edison Co., said the latest quarter increase reflects principally a January regulatory decision that altered its quarterly earnings pattern.

title: Review/Film;   A Mideast Variation Of 'Romeo and Juliet'
description: A film about an Israeli Romeo and an Arab Juliet has to work hard to avoid all those star-crossed cliches, to bring some freshness to those feuding families and foolish prejudices that trample young love. ''Torn Apart'' actually embraces the cliches, and self-destructs in the process. When the Israeli Ben and the Arab Laila swear as adolescents that they will always be friends, a fighter plane is heard overhead: a perfect mark of how sincere, obvious and trite the telling of their story is.

title: How a '74 Fracas Led to a High Court Libel Case
description: Sixteen years have passed since the wrestling match between the Mustangs of Maple Heights High School and the Mentor High Cardinals degenerated into a vicious brawl. But for Michael Milkovich, the melee lives on, though the people grappling now are lawyers, and their arena is the United States Supreme Court.

title: Gander Mountain reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Lockheed Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Standard Federal Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bowater Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
It Is 10 P.M., Parents; How Do You Plead?
description: Patrick Hildreth has always liked that little nightly spot on his local television station: ''It's 10 P.M.,'' the announcer intones. ''Do you know where your kids are?''

title: At the Bar
description: For many years, Simon H. Rifkind spurned all entreaties to tell his life story, except for frequent autobiographical luncheon speeches to Paul, Weiss associates. But recently his law firm, Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, did the next best thing: It published the third - and for now, at least, the last - volume of ''One Man's Word: Selected Works of Simon H. Rifkind.''

title: Evolution in Europe;   TOUGHENING STAND, MOSCOW CUTS BACK GAS FOR LITHUANIA
description: The Kremlin sharply increased its economic sanctions against Lithuania today, slashing supplies of natural gas to the republic only hours after completely halting the flow of crude oil there.

title: Pohl Defends His Plan For Mark Conversion
description: The president of the Bundesbank, Karl Otto Pohl, defended the West German central bank's proposals for monetary union today and lashed out at the nation's political leaders for leading East Germans to expect a one-to-one conversion rate with the West German mark.

title: Ashland Coal Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Associated Banc-Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
George Will Go First, but Where?
description: The National Football League's 55th annual draft of college players on Sunday is ordinary in this respect: speculation about which players are coveted most is answered with more speculation, and questions about which teams will be most active with trades are answered with more questions.

title: Union Carbide Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: First quarter earnings do not include gains that will accrue on completion of the sales of its polysilicon and primary alcohol ethoxylates businesses accounced during the quarter. The company said Brazil's economic program begun in March had little effect on first quarter results but should affect future results negatively when compared to prior periods. Union Carbide said Brazilian operations contributed 7 cents a share in the 1990 first quarter and 5 cents a share in the 1989 quarter. The company said rising costs in Brazil mostly offset higher sales and gross margin there.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: A NEW ERA AT EASTERN

title: Guarding The Family D-Word
description: News item: The proprietors of a bar in Brooklyn, named the Brooklyn Dodger, have been sued by the proprietors of a baseball team in Los Angeles, named the Los Angeles Dodgers. The owner of the baseball team, one Peter O'Malley, claims to have control over the name Brooklyn Dodgers. ''Who is this Dickens?'' O'Malley shrieked. ''Beg your pardon, sir?'' asked his secretary.

title: Review/Art;   Black Images, American History
description: After all is said and done, ''Facing History: The Black Image in American Art 1710-1940,'' which opens today at the Brooklyn Museum, is a triumph. It is a didactic show with an academic feel and many contentious moments, but anyone who is willing to consider it patiently, work by work, is likely to come out of it changed.

title: Colgate-Palmolive Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Evolution in Europe;   The Pope and Prague
description: The Vatican and Czechoslovakia restored diplomatic relations today in a step that expands the Roman Catholic Church's influence in the former Communist-governed countries of Eastern Europe.

title: Review/Music;   Van Buskirk Gives Recital On Fortepiano
description: Not all of New York's big halls are suitable for the soft pipings and gentle scrapings of original instruments. But Merkin Concert Hall, where John Van Buskirk performed a fortepiano recital Wednesday night, is ideal, at least for intimate offerings.

title: Kennametal Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Time Warner's Global Image
description: Once they were two, a staid magazine publisher called Time Inc. and an old-line Hollywood movie studio known as Warner Brothers. Today, they are Time Warner Inc., and in its first corporate image television advertising campaign, the company is presenting itself as the hippest of the hip.

title: Allen Organ Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bucs Get Anderson
description: The San Diego Chargers yesterday traded Gary Anderson, their dissatisfied running back, to the Tampa Bay Buccaneers for a third-round selection in the draft Sunday and a second-or third-round choice in 1991.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY

title: Shearson Lehman Hutton reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included restructuring charge of about $630 million associated with a reduction program and plans to withdraw from or curtail certain business activities, a charge of $157 million from a change in accounting principle, an increase of $50 million to reserves for litigation, an addition of $32 million to its reserve for loan losses, $34 million in losses related to fluctuations in the high-yield bond market, income of $54 million from the settlement of litigation in connection with the suspension of trading in tin by the London Metal Exchange in 1986. c-Included a $35 million pretax writedown of MCorp Securities and a $16 million pretax reversal of reserves that had been established in connection with the tin litigation. The company reported a tax benefit of $1 million for the latest quarter, compared to $8 million a year ago. The company did not recognize any U.S. tax benefits on 1990 first quarter losses because it was unable to carry back net operating losses, or under SFAS 96, to recognize anticipated future tax benefits. While the charges recognized in the quarter did not have an immediate tax benefit, they did result in increased operating loss carryforwards for financial statement purposes available to offset future income.

title: Britain Will Offer Refuge to 50,000 Successful Hong Kong Families
description: Despite a break in the ranks of the Conservatives, the House of Commons tonight approved by a large margin a Government bill that would offer refuge in Britain to 50,000 of the most successful people in Hong Kong and their families before China takes over the Crown colony in 1997.

title: Trustee Has Experience, And Plenty of Problems
description: The appointment of Martin R. Shugrue as the special trustee of Eastern Airlines puts the troubled company in the hands of an experienced airline executive, but analysts doubt that he will be able to attract the thousands of additional passengers that Eastern must have to emerge from bankruptcy as an independent airline.

title: Union Camp Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Latest quarter results included a gain of about 8 cents a share from the sale of land in northeastern Florida to several Florida government agencies.

title: Auctions
description: Rembrandt's ''St. Peter in Prison,'' from 1631, one of the most important early paintings by the artist still in private hands, is to be auctioned at Christie's in New York on May 31. The presale estimate for the painting, from the period before the artist moved from Leyden to Amsterdam, is $10 million to $15 million.

title: Nicholls Leads Ranger 'Gunners' Past Capitals
description: The puck was up for grabs, and as it slid from one zone into another, the suspicion swept Madison Square Garden that the game was there for the taking, too. The score read: Rangers 4, Capitals 3. The clock read: 8:15 in the third period. The race was on.

title: Parker Hannifin Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss from extinguishment of debt of $3,760,000, and included income from discontinued operations of $4,792,000, or 10 cents a share. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $876,000, or 2 cents a share, and $2,923,000, or 6 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The 9-month net also included a gain of $21,698,000, or 44 cents a share, from a change in accounting for overhead recorded in inventory and for long-term research and development.

title: Nepal's New Premier Takes Office
description: Nepal's experiment with multiparty democratic government formally began today on an enthusiastic and emotional note.

title: American Brands Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Alexander & Baldwin reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included $28.4 million, or 62 cents a share, from the sale of an undeveloped property. c-Included $100.7 million, or $2.14 a share, from the sale of the assets of Wailea Development Co.; $19.4 million, or 41 cents a share, from the sale of the company's holdings in Pacific Resources Inc.; and $4.3 million, or 9 cents a share, from commercial-industrial property sales to lessees. In addition, expenses associated with a share repurchase reduced first-quarter 1989 pre-tax income by $8.4 million.

title: Heritage Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The company said the loss in the latest first quarter was primarily due to a $20 million provision to loan loss reserves.

title: S.E.C. AUTHORIZES A FREER MARKET FOR BIG INVESTORS
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today authorized the creation of a new market for stocks and bonds in a move that could increase the dominance of large investment firms in the United States financial markets.

title: Oh, Those Imperial Judges!
description: Three years ago a Federal judge in Kansas City, Mo., stirred howls of protest from conservative critics of the courts. He ordered the school district to raise its tax rate to pay for long-deferred racial desegregation. The Imperial Judiciary had struck again, this time taxing the people, without representation, just to buy fancier schools that would draw white kids back from the suburbs.

title: Lone Star Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Two Utilities Agree to Venture
description: DQE Inc. and General Public Utilities said they had agreed to generate and transmit electricity from western Pennsylvania to eastern Pennsylvania and New Jersey. The companies will build a new 200-mile transmission line, to carry about 1,500 megawatts of power, at a cost estimated at $480 million. General Public Utilities will own two-thirds and DQE one-third of the line, which is expected to be in service in 1996.

title: American Express Has Worst Loss
description: The American Express Company, reflecting record losses at its Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. subsidiary, reported the worst quarterly results in its history yesterday - a loss of $619.8 million in the first quarter, compared with a gain a year earlier of $251.9 million, or 59 cents a share.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-8

title: Roy Schreiber, Entrepreneur, 72
description: Roy Schreiber, an owner of McCreedy & Schreiber, the family-operated Manhattan shoe store founded in 1922, died of Alzheimer's disease Monday at Northport Veterans Hospital on Long Island. He was 72 years old and lived in Manhasset Hills, L.I.

description: To the Editor:

title: Jack Shamash, Leading Importer Of Chinese Textiles, Is Dead at 65
description: Jack Shamash, a major textile importer and business broker, died of a heart attack on Wednesday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. He was 65 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Desoto Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago quarter included $76,000 of income from a minority interest.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allwaste Inc., Houston, an environmental services company, named I. T. Corley executive vice president and chief financial officer. The company named James H. Haddox senior vice president, treasurer and chief accounting officer.

No Support Means No Victory For Perez
description: Pascual Perez allowed himself to smile. He shrugged, he said these things happen, and then he dressed and packed.

title: Drop at Texas Instruments
description: Texas Instruments Inc. today reported an 84.7 percent decline in first-quarter earnings as a sluggish semiconductor market continued to plague the electronics industry.

title: New Push to Expose Drug Profits in Banks
description: Intensifying an effort to uncover illegal narcotics profits, the world's seven leading industrial countries proposed broad regulatory and banking reforms. Their bid was joined by eight other nations, three well-known for bank secrecy -Switzerland, Austria and Luxembourg. Page D1.

title: Firstar Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
First Hawaiian Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Per share earnings reflected 2-for-1 stock dividend paid in January.

description: b-Included special charge of $13.8 million, after tax, for plant closing.

title: Puget Sound Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
76ers Top the Pistons And Take Atlantic Title
description: The Philadelphia 76ers clinched their first Atlantic Division championship since 1983 as Charles Barkley scored 36 points to pace a 107-97 victory tonight over the Detroit Pistons in a game marred by a melee in the closing seconds.

title: Yellow Freight System reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included an accounting adjustment gain of $29,200,000, or $1.01 a share.

title: Chronicle
description: Cookbook writers rarely open restaurants, but MARCELLA HAZAN is putting her money where her mouth is. Mrs. Hazan, whose books on Italian cuisine and cooking classes, held in Italy, influenced a generation of American cooks, is a partner in Veni, Vidi, Vici, which is to open on Monday in the I.B.M. Tower in Atlanta.

title: 9% Decline in Toxic Pollution Is Cited in Survey by E.P.A.
description: The Environmental Protection Agency said today that its second annual inventory of toxic substances released into the environment by industry showed a substantial decline from 1987 to 1988, but it cautioned that the data did not necessarily indicate improved pollution control.

title: Ralston Purina reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Latest quarter results were adversely affected by an after-tax charge of $6.8 million related to a pet food plant closure and the settlement of a patent infringement suit.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We now have a fixed date for the end of the war. It is a reason to celebrate.''

title: Waste Management reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Old Stone Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said net interest income of $24.4 million in this year's first quarter was 17.5 percent lower than last year first quarter on a $400 million smaller asset size and a higher level of nonperforming assets.

title: Prices of Treasury Issues Decline
description: Prices of Treasury securities dipped for the fifth straight session in light trading yesterday, but traders said that after the big losses of the last few days bargain-hunters were creeping back.

title: Theater Led by Dukakis To Close Over Finances
description: The Whole Theater of Montclair, N.J., directed by the actress Olympia Dukakis, will close this month because of financial difficulties.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Kremlin Talks Go On To Overhaul Economy
description: The Gorbachev Government today continued its long and thus far inconclusive deliberations to form a long-term plan for overhauling the stagnant economy.

title: American Medical Buildings reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and a loss of $447,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Knight-Ridder Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $195,000.

title: Commerce Clearing House reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Chronicle
description: LINDA SMITH, the daughter of JOAN KROC, the owner of the San Diego Padres, has filed for divorce from JERRY KAPSTEIN, a former baseball player who is the team's chief executive, according to reports in The San Diego Union and The San Diego Tribune. The couple were married 18 months ago.

title: Martinez's No-Hit Bid Spoiled in 8th
description: Dennis Martinez's bid to pitch baseball's second no-hitter in nine days ended when Darren Daulton doubled with one out in the eighth inning tonight in the Montreal Expos' 5-0 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: Piano Premieres
description: Phoenix, an ensemble specializing in contemporary music, is to present the world premieres of two new piano works by Otto Luening, ''Sonority Form 3'' and ''Chords at Night,'' as part of the group's fifth-anniversary concert tonight at 8 at St. Michael's Episcopal Church, 225 West 99th Street. The pieces are to be played by Barry Salwen, who is also to perform Mr. Luening's Short Sonata No. 3. The program includes David Irving's ''Four Songs,'' Chen Yi's ''Guessing,'' Robert Hughes's ''Herbert's Babies'' and works by Francis Orval, Eve Beglarian, Jerry Weir, Robert Hogenson and Walter Hilse. Admission is $5; free for the elderly. Information: 580-0007 or 787-5904.

title: Across a Sad, Severed Isle, a Wall That Endures
description: It never rivaled Berlin's Checkpoint Charlie for drama or tension. But for the last 16 years, the Ledra Palace Checkpoint here - 200 yards of empty road fenced by mountains of rusty barbed wire - has been the only breach in the hermetic division of Cyprus into a Turkish North and a Greek South resulting from the Turkish invasion of 1974.

title: Books of The Times;   Lyrical Loss and Desolation of Misfits in Chicago

title: Sikma Sinks Knicks With 2 Free Throws
description: A pair of free throws by Jack Sikma, one of the National Basketball Association's best foul shooters, enabled the Milwaukee Bucks to edge the Knicks, 96-95, tonight at the Bradley Center on a night the Knicks learned their first-round playoff opponent would be the Boston Celtics.

title: Our Towns;   Price of Freedom And Budget Cuts: Retraining on L.I.
description: It's painfully easy for Alan Muller to remember the day he lost his job at the Grumman Corporation: Jan. 13, 1989. Friday the 13th.

title: Charles Huggins, 60; Modernized Storage Of Red Blood Cells
description: Dr. Charles Edward Huggins, a physician and cryobiologist who helped develop the process for freezing and reusing red blood cells, died of pancreatic cancer on Wednesday at his home in Boston. He was 60 years old.

description: To the Editor:

title: Reebok International reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said sales in its international business accounted for most of its sales growth; sales outside of the U.S., more than doubled to $116 million from $57 million in the year- ago quarter.

title: Evolution in Europe;   SOLIDARITY MEETS TO PONDER FUTURE
description: With Communism vanquished as a political force in Poland, Lech Walesa and the Solidarity trade union he founded began grappling today with the question of what next, for the union, for the Government it dominates and for Mr. Walesa himself.

title: Cooper Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Outboard Marine reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $1,800,000, or 9 cents a share, due to early extinguishment of debt. c-Net income and included income from discontinued operations of $2,700,000, or 15 cents a share, and $2,500,000, or 14 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Year-ago quarter and 6-month results are restated to reflect sale of Lawn Boy and Cushman units. The company said the loss for 1990 was partially offset by a gain of 9 cents a share from the repurchase of $26 million of long-term debt and a gain of 29 cents a share from adjustments reflecting the settlement of prior years' income tax and related interest liabilities.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Hard-Line Albanians Signal Desire to Resume Ties With U.S. and Soviets
description: The Government of Albania, one of the last hard-line Communist regimes in the world, signaled today that it was willing to take up relations with the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: Unisys Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said that business operations posted operating income of $86 million compared to an operating loss of $37 million in the 1989 first quarter, gross profit margins exceeded the depressed levels of each of the past four quarters, and debt decreased in a quarter when debt typically increases.

title: Nash Finch Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 24
description: Results for 1990 included partial first-quarter results of Timberlake Grocery Co., acquired Jan. 26.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Edge Down on Big Board
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest declined slightly in the month ended April 12, after reaching a record level for the month ended March 15. It fell by 625,328 shares, or about one-tenth of 1 percent.

title: A Giant Artistic Gibe at Jesse Helms
description: One of the sculptures to be seen this weekend has as its target Senator Jesse Helms, whose opposition to Federal financing of artworks he considers obscene has earned him notoriety on the SoHo art scene. The sculpture is ''Helmsboro Country,'' an object in the shape of a monumental flip-top box of cigarettes, which is on view at the John Weber Gallery, 142 Greene Street, through tomorrow.

description: Year-ago per share earnings adjusted to reflect 2-for-1 stock split paid Jan. 30.

Santa Fe Pacific Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included out-of-court settlements of two major lawsuits, the ETSI Coal Slurry Pipeline litigation and the Texas Utilities (TU) Chaco Royalty litigation. The combined settlement of these lawsuits resulted in a net aftertax charge of about $115 million. c-Net income and included $210 million, or $1.32 a share, for adoption of new rules for accounting for income taxes. In addition, the 1989 quarter included a special charge of about $32 million after tax, for a change in the method of estimating personal injury liability at Santa Fe Railway. Operating income of Santa Fe Railway was $66.1 million, compared with a loss of $18 million in the comparable 1989 quarter. Revenues were even with last year's quarter, with carloadings 1 percent above last year and revenue per carload down 1.1 percent. The 1990 quarter includes operating income from settlement of property taxes of $31.3 million. The 1989 quarter included a special charge for changing method of estimating personal injury liability of $52.2 million.

title: Lockheed Posts Gain of 11.3%
description: The Lockheed Corporation said today that first-quarter earnings increased 11.3 percent, to $69 million, or $1.09 a share, from $62 million, or $1.04 a share, in the 1989 period. Sales rose 7.7 percent, to $2.25 billion from $2.09 billion.

title: Saxophone Virtuosos Of Whisper And Howl
description: For 20 years, between 1935 and 1955, the tenor saxophone defined instrumental sensuality. Whether it was Coleman Hawkins playing ''Body and Soul'' in 1939, or Joe Houston honking and screaming through ''Houston's Hot House,'' the tenor saxophone was the lead instrument in popular music. The guitar changed all of that, but by the late 1940's, jazz had begun to splinter anyway, moving from an entertainment music to an art form.

title: Reviews/Music;   The Glory of Wit and a Tune: A Reminder
description: It is worth examining the depths of our nostalgia for such Broadway musicals as Jerome Kern's ''Cat and the Fiddle.'' What is it that we have lost that makes revivals like the current one at Weill Recital Hall happy, even euphoric occasions?

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: The assets of the nation's 508 money market mutual funds decreased by $1.25 billion, to $388.6 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 160 institutional funds decreased by $1.02 billion, to $90.23 billion. The assets of the 246 general-purpose funds were down by $467.30 million, to $133.05 billion. The 102 broker-dealer funds increased by $237.30 million, to $165.32 billion, the institute said.

Georgia Gulf Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Leader of the Wolfpack
description: North Carolina State is expected to name Todd Turner of the University of Connecticut as its new athletic director today, filling a post once held by Jim Valvano, who agreed two weeks ago to leave as basketball coach.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Fred Ward's 'Blues'

title: Corrections
description: A chart on the Health page yesterday about preventive health procedures misstated the recommended frequency of mammograms to detect breast cancer for women over 50. It is one to two years, not every two years.

title: Fama Confessed, a Prisoner Testifies in Bensonhurst Trial
description: A prisoner with a criminal record testified yesterday that Joseph Fama had confessed to killing Yusuf K. Hawkins in a jailhouse conversation last month. ''I shot him. I shot him. I can't bring the guy back,'' Mr. Fama told him, the prisoner said.

title: Cease-Fire Begins in Nicaragua As the Contras Agree to Disarm
description: Leaders of the Sandinista Government, the government-elect and the contra rebel army signed agreements today for an immediate cease-fire in Nicaragua's eight-year civil war and the complete disarming of the rebel army by June 10.

title: Disease Agency Blocks Lab Monkey Imports
description: The Federal Centers for Disease Control has halted imports of research monkeys into the United States until importers present plans to combat a potentially deadly virus.

title: Eastchester Deal
description: The North Fork Bancorporation, based in Mattituck, L.I., reached a definitive agreement to acquire the Eastchester Financial Corporation for $20 a share, or a total of about $79.5 million. Eastchester will become a division of Southold Savings Bank, a savings bank subsidiary of North Fork with eight branches in Suffolk County. North Fork also has a commercial bank with 25 offices on Long Island. Eastchester, based in White Plains, is the parent of the Eastchester Savings Bank, which operates nine branches in Westchester and Rockland Counties. It has been publicly traded only since last April, when its shares were offered to the public at $10 each. Eastchester's stock rose $1.50 yesterday, to $16.25, in over-the-counter trading.

title: Notebook;   Wood Favorites Carry Weight of an Old Rivalry
description: On Aug. 4, 1984, the Whitney Handicap at Saratoga was the scene of one of the most humiliating defeats one horse has ever inflicted upon another.

title: L. R. Chenault, 92, Economics Professor
description: Lawrence R. Chenault, emeritus professor of economics at Hunter College, died Monday at Centre Community Hospital in State College, Pa. He was 92 years old and lived in State College.

title: Oil Prices Stage a Rally; Technical Factors Are Cited
description: Oil prices rebounded yesterday after sinking to a 19-month low on Wednesday. While the prices were bolstered by reports that OPEC was planning an emergency meeting on May 2 to discuss ways to stabilize production and prices, traders attributed most of the advance to technical market factors.

title: Economic Scene;   It's 'Slugflation,' Not 'Stagflation'
description: IS the United States economy on the verge of stagflation, that baleful mixture of stagnation and inflation from which it suffered in the late 1970's and early 1980's?

BRIEFS
description: * CRH P.L.C., Dublin, a building materials group, said its U.S. subsidiary Oldcastle Inc. and Georgia Investors had each acquired a 50 percent interest in the architectural glass division of HGP Industries, a custom glass fabricator, for a total of $100 million.

title: Review/Art;   Sculptural Paintings by Larry Poons
description: It is unlikely that the small retrospective of paintings by Larry Poons at the Salander-O'Reilly Galleries will completely change anyone's opinion about this artist. The works that have been brought together describe what is by now a familiar path to those who have followed Mr. Poons's career.

title: McDonald's Net Up 12%
description: The McDonald's Corporation today reported its 100th straight quarter of record year-to-year increases in net income, earnings per share and revenues since going public in 1965. First-quarter net income climbed 12 percent, to $158 million, from $142 million in the comparable period of 1989.

description: Two rival groups within the Satmar Hasidic movement clashed for more than an hour outside a synagogue in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn last night, the police said.

description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision on Wednesday that Federal judges may order local governments to increase taxes to remedy constitutional violations like school segregation. Justice Byron R. White wrote the majority opinion, Justice Anthony M. Kennedy the dissenting opinion.

description: Pacificare Health Systems Inc. said it would make an offer to acquire Maxicare Health Plans Inc., a health maintenance organization that is preparing to emerge from bankruptcy proceedings.

Anchor also said the extraordinary credits represented utilization of net operating loss carryforwards. description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh acknowledged today that his press secretary had played a role in confirming for a CBS reporter a politically damaging report about Representative William H. Gray 3d that the network later broadcast.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on April 12 about a new development bank for Eastern Europe misidentified the ranking Republican on the Senate Appropriations Committee. He is Mark O. Hatfield of Oregon, not Robert W. Kasten Jr. of Wisconsin.

description: b-Included charges related to Shearson Lehman Hutton of $630 million, after tax, for restructuring and $157 million, after tax, for the cumulative effect of a change in accounting principles. American Express said a first quarter net loss of $915 million reported for Shearson Lehman Hutton represented 100 percent of Shearson's $787 million charges for restructuring and change in accounting and American Express' equity interest in Shearson's remaining $128 million loss after the preferred dividend requirements on Shearson stock. title: Review/Art;   Sculpture in the City, From Blankets to Bronze
description: ONE thing is apparent in the art galleries this weekend: sculpture lives. In fact, it thrives in a state of unusual diversity. This sense of liberation is not particular to the medium; at the moment, many kinds of art are possible. Yet sculpture seems especially open, if only for purely physical reasons: to a greater extent than painting, sculpture can be made out of anything, and its new materials can in turn open up new meanings.

title: Devon's Aztech Chief Will Head New Unit
description: Andrew I. Cramer was a bit beside himself yesterday, trying to figure out how to meld his relatively new Aztech Financial Printers unit with elements of the Chas. P. Young Company, one of the nation's oldest financial printing firms.

title: Gooden Back in the Groove As Mets Defeat the Cubs
description: Baseball historians will find it hard to believe someday, considering that he won 101 games and lost only 41 in the big leagues by the age of 25, but Dwight Gooden went 10 months without winning a game - until yesterday, that is.

title: 6 at St. John's Are Questioned In Sexual Attack
description: Six students at St. John's University in Queens were questioned yesterday by law-enforcement authorities about another student's accusation that she was sexually assaulted at an off-campus residence.

title: Saks Store Closing
description: Saks Fifth Avenue said it would close its store in the West Oaks Mall in Houston on May 1. Earlier this week, Lord & Taylor said that it will close its store in the same mall by April 30. Melvin Jacobs, chairman of Saks Fifth Avenue store, said that in spite of Houston's strengthening economy, the Saks store in West Oaks Mall ''has not met our projections.'' But the Saks store in the Pavilion Saks Fifth Avenue Center in Houston remains ''a strong performer,'' he said, and will continue to operate.

title: Regan Attacks Proposal to Reduce State Payments to Pension Funds
description: Comptroller Edward V. Regan, in an unusually stinging attack, today accused other state leaders of trying to solve their budget problems through irresponsible reductions in payments to public employees' largest retirement funds.

title: Chronicle
description: The mezzo-soprano REGINA RESNIK is going home again, to the New York City Opera, where she sang in 1944, and to the Metropolitan Opera, where she became a star overnight in a storybook debut that year.

title: Donald B. Armstrong Jr., Executive, 74
description: Donald B. Armstrong Jr., retired executive vice president of the J. Walter Thompson advertising agency, died of a malignant melanoma on Tuesday at his home in Porte Vedra Beach, Fla. He was 74 years old and had previously lived in Manhattan and Scarborough, N.Y.

description: Helene Pons, a leading costume designer for almost four decades until her retirement in 1965, died of kidney problems yesterday at a private clinic in Rome. She was within two weeks of her 92d birthday.

The performers include Linda Kent, Laurie Carlos, Gallman's Newark Dance Theater and Penny Arcade. Bill T. Jones and Bertram Ross and John Wallowitch, a cabaret duo, are to be the hosts. Tickets are $15. Information and reservations: 941-5800.
