title: Beth Cherashore Wed To Eric Dean Schlager
description: Beth Madeline Cherashore, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joel S. Cherashore of Upper Montclair, N.J., was married last evening at the Plaza in New York to Eric Dean Schlager, a son of Mr. and Mrs. S. Lawrence Schlager of Chestnut Hill, Mass. Rabbi Steven Kushner officiated.

title: A LIFE A LAUGHS
description: MADCAP

title: A Legacy of Conflict
description: 1947 - When British India is partitioned into India and Pakistan, a Muslim revolt backed by tribesmen from Pakistan flares up against the maharaja governing the state of Jammu and Kashmir, or simply Kashmir. Indian forces are dispatched to suppress the uprising and Pakistan sends troops to back the rebels.

title: Style Makers;   Eli Noyes and Kit Laybourne, Children's Broadcasters
description: It is not easy for Eli Noyes and Kit Laybourne, the director and the producer of ''Eureeka's Castle,'' a new cable television show for children, to escape the influence of Jim Henson, the originator of the Muppets.

title: Robert Harris, Pianist, 74
description: Robert Harris, a pianist who taught at The Juilliard School for 24 years, died of a stroke on Tuesday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

Don't Roll Back Human Rights
description: LEAD: IT is sadly ironic that in the same year that President Bush spoke so eloquently against bigotry in his State of the Union address, a debate is being waged in Suffolk County to abolish the Human Rights Commission.

title: Baymen Optimistic on Scallop Yield
description: LEAD: HAS the tide turned on the brown tide? East End baymen and biologists are cautiously optimistic that it has, and that there will be a scallop harvest in September and a strong commercial catch a year later.

title: THE BIG GIVEAWAY
description: CITY ON THE ROCKS

title: Outdoors;   Proposal Offered On Striped Bass
description: New York State's proposal to allow resumption of commercial fishing for striped bass in its marine waters is a neat balancing act.

title: Jane Kirby and George Gager Married
description: Jane Crocker Kirby a daughter of Gerard L. Kirby of Boston and the late Gertrude M. Duffy, and George Webb Gager, a son of Alice G. Goodrich of New London, Conn., and the late Dr. John Jay Gager, were married yesterday at the Harkness Chapel at Connecticut College in New London by the Rev. James Helton, a priest of the Anglican-Catholic communion.

title: Eau-de-Vie, the Spirit of Alsace
description: LEAD: FORESTS, fruit orchards and quaint half-timbered mountain villages make up the landscape of the Vosges Mountains in northeast France. This is Alsace, the garden of France, a land redolent of pine, wood fires, mushrooms and wildflowers. In the small hidden valleys of the Vosges, people have long distilled clear fruit brandies called eaux-de-vie, or waters of life, to give warmth through the long winters, when many villages are isolated.

title: Fashion: On The Street;   Hemlines Rise, Saluting Spring and Couture
description: For those who ponder the question of hemlines, the short answer appears to be the best one. At this very minute, in the more fashionable quarters of this fashion-conscious city, above-the-knee skirts are de rigueur.

title: STREETSCAPES: The New York State Pavilion;   A Windswept, Gaudy Ghost in Search of a New Role
description: BY now the New York State Pavilion is just part of the landscape, passed by millions on the Grand Central Parkway in Flushing, Queens, a dim memory even for those who went to the 1964 World's Fair. The gaudy, open building, one of the best works of architecture at the fair, narrowly escaped demolition. Although a theater occupies part of it, the overall structure is a windswept elegy and continues to elude a successful reuse.

title: Off-Season Travel
description: To the Editor: My father and I recently returned from a 10-day trip to Italy. Though I had spent summers in Europe, this was my first time there in the winter. Even before we left the United States, it was apparent that there were advantages to traveling in the off-season. Aided by a wily travel agent, my father booked passage for us three days before our departure on British Airways, taking advantage of two separate specials. The first was New York-London, whose fare British Airways was matching to its competitors, and the second was a reduced intra-European fare for London-Rome. The resulting fare of approximately one third the usual price more than compensated for the four-hour layover at Heathrow. Through EuroCar's New York office my father reserved a car for $20 a day. Though admittedly it was only an upgraded Fiat, the mileage was unlimited and insurance was provided by Visa.

title: Viola Sputters But Is 3-0
description: In a messy early season that has been fraught with shoddy defense, lack of timely hitting and days spent in last place, the one thing the Mets have been able to rely on is the steady pitching of Frank Viola.

title: Garbo: Illusion Was All
description: It began as a temporary retirement from the screen in 1941 after the critical and box-office failure of ''Two Faced Woman.'' As the years went on, and as Greta Garbo continued to turn down roles, the temporary retirement gradually eased into something permanent, though it could never be called permanent with certainty. She might change her mind at any minute. As it turned out, Garbo was enough of a strategist finally to realize that the accumulated anticipation could never be satisfied by anything she might do as a comeback.

title: ALMODOVAR ON THE VERGE
description: WALL OR NO WALL, FEBRUARY IN BERLIN means Film Festival. In front of the Zoo Palast Theater, near the center of the western part of the city, a giant cube has been erected, thrusting 30 feet into the air and painted on all four sides with scenes from ''Atame!'' (in English, ''Tie Me Up! Tie Me Down!''), the official Spanish entry in the festival competition and the eighth film by the director Pedro Almodovar. Though billboards advertising movies abound this week in Berlin, nothing approaches the cube for massiveness or provocation. On one side a gargantuan masked bodybuilder wearing a leather doublet stares out in challenge; on another a battered young man holds his hand over the mouth of a bewildered young woman; on still another the same young woman, dressed in a slight, clingy shift, poses sensuously, catlike, on all fours.

title: William Levine and Susan Diker Wed
description: Susan Helen Diker, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bertram J. Diker of New York, and William Mark Levine, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mervyn M. Levine of Winnipeg, Canada, were married last evening at the Harmonie Club in New York. Rabbi David M. Posner officiated.

title: Housing Remedy Reviewed by Backer
description: I read with great interest, ''A New Critique of Homeless Policy'' (April 1) and agree that the county is wasting millions of dollars keeping people homeless.

title: NONFICTION
description: WHAT HAPPENED TO THEIR KIDS? Children of the Rich and Famous. By Malcolm Forbes with Jeff Bloch. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) What did happen to Charles Boyer's son? Or, for that matter, Galileo's daughter? ''What Happened to Their Kids?'' will take you down the littered trail of the offspring of the powerful, rich and famous. Though some names in this book by Malcolm Forbes and Jeff Bloch, who also wrote ''They Went That-a-way,'' elicit sighs of ''Do we really want to hear about them again?'' - J. Paul Getty's grandson, for example - the lesser-knowns will pique your interest. There are few winners. Albert Einstein's younger son suffered a serious breakdown. A Vanderbilt son committed suicide, as did Gregory Peck's eldest son. Eugene O'Neill's boys, heavy drinkers, could have won Pulitzer Prizes for despair: Eugene Jr. slashed himself in a bathtub, stumbled down the stairs and died; Shane leaped to his death from a fourth-floor window. Daughters fared slightly better. Mostly they drifted into oblivion or went crazy, as did Victor Hugo's daughter Adele, and Ada Byron, the child of Lord Byron, who showed genius at mathematics only to end up as a compulsive gambler. Some children just take advantage of their je ne sais quois circumstances. Take Tommy Manville, the son of a millionaire industrialist, who married 13 times. Or the Hearst boys, who, given lucrative jobs in their father's empire, had almost nothing to do. And finally, to the reader's enormous relief, there are, to name a couple, those who triumphed: Jean Renoir the film maker, son of Pierre-Auguste, and Al Capone Jr., who ran a restaurant with his mother. You never know.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In: Leonia
description: LEAD: ON a recent day, even before the early morning chill had lifted, downtown Leonia was already humming. Residents were setting out on daily chores, shop owners were getting ready to open and small groups of commuters waited on corners for buses.

title: RESPONSES TO OPINION: HOW BEST TO HEAL PSYCHIC WOUNDS?
description: At the risk of sounding like the defender of the sacred text, I have to disagree with Howard Schneider. In our decidedly complex world of signs, seemingly without referents, some look backward to the traditional folk wisdom of the past.

title: THE GUIDE
description: TO EARTH

title: Pastimes;   Coins
description: When a Manhattan business man Haig Manoogian withdrew money from a cash machine, he was surprised to see several old notes in his stack of bills. Amid the silver certificates was a $10 National Currency Note, a half-century old.

title: Ann Hunt Is Married
description: At St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Albany, Ann Frances Hunt, a daughter of Mary D. Hunt of Albany and the late William E. Hunt, was married yesterday to Dennis Patrick Leddy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo P. Leddy of Spring Lake, N.J. Msgr. Joseph P. Conway officiated. Mrs. Leddy is a graduate of McGill University. The bridegroom, an institutional sales trader at Morgan Stanley & Company in New York, graduated from Ursinus College.

description: For the Rangers, the lapses, frequent and frightening during the first couple of weeks of the playoffs, had been lost in the bursts of offense that had almost invariably followed and the euphoria that had consequently reigned.

title: FAMILY OF STEICHEN BATTLES ART MUSEUM OVER A MATISSE WORK
description: As photographer, administrator and benefactor, Edward Steichen was a pillar of the Museum of Modern Art. But now, the late photographer's heirs are wrestling with the museum over a painting by Henri Matisse which, they contend, belongs to Steichen's 6-year-old great-granddaughter.

title: A MORE PERFECT UNION
description: THE VERY IDEA OF a face lift goes against the grain of most architects' thinking. Their instincts lean much more toward all-out plastic surgery, reshaping the body to take on a whole different cast. That is, if they are willing to keep the old body at all. Throwing it out and starting from scratch probably gets closer to their way of doing things.

title: An Elmont Seamstress Is the Betsy Ross of Horse Racing
description: WHEN the gate clangs open for the first race of the new Belmont season on May 9 and the horses explode down the track, no one will be straining harder to see the colors and patterns worn by the jockeys than Antoinette Brocklebank.

description: BECAUSE IT IS BITTER, AND BECAUSE IT IS MY HEART

title: At $250,000, It Flushes Up and It Could Save Money
description: In the dispatchers' office at the Chambers Street station on the IRT, workers are putting the finishing touches on $250,000 worth of equipment that is expected to save the Transit Authority $50,000 a year and make the lives of transit workers a lot easier.

title: SCHUYLERVILLE STANDS STILL
description: I knew Schuylerville when I was a teen-ager, during the war years. It was a mill town where everyone who wanted to could find work. After the war, many people left Schuylerville for better jobs and pay.

title: BLACK STUDIES' NEW STAR
description: As a recent Ph.D. recipient, I was dismayed by the uncritical attitude taken toward the academic ''star'' system in your article. The bidding war for black scholars that Mr. Begley describes so cheerfully is one part of an oppressive system that also exploits the majority of workers who are not stars. The same institutions that hire stars often claim to have no money in their budgets to include part-time faculty members in a health plan, to pay clerical workers decent salaries or benefits; to recruit and support minority-group graduate students or to pay junior faculty members a salary that reflects the work they do.

title: 200-Bed Nursing Home Plan May Be Scrapped
description: LEAD: SINCE 1983, St. Charles Hospital and Mather Memorial Hospital, both in Port Jefferson, have been working together to build a 200-bed nursing home. Seven years and $700,000 later, the project, having encountered one obstacle after another, may be abandoned.

title: Question Of the Week;   Who Is The M.V.P. In the N.B.A.?
description: This year, more than any in memory, the award should be m.v.p.'s: most valuable players. Barkley, Jordan, Johnson, Ewing and Malone. Each deserves a piece. Now, that is a dream m.v.t.: most valuable team.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester;   A Shopping Mall Opens East of Hartford
description: THE malling of Connecticut in the last 20 years has produced 19 enclosed regional shopping centers. Danbury Fair Mall, with 1.2 million square feet, is the largest, and some are as small as 160,000 square feet. Half a dozen new ones are proposed but their developers have been unable to find anchor stores or get zoning approval.

title: Patricia Hohn to Wed Bradley Brehm; Nancy Hohn to Marry Frank Frehill
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harry Hohn of Scarsdale, N.Y., and New York have announced the engagement of two of their daughters. Patricia La Rosa Hohn is the fiancee of Bradley L. Brehm, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth E. Brehm of Coram, L.I. Nancy La Rosa Hohn is engaged to Lloyd Frank Frehill, a son of Mrs. Clyde Merry of Sherman Station, Me.

title: In Brazil: Miners vs. Indians
description: Symbolic of the economic and environmental problems confronting Brazil, the airstrip shown at left is among the 100 or so clandestine landing strips in the northern state of Roraima ordered destroyed late last month by the newly inaugurated President, Fernando Collor de Mello. The strips, constructed by miners, provide access to remote Amazon regions that have yielded an estimated $1 billion worth of gold since 1987. However, the miners have also been deemed responsible for severe environmental damage and the decimation of the indigenous Indians. More than half of the 9,000 surviving members of the Stone Age Yanomami tribe have contracted diseases from contact with miners in the last three years. About 1,000 have died.

title: Shari Bunks Is Engaged
description: The May wedding plans of Shari Lynn Bunks and Dr. Jay D. Geller, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur Geller of Morristown, N.J., have been announced by Miss Bunks's mother, Rae Bunks of Cherry Hill, N.J. Ms. Bunks, 27 years old, is also a daughter of the late Frank Bunks. She is an associate in the law firm of Katzenbach, Gildea & Rudner in Lawrenceville, N.J. She is a graduate of Syracuse University and the Rutgers University School of Law. Mr. Geller, 29, is a dermatology resident at Wayne State University. He graduated magna cum laude from Dartmouth College and received his M.D. from the Dartmouth Medical School.

title: THE LAST AGE OF HEROES
description: PIVOTAL DECADES

title: Style Makers;   John Cross, Whittler
description: Over the years, John Cross has gotten used to people coming up to him on the street or in Central Park. ''That's because I literally do it all the time,'' said the 54-year-old advertising writer whose passion and hobby is the traditional art of whittling.

title: SCHUYLERVILLE STANDS STILL
description: It is not that what James Howard Kunstler says about Schuylerville, N.Y., is untrue; rather, it is incomplete (''Schuylerville Stands Still,'' March 25). What he seems to miss is that Schuylerville's very strength is its maintenance of a sense of community amid what he calls ''rot and disrepair.'' He writes as if Walt Disney World was the mean for an American community - new sidewalks, every storefront brimming with goods, shiny-faced children holding mommy's and daddy's hands, etc. For good or ill, a community must find room in its streets and in its heart for single parents, pregnant teen-agers, discouraged, homeless, angry and inefficient neighbors.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our 50-year-old house has a brick chimney that goes up through the attic, and the bricks are exposed inside the attic. There are four flues inside the chimney, and the bricks in the attic have developed a white, flaky material that my husband calls bloom. There is also a white powder on top of some items stored next to the chimney. The chimney has no cover or cap. What is causing this bloom?

title: High School League Has Boys Jumping for Volleyball
description: LEAD: AFTER watching the United States men's volleyball team win a gold medal at the 1988 Olympics, Ed Bengermino, the coach of the girls' volleyball team at Fairfield High School, wondered why local high schools had no boys' teams in the sport. Then he wondered how he could change the situation.

title: HOLMAN'S NEAR MISS
description: Trailing the Seattle Mariners by six runs was bad enough; being held hitless and runless on their own field was even worse. But to the world champion Oakland A's on Friday night, being on the imperfect side of a perfect game was simply intolerable.

description: MONDAY: The United Nations General Assembly convenes a special session on promoting economic growth in developing nations. Martin R. Shugrue is scheduled to discuss his plans as special trustee of Eastern Airlines.

description: I'M NEVER SURE HOW I get roped into it but several times a year, I find myself engaged in what Gloria Steinem calls the world's second oldest profession: fund raising.

title: A Monumental Day
description: On Earth Day 1970, Americans rose up against what they had done to foul the environment. That wave of dismay drove Congress to decree a substantial cleanup of air and water. Twenty years later, on Earth Day 1990, public concern about the environment is again at a peak. And this time the wave washes far beyond American shores. Whether the issue is global warming or ozone depletion, what happens in Eastern Europe or China matters as much as what happens here.

title: Miss Mengarelli Weds E. R. Neaher Jr.
description: Francesca Mengarelli and Edward R. Neaher Jr. were married yesterday at the Santa Agnese in Agone Roman Catholic Church in Rome by the Rev. James J. Foley.

description: The Oregon Lottery's first experiment with betting on professional sports ends this weekend to mixed reviews.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: A. & S. Plaza;   Launching a 4-Deck Flagship for Children's Wear
description: AS busy as the new A. & S. Plaza on Greeley Square appears to be, the greatest amount of buying and selling that goes on around its vast atrium may eventually be invisible to the public.

title: Correction
description: A report on the Headliners page last Sunday about historians' views of Charles de Gaulle misstated the year of de Gaulle's resignation as President of France. It was 1969, not 1968.

Rapid Growth Near Chicago
description: LEAD: WITH 11 subdivisions under way and four awaiting approvals, this northeastern Illinois village has become one of the fastest growing in greater Chicago.

description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or return unpublished letters.

title: In the Running for School Boards
description: LEAD: WILLIAM COOK, 32 years old, a merchandising manager; Christopher T. Dawes, 18, a high school senior; Shirley Knight, 68, a retired college administrator, and Janice Lightner, 40, a teacher, have something in common: they want to serve on their school boards.

title: David Smith's Nudes Come Out of Hiding
description: It is rare to encounter an exhibition of a major artist as weird and challenging as ''David Smith - Nudes'' (at the Knoedler Gallery). Although Smith worked from the female nude all through his 40-year career, his sustained involvement with one of the oldest and most traditional artistic motifs has rarely been addressed by scholars and critics. How could such a revered, card-carrying, self-respecting modernist, whose abstract sculpture informed the radical achievements of Carl Andre, Donald Judd, Richard Serra and so many others, refuse to renounce figurative art?

title: Ann Goodman and Joel H. Weinstein Are Married
description: Ann Josephine Goodman, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ernest J. Goodman of Oneonta, N.Y., was married there last evening at Cathedral Farms to Joel Henry Weinstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Weinstein of West Islip, L.I. Rabbi Max Rothschild performed the ceremony.

title: U.N. Says Ethiopia Thwarts Delivery of Food Aid
description: As the threat of famine grows in Ethiopia, the delivery of emergency supplies of food is being blocked by the refusal of President Mengistu Haile Mariam to guarantee the safety of relief workers using the Red Sea port of Massawa, United Nations officials and Western diplomats say.

title: CART Puts an Outsider at the Wheel
description: Championship Auto Racing Teams, the INDY-car sanctioning group, went outside the racing community to find its new chairman of the board, A. William Stokkan. And if CART's board of directors was looking to shake up the way racing does business, Stokkan seems ready to help.

title: Canseco Sees Racism
description: There are a couple of theories among Oakland players as to why the National League champion San Francisco Giants gave a four-year, multimillion-dollar contract to their slugger, Will Clark, after the 1989 season, while the World Series champion Athletics limited their slugger, Jose Canseco, to a one-year contract.

title: Question Of the Week;   Who Is The M.V.P. In the N.B.A.?
description: Magic Johnson is the most valuable player in the N.B.A. As of April 13, Johnson had 10 triple-doubles, the Lakers have the best record in the N.B.A., and after their victory of April 15, the Lakers have won their ninth straight division title. Magic Johnson is simply the best.

title: Miss Dorsey Wed In Binghamton
description: Adrienne Celeste Dorsey and Derek Chandler Wheeler were married yesterday at Trinity Memorial Episcopal Church in Binghamton, N.Y., by the Rev. H. Arthur Doersam. The bride is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Beverly R. Dorsey of Binghamton. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Wheeler of Hempstead, L.I.

title: Review/Theater;   An Officer's Life-or-Death Dilemma
description: Heinrich von Kleist, a Prussian officer who traded his sword for a pen and became a major light of German Romanticism, could never resolve his ambivalent feelings toward the Prussian fatherland. When he resigned his commission, he wrote a friend that while in uniform he was ''always in doubt whether to act as an officer or a human being.''

title: Galley's Goal Gives Boston a 2-0 Lead
description: Garry Galley's goal 3 minutes 42 seconds into overtime tonight gave the Boston Bruins a 5-4 come-from-behind victory over the Montreal Canadiens and a two-game lead in the Adams Division finals.

title: How the First Round Might Go
description: A projected first round as selected by Thomas George of The Times. There are 25 selections instead of 28 because Dallas, Phoenix and Cleveland lost theirs in the supplemental draft.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Real Estate section last Sunday about Larchmont misstated the party affiliation of Mayor Miriam Curnin. She is a Democrat.

title: Renamed Museum Weighs Anchor as It Looks Out to Sea
description: THE Museum of Art, Science and Industry in Bridgeport has been born again as the Discovery Museum, Connecticut's Adventure in Art and Science. The new name should not discourage the art public from checking out the show that coincides with its announcement. The show, ''Sounding the Depths: 150 Years of American Seascape,'' was organized for the American Federation of the Arts by Harold B. Nelson, who is director of the Long Beach (Calif.) Museum. (The time is not far off when reviews will consist entirely of titles.) Unlike the marine exhibition last winter at the Whitney Museum's branch in Stamford, the present survey includes contemporary images. And though these are not of the kind favored by the Maritime Museum in Mystic, they are disconcerting.

title: Question Of the Week;   Who Is The M.V.P. In the N.B.A.?
description: Charles Barkley. The Round Mound has proved that he is no longer simply a rebounding machine. While he is currently third in the league on the boards (and first on the offensive end of the court), Charles is also sixth in scoring, second in field goal percentage, and 13th in steals. More importantly, Charles's havoc and leadership have made the 76ers serious contenders for the N.B.A. championship.

title: College Teams And Economics
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The Joy of Five Characters All Talking at Once
description: For years people told the novelist Jose Yglesias that he ought to write a play because his dialogue was so good. He even thought like a dramatist: ideas would come to him in the voices and accents of well-defined characters. This writer of Spanish and Cuban descent would find himself thinking, for example, in the voice of a snobbish New England matron.

title: From Bar Mitzvah Gifts, Posters
description: LEAD: BECAUSE of the contribution of his bar mitzvah money, Peter Bradley Freund, a 13-year-old from Pound Ridge, has made it possible for Iona College in New Rochelle and the Rippowam-Cisqua School in Bedford to receive and exhibit a poster set: ''The Courage to Remember: The Holocaust, 1933-1945.''

title: Style Makers;   Carol Goldman, Jewelry Designer
description: Carol Goldman comes from a family of big women and, she said, since childhood she has known that ''big did not mean that you could not dress well and look well.''

title: Japanese Film Series Goes Behind the Scenes
description: LEAD: A NEW documentary film series, ''The Arts and Cultures of Japan,'' will be offered by the Greenburgh Arts and Culture Committee as a tribute to David Wells MacEachron, a longtime resident of Hastings-on-Hudson and former president of the Japan Society, based in Manhattan.

title: Later Picks May Be Crucial Ones for Jets
description: The Jets' break with a hidebound tradition that brought little more than mediocrity in the 1980's could be symbolized by their actions in today's draft.

title: Pickfair Torn Down
description: Pickfair, the legendary estate of the Hollywood film stars Mary Pickford and Douglas Fairbanks, has been razed by Pia Zadora, the actress and singer, and her husband, the industrialist Meshulam Riklis. They plan to build a Venetian-style palazzo on the site.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: MARKING EARTH DAY

title: Campus Life: S.M.U.;   After Graduation, Class Still Keeps Neighbors Awake
description: A farewell gift from the Southern Methodist University Class of 1989 has recently begun to keep its neighbors awake at night.

title: A JOURNEY AROUND THE RIM
description: PACIFIC DESTINY

title: Woman Finds Grandson, 10, Shot to Death in the Bronx
description: A 10-year-old boy was pronounced dead at Lincoln Hospital yesterday after his grandmother found him in their Bronx apartment with a bullet wound in his side, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Travel Advisory column on April 1 misstated the date of the next total eclipse of the sun. It is July 22.

title: Daphne Davison Ross to Wed John James Dalton
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jeremiah K. Ross Jr. of New York have announced June wedding plans for their daughter, Daphne Davison Ross, and John James Dalton, a son of Mr. and Mrs. A. C. Dalton of Plandome, L.I.

title: Does Carter Expect More From Israel and Less From the Arabs?;   Bush Push
description: To the Editor:

title: East Bloc's Admirers in Africa Draw Line at Multiparty Politics
description: African leaders who long admired Eastern Europe, accepted its aid and copied its political structures are vigorously resisting suggestions that multiparty democracy of the kind taking root in places like Poland and Hungary has any application at home.

title: Neutrality Has Its Dangers in the Blood Feuds of a South African Province
description: Lillian Gebashe rummaged through the few possessions salvaged from her fire-gutted home in the black township of Imbali and lovingly held up a charred china cup given her by a son of the white family she had served as a maid.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Rev. Thaddeus Horgan, Franciscan, Dies at 54
description: The Rev. Thaddeus Horgan, associate director of the Secretariat for Ecumenical and Interreligious Affairs of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops, died on Thursday at St. Mary's Hospital in Waterbury, Conn., after suffering a heart attack. He was 54 years old and lived in Washington.

title: Susan Steinberg Is Married
description: Susan Gail Steinberg, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Steinberg of New York, was married last evening to Paul Saltzman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ellis Saltzman of Brooklyn, at the Metropolis Country Club in White Plains. Rabbi Paul Siegel officiated. Mrs. Saltzman, 27 years old and a graduate of American University, is an account executive at the Image Bank photography archive in New York. The bridegroom, 29, is an assistant general counsel at Kidder, Peabody & Company in New York. He graduated from Clark University and the Boston University School of Law.

title:
IN SHORT;

FICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Recent Sales
description: Howell $168,900

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Campus Life pages on April 8 about coeducational fraternities misidentified a sorority at Bucknell University in Lewisburg, Pa., that is considering membership for men. It is Beta Gamma.

title: Serbian Police Use Tear Gas To Disperse Albanian Protest
description: The police fired tear gas to disperse ethnic Albanian youths throwing stones after a soccer match in Kosovo province today, the Yugoslav press agency said.

title: Lucy Reich Married to Bruce W. Hurd
description: Lucy Elizabeth Reich, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert M. Reich of Savannah, Ga., was married yesterday in New Canaan, Conn., to Bruce Ward Hurd, a son of Isabel W. Hertz of Red Bank, N.J., and the late Richard M. Hurd 3d. The Rev. Charles Crawford Smith performed the ceremony at the Congregational Church.

title: They Need Our Know-How, Not Our Bucks
description: To the Editor:

title: Hungarians in Romania Meet Amid Tensions
description: The police patrolled this Transylvanian town amid ethnic tensions today as an opposition party promoting the rights of the Hungarian minority opened a two-day congress.

title: Mike Milken And Market Perversity
description: Ah, the perversity of Wall Street.

title: LOVE AND RESENTMENT
description: It sounds to me as if Barbara Bick and her daughter Kathy have not worked out the problems that fuel Kathy's illness (Hers: ''Two Weeks of Love and Resentment,'' March 25). I believe that both women could do much better. I would say to them, don't give up, go to another doctor, find the right medication and continue to work on the illness together.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Hopkinton, R.I.;

Fight Over Resort
description: LEAD: RESIDENTS of this rural community near the Connecticut border are divided over a proposal by a local developer for Brae Bern, a $55 million development that would be one of the largest golf resort and housing projects in the Northeast.

title: POSTINGS: Called by Cuomo;   Parley's Agenda: Low-Cost Housing
description: Innovative strategies to produce more low-cost housing will be discussed by 350 New York State leaders, including Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, at a daylong conference Thursday at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan.

title: Love With Improper Strangers
description: When Bacall first laid her sultry eyes on Bogart in ''To Have and Have Not,'' appearing in the doorway of his hotel room and wondering, ''Anybody got a match?,'' the sparks set off one of Hollywood's legendary romances, on and off screen.

title: Senior Golfers Are Stealing the Thunder
description: While driving to a local golf course last weekend, I wondered which of the two professional golf matches being televised that afternoon would occupy the large-screen television in the clubhouse. The usual crew of kibitzers would be forced to select between a regular PGA Tour event with Greg Norman and the two-time Masters champion Nick Faldo in contention, and a Senior PGA Tour contest matching Jack Nicklaus against Lee Trevino and Gary Player.

title: Campus Life: Texas;   8 Weeks in France Give Students Insights Into War
description: Although Tina LeBlanc had taken two history courses at the University of Texas, she had little knowledge of World War II.

title: Schools Should Ban Smoking
description: Long Island - Nassau and Suffolk Counties - has every right to be proud of its leadership role in limiting and even barring, smoking from most public areas.

title: Sally J. Reich Becomes the Bride of Donald Kress
description: Sally J. Reich, a daughter of Maude Reich of Westport, Conn., and the late Samuel Reich, was married yesterday to Donald Kress, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John W. Kress. The Rev. Raymond Kress, the bridegroom's twin brother, and the Rev. Stephen Rozzelle officiated at St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Basking Ridge, N.J.

title: Sex, Lies And Now Videotape
description: ''The film's intimate scale translates very well on tape,'' says the director Steven Soderbergh of his highly acclaimed ''Sex, Lies and Videotape,'' which will be released on Wednesday by RCA/Columbia (see review at left). But does he think his movie will be as successful on videotape as it was on film in theaters? ''It could go either way,'' Mr. Soderbergh says. ''I like the idea of somebody sitting down alone in quiet circumstances and watching it. But I don't know whether it's the kind of film that can withstand a lot of the extraneous activity that goes on when people watch tapes. You get up to do something else and you miss a lot.''

title: Race Track's Manure Is a Salable Product
description: LEAD: THE Meadowlands Racetrack has found an ingenious use for its horse manure: selling it. What's more, said John Chevalier, director of backstretch operations at the track, it's in great demand. Whenever a contract is awarded for hauling it away, several companies bid on it.

title: A Concert to Celebrate a Celebrated Composer
description: IT would be difficult to overestimate the achievements of the composer William Schuman of Greenwich.

title: HOROWITZ'S PARTING GIFT: CHARMING NOVELTIES
description: ''Horowitz: The Last Recording.'' How sad. It sends a pang through you. It is the end of a recording career that started in 1928, with 78-rpm disks, went on to LP, stereo and then CD. When Vladimir Horowitz died last November, he still had a few things in the ''icebox,'' and here they are (Sony/CBS 45818; all three formats).

title: Hopes Are Still Keen On Release of Hostage
description: A Syrian official said he expected an American hostage to be released today to the United States Embassy, but the embassy had no comment. Iran and the United States also raised hopes that a hostage would be released in the next few days, despite the absence of any evidence of progress in that direction.

title: A Tireless Collector's Gift to Vermont
description: IN the middle of 45 verdant acres in Vermont, a stolid lighthouse keeps watch over an old paddle wheeler moored on a sea of grass. The only water in sight fills a small pond excavated to give a splash of plausibility to the covered bridge that spans it. How did this 220-foot-long, 900-ton steamboat get beached like an abashed whale two miles from its former home on Lake Champlain? How was the 1871 lighthouse lifted from its original shoals on a treacherous reef? Laboriously - just as the 50-ton slate jailhouse was inched on a three-day journey from its site 64 miles away, and as the enormous silo of a great round barn was flown, suspended from a helicopter, clear across the state.

title: FUNNY,IT DOESN'T LOOK LIKE GLASS
description: Gloriously colored Chinese glass artifacts, as transparent as air or as opaque as clay, are exhibited in the first comprehensive survey of the craft at the China Institute in America, 125 East 65th Street. The 68 vessels and jewelry items in ''Clear as Crystal, Red as Flame: Later Chinese Glass'' reveal how deftly artisans imitated ceramics and stones in objects fashioned from the 14th to the 19th centuries. The show remains through June 16.

title: SURVIVING HISTORY
description: In her article ''Surviving History'' (March 25), Mary Gordon asserts that ''20th-century Italian literature is notably short on women.'' Nothing could be further from the truth.

title: Spring Salads With Some Less-Common Greens
description: THE salad options are more varied than ever. Not long ago, all one could expect to find in the salad-greens department of a produce stand or supermarket was iceberg, Romaine and perhaps Boston lettuce. Today there are at least a dozen choices and it seems as though more are added every season.

title: DUKAKIS SAYS RACE WAS HARMED BY TV
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis says he made a major mistake in the 1988 Presidential race by underestimating the power of negative campaigning and the growing importance of the television ''sound bite.''

title: Responses to Opinion: How Best to Heal Psychic Wounds?
description: Howard Schneider's article expressing disdain for the post-catastrophe healer (Opinion: ''For Psychic Wounds, Time Still Heals Best,'' March 18), with his assertion that time is the best healer, fails to consider the benefits of professional crisis intervention. A crisis brought on by a disaster in the life of an individual can disturb equilibrium, impair judgment and tax an individual's ability to function.

title: Reviews/Music;   Double Band: Multi-layered Cubist Funk
description: The music Ned Rothenberg writes for his Double Band is a cornucopia of riffs - strung together, staggered, overlapping or spiraling around one another like the parts of a DNA molecule. At the Knitting Factory on Wednesday night, its music was a kind of jazz-funk in Cubist perspective, dizzying yet still visceral.

title: Does Carter Expect More From Israel and Less From the Arabs?
description: To the Editor:

title: Trade in Rumors About the Deficit
description: Buy on the rumor and sell on the news, or so goes the old saw. That is what happened last week with the dollar, leaving it surprisingly down against the yen. The rumor was that the United States trade deficit for February would fall sharply, perhaps as low as $4 billion. Traders liked the idea so much they brought dollars in advance, especially against the yen, which fell to 160 to the dollar.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on March 18 with an article about horseback riding in Hungary misidentified the coat of arms on a building at Nagycenk, Hungary. It was the coat of arms of the Szechenyi family, not of Hungary.

title: Walesa Again Chosen Chairman of Solidarity
description: Lech Walesa was easily re-elected chairman of Solidarity today, and he pledged to continue the union movement's sometimes-conflicting roles as workers' advocate and supporter of Poland's new democratic Government.

title: RESPONSES TO OPINION: HOW BEST TO HEAL PSYCHIC WOUNDS
description: Accolades, accolades and more accolades to Howard Schneider for his sensitive and thought-provoking article. My only regret when reading his article was that he limited himself to the mental health field. Just as this ''cottage industry of mental health specialists descended on the passengers who were injured in the Avianca tragedy,'' so did rescue workers, physicians and nurses.

title:
IDEAS & TRENDS;

Do Sex Offenders Belong in Treatment or in Jail?
description: LEAD: SINCE the mid-1980's, many scientists and law enforcement experts have been leaning toward the theory that sex offenders should be given mental health treatment instead of simply being imprisoned. But now the pendulum seems to be swinging the other way. Faced with budget problems and public demands for harsher punishment of people convicted of child abuse, rape and other crimes, many states are deciding that incarceration is more economical and effective than expensive treatment programs.

title: Prenuptial Agreements In History
description: Your readers may be interested to know that something so seemingly new - the prenuptial agreement [Long Island Sound, March 25] - is quite old. For example, the ancient Hebrew marriage contract known as the ketubah dates back at least 2,000 years. In France, the customary prenuptial derives from the dowry, first recorded in the ninth century.

title: RESPONSES TO OPINION: HOW BEST TO HEAL PSYCHIC WOUNDS?
description: It was with great dismay that I and many of my colleagues and clients read Howard Schneider's article, which distorted description of those professional mental health workers dedicated to working with (not on, as he stated) victims and survivors of traumatic events. Anyone the least familiar with trauma and post-traumatic stress disorder knows that the earlier the therapeutic intervention, the less likely the development of subsequent chronic psychological difficulties.

title: Pastimes;   Stamps
description: Some rapid-fire changes in the schedule of United States issues underline problems with stamp production that the public is rarely aware of. Putting out stamps, superficially one of the humblest of Government functions, is a good deal more complicated than it seems.

title: For Slovaks, a Hyphen Means Recognition
description: To the Editor:

title:
FORUM;

AFFIRMATIVE ACTION AND COMPETITIVENESS
description: LEAD: The education President tells us the American economy is about to face a critical shortage of labor. Without an adequate supply of workers capable of and willing to risk learning new skills, the new microelectronic and biological technologies cannot possibly achieve their potential. Nothing less than American competitiveness is at stake, he says.

title: Review/Music;   An Exploration of a Common History
description: Louis Johnson and Joanne Tucker have put together a moving and thought-provoking piece in ''Let My People Go,'' a theater-dance work that was performed on Wednesday night at the Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion in Greenwich Village. Mr. Johnson, the dance director at the Henry Street Settlement, is a black choreographer known for the eclecticism and passion of his dances. Ms. Tucker is the founder and director of the Avodah Dance Ensemble, for which she creates pieces that explore Jewish ritual and dance. ''Let My People Go'' is not the most interesting choreography either one of them has done. But it forces the viewer, in the most even-tempered way imaginable, to examine the common history of American blacks and Jews.

title: LITHUANIA CLOSES MOST INDUSTRIES
description: Lithuania closed its factories today to conserve fuel and raw materials during an expanding Kremlin embargo.

title:
Your Own Account;

Playing Retirement Roulette
description: LEAD: Thomas M. Iezzi is only 48, but already he is planning his retirement. ''I've worked hard all my life,'' said Mr. Iezzi, the chief financial officer for a wholesale beer distributor in Houston. ''If, at age 58, I have adequate resources, I might say the heck with it all.'' His major concern, though, is how he will provide health insurance for his retirement years.

title: When Life Itself Is a Conflict of Interest
description: NEW YORKERS last week got a strange taste of what might get done in their town when the handful of people who run it and the web of companies that serve it have too many ties to each other: Nothing.

title: Pastimes;   Camera
description: Have you noticed any eyes prying into your life this week? Perhaps they belong to one of the 5,000 members of the American Society of Magazine Photographers, more commonly known as ASMP.

title: SOUTHERN EXPOSURE
description: In the 1930's, years before the publication of her first short story and all the fame that would eventually surround her, Eudora Welty was a junior publicity agent for the Federal Works Progress Administration. She wandered through county after county of her native Mississippi, talking to people about their lives, jotting down observations and otherwise taking official and unofficial note of the Deep South, her own land and the land that would figure so predominantly in her fiction. Early on in the assignment, Ms. Welty, intending to reveal ''the life in front of me,'' equipped herself with an inexpensive Kodak camera and began taking her ''snapshots,'' those ''now or never'' moments snatched from time by the quick, observant eye of an instinctive photographer. This early, Depression-era work constitutes the bulk of PHOTOGRAPHS (University Press of Mississippi, $49.95). Whether it is a Baptist deacon, a blind weaver or a child dressed in her Sunday best, these are people who cannot be neatly summarized as victims, but are instead the unposed, unselfconscious, playing, working, struggling denizens of a particular time and place. In the introductory interview with Hunter Cole and Seetha Srinivasan of the University Press of Mississippi, Ms. Welty denies any conscious connection between the photographs and her fiction - though Reynolds Price, who wrote the foreword, detects in her short stories and novels the same ''instant indelible force'' that we hope to find in a photograph - and do, in Ms. Welty's. Above all, Ms. Welty stresses the importance of the subjects of her photographs. ''I wasn't trying to say anything about myself,'' she tells her interviewers. ''I was trying to say everything about them.''

title: An Illustrator Adds Words to His Palette
description: LEAD: IT is only a theory, wishful thinking, perhaps, but Peter Catalanotto says today's children are beginning to discover books.

title: Elizabeth Lacovara to Marry in June
description: June wedding plans for Elizabeth Marie Lacovara and Derek James Mills have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Philip A. Lacovara of New Canaan, Conn. Mr. Mills is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh J. Mills of Glasgow.

title: FARMHOUSE FACE-OFF
description: MY UNCLE LEFT me his country house in New Marlborough, Mass., when he died in 1985. The Farmhouse, as it is called by all who know it. It quickly became clear to me that I had spent more than 40 years of my life with a mildly spoiled city/suburban kid's idea of what a house actually was. I thought a house was a house. It sat there, at worst user-neutral, sempiternally ready to accommodate me. The householder's lamentations of my uncle and father seemed to my youthful ears a form of conversational recreation.

title: Extinction Hovers Over the Barnyard
description: LEAD: THANKS to modern agriculture, many older varieties of livestock and crops may be doomed to extinction. Why they should be preserved is the subject of ''Endangered Breeds and Seeds,'' an exhibition at the Stamford Museum and Nature Center, where an early New England animal farm and heirloom garden are nurtured.

title: Victim's Pain Yields Help for Others
description: LEAD: AS she lay in a hospital bed, slowly recuperating from a vicious assault, Adele Humphrey vowed that she would start a support group to help other victims of street crimes rebuild their lives. Five years later, she says she has finally mended enough to keep her promise Mrs. Humphrey, who lives in the Gales Ferry section of Ledyard, said support groups have been established in Connecticut for victims of sexual assaults and domestic violence.

title: Croatian Republic Voting Today In a Test of Yugoslav Communism
description: The wave of political change sweeping Yugoslavia will wash over Croatia on Sunday as the republic begins its first free multiparty parliamentary elections in more than 50 years. But in Yugoslavia's southern republics, uncertainty remains about when free elections will take place, despite official promises of political change.

title: At the Brink in Kashmir
description: The most dangerous threat to world peace is boiling up between India and Pakistan.

title: For More Initiatives On Roadside Rubbish
description: This month we will be focusing our attention on Earth Day. There are multiple environmental issues that require our effort and attention. The issue that I would like to bring to your readers' attention is one that affects not only my community but almost any community that one travels through. It is an issue that I feel that something can be done about with minimal effort.

title: Home Sites
description: To the Editor:

title: Alomar Drives In Five Runs For Indians
description: Sandy Alomar Jr., a rookie, hit his first American League homer and drove in five runs today, and Tom Candiotti overcame a shaky start as the Cleveland Indians beat the Chicago White Sox, 8-4, gaining consecutive victories over the Perez brothers.

title: INTELLIGENCE DOWN THE DRAIN IN VIETNAM
description: SLOW BURN

title: Review/Theater;   'Beyond Belief,' Comical Time Warp
description: The world holds few surprises more disconcerting than those faced by Dr. Jeremy Peregrine Calthorpe (Jerry Perry to his disrespectful friends), a philosopher, and Jake, an apprentice stand-up comic, who find themselves suddenly transported to an alien dimension in ''Beyond Belief,'' a delightfully zany fantasy.

title: Abortion Protests Put Strain on Dobbs Ferry
description: Village officials of this scenic Hudson River community are upset over what they say are disruptive and costly demonstrations by an anti-abortion group that has repeatedly attempted to block the entrance to a women's health clinic here.

title: Erte, a Master of Fashion, Stage and Art Deco Design, Is Dead at 97
description: Erte, the Russian-born Art Deco designer whose prolific career in theater, sculpture and the graphic arts spanned most of the 20th century, died here today after a short illness. He was 97 years old.

title: Dr. Mary Sciutto Weds J. P. Lowe
description: Dr. Mary Spelman Sciutto, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Sciutto of New York, and James Peck Lowe, a son of Kay Lowe Masuhr of Louisville, Ky., were married yesterday at St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in New York by the Rev. Robert J. Haskins.

title: Ethel S. Masland to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. William Stafford Masland of Tucson have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Ethel Stafford Masland and Peter Wolcott, the son of Mr and Mrs. Calvin Wolcott of San Rafael, Calif. Miss Masland, 29 years ols, graduated from Yale University and received a Master's degree in management information services from the University of Arizona, where her fiance, 28, is a candidate for a doctorate in the same field. Mr. Wolcott graduated from Dartmouth College.

title: Warning Sounded Over Weather Radar Station
description: LEAD: AS much a novice in forecasting public reaction as it is unused to controversy, the National Weather Service chose a name for the next generation of weather radar stations it proposes to install around the country that seemed almost certain to cause alarm.

title: Dirty Pictures
description: Slumped in the subway seat is a young man with vacant eyes, a fatigue jacket, and a copy of ''Catcher in the Rye,'' the familiar red cover curled in his hand. Maybe his mind is the psychological equivalent of a Salvador Dali painting. Maybe he's just a college student facing a long day's journey into a Modern American Lit exam. The book makes me think first one thing, then the other.

title: SHE FELL FOR A PHOTO
description: REACHING TIN RIVER

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Outing;   Where Stoops Offer a Great Skyline
description: In this waterfront city across the Hudson from lower Manhattan, residents convene on stoops to while away weekend afternoons. Often people join the conversations from above, hanging over the rails of the many furbelowed wrought-iron fire escapes precariously fastened to house fronts.

title: Kennedy Airport
description: To the Editor: My experience of arriving at the International Arrivals Building at Kennedy International Airport on Feb. 25 indicated to me a serious crisis in this aging and overcrowded facility.

title: Mutual Funds;   When All Junk Is Not Equal
description: As managers of ''junk bond'' funds scramble to recoup losses and pull investors back into their shattered business, one of the biggest losers in last year's market collapse has come up with a plan to separate the wheat from the chaff - or at least the blue-chip junk from the junky junk.

title: DEMOLITION ALFRESCO
description: IF YOU ARE NOW EMBROILED in a renovation, you may have good reason to wonder why it ever seemed like a good idea. The thought of taking on a second reconstruction is probably beyond your wildest nightmares. But you may notice that while the inside of your home is slowly moving from chaos to order, the outside appears to be heading in the opposite direction.

title: Bookbinder's Invention Clearly Shows Her Art
description: AFTER spending more than 60 years preserving old books, Polly Lada-Mocarski decided to try something new. The 87-year-old New Haven resident received a patent a few years ago for her first invention, a new kind of boxlike plastic exhibition case that can hold small objects like sculptures, dolls, documents - and lovingly preserved books.

title: TALKING: Meetings;   Putting Together A Quorum
description: SPRINGTIME is likely to bring out ballots as well as blossoms in cooperatives, condominiums and homeowner associations.

title: Spending Money On the Best
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The Executive Computer;   The Power Culture Elbows In at Macworld
description: Tens of thousands of Apple Macintosh users visited the Macworld trade exposition here earlier this month, examining the hardware and software on offer. But unlike the Macworld shows of a couple of years ago, when people in blue jeans and polo shirts came to look at Apple's small and relatively underpowered computer family, this year's show attracted what appeared to be an unusually high percentage of corporate users. ''Look at all the suits and ties,'' one visitor marveled, intrigued more by the changing Apple culture than by the technological wonderland around him.

title: Rose Case: Players Beware
description: With Pete Rose now awaiting sentencing for failing to report money he earned from the sale of memorabilia and autographs, it might seem unneccessary to remind baseball players of the dangers of ignoring income-tax laws. But officials in both management and the players' union say they will strive to see that major leaguers fully understand the rules that the Federal Government is obviously prepared to enforce.

title: Homework in a Place That's Not Home
description: THREE afternoons a week, about 25 children living temporarily at the Coachman Hotel in White Plains, come to its Homework Center after school. Five years ago, the Coachman was an ordinary hotel, but now the people who live there aren't ordinary guests.

title: 900 Protest Officer's Fatal Shooting of a 16-Year-Old in Teaneck
description: Chanting ''Teaneck, Teaneck, have you heard? This is not Johannesburg!'' 900 demonstrators marched a mile and a half to the Teaneck, N.J., Police Headquarters yesterday to protest the fatal shooting of a black 16-year-old by a white police officer 11 days ago.

title: CRIME IN THE FAMILY
description: REASONABLE DOUBT

title:
MUSIC;

Beyond the 'Salad Bar' Approach to Concerts
description: LEAD: STEPPING into a nearly 40-year-old organization did not deter the Israeli-born conductor Yehuda Gilad from making substantial changes. Mr. Gilad, the 36-year-old music director of the Madison-based Colonial Symphony, now in his second season as the orchestra's conductor, says he and his orchestra are still in the honeymoon stage.

title: Lori Blodnick to Wed in May
description: A May wedding is planned by Lori S. Blodnick, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward K. Blodnick of Great Neck, L.I., and Robert J. Krakow, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Krakow of Princeton, N.J. Ms. Blodknick, 28 years old, graduated from George Washington University, where her fiance received a law degree. She is an art consultant to Marad Wall Decor in Thornwood, N.Y. Mr. Krakow, 36, is a lawyer in New York. He graduated from the State University of New York at Binghamton.

title: Fashion;   For a Subtle Change, Try a Jacket
description: It all starts with a jacket. Whatever the season, the jacket is the basis of a woman's wardrobe. One new jacket can update all last year's clothes because every season there are subtle differences. That doesn't mean last year's styles are passe. It just means there's always a new look to add to one's closet.

title: New York Officials Are Especially Agitated
description: IF the national rate of response to the census is low, New York City's is, as nearly everyone expected, lower. As of last week only 52 percent of New York City households had mailed back their census forms, a dismal rate that now shifts the burden of counting to a door-to-door enumeration that starts Thursday. But city officials have no more faith in this next phase of the Census Bureau's 1990 operation than they did in the first.

title: Parenting's Relationship With Time Warner
description: To the Editor:

title: May Morgan Robinson, Community Leader, 85
description: May Morgan Robinson, a leader in civil rights and in the Democratic Party in Westchester, died of cancer of the uterus on Thursday at her home in Yonkers. She was 85 years old.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE HILL-STEAD MUSEUM IN FARMINGTON;

Art-Filled Mansion Fulfilled One Woman's Dream
description: LEAD: SINCE it opened to the public in 1947, the Hill-Stead Museum in Farmington has been famous for its displays of French Impressionist paintings as well as exceptional prints, furniture and decorative arts. But in the past few years, a series of discoveries has shed new light on the history of the mansion and its grounds and on the uncommon family that lived there.

title: Are You Your Planet's Keeper?
description: DESIGN FOR A LIVABLE PLANET

title: TAKE IT FROM THE TOP
description: ON THE LINE

title: Size of Mosquito Crop Will Depend on Rainfall
description: LEAD: THE weather during the next few weeks will determine if Connecticut's inland residents must suffer this summer with a bumper crop of mosquitoes as they did last year.

title: The Census, in One Not-So-Easy Lesson
description: WHAT if they gave a census and nobody came? Like the Netherlands in 1970 and West Germany in the early 1980's, the United States in 1990 is coming face to face with the prospect of being unable to determine - or determine exactly - who and where the people are.

title: Katri Backman Weds H. William Koster 3d
description: Katri Backman, a vice president of Bear, Stearns & Company, and H. William Koster 3d, an associate at Morgan Stanley & Company, both in New York, were married yesterday at St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in New York. The Rev. Stanley Mosely, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated, assisted by the Rev. Paiva Tarjamo, a Lutheran minister.

title: Campus Life;   Teaching Assistants Looking to Unions
description: The union movement may have been in decline for years, but graduate teaching assistants seem to be running counter to the trend.

title: Miss Dudley Wed To Anthony Coles
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Margaret Dudley, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Dudley of Guilford, Conn., to Anthony Paul Coles, a son of Dr. Roberta Goldring Coles of New York and the late Dr. Robert S. Coles, took place yesterday at the Pine Orchard Union Chapel in Branford, Conn. Rabbi Charles Davidson and the Rev. Stephen H. Bzydra, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: BLACK STUDIES' NEW STAR
description: Your article on Henry Louis Gates was an honor to that scholar and to other academics of color (''Black Studies' New Star,'' by Adam Begley, April 1). However, it would be nice if The New York Times could keep its admiration of yuppie values in check long enough to admire scholars and thinkers for their ideas. By treating Professor Gates as if he were a corporate C.E.O., by showing us his sprawling house, his Mercedes with cellular phone, his perquisites, possessions and paycheck, you have made it seem as if the proof of the profession is in the possessions. Precious little space was devoted to Professor Gates's work, and entirely too much was spent on what others thought about his career.

title: Correction
description: The Stamps column on April 1 referred incorrectly to the historic boundaries of the kingdom of Lithuania. At its greatest, in 1560, the kingdom stretched from the Baltic Sea to the Black Sea, and included today's Byelorussia and the Ukraine; it did not reach the Ural mountains, which are 1,000 miles further east.

title: Review/Dance;   The Moon As Witness To Rituals
description: On one level or another, wholeheartedly or slyly, Paul Taylor's dances tend to sidle imperturbably into anarchy. There is an undercurrent of unbridled sensuality in the dewily sweet ''Roses,'' which opened the program presented by the Paul Taylor Dance Company on Thursday at City Center. ''Runes'' is a dark, mysterious ritual whose urgency recalls one ancient root of the word that means both ''secret'' and ''cries.'' And ''Esplanade,'' Mr. Taylor's lovingly impudent homage to its Bach score, is so bizarre that it makes ''Concerto Barocco,'' George Balanchine's equally fresh reading of part of the score, look like note-for-note replication.

title: Asian Cuisines Blend at New Restaurant
description: CALLING a restaurant Bal does not necessarily make it Indonesian. True, there are several Indonesian dishes on the menu of a handsome new restaurant in Greenwich by that name; among them is a prix-fixe rijsttafel dinner at $30 each for a minimum of two people. And true, the chef is said to be Chinese-Indonesian. But more than two-thirds of the dishes on the menu are Chinese, and many that are not have a decided Chinese cast, while the decor is totally Chinese from the red wallpaper to the Chinese Chippendale chairs.

title: As Shaw Sees It, Love Conquers All
description: ''GETTING MARRIED,'' now through next Sunday at Long Island Stage in Rockville Centre, is the sparkling centerpiece of this weekend's symposium on the lasting impact of George Bernard Shaw on Western culture.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

As the Country Goes, So Goes Its Litter
description: LEAD: THE year 1990 is going to be a good year for the economy and civilization in general. How do I know? I have seen the future in a handful of trash.

title: Now It's Red Poling's Turn at Ford
description: Red Poling, the Ford Motor Company's new chief executive, keeps a model of a 1948 Jaguar XK-120 on his desk, symbolic of Ford's acquisition of the British car maker this year. No doubt the toy is less a plaything than a reminder of the $2.5 billion paid for Jaguar and the hundreds of millions more Ford must invest to refurbish the ailing company.

title: Under Threat of Occupation
description: To the Editor:

title: William A. Ernst and Karen Kazlau Wed on L.I.
description: Karen A. Kazlau, the daughter of Joseph Kazlau of Coram, L.I., and Joan A. Kazlau of Port Jefferson, L.I., was married in Port Jefferson yesterday to William A. Ernst, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Ernst of Seaford, L.I. The Rev. Robert Scheckenback officiated at Infant Jesus Roman Catholic Church.

title: The Doughboy Gets A Streamlined Look
description: Four years ago, with the roof about to cave in on his head, Jay Morgan still could not get his bosses at the Pillsbury Company to act. Mr. Morgan, who oversees the buildings that house Pillsbury's research and development staff, evacuated a pair of converted livery stables in the complex after an engineer's report confirmed his fears that they were in danger of collapsing. But until recently, he was unable to get authorization to raze the buildings.

title: Builders Feel Pinch of New S & L Act
description: FOR more than 20 years, the Cardinal Federal Savings and Loan bank in Owensboro, Ky., financed the land acquisition and construction costs of Tommy Thompson's house-building business, and Mr. Thompson hardly expected that relationship to change when he recently took an option on another piece of developable land.

title: Correction
description: A recording review last Sunday about an album by Tommy Flanagan misstated the number of piano trio recordings he has made since 1975. It is 15.

title: NONFICTION
description: MARK TWAIN. The Bachelor Years: A Biography. By Margaret Sanborn. (Doubleday, $24.95.) Mark Twain is always a pleasure to read, even on loan, and this account of Twain's life and travels up to his marriage to Olivia Langdon in 1870, at the age of 34, makes free use of his letters and journals, his early newspaper writing and his later fictional retellings of his adventures to trace his development as a writer. Twain was a writer whose imagination built on his personal experiences, and ''Mark Twain: The Bachelor Years'' covers the experiences that made up the material for nearly all of his later books - his boyhood in Hannibal, Mo., his years on the Mississippi riverboats, his travels to the Nevada mining towns and to California, to Hawaii and to Europe and the Holy Land. Margaret Sanborn, who has written a two-volume biography of Robert E. Lee, is scrupulous in picking out discrepancies between Twain's version and the probable truth of an event - and in the process reveals much about Twain's methods of working. She picks out the likely first occasion when Sam Clemens signed himself ''with the pen name that was to become the most famous in American literature,'' and she is at her best describing the growth of Twain's fame as a journalist and a lecturer, first in the Far West and later in the East. Her book is too long by at least 50 pages, but it makes fascinating reading, and it succeeds on the simple principle that the best representation of Mark Twain is Twain himself.

title: Campus Life: Washington;   R.O.T.C. Wins Some Battles, But Foes Fight On
description: The Reserve Officer Training Corps at Washington University has won the most recent fight over its enlistment policies, which exclude homosexuals, as well as a battle over its own existence.

title: Managing;   Asking Workers What They Think
description: The Libbey-Owens-Ford Company wanted to reduce health-care costs.

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart on April 1 with the Mutual Fund column included an erroneous figure supplied by the Freedom Environmental Fund for its return for Dec. 31 to March 15. The return was -5.82 percent, not -10 percent.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;

A Thumb Green Only From Envy
description: LEAD: SOME people feed their plants, bathe their leaves, spray them and talk to them. I tried talking to my plants once. They said they would only speak to me through their attorney.

title: Now Boarding
description: In the eyes of a Federal bankruptcy judge, Frank Lorenzo was no asset for Eastern Airlines. Blaming Mr. Lorenzo for Eastern's staggering losses of more than $1.2 billion in the year that the company has been in bankruptcy proceedings, the judge granted a request by Eastern's creditors and ousted Mr. Lorenzo from control of the company. In a move welcomed by the airline's unions, which accused Mr. Lorenzo of union-busting during the strike that precipitated Eastern's slide, the court appointed Martin Shugrue as special trustee of Eastern. ''It's time to change the captain of Eastern's crew,'' said Judge Burton R. Lifland Jr. Mr. Shugrue, a former airline pilot, was forced out of the presidency of Continental Airlines last year by Mr. Lorenzo, whose Texas Air Corporation is the parent company of Eastern and Continental. A spokesman for the pilots' union, which had long sought Mr. Lorenzo's replacement by a trustee, said he was ''overjoyed'' by the move.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

A Child Struggles to Be Understood
description: LEAD: RAISING children can drive even the most competent parent to distraction. But when the child has a disability, no matter how small, life can become endlessly frustrating. It never crossed our minds that there was anything wrong with our litle girl. We thought she simply overreacted to the ups and downs of life.

title: States Are Finding Pension Funds Can Be a Bonanza Hard to Resist
description: LEGISLATORS here and in other state capitals use words like ''adjustment'' or ''revision'' when they change the formula that determines how much money will be set aside for state workers' retirement. But in virtually all cases in recent years, these changes have gone in one direction, decreasing the amount the states paid to the funds. Now, the people whose pensions are at stake are starting to use other words, like ''robbery'' and ''raiding,'' to describe the changes.

title: Gorbachev's Other Crisis
description: LEAD: If Mikhail Gorbachev's perestroika had succeeded, the strong secessionist forces unleashed in the Soviet Union by glasnost might have been tempered. Unfortunately, so far, perestroika has failed.

title: Congressional Help For Cable TV Fight
description: WHEN a delegation of angry Long Island cable-television subscribers came to Capitol Hill earlier this month, they sought to send a message to lawmakers that consumers were not taking their disappointment with rising cable rates and unpopular programming decisions sitting down.

title: Learning Russian At the Source
description: I HAD two goals in mind last spring when I signed up for a three-week summer course to study Russian in Moscow. First, I wanted the immersion that would advance me a level beyond what I had managed to pick up in six hours a week of classes since the fall. Second, I wanted to stay in Moscow without paying the exorbitant price Intourist demands for individually booked hotel rooms.

title: Data Bank: April 22, 1990
In Moscow, a Happy Ending For a Jewish Film Festival
description: It took some enterprise to present a festival of films about Jewish themes in Moscow earlier this spring. Two energetic American women, Deborah Kaufman and Janis Plotkin, directors of the annual Jewish Film Festival in San Francisco, presented critically acclaimed films on Jewish themes during one week last month.

title: How Rome Worked Its Way Back Into the Eastern Bloc
description: FOR Pope John Paul II, born Karol Wojtyla in Wadowice, Poland, the collapse of Communism in Eastern Europe has been a personal triumph. He was, after all, an important supplier of moral firepower for the revolution. Now, Vatican relations with formerly hostile countries have shifted, one after another, almost as fast as those societies themselves.

title: Pastimes;   Bridge
description: There was some perceptible paranoia in the early stages of the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship final played in Fort Worth three weeks ago. In the first 32 deals the computer served up 15 hands in the slam zone, an extraordinarily high frequency, and a bunch a weird distributions.

description: IN France you eat well, in Germany you eat a lot and in Strasbourg you eat both well and a lot. Or at least so the saying goes, a saying that is tested daily by German visitors who cross the Rhine for dinner and don't expect to go home hungry. Here, even nouvelle cuisine cannot be tiny delicacies served up on huge plates.

title: WHEN LEGAL TITANS CLASH
description: YOU PEOPLE ARE NOT A RANDOM, TYPICAL sample of the U.S. population,'' deadpans the new dean of Harvard Law School to appreciative laughter. After all, the hundred-odd students gathered to hear Robert C. Clark's talk on ''Laws, Markets and Morals'' are investing nearly $75,000 in their Juris Doctor degrees. Although you'd never guess from their backpacks and corduroys, many of them will earn more than their money back the very first year they graduate to briefcases and gray flannel.

title: Holocaust Tales, Set To Music, Will Open
description: WHEN ''Hasidic Tales of the Holocaust'' was published in 1982, its author, Yaffa Eliach, a professor of Judaic studies at Brooklyn College and herself a Holocaust survivor, said that the 89 tales told in her book - all of them true - found in the harrowing experiences of victims ''a glimmer of hope, a hint of laughter.''

title: Evening Hours;   Spring Whirl: Auctions, Dances, Honors, Awards
description: A whirl of spring benefits has uncovered a new formula for raising money: shorter speeches, shorter evenings and shorter dresses.

title: Review/Dance;   'Split Personality,' By Elisa Monte Troupe
description: Dances should not be judged by their titles. Nevertheless, a title is important, for it provides the audience with its first clue as to what a particular work may be like.

title:
ART;

Dutch Bring International Perspectives
description: LEAD: AT one time, exhibitions of art from foreign countries were thought to contribute toward the understanding of other cultures. Now they seem to reinforce the concept of the world as one big melting pot, at least so far as contemporary industrial democracies are concerned. Easy, rapid image communication has fostered creative interests that are increasingly international.

title: POSTINGS: Southbury Home Sites;   Ancestor's Initiative Paying Off
description: Despite a bleak market, two developers in Connecticut - one of them a descendant of the man who bought the tract they are developing from the Indians - are reporting success in selling expensive lots and building upscale homes in the Town of Southbury in New Haven County. Edward Hinman Williams of Southbury and Paul Tolk of Fairfield last year subdivided 104 acres into 38 lots of 1.5 to 5 acres, leaving 18 acres as deeded open space. They named the development Hunters Ridge and have so far sold 16 lots at $130,000 to $165,000.

title: Margo Donahue Wed in Palm Beach
description: Margo Mutrie Donahue and Frederic Ashton de Peyster 3d were married yesterday at St. Edward's Roman Catholic Church in Palm Beach, Fla., by the Rev. Clement Hammerschmitt. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Peter Donahue of Litchfield, Conn. and Palm Beach. Mr. de Peyster is a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Abercrombie de Peyster of Palm Beach.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on April 8 about businesses in the state affected by the real estate slump misidentified the man seen painting a window for the Renaissance Painting Company of Glastonbury. He is Michael C. Caisse, an employee of the concern, not Mark Coley, its president.

description: Pamela Frank was noted as an exceptionally promising young violinist in 1986, when she was 18 years old and appeared as a concerto soloist with Alexander Schneider's Brandenburg Ensemble. In 1988, she was awarded an Avery Fisher Career Grant.

title: A State Budget Plan That Breaks the Rules
description: POLITICIANS who think about the long-term interests of their constituents have a choice, according to today's cynics. They can commit political suicide by proposing complicated solutions to hard problems. Or they can go for short-term, superficial fixes that don't really do the job.

title: CAR STEREOS DESIGNS ARE UP TO THE MINUET
description: Henry Ford didn't believe in giving his customers much of a choice. When he launched his famous Model A in 1927, he felt that painting the cars in different colors was wasteful. ''They can have any color they want,'' he declared, ''as long as it's black.''

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our 50-year-old house has a brick chimney that goes up through the attic, and the bricks are exposed inside the attic. There are four flues inside the chimney, and the bricks in the attic have developed a white, flaky material that my husband calls bloom. There is also a white powder on top of some items stored next to the chimney. The chimney has no cover or cap. What is causing this bloom?

title: DAFT DIGNITY
description: REBUILDING COVENTRY: A Tale of Two Cities. By Sue Townsend. (Grove Weidenfeld, $16.95.) Sue Townsend's brittle, brilliant farce begins when Coventry Dakin, a beautiful middle-aged British housewife, seizes an Action Man doll and brains a slobbering, philandering neighbor who is about to strangle his wife. The neighbor, a loathsome physical wreck, drops dead and Coventry takes off, leaving behind, in order of insignificance: pompous cops, sniping suburban gossips, a ''pettifogging collection of concrete and brick they called an estate,'' her numbed teen-age children and her whining, toadlike husband and his collection of inexplicably anorexic pet tortoises. Coventry's fate is to become another anonymous face among London's homeless. There Ms. Townsend, author of the popular novel ''The Adrian Mole Diaries,'' sends her innocent and slightly screwball heroine along a bent path through London's upper and lower crusts. In one incredible week, Coventry becomes a bag lady, a prostitute, a maidservant and an earnest guest at a society dinner party. As we may expect, the homeless she meets have their daft dignity, the young professionals are feckless snobs and the upper-class swells come off as bloated, bigoted oafs mouthing Thatcherite platitudes. The book's title suggests that Coventry's flight, as with the running rabbits in American suburban escape novels of the 1960's, will lead her to a renewed sense of self. This doesn't quite happen, and the short chapters, jarring shifts in points of view and sketchy plot details make ''Rebuilding Coventry'' more a series of hilarious comic moments than a cohesive novel. But the book remains great fun, thanks to Ms. Townsend's crisp, clever prose and her unabashed glee at wringing from her wacky characters the essence of their vileness: everyone in England is rotten through and through, except for Coventry - who, as she reminds us, is beautiful and a murderer - and her friend Dodo, a high-society refugee who joins in her escape. One finishes the book longing to go with them.

title: When or Whether to Retire: New Ways to Handle Strain
description: It has been three years since Steven August, now 61 years old, lost his job as associate creative director at a New York advertising agency, and although he has patched together some freelance work and teaches two continuing education courses, a terrible sense of displacement is still with him.

title: American History Told Through Early Ballads
description: LEAD: FOR Murray Phillips, a nationally known folk singer and guitarist, it is the looks on the faces of his audiences that make his work worthwhile.
