''There's joy from the children, who shine like a million lights,'' he said, ''wistfulness from old people as memories take them back to places they came from, languages once spoken.

title: Miss Borthwick Weds S. M. Bass
description: Pamela Chapman Borthwick was married to Shannon Melvin Bass yesterday at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York by the Rev. J. Seymour Flinn.

title: HISTORY IN THE REMAKING
description: LEAD: AS THE 20TH CENTURY draws to a close, many homeowners are looking back to its finest moments and those of past eras for remodeling inspiration. Rather than strip their houses of period details to create a modern look, they are taking the opposite approach, painstakingly re-creating certain historical styles.

title: A Pianist Who Makes Longevity an Art
description: They talk about musicians who played from here to eternity - those great veterans like Pablo Casals, Leopold Stokowski, Arthur Rubinstein, Isidor Philipp, all of whom were active in their late 80's and even middle 90's. But their record is about to be shattered by Mieczyslaw Horszowski, who is giving a piano recital tomorrow in Carnegie Hall.

title: Plan to Test Firefighters And Police For Drugs Is Questioned
description: ORDINANCES proposed by municipal officials in Union City that establish a program of random drug testing for public safety personnel have raised Federal and state constitutional issues and may be an infringement on police officers' and firefighters' rights, legal experts and labor union officials say.

title: Earth Day at 20: How Green the Globe? - A special report:   Guarding Environment: A World of Challenges
description: Twenty years after the first Earth Day, the Cuyahoga River no longer catches fire on its way through Cleveland, and bald eagles, once threatened by DDT, have increased nearly sevenfold in the continental United States, enough for Government biologists to consider promoting the population to ''threatened'' from ''endangered.''

title: The Duet's Multiple Choices
description: Two dancers moving side by side may not be dancing together at all. Imaginative choreography can suggest that they are miles apart or, though they are both obviously physical entities, that one is only an apparition. On other occasions, a choreographer can demonstrate that no matter how physically distant two people may be, they are still emotionally close. Several recent examples illustrate just how infinitely varied a form the duet can be.

title: All About/Women's Swimwear;   Fabric, Fit and a Rose-Tinted Mirror
description: In the coming weeks, millions of American women will face an ordeal they dread: shopping for a swimsuit. Sixty percent of the swimwear sold in this country is purchased in May, June and July.

title: Elizabeth Marks to Wed Harry Ostrer
description: June wedding plans for Elizabeth Marks and Dr. Harry Ostrer have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Paul A. Marks of Bridgewater, Conn.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: Lisa Blonkvist never watched the ABC soap opera, ''Ryan's Hope.'' Still, she had a very good idea what Mary Ryan, one of the principal characters, looked like. In fact, Mary Ryan might have been, according to others, the reflection Ms. Blonkvist saw in the mirror every morning, an oval face, green eyes, hair style not quite pageboy.

title: CALIFORNIA: COASTING ALONG
description: Pork medallions snuggled next to creamy, garlicky potatoes. Prime rib rubbed with olive paste. Chocolate-stuffed croissants soaked with creme anglaise. This is California cuisine - a far cry from the raw baby vegetables, edible flowers and pizzas that put the state on the culinary map. And while pork, potatoes and bread pudding may seem at odds with the trim, tanned population, restaurants that serve robust food are experiencing a mini-revival.

title: Public Enemy Makes Waves - and Compelling Music
description: Ever since Public Enemy first hit the stage in 1987, dressed in fatigues and surrounded by bodyguards armed with fake Uzi's, they've kicked up a fuss. The group - Chuck D (Charles Ridenhour), Flavor-Flav (William Drayton) and Terminator X (Norman Rogers) - all from Roosevelt, L.I., came on with bursts of black nationalist political rhetoric that hadn't been heard since the movement fizzled in the early 1970's.

title: A Message For Al Arbour
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Lester Young and Uncle Sam
description: To the Editor:

title: Wine;   AND THE WINNER IS . . .
description: YOU KNOW THE SCENE: DIRTY HARRY , alias Clint Eastwood, has just dispatched the villain with an unerring shot. Reholstering his .357 Magnum, he mutters: ''A man's got to know his limitations.''

title: The Knicks Need Ewing in the Game
description: In the early part of the season, winning for the Knicks was as easy as calling out Patrick Ewing's number and running a play for the 7-foot center. But as the season progressed, opposing coaches surrounded Ewing with two and three players and dared the Knicks to beat them from the outside.

title: Penn and Brown Advance to Final
description: Pennsylvania's men's varsity heavyweight crew defeated Yale by one boat length today to advance to the final Sunday against Brown for the championship of the fifth annual Redwood Shores-Stanford Crew Classic.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Tart Rhubarb Conjures Sweet Springtime Memories
description: LEAD: THERE it was on the shelf in the grocery store's produce section, its long, pink stalks greeting me like the hand of an old acquaintance. Rhubarb is a spring tonic that chases away the winter blues.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD:

title: PERSPECTIVES: Modular Housing;   Widening the Role of Factory-Built Units
description: A CRANE swings and a section of house is fitted into place at a development called Aqueduct Homes. It happened last week in the University Heights section of the West Bronx. It is also happening in the Hunts Point section, at a development called Villa Maria.

title: How Physicist's Weapons Genius Led Him to Greed and Then Death
description: Gerald V. Bull was a gifted designer of military hardware: at age 22, a doctor of aerophysics; at 32, star of a Pentagon ballistics lab. But when he could not earn a living making guns for the United States, he turned to illicit trade, and at 52 he was in a Federal prison for illegally exporting arms to South Africa.

title: Services for Abernathy
description: The funeral of the Rev. Ralph David Abernathy, the pioneer leader in the civil rights struggle, will take place at noon tomorrow at the West Hunter Street Baptist Church in Atlanta.

title: Political Memo;   For Women, Better Climate Is Seen
description: From the rise of the abortion issue to the new emphasis on other domestic concerns like education, the political climate is shifting in ways that could make the 1990's increasingly hospitable to women in politics, many analysts in both parties say.

title: A Museum to Match Hawaii's Natural Beauty
description: IT is difficult to compete with the natural masterpieces along the spiraling drive up Mount Tantalus, but the Contemporary Museum - perched on a ridge of the 2,000-foot mountain outside Honolulu - offers a cultivated beauty found nowhere else in the Hawaiian islands.

title: Review/Rock;   The Chills of New Zealand, Steeped in Sound of the 60's
description: Martin Phillipps is nearly torn apart in the songs he writes for the Chills, who performed Tuesday night at Woody's. Part of him wants to withdraw, either alone or with a loved one, to ruminate over fantasies and bittersweet memories. And part of him compresses those ruminations into terse pop songs, making private reveries public, aggressive and catchy. ''Wet Blanket,'' which has a folk-rock arrangement that could have come out of a garage in 1965, puts his dilemma clearly: ''I've got nothing to say to anyone, anyone, anyone - except to you.''

title: POSTINGS: Outlet for Jamaica;   From Farm To Market
description: For more than a century, Jamaica, Queens, has been a farm-to-market hub, and even before the Dutch arrived in the 17th century the area was a major trading center for the Canarsie Indians. Now that tradition is being reinforced with the creation of a permanent greenmarket at 160th Street and 90th Avenue.

title: Miss Shore to Wed John Le Boutillier
description: June wedding plans for Susanna G. Shore and John Le Boutillier, a son of Martin Le Boutillier of Lyme, Conn., and Mrs. Gilbert Lincoln of West Hartford, Conn., have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Drs. Miles F. and Eleanor G. Shore of Needham, Mass.

title: Susan Babits, a Banker In New Jersey, Marries
description: Susan Noreen Babits, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Steven L. Babits of Cranford, N.J., was married there yesterday to Dean Mathew Vogel, the son of Adelene Hall Vogel of Cranford and Harold A. Vogel Jr. of Bedminster, N.J. The Rev. Richard J. Regan officiated at St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church.

title: HAITIANS' OUTRAGE BRINGS SOLIDARITY
description: As more than 50,000 marchers, mostly Haitians, massed in lower Manhattan on Friday, they caught a city by surprise, stunning the police and transportation officials and even their own organizers with the size and order of the protest.

title: Filming a Masterpiece
description: To the Editor:

title: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE: Reporter's Notebook;   In East Germany, Smiles and Fewer Formalities
description: The political leaders of the world may be haggling and debating over the terms of German unification, but the German people on both sides of the border are making it happen so fast that you can almost miss it in a blink.

title: Miss Lavine Engaged To Gregory Warwick
description: June wedding plans for Nancy Kopp Lavine and Gregory Lawerance Warwick have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Leroy S. Lavine of Boston.

title: From Bonnets to Baseball Caps, Millinery Conquest Is Recalled
description: LEAD: HATS are edging back into fashion, but they have always been in style at the Fairfield Historical Society, which boasts a collection of more than 500. In ''Bonnets, Boaters and Baseball Caps,'' on view at the society through May 28, more than 100 examples reflect styles and mores from the 1700's to the present.

title: INSIDE THE GLITTER MACHINE
description: HYPE AND GLORY

title: Rene Davis Marries Christopher Hampton
description: Irene Marie Davis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Davis of Red Bank, N.J., was married there yesterday to Christopher Kennedy Hampton, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Walter R. Hampton of Tariffville, Conn. The Rev. Daniel S. Flynn officiated at St. James Roman Catholic Church.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: JUPITER, FLA.;

Builder's Bet: Drier Plantings
description: LEAD: THOUGH many home buyers here are transplanted Northerners seeking a tropicalenvironment, a home developer here is taking a marketing gamble by cutting back on the exotic landscapes for which the area is known.

title: A LUBBER IN THE ROPES
description: TUNING THE RIG

title:
DINING OUT;

A Reopened Landmark in South Salem
description: LEAD: WE had mixed feelings when, after 19 years, the old Horse and Hound Inn closed. The place was unique for serving a feudal feast of exotic meats in heavy sauces, for having spare but authentic early-American charm and for keeping one of the best wine cellars in the area. But its closing may have been fortuitous, occurring as it did a little more than a year ago, just as raised consciousness and dietary trends deemed unfashionable and unhealthy the consumption of large quantities of bear, reindeer, alligator and buffalo.

title: Earth Day Extravaganza Sheds Its Humble Roots
description: Millions of dollars and months of careful orchestration went into preparing events for this weekend marking Earth Day in some 3,600 communities in the United States and 140 countries abroad. The broad effort bears little similarity to the almost informal organizing in 1970 that drew 20 million Americans outside for an afternoon to celebrate the environment and support actions to insure that it would be cared for.

title: Social Events
description: A Special School

title: Tour Shopping With a Computer
description: A KNOWLEDGEABLE traveler with a personal computer stands at the threshold of an electronic shopping mall of advice and travel services that go well beyond booking an airplane ticket. The services make available information about adventure travel, cruises and other special interests. And one program harnesses the computer's power to search and seize the best air fares and seats.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE WILL ROGERS INSTITUTE;

Behind a Celebrity Image, Research
description: LEAD: MOVIEGOERS at 2,500 theaters nationwide will soon see a new short film before the feature: a 45-second trailer narrated by the actor William Devane that briefly outlines the symptoms of Lyme disease. At the end of the film, Mr. Devane tells where viewers may write for further information: the ''Will Rogers Institute, White Plains, N.Y.

title: 51 Burros Slain in Arizona
description: The carcasses of 51 wild burros have been found in the Black Mountain foothills and the authorities are looking for those who killed them. Kelly Grissom, a wrangler for the Bureau of Land Management, said Friday that bullets removed from the carcasses indicate that more than one weapon was used.

title: Time and Money
description: Federal prosecutors bit off a lot more than they could prove in the case of Robert A. Freeman, one of three Wall Street stock speculators who were arrested three years ago on sweeping insider trading charges. In a case that tarnished the reputation of Rudolph W. Giuliani, the United States Attorney who initiated the investigation, most of the charges against Mr. Freeman and all of those against the two others were eventually dropped. Mr. Freeman wound up pleading guilty to a single count of insider trading and came up for sentencing last week. Federal District Judge Pierce N. Leval was obviously impressed with Mr. Freeman, calling him ''a chastened man'' who did not require ''punishment of a serious nature.'' At the same time, Judge Leval said, he could not have Mr. Freeman appearing to get off lightly simply because he was a man of ''eminence, power and wealth.'' Mr. Freeman was sentenced to four months in prison and fined $1 million.

title: PLAY'S THE THING
description: THE TREASURES OF CHILDHOOD

title:
SOCCER;

With Cup Nearing, Ramos Looks Back
description: LEAD: Tab Ramos is not yet 24 years old, but he has already known more soccer success than most players achieve in an entire career.

title: New York and Cable TV Concerns Still Disagree as Deadline Nears
description: With a deadline for a decision less than a month away, representatives of New York City and a cable television operator have reached agreement on most points in the renewal of two cable television franchises in Manhattan.

title: Actor Comes East in Homecoming
description: LEAD: INTERVIEWED in his dressing room soon after giving an energetic matinee performance, Michael McKean thought for a moment before arriving at this advice for future theatergoers to ''Accomplice,'' the new comedy-thriller in which he enigmatically stars:

title: Robert L. Straus Wed To Ruth Clifton Wysor
description: Ruth Clifton Wysor, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William G. Wysor Jr. of Chapel Hill, N.C., was married there yesterday to Robert Leonard Straus, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Straus of Jersey City, by the Rev. Diane Corlett at the Episcopal Church of the Holy Family.

title: Syrian Official Says He Expects Release of Hostage
description: A Syrian official said today that he expected an American hostage to be released Sunday to the United States Embassy. The embassy had no comment.

title:
DINING OUT;

Chinese Dinners at an Ice Cream Parlor
description: LEAD: PICTURE a spiffed-up 1930's ice cream parlor and lunchroom that features such dishes as seaweed salad scented with coriander, grilled Sichuan beef and homemade espresso ice cream with hot fudge and walnuts. See the food artfully arranged on brightly colored plates and served by a friendly Chinese waiter, and you have dinner at Baumgart's Cafe.

title:
FARE OF THE COUNTRY;

Guadeloupe's Fresh, Fiery Creole Cuisine
description: LEAD: IF you start inquiring about the sources of Guadeloupe's celebrated cuisine, sooner or later you'll hear the story about the cook who was transplanted from Normandy to a 19th-century island plantation. Wanting to re-create the beignets aux pommes (apple fritters) of her native province, she made the batter before she realized that apples were not to be found on Guadeloupe.

title: Jean M. Tuomey Weds John Cleary
description: Jean Marie Tuomey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh B. Tuomey of Ridgewood, N.J., was married yesterday to John Charles Cleary, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Cleary of Binghamton, N.Y. The Rev. Peter J. Vaghi officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Gabriel the Archangel in Saddle River, N.J.

title: Kathleen Kelly Weds
description: Kathleen H. Kelly, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph L. Kelly of Norfolk, Va., was married yesterday to Keith L. Oberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond L. Oberg of West Hartford, Conn. The Rev. Charles Joy officiated at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Norfolk. The bride, 30 years old, graduated from the University of Virginia and received an M.B.A. from Stanford University. Mr. Oberg, 30, graduated from Harvard University and received an M.B.A. from Dartmouth College. He is an assistant regional director in Hampton, N.H., for Wheelabrator Technologies.

title: Gypsy Cabby Shot to Death by a Passenger in Brooklyn
description: A gypsy cab driver was shot in the head and killed in Brooklyn yesterday, the police said.

title: Keeping Students From Smoking
description: The ''mixed messages'' students receive about smoking do tend to be related to policies that are not comprehensive enough. Comprehensive policies include posted 'no smoking' signs on and near school grounds, a closed campus policy and a formal health education plan for smoking prevention programming. The most effective school smoking control policies, are therefore preventive in focus, encouraging the education of both students and staff. Punitive measures to regulate smoking have little effect.

title: On Tokyo Runways, Foreign Labels Still Rule
description: While Japan's emergence as an economic power has been driven by exported electronics and industrial products, it has been paralleled by a growing obsession at home with fashionable goods that have foreign cachet: clothing and accessories.

title: FOCUS: Gas Station Design;   Nearly 400 Enter Contest in Portland
description: WHEN Theo Holtwijk, a landscape architect and planner, approached the officers of C. N. Brown Company last September with the idea of sponsoring a national design competition to elicit fresh ideas for the company's newest gas station, he thought they would promptly turn him away. After all, he reasoned, more often than not, when a gas station is built these days, the design reflects a prototype chosen by whatever major oil company supplies the fuel.

title: BEYOND THE LUNCH COUNTER
description: THE CIVIL RIGHTS ERA

title: POP WITH NO 'THERE' THERE: SOOTHING, OR JUST ANNOYING?
description: As far as I'm concerned, the nastiest word in a rock critic's lexicon is ''bland.'' Not ''clumsy'' or ''crude'' or ''dumb'' or ''messy,'' all of which can be compliments, depending on the kind of music and whether there is some passion behind the mess. But give me something with a dead-calm center, a voice or an instrumental sound that betrays no strain or ambition, and my hackles rise.

title: Baseball Fans Must Fight Back
description: To the Sports Editor: rrThe major league owners and the players' union have earned, indeed invited, both Federal regulation and a public boycott for their contemptuous behavior during the 32-day lockout (''Baseball Negotiators Cleaning Up Loose Ends,'' The Times, March 20). Congress should mandate Federal regulation (overriding the Supreme Court's longstanding antitrust exemption) of professional baseball in view of the abuse of monopoly power and the callous disregard for basic Economics 101 principles of supply and demand in depriving the public of a historic and valued national product and depriving the local economies of spring training sites of essential revenues.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: The Unseen Self

title: A New Day To Save the Earth
description: I WAS a 1970 Earth Day participant. But 20 years later, I feel that in many ways the earth movement has gone astray, and I am appalled at what the environmental activists are doing to many attempts to solve environmental problems.

title: Township Struggles to Comprehend 1971 Murder of Family
description: THE old Victorian mansion on Hillside Avenue is gone now: it burned to the ground the summer after John Emil List slew five members of his family in the confines of its 18-room fading elegance. The police say that a group of teen-agers who were drinking beer during a candlelight gathering in the ballroom, where the bodies were discovered, set the house ablaze accidentally.

title: Tech Notes;   Faster Than the Speed of Electricity
description: Computer that use light instead of electricity to process information have the potential to process data far faster than today's supercomputers. To do this, gallium-arsenide computer chips, which are sensitive to light, are linked by laser light to form a circuit. Researchers at Bell Labs, in Holmdale, N.J., have now produced tiny laser emitting diodes that are between 1 and 5 microns in size and can be integrated into the computer chips themselves. A micron is one one-hundredth of the width of a human hair. These tiny lasers are located on the chip's substrate, which is made of quartz glass. The substrate contains miniature lenses, to focus the laser light, and a beam-splitting device that can divide the light so its pulses can be sent to one or more other chips in the circuit to convey information.

title: Dawn M. Selya, Teacher, Is Wed
description: Dawn Meredith Selya, a daughter of Judge and Mrs. Bruce M. Selya of Providence, R.I., was married last evening in Boston to Brian George Sherman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Norton Sherman of Newton, Mass. Rabbi Leslie Y. Gutterman officiated at the Ritz-Carlton.

title: Products Respond to the Earth's Plight
description: TODAY is Earth Day, and it may bethe beginning of what will be considered the Environmental Decade. During the next 10 years, concerned citizens hope that there will be heightened awareness of the earth's plight. And many suggestions will be put forth to make the planet a better place for future generations. There will be much to read, recommendations to follow, and many debates will probably arise.

title: Miss Byers Weds William Smilow
description: Kathleen Kay Byers, a buyer for Ann Taylor Stores, and William Scott Smilow, a sales assistant at Sports Channel America, both in New York, were married yesterday at the Lotos Club by the Rev. Karl Gilmeister, a Presbyterian minister, and Rabbi Charles Lippman.

title: Questioning the Need For Submarines
description: In the Connecticut Q&A column on March 18, with Congressman Sam Gejdenson, he is quoted as saying: ''People talk about cutting the B-1 or the MX or Star Wars and the Midgetman, but nobody talks about cutting submarines. We need them.''

title: Brookhaven Divided Over a Law on Signs
description: LEAD: A TOUGH new sign ordinance in the Town of Brookhaven, its proponents say, was designed to clean the town of a major environmental eyesore, but it may, according to those who oppose the measure, change the shape of future political races.

title: Wall Street;   Everyone (Almost) Loves Food Lion Oil: Missing That Old, Cartel-Like Feeling
description: In the past three months, a number of food-industry analysts have begun to rhapsodize over a homespun North Carolina grocery-store chain called Food Lion, whose shares trade over-the-counter. The basis for Wall Street's enthusiasm is clear: the company's sales and profits have both grown at an average annual rate of more than 25 percent for the past decade, and its customers and shareholders display a loyalty that borders on the fanatical.

title: ENSLAVEMENT IN SICILY
description: A HOUSE IN THE SHADOWS

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island;   Recent Sales
description: Bellport $159,000

title: Points of View On Wearing Furs
description: I was appalled at a statement in the Opinion Page piece by Marlene Fanta Shyer entitled ''Changing Thoughts on Furs'' on Feb. 18.

title: 400 YEARS OF STAGE DESIGN, ON PAPER
description: This critic has been a member almost since infancy of one of the more harmless among secret societies. It has no dues, no meetings, no coded signs of recognition, no oath of loyalty and no meetings. Its membership consists, worldwide, of men and women who would be delighted, any time, any place, to be locked up all day in a theater museum.

title: Away From It All
description: It's been a month since she ended her 10-year career as a downhill ski racer, but Maria Walliser has been so busy since then making personal tours and negotiating endorsement contracts that she decided she needed a little vacation from her retirement.

title: Study Sheds Light on Special Problems of Alcoholic Women
description: LEAD: WOMEN would seek treatment for alcoholism sooner if physicians and other professionals were more adept at diagnosing their symptoms and knew more about therapy for alcoholic women, concludes a new study by the Junior League of Greenwich.

title: A Week to Hear Chamber Works
description: CHAMBER and choral music lovers will find an especially bountiful concert harvest this week. The instrumental performing rosters range upward in size from duos to chamber orchestra, and the vocal programs offer masses, oratorios and cantatas.

title: FICTION
description: SQUEEZE PLAY. By Jane Leavy. (Doubleday, $18.95.) A woman in a locker room full of naked men, A. B. Berkowitz soon discovers, is not particularly welcome. A sportswriter covering the born-again Washington Senators for The Washington Tribune, she keeps a steno pad at the proper level, but often is confronted with the solid evidence that there's more to baseball than being primed to play. The story presented in ''Squeeze Play,'' a first novel by Jane Leavy, a former sportswriter for The Washington Post, does baseball mythology proud. The Senators, back after 18 years, are now owned by Jimy Boy Collins, a television evangelist who makes Jim Bakker look like a saint. His players have the usual problems. There's also wife swapping, videotaping, blackmailing, tobacco spitting, booze, drugs, four-letter words, five-letter words, people who don't understand six-letter words. Both on and off the field, most of these adolescent men have trouble getting to second base. In brief, unexpected bursts, the novel deals touchingly with the serious baseball dreams of Buck, the poor Southerner who lives only to play ball; Rump, the legendary but aging catcher; Joey Proud, A. B. Berkowitz's childhood Yankee hero, now broken down; and A.B. herself. But the overall effect is that of a surreal parody, with a baseball team and newsroom that Mel Brooks might have assembled, where nobody and no activity is life-size, and where sex is a metaphor for baseball: you gotta play hurt.

title: Katherine Schreiber to Wed
description: Katherine A. Schreiber, the owner of Schreiber Associates Landscape Architects, and Stephen E. Tise, president of Tise Architects, both in Cambridge, Mass., are planning a May wedding, her father, George Schreiber of Saddle River, N.J., has announced. A graduate of Skidmore College, Miss Schreiber, 36 years old, is a daughter also of the late Adrienne C. Schreiber. Mr. Tise, 45, is the son of Mrs. Henry H. Tise of San Rafael, Calif., and the late Mr. Tise. He graduated from the Boston Architectural Center and was a Loeb Fellow at Harvard University.

title: Mehtaville Awaits Masur's Leadership
description: Though Zubin Mehta's tenure still has a year to run, it is not too soon to ponder Kurt Masur's chances for success as the New York Philharmonic's next music director. Was his engagement the wisest move possible at a time of major-conductor scarcity or a panicky action taken out of fear of being left at the post in the maestro sweepstakes?

title: HIGHER THAN THE APES
description: ADAM AND EVE AND PINOCCHIO

title: THE UNIVERSITIES UNDER ATTACK ...
description: TENURED RADICALS

title: Women's Networks Changing Focus
description: LEAD: LAST fall, the 10-year-old Hartford Women's Network, one of the largest and oldest professional women's groups in the state, went out of business. The results of two surveys of some 250 members showed, in part, that the majority found the organization no longer served its original purpose as a forum for making professional contacts and career advancement.

title: Anni Dupre and Charles N. Santry Are Married
description: Annette Alice Dupre, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Dupre of Champion, Pa., was married yesterday in Latrobe, Pa., to Charles Nelson Santry, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Santry Jr. of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. James C. McSwigan, an uncle of the bride, officiated at the Roman Catholic Basilica of St. Vincent.

title:
ART;

Abstract Expressionism's Smaller Side
description: LEAD: ABSTRACT Expressionism is the stuff of myth and legend. It represents what the critic Irving Sandler called ''the triumph of American painting,'' which means, among other things, that armed with this style New York could replace Paris as the art capital of the world.

title: Earth Day Isn't Getting Any Easier
description: The 20th anniversary of Earth Day is being marked around the world. Here are four views on its significance.

title: Nancy C. Hoguet, an Editor, Marries G. H. Tilghman Jr., Portfolio Manager
description: Nancy Clarice Hoguet, the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Roland Hoguet of Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday to George Hammond Tilghman Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Tilghman of Locust Valley, L.I. The Rev. Stephen Price and the Rev. Henry Tilghman, an uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE PRINCESS IN THE PIGPEN

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: PETER ROBERTS;

Saving for a Child's College Education
description: LEAD: IN 1983, with the cost of a college education rising each year, Peter Roberts's brother asked how he could invest his money to prepay his children's education.

title: SCHUYLERVILLE STANDS STILL
description: Mr. Kunstler's portrait of Schuylerville is an all too common picture of rural life in the United States. I think he is correct in suggesting that tourism and development are not the answer to rural poverty and despair. The answer, as Mr. Kunstler suggests, would seem to be found in traditional American ideals of self-reliance and local control - in small family farms and businesses that make the best use of natural resources because the people who run them care about their homes and community as no distant corporation can.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a mechanical error, an article about antiques today in Home Design, part 2 of The Times Magazine, appears with a line omitted at the top of page 59. The sentence should read, ''Provenance also influences the decision to restore.''

title: Erin M. Norton Is Wed To Chester J. Straub Jr.
description: Erin M. Norton, a daughter of Barbara A. Norton of East Islip, L.I., and the late Raymond Norton, was married yesterday to Chester J. Straub Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Straub of Bronxville, N.Y. The Rev. Dennis McNally performed the ceremony at St. Francis Xavier Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: 2 Councilmen Won't Join South Africa Tour
description: After a day and half of controversy and pressure from their constituents and anti-apartheid groups, two New York City Council members said yesterday that they would not participate in a tour of South Africa sponsored by the Johannesburg City Council.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester;   Recent Sales
description: New Fairfield, Conn. $350,000

title: Pilot, Accused, Balks at Flying
description: A Northwest Airlines flight from Detroit to Atlanta was delayed for nearly four hours after a pilot refused to fly the plane because a passenger had accused him of being drunk, the airline said.

title: Why the U.S. Has a Case of The Mumbles On Lithuania
description: THE situation in Lithuania has become a test of whether the cold war is really over. The way President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev handle the explosive questions raised by Lithuania's drive for independence will demonstrate whether they are truly willing to treat one another more as allies than adversaries.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Sex, Lies and Videotape

title: Sorting the Garbage: How Well Is It Working?
description: IN the two decades since the first Earth Day, county residents have learned a thing or two. They are still planting trees and cleaning up local parks, but they are also sorting through their garbage.

title: World Markets;   The Glut in Europe; a Stir in Japan
description: In the first quarter of this year, country funds traded in the United States raised more than $2 billion to invest in stock markets outside the country - a record and almost four times the amount raised in any previous year.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: EARTH DAY

title: The Score on Drugs: It Depends on How You See the Figures
description: ''A FEW honest men are better than numbers,'' said Oliver Cromwell in the 17th century. That might still be the case today, as the Bush Administration and its opponents squabble over how to assess the nation's war on drugs.

title:
The Executive Life;

Branded by Drexel, And Still Out of Work
description: LEAD: To wear a Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. windbreaker around town these days is to invite abuse.

title: Technology;   Probing the Cycle of Sleeping and Waking
description: It looks like a typical power plant control room, complete with back issues of Nuclear Engineering magazine. Operators sit at a console, studying computer screens that display ever-changing plant indicators. The lights are low, the sotto voce chatter is mostly technical and the computer hum is often the loudest sound in the room.

title: Auto Insurance 'Reform' Really Isn't
description: The present New Jersey auto insurance reform act demonstrates the inherent weakness of political solutions to economic issues. Such solutions are based on lack of experience in the field and on emotion.

title: 6 Homers Insufficient To Save the Yankees
description: The season has not yet turned to summer, but already the Yankees have met their first crisis. After a quick start, they are suddenly in the midst of a losing streak, they are under .500 for the first time, and they seem to be flailing.

title: Traditions in American Painted Furniture, From 1800
description: HISTORIC HUDSON VALLEY is the organization that takes care of Sunnyside at Tarrytown, the recently opened Montgomery Place in Annandale-on-Hudson and three other estates in the area. Its senior director of museum operations is Joseph T. Butler and its assistant curator is James A. Abbott. Together they have, so to speak, gone on tour to the Scarsdale Historical Society, producing ''American Painted Furniture: 1800 to World War I.''

title: The Rage for Remodeling
description: For some, the need to remodel one ugly-duckling house after another is an incurable bug. For others, it's a necessity: In today's precarious real estate market, it is safer, and often cheaper, to stay put and make do. Whatever the reason, everyone's doing it, or so it seems. According to The National Association of the Remodeling Industry, $102 billion was spent fixing up homes across the country last year, which was $2.5 billion more than in 1988.

title: Ms. Wiltshire Weds G. W. Schomaker
description: Leslie deBenneville Wiltshire and George Warren Schomaker were married yesterday at the Kennebunkport (Me.) Inn by Frederick W. Griffin Jr., the inn's owner and a justice of the peace in Kennebunkport. The bride is a daughter of Mary E. Miller of Kennebunkport and the late Leslie Q. Miller. The bridegroom is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. George Schomaker of Sydney, Australia.

title:
IN SHORT;

NONFICTION
description: LEAD:

title: A Toscanini Edition Befitting a Legend?
description: LEAD: At mid-20th century, no classical musician was more celebrated than the conductor Arturo Toscanini (1867-1957). Active first in Italian opera houses, he enjoyed landmark tenures at the Metropolitan Opera (1908-15), La Scala in Milan (1920-29), the New York Philharmonic (1928-36) and the NBC Symphony Orchestra (1937-54).

title: Bonnie Honig and Michael Whinston, Harvard Professors, to Marry in July
description: The engagement of Bonnie Honig to Michael Dennis Whinston, the son of Dr. George J. Whinston of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Dr. Joan Aronson Whinston, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. David Honig of Montreal. A July wedding is planned.

title: Police Shoot Suspect After Girl, 16, Is Slain
description: A 16-year-old girl was shot to death and two men were seriously wounded in a Washington Heights apartment early yesterday, the police said.

title: 6 Arab Guerrillas Reported Killed in Israeli Attack in Lebanon
description: Israeli soldiers killed six Arab guerrillas of the pro-Iranian Party of God militia in an overnight attack on the group's training headquarters in southeast Lebanon, the army said today.

title: Bucs Sign Anderson
description: Completing a trade with the San Diego Chargers made two days earlier, the Tampa Bay Buccaneers signed the running back Gary Anderson to a four-year, $3.6 million contract yesterday.

title: The Bone-Marrow Transplant Twins
description: They wear matching gold chains with the word ''twin,'' but that only adds to the confusion. When they're apart, even those on the University of Arizona campus who know the Singleton brothers are never quite sure whether it's Chris or Kevin. But when the 6-foot-3-inch identical twins are together now, it's easier to know who's who. Chris is still a husky 245 pounds. Kevin is recuperating from a bone-marrow transplant from his brother after leukemia prevented him from playing football last season.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-19

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of Earth Day celebrations, Broadway will be closed today from 43d to 45th Streets from 1 A.M. to 6 P.M. and the Avenue of the Americas will be closed from 42d to 59th Streets from 8 A.M. to 7 P.M.

title: In Deal With U.S., Milken Won't Be Forced to Testify
description: Michael R. Milken, the financier who agreed Friday to plead guilty to six felony charges and pay $600 million in penalties, is not required to provide evidence of further wrongdoing to the Government as part of the settlement, people who have been briefed on the deal said yesterday.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: India and Pakistan Make the Most of Hard Feelings
description: HEIRS of a shared ancient history, products of the same colonial administration and home to similar peoples and languages, Pakistan and India might be expected to understand and communicate with each other in times of crisis. Yet more than 40 years after their simultaneous creation, their differences have them once again polishing the words and weapons of war.

title: THE NINE-YEAR ITCH
description: A decorator's own home is perhaps the best barometer of his personal style. It is also a laboratory of sorts, a place where ideas are tested and fantasies lived out. That's not to say, however, that decorators redo their homes on a whim. For nine years, the New York designer Mark Hampton and his wife, Duane, were happy with their all-chintz living room - ''until the chintz began to look a little down and dreary,'' Hampton says. ''Then I knew it was time for a change.''

title: When a Spouse Makes a Career Move
description: To the Editor:

title: Pastimes;   Around the Garden
description: For This Week: If earliest daffodils and tulips are fading, snap off flowers to prevent seed pod formation; the thrust of foliage ripening goes toward the bulb and new flowers for next spring. Prune and reshape early-flowering shrubs such as forsythia. Last call to apply pre-emergent herbicides to control seeds of pesky lawn and border weeds.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Baltimore;

Recalling The 1800's
description: LEAD: A 2.2-ACRE downtown block that has defied attempts to develop it for 20 years is finally coming to life as an $18.6 million, 196-unit apartment project rises there.

title: Remember Rootie Kazootie?
description: To the Editor:

title: Fashion;   Inside Out, Sleek or Frilly
description: This spring, underwear is often outer wear. But forget the aggressively sexy brassieres and bustiers Madonna made famous. The new lingerie is subdued. Demure camisoles, bustiers and bodysuits are available in styles, fabrics and trims appropriate for either casual or more formal settings.

title: A Profusion of Remedies
description: For Earth Day, Nicholas Wade reviews a profusion of books prescribing remedies for the environment.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

The Camaraderie and Kindness Of Strangers on a Bus
description: LEAD: THERE'S no rhythm under your feet like that of a moving bus: lurching over bumps, hitting potholes, laboring up asphalt hills, lumbering between stops.

title: Leninist Zeal Is Overtaken By the Blahs
description: Workers of the world, relax.

title: Horst Sindermann; Communist Official in East Germany, 74
description: Horst Sindermann, a powerful East German Communist official ousted in last year's pro-democracy revolt, has died, the official A.D.N. press agency said today. He was 74 years old.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our 50-year-old house has a brick chimney that goes up through the attic, and the bricks are exposed inside the attic. There are four flues inside the chimney, and the bricks in the attic have developed a white, flaky material that my husband calls bloom. There is also a white powder on top of some items stored next to the chimney. The chimney has no cover or cap. What is causing this bloom?

title:
DANCE;

Meeting Challenge of a 'Nonballet'
description: LEAD: ''GOOD choreography feels good to dancers,'' said Lila York, a former dancer with the Paul Taylor Dance Company, who is staging a Taylor work, ''Mercuric Tidings,'' for the Princeton Ballet.

title: Have Women Surrendered In MTV's Battle of the Sexes?
description: Paula Abdul is the hottest material girl of the moment. Her video ''It's Just the Way That You Love Me'' gives a perfect double message. The poor, uneducated beauty is in love with a rich, classy executive type - gray suit and horn-rimmed glasses - who lavishes upon her all the status brand names America has to offer. The beauty insists she only wants the romance. And the sex. She sings: ''It's the way that you love me in the heat of the night . . . I ain't impressed with those material things.''

title: For the Movies, the Bronx Is Up
description: When it comes to the five boroughs of New York, the Bronx usually receives a bad press. No matter that its 42.5 square miles embrace everything from lovely mansions and expansive parklands to alluring retreats like City Island and exciting venues like Yankee Stadium; no matter its ethnic and cultural diversity, the Bronx is usually described in terms reserved for combat zones.

title: New Source of Support For Diabetic Patients
description: LEAD: WHEN 26-year-old Cathy Brunetti delivered her daughter at Northern Westchester Hospital here, she recalled that the nurses were ''amazed'' at how ''healthy - normal weight, everything perfect'' - the child was. Mrs. Brunetti has diabetes, but doctors at the hospital had been monitoring her condition closely, and none of the complications sometimes associated with diabetic pregnancies arose.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: HOPKINTON, R.I.;

Residents Split On Golf Resort
description: LEAD: RESIDENTS of this rural community near the Connecticut border are divided over a proposal by a local developer for Brae Bern, a $55 million development that would be one of the largest golf resort and housing projects in the Northeast.

title: They Need Our Know-How, Not Our Bucks;   Making a Start
description: To the Editor:

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: SISTER BRIGID DRISCOLL;

The Benefits of a 'Women-Only' College
description: LEAD: TWO years ago Wheaton College in Norton, Mass., opened its doors to male students - something many other formerly ''women only'' colleges have also done over the last 20 years. The educational rationale for the changeovers, which were often prompted by the colleges' financial problems, is that co-education is more realistic.

title: KEEPING IT IN-HOUSE
description: STEPHEN MANES'S office has all of the information-age fire power of a modern corporate environment. On his desk are a high-performance computer and monitor, a modem, laser printer, multiline telephone and a fax machine.

title: Centuries of Exceptional Women Gathered in Book
description: LEAD: WHEN Gayle Samuels took on the Women's Project of New Jersey in 1984, she knew she was getting into something big, but she didn't realize its full scope. Nothing like it had been done in the state.

title: Elisa A. Neary to Wed Dr. G. A. San Roman
description: Mr. and Mrs. James F. Neary of Merrick, L.I., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Elisa A. Neary and Dr. Gustavo A. San Roman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Guillermo A. San Roman of Hempstead, L.I.

title: INSIDE
description: Political Climate Changing

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ended April 7

title: Vote for Openness
description: To the Editor:

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Medfield, Mass.;

Colonial Touch Selling Well
description: LEAD: DESPITE a soft market, nine of 11 condominiums have been sold in the $3 million first phase of a project in this suburb of 10,000 people about 40 minutes southwest of Boston.

title: Review/Music;   Double Bill Of Rappers
description: The show at Wetlands on Thursday night, a double bill of the rappers Lakim Shabazz and the group X-Clan, felt a bit like a closed rehearsal. About 50 people showed up to hear mostly mediocre performances that had political intentions but seemed neither fully formed nor acute, and that had the audience cheering mildly, as if by rote.

title: Chad Reports Rebel Deaths
description: Chadian forces attacked Libyan-backed rebels for the second time in three days, killing 103 guerrillas and taking 45 prisoner, the army said today. The fighting took place on Friday along the country's eastern border with Sudan in a reconnaissance operation after a battle on Wednesday that left 517 rebels dead, the high command reported. There was no mention of Government losses.

title: POSTHUMOUS PASSIONS
description: DORIT IN LESBOS

title: A CLEAN SWEEP
description: Maid's rooms and butler's pantries were common in prewar Manhattan apartment buildings, but they seem anachronistic today. Often, these spaces are converted into children's rooms or offices. Another option is to combine them with the kitchen to create an extra-large space - which is what the designer Paloma Picasso decided to do in her New York apartment. ''We gutted four maid's rooms and a pantry,'' says the architect Bonnie Roche, who renovated the kitchen with her colleague Lawrence Kenny. The kitchen now measures 16 by 25 feet and has a decidedly modern style: stainless-steel counters, black-lacquered refrigerator door, a bleached maple floor and distinctive green-colored glass adorning the table and back-splashes. ''The painted glass is a space-expanding trick,'' says Roche. ''The squares in the door provide a glimpse of the room beyond.''

title: Storytellers Living Happily Ever After
description: LEAD: WHEN Kate McClelland goes shopping, she often returns to her car to find notes stuffed under her windshield wiper, asking questions like, ''How can I find out about the storytelling?''

title: A Balanchine Bouquet
description: The highlight of the New York City Ballet's eight-week spring season, which opens Tuesday at the New York State Theater, will be a celebration of the dances of Jerome Robbins, so long a part of the company as both choreographer and a director. Three sailors romp through shore leave in ''Fancy Free,'' the earliest of the 26 works in the Robbins festival, while at the opposite end of the spectrum are ''Watermill'' and ''Glass Pieces,'' two of his most abstract creations.

title: SCHUYLERVILLE STANDS STILL
description: James Kunstler failed, for the most part, to record any of the good things about Schuylerville. He didn't mention the purchase of a piano for the high school from public donations, to honor a beloved teacher. He failed to mention the financial and emotional support given a budding Olympian en route to Calgary. He failed to note the community theater.

title: Campus Life: Emory;   Racial Attacks Leave Freshman In Severe Shock
description: Repeated written and verbal racial attacks, varying from epithets scrawled around her dormitory room to death threats sent through the campus mail, have rendered an Emory University freshman almost mute.

title: O'Neill's 'Anna Christie' Revived at Long Wharf
description: SO what if ''Anna Christie'' is second-rank Eugene O'Neill? The cast of the ripping production at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven is going at it with such conviction and bravura that it might as well be one of the playwright's towering achievements.

title: Melissa Hatch Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. John C. Hatch of Dover, Mass., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter, Melissa M. Hatch, and Jon K. Hirschtick, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel Hirschtick of Des Plaines, Ill. Miss Hatch, 28 years old and a graduate of Wheelock College, is an account executive at the Hatch-Anderson-O'Donnell Insurance Agency in Arlington, Mass. Mr. Hirschtick, 27, founded and heads the Premise software company in Cambridge, Mass. He received an undergraduate degree and a master's in engineering from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

title: Evicted By an Act of Congress
description: IN the five-room ranch house in Fairfield dotted with braided rugs and quilted pillows, Janet O'Donnell stands over the stove, turning pork chops, while her 3-year-old son, Patrick, curls up on the couch with his puppy. The plaque above the pantry door says, ''Home Sweet Home.'' Mrs. O'Donnell and her family moved into the house just three months ago, and now they are being evicted. Their landlord is the Pentagon.

title: Why Laura Dean Is Happy to Be A Major Minimalist Holdout
description: ''I'm not a choreographer,'' Laura Dean insists. ''I'm a choreographer/composer - there's no word for it yet; it doesn't exist in the dictionary.''

title: BUSINESS DIARY: April 15-20
description: COMPANIES

title: PRIVATE PLACES
description: When a man lives alone, his dressing room is as important as any room in the house,'' says the fashion designer Bill Blass. ''And it's especially nice to have everything out in the open, so you can see all your clothes at once.'' Blass's home was originally two apartments: The present dressing room had been a small guest bedroom; the revamped bath, a kitchen and bathroom. For the renovation of both spaces, Blass called on the New York interior designers Chessy Rayner and Mica Ertegun of MAC II. The new dressing room, with its Old Master drawings, bronze sculptures and World War I portrait, is inviting and masculine. The enlarged bathroom has a sleeker look, with brown epoxy paint applied to glass walls. Replacing the shower curtain is a clear-glass panel-''a practical, modern solution,'' says Rayner.

title: London's Turn
description: Having two major marathons on the same day may seem perverse, but for leading runners, the resulting bidding war to attract top talent can mean a bonanza.

title: ALDO ROSSI: SENTIMENT FOR THE UNSENTIMENTAL
description: Today in Los Angeles the Hyatt Foundation will announce that it is awarding the Pritzker Prize to Aldo Rossi, the architect from Milan whose brooding and thoughtful work was known mainly in academic circles until a few years ago, when he began to attract commissions for major commercial and institutional buildings around the world. Mr. Rossi, whose largest American project is the architecture school for the University of Miami at Coral Gables, now under construction, will be 59 years old next month. He is the 13th winner of the Pritzker Prize, which has come to be known as architecture's closest equivalent to the Nobel.

title: Fernandez Shuts Out Expos On 2 Hits
description: After 13 games, the Mets, a team that is so talented and has been so touted, achieved some milestones at Shea Stadium yesterday that seemed a bit overdue.

title: Shaping Up for Slopes When Snow Is Gone
description: IN the spring, most skiers forget about skiing until November, when snow will be on the ground again. But a growing number of people are finding alternative ways to improve skills, correct bad habits and strengthen muscles used in skiing.

title: Bridge
description: Very few deals are suitable for the old challenge: ''Would you like to play or defend?'' The diagramed layout is one of that select minority. How do you fancy your chances in five diamonds redoubled after the lead of the heart ace?

title: Services for Abernathy
description: In the church where he preached for 30 years, the Rev. Ralph David Abernathy was mourned today by civil rights leaders and citizens as a man ''high up on the honor roll'' of the battle for racial equality.

title: Three in Teaneck Will Talk Only to a State Grand Jury
description: Three women, all neighbors on the street where a teen-ager was shot and killed by a police officer earlier this month and considered witnesses in the case, announced today that they would testify before a state grand jury investigating the shooting but would not speak with the local authorities.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Accounts
description: * American Safety Razor Co., to Korey, Kay & Partners, with a budget of $4 million.

title: Ministers in Poor Areas Arming Against Crime
description: Ministers in poor neighborhoods are arming themselves with bats, knives and guns to fend off criminals who threaten their property and their lives.

title: In Europe, the Intentions Outpace Real Progress
description: Western Europeans observed Earth Day by staging demonstrations, climbing mountains and planting trees today, but these events served to make clear that growing public support for environmental protection has brought little change in the way the nations deal with nature.

title: How a Conductor Brought Harmony To East Germany's Peaceful Revolt
description: To New Yorkers he is the future music director of the New York Philharmonic, but to the people of East Germany, especially those of Leipzig, Kurt Masur is a hero of the revolution that overthrew Communist rule and the man who might have been President.

title: Victims' Rights Are Supported At a Memorial
description: Several hundred people, many of whose relatives or friends had been murdered or assaulted, gathered at a church in Manhattan yesterday to remember the victims of violent crime.

title: Army Command Seen as Tough Test for Chamorro
description: With just three days left before she is to take office, President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro is under increasing pressure to make important decisions about Nicaragua's future military leadership, in what her supporters and opponents alike believe will be a crucial test of her authority.

title: Who Puts Back the Cash in the Cash Machines' Caches?
description: In a world of workerless robot-controlled assembly lines, guideless recorded guided tours, chefless microwaveable fast food and tellerless night-and-day banks, there are consumers out there who always seem to run short and wonder why cash machines hardly ever do.

title: Defense Rules Field In Draft
description: Jeff George said he preferred playing for his hometown Indianapolis Colts, but could have been happy anywhere. He said there was no added burden he could not bear playing professionally so close to his backyard, and no, he was not all surprised that the week preceding the National Football League's 55th annual draft yesterday offered the unusual events that made his becoming a Colt a reality.

title: And Then There Were Seven
description: Washington always had two ways of gaining the release of American hostages held captive in Lebanon. One was high-risk military operations against Syria, Iran or Shiite terrorists in Lebanon. The second was to wait quietly, depreciate the hostage currency and hope that the leaders in Teheran and Damascus would find reasons to solve the problem themselves. Robert Polhill's steps to freedom on Sunday represent a vindication of the second strategy.

title: NEW YORK RALLY BACKS LITHUANIA
description: More than 1,000 demonstrators waving Lithuanian flags rallied outside the Soviet Mission to the United Nations yesterday to protest economic measures taken against Lithuania by the Soviet Government and to call on the United States to recognize the Baltic republic's independence.

title: Jets' Big Surprise: Unsurprising Pick
description: Surprise. The Jets shocked no one with their first pick in the draft today.

title: Oilers Take 3-0 Series Lead
description: Craig Simpson scored twice and launched Edmonton's comeback from a two-goal deficit as the Oilers beat the Los Angeles Kings, 5-4, tonight to take a lead of 3 games to 0 in their Smythe Division final series.

title: Two-Year Notes to Be Sold This Week
description: Treasury financings this week include today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of new two-year notes on Wednesday.

title: Soviet Party Official Denies Plans for Total Blockade of Lithuania
description: A senior Soviet Communist Party official denied today that the Kremlin was planning a total blockade of Lithuania.

title: POPE WILL SUMMON BISHOPS TO ASSESS COMMUNISM'S FALL
description: As he crossed this country carrying a message of European unity and liberty, Pope John Paul II said today that he would call a special synod of Europe's Roman Catholic bishops to consider the religious and social implications of Communism's collapse.

title: New Police Chiefs Put New Ideas on the Force
description: When Robert Wadman became Police Chief in Aurora, Ill., last October, the first thing he did was summon a maintenance man. Mr. Wadman had him remove the door to the chief's office and store it in the basement.

title: First Boston's New Offering
description: A new financing wrinkle in the burgeoning asset-backed securities market was introduced last week by investment bankers at the First Boston Corporation.

title: Louisiana Prison Editor Waits Governor's Word
description: For Wilbert Rideau, who became a journalist while serving a life sentence in the Louisiana State Penitentiary at Angola, 15 minutes of fame have stretched to 14 years.

title: Review/Television;   A Subtly Guided Tour Of a Park and Its People
description: No doubt there are goings-on that Frederick Wiseman missed in ''Central Park,'' his latest television essay on an American phenomenon, but not many. The three-hour tour, at 8 tonight on Channel 13, delivers flora, fauna and, mostly, the folks Mr. Wiseman encountered during five weeks in May and June 1988.

title: Crum & Forster Shift
description: Crum & Forster Inc., a unit of the Xerox Corporation, said last week that it would withdraw from standard personal insurance to concentrate on commercial insurance, specialty coverages and reinsurance. Crum & Forster will immediately begin to close Crum & Forster Personal Insurance, whose share of the standard insurance market is less than 1 percent and represents about 11 percent of Crum & Forster's business. About 950 Crum & Forster Personal Insurance employees will be laid off. Crum & Forster Inc. has about 10,600 workers.

title: INSIDE
description: Israel Underwrites Settlers

title: Newspaper Advertising Continues To Weaken
description: With advertising soft and profits down at many dailies, the annual convention of the nation's newspaper publishers, which starts here on Monday, is not expected to be a particularly happy affair.

title: Music and, Oh Yes, Earth Day in Park
description: So many people converged on Central Park for Earth Day yesterday that Beth Cramer, sitting on the park's Great Lawn, could not see many of the speakers denouncing the degradation of the environment on the dais in front of her.

title: Seizure by U.S. In California
description: Federal regulators seized First Network Savings Bank, a small savings and loan institution on Friday, and said they had referred the matter to the Justice Department for a possible criminal fraud investigation.

title: Israel Says It Helped Finance Settlers in Christian Quarter
description: The Israeli Government acknowledged tonight that it had secretly provided almost $2 million to help establish a new Jewish settlement in the Christian quarter of Jerusalem's Old City 10 days ago.

title: Report on New York Deplores Slowness of Environmental Reviews
description: Lengthy and unpredictable environmental reviews in New York City are hampering the development of new homes, schools and businesses, a prominent business group says.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I am sorry I kept you waiting so long. Thirty-nine months is a long time.''

title: Question Box
description: Oldest N.B.A. Arena

title: Texas High Court Cuts Into Secrecy in Civil Suits
description: The Texas Supreme Court has adopted rules sharply restricting the practice of sealing court records after civil suits are settled. The decision could allow much greater access to material that parties to a lawsuit would rather keep secret.

title: One Family Is Relieved; 2 Must Wait
description: It was a day of joy for one family that had not been expecting it and a disappointment for two that had held out hope.

title: Phnom Penh Journal;   Come to the Land of Angkor, War and Profiteers
description: In that hazy period more than 20 years ago, before Cambodia became a scene of genocide, and notables like Jacqueline Kennedy were visiting the temples of Angkor, some 60,000 tourists a year came to Cambodia and 200,000 visited Thailand.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: G.O.P. Fears It Is Losing Points on Environment
description: Rising public concern about the environment looms like smog across the Republican Party's political horizon.

title: National League;   Braves Stop Reds' Streak
description: The Cincinnati Reds figured they would stay unbeaten until they ran into a hot pitcher. And Tom Glavine of the Atlanta Braves proved them right.

title: Runners Feel Buoyed By Pool Training
description: A NEW training approach that improves running speed with almost no risk of injury is causing more and more performance-minded runners to get their feet wet.

title: Syracuse Wall Salutes 35 Students Killed on Jet
description: The memory of the 35 students killed when terrorists bombed Pan Am Flight 103 will endure as long as Syracuse University stands, Chancellor Melvin Eggers said today as the school dedicated a memorial to the students.

title: Norton Hints Of New Bid
description: A third party may be interested in paying more for the Norton Company than BTR P.L.C. has offered, Norton said Friday in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Norton did not disclose the identity of the interested party or state what the purchase price might be.

title: Beijing Reports 22 Deaths In Revolt in Western Region
description: China said today that 22 people were killed and at least 13 wounded in an armed rebellion in its far-western region of Xinjiang this month.

title: In Hong Kong, a Deepening Sense of Despair and Betrayal
description: The feeling of betrayal is heavy in the Hong Kong air, but when people here dissect the territory's crisis, they sometimes speak most bitterly not of hard-liners in Beijing but of Government officials in London.

title: When Plant Shuts Down, Retraining Laid-Off Workers Is Toughest Job Yet
description: Spread over miles of fissured asphalt and chain-link fences, blocks beyond the western edge of Chicago, lie the carcasses of once mighty factories.

title: Business Scene;   Difficult Switch For Arms Makers
description: AS military spending shrinks, the big names in American weapons manufacturing - companies like Raytheon, Grumman, General Dynamics and Boeing Helicopter - should be making plans to switch to civilian products. They are not. Naturally, these companies are reluctant to give up steady, profitable military work. More important, America's weapons makers say their operations are not suited for civilian production.

title: Rockets Land A Berth
description: The Houston Rockets won the final Western Conference playoff berth tonight in their last game of the season as they beat the Utah Jazz by 100-88.

title: Yanks' 10-4 Loss Puts Skid at Five
description: At the end of the day, Bucky Dent sat on one corner of the manager's desk and shook his head. If he was trying to rid himself of the memory of losing five games in succession, it probably did not work.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Below are the major economic indicators to be released this week.

title: Review/Opera;   'Gotterdammerung' Ends Met 'Ring'
description: ''Gotterdammerung,'' which received its first performance of the Metropolitan Opera season on Saturday afternoon, is the longest, perhaps musically richest, most muddled opera in ''Der Ring des Nibelungen.'' Its libretto, which Wagner wrote before the other ''Ring'' texts, is the most conventionally operatic, and its use of magic potions adds a disconcerting element of psychological inconsistency: in Wagner's other operas, magic is clearly a metaphor for human behavior; here, it just makes the world's greatest hero look like a louse.

title:
ON YOUR OWN;

Tennis Theater in the Park
description: LEAD: COURT 17 is occupied by a pair of intense young men for whom every point is a grave matter. On Court 18, a mixed doubles group is enjoying every aspect of the game - even double faults (especially double faults). Two middle-aged men on Court 6 have apparently reserved time for bickering since it's 25 minutes past the hour and there's no sign of strings on ball yet - just a lot of back-and-forth finger pointing.

title: World to Vilnius: Suffer
description: When an individual becomes a dissident, he or she is seen by the outside world as a hero: a Sakharov or Mandela stirs the conscience of the world. But when a captive nation becomes a dissident, its resistance to oppression becomes an inconvenience to mankind; it is accused of being an impediment to the Big Picture, a threat to worshipers of the idol of Stability.

title: Furor Over British Poll Tax Imperils Thatcher Ideology
description: The last time a British Government imposed a uniform poll tax on its citizens - in 1381 - a mob invaded the Tower of London, where the King's ministers had taken refuge, and beheaded the Chancellor of the Exchequer.

title: Sports of The Times;   Steinberg Spurns 'Dee-fense'
description: ONLY time will tell. But the Jets' future could turn on Dick Steinberg's first personnel decision as the team's new general manager. Turn up toward the Super Bowl or turn down to another treadmill.

title: AIDS WAR SHUNNED BY MANY DOCTORS
description: Nine years into the AIDS epidemic, most of the nation's physicians are still failing to take part in the fight to treat and control the deadly disease, many health experts say.

title: Chairman of Horsham Adding Chief's Post
description: Peter Munk, a Canadian entrepreneur and chairman of the Horsham Corporation, has been named chief executive as well. His longtime associate, Jerry Garbutt, will be president and chief operating officer.

title: Colombian Cocaine: Tracking Down Dealers - A special report.;   A Covert and Major Victory Is Reported in the Drug War
description: For Richard T. Garcia, the turning point came when three customers, whom he knew to be Colombian cocaine dealers, began discussing whether they were being recorded. One of them, Javier Mendez, pointed to a wall in Mr. Garcia's small electronics shop here and said, ''If they record your voice, you can always say it's not you, but when they put you on video, then they've caught you.''

title: And Still No Honest Apology
description: LEAD: That's my son Jeff - the boy on the ground.

title: CHRONICLE
description: COUNT PAOLO MARZOTTO, a philanthropist who heads a new preservation group in Italy, will be honored by the World Monuments Fund at a lunch Thursday at the Mayfair Regent. The Comitato Italiano, which wants to raise $1 million a year for the preservation of Italian art and architecture, has adopted three projects which will be supported with matching grants from American sponsors. The count, whose family is from Vicenza, called it the first such private effort on a national scale. Until now, major efforts had been financed and directed by the Italian Government. ''Given the importance of what the World Monuments Fund has done in Italy in the last 20 years, I felt many Italians would like to get involved,'' he said.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Magazines Sold
description: Capital Cities/ABC has agreed to sell the magazines Compute!, Compute's Gazette, Compute's PC and Compute's Amiga Resource to General Media International, whose other titles include Omni and Penthouse. Terms were not disclosed. General Media said it would reduce the frequency of Compute!, a monthly, and would ''evaluate'' the other three computer magazines.

title: Argentina Tries to Sell Its Shaky Phone System
description: Every morning, at telephone offices in cities and towns across Argentina, people line up to tell horror stories about telephones that do not work, telephones they cannot get or bills that seem outrageous.

title: Books of The Times;   Peering Into a Family's Haunted Past
description: The Music Room

title: 30,000 Indians Celebrate Their Culture
description: Thirty thousand Indians from all over North America were here this weekend for a celebration of pride and culture.

title: Seoul Seeks Link in North
description: South Korea will seek joint oil exploration with North Korea as part of efforts to make the economies of the two countries interdependent, Government officials said Friday.

title: U.S. Team Loses To Colombia, 1-0
description: It was more of the usual for the United States soccer team today: little offense, a defensive mixup and another loss.

title: Johanna Lief Wed To John Socolow
description: Johanna Lief and John Miller Socolow were married yesterday at the Harmonie Club in New York by Rabbi Gary Bretton-Granatoor.

title: CHRONICLE
description: One of the largest AIDS research laboratories in the world is to open in New York next October, thanks primarily to IRENE L. DIAMOND, who gave the city $8 million to establish the research center. Next week, MAYOR DAVID N. DINKINS will present her with the 1990 Lambda Liberty Award from the Lambda Legal Defense and Education Fund. Mrs. Diamond is president of the Aaron Diamond Foundation, named after her late husband, a real-estate developer.

title: Days Inns Plan in India
description: Days Inns of the United States and an Indian corporation plan to collaborate on a chain of hotels in India aimed at travelers on modest budgets.

title: Rising Costs Fuel a Partisan Senate Debate on Campaign Spending
description: Amid the most insistent calls since Watergate to revamp the way political campaigns are paid for and run, the Senate is expected to begin debate on a campaign financing bill this week, tackling an issue seen as critical to each member's political survival.

title: Police Plan Offers Treatment For Drug Dealers Who Ask
description: When the knock at the door comes at the homes of suspected drug dealers in New Haven this week, the police officers outside the door may be offering help.

title: Rangers Wonder if Ciccarelli Will Play
description: zris King, who searched his memory without success when asked to recall his collision with Dino Ciccarelli in the immediate aftermath of a 6-3 loss Saturday night to the Washington Capitals, stood in front of the videotape machine this afternoon and conducted a more productive search with the remote control.

title: Washington Talk;   Selling Congress New Taxes On Flying
description: Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner likens promoting the Administration's new aviation program in Congress to selling I.B.M. computers, his job in the 1960's. Both are good products, he says, but this one is a harder sell.

title: Microsoft Set To Add to Staff
description: The Microsoft Corporaton said today that it plans to add at least 1,000 employees this year, increasing its worldwide employment by about 20 percent.

title: James Stewart Nods at Lady Luck For His Golden Age Film Career
description: A director who worked with him just after he arrived in Hollywood in 1935 once described him as ''unusually usual.'' Even with a pair of Oscars on his mantel and after a distinguished career of more than 70 films in which he played everything from idealistic young swains to ruthless bounty hunters, James Stewart still likes to cast himself in the role of the average guy who owes everything he has to hard work and lucky breaks.

title: BEIRUT KIDNAPPERS FREE AMERICAN, 55, A HOSTAGE 3 YEARS
description: Robert Polhill, a 55-year-old American taken hostage more than three years ago in Beirut by pro-Iranian kidnappers, was released into the custody of Syrian Army officers on Sunday.

title: Paying for Politics: New York's Model
description: The early success of New York City's new campaign financing system offers a healthy example to the country. Ably administered by an independent Campaign Finance Board led by the Rev. Joseph O'Hare, president of Fordham University, the system has replaced a regime that featured huge gifts from favor-seeking fat cats. But improvements are still needed, notably to make participation more attractive to City Council candidates.

title: Cavaliers Beat Knicks, 115-99
description: The Knicks' regular season, which began in November with great expectations, ended here today in defeat and disappointment.

title: Candy Maker Dealt Blow on Sugar Quotas
description: A Chicago candy maker's request to buy sugar at world prices instead of at the sharply higher domestic United States price has been rejected by a Commerce Department examiner, Congressional aides and industry officials say.

title: Yugoslavia Hopes for Free Vote in '90
description: After voting in the first parliamentary elections to be held in Croatia in more than five decades, Prime Minister Ante Markovic said today that the Yugoslav Government intends to conduct free, multiparty national elections before the end of this year.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of April 22, 1990:

title: Telling Erin's Story
description: To the Editor:

title: Time for Reconciliation Of German-Polish Strife
description: To the Editor:

title: No Overflow Field Expected for Derby
description: Of the 30 Triple Crown nominees who raced in major prep races Saturday, fewer than 10 are likely to run in the Kentucky Derby on May 5, a race that is looking more and more interesting and less and less likely to attract an overflow field.

title: Wall Street's Latest Racquet
description: IT is hardly surprising that squash, a game long associated with the leisure class, supposedly got its 19th-century start among the most leisured class of all, debtors confined to London's Fleet Prison.

title: Nigeria Reports It Foiled a Coup By Army Rebels
description: Nigeria announced today that troops loyal to the military Government of Gen. Ibrahim Babangida had thwarted an attempted coup, forcing rebel officers to surrender after 11 hours of fighting.

title: U.S. Mergers Firm Is Forming British Link
description: In a sign of Europe's increasing importance in the merger business, the Blackstone Group, a New York merchant banking concern, is forming an alliance with a British mergers firm.

title: Lincoln Cites 2 U.S. Memos
description: Lawyers for Charles H. Keating Jr. last week disclosed two internal Government memos that had warned Federal officials to be on the lookout for former employees of Lincoln Savings and Loan Association seeking new jobs in the savings industry.

title: No 'Horrible Design Flaw' in the Space Station
description: To the Editor:

title: Turkish Dam Drowning History of the Kurds
description: To the Editor:

title: The Move to Modular Software
description: A vast transformation is beginning in the way computer programs are designed. The change promises to allow software to be produced more quickly and to make computers easier to use.

title: At Lincoln Center, It's Regilding Time
description: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, preparing for the onset of the outdoor season and eager to make new friends, is treating itself to a multimillion-dollar shoeshine. Part of the tab, $17.7 million, is being picked up by the city.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   People
description: * Bill Croasdale, director of national broadcast media and program development, and Jerry Bonsaing, group director of spot broadcast, have been named executive vice presidents at Backer Spielvogel Bates.

title: The 17 Westerners Left Behind in Captivity
description: With the release yesterday of Robert Polhill, 17 Westerners, including 7 Americans, are missing in Lebanon and believed held by kidnappers.

title: FOCUS ON HUMANS, CARDINAL CAUTIONS
description: Amid all the Earth Day hoopla, John Cardinal O'Connor of New York added a note of caution yesterday. ''The earth exists for the human person and not vice versa,'' he said in his homily at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: As 6th Cabby Is Slain in Bronx, More Police Action Is Ordered
description: A gypsy-cab driver was found shot dead yesterday in the Bronx, the sixth cabdriver slain in the borough in less than seven weeks, the police said.

title: TEXAS CANDIDATE ADMITS BUYING SEX
description: Clayton Williams, the Republican candidate for Governor, acknowledged in an interview published today that he had patronized prostitutes as a young man.

title: People Day
description: The word of the day was not dissent, as it was for the original Earth Day 20 years ago, but descent. There was barely any dissent at all; have a million people, more or less, ever been more agreeable than they were yesterday, jammed in and around the Great Lawn of New York's Central Park?

title: Review/Dance;   The Washington Ballet As It Changes Directions
description: The founder and artistic director of the Washington Ballet is Mary Day, who is also one of the country's best teachers of classical ballet.

title: Pardon North, Poindexter and the Rest
