description: LEAD: Bound by his mandate, the independent counsel Lawrence Walsh has vowed to press on with his increasingly tedious investigation into the Iran-contra swamp of evasion and forgetfulness. Someone should put him - and the country - out of this misery, and I have an idea who.

title: Polish Police Accused in a Fatal Fire
description: A fire today swept through the apartment of an investigative journalist who has exposed abuses by the secret police, killing his wife, and the incident was immediately seized upon by critics who contend the Solidarity-led Government is moving too slowly in destroying the remnants of the Communist security apparatus.

title: Pamela Duke Is Wed
description: Pamela Myra Duke and Laurent Guy were married yesterday by Cantor Mark Lipson at the Manchester, Conn., home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Martin Duke. Mrs. Guy, 27 years old, graduated from Swarthmore College and is a third-year medical student at the University of Connecticut. Mr. Guy, 30, a son of Alain Georges Guy and Anne Schofield Guy, both of Paris, is a strategic service manager at Andersen Consulting in Hartford. He graduated from Swarthmore and received an M.B.A. degree from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

title: Court Clears Bid for Utility
description: A bankruptcy reorganization plan for the Public Service Company of New Hampshire was cleared on Friday in Federal court, two years after the state's largest utility filed for bankruptcy protection.

title: Penn Varsity Wins in Sprint
description: Pennsylvania's heavyweight crew staged a searing sprint finish today to defeat Brown and capture the featured varsity championship at the Redwood Shores-Stanford Crew classic.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   Old at Home
description: The setting: Manhattan's wealthy Upper East Side. The time: a cold, rainy afternoon in late March. The characters: a young woman from the Visiting Nurse Service of New York and three patients, for whom she represents the difference between living at home and living in a home for the aged.

title: A Warning to Would-Be Federal Judges
description: Imagine you are a lawyer looking to join a private club in your community, one known to be a good place to expand your business and professional opportunities. You meet all the necessary qualifications for membership except one: You are a woman and the club bars women.

title: Reds Find Relief With 'Nasty' Bunch On and Off Mound
description: THEY are known collectively as the Nasty Boys. No label would seem more appropriate for Randy Myers, Rod Dibble, Norm Charlton, Tim Birtsas and Tim Layana, otherwise known as the Cincinnati Reds' relief corps.

title: With Boycott and Ads, A Battle Over Selling
description: In Empire, Calif., some 400 copies of ''Little Red Ridinghood'' are locked away in a storage room of the public school district because the classic Grimm's fairy tale recounts that the little girl took a bottle of wine to her grandmother.

title: Review/Theater;   The Life and Rhythms Of Mahalia Jackson
description: In the liveliest scene of the new gospel musical ''Truly Blessed: A Musical Celebration of Mahalia Jackson,'' Queen Esther Marrow, who portrays the legendary gospel singer, endures interrogation by a team of musicologists at a New England symposium.

title: Lantern Lights the Way for Less
description: rrThe traditional outdoor lantern has been redesigned to burn unleaded gasoline instead of more costly products such as white gas, propane and butane.

title: Poland's Jobless Rising
description: Continuing its steep upward climb, unemployment in Poland reached nearly one-third of a million in mid-April, a Labor Ministry official said Friday. He said the number of people out of work had risen to 318,000, up from 266,572 at the end of March.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf

title: Arson Burns Buildings In Hasidic Community
description: A fire apparently caused by arson destroyed a commercial building under construction and damaged a shopping plaza in this Hasidic Jewish community, the police said today.

title: Philip Amram, 90; Led U.S. Delegation To World Law Talks
description: Philip Werner Amram, an expert on international private law and chairman of the United States delegation to the 1972 Hague Conference on International Private Law, died on Friday at the Allendale Nursing Home in Allendale, N.J. after a long illness. He was 90 years old and had lived in Washington more than 40 years.

title: Big Manhattan Rally For Armenian Victims
description: Thousands of Armenian-Americans gathered in Times Square yesterday afternoon to commemorate the 75th anniversary of the mass killing of Armenian civilians during World War I by the Ottoman Empire.

title: Report Cites Higher Danger Of Crime That Blacks Face
description: Blacks are more likely than whites to be victims of rape or aggravated assault and are more than twice as likely to be victims of robberies, the Justice Department reported today.

title: Lyons Festival to Focus On U.S. Dance Troupes
description: Seventeen American dance companies will perform in An American Story: A Century of Dance in the United States, the three-week Lyons Biennial festival that begins on Sept. 13 in Lyons, France. The Biennial, announced last week at the Cultural Services of the French Embassy, will include classics and new works of modern dance, as well as ballet, tap and folk dance. Six French dance companies and choreographers will also participate, in dances representing Isadora Duncan and Loie Fuller and works about American culture.

title: Lillian H. Planer, 86, Writer of Radio Series
description: Lillian H. Planer, a radio and screen writer in the 1940's, died after a long illness on Friday at her home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. She was 86 years old.

title: Linda Sheer Wed To Colin L. Jones
description: Linda G. Sheer and Colin L. Jones were married yesterday at the Bronxville (N.Y.) Field Club by the Rev. Ralph Ciampa, a Methodist minister. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fred W. Sheer of Bronxville. Mr. Jones is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Jones of Manotick, Ontario.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   An Unusual New Shop In Detroit
description: THERE is not much variety in the resumes of most advertising agency chairmen; their forte is either creating ads or running a business. Not so with the leaders of Cognos Advertising Inc., an unconventional new agency in Detroit. It's co-chairmen are black Baptist preachers, who have enlisted in their cause a white Southerner who co-founded Atlanta's first nationally esteemed agency.

title: Tektronix Head Ousted; Poor Earnings Are Cited
description: Three years after his surprise promotion to president and chief executive of Tektronix Inc. over higher-ranking colleagues, David P. Friedly resigned on Friday at the request of the company's board. Tektronix said a search for a new president and chief executive had begun.

title: Giants Do Better Than Expected
description: As the National Football League draft started yesterday, the Giants were looking for a running back, a quarterback and a pass rusher. On four of the day's five rounds, they got there by taking a highly rated running back, two pass-rushing defensive linemen and an obscure quarterback.

title: Millions Join Battle for a Beloved Planet
description: Two decades after the birth of the modern environmental movement, millions of people around the nation and the world renewed the call to arms for an endangered planet yesterday with an exuberant and bittersweet celebration of Earth Day 1990.

title: Iran Reportedly Gave Weapons To Obtain U.S. Hostage Release
description: The Iranian Government gave Muslim fundamentalists in Lebanon weapons and financial assistance to persuade them to release American hostages, according to security officials here.

title: Conde Nast's Gamble: Creating Yet Another Image for Self
description: After 11 years of proclaiming the importance of self-renewal to women, Self magazine is renewing itself. Again. But this time it's different, insists Alexandra Penney, Self's fourth editor in chief since 1979. It involves a complete remake of the monthly magazine. A new cover look. An explosion of graphics throughout the magazine. Bolder uses of color.

title: Newborn Twin's Heart Transplanted to Sister
description: Doctors have saved the life of a baby girl born with a fatal heart defect by giving her the heart of her brain-dead twin brother.

title: Heavy Dues
description: FOR the corporate executive who has everything, there is something new he doesn't have.

title: Property Taxes Should Be Passed Along to Regulated Rents Too;   Unfair Valuation
description: To the Editor:

title: Johnny Beazley; Ex-Pitcher, 71
description: Johnny Beazley, who won two games in the 1942 World Series as a rookie to help the St. Louis Cardinals beat the New York Yankees, died Saturday after having suffered from cancer. He was 71 years old.

title: Critic's Notebook;   On Coughs, Beeps and Wrappers, The Bane of a Performer's Life
description: Pity the performer. No amount of planning, rehearsal or mental preparation can insure a musician against intrusions from the natural or urban environment or from the audience: the rare earthquake, the occasional siren outside the hall or the commonplace crinkle of candy wrappers.

title: Bush Denies Any Deal With Iran for Release
description: Administration officials said today that the release of the American hostage Robert Polhill was the result of months of messages to the Iranians that if they wanted better relations with Washington, they would have to unconditionally release all hostages.

title: Property Taxes Should Be Passed Along to Regulated Rents Too
description: To the Editor:

title: American League;   Jackson Clouts One as Royals Win, 7-1
description: Bo Jackson hit his first home run of the season and Tom Gordon allowed five hits in seven innings today to lead the Kansas City Royals over the Toronto Blue Jays, 7-1.

title: Metro Matters;   Now It's the Law, But New Charter Still Riles Koch
description: When Mayor David N. Dinkins named the final seven members of a politically crucial commission last week, the panel closely reflected New York City's population: seven whites, four blacks, three Hispanic members and one Asian-American.

title: Philip Morris Cigarette Vote
description: If a Catholic priest from New York has his way, the Philip Morris Companies will stop making and selling cigarettes by the year 2000.

title: This Is Where I Came in
description: The more things change, the French say, the more they stay the same. Now that Bush Administration officials have disclosed plans to spend $35 million to train the Peruvian Army to fight the Shining Path guerrillas, Americans can sing, ''It seems to me I've heard that song before.''

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Publishing;   The World Is Often Too Much to Grasp
description: AS big publishing houses have gone on an international buying spree, ''globalization'' has become the buzzword of the industry. But now, some people are wondering whether there are really that many advantages in being a worldwide book business.

title: Lawyer Aims to Shift Blame To a Bensonhurst Witness
description: In the Bensonhurst murder case, Stephen G. Murphy, a defense lawyer, has a simple argument. ''She's the one who is really responsible for this whole thing,'' he says repeatedly.

title: Slow Death for Drexel in Japan
description: The improbably sudden collapse of the Drexel Burnham Lambert Group shocked Wall Street in February, as did the United States Government's willingness to stand aside as the firm crumbled to financial rubble. But one of those caught most off guard was Masahiko Yamamoto, manager of Drexel's Tokyo branch.

title: After Struggle, Musical on Dr. King Is Opening
description: Last Thursday, just four nights before the opening here of ''King,'' a new musical about the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., the show's producers were trying to put a bright face on all the adversity they had experienced in bringing their musical to the London stage.

title: No 'Horrible Design Flaw' in the Space Station;   Mission of Settlement
description: To the Editor:

title: Almodovar Appeals X Given to His New Film
description: The Spanish film director Pedro Almodovar has appealed a decision by the Motion Picture Association of America to award his latest film, ''Tie Me Up! Tie Me Down!,'' an X rating. The rating restricts the film to audiences aged 17 and over and could threaten Mr. Almodovar's chances of matching the commercial success of his film ''Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown,'' which was nominated for an Academy Award for best foreign film last year.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Calvin Klein Tops Ad Poll
description: Once again, Calvin Klein can take credit for the top print campaign of the year, said Commercial Break, the newsletter of Video Storyboard Tests, an advertising research organization based in New York.

title: Unions Oppose Icahn
description: Forty-six union presidents representing 18,000 employees of the USX Corporation said they opposed Carl C. Icahn's proposal to split the company's steel and energy assets. Mr. Icahn, USX's largest shareholder, has proposed spinning off the company's steel business, saying two companies will be worth more than one.

title: Business Digest
description: The Economy

title: Floods Ravage Australia
description: Australia's worst floods in a century cut off outback towns and forced hundreds of people to take refuge on the roofs of their submerged homes today in the eastern states of Queensland, New South Wales and Victoria. The authorities say many people have been reported missing but only one death was reported.

title: Schuster Backs Away From Grove Deal
description: Simon & Schuster, which had been expected to buy Grove Weidenfeld, has abruptly withdrawn its bid, executives in the publishing industry said yesterday.

title: Nets Lose and Set Some Sorry Marks
description: It was fitting that the Nets ended their season tonight by losing to an expansion team, the Orlando Magic, 110-102.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Shift at The National
description: The National, a daily sports newspaper started in January, has reorganized its marketing department into an advertising sales development department. The job of marketing director, which had been held by Emmett Green, was eliminated. Peter A. Spina, the paper's advertising sales director, said his department needed the marketing team to provide it with research and promotional work.

title: A Woman Reflects on Midstream Contentment
description: LEAD: IT has been a long, damp wait, this past winter season, good only for the fishing dreams and earnest resolutions in which we fly fishers indulge. Here in Vermont, the Battenkill, pulsing in spring flood, is as swollen as my yearly intentions to fish more.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Abbott Laboratories Inc., Abbott Park, Ill., named Gary Coughlan senior vice president and chief financial officer.

title: C. M. Levy Wed To Miss Acevedo
description: Nalda Acevedo, a pediatric nutritionist at the Mount Sinai Medical Center in New York, and Dr. Clifford Marc Levy, a resident in orthopedic surgery at Mount Sinai, were married yesterday at the Inn at Pound Ridge, N.Y. Rabbi David Posner officiated.

title: Discovery Awaits Launching To Orbit Powerful Telescope
description: Five astronauts prepared today for a second attempt to launch the shuttle Discovery with the space agency's most valuable and celebrated payload, the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope.

title: Lorenzo Says He Is Proud of Job Done at Eastern
description: Frank Lorenzo, characterized by organized labor as a high priest of corporate greed in the 1980's, has come in for some virulent abuse in his years as the chairman of the Texas Air Corporation.

title: Comments by the Hostage
description: Following is an excerpt of a videotaped interview held yesterday with Robert Polhill, the American hostage, by a Syrian television correspondent on a car trip between Beirut and Damascus. The videotape of the interview, which was conducted in English, was made available to Cable News Network.

title: Market Place;   The Mystery Of the Gold Selloff
description: NEARLY a month after investors in gold suffered their biggest losses in seven years, precious metals analysts are still trying to find out who or what caused the March 26 selloff, and why.

title: Skeptics And a Slide Test Pistons
description: AFTER spending years climbing the ladder toward basketball's pinnacle, the Detroit Pistons finally reached it last season. They won the National Basketball Association championship, they exorcised years of frustration, and they dominated the league with a tough, unapologetic style that was loved by their fans and loathed by their critics.

title: Ceausescu Wept as He Faced Firing Squad, Footage Shows
description: Nicolae and Elena Ceausescu begged for mercy as soldiers prepared the Romanian dictator and his wife for the firing squad, according to footage of the execution broadcast here today.

title: Raymond Cantwell, 73 Engineering Executive
description: Raymond J. Cantwell, chief financial officer of the Babcock & Wilcox engineering company, died of cancer on Saturday at Memorial-Sloan Kettering Cancer Center. He was 73 years old and lived in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Tough Going
description: THE last time anyone tried to run an auto rally through South America, the organizers went broke before the race ever began. But it took more than that to stop the intrepid drivers in the Trans-Amazon Rally of 1988.

title: Barbara Tobias Is Wed To John Daniel Russell
description: Barbara Louise Tobias, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Tobias of New York, was married yesterday at Alger House in New York to John Daniel Russell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John O. Russell of Birmingham, Ala. Cantor David Benedict officiated.

title: Rate Rise Is Expected To Persist
description: Credit market analysts say the recent surge in long-term interest rates, which have moved to their highest levels in nearly a year, is not over yet.

title: Centel Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $2,341,000. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $4,025,000, or 5 cents a share. The company said share earnings figures reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in February.

title: Capitol Transamerica reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Evelyn K. Hill, 88; Had Souvenir Shop At Statue of Liberty
description: Evelyn K. Hill, who operated souvenir and food concessions at the Statue of Liberty for more than half a century, died of cardiac arrest yesterday at St. Joseph's Medical Center in Yonkers. She was 88 years old and lived in the Bronx.

title: Cultures in Conflict: M.D.'s and Ph.D.'s
description: KENNETH Culver, M.D., and Richard Mulligan, Ph.D., both work at the vanguard of human gene therapy, the grand new scientific enterprise to treat patients afflicted with genetic diseases by inserting foreign genes into their cells.

title: U.S. Urged to Join Effort to Preserve Plants' Gene Resources
description: THE Bush Administration is being urged to join an international organization seeking to preserve thousands of obscure plants and seeds that may hold the key to future food needs.

title: Notebook;   Knicks Put Oakley on the Roster for Playoff Run
description: The Knicks restored Charles Oakley to their 12-man roster yesterday, indicating that the forward, one of the National Basketball Association's best rebounders, will be in the lineup Thursday night at Boston Garden for the opening game of New York's three-of-five-game playoff series with the Celtics.

title: CHRONICLE
description: GRETA GARBO, who died April 15 at the age of 84, may have been a woman of mystery, but there is no mystery about her estate, according to THEODORE A. KURZ, the head of the trusts and estates department at the law firm of Debevoise & Plimpton.

title: Lubrizol Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Soviet View on Cuba
description: The Soviet Union and Cuba are trying to improve their economic relations and can expand them further despite the diverging economic and political paths taken by their Governments, the Soviet Deputy Prime Minister, Leonid Abalkin, said here last week. In a weeklong stay in Cuba, Mr. Abalkin, the Soviet Union's leading economic reformer, signed a $14 billion bilateral trade protocol for 1990 and helped to set up a commission to discuss future economic relations. Soviet-Cuban trade is based mainly on an exchange of Cuban sugar, nickel and citrus for Soviet oil, machinery, cereals and food.

title: Mel Powell's Musical Journey to a Pulitzer Prize
description: Mel Powell, who runs the composition department at the California Institute of the Arts in Valencia, near Los Angeles, has taken a path with several detours on his way to winning the 1990 Pulitzer Prize for music this month at the age of 67.

title: Imperial Oil reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain on the sale of oil and gas properties of $91 million. The results are in Canadian funds.

title: View of Milky Way's Center
description: A ROBOT spacecraft that is scanning distant skies for signs of the beginning of the universe has produced a bonus: the first clear picture of the center of the Milky Way, the galaxy containing the solar system.

title: Lomas & Nettleton Mortgage Investors reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The company said that in addition to a regular $500,000 quarterly provision for possible losses, it provided an incremental $37.5 million to its aggregate reserves at March 31, resulting in the latest quarter's loss.

title: Seacoast Banking Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Corrections
description: The Metro Matters column yesterday, about the composition of New York City's Planning Commission under the revised City Charter, referred incorrectly to the Mayor's role in its makeup. The Mayor appoints 7 of the 13 members.

title: Nigeria Reports 4 Are Dead And 160 Held in Failed Coup
description: Nigeria's military leaders said today that four people had been killed in the coup attempt by junior officers over the weekend.

title: East Germany, Coke in Deal
description: The Coca-Cola Company, the world's largest soft drink maker, announced a $140 million investment program to bottle and distribute Coca-Cola in East Germany.

title: Kysor Industrial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
3 Found Slain In Bronx House; Baby Is Unhurt
description: Three people were found shot to death yesterday, their hands cuffed behind them, on the second floor of a Bronx home that bristled with security cameras and floodlights. The victims, two men and a woman, had each been shot in the back of the head.

title: Fansteel Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a pre-tax loss from discontinued operations of $204,000. The year-ago quarter restated to reflect the December 1989 disposal of the metal products business.

title: Columbia Savings Move
description: The Columbia Savings and Loan Association said today that its chief financial officer, David A. Sachs, had resigned effective May 11 to pursue other opportunities. Edward G. Harshfield, Columbia's chief executive, will serve as acting chief financial officer until a successor is named. Mr. Sachs took on the position in January after serving as executive vice president.

The right, enclosed by a wire fence, was dotted with the soft, springy heather bushes with lavender blooms that once filled acres of hills, heaths and moors throughout Britain.

title: At the Funeral For Abernathy, Anger Is Eased

Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Nearly 2,000 people gathered for the funeral in the West Hunter Street Baptist Church, where Mr. Abernathy had been pastor. The flower-laden coffin was taken away on a wagon drawn by mules.

description: All right, ''The Best of Nightline With Ted Koppel, 1980 1990'' is not without its promotional aspect, but the program that began 10 years ago with the taking of American hostages deserves some back patting. As Ted Koppel reminds viewers at 10 tonight on ABC, he has tried to ''bring people together who are worlds apart.'' A worthy endeavor, whose results can be glimpsed during this lively hour in confrontations between an Iraqi and an Iranian, a Sandinista official and a State Department official, Palestinians and Israelis and black and white South Africans.

title: Paying for Murder
description: It is an old question, but it will not go away. When will the United States Government get serious about stopping the murderous behavior of the armed forces we train and finance in El Salvador? Over the last 10 years, the U.S. has spent nearly $5 billion on El Salvador, $1 billion of it for military aid. In that time the Salvadoran forces have killed more than 40,000 civilians, most of them because someone thought they were politically suspicious. Not one officer has been convicted of those crimes.

title: Clouds Are Yielding Clues to Changes in Climate
description: FRAGILE and fleeting, impossible to grasp, clouds have long eluded efforts to understand the powerful role they play in regulating the Earth's climate. title: CHRONICLE

DINKINS handed out awards yesterday - the start of National Volunteer Week - in the Blue Room at City Hall to five organizations and to one individual who has been likened to an organization unto herself. She is MOLLIE MOON, who founded the National Urban League Guild in 1942 to raise money for Urban League programs. With nearly 30,000 volunteers working out of 80 guilds across the country, Ms. Moon serves as the organization's full-time volunteer president.

''It's easier to design clothes,'' he said, mopping his brow. The mannequins were dressed in costumes from ballets, operas and other theatrical events shown in Milan, Italy; Leningrad; Brussels and other cities. All the costumes had been designed by Versace since 1984.

description: After decades of severely restricting the number of Muslims allowed to visit Mecca, the Soviet Union announced today that it would charter special direct flights to Saudi Arabia for the pilgrimage this year. Muslim leaders said thousands of people had applied to go. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, whose administration has seemed alarmed by the revival of Islam in the country's southern republics, ''has instructed the Ministry of Civil Aviation to organize special Aeroflot flights during this period'' from Moscow and other cities with large Muslim populations, Mr. Gorbachev's chief spokesman told a news conference here today.

Unfortunately, the colt may never have the chance to prove it one way or the other.

title: Gerte Willner; Ophthalmologist, 95

description: First-quarter earnings reported yesterday by two of Wall Street's biggest firms - Salomon Inc. and Morgan Stanley Group Inc. - were buoyed by strong trading profits. Investment banking revenues at both companies remained weak, reflecting the continued slowdown in corporate mergers and takeovers.

Japan Vehicle Output
description: Domestic production of Japanese cars, trucks and buses declined 2.8 percent in March from a year earlier, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association reported on Monday. Despite the decline, to 1.234 million units, overall vehicle output in the fiscal year that ended March 31 reached a record 12.954 million units, up 1 percent from a year earlier, the group said. The previous record of 12.819 million units was set a year earlier.

title: High-Tech Toddler
description: The father of a 3 1/2-year-old boy looked in on his son just after dawn one morning, expecting to find a sleeping innocent. Instead he found a wide-awake warrior, clutching a plastic sword and chanting: ''Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles. Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles. Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles. Heroes in a Half Shell. Turtle Power!''

title: Free to Speak, but Willing to Listen and Learn;   First Amendment Peril
description: To the Editor:

title: Paris Food Purveyor Begets a Restaurant
description: ''IMPOSSIBLE n'est pas francais'' (''Impossible is not French'') is a popular phrase in France, and Fauchon, the prestigious food emporium founded in 1886, seems to have just proved its veracity. Fauchon has opened an attractive restaurant at a site in Paris that only three and a half months ago was a hollowed-out three-story building.

title: Liz Claiborne Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Harsco reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Review/Theater;   Orton and Pinter One-Acts Investigate Dualities
description: Though both Joe Orton and Harold Pinter are playwrights with original, distinct voices, they have similarities as well as disparities. Arriving first, Mr. Pinter became something of a model to Mr. Orton. Just as Pinter plays have a metaphorical weasel lurking under the cocktail table, Mr. Orton's plays are inhabited by carpenter ants insidiously attacking the roofbeams and floorboards. For both playwrights, nothing is as it seems to be as they investigate dualities in everyday life.

title: Ernest W. Kulka, 93, Physician and Teacher
description: Dr. Ernest W. Kulka, an obstetrician and professor emeritus at New York University School of Medicine, died of a heart attack on Friday at New York Hospital in Manhattan. He was 93 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: 'King' Opens in London
description: ''King,'' a musical about the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., has opened at the Piccadilly Theater here to mostly negative reviews, with several critics asserting that the show lacked focus and failed to portray its central character realistically.

title: Grace Energy Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-The net income and share earnings were calculated on a pro forma basis to include interest and estimated administrative expenses as if the company's initial public offering in the 1989 third quarter had been completed on Jan. 1, 1989. Results for the latest quarter included an after-tax dry-hole expense of $1.3 million, which was offset by improvements in the energy service businesses. First quarter results also included net income from a gas comtract settlement of $4.3 million, after tax, or 17 cents a share, compared to contract settlements of $4.6 million, after tax, or 19 cents a share, in 1989.

description: The Senate Appropriations Committee approved a special $2.6 billion spending bill tonight that provides the full $300 million aid President Bush requested for Nicaragua and $420 million of the $500 million he sought for Panama.

title: Lawyers Ask Judge To Void Conviction Of Ex-Security Aide

title: Times Mirror Co. reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
Reviving the Flavor Of the Old West
description: SAM ARNOLD has been known to open champagne bottles by slashing off their necks off with a tomahawk. Such Wild West tactics are fairly typical for this mild-mannered, soft-voiced historian, radio commentator, food writer and restaurateur. He runs a popular restaurant, the Fort, an adobe reconstruction of a historic Southwestern trading post, in the foothills a few miles outside this city.

title: Dinkins Urges Halt to S.I. Naval Port Funds
description: Calling a planned naval station on Staten Island ''a port without a purpose,'' Mayor David N. Dinkins urged two Congressional panels at a hearing today to stop spending for the partly built project and free the money to help fight crime, homelessness and other domestic problems instead.

title: EG&G Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
Nicaragua's Second Revolution
description: Nothing happens tidily in Nicaragua. That's conspicuously true in today's landmark transfer of power from President Daniel Ortega to his conservative opponent, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro. Her succession is marred by defiance among the Sandinistas and die-hard contras, paralyzing strikes and unresolved arguments over the armed forces. Still, today marks a wonderful change in climate for Nicaragua and all the Americas.

title: Soviets and Chinese Sign Broad Pact
description: China and the Soviet Union signed a 10-year agreement today for economic and scientific cooperation that is to focus on developing the high-technology proficiency that both nations badly need.

title: Drug Abusers Still Sell Blood Plasma, Study Finds
description: In a new study, researchers say more needs to be done to prevent drug abusers who have the AIDS virus from selling blood plasma to commercial collection centers.

Real Estate;   Coffee, Sugar Exchange Expanding
description: AT 10 A.M. every weekday a buzzer sounds on the eighth floor of 4 World Trade Center in lower Manhattan and the sugar trading ring at the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange erupts in chaos as several hundred brokers shout and signal orders for clients around the world.

Royalty expense is reduced by a comparable amount and there is no change in operating income or net income. Prior year amounts have been restated to a comparable basis.

title: 2 Arrested in Court Rug Thefts
description: Two men who were in court last month to answer assault and weapons charges were arrested Monday and charged with stealing two cheap rugs on their way out of the courthouse. The authorities say Vern W. Campbell and John J. Unkel, both members of the Compadres Motorcycle Club, took two floor rugs from the Superior Court building on Kendrick Avenue on March 21. They were in court then to answer charges stemming from an incident in which Compadres members were accused of beating up a man in a bar.

title: Several Mistakes Seen In the Defense of Milken
description: Among the post-mortems following the agreement that ended the largest securities fraud case in history, many lawyers, prosecutors, academics and several people involved in the case say that Michael R. Milken and Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. could have drawn much more lenient treatment had they reached settlements years ago instead of putting up defiant fronts for so long and then abruptly reversing course.

title: In Miami, Oleander And Murder
description: LEAD: At 9 A.M. on New Year's Day, a husky man in a white shirt and tie appeared at our door.

Project for Homeless Delayed
description: Acting Justice Donald Silverman in State Supreme Court granted a temporary injunction today prohibiting WestHELP from starting work on a 108-unit housing project for homeless people. The ruling came in a suit filed by the Coalition for United Peoples, known as COUP, which said the construction would violate state environmental law and state education law. The injunction forbids the cutting down of trees and other clearing of the six-acre site on the grounds of the Westchester Community College.

title: Challenge to Pentagon
description: Eleven members of Congress today asked the Pentagon to reinstate Dr. Craig I. Fields as head of the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, or Darpa. Dr. Fields, 43 years old, had headed the agency for a year until he was transferred last Friday. The agency provides money to industry to develop high-technology goods with military uses. His supporters contend he was removed because he advocated spending money on ''dual-use'' technologies - those with civilian and military applications.

title: Shuttle Soars 381 Miles High, With Telescope and a Dream
description: In a thunderous overture to a promised new era in astronomy, the space shuttle Discovery rocketed into orbit today with the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope, which scientists believe will give them a commanding view of the universe as it was, is and will be.

description: The president of the National Academy of Sciences suggested today that Japanese industries compensate American universities for training Japanese scientists and engineers.

title: Man Shoots 5, Killing One, In a Georgia Shopping Mall

The '87 Bordeaux Charm on Their Debut
description: THE curtain went up on the 1987 Bordeaux vintage at the Four Seasons in Manhattan on Sunday. On previous New York opening nights, the reds showed the complexity of grand opera, but this time they resembled an operetta: colorful, romantic and crowd-pleasing.

title: Leading Foe of Teheran Slain In Ambush Near Swiss Home
description: Kazem Rajavi, a leading opponent of the Iranian Government, was shot dead near his home in this town on Lake Geneva today, relatives said.

title: Resting Two Players Brings Lakers a Fine
description: On the eve of the opening of the National Basketball Association playoffs, Commissioner David Stern yesterday fined the Los Angeles Lakers $25,000 because Coach Pat Riley failed to play two healthy starters Sunday night in Portland in the Lakers' final game of the season.

title: U.S. JEWISH GROUP CRITICAL OF ISRAEL ON AID TO SETTLERS
description: The leading pro-Israeli lobby in the United States told the Israeli Government today that its covert sponsorship of a Jewish settlement in the Christian Quarter of Jerusalem could seriously damage American-Israeli relations.

title: Corrections
description: A television schedule listing yesterday for the program ''Frontline: Hilary in Hiding'' referred incorrectly to the father of Hilary Foretich. In a custody dispute, his former wife has accused the father, Dr. Eric A. Foretich, of abusing their daughter. He has denied the accusations.

title: Final Twist in 'Rear Window' Case
description: In a copyright decision calling into question the legal status of hundreds of motion pictures, the Supreme Court ruled today that the current owners of Alfred Hitchcock's ''Rear Window'' had infringed the copyright of the short story on which the 1954 movie classic was based.

title: Ames Chapter 11 Bid Speculated On
description: Ames Department Stores Inc. has hired a bankruptcy specialist from a New York law firm, fueling speculation that the retailer will seek bankruptcy protection, The Hartford Courant said today. An article in the newspaper said Ames had hired Michael L. Cook, a partner at Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, to begin preparing for a Chapter 11 filing, which would allow Ames to continue operating while working out a plan to repay its debts.

title: Sallie Mae Notes
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering $200 milion in three-year notes through underwriters led by the Morgan Stanley Group. Initially the notes were priced at par to yield 9.12 percent, or about 20 basis points more than Treausury notes with a similar maturity. But now the notes will be reoffered to te public at various prices. For the first two years, the notes are noncallable by Sallie Mae.

title: 28 Sudan Officers Executed On Charges of Trying a Coup
description: A military firing squad executed 28 officers, including three retired generals and a brigadier, after a summary court-martial on charges of trying to stage a coup, official news organizations reported.

title: Chronicle
description: When the first Arab in space, Prince Sultan SALMAN AL SAUD, gave a dinner for a hundred or so friends at the Waldorf-Astoria Monday night, Earth Day was still much on his mind. The Prince, a nephew of King Fahd of Saudi Arabia, had joined other astronauts before the United Nations in a warning about the damage mankind is doing to its habitat, as seen from space.

title: Gooden Erasing Doubts
description: Forget, for the moment, the difficulty the Mets continued to have with pitchers named Smith. Note, but only briefly, that Barry Lyons, the Mets' catcher, actually threw out two would-be basestealers, albeit one with an umpire's assistance. Savor, with only a quick taste, the way the Mets won the game in the ninth inning, with the 6-foot-5-inch, 220-pound Mike Marshall scooting down the first-base line to avoid an inning-ending double play.

title: Investigators of Derailment Find Signs That Track Moved
description: Federal investigators said today that they had found ''slight indications'' of rail movement where an Amtrak passenger train derailed.

title: California Edison
description: The Southern California Edison Company yesterday priced $100 million in first and refunding mortgage bonds due in 1992 through competitive bidding, won by underwriters led by the Shearson Lehman Hutton unit of American Express. Underwriters gave the bonds a coupon of 9 1/8 percent and priced them at par, to yield about 27.5 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The bonds, which are noncallable through maturity, are rated Aa-2 by Moody's Investors Service and AA- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

description: The company said that earnings for the latest first quarter reflected a net cost of $1.1 million for the Employee Stock Ownership Plan (ESOP) adopted at the end of the second quarter of 1989, or about 5 cents a share. The company acquired about 2.2 million shares of its common stock in connection with the ESOP.

description: To the Editor:

description: Many black students may perform poorly in high school because of a shared sense that academic success is a sellout to the white world, according to a study by two anthropologists.

description: Two styles of dancing were happily allied when the Ballet du Nord performed Saturday night at the Colden Center for the Performing Arts at Queens College.

description: Pennsylvania's House of Representatives today overwhelmingly approved a controversial bill considered to be the nation's toughest anti-takeover measure.

description: Robert Polhill spent most of his captivity in a room with two fellow hostages and probably in the same building that held other Western captives in Lebanon, United States officials said today.

title: Industrial Equity
description: Industrial Equity (Pacific) Ltd., the Hong Kong investment arm of the New Zealand investor Ron Brierley, has sought Federal clearance to raise its stake in Petroleum Helicopters Inc. to as much as 25 percent, from 17 percent. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Industrial Equity said it would continue to try to gain a seat on the board of Petroleum Helicopters, which provides helicopter services to the oil and gas industry.

title: S.E.C. Chief Calling for Long Term
description: Richard C. Breeden, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today that Michael R. Milken should serve a lengthy prison sentence.

title: After Gains of 80's, Northeast Is Lagging In the Growth of Jobs
description: After years that brought some of the sharpest economic gains since World War II, the Northeast is now trailing the rest of the nation in job growth.

title: Computers to Help Drivers Find Their Way
description: This summer the General Motors Corporation will begin a yearlong experiment on a 12-mile stretch of Los Angeles freeway to examine how 12 cars equipped with electronic navigation systems can elude congested highways by turning on to local streets shown on a computerized map. In Japan, the Honda Motor Company announced last month that it plans to offer the first electronic navigation system as an option on some larger models, although it is tight-lipped about when the feature will be introduced.

title: Interface Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
Many Interests at Stake as Farm Act Is Rewritten
description: Addressing a trade group the other day, Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter complained that he had ''taken a lot of flak'' for supposedly seeking to cut farm subsidies by $1.5 billion when he actually favored a $2 billion increase.

title: Review/Piano;   A 98-Year-Old Virtuoso And Music of His Heart
description: According to the people who negotiate such matters at Carnegie Hall, Mieczyslaw Horszowski's piano recital on Monday night has been the toughest ticket to come by all season, the Vienna Philharmonic included. Musicians, music business professionals and just plain fans have wheedled and bargained to see and hear the 98-year-old pianist. Mr. Horszowski responded with a generous program of Bach, Beethoven, Schumann and Chopin and then three encores.

title: Helaine Lasky Is Wed To Marc E. Schweitzer
description: Helaine Beth Lasky, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Lasky of Pembroke Pines, Fla., was married yesterday to Marc Edward Schweitzer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin S. Schweitzer of New York. Rabbi Gilbert Klaperman performed the ceremony at Congregation Beth Sholom in Lawrence, L.I.

title: New Finishing Process Improves Steel
description: rrThe Nippon Steel Corporation of Japan and Inland Steel Industries of Chicago officially began production yesterday on one of the world's most advanced plants for finishing steel.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Pastas From India

title: Phillips Petroleum Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included net gain of $148 million from accounting change, settlement with Iran and charge from sale of insurance company.

title: About Education
description: Why is college so expensive? The question won't go away until parents get more believable answers.

title: Papers Urged to Include Minorities
description: The nation's newspaper publishers heard a blunt warning here today that they must change or risk becoming irrelevant.

title: Metro Datelines;   Man Held in Killing Of Brooklyn Cabbie
description: A 20-year-old man was arrested yesterday and charged with killing a taxi driver on Saturday in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: RJR Nabisco Holdings Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $12 million for RJR Nabisco Holdings from Feb. 9 through March 31, and income from discontinued operations of $24 million for RJR Nabisco from Jan. 1 through Feb. 8. First quarter 1990 results included $726 million of non-cash charges, primarily non-cash interest, amortization of intangibles, and depreciation. Consolidated sales for RJR Nabisco Holdings totaled $2,276,000,000 from Feb. 9 through March 31, and sales for RJR Nabisco amounted to $650 million from Jan. 1 through Feb. 8, for final total of $2,926,000,000 for 1989. The net loss figures totaled $66 million and $173 million for RJR Nabisco Holdings and RJR Nabisco, respectively, for year-ago period, for final total of $239 million.

title: Salomon Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss Revenue represented gross or total revenue.

title: Santa Fe Pacific Seeks To Spin Off 2 Big Units
description: In a move widely anticipated on Wall Street, the Santa Fe Pacific Corporation said today that it would seek to spin off to shareholders two of its three principal operating units - Santa Fe Pacific Realty and Santa Fe Energy Resources.

title: Milken Defends 'Junk Bonds' As He Enters His Guilty Plea
description: Apologizing for his crimes but defending the ''junk bond'' market he created, Michael R. Milken pleaded guilty yesterday to six felony charges of securities fraud and conspiracy. The 43-year-old financier agreed to pay $600 million in fines and penalties.

title: Richard DeLauer, Pentagon Aide And an Aerospace Executive, 71
description: Richard D. DeLauer, a former Under Secretary of Defense and an executive in the aerospace industry, died of leukemia on Sunday at Good Samaritan Hospital in Los Angeles. He was 71 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Sketches of Five Astronauts
description: Loren J. Shriver; Mission Commander

title: Peril Seen From Space Debris
description: A Congressional agency has warned that astronauts aboard the proposed space station could be endangered by space debris and that NASA is underestimating the threat.

title: Market Place;   Milken's Plea Reflects Ethics of Drexel in 80's
description: Michael R. Milken, the dethroned king of ''junk bonds,'' admitted yesterday that he had cheated some customers, rigged the prices of some stocks and bonds, and engaged in sham transactions designed to fool Federal regulators and help a crony avoid paying taxes.

title: Britain 'Deeply Skeptical' of Plan By France and Germany on Unity
description: Setting the stage for a fresh dispute with its European partners, Britain said today that it opposed a new French-German plan to speed the political integration of the European Community in response to developments in Eastern Europe.

title: Kansas City Power & Light reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Pedro W. Guerrero, 93; Headed Food Concern
description: Pedro W. Guerrero, an early entrepreneur in Mexican food specialties who was a founder of the Rosarita Company, died of kidney failure on Monday at Mesa (Ariz.) Lutheran Hospital. He was 93 years old and lived in Mesa.

title: Reports Stir Fears Of Inflation
description: Government reports provided fresh evidence today that the economy has successfully skirted recession but that it now confronts a problem of stepped-up inflation that may prompt the Federal Reserve to tighten monetary policy this spring.

title: Knitwear Group's Head Is Used to Import Fights
description: Sweater makers in the United States have won a big round in their battle against imports, and the man behind their victory is Seth Bodner, executive director of the National Knitwear & Sportswear Association, which represents 300 domestic manufacturers.

title: Review/Music;   Riches of the Clarinet, Familiar and Strange
description: Outside of the keyboard, the violin and, of course, the human voice, no solo instrument has more successfully prodded creative musical imaginations than the clarinet. Mozart raised the instrument to legitimacy, making it central to his dark orchestrations and composing for his friend Anton Stadler three of the instrument's important pieces.

title: German Leaders Agree on a July 2 Unification Date
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany held a hastily arranged meeting here with Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere of East Germany today, and the two leaders agreed to set July 2 as the date for a monetary, economic and social union of the two Germanys.

title: Dalton to Help Authors
description: B. Dalton Bookseller, the nationwide book chain, said yesterday that it would begin next Tuesday to promote first-time or little known authors by displaying their books prominently in more than 250 of its stores. The decision comes as the publishing industry has been accused by some writers of favoring commercial books at the expense of less profitable works of literary value. About 30 works will be chosen every two months. B. Dalton said the titles would be ''displayed at a prime location near the entrance to each store'' and be accompanied by a brochure containing reviews of the books.

title: Oryx Energy reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included $85 million gain from cumulative effect of accounting change. Latest first quarter is the first to include results of its international operations.

title: Almodovar Film's X Stands
description: The distributor of ''Tie Me Up! Tie Me Down!,'' the new film by the Spanish director Pedro Almodovar, which is soon to open in the United States, failed yesterday to reverse an X rating given the film by the rating board of the Motion Picture Association of America.

title: Holding Concern Signs Merger Pacts
description: The NUI Corporation signed agreements for Pennsylvania Enterprises Inc. and its Pennsylvania Gas and Water Company unit to merge into it. In addition, the United Water Resources Company will buy the water operations and related assets of Pennsylvania Enterprises for about $220 million.

title: $300 Million Issue By Philip Morris
description: The Philip Morris Companies is offering $300 million in notes due 1997 through the underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Harvard Picks Rosovsky For Post of Acting Dean
description: Henry Rosovsky, one of the most respected figures in American higher education, has been named acting dean of Harvard University's Faculty of Arts and Sciences, resuming a job he left six years ago.

title: Jostens Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WINE TALK
description: GERALD ASHER, the whilom wine merchant and distinguished wine writer, was in town recently to talk about clones, specifically chardonnay clones.

title: A Deadly Investment in Connecticut
description: Connecticut's State Treasurer, Francisco Borges, was boasting last month of a ''bold, exciting and very inventive partnership'' to which he had committed $25 million in pension funds belonging to state employees. Now he's gagging on those words, and well he should.

title: Bears Cleared by N.F.L.
description: The Chicago Bears did not violate National Football League policy when they negotiated a contract with Mark Carrier before drafting the safety from Southern Cal on Sunday, the league said yesterday.

title: Captive Audiences
description: Moviegoers who resent the commercials they're forced to watch before the main feature can applaud the Walt Disney studio's ultimatum to theater owners: No more commercials when Disney films are playing. Warner Brothers has now followed suit. More applause.

title: Control Data reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included an after-tax restructuring gain of $5.8 million primarily from the sale of a facility. c-Included an after-tax restructuring gain of $14.5 million, from the sale of several International Control Data Institutes. The company said in quarterly revenue from 1989 resulted from the sale or discontinuance of several operating units, most notably the imprimis disk drive subsidiary and the third-party maintenance business.

title: Allentown Journal;   True Love, True Life, And Truly Bizarre
description: ''Two for the nut movie,'' local residents say through the hole in the ticket window of the Eric Five Theater here on Fourth Street. Some ask for tickets to ''The Toto movie.''

title: USLife Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a capital loss of 9 cents a share primarily from disposal of a joint venture real estate investment. c-Included income from capital gains of 8 cents a share primarily from sales of fixed maturity investments. Exact figures for the capital gains and losses were not immediately available.

title: Clifton R. Wharton, 90, Is Dead; Pioneering Black U.S. Diplomat
description: Clifton R. Wharton, the first black American career diplomat to attain the ranks of Minister and Ambassador in the United States Foreign Service, died on Monday at the Sunridge Care Center in Phoenix, Ariz. He was 90 years old and lived in Phoenix.

title: Playoff Picture Is Far From Clear As Many Clubs Have High Hopes
description: The Los Angeles Lakers ruled the 1980's by winning five National Basketball Association championships. Will the new decade be anything like the old?

title: IMO Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Metro Datelines;   Priest Is Arrested In Sex Abuse of Boys
description: A Roman Catholic priest was arrested yesterday and charged with sexually abusing three boys he met as a parish priest in Queens, the police said.

title: Quaker Oats Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $34,800,000 and $25,500,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-After income from discontinued operations of $9,200,000, or 12 cents a share, and included a non-recurring pretax charge of $20.7 million relating to a planned consolidation of European pet food operations. The 9 months included income from discontinued operations of $38,400,000, or 49 cents a share. All periods excluded the results of Fisher-Price division, which was discontinued effective March 31. All results in 1989 were restated.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bogert Oil Co., Oklahoma City, agreed to be acquired for $13.20 a share in a merger agreement with LDEC Acquisition Corp, a unit of Louis Dreyfus Energy Corp.

title: Building Self-Esteem
description: To The Living Section:

title: Anyone Who Can Read Can Cook, Right? Five Men Find Out
description: Five of us sat in the living room, making small talk, acting nonchalant, but in reality we were at loose ends. Five women trying to play the usual roles of the men we are married to. For one night the roles were reversed and we weren't quite certain what to do with ourselves.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Milken Plea

title: Northern Telecom reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Fauntroy Investigation Closed
description: A Justice Department spokesman said today that the department had closed an investigation into a report that Walter E. Fauntroy, the District of Columbia's nonvoting delegate to Congress, had kept Thomas John Savage, the son of Representative Gus Savage, Democrat of Illinois, on his payroll while he ran for office in Illinois. There will be no prosecution, the spokesman said.

title: International Lease Accords for 15 Jets
description: The International Lease Finance Corporation said it had leased 15 jets to 11 airlines in deals worth $705 million. The company, based in Beverly Hills, Calif., also completed several other transactions, including selling four aircraft and acting as agent in leasing two aircraft on behalf of the financial institutions that own them.

title: Musician and Composer Wins $150,000 Award
description: Joan Tower, a professor of music at Bard College in Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y., was named the 1990 recipient of the $150,000 Grawemeyer Award for original music composition by the University of Louisville today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Accounts
description: * Tyco Toys, to Bozell, its creative agency, for the media portion of its account.

title: Free to Speak, but Willing to Listen and Learn
description: To the Editor:

title: Homestake Mining reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $1,841,000, or 2 cents a share.

title: Chronicle
description: ELIZABETH TAYLOR, who has pneumonia, was improving yesterday at a California hospital but breathing with the help of a ventilator after surgery to determine the cause of her illness.

title: Economic Scene;   Soviet Economy: Red Storm Ebbs
description: JUST how much are Soviet consumers really suffering? Alfred Volkov, a researcher from Moscow's Academy of National Economics, replies with a story about the quality of food in state-run markets: Criminals vowing not be be taken alive, he quips, now carry a piece of sausage to swallow in case they are cornered by the police.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Advertising column yesterday about the new officers of the Newspaper Advertising Bureau misidentified the position held in the organization last year by John P. Giuggio, vice chairman of the Globe Newspaper Company of Boston. He held the post of treasurer, to which he was re-elected this year.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Kennedy Delays Plan For Tobacco Ads
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, has temporarily dropped a provision in his tobacco regulation bill that would have permitted states to regulate tobacco advertising, which is currently the responsibility of the Federal Government. A staff member of the Labor and Human Resources Committee said, however, that the provision would be introduced as an amendment should the bill, as is expected, reach the Senate floor. Advertisers have argued that such a provision would hamper national tobacco advertising.

title: Portrait of a Collector: Walter Annenberg
description: Walter H. Annenberg, publisher, philanthropist, former Ambassador to Britain and high-rolling art acquisitor, doesn't really mind that the J. Paul Getty Museum bagged van Gogh's ''Irises'' in a recent transaction with Sotheby's. ''I like my irises better,'' he said, pointing to a big, lush Monet canvas, ''The Path Through the Irises,'' hanging over a white couch in a sitting area of his Astrodome-sized house here. ''I wouldn't swap them for van Gogh's irises.''

title: Jackie McLean Is Back With His Alto Sax After 20 Years Away
description: Jackie McLean's return to the Village Vanguard with his alto saxophone last night was both a homecoming and a personal renewal. In 1970, Mr. McLean, who was acknowledged as one of the jazz world's finest composers and saxophonists, made a major career decision: He left the performer's spotlight for the campus. Mr. McLean joined the faculty of the Hartt School of Music at the University of Hartford and started the school's Afro-American music department. He also founded Artist Collective in Hartford. And he virtually stopped performing.

title: Court Rejects Death Sentence Appeal by Outsider
description: The Supreme Court today barred outsiders from bringing Federal court challenges to the death sentences of convicted murderers who have decided not to appeal their own cases.

title: Experts Fear a German Inflation Rise
description: It is widely agreed that Bonn's decision to ground a German monetary union on a one-for-one exchange of currencies will make East Germans very happy indeed. And by pleasing East German voters, the concession is likely to serve the immediate interests of West Germany's ruling party, the Christian Democratic Union.

title: Bethlehem Steel Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a charge of $55,000,000 related to restructuring.

title: Yankees Stop Slide With LaPoint Victory
description: Dave LaPoint had just one word to describe the Yankees' 6-2 victory over the Seattle Mariners at the Stadium last night, his first pitching triumph since last June 6.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Old Agency Reaches for A New Image
description: THESE days the buzzword at Ayer is ''stretch.'' Today, exactly a year after he became chief executive of Ayer, Jerry J. Siano will introduce a campaign to forge a strong identity for the country's oldest advertising agency.

title: Mapco Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U.S. Vehicle Sales Fell 17.8% in Mid-April Period
description: Sales of domestically produced cars and light trucks fell 17.8 percent in mid-April from strong levels a year ago.

title: Why I Fear the Germans
description: LEAD: In 1973, while walking on the Langelinie Promenade in Copenhagen, I found myself admiring the imaginative toys in a playground filled with tow-headed children.

title: Spurs Sign Mitchell
description: In preparation for their first-round playoff series with Denver, which opens tomorrow night in San Antonio, the Spurs have signed Mike Mitchell, one of their former stars, and cut Zarko Paspalj, a rookie guard from Yugoslavia. Mitchell, who spent this last season averaging 32.9 points in Italy after playing with the Spurs from 1981 to 1988, was brought aboard to provide scoring insurance, the team said.

title: Louisville Gas & Electric reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After income from the cumulative effect of an accounting change of $18,236,000, or 87 cents a share.

title: Bridge
description: A decade or so ago, when some experts were hungrily hunting points in the McKenney Race for the most master points won in a year, one of them brought off a remarkable coup. He played in a Regional Team Championship one afternoon, left his team, flew West to an another time zone, and played in the evening in another Regional with different teammates. He won both events, and the American Contract Bridge League hurriedly and indignantly introduced a regulation to bar this maneuver.

title: The Bush Message to Vilnius: Talk
description: For days, Administration officials have been floating stories suggesting that the United States would impose sanctions against the Soviet crackdown in Lithuania. Yesterday President Bush did the right thing - nothing. And he chose to do it at the right time.

title: Cyclops Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Hockey And Hoops Get Real
description: This is the real season, the one we've been waiting for since, oh, October. This is when the hockey players and the basketball players put on their game faces that they keep in a jar by the door. Who is it for? Their playoff opponents. It's a different season, and almost a different sport. Basketball referees totally give up calling walking, double-dribbling and palming on the theory that if these guys were good enough to get into the playoffs, they must know what they're doing.

title: In Books, Greed Is Out; The Environment Is In
description: If the books people are buying are an indication, a new decade has already ushered in a new mood in America.

title: Excerpts From Ruling On Death-Case Appeals
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's 7-to-2 decision today barring Federal court appeals on behalf of death row inmates who choose not to appeal their own death sentences.

title: Dissident South African Rebels Return Home
description: The African National Congress faced the prospect of embarrassing disclosures from within its own ranks as a group of dissident members returned home today with stories of torture and imprisonment at the group's hands.

title: Police Seize Vial Machines Tied to Crack
description: Customs agents searching for a man wanted in the smuggling of drug paraphernalia stumbled onto a factory Monday night in Brooklyn where workers were producing millions of crack vials, Federal authorities said yesterday.

title: Progressive Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Savings Officials Delay Sales Plan
description: Savings and loan bailout officials today delayed action on a proposal to speed the sale of repossessed real estate after a top bank regulator said the plan could hurt struggling institutions.

title: Washington at Work;   An Unlikely Diplomat Seizes the Opportunity To Shape Latin Policy
description: The day the Senate confirmed the nomination of Bernard W. Aronson as Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs a year ago, lightning struck two century-old oak trees on his lawn, toppling one into his dining room.

title: INSIDE
description: Escrow Violations Charged

title: Chiles Transforms Florida Campaign
description: Less than two years ago, Lawton Chiles stunned Florida voters and political veterans by complaining of ''burnout'' and promptly retiring from the United States Senate. Now he has caused another stir, this time by declaring he wants to be Governor of Florida.

title: Rorer Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After one-time transaction-related costs totaling $26.9 million; $11.9 million in connection with the pending combination of the worldwide human pharmaceutical business of Rhone- Poulenc S.A. with Rorer; and $15 million associated with Rorer's marketing alliance for consumer pharmaceuticals with Procter & Gamble Co. c-Net income

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   People
description: * Robert S. Minner has announced his retirement as vice president and treasurer of Leo Burnett Co.

title: Japan Studying Insider Case
description: The Tokyo police are in the final stages of an investigation into stock dealings that could become the first significant insider-trading case in Japan, a police official said today.

title: Freshness, Convenience: Juice for Today's Tastes
description: STICKER shock is what orange juice producers have been calling the reaction of shoppers who recoil at prices resulting from a devastating freeze just after Christmas.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Interpublic Group
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies yesterday reported earnings of $8.64 million, or 26 cents a share, for the first quarter, up 8 percent from $8.01 million, or 24 cents a share, for the comparable period in 1989.

title: Interpublic Group of Cos.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included after-tax losses from exchange and translation of foreign currencies of $2,939,000 for latest first quarter and $825,000 for year-ago period. Revenue represented gross income.

description: To The Living Section:
