description: To the Editor:

title: Israel Defends Aid to Settlers in Christian Quarter
description: Israel expressed defiance today over the international criticism of secret Government funding for a new Jewish settlement here in the Christian Quarter of the Old City.

title: KEY RATES
Ex-Party Chief Cleared In Yugoslavia Unrest
description: The ethnic Albanian former Communist Party chief of Yugoslavia's strife-torn Kosovo region was acquitted today of criminal charges that he instigated a wave of strikes and protests that set off popular unrest in the region a year ago.

title: Verda F. Welcome, 83, A Maryland Legislator
description: Verda Freeman Welcome, who was the first black woman to become a state senator in Maryland, died in a Baltimore hospital on Sunday after a series of strokes. She was 83 years old.

title: Yields at Banks Are Mixed
description: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts at commercial banks and savings institutions were mixed for the week ended yesterday.

title: Telecom USA Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said net income and earnings per share comparisons were negatively impacted by an increase in the company's effective tax rate from 36 percent in the first quarter of 1989 to 41 percent in the current quarter.

title: Intel Sues Advanced Micro
description: In an extension of a bitter feud between two Silicon Valley computer chip makers, the Intel Corporation today sued Advanced Micro Devices for copyright infringement.

title: Soviet Deal On Ice Cream
description: Baskin-Robbins Inc. said today that it had signed a joint venture agreement with Soviet officials to build an ice cream plant in a suburb of Moscow.

title: How Airport Rail Link Could Serve the Region
description: To the Editor:

title: No, No, Not Ratty
description: We had a white Thanksgiving with six inches of snow, so I could not fertilize the lawn on Thanksgiving Day as is my wont.

title: Morgan Stanley Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Revenue represented total revenue. The net revenue, which is total or gross revenue less interest expense, was $578,252,000 for the latest first quarter, compared with $534,119,000 for year-ago period. Share earnings and shares outstanding have been retroactively adjusted to give effect to a 3-for-2 common stock split, which became effective Feb. 27, 1989.

title: Black-Hispanic Alumni Unit Approved by Baruch College
description: The administration at Bernard M. Baruch College and a group of black and Hispanic graduates who want their own alumni association have ended a long court battle over the school's refusal to recognize such an organization.

title: Villagers Say Sandinista Raid Breaks Cease-Fire
description: Five rebels were ambushed and nearly killed on Sunday by Sandinista troops while preparing a feast for villagers here, residents say.

title: Texaco Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $1,190,000,000 due to a restructuring gain, primarily resulting from the sale of Texaco Canada Inc.

title: Sears Earnings Drop 58.8% As Stores Lose $37.4 Million
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company today reported a 58.8 percent drop in its first-quarter earnings, citing losses in its department stores division and an unexpectedly large increase in claims at its Allstate Insurance Group.

title: Judge Finds Bias in Bus Terminal Search
description: A Manhattan judge has thrown out crucial evidence in a drug-arrest case at the Port Authority Bus Terminal, charging that the authority's drug-enforcement efforts were aimed almost exclusively at black and Hispanic people.

title: U.S. Studies Whether to Seek Tax Indictment of Rep. Flake
description: Justice Department officials in Washington are considering whether to approve criminal charges against Representative Floyd H. Flake, Democrat of Queens, in a tax investigation.

title: Freeport-McMoran Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included gains of $211.5 million from sale of certain nitrogen fertilizer assets and shares of Freeport- McMoran Gold Co. Year-earlier quarter included gain of $27.7 million from disposition of shares of Freeport- McMoran Australia Ltd.

title: Germans to Let Marx Wither
description: Karl Marx appears to be the loser among voters in this East German city.

title: American Petrofina reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included $23 million gain from an accounting adjustment.

title: Fifth Straight Decline Puts Dow at 2,654.50
description: Stock prices fell yesterday for the fifth consecutive day in the wake of rising bond rates, with the Dow Jones industrial average falling 12.17 points, to 2,654.50.

title: Albert Salmi, Actor, 62, Is Found Shot to Death in Home With Wife
description: Albert Salmi, an actor who made a career of portraying cowboys in television westerns like ''Gunsmoke,'' and his wife, Roberta, were found shot to death in an apparent murder-suicide, the police said today.

title: Capitals Confident With Liut in Goal
description: Mike Liut was acquired by the Capitals the day before last month's trading deadline to provide the kind of goaltending that brings success in the playoffs.

title: Rooney Thinks Tyson Is No Longer Interested
description: First came word that Mike Tyson would be training in a newly-built facility in Catskill, N.Y.

title: Chronicle
description: In color and black and white, the pictures - portraits, landscapes and city scenes - glowed on a screen in the Grand Ballroom of the New York Hilton last night. They were the works of two masters of photography who were being honored with the International Center of Photography Infinity Awards.

title: Toyota in Pakistan
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation, Japan's largest automobile maker, said it would build a car manufacturing plant in Pakistan by early 1993. A Toyota spokesman, Yoshiharu Tateishi, said the plant could produce up to 20,000 cars a year. He said about 3,000 Corollas would be produced in the first year, with production increasing later to 10,000 a year.

title: Hampton Is Content With His Big Decision
description: Last fall, when Rodney Hampton finished his junior season at Georgia, he faced a big decision. Should he stay in college for his senior season or should he make himself eligible for the National Football League draft?

title: Control Data Net Up by 94%
description: The Control Data Corporation reported today that its first-quarter profit rose by 94 percent from a year ago because of a huge after-tax gain from its reorganization, but the revenue of the scaled-down computer company declined sharply.

title: British Slightly Curb Period for Abortions
description: The House of Commons voted tonight to reduce the time limit on legal abortions in Britain to 24 weeks from 28. The 28-week limit was one of the most liberal provisions in the West.

title: CT Financial Services reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Morrison Knudsen Offering $500 Million Option Notes
description: The Morrison Knudsen Corporation, an Idaho-based holding company, is offering $500 million in liquid yield option notes due May 1, 2005, up from an orignally planned $375 million, through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Northeast Utilities reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $9,341,000, or 9 cents a share.

title: Rexene Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $12,911,000, or 41 cents a share, from the gain on repurchase of $84 million principal amount of senior increasing rate notes. c-Included a charge of $1,621,000 resulting from expenses related to the settlement of an employee lawsuit and expenses from the redemption of certain long-term notes.

title: Bush Delays Action on Lithuania, Not Wanting to Harm Gorbachev
description: After conferring with allies and Congressional leaders, President Bush today delayed carrying out a threat to take action against Moscow for tightening its chokehold on Lithuania, fearing sanctions might undermine President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and worsen the Baltic crisis.

title: The Pop Life
description: Putting Up 'The Wall'

title: Chronicle
description: Liberal politicians from all over the country flock to the rich West Side of Los Angeles to raise money, so it was perhaps inevitable that leaders of the fledgling democracies of Eastern Europe would find their way there, too.

title: University Chief's Ouster Is Tied To Investigation of Obscene Calls
description: Two weeks after Richard Berendzen startled American University here by abruptly resigning as its president, law-enforcement and university officials said he was forced out because of a police investigation into complaints that he had made obscene telephone calls from his office.

title: Warsaw Fire That Killed Wife Of Journalist Is Called Arson
description: Investigators have concluded that a fatal fire at the apartment of a journalist who specialized in exposing abuses by the secret police was arson.

title: USX Net Off 40.5%; Bethlehem, 67.1%
description: Citing continued weakness in demand for steel and higher operating costs, the USX Corporation and the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, yesterday reported sharply lower first-quarter earnings.

title: He Can Milk 'Em, But He Can't Hide
description: The deed, apparently, is done. Michael Milken, the premier financial swindler of all time, is being given a plea bargain.

title: Arthur N. Field; Lawyer, 84
description: Arthur N. Field, a lawyer for more than 60 years, died of congestive heart failure on Sunday at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Amdahl Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
Buenos Aires Journal;   Menems' Marriage: Well-Matched Pillow Fights?
description: A group of retirees interrupted a hunger strike in front of a Government office recently to call on Zulema Yoma de Menem, the Argentine First Lady, and press demands for pension increases to cover inflation.

title: Solicitor General to Review News Leak Report
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh has asked the Solicitor General to review the findings of an internal investigation into the role played by department employees in a politically damaging news report about Representative William H. Gray 3d last year, Government officials said today.

title: Panel Says Government Is Not Leading AIDS Fight
description: The Federal Government's top advisory panel on AIDS told President Bush today that AIDS policy in the United States was like ''an orchestra without a conductor'' because the Government had failed to lead the campaign against the epidemic effectively.

title: Metro Datelines;   Ex-Prosecutor Says He Made Up Attack
description: A former Camden County Prosecutor pleaded guilty yesterday to fabricating a story that armed drug dealers tried to kill him during a high-speed chase through the streets of Camden.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Addendum
description: * D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles has acquired the Australian advertising agency Weekes Morris & Osborn, which has $30 million in billings.

title: Quaker Oats Planning Fisher-Price Spinoff
description: Ending months of speculation, the Quaker Oats Company said today that it would leave the volatile toy business by spinning off its Fisher-Price division into an independent company.

title: Hitachi Opens U.S. Lab
description: Hitachi Ltd. has opened a biotechnology center at the University of California here that is believed to be the first research lab operated by a Japanese company at an American university. Hitachi officials said on Monday that they hoped the $16.5 million laboratory, called Plumwood House because of its plum color, would allow the company to advance in areas like neuroscience and biochemistry.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   G.M. Is Top Spender
description: Spending for motor vehicle advertising on broadcast television rose 15 percent in 1989, to $2.84 billion, the Television Bureau of Advertising reported yesterday. The leader was the General Motors Corporation, which spent $846.7 million, an increase of 17 percent. The Ford Motor Company, in second place, spent $381.9 million, up 12 percent.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I transgressed certain of the laws and regulations that govern our industry. I was wrong in doing so and knew that at the time and I am pleading guilty to these offenses.''

title: Collapse of Their Defense Is Making the Rangers Insecure
description: The Rangers' defense, having been picked apart and then shredded on the ice by the Capitals, later stood dispersed in a funereal locker room, wearing looks of embarrassment, confusion and very nearly fright.

title: Lessons
description: Is the battle to attract more students from minority groups in American colleges and universities being won or lost?

title: Centerior Energy Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MCI to Get Loan
description: The Bank of America said it had agreed to make a $1 billion loan to finance the proposed acquisition of Telecom U.S.A. by the MCI Communications Corporation. MCI, based in Washington, will draw down part of its $500 million credit line with Bank of America to pay for the $1.25 billion transaction, which must still be approved by state and Federal regulators and Telecom's shareholders.

title: Allegheny Ludlum reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Dr. Irving Sarot, 78, A Thoracic Surgeon
description: Dr. Irving Sarot, a retired New York thoracic surgeon, died on Monday, apparently of a heart attack, at the Lotus Club in Manhattan. He was 78 years old and lived in West Hampton Beach, L.I.

title: Belgian Bank Deal
description: Banque Nationale de Paris S.A., France's largest commercial bank, agreed to buy the banking assets of Banque Nagelmackers 1747, Belgium's oldest bank, for $123 million. Nagelmackers said it would propose that its assets be split into a banking company and a real estate and portfolio investment company.

title: Roche Holding Ltd.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said sales and other figures were translated at rate of one Swiss franc equals 61 cents, the average 1989 prevailing rate, while consolidated net income was translated at one Swiss franc equals 65 cents, the rate at Dec. 31.

title: Mercury Capri To Cost $12,588
description: The Ford Motor Company today set $12,588 as the base price for its new Mercury Capri two-seat sports convertible, a model that Ford hopes will emulate the success of the Mazda Miata.

title: Umpire Arrested
description: Bob Engel, a crew chief among National League umpires, was arrested over the weekend on a charge of stealing 4,180 baseball cards from a retail store in Bakersfield, Calif., authorities said.

title: Melville Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Accounting Official to Quit
description: Raymond C. Lauver said yesterday that he would resign from the seven-member Financial Accounting Standards Board at the end of the year, more than three years before his current term would have expired.

title: Gorbachev Is Said to Delay Soviet Economic 'Shock Therapy' Plan
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has ruled out a Polish-style economic ''shock therapy'' for the Soviet Union this year because the Government does not have the popular support for such drastic change, Mr. Gorbachev's main economic advisers say.

title: Genuine Parts Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Helping Migrant Students Beat the Odds in School
description: All her life, Christina Garza has worn the path between this small agricultural town and Texas, moving with her parents and the crops.

title: Landmarks Panel Decision Is Blow to Developer
description: The New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission yesterday gave landmark status to a complex of 14 buildings in the Yorkville section of Manhattan that were originally constructed as a privately financed experiment to provide housing for the poor.

title: Oilers Need Overtime, but Sweep
description: Joe Murphy banged in a rebound of his own shot 4 minutes 42 seconds into overtime, lifting the Edmonton Oilers to a 6-5 victory over the Los Angeles Kings tonight and a sweep of the Smythe Division finals.

title: Lenders Accused On Escrow
description: Attorneys General from seven states charged yesterday that the nation's mortgage lenders are charging homeowners billions of dollars in excess escrow payments and holding the funds in accounts that bear little or no interest.

title: Celtics' Lewis Set To Exploit Any Chance
description: Reggie Lewis has grown accustomed to fighting for recognition.

title: Marion Merrell Dow Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Donors Plead for Ethiopian Truce To Prevent Starvation in the North
description: A group of Western countries appealed today to the Ethiopian Government and its rebel opposition for an immediate cease-fire and the reopening of the Red Sea port of Massawa to allow food shipments to avert starvation in the country's northern region.

title: Allergan Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago results are on a pro forma basis. Allergan, formerly a division of Smithkline Beckman Corp., became a stand-alone public company on July 27, 1989, resulting in a new capital and administrative structure. Therefore, year-ago net income data was adjusted to a pro forma basis compared to 1990 results.

title: CHOICE IN MANAGUA FOR MILITARY CHIEF SETS OFF A FUROR
description: On the eve of taking power, the political coalition of President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro has been thrown into crisis over a tentative agreement by Mrs. Chamorro to retain the Sandinista Defense Minister, Humberto Ortega Saavedra, as head of Nicaragua's army.

title: Lieutenant Who Aided Bronx Club Faces Charges
description: The police lieutenant who, acting as a private lawyer, filed incorporation papers for the Bronx social club in which 87 people were killed last month has been brought up on departmental charges of giving evasive answers about his moonlighting activities.

title: Harris Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,888,000 for the quarter and $8,070,000 for the 9 months.

title: Dow Chemical Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U.S. Securities Narrowly Mixed
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were narrowly mixed in a turbulent session yesterday, despite reports suggesting the economy is gathering strength and that inflation remains a real worry.

title: Times Mirror Net Down 33%
description: The Times Mirror Corporation said today that its first-quarter profit fell by 33 percent, while revenues rose by 3.3 percent.

title: How Do You Fix A Broken Planet?
description: PATTY FREEMAN DORSON is not unlike many other Americans trying to do their part when it comes to the environment.

title: EATING WELL
description: CARLOTTA FLORES would rather have a corn tortilla than a flour tortilla any day. A self-proclaimed health nut in the land of lard and melted cheese, Mrs. Flores has managed to provide an oxymoron: low-fat, low-cholesterol Mexican food.

title: Gaylord Container Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Rig Count Slips a Bit
description: The number of working United States oil and gas rigs fell last week by two, to a total of 932, Baker Hughes reported on Monday. The rig count also declined slightly in the previous two weeks.

title: Ingersoll-Rand Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $8.5 million, or 17 cents a share, representing utilization of capital loss carryforward from the sale of its finance subsidiary.

title: 2 Chemical Makers' Net Off
description: The Dow Chemical Company, the nation's second-largest producer of chemicals, said yesterday that its first-quarter net income plunged almost 38 percent because of higher costs for raw materials and lower prices for some products.

title: Surgery for McCants
description: Keith McCants underwent arthroscopic knee surgery yesterday, and the Tampa Bay Buccaneers' coach, Ray Perkins, said the procedure reassured him it wasn't a risk for his team to have taken the former Alabama linebacker with the fourth pick in the National Football League draft Sunday.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: THE assertive, rich flavor of calf's liver presents a challenge - and endless opportunities - to the home cook.

title: Vincent J. Hines, 77, Ex-Bishop of Norwich
description: The Rev. Vincent J. Hines, Roman Catholic Bishop of the Norwich Diocese in Connecticut from 1960 until he retired in 1975, died on Monday at Saint Francis Hospital and Medical Center. He was 77 years old.

title: Despite Loss, RJR Seen As Strong
description: Burdened with debt from history's largest buyout, the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation yesterday announced a first-quarter loss of $222 million, compared with a loss of $239 million for the comparable period of 1989. But strong operating profits and cash flow exceeded analysts' expectations.

title: Rates Jump At Citicorp Sale
description: Interest rates rose sharply at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper to their highest levels since late 1989.

title: Centex Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said improved results for both the quarter and year were due primarily to gains in its home building business.

title: Clemens Helps Red Sox Top Angels and Langston
description: Roger Clemens improved his record to 4-0 and the Boston Red Sox scored three unearned runs after an error by Mark Langston tonight to record a 4-2 victory over the California Angels.

title: Text of Statement to Court Describing 6 Felonies
description: Following is the text of the allocution, or statement to the court, by Michael R. Milken yesterday describing the six felonies to which he pleaded guilty:

title: Shell Oil Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included $70 million gain from insurance settlement. Shell is a unit of Royal Dutch-Shell Group.

title: President Named Chief At Cincinnati Milacron
description: Cincinnati Milacron Inc., a leading machine tool maker, announced yesterday that it had named Daniel J. Meyer chief executive, ending the long leadership of the founding Geier family at the company.

title: Test Finds High TB Rate At a Shelter
description: Doctors testing homeless men at a clinic in a New York City shelter have found that an extraordinarily high number are infected with tuberculosis.

title: As Oakley Practices, Knicks' Spirits Lift
description: Charles Oakley moved laterally a foot or so behind the foul line, catching the ball and shooting it while Paul Silas, one of the Knicks' assistant coaches, kibitzed with him.

description: b-Included loss from discontinued operations of $200,000, and an extraordinary loss of $600,000 from additional costs of 1983 settlement.

description: b-Included a charge of $3 million related to reorganization activities.

description: Victor Stello Jr., the nuclear power expert nominated by President Bush to take charge of the nation's troubled nuclear weapons program, has asked that his nomination be withdrawn, the Department of Energy disclosed yesterday.

description: b-The company said 1990 quarter and second half net losses were adversely affected by expenses from the acquisition and integration of several company units and investment in systems and facilities to accommodate expected future growth for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net income

title: Fun (Some of It Serious) at Kips Bay
description: SAVING the planet and recycling, making the most of small spaces, lots of electronic gadgetry and plenty of humor - these are the lively and surprisingly timely themes at this year's Kips Bay Decorator Show House.

title: Engelhard Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Addendum
description: * Leading National Advertisers has acquired Radio Expenditure Reports Inc. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Militant Urges Captors Not to Free Hostages
description: A leader of the pro-Iranian Party of God today urged kidnappers holding seven American hostages not to free any of them because of what he called ill will on the part of the United States.

title: Florida Orders Spraying to Combat Fruit Fly
description: Florida has ordered aerial spraying of the pesticide malathion to protect its $1.4 billion citrus industry from an infestation of Mediterranean fruit flies.

description: b-Net income

title: Harvesting the Universe
description: The deployment of the Hubble Space Telescope yesterday is among NASA's finest achievements. Floating above the distorting veil of the atmosphere, the huge instrument will bring the universe into view with far greater clarity than ever before. Landing on the Moon was a giant technical step for humankind; the Hubble telescope promises giant intellectual strides toward understanding the structure of the universe.

title: Tough Anti-Smoking Effort Aims at Cigarette Marketers
description: In Paul Keye's view, the most effective way to combat smoking, especially among teen-agers and the underprivileged, is to undermine the advertising that portrays cigarettes as glamorous or ''cool.''

title: Auberges des Gouverneurs reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a loss of $123,000 from the sale of shares. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Review/Television;   Jennings Says U.S. Helps Khmer Rouge
description: ''From the Killing Fields,'' tonight's report by Peter Jennings at 10 P.M. on ABC, makes the argument that the United States is covertly supporting the return to power in Cambodia of the Khmer Rouge. That is a heavy accusation, given the death and devastation that the Communist movement under Pol Pot inflicted on the country before it was driven out by the Vietnamese a decade ago.

title: CCX Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $119,000, or 3 cents a share for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income and the 9 months included income from discontinued operations of $401,000, or 10 cents a share.

description: b-Included a $30 million after-tax benefit resulting from the cumulative effect for prior years of a change in accounting principle related to refinery maintenance shutdowns.

description: The company said 1989 share earnings reflected a 2-for-1 stock split in October.

title: 'The German Question Remains Open'
description: The message from the President of the United States was delivered to me on the Lufthansa plane even before the takeoff for Germany.

description: b-Included extraordinary loss of $1,996,000, net of related income tax benefit of $1,027,000, or 16 cents a share, related to the company's Aug. 31. 1989 redemption of $33 million outstanding on its $35 million issue of 14.5 percent subordinated debentures due 1994 at 100 percent of their principal loss. c-Net loss The latest first quarter's revenue included about $8,736,000 in fees and distributions upon the sale of the remaining cable television systems owned by a managed limited partnership.

description: * Irwin Gotlieb has been promoted to worldwide director of broadcast and programming at D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, and Rino Scanzoni to director of national broadcast for the agency's United States division.

description: b-Net income

title: Bush Can Discontinue Drops For Glaucoma, Doctors Say
description: Two prominent eye doctors said today that President Bush could discontinue using prescription eye drops for his glaucoma.

description: Two teams of researchers, one French and one American, report that they have developed separate ways to improve the success rates of kidney transplant surgery.

title: CHRONICLE
description: After a bout of pneumonia that nearly killed her last weekend, ELIZABETH TAYLOR was much improved yesterday, her doctors said. They said they could find no evidence that she had either AIDS or cancer. Rumors about the health of the 58-year-old screen star have been circulating since she was hospitalized in California on April 9.

title: Iroquois Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Iroquois became the thrift holding company of Cayuga Savings Bank on March 1 and reports consolidated financial information of Iroquois and Cayuga.

title: Clevetrust Realty Investors reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income c-After extraordinary credits of $84,000, or 4 cents a share for the quarter and $266,000, or 13 cents a share for the 6 months. The company said year-ago revenues for both the quarter and 6 months included a $420,000 rent settlement received in January 1989.

title: Delvin Miller: Eight Decades In the Sulky
description: While touring Ireland a few years ago, Delvin Miller was invited to visit the Portmarnock trotting track. But because of traffic and misdirections on the small country roads outside Dublin, he and his friends didn't arrive until well after the first race was scheduled to go off. ''I'm sorry I'm late,'' he said. ''You're not late,'' one of the track executives said. ''We decided to hold up the start of the races until such a trotting legend as yourself finally got here.''

title: Lone Star Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $1.6 million.

Accounts
description: * Borden Inc., to W. B. Doner & Co., for Wise Foods and other snack brands, including Krunchers! potato chips.

The Poverty Line - Too Low for the 90's
description: LEAD: Mary A. works hard, but no matter how hard she tries, there is just no way to make ends meet. This week her 7-year-old son Tim is sick, but one trip to the doctor will wipe out the week's food budget.

title: HAILS A NEW ERA
description: Ending more than a decade of rule by the Sandinista National Liberation Front, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro was inaugurated today as Nicaragua's President. In a gesture of reconciliation, she then retained the top Sandinista military leader as the senior commander in the armed forces.

title: Nicaragua's Hard Road to a New Day
description: Jan 10, 1978: Pedro Joaquin Chamorro, a newspaper publisher who is an outspoken opponent of the dictator Anastasio Somoza Debayle, is killed in downtown Managua, and widespread anti-Government protests ensue.

title: Article 654290 -- No Title
description: Sotheby's, the auction house, and William Acquavella, a major New York art dealer, have agreed to buy the contents of the Pierre Matisse Gallery in New York for $142.8 million, acquiring one of the great inventories of 20th-century art.

description: DESIGNER show houses and house and garden tours are being offered up and down the East Coast over the next two months. Here are some of the possibilities for a spring outing.

description: Georgia officials are trying to sort out why the man accused of shooting five people in a shopping mall here Tuesday had been released from a state mental hospital a day earlier.

description: Saks Fifth Avenue, one of the world's premier high-fashion retailers, will be sold by its British owners for $1.5 billion to a Mideast financial group known as Investcorp.

AMR Upgrading
description: The AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines, said it would spend $11 billion to expand passenger services to try to become the nation's premiere international airline. The company said it was beginning a five-year plan that would include such luxuries as lobster served on china, despite the $19.3 million first-quarter loss that AMR reported last week.

title: Glade Peterson, Tenor, 61
description: Glade Peterson, a tenor, died of cancer on Saturday. He was 61 years old. Mr. Peterson made his professional debut in 1958 as Pinkerton in Puccini's ''Madama Butterfly'' with the NBC Touring Company in Amherst, Mass. His European debut was in 1960 in Spoleto, Italy.

title: New U.S. Aid Sought For High Technology
description: Proponents of increased financial support for the development of advanced technologies, concerned that the Bush Administration is reducing its commitment to research sponsored by a Pentagon agency, are scrambling to find new sources of money outside the military budget.

title: Walt Disney Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

Electronics Notebook;   Adventures in Never-Never Land    The Revenge of Shinobi. Ninja without the turtles. Magic powers involving floating and fire help in duels over waterfalls, a Detroit junkyard and New York Harbor.    Phantasy Star 2. An epic puzzle game that can take 150 hours to solve. Players collect weapons and clues and negotiate mazes.    NEC TURBOGRAFX-16 The system's list price is $199, and it comes with the game Keith Courage. Other individual games sell for $39 to $67.50, including these:    World Class Baseball. Index-finger batting and pitching aided by strategic planning and statistics.    Blazing Lazers. Breathless arcade battles in space. A suitable companion to Alien Crush, pinball amid alien body parts.
description: FOR the last month I have been the envy of every 8-year-old on my block. I have played pinball inside an alien's skull, my ball ricocheting against bones and eyeballs. I have changed from a muscle-bound weightlifter into a werewolf that can throw fire. And I have found myself, at long last, as a mustachioed Italian plumber in overalls who can break bricks with his head, jump over canyons and climb through pipes into strange other worlds.

title: Officials Fear Albany Cuts Will Raise Local Taxes
description: While Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and legislative leaders continue their private negotiations on how to slash state spending, local officials fear that they may be the ones who get bloodied, both fiscally and politically.

description: Pete Rose is no longer in baseball, but just as his career hits record will live long after him, so apparently will the Pete Rose telephone logs.

description: Year-ago figures included a gain of $1.8 million related to a pension settlement.

description: Shareholders of the Swedish car maker Volvo A.B. approved a link with Renault S.A. of France. The alliance of the companies' car, truck and bus operations through cross-ownership deals calls for cooperation on research and development, component purchases and investment.

description: The Soviet Union has bought an additional 149,000 metric tons of United States wheat at subsidized prices for delivery next month, the Agriculture Department said this week. It said the wheat had been sold by two private companies, which will receive subsidies under the department's Export Enhancement Program.

description: b-Included results of Sylvan Learning Corp., which experienced anticipated seasonal losses, and Mini- Skools Ltd., both of which Kinder- Care acquired in November 1989.

description: Saturday Night

description: THE Dayton Hudson Corporation's $1.04 billion deal to buy Marshall Field & Company, announced last Thursday, shows that despite the recent troubles of several big department stores, a strong economic niche still exists for full-line, broad-based chains, merchants and analysts say.

description: b-Included a nonrecurring charge of 6 cents a share in the latest quarter and a gain of 11 cents a share in the year-ago quarter.

title: Genentech's Income Rises
description: Genentech Inc. today reported improved revenues and profits for the first quarter. But the company said it expected expenses of about $150 million related to its proposed merger with Roche Holdings Inc. and was likely to report a loss for the year.

Evolution in Europe;   Victory Seen for Nationalists in Yugoslav Republic
description: A conservative nationalist party appears to have swept to victory in the opening round of the first free multiparty elections to be held in the Yugoslav republic of Croatia in more than 50 years.

title: A Top Auto Theft Ring Is Reported Smashed
description: The police reported breaking up a major automobile-theft ring yesterday that they said was stealing 15 cars a week from Ozone Park, Queens, and selling the parts through a salvage yard in downtown Brooklyn.

The companies said that no further talks were scheduled, but Pacificare, a unit of Unihealth America, said that it would review its options.

description: The agreement by Compagnie Saint-Gobain to buy the Norton Company for about $1.9 billion is the latest, and largest, in a recent string of some two dozen acquisitions by the French glass and packaging conglomerate.

description: WHEN an old or historic house is being restored, an interior architectural detail often in need of repair or replacement is plaster, in the form of ceiling medallions, cornices, capitals, pilasters, moldings and brackets.

description: b-Net income

description: Under siege by environmentalists for more than a year, Lawrence G. Rawl, the chairman of the Exxon Corporation, won a measure of support today as a series of environmental initiatives were overwhelmingly rejected at the company's annual shareholders' meeting.

description: The company said the latest quarter results included a provision for loan losses of $1.7 million.

title: Power Cut in West as Protest
description: A total of 92,000 Pacific Gas and Electric customers in Santa Cruz County were without power for six hours Sunday and early Monday because of vandalism, and an underground environmental group has claimed responsibility. Handwritten messages delivered Monday to several news organizations asked for understanding for the action by the Earth Night Action Group. A wooden pole was cut and a steel transmission tower toppled. The message blamed the utility for buyouts of solar energy companies.

title: Spots by Follis & Verdi To Fight Child Abuse
description: The camera first looks down on the basketball player's sneakers, and then, amid chilling music, it pans seven feet up to his head. He bends toward the camera and says, ''If it makes you nervous to have someone my size in your face, now you know how your kid feels when you're in his.'' In one spot the player is Mark Eaton, the 7-foot-4 center of the Utah Jazz. In another he is Bill Cartwright, the 7-foot-1 center of the Chicago Bulls.

title: Energen Corp. reports earnings for 12mo March 31
description: b-After a loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $2,061,000 and a loss from discontinued operations of $499,000. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $266,000, or 3 cents a share.

title: Police Say Drug-Program Profiles Are Not Biased
description: All but 2 of the 210 people arrested last year in a drug-interdiction program at the Port Authority Bus Terminal in midtown were black or Hispanic, the bistate agency said yesterday.

title: Shell Canada reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Ampco-Pittsburgh reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $1,040,000, or 11 cents a share. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $460,000, or 5 cents a share and an extraordinary tax credit of $400,000, or 4 cents a share.

title: Yanks Lose to Mariners; Perez's Shoulder Is Ailing
description: After six years in the major leagues, Pascual Perez has a pretty good handle on the art of pitching, but now that he's in New York, the $5.7 million dollar Yankee righthander has to work on another aspect of the game.

title: County Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Chiquita Brands International Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results in the latest quarter included a pretax gain of $8.5 million resulting from the sale of common stock investments.

title: Michener's Random Deal
description: A month after he threatened to abandon Random House, the novelist James Michener has decided to stay with his longtime publisher after all.

title: Dr. Max L. Som, 84, Specialist in Tumors Of Head and Neck
description: Dr. Max L. Som, a surgeon and leader in the field of otolaryngology whose specialty was the treatment of tumors of the head and neck, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan, after a long illness. He was 84 years old.

title: Dexter Gordon Dies at 67; A Charismatic Jazz Figure
description: Dexter Gordon, one of the great tenor saxophonists and a charismatic figure in the jazz world, died of kidney failure yesterday at Thomas Jefferson University Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 67 years old, and had entered the hospital on March 18 for treatment of cancer of the larynx. He lived in New York City.

title: Mips Computer Systems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $374,000.

title: BCE Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included $10 million loss from real estate operations. Year-ago results are restated. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with the continuation of an article about Walter H. Annenberg's art collection misidentified the bottom painting of the two shown. It was van Gogh's ''Olive Trees,'' not Cezanne's ''Mont Sainte-Victoire.''

title: House Passes Bank Bill On Money Laundering
description: The House voted today to set up a process that would allow the Government to close banks and savings and loans convicted of laundering drug money.

title: Diagnostic Products reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Currents;   One Thing About Dirt: It's Really Dirty
description: SPRING is a dirty business, with all its potting, repotting and coaxing seeds into life. It's especially messy for those without a proper place to play in soil. But now tidy potting is possible anywhere, with a gadget that Graham Kinsman sells by mail order in Pennsylvania.

title: Off Broadway (Way, Way Off), A Tuneful 'Spider Woman' Is On
description: John Rubinstein and Kevin Gray are sitting at a small table, stage center, in a dimly lighted, somewhat seedy Latin American nightclub. They are cellmates in a dark and torture-filled prison in a Latin American dictatorship, but their cell has been transformed into the nightclub, which is part of a movie musical unfolding in Mr. Rubinstein's mind.

title: Landmark Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Sysco Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Envirosafe Services reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $424,000.

title: Misguided Missile in Europe
description: President Bush and Prime Minister Thatcher displayed a puzzling shortsightedness in their recent Bermuda meeting. Bowing belatedly to reality, they finally stopped trying to put new short-range ground-launched nuclear missiles into West Germany. Those missiles have been made superfluous by revolutionary change in Eastern Europe.

title: Is Too Tall Too Old?
description: Ed (Too Tall) Jones, the Dallas Cowboys' 39-year-old defensive end, said yesterday that he did not intend to return for a 16th season. He said yesterday in Dallas that he might consider offers from other N.F.L. teams, but also hinted that he might retire.

title: First Fedl Svgs of Charlotte County, Fla.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago quarter's per share earnings reflected restatement to show 10 percent stock dividend declared on Nov. 16, 1989.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Second National Fedl Savings reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included about $400,000 from securities gains. The latest per share earnings were after preferred dividends.

title: Foundation Clears Plan To Sell Gannett Shares
description: Trustees of the Gannett Foundation today approved the possible sale of some or all of its 10 percent stake in the Gannett Company, one the nation's largest communications companies.

title: Stocks Rise, With Dow Rebounding 11.94
description: Stock prices yesterday broke a five-day losing streak, with the Dow Jones industrial average advancing 11.94 points, to 2,666.44. Analysts attributed the momentum to takeover fever.

title: Baldwin Piano & Organ reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Brunswick Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
New Ballet Theater Dancer
description: Faruk Ruzimatov, a principal dancer with the Kirov Ballet, has joined American Ballet Theater as a principal, effective immediately, Ballet Theater has announced. Mr. Ruzimatov, whose Ballet Theater contract runs through November, is to perform in the company's eight-week season, opening on May 7, at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Datum Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U.S. Checks Possibility Of Attack on a Judge
description: The rear window of a Federal judge's car was shattered as he drove to work today, and the authorities immediately undertook an investigation to determine whether the incident was related to a mail bomb that killed a judge of the same court four months ago.

title: Metro Matters;   Alumni of Club, Recalling Past, Ponder Present
description: Gray-haired Brownsville natives were debating whether the legendary boys club some joined as teen-agers 50 years ago could be duplicated today when Norman Podhoretz impatiently held up a photograph.

title: Harvard Law School Torn by Race Issue
description: Professors and students at Harvard Law School have been polarized over the issues raised by a black professor's declaration on Monday that he intended to stay off the job until the school appoints a black woman to its tenured faculty.

title: First Republic Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Exalting the Tassel, Or, Chrome Go Home
description: MARTHA STEWART'S favorite book is titled ''The Standard of Perfection.'' The book is about raising chickens, not decorating, but there are parallels. ''It's not necessary to do everything yourself,'' she explained, ''but to be able to judge what's good.''

title: Saab Stock Option
description: An investment house controlled by the Swedish financier Peter Wallenberg said it had an option to buy 13 million shares in the vehicle maker Saab-Scania A.B. at a hefty premium from another Swedish investment firm, Barkman & Company. The financial daily Dagens Industri reported that the shares would give Mr. Wallenberg 51 percent of Saab's capital and 58 percent of the voting rights. The deal was further evidence of Mr. Wallenberg's strategy to tighten control over his sprawling empire of blue-chip Swedish companies, which includes Saab, SKF and Stora.

title: Perry K. Sellon, Editor, 78
description: Perry Kimball Sellon, a business editor for U.S. News and World Report for 21 years, died of congestive heart failure on Monday at his home in Chevy Chase, Md. He was 78 years old.

title: Albany Reaches Accord on Trucking Bills
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and legislative leaders have reached agreement on a broad package of safety measures for the trucking industry, including a ban on the use of radar detectors by truckers and new prohibitions against drinking.

title: Events: Architecture Of a New Generation
description: Violet Venue, Horticultural Society of New York, 128 West 58th Street; 212-757-0915.

title: Sun's Work Station Gets More Power
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. said it had raised the performance on its most popular desktop work station, the Sparcstation 1, and lowered prices on various peripheral products. Depending on configuration, the resdesignated Sparcstation 1+ is priced from $8,995 to $27,695.

title: Parsippany Home of Gustav Stickley Opening This Weekend
description: THIS weekend, a house that may well become a major shrine of the American Arts and Crafts Movement is scheduled to open to the public. The opening festivities mark the beginning of an ambitious, long-range program for a museum and study center at Craftsman Farms, the family residence of Gustav Stickley, the Arts and Crafts furniture manufacturer and philosopher.

title: United Industrial reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and included a non-cash charge of $6,595,000, or 50 cents a share, from a court settlement.

title: Inter Federal Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After extraordinary tax loss carryforwards of $160,000, or 16 cents a share, for the latest first quarter and $169,000, or 16 cents a share, for year- ago period.

title: Senate Debates Spending Bill, Delaying a Clash on Abortion
description: Temporarily putting aside a brewing fight over abortion, the Senate today began debate on a $2.3 billion emergency spending bill to provide aid for Panama and Nicaragua as well as money that the Census Bureau needs to complete the 1990 census.

title: Ameriana Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Holiday Inns Cuts
description: Holiday Inns Inc. said it would eliminate 600 jobs by reorganizing its hotel management efforts into separate divisions overseeing franchise operations and its company-owned hotels. The company, purchased by the British brewery and hotel conglomerate Bass P.L.C. in February, plans to concentrate on hotels, its main business.

title: Sara Lee Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a pretax gain of $32 million made up of a gain of $87 million from the sale of certain subsidiaries and a restructuring charge of $55 million. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in December.

title: Amwest Insurance Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said first quarter 1990 earnings included a $135,000, or 5 cents a share, negative adjustment due to potential rebates Amwest may incur under Proposition 103, which would roll back rates of certain insurance companies.

title: The Homely Floor Cloth, With a Touch of Mystery
description: CHARLES GOFORTH, a Manhattan artist, has taken a homely accessory dating from the 18th century and made it exotic. He paints trompe l'oeil floor cloths: an Oriental rug that seems to be peeled back from a tile floor; a mosaic floor that appears to be worn and stained in one corner.

title: Roosevelt Island: A 'Wonderful' Experiment Still Building
description: Twenty years after New York City and state officials decided to create a new community on Roosevelt Island, integrated by race and income, the social experiment has been hailed as a success while the housing development is still struggling toward completion.

title: Knicks Counting on Revised Cast To Come Up With a Different Act
description: Patrick Ewing's and Gerald Wilkins's records against the Boston Celtics during the regular season were 1-4. Charles Oakley was 1-2; Maurice Cheeks and Kiki Vandeweghe were 0-2.

title: Anthony Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said share earnings reflect a 5 percent stock dividend in December 1989.

title: Solzhenitsyn Bars 'Gulag' Staging So Muscovites Have 'Rehearsals'
description: Two men sit in a large Moscow building among scaffolding and buckets of paint and wait for a word from Vermont. They are Vyacheslav Spesivtsev, the director of the Moscow Experimental Theater Studio, and his aide, Vitaly Mozgalin, and they are filled with hope that Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn will one day say yes to their theatrical interpretation of his ''Gulag Archipelago.''

title: President Is Promoted At Battle Mountain Gold
description: The Battle Mountain Gold Company has named Karl E. Elers as chairman and chief executive. His mission will be to bring the company successfully through the next few years as its most important gold mine runs out.

title: Real Estate Feels the Pain Of Tighter Credit Standards
description: The real estate industry, more than any other, is feeling the pinch of the tighter lending standards being applied by banks across the country.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: A 40-year-old man with mysterious symptoms entered the hospital for tests. A week later, he died. The cause of his death was never revealed, although the family had reason to believe that one of the tests was responsible.

title: Yankees Turn to Grey
description: In yet another addition to the ever-changing New York Yankee roster, George Steinbrenner has hired Grey Entertainment and Media, a division of Grey Advertising, as its new advertising agency. Grey's campaign, entitled ''Heroes in Pinstripes,'' will draw heavily on Yankee legends. Billings for the account, formerly handled in the house that Ruth built, were not disclosed. Grey Entertainment and Media's other accounts include the New York Knicks and the New York Rangers.

title: Former Trader Settles Case
description: A former trader at Marcus Schloss & Company, a New York Stock Exchange specialist firm, has settled Government charges that he traded inside information about possible corporate takeovers, the Securities and Exchange Commission said on Tuesday.

title: Washington Talk;   Democrats Look to '92 Starting Line
description: A Bob Kerrey boomlet hit the nation's capital not long ago, one more example of the twitching, anxious yearning in some political circles for the start of the 1992 Presidential campaign.

title: Knowledgeware Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Northern States Power Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Shorter Rations for Borrowers
description: Some companies are complaining that their banks have turned stingy with loans, creating a ''credit crunch'' that could needlessly strangle business activity and cause a recession. For their part, bankers talk about ''prudent'' lending as a reasoned response to a weaker economy and to the tightening of standards by Federal bank regulators.

title: Cuomo and Lawmakers Agree on Medicaid Cuts
description: Inching toward an agreement on a new state budget, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and legislative leaders said today that they had resolved two issues - how to cut Medicaid spending and how to reduce the state's contribution to its pension system.

title: Du Pont (E.I.) de Nemours & Co.  (N) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said first-quarter results included non-recurring charges, mostly from business restructurings. These charges lowered earnings by 7 cents a share, 4 cents of which related to the polymers segment. The prior year's quarter included a benefit of 5 cents a share from the sale of an interest in a north sea natural gas property.

title: Article 623590 -- No Title
description: The Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation, which sells securities on behalf of the 15 banks in the Farm Credit System, yesterday priced a three-part financing totaling $2.85 billion through a nationwide group of securities dealers and dealer banks.

title: Fort Wayne National reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Ameritrust Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Consolidated Freightways Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and included a gain of $11,300,000, or 30 cents a share from an accounting adjustment. Year-ago results are restated for the restroactive adoption of SFAS No. 96, regarding a change in method of accounting for income taxes. The company said the increase in revenues primarily reflects the acquisition of Emery Worldwide. The company also said the net loss is mostly attributable to Emery, which reported an operating loss of $69,500,000, on revenues of $317,800,000 for the quarter.

title: Christian Factions Resume Battle in Beirut
description: Rival Christian forces fought with tanks, artillery and multi-barreled rocket launchers today in a fresh flareup of their three-month battle for control of their enclave north of here.

title: Currents;   Don't Squeeze The Grapes
description: ''NEW YORKERS seem starved for fruit and flower motifs: they like eating them, looking at them and wearing them,'' said Anne Bialos, an artist whose Brooklyn garden is the inspiration for her line of horticultural jewelry.

title: Washington Gas Light reports earnings for Year to March 31
Samplers Offer Look At History
description: In the 18th and early 19th century, a well-bred young woman was an accomplished seamstress. She stitched the alphabet on samplers so that when she was married, clothes and linens could be marked with the family's initials. At finishing school, she made silk embroideries that might have commemorated the death of George Washington or depicted a river scene.

title: Illinois Power Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included an after-tax charge of $346 million in response to disallowances relating to the construction of Clinton power station.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * EMI Music Worldwide, New York, a subsidiary of Thorn EMI P.L.C., London, promoted Philip Rowley to executive vice president.

title: Empi Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Guess Who Doesn't Recycle. Hint: They Run the Country.
description: Since the Sierra Club threatened to sue Federal agencies for not complying with the District of Columbia's recycling law, the State Department and others have begun to separate and sort their trash.

title: Gateway Financial reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included $1.5 million recognition of securities losses to bring the investment portfolio in bank stocks to its current market value. c-Net income

title: Du Pont's Profits Declined By 16.4% in First Quarter
description: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, the nation's largest chemical manufacturer, said yesterday that its first-quarter net income dropped 16.4 percent, reflecting a cost-improvement program and continued weakness in the housing and automotive industry.

title: Jackson Visits Teaneck And Talks to Students
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson today urged 1,200 Teaneck High School students to rise above the divisiveness caused by the police shooting of a black teen-ager and to ''give justice and peace a chance.''

title: Tax the Toxics Out of the Environment
description: To the Editor:

title: Civic Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Currents;   A Bliss Of Orchids Is Nigh
description: DEPRESSED by a droopy Dendrobium? The place to work out your angst is the orchid show that opens this morning at the Enid A. Haupt Conservatory of the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

title: Allegheny Power System reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said net income for the recent periods reflects the continued growth in kilowatthour sales and the elimination in January of the previously reported temporary $20 million reduction in annual revenues in Pennsylvania.

title: First Harrisburg Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Latest per share earnings adjusted for 10 percent stock dividend paid in the fourth quarter of 1989.

title: Confertech International reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $59,302.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Bonn Opposition Chief Stabbed at Campaign Rally
description: Oskar Lafontaine, the candidate for Chancellor from the opposition Social Democratic Party, was stabbed in the throat today by a German woman carrying a knife concealed in a bouquet of flowers.

title: Pitney Bowes Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $97,000 and an accounting adjustment gain of $66,048,000, or 83 cents a share. Results for 1989 have been restated to reflect discontinued operations and change in method of accounting for income taxes.

title: Rio Algom reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $1,824,000, or 4 cents a share. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: One Valley Bancorp of W.Va.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Heart Medicine Appears to Slow Lung Damage in Cystic Fibrosis
description: A preliminary study has found that a new form of a high blood pressure medicine appears to slow the life-threatening lung damage of cystic fibrosis.

title: Knicks Look to a Graybeard to Be a Greyhound
description: There are no state secrets in the National Basketball Association.

title: To Abortion Foes, Issue Is Ethical, Not Moral
description: To the Editor:

title: Davox Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Fuqua Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Suspension for Myricks
description: Larry Myricks, the world's second-ranked long jumper, has been suspended from American and international competition for three months for testing positive for a stimulant commonly found in an over-the-counter cold medication.

title: Prototype of Submarine Reactor Prepared for Tests
description: A prototype for a powerful new nuclear reactor, intended to propel a new generation of submarines at greater speeds and depths, is quietly being prepared for testing at a Government laboratory near Schenectady, experts said yesterday.

title: Western Union Seeks Note Swap
description: The Western Union Corporation told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it would seek to swap new secured notes and common stock for $530 million worth of its outstanding notes. The company also said in a filing that it would seek to reclassify its preferred stock and class B common shares, which require dividend payments, as regular common shares, which do not require dividend payments. The company has been unable to make dividend payments because of financial difficulties.

title: Incstar Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary tax benefit of $186,000, or 1 cent a share. c-Net loss and after an extraordinary loss of $321,000 from early retirement of debt.

title: Islamic Militants Dominating Sudan, Exiles Assert
description: The execution of 28 officers by firing squad in the Sudan left no doubt that the 10-month-old military Government was totally dominated by the fundamentalist National Islamic Front, Sudanese exiles and human rights monitors say.

title: Altos Computer reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included net gain of $5.7 million, or 48 cents a share, from the sale of the company's majority owned subsidiary, Communications Solutions Inc.

title: Li Peng Says Soviet Ideas of Change Do Not Apply to China
description: Prime Minister Li Peng of China said today that reports of a rift with Moscow over the waning of Communism had been exaggerated, but he left little doubt that the two neighbors are on different political wavelengths.

title: Arctic Alaska Fisheries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Anheuser Net Up 9.2%
description: The Anheuser-Busch Companies reported today that its profits had risen 9.2 percent in its first quarter. The company, the world's largest brewer, said it had earned $182.5 million, or 64 cents a share, in the quarter, up from $167.1 million, or 58 cents, a year earlier. Sales rose 8.1 percent, to $2.59 billion from $2.40 billion. The company's share of the beer market rose to 42 percent in 1989 from about 40 percent in 1988.

title: Mid Maine Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest quarter included $170,000 in income tax expenses related to a proposed change in tax regulations, and a pre-tax gain of $325,000 from the sale of about $8.5 million of mortgage loans.

title: Michael Milken's Guilt
description: Michael Milken is a crook. He admitted that much in U.S. District Court Tuesday when he pleaded guilty to six felonies and agreed to put up $600 million, $200 million of that in fines, to settle the biggest fraud case in the history of the securities industry.

title: Robert L. Finley, 90, Lawyer and U.S. Aide
description: Robert Lawrence Finley, a lawyer in Manhattan and a retired Government official, died of cancer on Sunday at Huggins Hospital in Wolfeboro, N.H. He was 90 years old and lived in Tamworth, N.H.

title: Allen Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $8,855,000, or 86 cents a share. The company said discontinued operations reflected the gain on disposal of those operations. The company also said latest quarter figures do not include a provision related to the award in January of $17.2 million in damages to Modine Manufacturing Co.

title: P.&G. Profits Rise by 30%
description: The Procter & Gamble Company, one of the world's leading makers of consumer products, said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings rose more than 30 percent, to $404 million, or $1.14 a share, compared with a profit of $310 million, or 92 cents a share, in the corresponding period a year ago.

title: Icahn May Lift Stake If USX Plan Is Cleared
description: Carl C. Icahn, the New York financier, said yesterday that he intended to buy an additional $800 million of stock in the USX Corporation if a proposal to split the company is approved by shareholders at the May 7 annual meeting.

title: Burritt Interfincl reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Catherine M. Quigley, Mayor, 59
description: Catherine M. Quigley, the Mayor of this Camden County community of about 5,000 people since 1986 died of cancer on Monday at her home here. She was 59 years old.

title: International Rectifier Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: FirstFed Financial reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bhopal Pact Won't Increase
description: Shareholders of the Union Carbide Corporation voted not to increase a $470 million settlement to victims of the 1984 Bhopal disaster at today's annual meeting.

title: Overtime Goal Gives Capitals 3-1 Series Edge
description: For each of the Rangers on the ice for Rod Langway's overtime goal, panic set in at different intervals in the brief sequence that led to a 4-3 loss to the Capitals, a defeat that carried with it a nearly suffocating despair.

title: Amoskeag Bank Shares reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Reviews/Dance;   Ballet Season Begins
description: The New York City Ballet opened its spring season on Tuesday night at the New York State Theater with three well-danced works by George Balanchine. It was a program that suggested the remarkable variety of which Balanchine was capable and that showed off the considerable talents of the company's principal dancers and young soloists.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Msgr. WILLIAM B. O'BRIEN, the founder and president of Daytop Village, the international drug-rehabilitation program, will visit China in June to help establish a center in Kunming in Yunnan province. ''They are having a drug epidemic,'' he said. Kunming is near drug-producing centers in Laos, Myanmar and Thailand. Last June, Chinese officials, including Dr. ZUONING JIANG, the director of China's drug-dependency treatment program, visited Daytop's treatment center outside Bangkok, Thailand. Last October, Dr. Zuoning conferred with Daytop officials in New York. The formal request for the Kunming center came from CHEN MINZHANG, China's Minister of Health.

title: Branford Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Rome Journal;   Marcus Aurelius Rides Again, but Behind Glass
description: On this day of Italian liberation, the most unliberated soul in town happened to be a figure often regarded, Shakespeare notwithstanding, as the noblest Roman of them all.

title: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included $4.4 million, or 7 cents a share, for the latest first quarter and $4.4 million, or 8 cents a share, for year-ago period, both from utilization of foreign loss carryover tax benefits. Goodyear said net income for 1990 reflected depreciation of the All American Pipeline System as well as inclusion of its operating and interest expenses which were capitalized last year. Recognition of these items in the 1989 quarter would have reduced that period's net income by $27.1 million, or 47 cents a share.

title: AMP Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a pretax charge of $20 million for early termination program and other restructuring costs.

title: Reviews/Dance;   Blend With Conceptual Art
description: There is a wonderfully theatrical effect toward the end of Jonathon Appels's new ''Crimson,'' presented by the Company Appels on Friday night at the Cooper Union Great Hall. A line of dancers stretches across the shallow stage space, shifting in almost continuous motion as a floodlight at the back of the auditorium slowly pans the stage. The shadows of the stagelights and of the auditorium's pillars move across the stage like inanimate dancers in an unsettled field of motion.

title: Freeport-McMoran Resource Partners L.P.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $100.9 million on sale of certain nitrogen fertilizer assets. Share earnings and shares outstanding are in units.

title: American Savings Bank (N.Y.) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The bank said about $11 million was added to real estate reserves, reflecting weakened Northeast market conditions. The 1990 provision included a previously announced charge of $4 million related to the reacquisition of unsold shares in four residential co-op conversion projects.

title: Cyprus Minerals Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
One Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $29,716,000, or $3.63 a share, from retirement of debt. c-Net loss and after an extraordinary credit of $577,000, or 7 cents a share.

title: Cominco Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Korean Shipyard Strike
description: About 20,000 workers at South Korea's largest shipyard went on strike today to protest the arrest of their union leaders, company officials said. Hyundai Heavy Industries, the scene of a three-month labor dispute last year, is the first important manufacturing company to be hit by a strike this year. A union leader, Lee Yong Hon, was arrested in February and his deputy, Woo Ki Ha, was detained last week while trying to organize union action to back demands for Mr. Lee's release. Hyundai has brought charges against both men, accusing them of causing disruptions.

title: Ferrell to Miss Season For Positive Drug Test
description: The Phoenix Cardinal fullback Earl Ferrell, the team's leading rusher the past two seasons, was informed by the National Football League that he had tested positive for drugs and must miss the 1990 season.

title: In Switch, U.S. Studies Home Test Kits for AIDS
description: The Food and Drug Administration said today that it had reconsidered its longstanding opposition to the idea of testing for AIDS in the home and would accept applications for approval of test kits.

title: Soviet Old and Disabled Faring Better
description: To the Editor:

title: BancOklahoma Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Retail Leaders Cautiously Optimistic on Saks Sale
description: New York store and fashion industry executives reacted with surprise and some optimism to the announced sale of Saks Fifth Avenue yesterday.

title: Prison Sentence of Top Aide To Bakker Cut to 2 1/2 Years
description: A Federal judge today reduced from eight years to two and a half the prison sentence of Richard Dortch, former top aide to Jim Bakker at the PTL television ministry.

title: Parent & Child
description: A 10-YEAR-OLD boy was sent to the principal's office at Belmont Elementary School in Lincoln, Neb., after he came to class with answers to a standardized test written on his hands. The boy had copied some of the questions from the test booklet the day before the examination.

title: Adac Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
Article 717190 -- No Title
description: In a surprise bid that ended a bitter takeover fight with BTR P.L.C., the Norton Company announced yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by Compagnie de Saint-Gobain, a French conglomerate, for $90 a share, or about $1.9 billion in cash.

title: SUSPECT IS NAMED In A STORE BOMBING
description: The authorities have determined that a small bomb that maimed a 5-year-old girl at a K Mart store here a year ago was built by a teen-ager who, apparently despondent over his act, committed suicide two days later.

title: Gateway Federal reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

title: Calling to Mind One of Music's Forgotten
description: Meet Gordon Wright, the president of the Reznicek Society. The what society? Emil Nickolaus von Reznicek (1860-1945) was a German composer and conductor who wrote about a dozen operas, four symphonies, chamber music and just about everything else. He was associated with Mahler and every other major musician of his time, his music was conducted by the likes of Felix Weingartner and Karl Muck, and he was at one time very well known. But he lives on today, if one can call it much of a musical afterlife, by one piece, the short, bubbling ''Donna Diana'' Overture.

title: Geraldine Murphy, 70, A Professor of English
description: Geraldine Murphy, a professor of English at Wesleyan University who was the first female faculty member promoted to a tenured position, died last Friday at a hospital in Florence. She was 70 years old. Professor Murphy fell while traveling on a break and lapsed into a coma, the university said.

But the day before she was to have sung the Verdi Requiem, she was dismissed by the chorale's director, ROBERT BASS. He said she had been uncooperative and unreasonable; she said they had engaged in the ordinary give-and-take of rehearsals.

title: Child-Care Worker Is Cleared
description: A state child protection worker was acquitted today of charges that she had failed to report suspected abuse before the death of an infant who, the authorities say, was dunked in a toilet for soiling his pants. The defendant, Shirley Duboise, contended that she had never seen any evidence that would have led her to suspect abuse. Her acquittal was the second involving four workers charged with negligence in the death of 2-year-old Bradley McGee last July 28. The charges against a third worker were dropped. A fourth is awaits trial.

title: Bridge

Seymour Reich, the least-known member of the squad, was the only one of the five players to play in all eight matches en route to a comfortable victory. On the diagramed deal, one of the most interesting of the day, Reich overcame a bad split in a key suit. He was in three no-trump, knowing that West held a six-card diamond suit and East a seven-card spade suit.

title: Close to Home
description: ON a recent bleary-eyed Sunday morning, I got up early to watch a movie that had played on public television at 4 A.M. (For months after I'd bought a VCR I was drunk on rental movies. Now I realize that true inebriation lies in taping the stuff that's shown when all but muggers and their victims are asleep.) The movie was called ''Kitty,'' starred Paulette Goddard and Ray Milland, and had Sir Thomas Gainsborough among the characters. The setting was 18th-century London; the wigs were high and haughty, and the coaches carrying the gentry to parties in great houses were preceded by footmen brandishing flambeaux. The plot, as is so often the case, was based on the story of Pygmalion and Galatea.

title: Dinkins Promises Shift In Social Service Units
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that the city would move to break down bureaucratic barriers and provide social services to people where they live, rather than have them go to different offices in different areas.

description: AFTER a cold reception from institutions, the initial public offering of Safeway Stores Inc. will go forward today at a lower price in the retail market.

title: To Abortion Foes, Issue Is Ethical, Not Moral;   Selling Church's View
description: As Ms. Quindlen correctly points out, the Gospel is preached quite effectively by the example of men and women whose lives exhibit a love and compassion that far surpass mere words and the efforts of paid professionals.

title: Gruber Leads Blue Jays Past Indians
description: Kelly Gruber hit his seventh home run tonight, the most in the major leagues, and went 4 for 5 as the Toronto Blue Jays beat the Cleveland Indians, 5-3.

title: Texas Air Investor
description: Mark Schwarzman, a Greenwich, Conn., investor, has acquired a 6.77 percent stake in the Texas Air Corporation's 6 3/4 percent cumulative convertible junior preferred stock. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Schwarzman said he had purchased the shares of the troubled airline holding company for investment purposes only.

title: North Fork Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
New Jersey Voters in Revolt Against Soaring School Taxes
description: Voters in nearly half the school districts in New Jersey soundly rejected budgets in elections on Tuesday in the most sweeping revolt against soaring taxes since the state was forced to change its financing of education 14 years ago.

title: Neglect and Acceptance Greet Census, Poll Finds
description: As census enumerators begin to go door to door today to complete the 1990 census, they will find a mixed reception from the estimated 35 million households that have yet to be counted, a New York Times Poll indicates.

title: Chariot Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
